Niddah



Daf 1a



Daf 1b



Daf 2a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> Shammai <b>says:</b> For <b>all women</b> who do not have a fixed menstrual cycle, <b>their time is sufficient.</b> Women who discern that menstrual blood emerged do not need to be concerned that perhaps the flow of blood began before they noticed it. Rather, they assume their ritual impurity status begins at that moment, in terms of rendering impure <i>teruma</i> and ritually pure items with which they come in contact. <b>Hillel says: From examination [<i>mipekida</i>] to examination,</b> i.e., she assumes ritual impurity status retroactive to the last time she examined herself and determined that she was ritually pure, <b>and</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even</b> if her examination took place <b>several days</b> earlier. Any ritually pure item with which she came in contact in the interim becomes ritually impure.
<b>And the Rabbis say:</b> The <i>halakha</i> is <b>neither in accordance with the statement of this</b> <i>tanna</i> <b>nor in accordance with the statement of that</b> <i>tanna</i>; <b>rather,</b> the principle is: A twenty-four-hour <b>period reduces</b> the time <b>from examination to examination.</b> In other words, if her final self-examination took place more than twenty-four hours earlier, she need only concern herself with ritual impurity for the twenty-four-hour period prior to discerning the blood. <b>And from examination to examination reduces</b> the time <b>from</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period.</b> In other words, if she examined herself in the course of the previous day and discovered no blood, she was certainly ritually pure prior to the examination.
For <b>any woman who has a fixed</b> menstrual <b>cycle [<i>veset</i>],</b> and she examined herself at that time and discovered blood, <b>her time is sufficient,</b> and it is only from that time that she transmits ritual impurity. <b>And</b> with regard to a woman <b>who engages in intercourse while</b> using <b>examination cloths [<i>be’edim</i>]</b> before and after intercourse, with which she ascertains whether her menstrual flow began, the halakhic status of such an action <b>is like that of an examination, and</b> therefore <b>it reduces</b> the time <b>from</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period, and</b> reduces the time <b>from examination to examination.</b>
<b>Her time is sufficient, how so?</b> If the woman <b>was sitting in the bed and engaged in</b> handling <b>ritually pure items, and she left</b> the bed <b>and saw</b> blood, <b>she is ritually impure and</b> those items <b>are ritually pure.</b>
<b>Although</b> the Rabbis <b>said</b> that a woman without a fixed menstrual cycle <b>transmits ritual impurity</b> retroactively <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period,</b> a woman with a fixed cycle <b>counts</b> her menstrual days <b>only from the moment that she saw</b> blood.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that when a woman discerns that her menstrual blood emerged, Shammai holds that her impurity status starts from that moment, while Hillel maintains that it begins from the time of her most recent self-examination. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Shammai?</b> The Gemara answers: Shammai <b>holds</b> that as there is a principle that when the status of an item is uncertain it retains its presumptive status, here too: <b>Establish</b> the <b>woman in her presumptive status, and a woman remains with the presumptive status of</b> being <b>ritually pure. And</b> what is the reasoning of <b>Hillel?</b> He claims that <b>when</b> one <b>states</b> the principle: <b>Establish an item in its presumptive status,</b> that applies only <b>where there is no weakening</b> in the presumptive status that is a result <b>of</b> the item <b>itself. But</b> in the case of <b>a woman,</b>

Daf 2b

<b>since</b> it is her nature <b>to see</b> blood flow <b>from her body</b> at regular intervals, <b>we do not say: Establish her in her presumptive status</b> of ritual purity. Her body is constantly changing, and therefore she has no such presumptive status.
With regard to the opinions of both Shammai and Hillel, the Gemara asks: <b>And</b> in <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> this case <b>different from</b> that of <b>a ritual bath? As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Mikvaot</i> 2:2): In the case of <b>a ritual bath</b> that was known to have contained the requisite forty <i>se’a</i>, <b>which was</b> then <b>measured and found lacking</b> in its quantity of water, <b>all pure items that had been rendered</b> pure <b>in it,</b> i.e., any impure items that had been purified through immersion in this ritual bath, <b>retroactive</b> to when the ritual bath was last measured, <b>whether</b> this ritual bath is found <b>in the private domain or in the public domain, are impure.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>Shammai,</b> the mishna poses <b>a difficulty from</b> its statement that the change in the ritual bath’s status is assumed <b>retroactive</b> to the time when it was last measured, as he maintains that a menstruating woman’s status changes only at the present moment, not retroactive to the last time she examined herself.
<b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>Hillel,</b> the mishna also poses <b>a difficulty</b> with regard to its ruling that the items purified in the ritual bath are deemed impure with <b>certainty, whereas</b> a menstruating women does not assume retroactive impurity with certainty. In other words, although according to the Rabbis there is a twenty-four-hour <b>period</b> of retroactive ritual impurity in the case <b>of a menstruating woman,</b> and according to Hillel the retroactive impurity extends back to her most recent examination, nevertheless any <i>teruma</i> that she touched during that period is not deemed definitely impure to the extent that it must be burned. Rather, the impure status of the items she touched is uncertain and the status of the <i>teruma</i> is <b>suspended,</b> i.e., one may <b>neither eat</b> it <b>nor burn</b> it. <b>Whereas here,</b> in the case of the ritual bath, any item purified in it is retroactively deemed <b>definitely impure.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> in the case of a ritual bath, it is different, <b>since it can be said: Establish</b> the <b>impure</b> item <b>in its presumptive status and say</b> that <b>it was not</b> properly <b>immersed.</b> In other words, the presumptive status of the item as ritually impure is in keeping with the current deficient state of the ritual bath. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>On the contrary,</b> one should <b>establish the ritual bath in its presumptive state</b> of validity <b>and say that</b> the ritual bath <b>was not</b> previously <b>lacking</b> the requisite measure of water. The Gemara responds: There is no presumptive state of validity, as the ritual bath <b>is lacking before you,</b> i.e., at present, and this offsets the presumptive status that it was full.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Here too,</b> in the case of a menstruating woman, she is one who has experienced a discharge of <b>blood before you,</b> i.e., at present. Just as the ritual bath’s presumptive status of validity is offset by its present lack of the requisite measure of water, so too the woman’s previous presumptive status of ritual purity is offset by her present state of impurity due to menstruation. The Gemara answers: In the case of the menstruating woman, it is possible that <b>it is</b> only <b>now that she saw</b> the first emission of her menstrual blood. The Gemara retorts: One can say the same with regard to the ritual bath: <b>Here too, it is</b> only <b>now that</b> it <b>became lacking</b> in the requisite measure of water.
The Gemara answers: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> in the case of the ritual bath, <b>it can be said</b> that the water slowly trickled out and consequently the amount of water was <b>continuously diminishing.</b> Therefore, it is possible that the ritual bath lost its valid status long ago without anyone realizing. By contrast, <b>here,</b> with regard to a menstruating woman, <b>can it be said</b> that she was <b>continuously seeing</b> menstrual blood? The Gemara responds: <b>And what is the difficulty?</b> The same possibility does in fact exist in the case of a menstruating woman, as <b>perhaps she saw</b> the blood depart <b>bit [<i>hagas</i>] by bit.</b>
The Gemara states a different answer: <b>There,</b> in the case of the ritual bath, <b>there are two</b> factors <b>that weaken</b> the suggestion that the items are ritually pure: First, the ritual bath is lacking at present; second, the item has a presumptive status of impurity. <b>Here,</b> by contrast, <b>there is</b> only <b>one</b> factor <b>that weakens</b> the possibility that the items touched by the currently menstruating woman were rendered ritually impure, i.e., that she is currently experiencing a menstrual flow. Therefore, according to Shammai she assumes impurity status only from that moment onward, and according to Hillel her retroactive impurity status applies only as an uncertainty.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to Shammai, who holds that her time is sufficient and there is no retroactive impurity, <b>what is different</b> in the case <b>of a barrel? As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Terumot</i> 2:8): If someone <b>would inspect</b> the contents of <b>a barrel</b> to see if it still contained enough wine <b>to continually</b> mentally <b>separate <i>teruma</i> from it,</b> i.e., to exempt other untithed wine of his until all the wine in this barrel will be <i>teruma</i>, <b>and afterward</b> the contents of the barrel <b>were found</b> to have turned to <b>vinegar,</b> which cannot be set aside as <i>teruma</i> for untithed wine, then for <b>all of the first three days</b> following his most recent inspection, it is <b>definitely</b> considered to have been wine. Therefore, any of the untithed wine for which <i>teruma</i> was separated during those days is tithed.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>From that</b> point <b>forward,</b> i.e., more than three days after the most recent inspection, it is <b>uncertain</b> whether it had already turned to vinegar, and consequently any untithed wine for which <i>teruma</i> was separated during those days remains uncertainly tithed. This poses <b>a difficulty for Shammai,</b> who maintains that there is no such retroactive consideration in the case of a menstruating woman.
The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> in the case of the barrel, it is different, <b>since it can be said: Establish the untithed produce in its presumptive status,</b> as when it first grew it was definitely untithed, <b>and say</b> it was <b>not amended,</b> i.e., exempted, and its status continues to be untithed produce. The Gemara asks: <b>On the contrary,</b> one should <b>establish the wine in its presumptive status, and say</b> that it had <b>not turned to vinegar.</b>
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: This is impossible, as <b>it is turned to vinegar before you,</b> i.e., at present. The Gemara replies: <b>Here too,</b> in the case of a menstruating woman, one who has experienced a discharge of <b>blood</b> is <b>before you,</b> at present, so what is the difference? The Gemara explains: With regard to the woman, it is possible that <b>it is</b> only <b>now that she saw</b> the beginning of her menstrual blood. The Gemara responds: <b>There too,</b> it is possible that <b>it is</b> only <b>now that it turned to vinegar,</b> but not earlier.
The Gemara again answers: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> in the case of the wine, <b>it can be said</b> that it was <b>continuously turning to vinegar.</b> Therefore, it is possible that the wine turned to vinegar much earlier without anyone realizing. By contrast, in the case of the menstruating woman, <b>can it be said</b> that she was <b>continuously seeing</b> menstrual blood? Once again, the Gemara responds: <b>And what is the difficulty?</b> The same possibility does in fact exist in the case of a menstruating woman, as <b>perhaps she saw</b> the blood depart <b>bit by bit.</b>
The Gemara provides a different answer: <b>There,</b> in the case of the barrel, there are <b>two</b> factors <b>that weaken</b> the suggestion that the wine is tithed: First, it is vinegar at present; second, the wine has a presumptive status that it is untithed. <b>Here,</b> by contrast, <b>there is</b> only <b>one</b> factor <b>that weakens</b> the possibility that the items touched by the menstruating woman were rendered ritually impure, i.e., that she is currently experiencing a menstrual flow.
§ <b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction between</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the <b>barrel</b> and that <b>of</b> the <b>ritual bath: What is different here,</b> in the case of the ritual bath, where the items are <b>definitely</b> impure, <b>and what is different there,</b> with regard to the barrel, where it is only <b>uncertain</b> that the produce remains untithed? In both cases the current situation, that the ritual bath is deficient and the contents of the barrel have turned to vinegar, should lead to a definite status.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Ḥanina of Sura says: Who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> who <b>taught</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the <b>barrel? It is Rabbi Shimon, who, with regard to a ritual bath also considers it</b> as a matter of <b>uncertainty,</b> rather than as definitely impure. Therefore, there is no contradiction between the two <i>halakhot</i>.
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Mikvaot</i> 2:2): In the case of <b>a ritual bath</b> that was known to have contained the requisite forty <i>se’a</i>, <b>which was</b> then <b>measured and found lacking</b> in its quantity of water, <b>all pure items that had been rendered</b> pure <b>in it,</b> i.e., any impure items that had been purified through immersion in this ritual bath, <b>retroactive</b> to when the ritual bath was last measured, <b>whether</b> this ritual bath is located <b>in the private domain or in the public domain, are impure.</b>
The mishna continues: <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> If the impure items were immersed in a ritual bath that was <b>in the public domain,</b> they are deemed <b>pure.</b> But if they were immersed in a ritual bath that was <b>in a private domain,</b> the status of any <i>teruma</i> that touched them is <b>suspended,</b> i.e., it is neither consumed nor burned. Rabbi Shimon holds that even in the case of a ritual bath, the items are not retroactively deemed definitely impure. Rather the status is uncertain, just as in the case of the barrel.

Daf 3a

The Gemara explains their reasoning: <b>And both</b> <i>tanna’im</i> <b>derived</b> their respective opinions <b>only from</b> the case of <b>a woman suspected by her husband of having been unfaithful [<i>sota</i>],</b> who is forbidden to engage in intercourse with her husband just like a definite adulteress.
<b>The Rabbis hold:</b> This case of a ritual bath is <b>like</b> the case of <b>a <i>sota</i>. Just as</b> in the case of <b>a <i>sota</i></b> it is <b>uncertain</b> whether <b>she</b> was actually unfaithful, <b>and</b> nevertheless the Torah <b>rendered her like</b> one who <b>definitely</b> committed adultery in that she is forbidden to her husband until she drinks the water of a <i>sota</i>; <b>here too,</b> in the case of a ritual bath, it is <b>uncertain</b> whether it was lacking the requisite measure of water <b>and</b> yet the Torah <b>rendered it as</b> though it was <b>definitely</b> lacking water, to the extent that <i>teruma</i> that touched an item that had been immersed in it must be burned.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of the ritual bath are derived <b>from</b> those of <b>a <i>sota</i>,</b> then one can <b>say</b> that it should be <b>like</b> the <i>halakha</i> of a <b><i>sota</i></b> in another respect: <b>Just as a <i>sota</i></b> who is suspected of having been unfaithful <b>in a public domain</b> is considered <b>pure,</b> i.e., she does not undergo to rite of a <i>sota</i>, <b>here too,</b> any impure item that was immersed in a currently deficient ritual bath that is situated <b>in a public domain</b> should be considered <b>pure.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared?</b> One cannot apply the <i>halakha</i> of a <i>sota</i> in a public domain to any other case. <b>There,</b> the reason why a <i>sota</i> is treated as having definitely been unfaithful is <b>due to</b> her <b>seclusion</b> with another man. <b>And</b> as a proper <b>seclusion in the public domain is not</b> possible, she does not assume the status of a <i>sota</i>. By contrast, <b>here,</b> in the case of the ritual bath, the uncertainty <b>is due to</b> the <b>lack</b> of the requisite measure of water in the ritual bath. If so, <b>what</b> difference is it <b>to me</b> if the ritual bath is <b>lacking in a public domain</b> or if it is <b>lacking in a private domain?</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>And if you would say</b> that the guiding principle in <b>any</b> case of <b>uncertainty</b> involving <b>impurity in a public domain</b> is that it is <b>ritually pure,</b> and therefore all items immersed in a ritual bath situated in the public domain should be pure even if there is uncertainty about its status of purity, that suggestion can be rejected, as follows: <b>Since there are two</b> factors <b>that weaken</b> the possibility that the items are ritually pure: First, the ritual bath is currently lacking, and second, the item has a presumptive status of impurity, it is therefore <b>considered as</b> an item of <b>definite impurity.</b>
After analyzing the reasoning of the Rabbis, the Gemara turns to the opinion of Rabbi Shimon. <b>And Rabbi Shimon holds:</b> This case of a ritual bath is just <b>like</b> the case of <b>a <i>sota</i>. Just as a <i>sota</i></b> who is suspected of having been unfaithful <b>in a public domain</b> is considered <b>pure, here too,</b> any impure item that was immersed in a currently deficient ritual bath that is situated <b>in a public domain</b> is considered <b>pure.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of the ritual bath are derived <b>from</b> those of <b>a <i>sota</i>,</b> then one can <b>say</b> that it should be <b>like</b> the <i>halakha</i> of a <b><i>sota</i></b> in another respect: <b>Just as a <i>sota</i></b> who secluded herself with the man <b>in a private domain</b> is deemed <b>definitely impure,</b> i.e., she is forbidden to her husband until she undergoes the rite of the <i>sota</i>, <b>here too,</b> any ritually impure item that was immersed in a currently deficient ritual bath situated <b>in a private domain</b> should be considered <b>definitely impure.</b> If so, any <i>teruma</i> that comes in contact with the immersed vessel should be burned. Why, then, does Rabbi Shimon rule that its status is suspended and it is neither consumed nor burned?
The Gemara answers: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> in the case of a <i>sota</i>, <b>there is a basis for the matter.</b> She is considered definitely impure, <b>as</b> her husband <b>issued a warning to her</b> about this particular man <b>and she</b> then <b>secluded</b> herself with him. By contrast, <b>here,</b> in the case of a ritual bath, <b>what basis for the matter is there?</b> Why should one assume impurity with certainty?
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>this is</b> the <b>reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Shimon:</b> He does not base his ruling on the case of a <i>sota</i>; rather, he <b>derives the end of impurity from the beginning of impurity,</b> i.e., he derives the <i>halakha</i> of the immersion of an impure item into a ritual bath from the <i>halakha</i> of the initial contraction of ritual impurity.
The Gemara explains: <b>Just as</b> with regard to the <b>beginning of impurity,</b> if there is <b>uncertainty whether or not</b> a pure item <b>came into contact</b> with a source of impurity, if this occurred <b>in the public domain</b> it is considered ritually <b>pure; so too</b> in the case of the <b>end of impurity,</b> if there is <b>uncertainty whether or not</b> the impure item was <b>immersed</b> in a ritual bath with the requisite amount of water, the <i>halakha</i> is that if the ritual bath is located <b>in the public domain,</b> the item is considered <b>pure.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how would <b>the Rabbis</b> respond to this claim? They would respond: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> with regard to the beginning of impurity, <b>the man</b> who might have touched an impure item <b>remains with the presumptive status</b> of <b>ritual purity.</b> Consequently, <b>we do not lower his</b> status to one who has contracted <b>ritual impurity</b> merely <b>due to uncertainty. Here,</b> in the case of the ritual bath, <b>the man</b> who immerses in that ritual bath <b>has the presumptive status</b> of <b>ritual impurity.</b> Therefore, <b>we do not remove him</b> from <b>his</b> status <b>of ritual impurity due to uncertainty.</b>
§ The Gemara returns to its analysis of the mishna. Shammai said: For all women, their time is sufficient, i.e., women who discern that menstrual blood emerged do not need to be concerned that perhaps the flow of blood began before they noticed it. The Gemara asks: In <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> this case <b>different from</b> that of <b>an alleyway? As we learned</b> in a mishna (66a): With regard to the carcass of <b>a creeping animal that is found in an alleyway,</b> it <b>renders</b> any item in the alleyway <b>ritually impure retroactively to</b> the time <b>that</b> a person can <b>say: I examined this alleyway and there was no</b> carcass of <b>a creeping animal in it, or until the time of the</b> last <b>sweeping</b> of the alleyway.
The Gemara answers: <b>There too,</b> one can explain: <b>Since there</b> are two types of carcasses of creeping animals that are likely to be found in the alleyway, <b>creeping animals from</b> the alleyway <b>itself and creeping animals that came from the world</b> at large, <b>it is compared to</b> a case where there <b>are two</b> factors <b>that weaken</b> the possibility that the items are ritually pure. Therefore, even Shammai agrees that in such a case the impurity extends retroactively back in time.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>this is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Shammai: Since a women senses within herself</b> if she is experiencing a flow of blood, if she felt the flow only at present, it is certain that she did not experience a flow previously. <b>And Hillel</b> holds that she might have experienced a flow earlier while she was urinating and <b>she thought it</b> was all <b>the sensation of</b> her flow of <b>urine.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to Shammai, isn’t there</b> the case of <b>a sleeping</b> woman, who would not sense her flow of menstrual blood? The Gemara answers: <b>A sleeping</b> woman would <b>also</b> sense her flow, and <b>due to her discomfort</b> she <b>would awaken, just as it is with the sensation</b> of the need to <b>urinate.</b>
The Gemara raises another difficulty with regard to the opinion of Shammai: <b>But there</b> is the case of <b>a mentally incompetent</b> woman, who does not properly understand what she is sensing. She might have previously experienced a flow of menstrual blood that she did not notice. The Gemara answers: <b>Shammai concedes</b> in the case <b>of a mentally incompetent</b> woman that she is impure retroactively. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> the mishna explicitly <b>teaches</b> that Shammai mentioned <b>all women,</b> which apparently includes even the mentally incompetent. The Gemara answers: When the mishna teaches: <b>All women,</b> it is referring to all <b>mentally competent</b> women.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But</b> if so, <b>let</b> the mishna <b>teach</b> that Shammai’s opinion applies to: <b>Women,</b> rather than referring to all women. The Gemara answers: The inclusive statement: All women, serves <b>to exclude</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Eliezer. As Rabbi Eliezer said</b> in a mishna (7a): There are <b>four women</b> with regard to whom the <i>halakha</i> is that their time is sufficient. This indicates that there are only four, <b>and no more.</b> Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us: All women,</b> to include all mentally competent women, not only the four mentioned by Rabbi Eliezer.
The Gemara raises yet another difficulty against the opinion of Shammai: <b>But there is</b> the case of blood <b>stains.</b> The mishna teaches (66a) that a woman who finds a blood stain is impure retroactive to the last time she examined her clothing and found them clean. <b>Shall we say</b> that <b>we learned</b> the mishna with regard to <b>stains not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shammai? Abaye said: Shammai concedes</b> in the case <b>of stains.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason?</b> The reason is <b>that she neither engaged in</b> handling a slaughtered <b>bird nor</b> did <b>she pass through a marketplace of butchers.</b> If so, <b>from where</b> could <b>this blood</b> stain on her clothing have <b>come?</b> Since it must be from her last menstrual flow, Shammai agrees that she is impure retroactively.
The Gemara suggests another analysis: <b>Or if you wish, say</b> that <b>this is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Shammai:</b> She is impure only from that point onward, <b>as, if it is so that there was</b> any menstrual <b>blood</b> previously, <b>it would have come</b> out <b>at the outset,</b> i.e., at the earlier time. The Gemara explains why Hillel maintains that there is ritual impurity retroactively, in light of this analysis: <b>And</b> as for <b>Hillel,</b> he holds that the <b>walls of the womb,</b> i.e., the walls of the vaginal canal, <b>held back</b> the menstrual blood from leaving the body entirely, and therefore there might have been a previous emission from the uterus into the vaginal canal that was not visible on the outside. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>Shammai</b> respond to this claim? The Gemara answers: Shammai maintains that the <b>walls of the womb do not hold back blood.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to</b> a woman who <b>engages in intercourse</b> while using a contraceptive absorbent <b>cloth</b> in the form of a wad that she inserts in her vagina at the opening of her womb so as not to become pregnant, <b>what is there to say?</b> In other words, how does Shammai explain why there is no retroactive impurity status in such a case, as it cannot be claimed that any previous menstrual blood would have flowed out earlier. <b>Abaye says: Shammai concedes with regard to</b> a woman who <b>engages in intercourse</b> while using a contraceptive <b>cloth</b> that she is impure retroactively.
<b>Rava says:</b> Here <b>as well,</b> in a case where a woman engages in intercourse while using a contraceptive absorbent <b>cloth,</b> any previous menstrual blood would have flowed out, as the absorbent cloth does not hermetically seal the womb. The reason is that the cloth <b>wrinkles due to perspiration,</b> leaving space for blood to pass through. The Gemara adds: <b>And</b> nevertheless <b>Rava concedes</b> to Abaye that Shammai agrees that she is retroactively impure in a case <b>where</b> a woman engages in intercourse while using a tightly <b>packed</b> absorbent <b>cloth.</b>
§ The Gemara suggested that the reasoning for Shammai’s opinion is that the woman would have felt any previous menstrual flow, or that any prior menstrual blood would have flowed out previously. Yet, earlier the Gemara suggested that his reason was that the woman retains her presumptive status of ritual purity. With regard to the explanations given for the opinion of Shammai, the Gemara asks: <b>What</b> difference <b>is there between these versions and that version</b> suggested earlier?

Daf 3b

The Gemara answers: The difference <b>between</b> them is with regard to the possibility <b>of raising a contradiction</b> between Shammai’s ruling here and the cases of <b>a barrel, a ritual bath, and an alleyway. According to that version,</b> that Shammai’s reasoning is based upon the principle that an item retains its presumptive status, <b>there is</b> room <b>to raise these contradictions,</b> as the Gemara explained. By contrast, <b>according to these</b> other <b>versions,</b> that the woman would have felt any previous menstrual flow or that any prior menstrual blood would have flowed out previously, <b>there is no</b> room <b>to raise</b> such <b>contradictions,</b> as those rulings do not contradict the <i>halakha</i> here, where a unique factor is relevant.
The Gemara further asks: <b>And what</b> difference <b>is there between this version,</b> that any prior menstrual blood would have flowed out, <b>and that version,</b> that she would have felt any previous menstrual flow? The Gemara answers: <b>According to Abaye,</b> who maintains that Shammai agrees that a woman who engages in intercourse while using a contraceptive cloth is impure retroactively, <b>there is</b> a difference in a case where the woman engages in intercourse while using a contraceptive <b>cloth.</b> If Shammai’s reasoning is that a woman senses the emission of blood, in this case too it is assumed that she did not emit blood earlier. By contrast, if his reasoning is that any prior menstrual blood would have come out at the outset, it is possible that the cloth blocked the emission of blood, and she already emitted blood. Consequently, she is impure retroactively.
<b>According to Rava,</b> who maintains that blood can emerge even if the woman engages in intercourse while using a contraceptive absorbent cloth, <b>there is</b> a difference between the two interpretations in a case where she engages in intercourse while using a tightly <b>packed</b> absorbent <b>cloth,</b> as such a cloth will prevent the blood from flowing out, but it does not affect her ability to sense an emission.
It is <b>taught</b> in a mishna (<i>Teharot</i> 4:4) <b>in accordance with this version,</b> i.e., that Shammai’s reasoning is <b>that if it is so, that there was</b> menstrual <b>blood</b> previously, <b>it would have come</b> out <b>at the outset: Hillel said to Shammai: Don’t you concede</b> to the following <i>halakha</i>: In the case <b>of a basket</b> that <b>was used</b> as a container for <b>ritually pure</b> items, and those items were placed <b>in</b> one <b>corner, and</b> subsequently the carcass of <b>a creeping animal was found in a different corner</b> of the basket, the <i>halakha</i> is <b>that the</b> items <b>initially</b> considered <b>ritually pure</b> are now retroactively considered <b>impure? Shammai said to him: Indeed,</b> that is correct.
Hillel continues: <b>And</b> if so, <b>what difference</b> is there between <b>this</b> case of the pure items stored in the basket, which are now considered retroactively impure, <b>and that</b> case of the ritually pure woman who experiences a menstrual flow, who is impure only from that point onward? Shammai answers: <b>This</b> one, the basket, <b>has a base</b> on which it rests, and therefore the creeping animal might have been there earlier unseen. <b>That one,</b> the menstruating woman, <b>has no base,</b> i.e., there is nothing to impede her menstrual blood from flowing out. Shammai’s response indicates that she is not retroactively impure because if she had experienced a previous menstruation it would have flowed at that stage.
§ <b>Rava says:</b> The <b>reason for</b> the opinion of <b>Shammai</b> that a woman who experiences menstruation is not deemed ritually impure retroactively is <b>due to the dereliction of</b> the mitzva to <b>be fruitful and multiply.</b> If woman is always deemed retroactively impure, she and her husband might abstain from engaging in sexual intercourse out of fear that she is already impure even if she has not yet experienced bleeding. The Gemara adds <b>that this</b> explanation <b>is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Shammai said to Hillel: If</b> it is <b>so,</b> that a woman is rendered retroactively impure as you claim, <b>you</b> will <b>have caused the Jewish women to be derelict in</b> the mitzva to <b>be fruitful and multiply.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> according to <b>the one who taught this version,</b> i.e., Rava, there is a difficulty: <b>Isn’t it taught in</b> the aforementioned mishna <b>in accordance with that</b> other <b>version,</b> that Shammai’s reasoning is <b>that if it is so, that there was</b> any menstrual <b>blood</b> previously, <b>it would have come</b> out <b>at the outset?</b> The Gemara answers: There, in that mishna, <b>it is Hillel who erred. He thought</b> the <b>reason</b> of <b>Shammai</b> is <b>that if it is so, that there was</b> any menstrual <b>blood</b> previously, <b>it would have come</b> out <b>at the outset. And</b> therefore, <b>he raises a difficulty</b> against Shammai’s opinion from the case of the <b>basket.</b>
<b>And Shammai said to</b> Hillel: You are mistaken. <b>My reasoning</b> is actually <b>due to the dereliction of</b> the mitzva to <b>be fruitful and multiply. But even according to your erroneous</b> reasoning <b>that</b> led <b>you to raise a difficulty</b> from the case of the <b>basket,</b> I have an answer for that as well: <b>This</b> basket <b>has a base,</b> and therefore the creeping animal could have been there earlier, unseen; <b>but that</b> menstruating woman <b>has no base.</b>
The Gemara asks the reverse question: <b>And according to the one</b> who <b>teaches this</b> other <b>version,</b> that Shammai’s reasoning is that if there was previous menstrual blood it would have come out at the outset, <b>isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with that</b> other <b>version,</b> that Shammai’s reasoning is <b>due to the dereliction of</b> the mitzva to <b>be fruitful and multiply?</b>
The Gemara answers: That <i>baraita</i> was recorded at a later point in their discussion, as <b>this</b> is what <b>Hillel is saying to Shammai: Yes,</b> the <b>reason</b> that <b>you say</b> for your opinion has merit, <b>that if it is so, that there was</b> any menstrual <b>blood</b> previously, <b>it would have come</b> out <b>at the outset. Nevertheless,</b> you should <b>enact a safeguard for your statement</b> and render her retroactively impure, <b>as</b> in <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> this case <b>different from the rest of the entire Torah, where</b> the Sages <b>enact safeguards?</b>
Shammai <b>said to</b> Hillel: <b>If so,</b> i.e., if she is considered impure retroactively as a safeguard, <b>you</b> will <b>have caused the Jewish women to be derelict in</b> the mitzva to <b>be fruitful and multiply.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>Hillel</b> respond to Shammai’s reasoning with regard to the mitzva to be fruitful and multiply? The Gemara explains that Hillel would answer: Although I rule that she is retroactively impure, <b>did I say</b> that she is forbidden to her husband and must therefore abstain <b>from</b> the mitzva to <b>be fruitful and multiply? I said</b> only <b>that</b> she renders impure any <b>ritually pure</b> items that she touched.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how would <b>Shammai</b> reply to this? The Gemara answers: Shammai maintains that <b>even</b> a safeguard that renders <b>ritually pure</b> items impure should <b>not</b> be imposed. The reason is <b>that if</b> it were <b>so,</b> the <b>heart</b> of a scrupulous husband might <b>strike him</b> with pangs of conscience over sins that he could transgress <b>and he</b> would <b>separate</b> from his wife, out of fear that she is impure.
The Gemara provides <b>a mnemonic</b> for the ensuing discussions: <b>A base; examined; covered; in a corner.</b> It <b>was stated:</b> If one has <b>a basket</b> that <b>was used</b> as a container for holding <b>ritually pure</b> produce, and those items were placed <b>in</b> one <b>corner</b> of the basket, <b>and</b> subsequently the carcass of <b>a creeping animal was found in a different corner</b> of the basket, <b>Ḥizkiyya says:</b> That produce <b>initially</b> considered <b>ritually pure</b> is still <b>pure. Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The produce <b>initially</b> considered <b>ritually pure</b> is now retroactively deemed <b>impure.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> how can Ḥizkiyya rule that it is pure? After all, don’t <b>Shammai and Hillel agree in</b> the case of the <b>basket that</b> the produce <b>initially</b> considered <b>pure</b> is now retroactively <b>impure?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>When</b> do <b>Shammai and Hillel agree</b> that all the produce is retroactively impure? <b>With regard to a basket that has a base.</b> In such a case, the carcass of the creeping animal might have previously been in the basket and it went unnoticed when one removed the pure produce items. <b>When Ḥizkiyya and Rabbi Yoḥanan disagree,</b> it is <b>with regard to a basket that has no base,</b> i.e., both ends were open and the basket was used while it was lying on its side. In that situation, the contents of the basket are emptied by raising one end, which causes all items inside to fall out. Consequently, any creeping animal that was found subsequently must have entered the basket only after that produce was removed, which is why Ḥizkiyya rules that the produce remains pure.
The Gemara asks: If this is referring to a case where the basket <b>has no base, what is the reasoning of Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> for ruling that the produce is ritually impure? The Gemara answers: The basket <b>has no base but it</b> does <b>have</b> an inward-curved <b>rim.</b> Therefore, it is possible that the carcass of a small creeping animal might have been held back by the rim and remained inside the basket even after it was turned over. Rabbi Yoḥanan rules that the produce is retroactively impure, due to the possibility that the creeping animal might have been in the basket previously together with the initially pure produce.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who draws ten pails of water one after another,</b> i.e., he draws out water in one pail and from it he fills another ten pails with water, <b>and</b> the carcass of <b>a creeping animal is found in one of them, that</b> pail of water <b>is ritually impure but all</b> the rest <b>of them</b> are <b>pure. And Reish Lakish says in the name of Rabbi Yannai:</b> This <i>halakha</i> was <b>taught only</b> in a case <b>where</b> the pail <b>has no</b> inward-curved <b>rim.</b> Consequently, its contents are entirely emptied each time it is overturned, which means that the creeping animal must have entered only this pail. <b>But</b> if the pail <b>has a rim, all of</b> the water that had been drawn is <b>impure,</b> as the creeping animal might have entered the pail earlier and the rim held it back each time the pail was overturned.
The Gemara explains the difficulty: <b>Shall we say</b> that <b>Ḥizkiyya,</b> who is not concerned that the rim of the basket might have held back the creeping animal, does <b>not agree</b> with the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yannai?</b> The Gemara answers that there is a difference between the two cases: <b>Water is slippery,</b> whereas <b>produce is not slippery.</b> In order to pour water out of the pail it is not necessary to turn it over completely. Therefore, the rim might hold back a creeping animal. By contrast, a basket must have one end fully raised in order to empty out all the produce it contains. In such a case Rabbi Yannai would agree that nothing could have been held back, and therefore the emptied produce remains pure.
Alternatively, there is a different reason why one does not overturn a pail of water entirely: In the case of <b>water, one is not particular about it,</b> i.e., he does not mind if some is left over. Therefore he does not overturn the pail completely. By contrast, in the case of <b>produce one is particular about it,</b> so he raises one end of the basket entirely to ensure that every last piece of produce is emptied. Consequently, in the case of produce Rabbi Yannai would agree that even if the basket has a rim, all the produce remains pure.
As an alternative to its previous resolution that Ḥizkiyya is discussing the case of a rimmed receptacle, the Gemara suggests another resolution of the apparent contradiction between Ḥizkiyya’s ruling and the opinions of Hillel and Shammai. <b>And if you wish, say: When</b> do <b>Shammai and Hillel agree? In</b> the case of <b>a basket that was not examined.</b> Since he did not examine the basket when he placed the pure produce there, a creeping animal might have already been inside. Consequently, they agree that the produce does not retain its presumptive state of purity but is considered retroactively impure.

Daf 4a

<b>When Ḥizkiyya and Rabbi Yoḥanan disagree,</b> it is <b>with regard to a basket</b> that was <b>examined.</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Ḥizkiyya, <b>holds</b> that <b>since</b> it <b>was examined</b> before the produce was placed inside and was found to be clean of creeping animals, it is reasonable to assume that the creeping animal entered only after the ritually pure produce was removed. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>holds</b> that one can <b>say</b> that it is possible that <b>when he removed his hand</b> after feeling around to examine the basket, the creeping animal <b>fell</b> in.
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t</b> the case of a basket <b>taught</b> as being <b>similar to</b> the case of a menstruating <b>woman?</b> Hillel had cited the case of the basket as a difficulty with regard to Shammai’s opinion in the case of a menstruating woman. <b>And</b> since <b>a woman is</b> considered fully <b>examined,</b> since she examines herself with examination cloths twice a day, the other case must also be referring to a basket that had been examined. The Gemara answers: <b>Since blood is commonly found</b> flowing from <b>her,</b> as women regularly experience menstrual flows, it is <b>considered as</b> though she were <b>not examined.</b>
The Gemara suggests another resolution of the apparent contradiction between the ruling of Ḥizkiyya and the opinions of Hillel and Shammai. <b>And if you wish, say: When Shammai and Hillel agree,</b> it is <b>with regard to a basket that is not covered. When</b> do <b>Ḥizkiyya and Rabbi Yoḥanan disagree? With regard to a basket</b> that is <b>covered.</b> The Gemara asks: If the basket <b>is covered, how did</b> the creeping animal <b>fall</b> inside? The Gemara answers: <b>For example, if</b> the basket <b>is used by</b> removing its <b>lid.</b> Ḥizkiyya holds that the creeping animal must have fallen in after the produce was removed, because as long as the produce was inside one would be careful not to allow anything else inside. Rabbi Yoḥanan is concerned that perhaps while the basket was uncovered a creeping animal could have fallen inside without one noticing.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: But <b>isn’t</b> the case of a basket <b>taught</b> as being <b>similar to</b> the case of a menstruating <b>woman? And</b> just as a woman <b>is considered covered,</b> since no outside blood can enter her, so too in the case of a basket, it must be one where it is constantly covered. The Gemara explains: <b>Since blood is commonly found</b> flowing from <b>her,</b> as women regularly experience menstrual flows, it is <b>considered as</b> though she is <b>not</b> always <b>covered.</b>
The Gemara suggests another resolution. <b>And if you wish, say: When</b> do <b>Shammai and Hillel agree?</b> In a case where the produce was stored <b>in</b> the <b>corner</b> of <b>a basket.</b> By contrast, <b>when Ḥizkiyya and Rabbi Yoḥanan disagree,</b> it is in a case where the produce was stored <b>in</b> the <b>corner</b> of <b>a house.</b> The Gemara expresses puzzlement at this suggestion: <b>But</b> the Gemara on 3b explicitly <b>states</b> that they are referring to a case of <b>a basket.</b>
The Gemara explains that <b>this</b> is what the Gemara on 3b <b>is saying:</b> If one has <b>a basket that was used</b> as a container for <b>ritually pure</b> produce <b>in this corner</b> of the <b>house, and</b> after the produce was removed <b>it was</b> subsequently <b>carried to another corner, and</b> the carcass of <b>a creeping animal was found</b> in the basket while it was <b>in</b> that <b>other corner, Ḥizkiyya holds:</b> The produce remains ritually pure, as <b>we do not presume</b> that <b>ritual impurity</b> moved <b>from place to place.</b> In other words, the impure creeping animal is not assumed to have moved from the first corner where the produce was kept. Instead, it fell inside while the basket was in the second corner, and therefore the produce that it previously contained remains pure. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan holds:</b> The produce is retroactively considered impure, as <b>we</b> do <b>presume</b> that ritual impurity, i.e., the carcass of the creeping animal in the basket, moved from place to place.
The Gemara asks a question with regard to the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan: <b>And do we presume</b> that ritual impurity moved from place to place? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Teharot</i> 5:7): If someone <b>touched one</b> other person <b>at night, and he does not know whether</b> the person he touched was <b>alive or dead, and on the following day he arose and found him dead,</b> and he is uncertain whether or not he contracted ritual impurity from contact with a corpse, <b>Rabbi Meir deems him</b> ritually <b>pure.</b> It is assumed that the deceased was still alive until the point that it is known with certainty that he was dead.
<b>And the Rabbis deem him</b> ritually <b>impure, as</b> it is presumed that <b>all</b> ritually <b>impure</b> items had already been in the same state as they were <b>at the time they were discovered.</b> Just as the deceased was found dead in the morning, so too, it is presumed that he was dead when he was touched in the middle of the night.
The Gemara concludes its question: <b>And it is taught with regard to</b> this mishna: It is presumed that ritually impure items had been in the same state as they were <b>at the time they were discovered, but</b> only <b>in the place</b> in which <b>they were discovered.</b> In other words, if the corpse had been found in a different spot than he was at night, it is not presumed that he was already dead in the first spot, and the man who touched him remains ritually pure. If so, how can Rabbi Yoḥanan maintain that we presume impurity moved from place to place?
<b>And if you would say</b> in response: <b>This statement,</b> that impurity is presumed only in the place in which it was discovered, applies specifically with regard to definite impure status, i.e., <b>to burn</b> <i>teruma</i>, <b>but</b> with regard to uncertain impurity, i.e., <b>to suspend</b> the status of <i>teruma</i>, <b>we</b> do in fact <b>suspend</b> its status and it may be neither burned nor eaten; is this distinction correct? <b>Do we</b> in fact <b>suspend</b> the status of ritually pure items in such a case, due to the concern that the dead man whom this individual touched might have already been dead in the first location?
<b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Teharot</i> 3:5): With regard to a previously impure <b>needle that is found</b> on top of <i>teruma</i> and it is <b>full of rust or broken,</b> and therefore no longer contracts or transmit ritual impurity, the <i>teruma</i> remains <b>pure, as</b> it is presumed that in <b>all</b> cases of <b>impurity,</b> the items in question had already been in the same state as they were <b>at the time they were discovered? But why</b> should that be the case? <b>Let us say</b> that <b>initially,</b> when it had fallen onto the <i>teruma</i>, <b>this needle was a proper,</b> non-rusty and unbroken, <b>needle,</b> capable of contracting and transmitting ritual impurity, <b>and it is</b> only <b>now that rust</b> had <b>formed</b> on it. The status of the <i>teruma</i> should at least be held in suspension. Rather, it is evident that the <i>teruma</i> is considered definitely pure and is not held in suspension due to the possibility that it might have become impure from the nail at a previous time or, presumably, in a previous place.
<b>And furthermore, we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Teharot</i> 9:9): If one <b>found</b> the carcass of <b>a burned creeping animal on top of</b> a pile of <b>olives,</b> and that animal no longer transmits impurity as it is burned, <b>and similarly</b> if one finds <b>a tattered rag</b> of a <i>zav</i>, which likewise no longer transmits impurity, on top of a pile of olives, the olives are <b>pure.</b> The reason is <b>that</b> it is presumed in <b>all</b> cases of <b>impurity,</b> the items in question had already been in the same state as they were <b>at the time they were discovered.</b> Once again, this demonstrates that when this presumption is applied, the item is considered definitely pure, and is not held in suspension due to uncertainty.
<b>And if you would say</b> that there is a difference between these last cases, where the items did not move, and the case of the basket that moved, this distinction is not correct. The suggestion is that in the last cases the items are treated entirely as if they had always been as they were <b>at the time they were discovered, whether</b> this leads <b>to a leniency,</b> as in the cases of the needle and the rag, <b>and whether</b> it leads <b>to a stringency,</b> in the case of one who touched someone at night, when he is considered to be definitely impure, <b>but</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> only with regard to the <b>place</b> where <b>they were discovered,</b> i.e., if they did not move. <b>But</b> with regard to a location that is <b>not the place</b> where <b>they were discovered,</b> we do suspect that ritual impurity moved from place to place, and therefore although <b>we do not burn</b> the <i>teruma</i> in question, <b>we hold it in suspension.</b>
The Gemara refutes this suggestion: <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Teharot</i> 4:3): There was <b>a loaf</b> resting <b>on top</b> of <b>a shelf, and</b> there was <b>an item of light impurity,</b> e.g., a garment of a <i>zav</i>, which transmits impurity to food but not to people or vessels, <b>lying underneath it,</b> and the loaf was later found on the ground. <b>Even though</b> the situation was such <b>that if</b> the loaf <b>fell</b> to the ground it would be <b>impossible</b> for it to have done anything <b>other than touch</b> the impure garment on its way down, nevertheless the loaf is <b>pure.</b> The reason is <b>that I say</b> that <b>a ritually pure man entered there and took it</b> off the shelf and placed it onto the ground without it touching the impure garment.
The <i>baraita</i> concludes: This ruling applies <b>unless someone says: It is clear to me that no person entered</b> there. <b>And Rabbi Elazar says:</b> This principle is <b>necessary only when</b> the top shelf is <b>an inclined surface.</b> In other words, even if it is very likely that the loaf rolled off the shelf and touched the garment on its way down to the ground, nevertheless it is assumed to be pure. This indicates that one does not presume that the loaf contracted impurity and then fell to the ground where it was found. Since such a possibility is not even entertained to the extent that the <i>teruma</i> is held in suspension, this demonstrates that in a case involving a movement from one place to another there is no presumption of ritual impurity at all.
The Gemara explains that no proof can be cited from <b>there, as</b> that <i>baraita</i> explicitly <b>teaches</b> the <b>reason</b> for its ruling:

Daf 4b

The reason is not <b>that</b> one does not presume that ritual impurity moved from place to place, but because <b>I say</b> that <b>a ritually pure man entered there and took it</b> off the shelf and placed it onto the ground, avoiding the impure garment it would have hit had it fallen. When there is no such explanation, the principle that one presumes impurity moved from place to place does apply, e.g., in the case of the basket where the carcass of a creeping animal was found inside.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Here, too, let us say</b> that <b>a raven,</b> which often touches creeping animals, <b>came and threw</b> the creeping animal into the basket when it was in the second corner, after the produce had been emptied from it. The Gemara rejects this claim: In the case of <b>a person, who</b> acts <b>with intent, we</b> can <b>say</b> that perhaps a person moved the loaf from the shelf onto the ground. By contrast, with regard to <b>a raven, which</b> does <b>not</b> act <b>with intent, we</b> do <b>not say</b> that perhaps it committed such a purposeful act.
The Gemara raises a difficulty with regard to the ruling of the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>Now</b> the status of <b>this loaf</b> found on the ground <b>is</b> one of <b>uncertain impurity</b> found <b>in a private domain, and</b> the guiding principle in <b>any</b> case of <b>uncertainty</b> involving <b>impurity in a private domain</b> is that the item with <b>uncertain</b> status is deemed <b>impure.</b> If so, shouldn’t the loaf be deemed impure? The Gemara answers: No, <b>as</b> this <b>is an entity that lacks consciousness</b> in order for it <b>to be asked, and</b> the guiding principle is that with regard to <b>any entity that lacks consciousness</b> in order for it <b>to be asked, whether</b> it is found <b>in a public domain or in a private domain,</b> the item with <b>uncertain</b> status is deemed <b>pure.</b>
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: That principle, that in any case of uncertainty involving impurity in a private domain the item with uncertain status is deemed impure, applies to a case of impurity by Torah law, whereas <b>here</b> we are dealing <b>with ritual impurity by rabbinic law.</b> The Gemara adds: The language of the <i>Tosefta</i> <b>is also precise, as it teaches:</b> There was a loaf resting on top of a shelf, and there was an item of light impurity [<i>madaf</i> ] lying underneath it. The term <b><i>madaf</i></b> is similar to that <b>which is written: “A driven leaf [<i>niddaf</i> ]”</b> (Leviticus 26:36), i.e., a light item. Likewise, the <i>Tosefta</i> is referring to a light, or rabbinic, impurity.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> The <i>halakha</i> is <b>neither in accordance with the statement of this</b> <i>tanna</i> nor in accordance with the statement of that <i>tanna</i>. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> The <i>halakha</i> is <b>neither in accordance with the statement of this</b> <i>tanna</i> <b>nor in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>that</b> <i>tanna</i>. It is <b>not accordance with the statement of Shammai,</b> who rules that her time is sufficient and she does not need to be concerned that her menstrual flow started earlier, <b>as he did not enact</b> any <b>safeguard for his statement. And</b> is it <b>not in accordance with the statement of Hillel,</b> who rules that she assumes ritual impurity status retroactive to the time of her most recent examination, <b>as</b> he <b>went beyond [<i>hifriz</i>] his bounds</b> with his safeguard.
The Rabbis continue: <b>Rather,</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period reduces</b> the time <b>from examination to examination,</b> i.e., if her most recent self-examination took place more than twenty-four hours earlier, she need concern herself with ritual impurity only for the twenty-four-hour period prior to discerning the blood. <b>And from examination to examination reduces</b> the time <b>from</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period,</b> i.e., if she examined herself in the course of the previous day and discovered no blood, she was definitely pure prior to the examination.
The <i>baraita</i> elaborates: A twenty-four-hour <b>period reduces</b> the time <b>from examination to examination, how so?</b> A woman <b>examined herself on Sunday and found</b> that she was <b>ritually pure, and</b> then <b>she sat</b> through <b>Monday and Tuesday and did not examine</b> herself. <b>And</b> then <b>on Wednesday she examined herself and found</b> that she was <b>impure.</b> In such a case <b>we do not say</b> that <b>she should be impure</b> retroactively <b>from</b> the time of this <b>examination</b> extending back <b>until</b> the time of her most recent <b>examination. Rather,</b> she is impure retroactively <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: And <b>from examination to examination reduces</b> the time <b>from</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period, how so?</b> A woman <b>examined herself</b> in <b>the first hour</b> of a day <b>and found</b> that she was <b>ritually pure, and</b> then <b>she sat</b> through the <b>second and third</b> hours of the day <b>and did not examine</b> herself. <b>And</b> then <b>at the fourth</b> hour <b>she examined herself and found</b> that she was <b>impure.</b> In such a case <b>we do not say</b> that <b>she should be impure</b> retroactively <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period. Rather,</b> she is impure retroactively <b>from</b> the time of this <b>examination</b> extending back <b>until</b> the time of her most recent <b>examination,</b> three hours earlier.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: This <i>halakha</i> is <b>obvious. Since she examined herself at the first hour and found</b> that she was <b>pure,</b> there is <b>no</b> reason <b>to render her impure</b> retroactively <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period.</b> Why does the <i>baraita</i> state such an obvious <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers: Since the <i>baraita</i> taught that according to the Rabbis a twenty-four-hour <b>period reduces</b> the time <b>from examination to examination,</b> it <b>also taught</b> the parallel case, that <b>from examination to examination reduces</b> the time <b>from</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period,</b> despite the fact that this <i>halakha</i> is obvious.
<b>Rabba says: What</b> is the <b>reason</b> for the opinion <b>of the Rabbis? A woman</b> can <b>sense within herself</b> if she is experiencing a flow of blood. <b>Abaye said to</b> Rabba: <b>If so, her time should be sufficient,</b> as there should be no concern that her flow began earlier. The Gemara explains: <b>And Rabba</b> did not in fact mean this explanation seriously; rather, he <b>wanted to hone</b> the mind of <b>Abaye.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, <b>what</b> is the real <b>reason</b> for the opinion <b>of the Rabbis?</b>
The Gemara answers: It is <b>in accordance with that which Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel says: The Sages instituted that the Jewish women should examine themselves</b> twice each day, <b>morning and evening.</b> The <b>morning</b> examination is in order <b>to render fit</b> the <b>ritually pure</b> items <b>of the night,</b> i.e., any items that she touched the night before. <b>And</b> the <b>evening</b> examination is in order <b>to render fit</b> the <b>pure</b> items that she touched <b>during the day.</b>
The Gemara continues its explanation: <b>And this</b> woman, <b>since she did not examine</b> herself in accordance with the rabbinic enactment, <b>she loses</b> the status of the ritually pure items she touched over the <b>period [<i>ona</i>]</b> of a day or a night. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is meant by: <b>Period</b> of a day or a night? Doesn’t her retroactive impurity status extend back for a twenty-four-hour period? The Gemara answers: It means <b>an additional period</b> of a day or a night, i.e., twenty-four hours in total.
<b>Rav Pappa says to Rava: But</b> occasionally <b>you find three periods</b> of day or night within a twenty-four-hour period. For example, if she examined herself on Monday afternoon and finds blood, then the twenty-four-hour period extending back to Sunday afternoon includes three periods of day or night: Monday day, Sunday night and Sunday day from the time of her most recent examination, as these twenty-four hours do not fit precisely into two such periods. The Gemara answers: <b>The Sages rendered their measures equal, so</b> that <b>one should not differentiate</b> between cases. In other words, they wanted to issue a uniform ruling that applies universally <b>and</b> therefore they established a set twenty-four-hour <b>period</b> of retroactive impurity, regardless of the circumstances.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that they established the set twenty-four-hour period <b>so that the sinner should not profit</b> from his transgression. If the extent of retroactive impurity would be fixed at one additional period of day or night, a woman who remembers and examines herself in the early morning would be impure retroactively for a full twenty-four hours, back to early morning the previous day, whereas one who waits until noon would be impure only for the period of the morning and the previous night.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the difference <b>between</b> these two answers? The Gemara answers: The difference <b>between</b> them is in a case <b>where she was prevented</b> by outside circumstances <b>and did not perform an examination.</b> According to the second answer she would not be considered a sinner and therefore she would be impure only for an additional period of a day or night. By contrast, according to the first answer her impure status would span twenty-four hours regardless of the circumstances.
§ The mishna teaches: For <b>any woman who has a fixed</b> menstrual <b>cycle,</b> and she examined herself at that time and discovered blood, her time is sufficient, and she transmits impurity only from that time onward. The Gemara asks: <b>Shall we say</b> that the mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Dosa, and not</b> in accordance with <b>the</b> opinion of <b>the Rabbis? As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: There are four</b> categories of <b>women</b> for whom the <i>halakha</i> is that <b>their time is sufficient: A virgin,</b> i.e., a girl who has never experienced menstruation, <b>a pregnant woman, a nursing</b> mother, <b>and an elderly woman. Rabbi Dosa says:</b> For <b>every woman who has a fixed</b> menstrual <b>cycle,</b> and she examined herself at that time and discovered blood, <b>her time is sufficient,</b> and it is only from that stage that she transmits ritual impurity.
The Gemara answers: <b>You</b> may <b>even say</b> that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis. The Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Dosa only in</b> the case of a woman who discovers blood at an irregular time, <b>not at the fixed time of her</b> menstrual <b>cycle. But</b> if she discovers blood <b>at the fixed time of her</b> menstrual <b>cycle, they agree with him</b> that her time is sufficient and there is no retroactive impurity. <b>And the mishna</b> is referring to a woman who discovers blood <b>at the fixed time of her</b> menstrual <b>cycle, and</b> therefore <b>everyone agrees</b> that her time is sufficient.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>By inference,</b> one can conclude <b>that Rabbi Dosa says</b> that her time is sufficient <b>even</b> if she discovers blood <b>not at the fixed time of her</b> menstrual <b>cycle.</b> If so, <b>who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> who <b>taught</b> the following <i>baraita</i>? <b>As the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a woman who has a fixed</b> menstrual <b>cycle</b> who finds a blood stain, <b>her</b> blood <b>stain</b> is <b>impure retroactively</b> from when the garment in question was laundered. The reason is <b>that if she sees</b> a flow of menstrual blood <b>not at the fixed time of her</b> menstrual <b>cycle,</b> it renders her impure retroactively <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period.</b> Therefore, the blood stain likewise renders her retroactively impure.
The Gemara concludes its question: <b>Shall we say</b> that this <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis and not</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Dosa?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>You</b> may <b>even say</b> that it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Dosa,</b> as one can claim that <b>Rabbi Dosa disagrees with the Rabbis only</b> in a case where a woman sees menstrual blood <b>at the fixed time of her</b> menstrual <b>cycle. But</b> if she sees blood <b>not at the fixed time of her</b> menstrual <b>cycle, he agrees</b> with them that she is impure retroactively. <b>And</b> according to this answer <b>the mishna,</b> which deals with a woman who discovers blood <b>at the fixed time of her</b> menstrual <b>cycle, is</b> only in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Dosa,</b> in contrast to the earlier claim.

Daf 5a

<b>And</b> as for the ruling of <b>the <i>baraita</i>,</b> that a woman who discovers menstrual blood not at her fixed time for menstruation is impure retroactively, this is a <i>halakha</i> with which <b>everyone agrees.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But let</b> us <b>interpret</b> the mishna in the <b>opposite</b> manner. Why interpret the mishna in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Dosa and the <i>baraita</i> in accordance with everyone, when we can give precedence to the mishna, which is more authoritative, by interpreting it in accordance with all opinions, as was first explained, and the <i>baraita</i> only in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis.
The Gemara answers: <b>Since there is</b> a way <b>to interpret</b> it <b>as a leniency,</b> i.e., that all agree that blood discovered at the fixed time of menstruation renders items impure only from that point onward, <b>and</b> it can also be interpreted in a manner that leads <b>to a stringency,</b> i.e., everyone agrees that blood discovered not at her fixed time for menstruation causes retroactive impurity, and furthermore the Rabbis hold that this is the <i>halakha</i> even when blood is discovered at her fixed time of menstruation, <b>we interpret</b> it the way that leads <b>to a stringency.</b>
§ It <b>is taught</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: If a woman who has a fixed menstrual cycle finds a blood stain, her blood stain is retroactively impure. The reason is <b>that if she sees</b> a flow of menstrual blood <b>not at the fixed time of her</b> menstrual <b>cycle,</b> it renders her ritually impure retroactively <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period.</b> The Gemara analyzes this statement: The <b>reason</b> for this ruling is <b>that</b> she is <b>a woman who has a fixed</b> menstrual <b>cycle;</b> therefore, <b>the Rabbis distinguish between her</b> blood <b>stain,</b> which causes retroactive impurity like a sighting not at her fixed time, <b>and her sighting</b> of her menstrual flow at its fixed time, which does not cause retroactive impurity.
It can be inferred from here that in the case of those <b>other women,</b> e.g., a pregnant or elderly woman, <b>with regard to</b> whom <b>the Sages stated: Their time is sufficient</b> and their menstrual flow never causes retroactive impurity, the same <i>halakha</i> applies to <b>their</b> blood <b>stains as</b> to <b>their sighting</b> of their menstrual flow, i.e., the stains do not cause retroactive impurity.
The Gemara asks: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is this <i>baraita</i> taught? The Gemara answers: <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus, as Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel says in the name of Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus:</b> The <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to all women</b> is that <b>their</b> blood <b>stains are impure retroactively. But</b> any <b>women with regard to</b> whom <b>the Sages stated: Their time is sufficient, their</b> blood <b>stains</b> share the same ruling <b>as their sighting</b> of their menstrual flow, i.e., they do not cause retroactive impurity. This is the <i>halakha</i> <b>except</b> for the case of <b>a young girl whose time to see</b> the flow of menstrual blood <b>has not arrived.</b> With regard to her, <b>even if her sheets are soiled with blood one</b> need <b>not be concerned for it,</b> i.e., her blood stains do not cause any impurity at all, even from that point onward.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> does <b>Rabbi Ḥanina</b> ben Antigonus <b>hold</b> that a blood <b>stain</b> causes ritual impurity <b>at all? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>all women</b> is that <b>their</b> blood <b>stains are impure. And</b> similarly, <b>women with regard to</b> whom <b>the Sages stated: Their time is sufficient, their</b> blood <b>stains are</b> also <b>impure. Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus says:</b> The <i>halakha</i> of <b>women with regard to</b> whom <b>the Sages stated: Their time is sufficient,</b> is that <b>they do not have</b> the ritual impurity of a blood <b>stain. What, is it not</b> correct to say that this means <b>they have no</b> impurity caused by a blood <b>stain at all?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it means that <b>they do not have</b> impurity caused by a blood <b>stain retroactively, but they do have</b> the impurity caused by a blood <b>stain from here onward.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From the fact that</b> Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus holds that a blood stain imparts ritual impurity from that point onward, does this not indicate that <b>the first <i>tanna</i> holds</b> that it causes ritual impurity <b>even retroactively?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Yes,</b> the ruling of the first <i>tanna</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who is stringent with regard to</b> blood <b>stains. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>all women</b> is that <b>their</b> blood <b>stains are impure retroactively. And</b> similarly, <b>women with regard to</b> whom <b>the Sages stated: Their time is sufficient, their</b> blood <b>stains are</b> also <b>impure retroactively.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus says:</b> The <i>halakha</i> of <b>women with regard to</b> whom <b>the Sages stated: Their time is sufficient,</b> is that <b>their</b> blood <b>stains</b> share the same ruling <b>as their sighting</b> of their menstrual flow, i.e., they cause ritual impurity from that point onward. <b>And</b> in the case of <b>a young girl, if her time to see</b> the flow of menstrual blood <b>has arrived,</b> then <b>she has</b> impurity status when she finds a blood <b>stain. But if her time to see</b> the flow of menstrual blood <b>has not</b> yet <b>arrived, she does not have</b> impurity status when she finds a blood <b>stain.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And when</b> does a young girl <b>arrive</b> at <b>her time to see</b> the flow of menstrual blood? The Gemara answers: <b>When the days of</b> her <b>young womanhood have arrived.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And</b> with regard to a woman <b>who engages in intercourse while</b> using <b>examination cloths,</b> with which she ascertains whether the menstrual flow began, since the halakhic status of that act is like that of an examination, it reduces the time from a twenty-four-hour period and reduces the time from examination to examination. <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> The <b>examination cloth</b> with <b>which</b> she examined herself <b>before intercourse does not reduce</b> the time from a twenty-four-hour period <b>like</b> a regular <b>examination.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for the opinion of Shmuel? <b>Rav Ketina says: Since she is excited [<i>shemehuma</i>]</b> and hurried <b>for</b> intercourse with <b>her husband,</b> it is not considered a proper examination. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> even <b>if she is excited for</b> intercourse with <b>her husband, what of it?</b> Why does that invalidate her examination? The Gemara answers: <b>Since she is excited</b> and hurried <b>for</b> intercourse with <b>her husband, she does not insert</b> the examination cloth <b>into</b> her <b>recesses and folds.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>We learned</b> in the mishna: And a woman <b>who engages in intercourse while</b> using <b>examination cloths,</b> the halakhic status of that act <b>is like that of an examination.</b> The mishna refers to examination cloths in the plural. <b>What, is it not</b> speaking of <b>one</b> cloth used <b>before intercourse and one</b> cloth used <b>after intercourse?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>No, this</b> cloth <b>and that</b> cloth are both used <b>after intercourse; and</b> the reason why the mishna uses the plural is that <b>one</b> cloth is <b>for his</b> use <b>and one</b> is <b>for her</b> use. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (14a): It is the <b>custom of Jewish women to engage in intercourse</b> with their husbands <b>with two examination cloths, one for his</b> use <b>and one for her</b> use.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is this? Granted, if you say</b> that the mishna is referring to <b>one</b> cloth used <b>before intercourse and one</b> used <b>after intercourse,</b> it <b>was necessary</b> for the mishna to mention both examinations, as it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since she is excited</b> and hurried <b>for</b> intercourse with <b>her husband, she did not examine</b> herself <b>properly.</b> Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that her examination with a cloth before intercourse <b>is</b> considered <b>as</b> a halakhically valid <b>examination. But if you say</b> that <b>this</b> cloth <b>and that</b> cloth are his and her cloths used <b>after intercourse,</b> isn’t it <b>obvious</b> that they are treated as halakhic examinations? Why is this ruling necessary?
The Gemara answers: The <i>halakha</i> that the examinations performed after intercourse count as valid examinations is necessary, <b>lest you say</b> that <b>perhaps</b> she might <b>see a drop of blood corresponding</b> to the size of <b>a mustard seed and</b> a drop of <b>semen covered it.</b> In other words, it is possible that she discharged a tiny amount of menstrual blood that went undetected, as it was covered by a drop of semen. Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that one does not need to be concerned for this possibility.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: The mishna is referring only to her examinations, but the reason the mishna mentions two examinations is not to give them the status of valid examinations, but to teach that they are both obligatory. As <b>the Sages required her</b> to perform <b>two examinations: One before intercourse and one after intercourse. And when</b> the mishna <b>teaches:</b> The halakhic status of that act <b>is like that of an examination,</b> it is referring specifically <b>to</b> the examination performed <b>after intercourse.</b> The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But</b> the mishna <b>teaches:</b> A woman <b>who engages</b> in intercourse while using examination cloths. This formulation indicates that the examination is voluntary and is not mandated by the Sages. The Gemara explains that one should emend the text of the mishna so that it <b>teaches: And</b> a woman must <b>engage</b> in intercourse while using examination cloths.
§ The mishna teaches: And with regard to a woman who engages in intercourse while using examination cloths, as the halakhic status of that act is like that of an examination, <b>it reduces</b> the time <b>from</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period,</b> and reduces the time from examination to examination. The Gemara asks: <b>Now</b> that the mishna teaches that this examination <b>reduces</b> time <b>from</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period,</b>

Daf 5b

<b>is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to teach that an examination reduces the time <b>from examination to examination,</b> which is less than twenty-four hours?
The Gemara answers: This ruling is necessary, <b>lest you say</b> that with regard to the significant passage of a twenty-four-hour <b>period</b> the <b>Sages are</b> concerned <b>for</b> the possible <b>loss of ritually pure items, but</b> with regard to the smaller period <b>from examination to examination,</b> the Sages are <b>not</b> concerned for the loss of pure items, and therefore the use of an examination cloth should not reduce the time of possible impurity between that and her next examination. Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that it does reduce this time.
§ The mishna teaches with regard to a woman who has a fixed menstrual cycle: <b>Her time is sufficient, how so?</b> If the woman was sitting in a bed and engaged in handling ritually pure items, and she left the bed and saw blood, she is impure and those items are pure. The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need the mishna <b>to teach:</b> If the woman <b>was sitting in a bed and engaged in</b> handling <b>pure items? Let</b> the mishna <b>teach</b> the same ruling without mentioning the bed: If she <b>was engaged in</b> handling <b>pure items and she left and saw</b> blood. The detail that she was sitting in a bed is apparently superfluous.
The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> detail <b>teaches us</b> that the <b>reason</b> why the bed is not rendered impure is <b>that her time is sufficient</b> and there is no retroactive impurity. It can be inferred that in a case where she is impure retroactively for a twenty-four-hour <b>period, her bed is also rendered impure.</b> This <b>supports</b> the opinion <b>of Ze’eiri, as Ze’eiri said:</b> The level of impurity of the retroactive twenty-four-hour <b>period of a menstruating woman renders</b> impure <b>a bed</b> upon which she lies <b>and a chair</b> upon which she sits, <b>to</b> the extent that they <b>transmit impurity to a person</b> who comes in contact with them, <b>to</b> the extent that he <b>transmits impurity to the garments</b> he is wearing.
This Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Now, this bed</b> upon which she sat <b>is an entity that lacks consciousness</b> in order for it <b>to be asked,</b> and the principle with regard to <b>any entity that lacks consciousness</b> in order for it <b>to be asked</b> is that the item with <b>uncertain</b> status is deemed <b>pure.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>Ze’eiri interpreted</b> his ruling as applying specifically to a case <b>where her friends are carrying her in the bed, where</b> the bed <b>is</b> considered as the extended <b>hand of her friends.</b> In other words, it is part of an entity that has consciousness in order for it to be asked, and therefore the item with uncertain status is deemed impure.
