The Gemara provides another answer: <b>And now that Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> In a case of <b>uncertain ritual impurity that comes</b> about <b>by the hand of a person,</b> i.e., through his involvement, the owner of the vessel must <b>consult</b> a Sage <b>about it,</b> i.e., it is considered an entity that has consciousness in order for it to be asked, as in such a case <b>even with regard to a vessel that is placed upon the ground,</b> which is certainly incapable of providing an answer if asked, its halakhic status is <b>like</b> that of <b>an item that has consciousness</b> in order for it <b>to be asked.</b> With this statement in mind, one can explain that according to Ze’eiri a menstruating woman transmits impurity to a bed <b>even though her friends are not carrying her in the bed.</b> Rather, as the bed’s ritual impurity was caused by the hand of a person, it has the halakhic status of an item that has consciousness in order for it to be asked.
§ The Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter of Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement <b>itself. Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> In a case of <b>uncertain ritual impurity</b> that <b>comes</b> about <b>by the hand of man,</b> its owner must <b>consult</b> a Sage <b>about it,</b> i.e., it is ritually impure, as in such a case <b>even with regard to a vessel that is placed upon the ground,</b> its halakhic status is <b>like</b> that of <b>an item that has consciousness</b> in order for it <b>to be asked.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Teharot</i> 4:1): If a man who contracted ritual impurity <b>was wrapping</b> himself <b>in his cloak and</b> there were <b>pure</b> items beside him; <b>or</b> if he was pure and there were <b>impure</b> items <b>beside him</b> as he was wrapping his cloak; <b>or</b> if there were <b>pure</b> items and <b>impure</b> items <b>above his head</b> at the time and there is <b>uncertainty</b> whether he <b>touched</b> the impure items with his cloak and then touched the pure items with his cloak, and <b>uncertainty</b> whether it did <b>not touch</b> them, the <i>halakha</i> is that the pure items remain <b>pure. But if</b> it is <b>impossible</b> for him to have wrapped himself <b>unless</b> his cloak had <b>touched</b> the impure items in the process, then those previously pure items become <b>impure.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says</b> that <b>we say to him: Repeat</b> your action. <b>And he repeats</b> the action of wrapping himself with his cloak, and it can then be determined whether or not the cloak and the other items came in contact with each other. The Rabbis <b>said to him: We do</b> not rely on <b>repeated</b> actions <b>with regard to</b> the determination of ritually <b>pure</b> items. Since the second action may not exactly mimic the first, it cannot be relied upon to determine ritual purity status.
The Gemara explains the objection: But according to the Rabbis, <b>why</b> is the <i>halakha</i> that the items in question remain pure? <b>Isn’t</b> this a case of <b>uncertain ritual impurity that comes</b> about <b>by the hand of man,</b> which, according to Rabbi Yoḥanan, is considered as having consciousness in order for it to be asked? If so, these items should be ritually impure.
The Gemara answers: <b>Except for that</b> one, i.e., do not raise a difficulty from that <i>baraita</i>, since it is referring to a specific case. <b>As Rav Hoshaya teaches</b> with regard to an item whose purity status is uncertain: When it is <b>in the private domain,</b> the item with <b>uncertain</b> status is deemed <b>impure;</b> when it is <b>in the public domain,</b> it is deemed <b>pure.</b> The <i>baraita</i> is referring to an item located in the public domain. Consequently, even if it is considered as having consciousness in order to be asked, nevertheless it is pure, as its uncertainty occurred in the public domain.
§ The Gemara analyzes <b>the</b> matter of Ze’eiri’s ruling <b>itself. Ze’eiri says:</b> The level of impurity assumed during the retroactive twenty-four-hour <b>period of a menstruating woman renders a bed</b> upon which she lies <b>and a chair</b> upon which she sits impure <b>to</b> the extent that they <b>transmit impurity to a person</b> who comes in contact with them <b>to</b> the extent that he <b>transmits impurity to the garments</b> he is wearing.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? But when Avimi came from Bei Ḥozai, he came and brought</b> the following <b><i>baraita</i> with him:</b> The level of impurity during the retroactive twenty-four-hour <b>period of a menstruating woman</b> renders <b>her bed</b> upon which she lies <b>and her chair</b> upon which she sits impure <b>like</b> the impurity level caused by <b>her touch.</b> The Gemara explains the difficulty: <b>What, is it not</b> correct to say that this means that <b>just as</b> an item rendered impure by <b>her touch</b> does <b>not render</b> another <b>person impure, so too, her bed</b> does <b>not render</b> another <b>person impure?</b>
<b>Rava says: And</b> how can <b>you understand</b> it in that manner? There <b>is an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference here: <b>And if an earthenware vessel sealed</b> with <b>a tightly bound cover, which is spared</b> from impurity when it is <b>in a tent</b> that has <b>a corpse</b> in it, is nevertheless <b>not spared</b> from impurity if the woman moved it <b>during</b> the twenty-four-hour <b>period</b> of retroactive impurity <b>of a menstruating woman</b> and is impure as though she moved it after she experienced bleeding; <b>so too,</b> with regard to <b>beds and chairs, which are not spared</b> from impurity <b>in a tent</b> that has <b>a corpse</b> in it, <b>is it not logical that they are</b> also <b>not spared</b> from impurity when used <b>during the</b> twenty-four-hour <b>period</b> of retroactive impurity <b>of a menstruating woman</b> and are impure as though she used them after she experienced bleeding?
The Gemara asks: <b>But Avimi from Bei Ḥozai cited a <i>baraita</i></b> that apparently does not accept Rava’s <i>a fortiori</i> inference. The Gemara answers: One can <b>say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> does not mean that her bed and chair are rendered impure with the light level of impurity caused by her touch, but rather: <b>Her bed</b> upon which she lies <b>and her chair</b> upon which she sits

Daf 6a

are <b>like</b> her <b>touch itself. Just as</b> her touch <b>transmits impurity to a person</b> who comes in contact with them <b>to</b> the extent that he <b>transmits impurity to the garments</b> he is wearing, <b>so too</b> her bed and her chair <b>transmit impurity to a person</b> who comes in contact with them <b>to</b> the extent that he <b>transmits impurity to the garments</b> he is wearing.
§ It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rava:</b> If a woman <b>sees</b> menstrual <b>blood,</b> it <b>renders her impure</b> retroactively <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period. And</b> what does <b>she render impure</b> during that period? <b>Beds and chairs, food and drink, and an earthenware vessel sealed</b> with <b>a tightly bound cover [<i>tzamid patil</i>],</b> if she moves it. <b>But she does not disrupt her count</b> of the periods of menstruation and <i>ziva</i>, i.e., she starts her cycle only from that day when she saw the blood, <b>and she does not render impure retroactively a man who engaged in intercourse with her. Rabbi Akiva says:</b> She does <b>render impure a man who engaged in intercourse with her. And she counts</b> her seven days of impurity <b>only from the time that she saw</b> her menstrual blood, not retroactively.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: With regard to a woman <b>who sees</b> a blood <b>stain,</b> it <b>renders her impure retroactive</b> to when the garment was last checked. <b>And</b> what does <b>she render impure</b> during that period? <b>Food and drink, beds and chairs, and an earthenware vessel sealed</b> with <b>a tightly bound cover,</b> if she moves it. <b>And</b> it also <b>disrupts her count</b> of eleven days during which emission of blood renders the woman a <i>zava</i>, as the time of the stain is unknown, <b>and she renders</b> ritually <b>impure a man who engaged in intercourse with her. And she counts</b> her seven days of impurity <b>only from the time that she saw</b> her menstrual blood, not retroactively.
The <i>baraita</i> further teaches: With regard to both <b>this,</b> one who sees menstrual blood, <b>and that,</b> one who sees a blood stain, if they had touched <i>teruma</i>, its status is <b>suspended.</b> It is <b>not eaten,</b> as impure <i>teruma</i> is prohibited in consumption, <b>but</b> it is <b>not burned</b> either, since it is prohibited to burn pure <i>teruma</i>.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>And</b> as for <b>Rava,</b> why is the <i>halakha</i> <b>of</b> an earthenware vessel more obvious to him than the <i>halakha</i> of a bed and a chair? <b>If he</b> had <b>heard</b> this <b><i>baraita</i>,</b> which states the <i>halakha</i> of an earthenware vessel, then <b>let him say</b> that the <b><i>baraita</i></b> itself is proof for his opinion with regard to a bed and a chair as well, as the <i>baraita</i> states both <i>halakhot</i>. <b>And if he</b> had <b>not heard</b> this <b><i>baraita</i>, from where</b> did he learn his <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, which is based on the <i>halakha</i> that an earthenware vessel sealed with a tightly bound cover is not spared from impurity if a menstruating woman moved it during her twenty-four-hour period of retroactive impurity?
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually, he</b> did <b>hear</b> the <b><i>baraita</i>. But if</b> his proof had been merely <b>from the <i>baraita</i>, I would say</b> that a different <i>halakha</i> applies to a bed and chair than to the earthenware vessels, as the <i>baraita</i> means that the bed and chair render impure <b>a person or garments</b> that they touch, <b>but</b> they do <b>not</b> render <b>a person</b> impure to the extent that he then transmits impurity to his <b>garments.</b> It is <b>due to that</b> reason that Rava <b>says</b> the <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference.
§ <b>Rav Huna says:</b> The twenty-four-hour <b>period</b> of retroactive impurity <b>of</b> a <b>menstruating woman</b> applies only <b>to sacrificial</b> food <b>but not to <i>teruma</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>If so, let</b> the mishna in <i>Ḥagiga</i> 20b <b>teach</b> this <b>among</b> the other higher <b>levels</b> of purity that apply to sacrificial foods but not to <i>teruma</i>. That mishna lists stringencies of ritual purity that are in effect with regard to sacrificial foods and not <i>teruma</i>. The Gemara answers: <b>When</b> that mishna <b>teaches</b> those higher levels of purity, it is referring only to types of impurity <b>that have a connection [<i>derara</i>] to impurity</b> as defined by Torah law. <b>But</b> it <b>does not teach</b> a case <b>where there is no connection to impurity</b> as defined by Torah law, and the retroactive impurity of a menstruating woman is by rabbinic law.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from the aforementioned <i>baraita</i> that deals with the retroactive impurity of a menstruating woman: What does <b>she render impure</b> during that period? <b>Food and drink.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What, is it not</b> correct to say that this is referring <b>both to sacrificial</b> food <b>and to <i>teruma</i>? The</b> Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is referring only <b>to sacrificial</b> food, not to <i>teruma</i>.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a mishna (11a): With regard to women of priestly families who must examine themselves before partaking of <i>teruma</i>, <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Even when they conclude partaking of <i>teruma</i>,</b> they still need to examine themselves. <b>And we discussed</b> this statement of Rabbi Yehuda and asked: Why do they need to examine themselves after they finish eating <i>teruma</i>? <b>What was, was;</b> i.e., if a woman was impure when she ate the <i>teruma</i>, what is achieved by an examination now?
And <b>Rav Ḥisda says</b> in explanation: <b>It was necessary only</b> in order <b>to amend the</b> situation of the <b>remaining</b> <i>teruma</i> that is left <b>before her,</b> i.e., to prevent it from being rendered ritually impure. In other words, if she later experiences a flow of menstrual blood, her retroactive impurity status will not render the remaining <i>teruma</i> impure. This ruling apparently contradicts the opinion of Rav Huna, who said that the retroactive impurity of a menstruating woman affects only sacrificial foods, not <i>teruma</i>.
The Gemara answers: According to <b>Rav Huna,</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>teaches</b> that since impure <i>teruma</i> must be burned, she must examine herself in order to determine whether it is correct <b>to burn</b> the <b>remaining</b> <i>teruma</i> that was <b>in her hands.</b> If she <b>examined herself</b> immediately after eating the <i>teruma</i>, in the <b>period of time</b> needed for the onset of <b>menstruation</b> (see 14b), and she found that she was impure, it is assumed as a certainty that she was impure when she ate the <i>teruma</i>. Consequently, the remaining <i>teruma</i> must be burned, in accordance with the <i>halakha</i> of <i>teruma</i> that was definitely rendered impure. But in fact, Rav Huna maintains that she does not render that remaining <i>teruma</i> impure retroactively, in a case where she did not examine herself.
The Gemara further suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another difficulty with regard to the opinion of Rav Huna from a <i>baraita</i>: There was <b>an incident</b> in which <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>performed an action</b> by ruling that the <i>halakha</i> <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer.</b> Rabbi Eliezer maintains that a woman who passed three expected menstrual cycles without experiencing bleeding is presumed not to be menstruating any longer, and therefore any menstrual blood that she emits later renders her ritually impure only from then onward, but not retroactively. By contrast, the Rabbis contend that this <i>halakha</i> applies only to an older woman, for whom it is natural to stop menstruating, but not to a young woman, even if three typical periods have passed without bleeding.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>After</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>remembered</b> that Rabbi Eliezer’s colleagues disagree with Rabbi Eliezer on this matter and that he had apparently ruled incorrectly, <b>he</b> nevertheless <b>said: Rabbi Eliezer is worthy [<i>kedai</i>] to rely upon</b>

Daf 6b

<b>in exigent circumstances [<i>bishe’at hadeḥak</i>]. And we discussed it</b> and asked: <b>What is</b> the meaning of: <b>After he remembered? If we say</b> that this means <b>after he remembered that the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer but in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> if so, <b>how could</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>act in accordance with</b> Rabbi Eliezer even <b>in exigent circumstances,</b> since the <i>halakha</i> has been decided against him?
<b>Rather, is it not</b> correct that the <b><i>halakha</i></b> had <b>not been stated</b> on this matter, <b>neither in accordance with</b> the opinion of this <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Eliezer, <b>nor in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>that Sage,</b> i.e., the Rabbis. <b>And once</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>remembered that it was not a single</b> authority who <b>disagrees with</b> Rabbi Eliezer, <b>but</b> it was several Sages who <b>disagreed with him,</b> and there is a principle that the <i>halakha</i> follows the opinion of the many over that of an individual, <b>he</b> nevertheless <b>said: Rabbi Eliezer is worthy to rely upon in exigent circumstances.</b>
The Gemara explains the proof from the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Granted, if you say</b> that it was a case <b>of</b> a menstruating woman who had touched <b><i>teruma</i></b> during the previous twenty-four hours, <b>this is</b> fine, <b>as <i>teruma</i></b> still <b>existed in the days of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>But</b> if you say that it was a case <b>of</b> a woman who touched <b>sacrificial</b> food, <b>was there</b> still <b>sacrificial</b> food <b>in days of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, after the destruction of the Temple? Clearly, the case involved <i>teruma</i>, and according to the Rabbis, whose opinion is accepted as <i>halakha</i>, this woman who had skipped three menstrual cycles nevertheless renders <i>teruma</i> impure retroactively. This ruling apparently contradicts the opinion of Rav Huna.
The Gemara answers: This can be answered <b>in accordance with</b> the testimony <b>of Ulla, as Ulla said: <i>Ḥaverim</i> purify</b> their wine and oil <b>in the Galilee,</b> i.e., they produce their wine and oil by the standards of purity used for sacrificial food, in the hope that the Temple will be rebuilt in their lifetime. <b>Here, too, in the days of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi there were those who kept the standards of purity observed for sacrificial food.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i>: There was <b>an incident involving the maidservant of Rabban Gamliel, who was baking loaves of <i>teruma</i></b> bread. <b>And in between each and every one she</b> would <b>wash her hand in water and examine</b> herself. <b>After</b> the <b>last</b> one she <b>examined</b> herself <b>and found</b> that she was <b>impure</b> due to menstrual blood, <b>and she came and asked Rabban Gamliel</b> about the status of the loaves. <b>And he said to her: They are all impure,</b> due to her retroactive impurity for the previous twenty-four hours. <b>She said to him: My teacher, didn’t I perform an examination in between each and every one?</b> Rabban Gamliel <b>said to her: If so,</b> then <b>this</b> last one is <b>impure and</b> the rest are <b>all pure,</b> as your retroactive impurity is reduced until the time of the most recent examination.
The Gemara explains the difficulty: <b>In any event,</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> that the case involved <b>loaves of <i>teruma</i></b> bread. This apparently contradicts the opinion of Rav Huna, as Rabban Gamliel applied retroactive impurity in a case of <i>teruma</i>. The Gemara answers: What is meant by: <i>Teruma</i>? It means <b><i>teruma</i> of the loaves of the thanks offering,</b> i.e., the four loaves of the thanks offering that were separated from the total of forty and eaten by the priests. These are sacrificial foods, not <i>teruma</i>. The Gemara raises a difficulty with regard to this interpretation: <b>What</b> was she <b>doing baking the <i>teruma</i> of the loaves of the thanks offering</b> alone? All forty loaves of the thanks offering are baked together, and only afterward are four set aside as <i>teruma</i> to be eaten by priests.
The Gemara answers: This is referring to a case <b>where</b> dough for the <i>teruma</i> loaves <b>was separated</b> and designated for the priests <b>during its kneading. And</b> this <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with that which Rav Tovi bar Rav Ketina said:</b> If <b>one baked the loaves of the thanks offering as four loaves,</b> rather than the requisite forty loaves, <b>he has fulfilled</b> his obligation. <b>And we discussed it</b> and asked: <b>Isn’t one required</b> to bring <b>forty</b> loaves with the thanks offering, ten loaves of each of the four different types? The Gemara answers: One must bake forty loaves in order <b>to</b> fulfill the <b>mitzva</b> in the optimal fashion, but he has nevertheless fulfilled his obligation with four loaves, one of each type.
The Gemara continues its answer by further elucidating the statement of Rav Tovi bar Rav Ketina. And we asked with regard to this opinion: <b>But he is required to separate <i>teruma</i> from it,</b> i.e., to designate one loaf from each type that is given to the priests. <b>And if you would say that he separates a slice from each one</b> of the four loaves and gives them to the priest, this cannot be the case, as <b>the Merciful One states</b> in the Torah: “And of it he shall present <b>one</b> out of each offering for a gift to the Lord; it shall be the priest’s” (Leviticus 7:14). The word “one” indicates <b>that he may not take a slice,</b> but rather he takes a complete loaf. The Gemara answers: Rather, <b>we</b> must <b>say</b> that he <b>separated</b> dough for the <i>teruma</i> loaves <b>during its kneading. Here too, in</b> the incident involving Rabban Gamliel’s maidservant, she <b>separated</b> the dough <b>during its kneading.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a <i>baraita</i>: There was <b>another incident involving the maidservant of Rabban Gamliel who was sealing barrels of wine. And in between each and every one she</b> would <b>wash her hands in water and examine</b> herself. <b>And after the last</b> one <b>she examined</b> herself <b>and found</b> that she was ritually <b>impure, and she came and asked Rabban Gamliel</b> about the wine. <b>And he said to her: They are all impure. She said to him:</b> My teacher, <b>didn’t I perform an examination in between each and every one?</b> Rabban Gamliel <b>said to her: If so, this</b> last one is <b>impure and</b> the rest are <b>all pure.</b>
The Gemara clarifies the difficulty with regard to Rav Huna’s opinion: <b>Granted, if you say</b> that <b>one</b> incident involved a case <b>of sacrificial</b> food <b>and one</b> incident involved a case <b>of <i>teruma</i>, this is</b> the reason <b>that she returned and</b> again <b>asked</b> Rabban Gamliel what to do. <b>But if you say</b> that both <b>this</b> incident <b>and that</b> incident <b>involved sacrificial</b> food, <b>why</b> did <b>she</b> need <b>to return and ask him</b> the same question a second time? The Gemara answers: Each <b>incident that occurred was</b> with sacrificial food and they happened <b>with two</b> different <b>maidservants.</b>
<b>Some say another version</b> of Rav Huna’s statement. <b>Rav Huna says:</b> During the twenty-four-hour <b>period of</b> retroactive impurity of <b>a menstruating woman,</b> she <b>renders impure</b> both <b>sacrificial</b> food and <b><i>teruma</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> is this derived? The Gemara answers: It can be inferred <b>from</b> the fact <b>that</b> the mishna in <i>Ḥagiga</i> (20b) <b>does not teach</b> this matter <b>among</b> the other matters where higher <b>levels</b> of purity are required only for sacrificial foods but not for <i>teruma</i>. <b>Rav Naḥman said to</b> Rav Huna: <b>But doesn’t</b> the <b><i>tanna</i></b> explicitly <b>teach</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The retroactive impurity of a menstruating woman applies only <b>with regard to sacrificial</b> food but <b>not with regard to <i>teruma</i>?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak received</b> the following explanation <b>from</b> Rav Naḥman: The <i>baraita</i> means that this retroactive impurity applies <b>to non-sacred</b> food <b>that was prepared according to</b> the standards of <b>purity of sacrificial</b> food, <b>but not to non-sacred</b> food <b>that was prepared</b> according to the standards of <b>purity of <i>teruma</i>.</b> It does apply to <i>teruma</i> itself.
§ With regard to a non-sacred food prepared according to the standards of purity of <i>teruma</i>, <b>we learned</b> in a mishna <b>elsewhere</b> (<i>Ḥalla</i> 3:2): In a case of dough where <b>uncertainty developed</b> as to whether it was <b>ritually impure,</b> if the uncertainty developed <b>before it was kneaded, it may be prepared</b> even <b>in</b> definite <b>impurity,</b> i.e., with impure vessels. If it developed <b>after it was kneaded, it</b> must <b>be prepared in purity.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> elaborates: <b>Before it was kneaded it may be prepared</b> even <b>in</b> definite <b>impurity</b> because <b>it is non-sacred</b> food, <b>and</b> the <i>halakha</i> is that it is <b>permitted to cause impurity to non-sacred food in Eretz Yisrael. After it was kneaded it</b> must <b>be prepared in purity,</b> since <b>non-sacred</b> food <b>that is untithed with regard to</b> the obligation to separate <b><i>ḥalla</i>,</b> i.e., its <i>ḥalla</i> has not yet been separated, <b>is considered like <i>ḥalla</i>, and</b> it is <b>prohibited to cause impurity to <i>ḥalla</i>.</b>
It is <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>:

Daf 7a

<b>And</b> as the <b><i>ḥalla</i></b> of this kneaded, untithed dough is in a state of uncertain purity, its status is <b>suspended:</b> It is <b>neither eaten</b> like ritually pure <i>ḥalla</i>, <b>nor</b> is it <b>burned</b> like impure <i>ḥalla</i>. <b>With regard to which</b> uncertainty did <b>they state</b> this <i>halakha</i>? <b>With regard to <i>ḥalla</i></b> of <b>uncertain</b> status. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the concept of <b><i>ḥalla</i></b> of <b>uncertain</b> status? This apparently indicates a scenario of possible ritual impurity that applies specifically to <i>ḥalla</i>, not to non-sacred food.
<b>Abaye and Rava both say: One should not say</b> that <b>we learned</b> this case of <i>ḥalla</i> of uncertain status among the cases of equal <b>proofs,</b> i.e., an unresolvable uncertainty, <b>such as</b> the case of <b>two paths,</b> where someone walked down one of two paths, one of which was ritually impure and the other ritually pure, and he does not remember which one he walked down. <b>As there,</b> even <b>regular non-sacred</b> food is <b>also rendered</b> ritually <b>impure</b> due to uncertainty.
<b>Rather,</b> the uncertainty referred to here is similar to the less likely case <b>of leaning, as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Zavim</i> 3:2): In a case of <b>a <i>zav</i> and a ritually pure</b> person <b>who were unloading</b> a package <b>from a donkey or</b> who were <b>loading</b> a package onto a donkey, <b>when their package</b> is <b>heavy</b> the pure person is rendered <b>impure,</b> as perhaps the <i>zav</i> leaned on him while they handled the package together. If <b>their package</b> is <b>light,</b> he remains <b>pure. And</b> in <b>all those</b> cases, he remains ritually <b>pure</b> even if he is one of the <b>members of a synagogue</b> whose congregants handle non-sacred food according to the standards of sacrificial food, as this is not a true case of a <i>zav</i> moving a pure person. <b>But</b> he is <b>impure with regard to</b> matters involving <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> by rabbinic law.
The Gemara asks: <b>And is non-sacred</b> food <b>that is untithed with regard to</b> the obligation to separate <b><i>ḥalla</i></b> really <b>considered like <i>ḥalla</i></b> to the extent that it is rendered impure even in a case of leaning? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a woman who immersed that day</b> and is waiting for nightfall for the purification process to be completed, she may separate <i>ḥalla</i>: <b>She may knead the dough, and separate its <i>ḥalla</i> from it, and place</b> the separated dough <b>into a wicker basket or a wooden board [<i>be’anḥuta</i>], and</b> subsequently she may <b>bring</b> it <b>near</b> the rest of the dough, <b>and</b> she may then <b>designate it</b> <i>ḥalla</i> <b>by name.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: The reason that this is allowed, despite her impurity, is <b>because</b> the dough <b>is</b> impure by <b>third</b>-degree ritual impurity, <b>and</b> an item that has <b>third</b>-degree impurity is considered <b>pure with regard to non-sacred</b> food. The Gemara concludes its question: <b>And if you say</b> that <b>non-sacred</b> food <b>that is untithed with regard to</b> the obligation to separate <b><i>ḥalla</i></b> is <b>considered like <i>ḥalla</i>,</b> then she should <b>render it impure</b> with her touch, just as she would render actual <i>ḥalla</i> impure.
<b>Abaye says:</b> With regard to <b>any</b> item <b>that</b> when it is <b>definitely</b> impure <b>renders non-sacred</b> food <b>impure,</b> as in the case of the <i>zav</i>, the Sages <b>issued a decree</b> that <b>its uncertain</b> impurity should also render non-sacred food items impure, <b>due to</b> its status as <b>non-sacred</b> food <b>that is untithed with regard to <i>ḥalla</i>. But</b> with regard to <b>this</b> case of <b>one who immersed that day, since</b> even when she is <b>definitely</b> impure she <b>does not render non-sacred food impure, they did not issue a decree</b> that she should render that dough impure <b>due to</b> its status as <b>non-sacred</b> food <b>that is untithed with regard to <i>ḥalla</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> what about the twenty-four-hour <b>period</b> of retroactive impurity <b>of a menstruating woman? As a definitely</b> impure menstruating woman <b>renders non-sacred</b> food <b>impure and</b> nevertheless with regard to untithed dough the Sages <b>did not issue a decree</b> to treat <b>her uncertain</b> impurity as definite impurity <b>due to</b> the dough’s status as <b>non-sacred</b> food <b>that is untithed with regard to <i>ḥalla</i>.</b>
The Gemara cites its source for this claim: <b>As the Master said: Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak received</b> from Rav Naḥman: The retroactive impurity of a menstruating woman transmits impurity <b>to non-sacred</b> food items <b>that were prepared according to</b> the standards of <b>purity of sacrificial</b> food, <b>but not to non-sacred</b> food items <b>that were prepared</b> according to the standards of <b>purity of <i>teruma</i>.</b> It is assumed that the level of purity required for non-sacred food items prepared according to the standards required of <i>teruma</i> is the same as that of dough from which <i>ḥalla</i> has not been separated, i.e., it is not treated as real <i>ḥalla</i>, which is rendered impure by her retroactive twenty-four-hour period of impurity.
The Gemara answers: The level of purity required for non-sacred food items that were prepared according to the standards of purity of <i>teruma</i> is actually lower than the level required for dough from which <i>ḥalla</i> has not been separated. The reason is that <b>there,</b> in the case of non-sacred food items, there is <b>no</b> actual <b><i>teruma</i> mixed in it.</b> By contrast, <b>here,</b> in the case of untithed dough, there is <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> i.e., <i>ḥalla</i>, <b>mixed in it,</b> which will eventually be separated from this dough.
<b>If you wish, say</b> instead: <b>Leave</b> aside the twenty-four-hour <b>period</b> of retroactive impurity of a menstruating woman, as it applies <b>by rabbinic law.</b> One cannot raise a difficulty against the principle that untithed dough is treated with the same level of purity as <i>ḥalla</i> from the case of the retroactive impurity of a menstruating woman, since that retroactive impurity is a rabbinic decree, and therefore there is more room for leniency.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> Unlike the women with regard to whom it was taught that they transmit impurity retroactively, there are <b>four women</b> who discern menstrual blood and <b>their time is sufficient,</b> i.e., they transmit impurity only from the moment that they saw the blood: <b>A virgin, a pregnant woman, a nursing woman, and an elderly woman. Rabbi Yehoshua says: I heard</b> this <i>halakha</i> from my teachers <b>only</b> with regard to <b>a virgin,</b>

Daf 7b

<b>but</b> the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer.</b>
<b>Who is</b> the woman characterized as <b>a virgin</b> in this context? It is <b>any</b> woman <b>who has not seen</b> the flow of menstrual <b>blood in all her days, even if she was married</b> and has experienced bleeding as a result of intercourse consummating her marriage. The time of <b>a pregnant woman</b> is <b>from</b> the point in her pregnancy when the existence of <b>her fetus is known</b> to all who see her. The time of <b>a nursing woman</b> is <b>until she weans her child</b> from nursing. If she stopped nursing, e.g., <b>she gave her child to a wet nurse, weaned him</b> from nursing, <b>or</b> her child <b>died,</b> and she saw menstrual blood, <b>Rabbi Meir says: She transmits impurity for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period</b> or from her most recent examination. <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> Even in those cases, <b>her time is sufficient.</b>
<b>Who is</b> the woman characterized as <b>an elderly woman</b> in this context? It is <b>any</b> woman for <b>whom three</b> typical menstrual <b>cycles</b> of thirty days <b>passed</b> during which she saw no menstrual blood, at a stage of her life <b>close to her old age. Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> In the case of <b>any woman</b> for <b>whom three</b> typical menstrual <b>cycles passed</b> during which she saw no menstrual blood, if she then experiences bleeding, <b>her time is sufficient. Rabbi Yosei says:</b> With regard to <b>a pregnant woman and a nursing woman</b> for <b>whom three</b> typical menstrual <b>cycles passed</b> during which they saw no menstrual blood, if they then saw blood, <b>their time is sufficient.</b>
<b>And</b> in the above cases, <b>with regard to what did</b> the <i>tanna</i> say <b>her time is sufficient?</b> It is <b>with regard to the first sighting</b> of blood, <b>but with regard to the second sighting,</b> her status is like that of any other woman, and <b>she transmits impurity for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period</b> or from her most recent examination. <b>And if she saw the first</b> sighting as a result of <b>unnatural circumstances, even</b> with regard to <b>the second</b> sighting, the <i>halakha</i> is that <b>her time is sufficient.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> Rabbi Eliezer teaches in the mishna that there are four women who transmit impurity only from the moment that they saw menstrual blood, not retroactively. Rabbi Yehoshua said: I heard this <i>halakha</i> from my teachers only with regard to a virgin. The Gemara notes that <b>it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer said to Rabbi Yehoshua: You did not hear,</b> but <b>I did hear</b> it. In other words, you may not have received a tradition from your teachers with regard to any other woman, but I did receive such a tradition. Furthermore, <b>you heard</b> a halakhic ruling with regard to <b>only one</b> woman, <b>and I heard</b> rulings with regard to <b>many</b> women.
Rabbi Eliezer continued his rebuttal with a metaphor from the practice of sanctifying the new moon, which required the testimony of witnesses: <b>We do not say to one who had not seen the new moon</b> to <b>come and testify. Rather</b> we give such an instruction only <b>to he who saw it.</b> Similarly, my opinion is weightier with regard to this issue, as I heard many rulings about the matter, whereas you did not. The Gemara reports: <b>All the days of</b> the life of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, they would practice in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> i.e., only a virgin would be exempt from retroactive impurity. <b>After Rabbi Eliezer’s passing, Rabbi Yehoshua returned the matter to its former</b> custom, which was to follow the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that they <b>did not</b> act <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer during his lifetime?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Because Rabbi Eliezer was a <i>Shammuti</i>,</b> i.e., a follower of the rulings of Beit Shammai, and the <i>halakha</i> is generally in accordance with the opinion of Beit Hillel in their disputes with Beit Shammai. <b>And</b> the Sages <b>held</b> that <b>if we act in accordance with his</b> opinion <b>in one</b> matter, people will <b>act in accordance with his</b> opinion <b>in other</b> matters.
<b>And</b> that would be a problem, as if so, then during his lifetime, <b>due to the honor of Rabbi Eliezer, we</b> will <b>not be able to protest</b> against <b>them.</b> But <b>after Rabbi Eliezer’s passing, when we are able to protest</b> against <b>those</b> who act in accordance with Rabbi Eliezer’s opinion in other matters, Rabbi Yehoshua <b>returned the matter to its former</b> custom of deciding the <i>halakha</i> in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer in this matter.
§ The Gemara mentions other instances in which the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer. <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer in four</b> cases. <b>One</b> is the <i>halakha</i> <b>that we</b> just <b>mentioned,</b> of the four women who transmit ritual impurity only from the time of their sighting and onward.
<b>And another</b> is taught in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to a woman <b>who</b> experiences <b>labor</b> pain as a result of which she sees a flow of blood. Her discharge is attributed to childbirth rather than <i>zava</i> blood. The <i>baraita</i> asks: For <b>how long</b> must she be <b>relieved</b> from pain in order <b>to be</b> considered <b>a <i>zava</i></b> due to her flow of uterine blood? She must have relief <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer. And</b> the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with his statement.</b>
<b>And another</b> case in which the <i>halakha</i> follows Rabbi Eliezer is taught in a mishna (68b): A <i>zav</i> and a <i>zava</i> must observe seven days without a discharge in order to attain ritual purity. With regard to <b>a <i>zav</i> or a <i>zava</i> who examined themselves</b> on the <b>first day and found</b> themselves to be <b>pure,</b> and they examined themselves on the <b>seventh day and found</b> themselves to be <b>pure, but</b> on the <b>rest of the</b> intervening <b>days they did not examine</b> themselves, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: The presumptive status of</b> the <i>zav</i> and the <i>zava</i> is one of <b>ritual purity. Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> In that case, the <i>zav</i> and the <i>zava</i> <b>have</b> counted <b>only the first day and the seventh day,</b> two of the seven clean days, and they must count another five days to complete the tally.
The mishna continues: <b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> Since any impure discharge that they might have experienced in between the first and seventh days would negate their count and require them to restart the seven-day period, the <i>zav</i> and the <i>zava</i> <b>have</b> counted <b>only the seventh day,</b> and must count another six days to complete the tally. And with regard to this dispute, it <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon and Rabbi Yosei say: The statement of Rabbi Eliezer appears</b> more correct <b>than the statement of Rabbi Yehoshua, and the statement of Rabbi Akiva</b> appears more correct <b>than the statement of all of them. But</b> the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer.</b>
<b>And the other</b> case in which the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Teharot</i> 8:7): With regard to <b>the exterior of vessels that contracted ritual impurity</b> through contact <b>with</b> impure <b>liquids,</b> i.e., with liquids that had touched the carcass of a creeping animal, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says,</b> with regard to this impurity that applies by rabbinic law: These exteriors <b>transmit impurity to liquids</b> that come in contact with them, but <b>they do not disqualify foods</b> with which they come into contact. The mishna elaborates: <b>They transmit impurity to</b> other <b>liquids, and even non-sacred</b> liquids. <b>And they do not disqualify foods, and even <i>teruma</i>. Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> These exteriors <b>transmit impurity to liquids and they disqualify</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>foods,</b> as well.
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> I derived my ruling via <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference from the <i>halakha</i> of one who was ritually impure, who immersed that day and is waiting for nightfall for the purification process to be completed. <b>And if one who immersed that day, who</b> has second-degree ritual impurity status and therefore he <b>does not transmit impurity to non-sacred liquids,</b> nevertheless <b>disqualifies <i>teruma</i> foods</b> with which he comes into contact, then with regard to the <b>exteriors of vessels, which</b> do <b>transmit impurity to non-sacred liquids, is it not logical that</b> they should <b>render <i>teruma</i> food disqualified?</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Eliezer,</b> how does he refute this inference? The Gemara answers: He would counter that the <i>halakha</i> that the <b>exterior of vessels</b> are rendered impure through contact with impure foods or liquids is <b>by rabbinic law, and</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>one who immersed that day</b> apply <b>by Torah law. And</b> there is a principle that one does not <b>apply <i>a fortiori</i></b> inferences to derive conclusions <b>by rabbinic law from</b> cases that apply <b>by Torah law. As by Torah law</b> impure <b>foods do not transmit impurity to vessels, and</b> similarly, impure <b>liquids do not transmit impurity to vessels.</b>
The Gemara continues: <b>And</b> it was <b>the Sages who issued a decree</b> that the exterior of a vessel is rendered impure when it comes into contact with impure liquids, and they decreed that only liquids, not foods, are rendered impure when they come into contact with impure vessel exteriors. The reason for this is <b>due to</b> the <b>liquids</b> secreted <b>by a <i>zav</i> or <i>zava</i>,</b> e.g., their saliva and urine, which have a primary degree of ritual impurity and therefore transmit impurity to vessels. Consequently, with regard to <b>liquids, which are apt to contract impurity, the Sages issued a decree that they</b> contract impurity when they come in contact with these impure vessel exteriors. But with regard to <b>foods, which are not</b> as <b>apt to contract impurity,</b> as they must first be rendered susceptible to impurity through contact with a liquid, <b>the Sages did not issue</b> such <b>a decree with regard to them.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: Rabbi Eliezer agrees that if the interior of a vessel is rendered impure by contact with impure liquids, it renders impure any <i>teruma</i> foods that come into contact with it. <b>But what is different</b> about the <b>exterior of vessels, that</b> Rabbi Eliezer <b>cited</b> them as having a more lenient status? The Gemara answers: This is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> their <i>halakhot</i> are more <b>lenient</b> than those of the other parts of the vessel. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Kelim</i> 25:6): With regard to <b>a vessel whose exterior was rendered impure by</b> contact with impure <b>liquids,</b> its <b>exterior is impure,</b> while its others parts, such as <b>its interior, its ear,</b> i.e., its looped handle, <b>its rim,</b> the edge of the vessel that protrudes outward, and <b>its handles, are pure.</b> But if its <b>interior was rendered impure, it is all impure.</b>
These are the four cases with regard to which Shmuel said that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer. The Gemara asks: <b>What is Shmuel teaching us? In all</b> of these cases <b>we learned</b> explicitly that <b>the <i>halakha</i></b> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer.
<b>And if you would say</b> that he is <b>teaching us</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the <b>exterior of vessels, whose</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>we did not learn</b> from the mishna, <b>let</b> Shmuel simply <b>state</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer with regard to</b> the <b>exterior of vessels.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>Rather, this</b> is what Shmuel <b>teaches us: That</b> a final <b><i>halakha</i> may not be learned</b> directly <b>from the Talmud,</b> i.e., from a statement of a mishna or <i>baraita</i> that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with a specific opinion, unless the ruling is confirmed by <i>amora’im</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And is there nothing more</b> that can be added to the list of cases in which the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer? <b>But isn’t there</b> another case <b>that we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Yevamot</i> 109a): Two brothers married two sisters, one an adult and the other a minor. If the husband of the adult dies, the Torah obligation of levirate marriage applies to the other brother, which is not abrogated by the rabbinic prohibition of the <i>yevama</i> as the sister of his minor wife. In such a case, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b>

Daf 8a

<b>We instruct the minor,</b> i.e., the surviving brother’s wife, <b>to refuse</b> to continue to stay married to <b>him</b> so that her marriage is dissolved, and he may then enter into levirate marriage with her adult sister, the widow of his childless brother. <b>And Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>When Shmuel says</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer in four</b> cases, what he meant was four cases <b>within <i>Seder Teharot</i></b> in the Mishna, the order that deals with ritual purity. <b>But in the other orders, there are many</b> instances where the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer.
The Gemara adds: <b>This too stands to reason, as we learned</b> in a mishna in the order of <i>Zera’im</i> (<i>Ḥalla</i> 2:4) that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: Even</b> with regard to <b>one who removes</b> loaves of bread from an oven <b>and places them in a basket, the basket</b> serves to <b>combine them to</b> reach the quantity from which one is required to separate <b><i>ḥalla</i>,</b> despite the fact that each of the loaves does not contain the necessary measure for <i>ḥalla</i> on its own. <b>And Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer. Conclude from this</b> that Shmuel’s general statement applies only to <i>Seder Teharot</i>.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: The case of <i>ḥalla</i> was cited as proof that there is an exception to Shmuel’s principle that there are only four cases where the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer, after a difficulty was raised from the case of levirate marriage with the sister of one’s minor wife. <b>But</b> in <b>what</b> way is <b>this</b> case of <i>ḥalla</i> <b>greater</b> proof <b>than that</b> case of the levirate marriage? Neither case appears in <i>Seder Teharot</i>. The Gemara answers: The case of the levirate marriage is different, <b>as</b> there <b>Rabbi Elazar holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer.
<b>As we learned</b> in the mishna (<i>Yevamot</i> 111b): A <i>yavam</i> may perform levirate marriage with only one of his deceased brother’s wives. Once he does so, the other wives are forbidden to him, because they had been married to his brother. If a deceased brother had two wives, an adult and a minor, and the <i>yavam</i> engaged in sexual intercourse with the minor and then engaged in intercourse with the adult, the Rabbis maintain that he disqualifies the minor from staying married to him, as her levirate bond is uncertain, and the adult wife is also prohibited to him, because the levirate marriage with the minor is considered effective by rabbinic law. <b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> The court <b>instructs the minor to refuse him,</b> thereby annulling her marriage retroactively, and he may then perform levirate marriage with the adult. Accordingly, the case of <i>ḥalla</i> is a stronger example, as there the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer exclusively, as his opinion is not supported by another <i>tanna</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And does</b> Rabbi Elazar in fact <b>hold</b> in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer? <b>But doesn’t</b> the Gemara (<i>Yevamot</i> 111b) explain that both the opinions of Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Elazar <b>are necessary,</b> as they apply to different cases, <b>and</b> therefore <b>they are not comparable to each other?</b> The Gemara suggests a new answer: <b>Rather,</b> the ruling with regard to levirate marriage is a weaker example of a case where the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer <b>because Rabbi Yehuda ben Bava holds in accordance with his opinion.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Bava testified</b> about <b>five matters of</b> <i>halakha</i>: Normally, marriage refusals of girls married off by their mother or brothers are discouraged. Yet, in specific instances where it is clear that if the marriage were to remain in effect it would engender problems related to levirate marriage and <i>ḥalitza</i>, the court <b>persuades minor girls to refuse</b> to continue living with their husbands, thereby resolving the complications involved in the case.
<b>And</b> he also testified <b>that one may</b> allow <b>a woman</b> who seeks to remarry after hearing of her husband’s death <b>to marry based on</b> the testimony of <b>one witness,</b> as opposed to the two witnesses required for other matters of testimony. <b>And</b> he further testified <b>that a rooster was stoned</b> to death <b>in Jerusalem for killing a person,</b> in order to teach that the Torah law requiring the stoning of an ox that killed a person (see Exodus 21:28) applies to other animals as well. <b>And</b> he testified <b>about forty-day-old wine that was</b> used for <b>libation on the altar. And</b> finally, he testified <b>about</b> the <b>daily morning offering that was sacrificed at four hours</b> of the day.
The Gemara concludes its proof: When the <i>baraita</i> teaches that Rabbi Yehuda ben Bava testified that the court persuades minor girls to refuse to continue living with their husbands, <b>what</b> is the significance of the reference to <b>minor girls</b> in the plural? Is this <b>not</b> referring to the <b>one</b> minor girl who is the subject of the ruling <b>of Rabbi Elazar and</b> the other <b>one</b> that is the subject of the ruling <b>of Rabbi Eliezer?</b> Apparently, Rabbi Yehuda ben Bava holds in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer in the case of the minor’s refusal. If so, this ruling is a weaker proof that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer in cases outside of <i>Seder Teharot</i>. The Gemara answers: <b>No, what</b> is meant by the plural: <b>Minor girls?</b> It means <b>minor girls in general,</b> i.e., all minor girls in such cases where the ruling of Rabbi Elazar applies.
The Gemara challenges: <b>If so, with regard to</b> the <i>halakha</i> listed in the <i>baraita</i> that one may allow <b>a woman</b> to marry based on the testimony of one witness, <b>let it also teach: Women,</b> in the plural, <b>and we will say</b> that it is referring to <b>women in general. Rather, from</b> the fact that <b>here</b> it <b>teaches: A woman, and</b> yet <b>here</b> it <b>teaches: Minor girls, conclude from</b> this discrepancy that Rabbi Yehuda ben Bava <b>is teaching</b> his ruling <b>specifically</b> about two minor girls: The one who is the subject of Rabbi Elazar’s ruling and the one who is the subject of Rabbi Eliezer’s ruling. The Gemara comments: Indeed, <b>conclude from it</b> that Rabbi Yehuda ben Bava holds in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer.
§ <b>And similarly, Rabbi Elazar says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer in four</b> cases. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> are there <b>no more? But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> The court <b>instructs the minor to refuse</b> to stay married to <b>him, and Rabbi Elazar said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer?</b> The Gemara adds: <b>And if you would say</b> that <b>when Rabbi Elazar said</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer in four</b> cases, he meant four cases <b>within <i>Seder Teharot</i>, but in the other orders</b> of the Mishna <b>there are many</b> cases, <b>are there</b> really other such cases?
<b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Shevi’it</i> 7:6) that the <i>halakha</i> of the following fragrant plants: <b>The rose, the henna, the rockrose, and the balsam,</b> is that <b>they have</b> the sanctity of the <b>Sabbatical</b> Year, <b>and money</b> exchanged for <b>them has</b> the sanctity of the <b>Sabbatical</b> Year. Additionally, <b>they have</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>eradication and money</b> exchanged for <b>them has</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>eradication. And</b> with regard to this mishna, <b>Rabbi Pedat said: Who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> who <b>taught that balsam</b> has the status of <b>a fruit,</b> and is not merely sap, and therefore it has the sanctity of the Sabbatical Year? It is <b>Rabbi Eliezer.</b>
The Gemara continues: <b>And Rabbi Zeira said to</b> Rabbi Pedat: One can <b>see that from you and from your father,</b> i.e., between the two of you, <b>you have permitted balsam to the world,</b> since the ruling of Rabbi Eliezer is certainly not accepted. As <b>you said: Who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> who <b>taught that balsam</b> has the status of <b>a fruit?</b> It is <b>Rabbi Eliezer. And your father,</b> Rabbi Elazar, <b>said</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer in</b> only <b>four</b> cases.
The Gemara explains the difficulty: <b>And if it is so,</b> that Rabbi Elazar was referring only to <i>Seder Teharot</i>, then <b>let</b> Rabbi Pedat <b>say to</b> Rabbi Zeira: <b>When</b> my <b>father said</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer in four</b> cases, he meant only four cases <b>within <i>Seder Teharot</i>, but in the other orders there are</b> other such cases. From the fact that Rabbi Pedat did not reply in this manner, evidently there are no cases in the other orders of the Mishna where, according to Rabbi Elazar, the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer.
The Gemara asks: <b>But that</b> case, where the <i>amora</i> Rabbi Elazar said that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer with regard to persuading a minor to refuse to stay married to her husband, is <b>difficult.</b> This apparently conflicts with the statement that there are only four cases in which Rabbi Elazar rules in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer. The Gemara answers: There the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer only <b>because</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>Rabbi Elazar holds in accordance with his</b> opinion. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna that <b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> The court <b>instructs the minor to refuse</b> to stay married to <b>him,</b> thereby annulling her marriage retroactively.
The Gemara asks: <b>And does</b> Rabbi Elazar <b>hold</b> in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer in that case of the minor? <b>But doesn’t</b> the Gemara in <i>Yevamot</i> explain that both the opinions of Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Elazar <b>are necessary, and</b> therefore <b>they are not comparable to each other? Rather,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer in that case <b>because Rabbi Yehuda ben Bava holds in accordance with his opinion,</b> as explained earlier.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> are there <b>no more</b> cases in which Rabbi Elazar maintains that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with Rabbi Eliezer? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Berakhot</i> 33a): One recites the prayer of distinction between the holy and the profane [<i>havdala</i>], said in the evening prayer following Shabbat and festivals, in the fourth blessing of the <i>Amida</i> prayer: Who graciously grants knowledge. <b>Rabbi Akiva says: One recites</b> <i>havdala</i> as <b>a fourth blessing by itself. Rabbi Eliezer says</b> that <b>one recites it in</b> the blessing of <b>thanksgiving.</b> And with regard to this dispute, <b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer.</b>
<b>Rabbi Abba said,</b> in explanation: <b>That</b> case is different, <b>as</b> that is not the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer himself. Rather, he <b>stated</b> that ruling <b>in the name of Rabbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Akiva says: One recites</b> <i>havdala</i> as <b>a fourth blessing by itself; Rabbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel says: One recites it in</b> the blessing of <b>thanksgiving.</b>

Daf 8b

The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> wasn’t Rabbi Eliezer <b>much older than</b> Rabbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel? How could Rabbi Eliezer have cited the opinion of Rabbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel? The Gemara answers: <b>Rather,</b> the reason Rabbi Elazar ruled that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer in that case was <b>because Rabbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel held in accordance with his</b> opinion.
<b>And does</b> Rabbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel really <b>hold</b> in accordance with Rabbi Eliezer’s opinion? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: On <b>the night of Yom Kippur, one prays seven</b> blessings in the <i>Amida</i> prayer <b>and confesses;</b> in the <b>morning prayer, one prays seven</b> blessings <b>and confesses;</b> in the <b>additional prayer, one prays seven</b> blessings <b>and confesses;</b> in the <b>afternoon prayer, one prays seven</b> blessings <b>and confesses;</b> and <b>in</b> the <b><i>ne’ila</i> prayer, one</b> also <b>prays seven</b> blessings <b>and confesses. For the evening prayer</b> at the conclusion of Yom Kippur, <b>one prays seven</b> blessings in <b>an abridged</b> version of the <b>eighteen</b> blessings of the weekday <i>Amida</i> prayer. One recites the first three blessings, the final three, and a middle blessing that includes an abbreviated form of the other weekday blessings.
<b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel says in the name of his forefathers: One recites</b> the complete <b>eighteen</b> blessings, <b>due to</b> the fact that he is <b>required to recite <i>havdala</i> in</b> the fourth blessing of the <i>Amida</i>: <b>Who graciously grants knowledge.</b> <i>Havdala</i> cannot be inserted into the abridged version. Evidently, Rabbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel does not agree with Rabbi Eliezer’s ruling that one recites <i>havdala</i> in the blessing of thanksgiving, one of the final three blessings of the <i>Amida</i> prayer. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak says</b> in explanation: Rabbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel <b>said</b> this opinion <b>in the name of his forefathers, but</b> he <b>himself does not hold accordingly.</b>
§ Earlier, Rabbi Zeira questioned the claim of Rabbi Pedat, son of Rabbi Eliezer, that the Sage who holds that balsam is considered to be fruit and therefore has the sanctity of the Sabbatical Year is Rabbi Eliezer. <b>Rabbi Yirmeya said to Rabbi Zeira: And you? Do you not hold</b> that the <i>tanna</i> <b>who taught</b> that <b>balsam</b> sap has the status of <b>fruit is Rabbi Eliezer? As, didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Orla</i> 1:7) that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> With regard to <b>one who curdles</b> cheese <b>in the sap of <i>orla</i>,</b> the cheese is <b>prohibited,</b> as the sap is considered to be fruit of the tree.
The Gemara answers: <b>You</b> may <b>even say</b> that the mishna that deals with balsam is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b> As <b>the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Eliezer only with regard to</b> the <b>sap of the tree, but in</b> the case of the <b>sap of the fruit they agree with him. As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Orla</i> 1:7) that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua said: I heard explicitly that</b> in the case of <b>one who curdles</b> cheese <b>in the sap of the leaves</b> or <b>the sap of the roots</b> of an <i>orla</i> tree, the cheese is <b>permitted.</b> But if it is curdled <b>in the sap of unripe figs it is prohibited, because</b> that sap <b>is</b> considered to be <b>fruit.</b>
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>When the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Eliezer,</b> it is <b>with regard to a tree that bears fruit. But in</b> the case of <b>a tree that does not bear fruit, they agree that its sap is</b> considered to be <b>its fruit. As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Shevi’it</i> 7:6) that <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> The sanctity of the <b>Sabbatical</b> Year <b>does not</b> apply <b>to sap. And the Rabbis say:</b> The sanctity of the <b>Sabbatical</b> Year <b>does</b> apply <b>to sap, because its sap is its fruit.</b>
The Gemara explains the proof: <b>Who</b> are these <b>Rabbis?</b> Are they <b>not the Rabbis who disagree with Rabbi Eliezer?</b> If so, this demonstrates that they agree in the case of a tree that does not bear fruit. The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>A certain elder said to</b> Rabbi Zeira that <b>this is what Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Who</b> are <b>the Rabbis</b> in this mishna? It is <b>Rabbi Eliezer, who said</b> that <b>its sap is</b> considered to be <b>its fruit.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If it is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, why</b> are they <b>specifically</b> discussing the case of <b>a tree that does not bear fruit? Even</b> in the case of <b>a tree that</b> does <b>bear fruit,</b> Rabbi Eliezer maintains that <b>its sap is</b> like <b>its fruit.</b> The Gemara answers: Rabbi Eliezer <b>stated</b> his opinion <b>to them in accordance with the statement of the Rabbis</b> themselves, as follows: <b>According to my</b> opinion, <b>even</b> with regard to <b>a tree that bears fruit, its sap</b> is <b>also</b> considered to be <b>its fruit.</b> But <b>according to your</b> opinion, you should <b>at least agree with me in</b> the case of <b>a tree that does not bear fruit,</b> that <b>its sap is</b> considered to be <b>its fruit. And the Rabbis said</b> in response <b>to</b> Rabbi Eliezer: <b>It is no different.</b> Sap is not considered fruit whether it comes from a fruit-bearing tree or a barren tree.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>Who is</b> the woman characterized as <b>a virgin</b> in this context? It is <b>any</b> woman <b>who did not see</b> the flow of menstrual blood in all her days, even if she was married and experienced bleeding resulting from intercourse consummating her marriage. <b>The Sages taught:</b> If she was <b>married and she saw</b> a flow of <b>blood due to her marriage,</b> i.e., blood resulting from the tearing of her hymen; or if <b>she gave birth and saw blood due to the birth, I still call her a virgin</b> in this context. The reason is <b>that when they said: Virgin</b> here, they meant a menstrual <b>blood virgin,</b> i.e., one who did not yet see a menstrual flow, <b>and not a hymen-</b>blood <b>virgin,</b> i.e., one who did not experience bleeding from a torn hymen.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? But didn’t Rav Kahana say</b> that a Sage <b>taught: There are three</b> types of <b>virgins: A virgin human, virgin ground, and a virgin sycamore. A virgin human</b> is a woman for <b>as long as she has not engaged in intercourse. The relevance</b> of this designation is that only a virgin is permitted <b>to</b> marry <b>a High Priest</b> (see Leviticus 21:13–14). <b>Alternatively,</b> the relevance is <b>that her marriage contract is two hundred dinars,</b> instead of the one hundred dinars in the marriage contract of a non-virgin.
<b>Virgin ground</b> is ground for <b>as long as it has not been worked. The relevance</b> of this designation is <b>with regard to</b> the <b>rough</b> dried-up <b>stream</b> mentioned in the Torah. When the corpse of a murder victim is found between two towns and the murderer is unknown, the Torah states that a heifer’s neck is broken in a place that was not worked. <b>Alternatively,</b> the relevance is <b>with regard to buying and selling.</b> If one stipulates that he is buying virgin land, it is defined as land that has never been worked.
Finally, <b>a virgin sycamore</b> is a sycamore for <b>as long as it has not been felled,</b> i.e., cut to promote growth. <b>The relevance</b> of this designation is <b>with regard to buying and selling.</b> If one stipulates that he is buying virgin sycamore, it is defined as one that has never been felled. <b>Alternatively,</b> the relevance is <b>with regard to</b> the prohibition against <b>felling it in the Sabbatical</b> Year, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna: (<i>Shevi’it</i> 4:5): <b>One may not fell a virgin sycamore in the Sabbatical</b> Year, <b>because it is</b> considered <b>work,</b> as this promotes the growth of the tree. The Gemara explains its question: <b>And if it is so,</b> that there is a concept of a virgin from menstrual blood, <b>let</b> the <i>tanna</i> of this <i>baraita</i> <b>also teach this</b> type of virgin.
The Gemara cites several answers. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak says: When</b> the Sage <b>teaches</b> the list of virgins, he includes only <b>an item that does not have a modifier, but he does not teach an item that has a modifier.</b> A virgin human, virgin land, and a virgin sycamore can be referred to without another modifier. Conversely, a virgin with regard to menstrual blood cannot be referred to simply by the unmodified term: Virgin. <b>Rav Sheshet, son of Rav Idi, says: When</b> the Sage <b>teaches</b> the list of virgins, he includes only <b>an item that is dependent upon</b> an outside <b>action,</b> e.g., intercourse in the case of a human virgin or felling in the case of a virgin sycamore. But <b>he does not teach an item that is not dependent upon</b> an outside <b>action,</b> such as a woman’s menstrual flow.
<b>Rabbi Ḥanina, son of Rav Ika says: When</b> the Sage <b>teaches</b> the list of virgins, he includes only <b>an item that will not</b> later <b>revert to its</b> original <b>state.</b> But <b>he does not teach an item</b> that will later <b>revert to its</b> original <b>state,</b> such as a woman’s menstrual flow that ceases when she reaches old age. <b>Ravina says: When</b> the Sage <b>teaches</b> the list of virgins, he includes only <b>an item about which a buyer is particular,</b> such as one who purchases a virgin sycamore tree. But <b>he does not teach an item about which a buyer is not particular,</b> e.g., a woman’s menstrual blood.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is a buyer, i.e., a potential husband, <b>not particular</b> about her menstrual blood? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya says: Just as leaven is fortuitous for dough, so</b> too, <b>blood is fortuitous for a woman; and it is taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i> <b>in the name of Rabbi Meir: Any woman whose blood is plentiful, her children are plentiful?</b> A potential husband would certainly be particular about this factor. The Gemara provides an alternative answer: <b>Rather, when</b> the Sage <b>teaches</b> the list of virgins, he includes only <b>an item that buyers are eager</b> to purchase. But <b>he does not teach an item that buyers are not eager</b> to purchase, e.g., a woman without menstrual blood.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>What is virgin ground?</b> It is <b>any</b> ground <b>that raises up hard clumps</b> of <b>earth and whose dirt is not loose.</b> If one <b>finds</b> a shard of <b>earthenware in</b> the earth, <b>it is</b> thereby <b>known that it was</b> once <b>worked</b> and is not virgin ground. If one finds hard <b>rock, it is virgin ground.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: The time of <b>a pregnant woman</b> is sufficient <b>from</b> the point in her pregnancy when the existence of <b>her fetus is known</b> to all who see her. The Gemara asks: <b>And how much</b> time must pass for <b>the fetus to be known? Sumakhos says in the name of Rabbi Meir: Three months. And although there is no</b> explicit <b>proof for the matter,</b> that a fetus is discernable after three months of pregnancy, there is <b>an allusion to the matter, as it is stated: “And it came to pass about three months</b> after, that it was told to Judah, saying: Tamar your daughter-in-law has played the harlot” (Genesis 38:24).
The Gemara asks: Why does Rabbi Meir call this a mere <b>allusion to the matter?</b> An explicit <b>verse is written, and that is a significant proof.</b> The Gemara answers: It is only an allusion <b>because there are</b> some women <b>who give birth after nine</b> months <b>and there are</b> others <b>who give birth after seven</b> months. Although the verse indicates that a fetus is known to all after three months, it is possible that this applies only to a nine-month pregnancy. Since in the case of a nine-month pregnancy the fetus is recognizable after a third of the full term, with regard to a seven-month pregnancy, the fetus would likewise be noticeable after a third of the full pregnancy, i.e., at two and one-third months. Therefore, Rabbi Meir teaches that in all cases the fetus is known only after three months.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to a woman who <b>had a presumptive status that</b> she was <b>pregnant and she saw blood, and afterward</b> she <b>miscarried air, or anything that is not a viable</b> fetus, <b>she</b> retains <b>her presumptive status, and</b> therefore <b>her time is sufficient</b> from that flow of blood, i.e., it renders her impure only from then on, not retroactively, as even a non-viable fetus gives her full pregnancy status.
<b>And even though there is no</b> explicit <b>proof for</b> this <b>matter,</b> that even a pregnancy that ends in a miscarriage is like a full-fledged pregnancy, there is <b>an allusion to the matter, as it is stated: “We have been with child, we have been in pain, we have as it were brought forth wind”</b> (Isaiah 26:18). This verse indicates that even one who miscarries wind is considered as having been with child. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the reason that this is called a mere <b>allusion to the matter?</b> This explicit verse <b>is a significant proof.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>When that verse was written,</b> it was <b>written with regard to males</b> as bearing children. The allusion to child-bearing in the verse is symbolic, so halakhic inferences may not be drawn from it.
<b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: If a woman experienced <b>labor</b> pain for <b>two</b> days, during which she saw a discharge of blood, <b>and on the third</b> day <b>she miscarried air or anything that is not a viable</b> fetus, <b>that</b> woman <b>gives birth as a <i>zava</i>,</b> and the blood is treated as blood of a <i>zava</i> in all regards. The Gemara explains the contradiction: <b>And if you say</b> that miscarrying a non-viable fetus <b>is</b> considered <b>a proper birth,</b> this is problematic,

Daf 9a

as with regard to blood emitted while experiencing <b>labor</b> pain <b>close to</b> the time of a proper <b>birth, the Merciful One deems it pure,</b> and it should not be treated as the blood of a <i>zava</i>. <b>Rav Pappi says:</b> The miscarriage is not considered a proper birth and therefore her blood is considered the blood of a <i>zava</i>. And <b>leave</b> aside the first <i>baraita</i> and do not raise a contradiction from it, as the <i>halakha</i> that a woman who sees menstrual blood is retroactively impure <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period,</b> which is the topic under discussion in that <i>baraita</i>, applies <b>by rabbinic law,</b> and they did not impose this stringency in the case of a woman who miscarries.
<b>Rav Pappa says: That reason</b> for the <i>halakha</i> that a pregnant woman is not retroactively impure when she experiences bleeding is <b>only because her head and limbs</b> feel <b>heavy to her.</b> Her physical state is compromised, which also causes her regular menstrual cycle to cease. <b>Here, too,</b> in the case of a pregnancy that precedes a miscarriage, even if it is not considered a proper birth, <b>her head and limbs</b> felt <b>heavy to her</b> during her pregnancy, and therefore it can be assumed that she did not experience a prior menstrual flow.
With regard to the mishna’s ruling that the time of a pregnant woman is sufficient, <b>Rabbi Yirmeya asked Rabbi Zeira:</b> If <b>she saw</b> blood <b>and</b> only <b>afterward her fetus became known</b> to all who see her, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? One can claim that <b>since at the time when she saw</b> the blood <b>her fetus was not</b> yet <b>known,</b> therefore she <b>becomes impure; or perhaps, since she saw</b> blood <b>in close</b> proximity <b>to</b> the time that her fetus became known, she does <b>not become impure.</b>
Rabbi Zeira <b>said to him: That reason</b> for the <i>halakha</i> that a pregnant woman’s time is sufficient is <b>only because her head and limbs</b> feel <b>heavy to her.</b> In this case, where she was yet unaware of her pregnancy <b>at the time when she saw</b> her menstrual flow, <b>neither her head nor her limbs</b> felt <b>heavy to her.</b> Therefore she is impure retroactively, like any other woman.
§ <b>A certain elder asked Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> If the <b>time</b> of a woman’s fixed menstrual <b>cycle arrived during her pregnancy and she did not perform an examination, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>I raise</b> this <b>dilemma</b> only <b>according to</b> the opinion <b>of the one who said</b> that the obligation for a woman to perform a self-examination during her fixed menstrual <b>cycle</b> applies <b>by Torah law. What</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? According to that opinion, one can claim that <b>since</b> the obligation of an examination during one’s fixed menstrual <b>cycle</b> is <b>by Torah law,</b> she is <b>required</b> to perform <b>an examination</b> even during her pregnancy. <b>Or perhaps, since her blood has stopped,</b> as a pregnant woman generally does not experience a flow of menstrual blood, she is <b>not required</b> to perform <b>an examination.</b>
Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him: You learned</b> the answer to your dilemma from a mishna (39a): <b>Rabbi Meir says: If</b> a woman <b>was in hiding</b> from danger, <b>and the time of her</b> fixed menstrual <b>cycle came and she did not examine</b> herself, nevertheless she is <b>ritually pure, as</b> it may be assumed that she did not experience bleeding because <b>fear dispels</b> the flow of menstrual <b>blood.</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan explains the proof: The <b>reason</b> she is pure is <b>that there is fear,</b> from which it may be inferred that in a case where <b>there is no fear and the time of her</b> fixed menstrual <b>cycle arrived and she did not examine</b> herself, she would be <b>impure.</b>
Rabbi Yoḥanan concludes: <b>Evidently,</b> from the fact that Rabbi Meir rules that a woman is impure if the time of her period passed without a proper examination, he maintains that the obligation for a woman to perform an examination at the time of her fixed menstrual <b>cycle</b> applies <b>by Torah law. And,</b> nevertheless, <b>since there is fear, her blood has stopped and</b> she is <b>not required</b> to perform <b>an examination. Here, too,</b> in the case of a pregnant woman, <b>her blood has stopped and</b> therefore she is <b>not required</b> to perform <b>an examination.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: The time of <b>a nursing woman</b> is sufficient <b>until she weans</b> her child from nursing. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (see <i>Tosefta</i> 2:1): With regard to <b>a nursing woman whose child dies within twenty-four months</b> of his birth, <b>she is like all</b> other <b>women</b> with regard to her impurity status after seeing menstrual blood, <b>and</b> therefore <b>she transmits ritual impurity</b> retroactively <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period or from examination to examination. Therefore, if</b> a woman <b>continued to nurse</b> her child <b>for four or five years, her time is sufficient</b> and she does not retroactively transmit impurity for the entire four or five years. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon</b> all <b>say:</b> With regard to nursing women, <b>their time is sufficient</b> for <b>an entire twenty-four months. Therefore, if she nursed him for four or five years,</b> then after the first twenty-four months have passed, <b>she transmits ritual impurity</b> retroactively <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period or from examination to examination.</b>
The Gemara discusses the reasoning of each opinion: <b>When</b> you analyze the matter <b>you will find</b> that one must <b>say that according to the statement of Rabbi Meir</b> the case is that menstrual <b>blood spoils and becomes milk.</b> Therefore, it follows that this status continues for as long as she is nursing. By contrast, <b>according to the statement of Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon, her limbs become dislocated and her spirit,</b> i.e., her full strength and her regular menstrual cycle, <b>does not return</b> to her <b>until twenty-four months</b> have passed.
The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need the statement <b>of Rabbi Meir: Therefore,</b> if a woman continued to nurse her child for four or five years, her time is sufficient? Since his reasoning is that the menstrual blood of a nursing woman spoils and becomes milk, it is obvious that this applies as long as she continues to nurse him. The Gemara answers: This statement is indeed extraneous. It merely serves to form a parallel between the statement of Rabbi Meir and that of the other Sages. In other words, it was appended <b>due to</b> the statement: <b>Therefore,</b> if she was nursing him for four or five years, then after the first twenty-four months have passed, she transmits ritual impurity retroactively for a twenty-four-hour period or from examination to examination, which is referring to the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yosei.</b>
The Gemara further asks: <b>And why do I</b> need the statement: <b>Therefore,</b> if she was nursing him for four or five years, then after the first twenty-four months have passed, she transmits ritual impurity retroactively for a twenty-four-hour period or from examination to examination, which is referring to the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yosei?</b> The Gemara explains that this clause is necessary, <b>lest you say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yosei holds</b> that there are <b>two</b> reasons that a pregnant woman’s time is sufficient, both because her blood spoils and because her limbs become dislocated. Therefore, the additional clause <b>teaches us</b> that Rabbi Yosei maintains that the reason is only that her limbs become dislocated, and consequently she transmits retroactive impurity after twenty-four months.
<b>That</b> explanation <b>is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Menstrual <b>blood spoils and becomes milk;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yosei says: Her limbs become dislocated and her spirit does not return to her until twenty-four months</b> have passed. The Gemara analyzes their respective reasons. <b>Rabbi Ilai says: What is the reason of Rabbi Meir?</b> It is based upon a verse, <b>as it is written: “Who can bring a pure thing out of an impure?</b> Is it <b>not the One?”</b> (Job 14:4). In other words, is it not true that the One, i.e., God, can bring a pure thing, such as milk, out of an impure thing, such as menstrual blood?
