The Gemara asks: <b>And the</b> other <b>Sages,</b> i.e., Rabbi Yosei, Rabbi Yehuda, and Rabbi Shimon, how do they interpret this verse? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that according to those Sages <b>this</b> verse is referring to <b>semen, which is impure, and</b> yet <b>the person that is formed from it is pure.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Elazar says:</b> Those Sages maintain that this verse is referring to <b>the water of sprinkling,</b> i.e., the purification water mixed with the ashes of the red heifer. <b>As</b> the individual who <b>sprinkles</b> the water and the one <b>upon whom</b> the water is <b>sprinkled</b> are both <b>pure, and</b> yet one who <b>touches</b> the purification water is rendered <b>impure.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Is</b> the <b>one who sprinkles</b> the water actually <b>pure? But isn’t it written: “He who sprinkles the water of sprinkling will wash his clothes,</b> and he who touches the water of sprinkling will be impure until evening” (Numbers 19:21)? The Gemara responds: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the term: <b>“He who sprinkles”?</b> It means: <b>He who touches.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But it is written: “He who sprinkles,” and it is written</b> in the same verse: “And <b>he who touches.”</b> How can these two terms be referring to the same individual? <b>And furthermore,</b> that verse states that <b>one who sprinkles requires</b> the <b>washing</b> of his <b>clothes,</b> indicating a severe level of impurity, whereas <b>one who touches does not require</b> the <b>washing</b> of his <b>clothes.</b> Evidently, the phrase “he who sprinkles” is not referring to one who touches. <b>Rather,</b> the Gemara explains: <b>What</b> is the meaning of: <b>“He who sprinkles”?</b> This is referring to <b>one who carries</b> the purification waters.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, <b>let</b> the Torah <b>write</b> explicitly: <b>One who carries.</b> Why does it state “he who sprinkles” when it is referring to carrying? The Gemara answers: The use of the term sprinkling in reference to carrying <b>teaches us</b> that one becomes impure <b>only by carrying</b> the <b>measure</b> required for <b>sprinkling.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to the one who said</b> that <b>sprinkling requires</b> a minimum <b>measure</b> of water. <b>But according to the one who said</b> that <b>sprinkling does not require</b> a minimum <b>measure</b> of water, <b>what can be said?</b> According to this opinion, there is apparently no concept of a measure required for sprinkling.
The Gemara answers: <b>Even according to the one who said</b> that <b>sprinkling does not require</b> a minimum <b>measure</b> of water, <b>that statement</b> applies only to the measure of purification water that must be sprinkled <b>onto the back,</b> i.e., onto the body, <b>of</b> the impure <b>man.</b> In this regard, any amount will suffice. <b>But with regard to the vessel</b> into which one dips the hyssop in order to sprinkle the water, it <b>requires</b> a certain <b>measure</b> of water. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Para</i> 12:5): <b>How much</b> water must <b>be in</b> the vessel so that it <b>will be enough for sprinkling?</b> It must be <b>enough to dip the tops of the stems</b> of the hyssop branch, used in the rite of purification, into the water <b>and sprinkle</b> it.
The Gemara concludes the discussion of the purification waters with the following observation: <b>And that is</b> the meaning of that <b>which</b> King <b>Solomon said: “I said I would become wise, but it eludes me”</b> (Ecclesiastes 7:23). According to tradition, even Solomon in his great wisdom could not understand the contradictory nature of the sprinkling of purification water, as it renders an impure person pure, and a pure person impure.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>Who is</b> the woman characterized as <b>an elderly woman</b> in this context? It is <b>any</b> woman for <b>whom three</b> typical menstrual <b>cycles</b> of thirty days <b>passed</b> at a stage of her life <b>close to her old age,</b> during which she saw no menstrual blood. The Gemara asks: <b>What is considered close to old age? Rav Yehuda says: Any</b> woman <b>about whom her friends say</b> that <b>she is an elderly woman. And Rabbi Shimon says:</b>

Daf 9b

It is <b>any</b> woman who is old enough <b>that</b> people <b>call her: Mother [<i>Imma</i>], Mother, and she is not embarrassed. Rabbi Zeira and Rabbi Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak</b> disagree with regard to this matter. <b>One says</b> that the definition is <b>any</b> woman <b>who does not take offense</b> about being called: Mother, Mother. <b>And</b> the other <b>one says</b> that it is <b>any</b> woman <b>who is not embarrassed</b> by this. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the difference between</b> their definitions? The Gemara answers: The practical difference <b>between</b> them is in a case where a woman is <b>embarrassed but she does not take offense</b> when called: Mother.
The Gemara asks: <b>And how long</b> is a typical menstrual <b>cycle? Reish Lakish says in the name of Rabbi Yehuda Nesia:</b> The <b>average</b> menstrual <b>cycle</b> is <b>thirty days</b> long. <b>And Rava says</b> that <b>Rav Ḥisda</b> says: It is <b>twenty days.</b> The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> they <b>do not disagree.</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rav Yehuda Nesia, <b>counts</b> all the days of her cycle, including the <b>days of impurity and days of purity. And</b> the other <b>Sage,</b> Rav Ḥisda, <b>does not count</b> the <b>days of impurity,</b> i.e., the seven days of impurity of a menstruating woman and the three days of the sighting of <i>ziva</i>.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>an elderly woman</b> for <b>whom three</b> typical menstrual <b>cycles</b> of thirty days <b>passed and</b> then <b>she saw</b> a discharge of menstrual blood, <b>her time is sufficient. And</b> if <b>a further three</b> typical menstrual <b>cycles</b> of thirty days <b>passed for her and she</b> subsequently <b>saw</b> a discharge of menstrual blood, <b>her time is sufficient. And</b> if yet <b>a further three</b> typical menstrual <b>cycles</b> of thirty days <b>passed for her and</b> then <b>she saw</b> a discharge of menstrual blood, after this third time <b>she is</b> now <b>like all</b> normal <b>women,</b> and she <b>transmits impurity</b> retroactively <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period or from examination to examination.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And it is not necessary</b> to teach this <i>halakha</i> in a case <b>where she</b> experienced the three sightings in <b>even</b> intervals of ninety days, as in such a case it is obvious that she assumes the status of a normal woman who transmits impurity retroactively. <b>Rather, even if she</b> had intervals where she <b>decreased,</b> i.e., experienced bleeding at intervals smaller than that, <b>or even if she increased</b> and experienced bleeding at greater intervals, she still assumes the status of a woman who transmits impurity retroactively.
The Gemara infers: The wording of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Even if she</b> had intervals where she <b>decreased,</b> indicates that <b>it is not necessary</b> to teach the <i>halakha</i> in the case of a woman who experienced bleeding at <b>even</b> intervals. This is puzzling, as <b>on the contrary, if she</b> experienced bleeding at <b>even</b> intervals she thereby <b>fixes her</b> menstrual <b>cycle</b> as being every thirty days, <b>and</b> according to Rabbi Dosa (4b) the <i>halakha</i> is that <b>her time is sufficient.</b>
<b>And if you would say</b> that this <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, who disagree with Rabbi Dosa, as they say</b> that <b>a woman who has</b> a fixed menstrual <b>cycle transmits impurity</b> retroactively <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period,</b> then the <i>baraita</i> <b>should have</b> been written in the <b>opposite</b> fashion: <b>Let</b> it <b>say: And</b> the <i>halakha</i> that an elderly woman who sees menstrual blood at intervals returns to the status of normal women and transmits impurity retroactively applies <b>not</b> only to a case where she had intervals where <b>she decreased or increased,</b> i.e., she experienced bleeding less or more than ninety days apart, <b>but</b> this <i>halakha</i> applies <b>even</b> if she experienced bleeding at <b>even</b> intervals.
The Gemara answers: <b>Teach</b> in the <i>baraita</i> in accordance with this altered version: <b>And</b> the <i>halakha</i> applies <b>not</b> only to a case where she had intervals where <b>she decreased or increased, but</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even</b> if she experienced bleeding at <b>even</b> intervals. <b>And if you wish say</b> instead that <b>this</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> The <i>halakha</i> that an elderly woman is retroactively impure does <b>not</b> apply to a case when she saw menstrual blood at <b>even</b> intervals. <b>Rather,</b> it applies only if <b>she decreased or increased,</b> i.e., she experienced bleeding at intervals less or more than ninety days apart. <b>But</b> if she saw blood at <b>even</b> intervals, she thereby <b>fixes</b> a set menstrual <b>cycle</b> of ninety days and her time is sufficient. The Gemara adds: <b>And</b> if so, in accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is this <i>baraita</i>? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Dosa.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> With regard to <b>any woman</b> for <b>whom</b> three typical menstrual cycles <b>passed</b> during which she saw no menstrual blood, if she experiences bleeding, her time is sufficient. Rabbi Yosei says: In the case of a pregnant woman and a nursing woman for whom three menstrual cycles passed during which they saw no menstrual blood, if she then saw blood her time is sufficient. Rabbi Eliezer cites a proof for his opinion. It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: There was <b>an incident involving a certain girl in</b> the village of <b>Hitlo who stopped</b> menstruating <b>for three</b> typical menstrual <b>cycles,</b> after which she experienced menstruation. <b>And the matter came before the Sages, and they said</b> that <b>her time is sufficient</b> and she does not transmit impurity retroactively.
The other Sages <b>said to</b> Rabbi Eliezer: Decisions rendered <b>in exigent circumstances are no proof.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> were the <b>exigent circumstances? Some say</b> that <b>it was</b> during the <b>years of famine,</b> and <b>some say</b> that the girl had <b>handled many ritually pure</b> items <b>and the Sages were concerned for the loss</b> of those <b>pure</b> items if they were ruled retroactively impure.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: There was <b>an incident</b> in which <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>acted</b> by ruling that the <i>halakha</i> <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer. After he remembered</b> that Rabbi Eliezer’s colleagues disagree with him on this matter and that he had apparently ruled incorrectly, <b>he</b> nevertheless <b>said: Rabbi Eliezer is worthy to rely upon in exigent circumstances.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of: <b>After he remembered? If we say</b> that this means <b>after he remembered</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, but in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> if so, <b>how could he act in accordance with</b> Rabbi Eliezer even <b>in exigent circumstances,</b> since the <i>halakha</i> has been decided against him?
<b>Rather,</b> one must say <b>that</b> the <b><i>halakha</i></b> had <b>not been stated</b> on this matter, <b>neither in accordance with</b> the opinion of this <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Eliezer, <b>nor in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>that Sage,</b> the Rabbis. <b>And what</b> is the meaning of: <b>After he remembered? After</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>remembered that it was not a lone</b> authority who <b>disagrees with</b> Rabbi Eliezer, <b>but</b> it was several Sages who <b>disagreed with him,</b> and there is a principle that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of the many over the opinion of an individual, he nevertheless <b>said: Rabbi Eliezer is worthy to rely upon in exigent circumstances.</b>
The Gemara continues the discussion of a woman who fails to experience menstruation for three typical menstrual cycles. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a young girl,</b> less than twelve years old, <b>whose time to see</b> the flow of menstrual blood <b>has not arrived and she saw</b> menstrual blood, after the <b>first time her time is sufficient.</b> After the <b>second time,</b> again <b>her time is sufficient.</b> After the <b>third time, she is like all</b> normal adult <b>women, and</b> therefore <b>she transmits impurity</b> retroactively <b>for</b> a twenty-four<b>-</b>hour <b>period or from examination to examination.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: If she then <b>passed three</b> expected menstrual <b>cycles</b> without experiencing bleeding, <b>and</b> then <b>she saw</b> menstrual blood, she returns to the status of a young girl and <b>her time is sufficient. And</b> if it <b>further</b> happens that she again <b>passed three</b> expected menstrual <b>cycles</b> without experiencing bleeding, <b>and</b> then <b>she saw</b> menstrual <b>blood, her time is sufficient. And</b> if she <b>passed three further cycles</b> without experiencing bleeding, and <b>she</b> subsequently <b>saw</b> menstrual <b>blood, she is like all</b> normal adult <b>women.</b> She is considered a woman who experiences regular menstruation at long intervals with breaks of ninety days. <b>And</b> therefore <b>she transmits impurity</b> retroactively <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period or from examination to examination.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> concludes: <b>And</b> with regard to a girl <b>whose time to see</b> the flow of menstrual blood <b>has arrived,</b> i.e., she has reached the age of twelve, when she sees menstrual blood for the <b>first time, her time is sufficient.</b> After the <b>second</b> time, <b>she transmits impurity</b> retroactively <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period or from examination to examination.</b> If <b>three</b> menstrual <b>cycles</b> then <b>passed</b> without her experiencing bleeding, <b>and</b> afterward <b>she saw</b> menstrual <b>blood, her time is sufficient.</b> This is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer, who holds that any woman who passed three expected menstrual cycles without experiencing bleeding is presumed not to be menstruating.
<b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: If the young girl who had started menstruating <b>passed three</b> expected menstrual <b>cycles</b> without experiencing bleeding and then saw menstrual blood, she returns to the status of a young girl and <b>her time is sufficient.</b>

Daf 10a

The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> if she <b>then sees</b> menstrual blood <b>at</b> regular intervals of thirty-day <b>cycles?</b> Is her time sufficient, or does she transmit impurity retroactively? <b>Rav Giddel says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> With regard to the <b>first time and</b> the <b>second</b> time that she sees menstrual blood, <b>her time is sufficient.</b> After the <b>third</b> time, <b>she transmits impurity</b> retroactively <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period or from examination to examination.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> further teaches, with regard to a young girl who did not experience bleeding for three typical cycles and then saw blood, <b>and three further</b> expected menstrual <b>cycles passed</b> without her experiencing bleeding <b>and</b> then afterward <b>she saw</b> menstrual <b>blood,</b> that <b>her time is sufficient.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> if she <b>then sees</b> menstrual blood <b>at</b> regular intervals of thirty-day <b>cycles?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Kahana says</b> that <b>Rav Giddel says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> The <b>first time</b> that she sees menstrual blood, <b>her time is sufficient.</b> After the <b>second</b> time, <b>she transmits impurity</b> retroactively <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period or from examination to examination.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Who is</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i>? The Gemara answers: Since the <i>baraita</i> teaches that she attains the status of a regular adult woman upon the third sighting of menstrual blood, apparently it is <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>who said</b> that <b>presumption is</b> established <b>by two occasions.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Say the latter clause:</b> If she then <b>passed three</b> expected menstrual <b>cycles</b> without experiencing bleeding, <b>and</b> then <b>she saw</b> menstrual blood, she returns to the status of a young girl and <b>her time is sufficient.</b> In this ruling <b>we come to the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer,</b> who holds that any woman who passed three expected menstrual cycles without experiencing bleeding is presumed not to be menstruating and her time is sufficient. Is the <i>baraita</i> in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi or Rabbi Eliezer?
<b>And if you would say</b> that the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>is Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>and in</b> the case of a woman who passes three menstrual <b>cycles</b> without experiencing bleeding, he <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, but does he</b> really <b>hold</b> in accordance with <b>this</b> opinion? Doesn’t the <i>baraita</i> <b>state</b> that <b>after</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>remembered</b> that several authorities disagreed with the ruling of Rabbi Eliezer, he said: Rabbi Eliezer is worthy to rely upon in exigent circumstances, i.e., only in exigent circumstances. The Gemara concludes: <b>Rather,</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>is Rabbi Eliezer, and with regard to</b> menstrual <b>cycles</b> he <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi,</b> that a presumptive cycle is established after two occasions of seeing menstrual blood.
§ With regard to a young girl who was just starting to menstruate, the Gemara states: If she finds a blood <b>stain between</b> the <b>first</b> and <b>second</b> time that she sees menstrual blood, she is <b>pure.</b> If it is <b>between</b> the <b>second and</b> the <b>third</b> time, <b>Ḥizkiyya says:</b> She is <b>impure; Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> She is <b>pure.</b> The Gemara explains the reasoning behind their respective opinions. <b>Ḥizkiyya says:</b> She is <b>impure, since if she had seen</b> menstrual blood it would <b>render her impure.</b> Consequently, her blood <b>stain is also impure. And Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> She is <b>pure, since she has not</b> yet attained the <b>presumptive status of</b> one who sees menstrual <b>blood.</b> Therefore, <b>we also do not render her impure</b> on account of <b>her</b> blood <b>stain.</b>

Daf 10b

<b>Rabbi Ilai objects to this</b> ruling of Ḥizkiyya: <b>And what</b> is the difference <b>between this</b> case of a girl who has not yet started menstruating <b>and</b> a recently married menstrual <b>virgin whose</b> stain is deemed pure for as long <b>as her blood is pure,</b> since the stain is presumed to be from her torn hymen? <b>Rabbi Zeira said</b> to him: With regard to <b>this</b> menstrual virgin, <b>her secretion [<i>sirfah</i>] is common,</b> i.e., blood from her torn hymen is normally found during this period. Therefore, any blood stain that is found is also assumed to be from her hymen. <b>But</b> in the case of <b>this</b> young girl, <b>her secretion is not common.</b> Therefore, if a blood stain is found, it is assumed to be menstrual blood.
§ <b>Ulla says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Yehotzadak:</b> With regard to <b>a young girl whose time to see</b> the flow of menstrual blood <b>has not arrived and she saw</b> menstrual blood <b>one time and</b> then <b>a second</b> time, but not the third time that would render her a woman who regularly sees menstrual blood, <b>her saliva and her</b> garment that she <b>treads</b> upon that are found <b>in the marketplace</b> are <b>pure</b> if we do not know whether she has menstruated. Likewise, <b>her</b> blood <b>stain</b> is <b>also pure.</b> Ulla added: <b>And I do not know if</b> this ruling with regard to the stain is merely Rabbi Yoḥanan’s own conclusion <b>or</b> if that is also part of the opinion <b>of his teacher.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What difference is</b> there? That is, what does it matter who said it? The Gemara explains: It makes a difference <b>for it to be</b> considered the <b>statement of one</b> Sage <b>in the place of two</b> dissenting opinions. As stated above, Ḥizkiyya disagrees with this ruling and maintains that a young girl’s blood stain is impure after she sees menstrual blood twice. If this statement is both Rabbi Shimon ben Yehotzadak’s opinion and that of Rabbi Yoḥanan, then Ḥizkiyya’s ruling is opposed by two Sages, which means that his is a minority opinion. If it is Rabbi Yoḥanan’s opinion alone, then the two sides are equal, with one Sage maintaining each opinion.
<b>When Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia along with <b>all the seafarers [<i>naḥotei yamma</i>], they stated</b> this ruling <b>as</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yehotzadak.</b> If so, Rabbi Yoḥanan was relating his own opinion, which echoed that of his teacher, Rabbi Shimon ben Yehotzadak, and therefore the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with this majority opinion.
§ <b>Rav Ḥilkiya bar Tovi says:</b> With regard to <b>a young girl whose time to see</b> menstrual blood <b>has not arrived, even</b> if she <b>continuously discharges</b> menstrual blood <b>for all seven</b> days of a typical menstrual period, it is considered as <b>only one sighting</b> of blood and she remains in the category of one who lacks blood until she sees menstrual blood twice more. The Gemara asks: Why did Rav Ḥilkiya bar Tovi stress: <b>Even</b> if she <b>continuously discharges</b> menstrual blood, which indicates that <b>it is not necessary</b> to teach that this is the <i>halakha</i> if she <b>stops</b> seeing a discharge and then starts again? <b>On the contrary,</b> if she <b>stops</b> and restarts <b>it is as</b> though she has had <b>two sightings</b> of menstrual blood.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rather,</b> this is what Rav Ḥilkiya bar Tovi meant: With regard to <b>a young girl whose time to see</b> menstrual blood <b>has not arrived, and</b> she then <b>continuously discharges</b> menstrual blood <b>for all seven</b> days of a typical menstrual period, it is considered as <b>only one sighting</b> of blood. In other words, he did not state the word: Even.
<b>Rav Shimi bar Ḥiyya says:</b> The case of woman who constantly <b>drips</b> menstrual blood is <b>not</b> considered <b>like</b> a full <b>sighting</b> of blood. The Gemara expresses surprise at this claim: <b>But</b> she <b>saw</b> blood. The Gemara answers: <b>Say</b> that what Rav Shimi bar Ḥiyya meant was that she is <b>not</b> considered <b>like</b> one who <b>continuously discharges</b> blood, but <b>rather like</b> one who <b>stops</b> and starts again, even if she drips constantly.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>From the fact</b> that Rav Shimi bar Ḥiyya claims that a different <i>halakha</i> applies to a woman who constantly drips menstrual blood, it can be inferred <b>that</b> the blood of one who <b>continuously discharges</b> menstrual blood streams <b>like a river</b> for seven days. But this is physically impossible. The Gemara explains: <b>Rather, say</b> that Rav Shimi bar Ḥiyya meant that the status of a woman who constantly drips menstrual blood is <b>nothing other than</b> the status <b>of</b> a woman who <b>continuously discharges</b> blood. In both cases, it is all considered as one sighting.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The <b>presumption</b> with regard to the <b>daughters of Israel</b> is that <b>until they have reached their</b> physical <b>maturity they have</b> the <b>presumptive status of ritual purity, and</b> adult <b>women do not</b> need to <b>examine them</b> to check if they are ritually pure before they handle consecrated items or <i>teruma</i>. <b>Once they have reached their</b> physical <b>maturity, they have</b> the <b>presumptive status of ritual impurity,</b> due to the possibility of an unnoticed menstrual discharge, <b>and</b> if they are still minors, adult <b>women</b> must <b>examine them</b> to check if they are ritually pure.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says: They should not examine them by hand, because that</b> is likely to scratch them and <b>ruin their</b> status, as it will be assumed that they are ritually impure with menstrual blood. <b>Rather,</b> they <b>should smear them with oil inside and wipe them</b> off <b>on the outside. And</b> through this method <b>they are automatically examined,</b> i.e., if at that age they are ready to menstruate, the oil will cause the blood to flow.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> With regard to <b>a pregnant woman</b> and a nursing woman for whom three expected menstrual cycles passed during which they saw no menstrual blood, if she then saw blood, her time is sufficient. <b>A <i>tanna</i> taught</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>before Rabbi Elazar: Rabbi Yosei says:</b> With regard to <b>a pregnant woman and a nursing woman for whom three</b> expected menstrual <b>cycles passed</b> during which they saw no menstrual blood, if she then experienced bleeding <b>her time is sufficient.</b> Rabbi Elazar <b>said to him:</b> The structure of your <i>baraita</i> is inconsistent. <b>You opened with two</b> categories of women: A pregnant woman and a nursing woman, <b>and you ended</b> your quote <b>with one,</b> as you concluded in the singular form: Her time is sufficient.
Rabbi Elazar continued: <b>Perhaps you are saying</b> that this is a case of <b>a pregnant woman who was also nursing. And</b> if so, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us a matter in passing, that</b> with regard to tallying three menstrual cycles in which she saw no menstrual blood, <b>her days of pregnancy count</b> toward, i.e., combine with, <b>her days of nursing and her days of nursing count</b> toward <b>her days of pregnancy. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Her days of pregnancy count</b> toward <b>her days of nursing and her days of nursing count</b> toward <b>her days of pregnancy.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>How so?</b> If a woman <b>stopped</b> seeing menstrual blood for <b>two</b> expected menstrual cycles <b>during her days of pregnancy and</b> then for <b>one</b> more cycle <b>during her days of nursing,</b> or she passed <b>two</b> expected menstrual cycles <b>during her days of nursing and one</b> more <b>during her days of pregnancy,</b> or <b>one and a half</b> cycles <b>during her days of pregnancy and one and a half</b> cycles <b>during her days of nursing,</b> in all these cases the missed cycles spanning her pregnancy and nursing <b>combine to</b> a total of <b>three</b> missed <b>cycles,</b> and therefore her time is sufficient.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> with regard to the claim that <b>her days of pregnancy count</b> toward <b>her days of nursing, you</b> can <b>find it</b> in a case where <b>she was nursing continuously and</b> then she <b>became pregnant. But</b> the scenario mentioned in the <i>baraita</i> where <b>her days of nursing count</b> toward <b>her days of pregnancy, how can you find these</b> circumstances? Since she certainly experienced bleeding when she gave birth, how can there be three consecutive menstrual cycles where she did not experience any discharge of blood?
The Gemara provides several answers: <b>If you wish, say</b> that it is referring to a case <b>of a dry birth,</b> i.e., one without any discharge of blood. Or, <b>if you wish, say:</b> The <b>blood</b> of <b>a menstruating woman</b> is <b>discrete and</b> the <b>blood</b> seen during <b>birth</b> is <b>discrete.</b> Blood seen during birth does not disrupt the count of menstrual cycles during which a woman does not see menstrual blood. Therefore, the cycles before and after the birth combine to form the requisite three cycles according to Rabbi Eliezer. <b>Or, if you wish, say: Teach</b> only <b>one</b> of these scenarios. In other words, teach only the case where the days of pregnancy count toward the days of nursing, but not the case where the days of nursing count toward the days of pregnancy.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And with regard to what</b> did <b>they say</b> that <b>her time is sufficient?</b> It is with regard to the first sighting of blood. But with regard to the second sighting, her status is like that of any other woman and she transmits impurity for a twenty-four-hour period or from her last examination. The Gemara inquires concerning which case this clause is referring to. <b>Rav says:</b> This qualification is stated <b>with regard to all of them,</b> i.e., all four cases of the mishna: The menstrual virgin, the elderly woman, the pregnant woman, and the nursing woman.
<b>And Shmuel says: They taught</b> it <b>only</b> with regard to a menstrual <b>virgin and an elderly woman. But</b> in the case of <b>a pregnant woman and a nursing woman, their</b> time is <b>sufficient</b> for <b>all their days of pregnancy and their</b> time is <b>sufficient</b> for <b>all their days of nursing.</b>
The Gemara notes that another pair of Sages had the same dispute. <b>And similarly, Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says:</b> This qualification applies <b>to all of them; and Rabbi Yoḥanan says: They taught</b> it <b>only</b> with regard to a menstrual <b>virgin and an elderly woman. But</b> in the case of a <b>pregnant woman and a nursing woman, their</b> time is <b>sufficient</b> for <b>all their days of pregnancy and their</b> time is <b>sufficient</b> for <b>all their days of nursing.</b> The Gemara suggests: This is <b>like</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i></b> in the following <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a pregnant woman and a nursing woman who were</b>

Daf 11a

<b>continuously discharging</b> menstrual <b>blood, their</b> time is <b>sufficient</b> for <b>all their days of pregnancy and their</b> time is <b>sufficient</b> for <b>all their days of nursing.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon</b> all <b>say: They said</b> that <b>her time is sufficient only with regard to</b> the <b>first sighting</b> of blood, <b>but with regard to the second</b> sighting, her status is like that of any other woman, and she <b>transmits impurity for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period or from examination to examination.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And if she saw</b> the <b>first</b> sighting as a result of unnatural circumstances, then even with regard to the second sighting her time is sufficient. <b>Rav Huna says:</b> If she <b>jumped and saw</b> menstrual blood, and again she <b>jumped and saw</b> menstrual blood, and a third time she <b>jumped and saw</b> menstrual blood, she has <b>established a fixed</b> menstrual <b>cycle.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>For what</b> occurrence has she established a fixed cycle? <b>If we say</b> that it is a cycle <b>of days</b> alone, <b>this</b> cannot be correct, <b>as every day that she did not jump,</b> she also <b>did not see</b> menstrual blood. Therefore, her cycle cannot be a mere pattern of days.
The Gemara explains: <b>Rather,</b> the established menstrual cycle is caused <b>by jumps,</b> i.e., by observing a pattern of jumping and seeing blood three times, she has established that jumping causes the onset of her menstrual period. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Any</b> woman who <b>establishes</b> a pattern of seeing menstrual blood <b>due to</b> a recurring <b>accident,</b> even if the pattern repeats, still has <b>not established a fixed</b> menstrual <b>cycle?</b> An accidental menstrual pattern brought about by external causes does not create a menstrual cycle. The Gemara explains the difficulty: <b>What, is it not</b> correct to say that the <i>baraita</i> means that she has <b>not established a fixed</b> menstrual <b>cycle at all?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> the <i>baraita</i> means that she has <b>not established a fixed</b> menstrual <b>cycle of days alone, nor of jumps alone, but</b> she has <b>established a fixed</b> menstrual <b>cycle for</b> a combination of <b>days and of jumps.</b> In other words, she has established a fixed menstrual cycle when she jumps on specific days. The Gemara asks: Isn’t it <b>obvious</b> that she does not establish a cycle <b>for days alone?</b> Why is it necessary to state this? <b>Rav Ashi says:</b> It is necessary to teach this in a case <b>where</b> she <b>jumped on Sunday and saw</b> menstrual blood, <b>and</b> again she <b>jumped on Sunday and saw</b> menstrual blood, <b>and</b> then <b>on</b> the following <b>Shabbat she jumped and did not see</b> blood, <b>but on Sunday,</b> the next day, <b>she saw</b> menstrual blood <b>without jumping.</b>
Rav Ashi explains: <b>Lest you say</b> that the <b>matter</b> is <b>revealed retroactively that it</b> was <b>the day that caused</b> her to experience menstruation <b>and</b> not the <b>jumping,</b> and therefore she has established a menstrual cycle of menstruating on Sundays, regardless of jumping, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us that</b> it was <b>also</b> the jumping <b>of yesterday,</b> on Shabbat, that <b>caused</b> the menstruation today, on Sunday. <b>And</b> as for the fact <b>that she did not see</b> menstrual blood then, that was <b>because the time</b> when <b>jumping</b> causes menstruation had <b>not</b> yet <b>arrived.</b>
The Gemara presents <b>another version</b> of Rav Huna’s statement. <b>Rav Huna says:</b> If a woman <b>jumped and saw</b> menstrual blood, and again she <b>jumped and saw</b> menstrual blood, and a third time she <b>jumped and saw</b> menstrual blood, she has <b>established a fixed</b> menstrual <b>cycle for</b> a pattern of <b>days and not for</b> a pattern of <b>jumps.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances? Rav Ashi says:</b> This is referring to a case <b>where</b> she <b>jumped on Sunday and saw</b> menstrual blood, <b>and</b> then again she <b>jumped on Sunday and saw</b> menstrual blood, <b>and</b> then <b>on</b> the following <b>Shabbat she jumped and did not see</b> blood, <b>but on Sunday,</b> the next day, <b>she saw</b> menstrual blood <b>without jumping.</b> In that case <b>there,</b> the <b>matter</b> is <b>revealed retroactively</b> that it is <b>the day that causes</b> her to menstruate, not the jumping.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Although</b> the Rabbis <b>said</b> that for a woman with a fixed menstrual cycle <b>her time is sufficient</b> and she does not transmit impurity retroactively, <b>she is required to examine herself</b> each day to ensure that she is ritually pure and will not impurify pure items that she is handling. All women must examine themselves each day <b>except for a menstruating woman,</b> whose impure status is known, <b>and</b> a woman after childbirth <b>who is observing</b> the period of the <b>blood of purity,</b> whose ritually pure status is known even if she experiences bleeding.
<b>And</b> even a woman with a fixed menstrual cycle <b>engages in intercourse while</b> using <b>examination cloths</b> to ascertain whether her menstrual flow began, <b>except for</b> a woman after childbirth <b>who is observing</b> the period of the <b>blood of purity, and a virgin whose blood is ritually pure</b> for four days after engaging in intercourse for the first time.
<b>And she is required to examine</b> herself <b>twice</b> each day: In the <b>morning,</b> to ascertain if she menstruated during the night, <b>and</b> at <b>twilight,</b> to ascertain if she menstruated during the day. <b>And</b> she is also required to examine herself <b>at a time that she is about to engage in intercourse with her husband.</b> The obligation of <b>women of priestly</b> families is <b>greater than</b> that of other women, as they are also required to examine themselves <b>when they</b> seek to <b>partake of <i>teruma</i>. Rabbi Yehuda says: Even when they conclude partaking of <i>teruma</i></b> they are required to examine themselves, in order to ascertain whether they experienced bleeding while partaking of <i>teruma</i>.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches: All women must examine themselves each day, <b>except for a menstruating woman.</b> The Gemara explains: Such a woman does not need to examine herself, <b>as during the days of her menstruation</b> she <b>does not need examination.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>This works out well according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, who said</b> that <b>a woman</b> can <b>establish a fixed</b> menstrual <b>cycle</b> even <b>during the days</b> that she <b>has <i>zava</i> status, but a woman does not establish a fixed</b> menstrual <b>cycle during the days of her</b> impurity due to <b>menstruation,</b> as any bleeding during these seven days is merely a continuation of her original menstruation. According to this opinion, it is <b>well,</b> and one can understand the mishna. <b>But according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan, who said</b> that <b>a woman</b> can <b>establish a fixed</b> menstrual <b>cycle during the days of her menstruation, let her examine</b> herself, as <b>perhaps</b> she will <b>establish a fixed</b> menstrual <b>cycle.</b>
The Gemara explains that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> could <b>say to you: When I say</b> that a woman can establish a fixed menstrual cycle during the days of her menstruation, that applies only in a case <b>where</b> the first two instances of her fixed cycle were established when she first <b>saw</b> blood <b>from a stopped source,</b> i.e., she saw blood on those particulars days at the outset of her period. <b>But</b> when she first <b>saw</b> blood <b>from an open source,</b> i.e., when the first two instances that she experienced bleeding on those particular days was in the middle of her menstrual period, <b>I did not say</b> that she establishes a fixed menstrual cycle, and therefore there is no need for her to examine herself.
§ The mishna teaches: All women must examine themselves each day, except for a menstruating woman, whose impure status is known, <b>and</b> a woman after childbirth <b>who is observing</b> the period of the <b>blood of purity.</b> The Gemara explains: It may <b>enter your mind</b> that when the mishna mentions a woman who is observing the period of the blood of purity, it is referring to one who is finishing the period of impurity following a birth and is <b>anticipating observing</b> the period <b>of</b> the <b>blood of purity.</b> In other words, her days of impurity are ending and she is about to start her days `of purity, and the mishna is stating that there is no need for an examination to conclude her days of impurity before starting her days of purity.
The Gemara analyzes the mishna in accordance with this interpretation. <b>This works out well according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav, who said</b> that blood after birth and blood of purity both come from <b>one source,</b> and <b>the Torah deemed</b> blood after birth <b>impure, and the Torah deemed</b> blood of purity <b>pure.</b> According to this opinion, it is <b>well,</b> and one can understand the mishna, since even if she emits blood continuously through the end of her days of impurity into her days of purity, the blood during her days of purity is pure.
But <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Levi, who said</b> that <b>there are two</b> distinct <b>sources,</b> one for blood after birth and one for blood of purity, <b>she should</b> be required to <b>examine</b> herself at the end of the period following birth, as <b>perhaps that impure source</b> of blood after birth had <b>not yet stopped</b> flowing. The Gemara explains that <b>Levi</b> could <b>say to you:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> ruling?

Daf 11b

<b>It is</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai, who say</b> that there <b>is</b> only <b>one source</b> for the two types of blood (see 35b). The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> can it be that <b>the <i>tanna</i> taught us an unattributed</b> mishna, which is generally accepted as the <i>halakha</i>, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai,</b> whose opinion is usually not accepted as <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>It is</b> a case where the mishna first records <b>an unattributed opinion and afterward</b> it records <b>a dispute</b> with regard to the same matter. <b>And</b> there is a principle that <b>any</b> time the mishna first records <b>an unattributed opinion and afterward</b> it records that the ruling is subject to <b>a dispute,</b> then the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>not</b> necessarily <b>in accordance with the unattributed opinion.</b>
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>Does</b> the mishna <b>teach:</b> A woman is <b>anticipating observing</b> the period <b>of</b> the blood of purity? Rather, it teaches: <b>Who is observing</b> the period of the blood of purity. The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> the mishna is referring to a woman <b>who is</b> already <b>observing</b> the period of the blood of purity, <b>what</b> is the purpose <b>of stating</b> that she is exempt from performing examinations? Isn’t this obvious? The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>she should examine</b> herself, <b>as perhaps</b> she will find that <b>she established a fixed</b> menstrual <b>cycle</b> through blood found on her examination cloths, the mishna <b>teaches us that</b> a woman <b>does not establish</b> a cycle from sightings of blood that came from <b>a pure source</b> that transfers <b>to</b> the period when she sees blood from <b>an impure source.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty with regard to this answer: <b>This</b> answer <b>works out well according to Levi, who said</b> that <b>there are two</b> distinct <b>sources,</b> one for blood after birth and one for blood of purity; one can understand that she does not establish a cycle with regard to blood from one source, from a sighting of blood from a different source. <b>But according to Rav, who said</b> that blood after birth and blood of purity both come from <b>one source, she should</b> be required to <b>examine</b> herself during the period of the blood of purity, as <b>perhaps she established a fixed</b> menstrual <b>cycle.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Even so,</b> i.e., that both types of blood come from the same source, nevertheless a woman <b>does not establish</b> a cycle <b>from</b> her <b>days of purity</b> that transfers <b>to</b> her <b>days of impurity.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And</b> even a woman with a fixed menstrual cycle <b>engages in intercourse while</b> using <b>examination cloths</b> to ascertain whether her menstrual flow began, except for a woman after childbirth who is observing the period of the blood of purity, and a virgin whose blood is ritually pure for four days after engaging in intercourse for the first time. In this connection, the Gemara notes that <b>we learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (64b): With regard to <b>a young girl whose time to see</b> the flow of menstrual blood <b>has not arrived,</b> as she has not yet reached puberty, <b>and she married, Beit Shammai say:</b> The Sages <b>give her four nights</b> after intercourse during which the blood is attributed to her torn hymen and she is ritually pure. Thereafter, any blood is menstrual blood and she is impure. <b>And Beit Hillel say:</b> The blood is attributed to the torn hymen <b>until the wound heals.</b>
With regard to Beit Hillel’s statement, <b>Rav Giddel says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> They <b>taught</b> this <b>only</b> in a case <b>where</b> she <b>does not stop</b> seeing blood <b>due to intercourse.</b> In other words, every time she engages in intercourse she experiences bleeding. In that case, even if <b>she saw</b> blood <b>not due to intercourse,</b> Beit Hillel still attribute the blood to the torn hymen. <b>But</b> if she <b>stops seeing</b> blood <b>due to intercourse, and</b> then she subsequently <b>saw</b> blood on another occasion, that blood renders her <b>impure.</b>
He continues: Similarly, if <b>one night passed without</b> them engaging in <b>intercourse and she</b> subsequently <b>saw</b> blood without connection to intercourse, this indicates that the blood is no longer from her torn hymen and therefore she is deemed <b>impure.</b> Likewise, if the <b>appearance</b> of <b>her blood</b> had changed since her initial blood from her torn hymen, she is <b>impure. Rabbi Yona raises an objection</b> to this last <i>halakha</i> from the mishna: <b>And a virgin whose blood is ritually pure</b> is not required to examine herself when she engages in intercourse. <b>Why</b> not? <b>She should engage in intercourse while</b> using <b>examination cloths, as perhaps</b> she will find that the <b>appearance of her blood</b> has <b>changed,</b> which would mean that her blood is no longer ritually pure blood from her torn hymen.
<b>Rava says: Say the first clause:</b> All women must engage in intercourse while using examination cloths, <b>except for a menstruating woman</b> whose impure status is certain <b>and</b> a woman after childbirth <b>who is observing</b> the period of the <b>blood of purity.</b> It can be inferred from here that these two exceptions are not required for women to examine themselves, <b>but a virgin whose blood is pure</b> is <b>required</b> to perform <b>an examination.</b> This ruling apparently supports Shmuel’s opinion that examination is required to determine if there is a change in the appearance of her blood. <b>But</b> if so, then the two clauses of the mishna are <b>difficult,</b> as they contradict <b>each other.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>Here,</b> in the latter clause that indicates that a virgin requires no examination, it is referring to a case <b>where she had engaged in intercourse.</b> In such a situation an examination would be inconclusive, <b>as</b> even if the appearance of her blood had changed, one can <b>say</b> that it was because the man’s <b>organ soiled it,</b> i.e., perhaps the intercourse caused the change of appearance in her blood. By contrast, <b>there,</b> in the first clause, it is referring to a case <b>where she</b> had <b>not engaged in intercourse,</b> and therefore she is required to perform an examination to determine if there was a change in appearance in her blood, as any difference in appearance would indicate a change from pure blood to impure blood.
The Gemara notes <b>that</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>. With regard to the opinion of Beit Hillel that blood is attributed to the torn hymen until the wound heals, the <i>baraita</i> asks: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> In a case <b>where she does not stop</b> seeing blood <b>due to intercourse,</b> i.e., every time she engages in intercourse she experiences bleeding. If so, even when <b>she sees</b> blood <b>not due to intercourse,</b> it is deemed pure.
<b>But</b> if she <b>stopped seeing</b> blood <b>due to intercourse, and</b> she subsequently <b>sees</b> blood at a different time, that sighting renders her <b>impure.</b> Similarly, if <b>one night passed without</b> her engaging in <b>intercourse and</b> then <b>she saw</b> blood without connection to intercourse, she is deemed <b>impure.</b> Furthermore, if she sees blood and the <b>appearance</b> of <b>her blood</b> had changed from her initial blood from her torn hymen, she is <b>impure.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And she is required</b> to examine herself <b>twice</b> each day, in the morning and at twilight. <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> The mishna <b>taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only with regard to</b> touching ritually <b>pure</b> items. <b>But with regard to her husband, she is permitted</b> to him without any requirement to perform examinations. The Gemara asks: Isn’t this <b>obvious,</b> as <b>we learn</b> in the mishna that she must examine herself twice a day, and the first time is in the <b>morning?</b> This indicates that the mishna is concerned about the status of ritually pure items that she will handle during the day, but not about intercourse with her husband, as a couple usually engages in relations at night rather than during the day.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rather, if</b> the statement of Rav Yehuda citing Shmuel <b>was stated,</b> it <b>was stated with regard to the latter clause</b> of the mishna: <b>And</b> she is also required to examine herself <b>at a time that she is about to engage in intercourse with her husband. Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> The mishna <b>taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only with regard to a woman who is engaged in</b> handling <b>pure</b> items. She alone is required to examine herself before intercourse. The reason is <b>that since</b> she is <b>required</b> to perform <b>an examination</b> in preparation <b>for</b> handling <b>pure</b> items, she <b>also requires an examination</b> in preparation <b>for</b> intercourse with <b>her husband. But</b> with regard to a woman who <b>is not engaged in</b> handling <b>pure</b> items, she is <b>not required</b> to perform <b>an examination</b> in preparation for intercourse with her husband.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> Rav Yehuda <b>teaching us? We</b> already <b>learn</b> this from the mishna (15a): <b>All women have the presumptive status of purity to their husbands,</b> and therefore the husband does not need to ascertain whether she is ritually pure before engaging in intercourse. The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> this <i>halakha</i> is learned <b>from the mishna</b> alone, <b>I would say</b> that <b>this statement</b> applies only <b>to a woman who has</b> a fixed menstrual <b>cycle. But</b> in the case of <b>a woman who does not have</b> a fixed menstrual <b>cycle,</b> she is <b>required</b> to perform <b>an examination</b> before intercourse. Consequently, Rav Yehuda teaches us that even a woman who does not have a fixed menstrual cycle is not required to perform an examination before intercourse, unless she handles pure items.
The Gemara asks: <b>But aren’t we are dealing</b> in <b>the mishna with</b> a case <b>of a woman who has</b> a fixed menstrual <b>cycle?</b> The Gemara answers: The mishna <b>is dealing both</b> with a case <b>where she has</b> a fixed menstrual <b>cycle</b> and with a case where <b>she does not have</b> a fixed menstrual <b>cycle. And this</b> is what the mishna <b>teaches us: That even though she has</b> a fixed menstrual <b>cycle,</b> and therefore one might think that she is exempt from examination, nevertheless if she handles pure items, <b>since</b> she is <b>required</b> to perform <b>an examination</b> in preparation <b>for</b> handling those <b>pure</b> items, she is <b>also required</b> to perform <b>an examination</b> in preparation <b>for</b> intercourse with <b>her husband.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t Shmuel</b> already <b>state</b> this <i>halakha</i> on <b>another occasion? As Rabbi Zeira said</b> that <b>Rabbi Abba bar Yirmeya says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> With regard to <b>a woman who does not have</b> a fixed menstrual <b>cycle,</b> it is <b>forbidden</b> for her to engage in intercourse with her husband <b>until she examines</b> herself and determines that she is pure. <b>And we interpreted</b> this <i>halakha</i> as referring to a case <b>where she is engaged in</b> handling <b>pure</b> items. The Gemara answers: Shmuel did not in fact issue two statements; rather, <b>one was stated by inference from the other.</b> In other words, Shmuel said one of these statements explicitly; the other was reported by his students in his name based on an inference from what he had said.
The Gemara adds: <b>This is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement,</b> that a woman requires an examination, <b>said?</b> It is said with regard to a woman who is preparing <b>for</b> handling <b>pure</b> items. <b>But</b> with regard to engaging in intercourse <b>with her husband, she is permitted</b> to do so without performing an examination. The <i>baraita</i> qualifies this ruling: And <b>in what</b> case <b>is this statement,</b> that she is not required to perform an examination, <b>said?</b> It is said <b>when</b> her husband traveled and <b>left her with the presumptive status of ritual purity.</b> If so, upon his return she does not need to perform an examination before they engage in intercourse. <b>But</b> if he <b>left her with the presumptive status of ritual impurity,</b> she remains <b>forever in her status of impurity, until she says to him: I am ritually pure.</b>

Daf 12a

§ <b>Rabbi Zeira raised a dilemma before Rav Yehuda: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> as to whether <b>a woman should examine herself</b> before engaging in intercourse <b>with her husband?</b> Rav Yehuda <b>said to him: She should not examine</b> herself. Rabbi Zeira asked: <b>And let her examine</b> herself; <b>what</b> would be the problem <b>with that?</b> Rav Yehuda answered: <b>If so,</b> the <b>heart</b> of a scrupulous husband might <b>strike him</b> with pangs of conscience over sins that he could transgress, <b>and he</b> will <b>separate</b> from his wife out of fear that she is impure.
<b>Rabbi Abba raised</b> a similar <b>dilemma before Rav Huna: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> as to whether <b>a woman should examine herself</b> immediately after engaging in intercourse, within the minimum <b>period of time</b> needed for the onset of <b>menstruation, in order to render her husband liable to</b> bring <b>a sin offering</b> for engaging in intercourse with a menstruating woman?
Rav Huna <b>said to him:</b> Can <b>you find</b> a case <b>where</b> it is physically possible to perform a full examination after intercourse within the <b>period of time</b> needed for the onset of <b>menstruation? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>What is</b> the <b>period of time</b> needed for the onset of <b>menstruation?</b> This is <b>comparable to</b> a male <b>organ and an examination cloth that are standing alongside the doorpost,</b> i.e., at the entrance to the vagina; <b>upon the exit of</b> the <b>organ</b> the <b>examination cloth</b> immediately <b>enters.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>It is</b> apparent that <b>the period of time that they stated</b> is the time required <b>for</b> an external <b>wipe, and not</b> for a full internal <b>examination.</b> Therefore, if she did an internal examination and found blood, one cannot be certain that she was already menstruating during intercourse and thereby render the husband liable to bring a sin offering. <b>Rather,</b> this is Rabbi Abba’s dilemma: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> as to whether a woman <b>should wipe</b> herself immediately after engaging in intercourse? Since this action can be performed quickly, if she were to find blood her husband would be liable to bring a sin offering.
<b>Some say</b> that <b>this</b> is the dilemma that Rabbi Abba <b>raised before</b> Rav Huna: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> as to whether <b>a woman should examine herself</b> immediately after engaging in intercourse, <b>in order to render her husband liable to</b> bring <b>a provisional guilt offering</b> brought by one who is uncertain as to whether he committed a sin that requires a sin offering? Rav Huna <b>said to him: She should not examine</b> herself. Rabbi Abba asked: <b>And</b> let <b>her examine</b> herself; <b>what</b> would be the problem <b>with that?</b> Rav Huna answered: <b>If so,</b> the <b>heart</b> of a scrupulous husband might <b>strike him</b> with pangs of conscience over sins that he could transgress, <b>and he</b> will <b>separate</b> from his wife out of fear that she is impure.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And</b> she is also required to examine herself <b>at a time that she is about to</b> engage in intercourse with her husband. <b>Rabbi Ami says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yannai says: And this</b> examination performed before intercourse is known as: The <b>examination cloth of virtuous women,</b> as this examination is not strictly required. <b>Rabbi Abba bar Memel said to Rabbi Ami:</b> The <i>tanna</i> teaches that women <b>are required</b> to perform this examination, <b>and</b> yet <b>you teach</b> that only <b>virtuous women</b> perform it. Rabbi Ami <b>said to him:</b> Yes, <b>as I say</b> that <b>anyone who fulfills the statements of the Sages is called virtuous.</b> Rabbi Ami did not mean that this examination is beyond the letter of the law. He was simply praising those who abide by the established <i>halakha</i>.
With regard to Rabbi Ami’s claim, <b>Rava says: And</b> according to your opinion, with regard to one <b>who does not fulfill the statements of the Sages, he is not called virtuous. But</b> this indicates that <b>he is not called wicked</b> either. This cannot be correct, as one who does not heed the instructions of the Sages is certainly wicked. <b>Rather, Rava said: Virtuous women</b> are those who do not reuse <b>the examination cloth that they used to examine themselves before this intercourse.</b> Even if no blood was found on it, <b>they do not examine themselves with it prior to another</b> act of <b>intercourse,</b> as once it was used once, it is not as clean as before. <b>And those who are not virtuous women</b> reuse the same examination cloths and <b>examine</b> themselves with them <b>and they are not particular</b> about this matter.
§ The Gemara returns to <b>the</b> matter <b>itself: Rabbi Zeira says</b> that <b>Rabbi Abba bar Yirmeya says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> With regard to <b>a woman who does not have</b> a fixed menstrual <b>cycle,</b> it is <b>forbidden</b> for her <b>to engage in intercourse until she examines</b> herself. <b>Rabbi Zeira said to Rabbi Abba bar Yirmeya:</b> Does Shmuel mean that if <b>she does not have</b> a fixed menstrual <b>cycle</b> she is <b>required</b> to perform <b>an examination,</b> but if <b>she has</b> a fixed menstrual <b>cycle</b> she is <b>not required</b> to perform <b>an examination?</b> This is difficult, as the mishna teaches that even a woman with a fixed menstrual cycle is required to perform an examination before she engages in intercourse.
Rabbi Abba bar Yirmeya <b>said to him:</b> The mishna means that if <b>she has</b> a fixed menstrual <b>cycle</b> and she is <b>awake,</b> she is <b>required</b> to perform <b>an examination;</b> if she is <b>sleeping</b> she is <b>not required</b> to perform <b>an examination</b> before intercourse, as this would involve much effort. If <b>she does not have</b> a fixed menstrual <b>cycle,</b> then <b>whether</b> she is <b>awake or sleeping,</b> she is <b>required</b> to perform <b>an examination.</b>
<b>Rava says: And let</b> Rabbi Abba bar Yirmeya <b>say</b> a different answer <b>to</b> Rabbi Zeira: Shmuel means that if <b>she has</b> a fixed menstrual <b>cycle,</b> then <b>in</b> the case of a woman who handles <b>pure</b> items, she is <b>required</b> to perform <b>an examination</b> for the sake of intercourse as well. If she does not handle pure items, then <b>for</b> the sake of intercourse with <b>her husband</b> alone she is <b>not required</b> to perform <b>an examination.</b> By contrast, if she <b>does not have</b> a fixed menstrual <b>cycle,</b> then she is <b>required</b> to perform <b>an examination even for</b> the sake of intercourse with <b>her husband.</b> Rava concludes: <b>And from</b> the fact <b>that</b> Rabbi Abba bar Yirmeya <b>did not say this</b> answer, one can <b>learn from</b> it that <b>Shmuel holds</b> that in <b>any</b> case where an examination is only <b>for</b> the purpose of intercourse with <b>her husband,</b> she is <b>not required</b> to perform <b>an examination.</b>
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>donkey drivers and laborers</b> who return home, <b>and those who come</b> home <b>from the house of mourning or from the house of feasting</b> for a wedding, <b>their wives</b> remain <b>in a presumptive status of purity. And</b> therefore <b>they may come and remain with them,</b> i.e., engage in intercourse with them, <b>whether they are sleeping or awake.</b> The <i>baraita</i> clarifies: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said? When</b> the husbands <b>left</b> their wives <b>in a presumptive state of purity. But</b> if the husbands <b>left them in a presumptive state of impurity, she</b> remains <b>forever</b> in a status of <b>impurity, until she says to him: I am ritually pure.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> according to Rabbi Abba bar Yirmeya, <b>with regard to what</b> case does <b>Shmuel interpret this</b> <i>baraita</i>? If the <i>baraita</i> is dealing <b>with</b> a woman <b>who has</b> a fixed menstrual <b>cycle,</b> it is <b>difficult,</b> as Shmuel holds that such a woman who is <b>awake</b> is required to perform an examination, whereas the <i>baraita</i> indicates that no examination is necessary. <b>And if</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to</b> a woman <b>who does not have</b> a fixed menstrual <b>cycle,</b> it is also <b>difficult,</b> as Shmuel holds that she always is required to perform an examination, <b>whether</b> she is <b>awake or sleeping.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where she has</b> a fixed menstrual <b>cycle, and since</b> her husband came home from his travels and <b>requested of her</b> that they engage in intercourse, <b>there is no greater examination than this.</b> Since she had time to consider the matter while he was asking her, she would have remembered had she sensed the onset of her menstrual cycle, whereas under regular circumstances she might not have time to recall. Based upon this explanation, <b>Rav Pappa said to Rava: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard <b>to acting in accordance with this <i>baraita</i>?</b> Perhaps it is necessary to wake her and ask her whether she is ritually pure.

Daf 12b

Rava <b>said to</b> Rav Pappa: <b>Wise one [<i>sudani</i>]! No, won’t she be demeaned before him?</b> It is embarrassing for her if she is awoken and has to think about whether or not she is pure. <b>Rav Kahana says: I asked the members of the households,</b> i.e., the wives, <b>of Rav Pappa and of Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua: When the Sages,</b> your husbands, <b>came</b> home <b>from</b> the <b>study hall,</b> did they <b>require you</b> to perform <b>an examination prior</b> to intercourse? <b>And they said to me: No.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why ask their wives? Why not <b>ask</b> those Sages <b>themselves?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Perhaps</b> they might rule leniently for others, while <b>acting stringently with themselves.</b> Therefore, their wives were asked, to determine how the Sages conducted themselves in their personal lives.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a woman who does not have</b> a fixed menstrual <b>cycle,</b> she is <b>forbidden to engage in intercourse, and she does not have</b> the right to receive payment of her <b>marriage contract</b> if divorced or widowed, <b>nor</b> is she entitled to payment from her husband for the <b>produce</b> of her property that he consumed, <b>nor</b> is she entitled to provisions for her <b>sustenance</b> from his estate, <b>nor</b> does she get back her <b>worn clothes</b> or other items she brought with her to her marriage as part of her dowry. And furthermore, her husband <b>must divorce</b> her <b>and he may never remarry</b> her. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
<b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus says:</b> She is permitted to <b>engage in intercourse</b> with her husband, but she must examine herself <b>with two examination cloths,</b> one prior to intercourse and one afterward. <b>They</b> may be to <b>her detriment</b> if she finds blood on the cloths, or <b>they</b> may lead to <b>her betterment,</b> since if she finds no blood she is permitted to her husband. <b>They said in the name of Abba Ḥanan: Woe to her husband!</b>
The Gemara explains each clause of the <i>baraita</i>: She is <b>forbidden to engage in intercourse,</b> as <b>perhaps she will ruin</b> her husband if she emits blood during intercourse. <b>And</b> with regard to the <i>halakha</i> that <b>she does not have</b> the right to receive payment of her <b>marriage contract,</b> the reason is that <b>since</b> she is <b>not fit for intercourse, she is not</b> entitled to payment of her <b>marriage contract.</b>
The Gemara continues its explanation: <b>And</b> she is <b>not</b> entitled to payment for the <b>produce</b> of her property, <b>nor</b> is she entitled to provisions for her <b>sustenance</b> from his estate, <b>nor</b> does she get back her <b>worn clothes.</b> The reason for all these is because <b>stipulations in the marriage contract are considered like the marriage contract</b> itself. Since she is not entitled to a marriage contract, she is likewise not entitled to these additional provisions that are stipulated in the marriage contract.
The Gemara analyzes the next clause in the <i>baraita</i>: Her husband <b>must divorce</b> her <b>and he may never remarry</b> her. The Gemara asks: Isn’t that <b>obvious?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to teach this in a case <b>where</b> her situation <b>was subsequently amended,</b> i.e., she established a fixed menstrual cycle. <b>Lest you say</b> that he <b>may remarry her,</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that this is not permitted, <b>as sometimes</b> such a woman might <b>go and marry</b> someone else <b>and</b> her status is <b>subsequently amended.</b>
<b>And</b> the problem in this scenario is that her first husband might <b>say: If I would have known that it is like this,</b> that she would be cured, <b>even if you would have given me one hundred</b> times <b>one hundred dinars</b> to divorce her <b>I would not have divorced her. And</b> if so, the <b>bill of divorce</b> will be <b>found</b> to be <b>void, and her children</b> from her second husband will be considered <b><i>mamzerim</i>.</b> Therefore it must be made clear to him from the outset that this divorce is final.
The Gemara analyzes the final clause of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>They said in the name of Abba Ḥanan: Woe to her husband! Some say</b> that <b>he said this to Rabbi Meir, as</b> Abba Ḥanan maintains that the husband is <b>required to settle</b> her payment of <b>her marriage contract</b> upon their divorce. And <b>some say</b> that <b>he said this to Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus,</b> since Abba Ḥanan disagrees with his opinion and holds that it is forbidden to engage in intercourse with her, <b>as</b> perhaps <b>she will ruin him</b> if they engage in intercourse when she is menstruating.
<b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And with regard to what</b> case did Shmuel issue this ruling of <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara elaborates: <b>If</b> it is referring to a woman who <b>is engaged in</b> handling ritually <b>pure</b> items, <b>didn’t Shmuel</b> already <b>say</b> on <b>another occasion</b> that a woman without a fixed menstrual cycle must examine herself prior to intercourse?
<b>And if</b> it is referring to a woman <b>who is not engaged in</b> handling ritually <b>pure</b> items, <b>doesn’t</b> Shmuel <b>say</b> that in <b>any</b> case where an examination is only <b>for</b> the purpose of intercourse with <b>her husband,</b> not for handling pure items, she is <b>not required</b> to perform <b>an examination? As Rabbi Zeira said</b> that <b>Rabbi Abba bar Yirmeya says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: A woman who does not have</b> a fixed menstrual <b>cycle is forbidden to engage in intercourse until she examines</b> herself, <b>and we interpreted this</b> statement as referring to cases <b>where she is engaged in</b> handling ritually <b>pure</b> items. The Gemara answers: <b>He who teaches this does not teach that,</b> i.e., Shmuel’s ruling is in fact referring to a woman engaged in handling pure items, and the two rulings were cited in his name by different Sages.

Daf 13a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>any hand that is diligent to examine</b> bodily emissions to ascertain ritual impurity, <b>among women</b> such a hand <b>is praiseworthy. But among men</b> such a hand <b>should be severed,</b> as this action is apt to lead to a seminal emission for naught.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about <b>women and what is different</b> about <b>men,</b> that women are praised for examining for bodily emissions while men are castigated for the same? The Gemara answers: <b>Women are not susceptible to</b> sexual <b>arousal</b> by this action, and therefore when a woman is diligent to examine herself she is considered <b>praiseworthy;</b> whereas <b>men, who are susceptible to</b> sexual <b>arousal</b> and may experience a seminal emission as a result of this contact, may not do so, and the hand of a man who conducts frequent examinations for emissions <b>should be severed.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, why</b> does the mishna state <b>specifically</b> among men that only the hand that is <b>diligent</b> to examine, i.e., that does so often, should be severed? Even <b>when</b> a man <b>is not diligent</b> to examine, but does so occasionally, this action is <b>also</b> apt to cause a seminal emission. The Gemara answers: <b>When</b> the mishna <b>teaches:</b> Any hand that is <b>diligent</b> to examine, it states this only <b>with regard to women,</b> as men should not examine even occasionally.
The Gemara continues to discuss the examination of men for seminal emissions. It is <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement,</b> that men should not examine themselves, <b>said?</b> It is said <b>with regard to</b> an examination for <b>semen. But with regard to</b> a man who examines himself for gonorrhea-like <b>discharge [<i>zov</i>], he too is praiseworthy</b> for examining diligently, <b>as women</b> are. The reason is that a man who experiences two such discharges is ritually impure but is not obligated to bring an offering, whereas one who experiences three such emissions must bring an offering as a <i>zav</i>. Therefore, it is important for a man who experiences a gonorrhea-like discharge to examine and count his emissions carefully.
The <i>baraita</i> adds: <b>And even with regard to semen, if one wants to examine</b> himself <b>with a rock or with</b> a piece of <b>earthenware,</b> which are hard and will not warm the body, <b>he may examine</b> himself in this manner.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> may a man <b>not</b> examine himself <b>with</b> a linen <b>cloth? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: A man <b>may examine himself with a cloth,</b> to see if he has emitted semen, <b>or with any</b> similar <b>item that he wants?</b> The Gemara answers: Just <b>as Abaye said,</b> with regard to a different issue, that it is referring <b>to a coarse cloth,</b> which will not warm one’s body, <b>here too,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to a coarse cloth,</b> which will not lead to a seminal emission.
The Gemara asks: <b>And where was</b> this statement <b>of Abaye stated?</b> It was stated <b>with regard to that which we learned</b> in a mishna (40a): If a priest <b>was eating <i>teruma</i> and he sensed that his limbs quaked,</b> indicating that a seminal emission was imminent, he should firmly <b>hold his penis</b> to prevent the emission from leaving his body, <b>and swallow the <i>teruma</i></b> while ritually pure.
A difficulty was raised with regard to this mishna: May he actually <b>hold</b> his penis? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> With regard to <b>anyone who holds his penis and urinates,</b> it is considered <b>as though he is bringing a flood to the world,</b> as masturbation was one of the sins that led to the flood (<i>Sanhedrin</i> 108b)? <b>Abaye says</b> in resolution of this difficulty that the mishna is referring to one who holds his penis <b>with a coarse cloth.</b>
<b>Rava says</b> with regard to that mishna: <b>You</b> may <b>even say</b> that it is referring to a priest who holds his penis <b>with a soft cloth,</b> and the reason it is permitted is that <b>once</b> the semen <b>has</b> already been <b>uprooted</b> from his body, it is <b>uprooted,</b> and his subsequent holding of the penis, even with a soft cloth, does not increase the emission of semen. <b>And Abaye</b> prohibits the use of a soft cloth even here, as he is <b>concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> due to the contact of this cloth one might <b>come to increase</b> the emission of semen. <b>But Rava is not concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> one might <b>come to increase</b> the emission.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is Rava <b>not</b> concerned for this possibility? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>To what is this</b> repeated examination of a man <b>comparable? To</b> one who <b>places a finger in</b> his <b>eye, for as long as</b> the <b>finger</b> is <b>in the eye,</b> the <b>eye will tear and continue to tear.</b> Here too, the priest’s action will lead to an increased emission of semen.
The Gemara answers: <b>And Rava</b> would claim that if the priest’s limbs were not quaking and the semen was coming out in drops, there is indeed a concern that an examination might increase the emission. But when he feels his limbs quaking, this concern does not apply. The reason is that with regard to <b>any warming</b> of the body that leads to a seminal emission <b>and</b> that is <b>then</b> followed by another <b>warming at the time</b> when the semen is being uprooted, it is <b>uncommon</b> for the latter warming to increase the emission. Consequently, in this case the priest may hold his penis even with a soft cloth.
The Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself. Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> With regard to <b>anyone who holds</b> his <b>penis and urinates,</b> it is considered <b>as though he is bringing a flood to the world.</b> The Rabbis <b>said to Rabbi Eliezer: But</b> if one does not hold his penis, <b>small drops are sprayed on his legs, and he appears as one whose penis has been severed.</b> A man with that affliction is incapable of fathering children. People who see urine on his legs might suspect that he is suffering from that condition <b>and as a result</b> they will <b>cast aspersions about his children</b> and say <b>that they are children born from a forbidden relationship [<i>mamzerim</i>].</b>
Rabbi Eliezer <b>said to them: It is preferable that</b> people <b>cast aspersions about his children that they are <i>mamzerim</i>, and he should not render himself wicked</b> even <b>one moment before the Omnipresent.</b>
With regard to the same issue, it <b>is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer said to</b> the other <b>Rabbis</b> in response: It is <b>possible</b> for one to avoid spraying urine on his legs. How so? <b>Let a person stand on an elevated place and urinate</b> downward, <b>or urinate into</b> an area where there is <b>loose soil,</b> which absorbs the urine, so that it does not ricochet upward, <b>and he should not render himself wicked</b> even <b>one moment before the Omnipresent.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Which</b> of these replies <b>did</b> Rabbi Eliezer <b>say to</b> the Rabbis <b>first? If we say</b> that it was the <b>first</b> statement, i.e., that one should not hold his penis even if people might cast aspersions about his children, that he <b>said to</b> the Rabbis <b>first,</b> and subsequently he told them that there was a way to avoid urine being sprayed on his legs, this is difficult; <b>after saying to them</b> that it is <b>a prohibition, would he then say to them</b> a practical <b>remedy?</b> By saying that one can avoid urine being sprayed on his legs, Rabbi Eliezer indicated that if one cannot do so he may hold his penis, which contradicts his other statement.
<b>Rather,</b> clearly <b>he said this</b> practical solution <b>to</b> the Rabbis <b>first, and they</b> then <b>said to him:</b> If <b>one does not have an elevated place or loose earth</b> upon which he can urinate, <b>what</b> should he do? In response to this question, <b>he said to them: It is preferable</b> that people <b>cast aspersions about his children that they are <i>mamzerim</i>, and he should not render himself wicked</b> even <b>one moment before the Omnipresent.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> why must one refrain <b>to that extent</b> from holding his penis? <b>Because</b> as the result of holding his penis <b>he</b> might <b>emit semen for naught. As Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Anyone who emits semen for naught is liable</b> to receive the punishment of <b>death</b> at the hand of Heaven, <b>as it is stated</b> with regard to Onan, son of Judah: “And it came to pass, when he engaged in intercourse with his brother’s wife, that he spilled it on the ground, lest he should give seed to his brother. <b>And the thing that he did was evil in the eyes of the Lord, and He slew him also”</b> (Genesis 38:9–10).
<b>Rabbi Yitzḥak and Rabbi Ami say:</b> One who emits semen for naught is considered <b>as though he sheds blood, as it is stated:</b> “But draw near here, you sons of the sorceress, the seed of the adulterer and the harlot…Are you not children of transgression, a seed of falsehood, <b>you that inflame yourselves among the terebinths, under every leafy tree, that slay [<i>shoḥatei</i>] the children in the valleys, under the clefts of the rocks?”</b> (Isaiah 57:3–5). <b>Do not read</b> this word as <b><i>shoḥatei</i>; rather,</b> read it as <b><i>soḥatei</i>,</b> i.e., one who squeezes out [<i>soḥet</i>] semen is considered to have shed the blood of the children who could have been born from that seed.
<b>Rav Asi says:</b> It is considered <b>as though he worships idols,</b> as <b>it is written here: “Under every leafy tree,” and it is written there,</b> with regard to the mitzva of eradicating idols from Eretz Yisrael: “You shall destroy all the places, where the nations that you are to dispossess worshipped their gods, <b>upon the high mountains,</b> and upon the hills, <b>and under every leafy tree”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:2).
§ With regard to the issue of holding one’s penis for the purpose of urinating, the Gemara relates that <b>Rav Yehuda and Shmuel were standing on the roof of the synagogue that was destroyed and rebuilt in Neharde’a. Rav Yehuda said to Shmuel:</b> What can I do? <b>I need to urinate.</b> Shmuel <b>said to him: <i>Shinnana</i>, hold your penis,</b> so that the water does not fall onto the synagogue roof, <b>and urinate outward,</b> away from the synagogue.
The Gemara asks: <b>How could</b> Rav Yehuda <b>do so? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> With regard to <b>anyone who holds his penis and urinates,</b> it is considered <b>as though he is bringing a flood to the world?</b>
