§ <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava asked Abaye: According to Rabbi Meir, who said</b> that an item that is similar to <b>an animal in the womb of a woman is</b> considered <b>a full-fledged offspring, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a human</b> fetus <b>in the womb of an animal?</b> The Gemara explains: <b>What is the</b> practical <b>difference</b> of this inquiry? The difference is <b>with regard to permitting</b> the fetus <b>in consumption.</b> A full-fledged fetus found inside its slaughtered mother is permitted to be eaten, despite the fact that it was not slaughtered itself.
The Gemara suggests: <b>But</b> one can <b>resolve</b> the dilemma <b>from that</b> statement <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan, as Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> In the case of <b>one who slaughters an animal and finds in it</b> an item that has <b>the form of a pigeon,</b> the pigeon <b>is prohibited for consumption.</b> Evidently, the ritual slaughter of a pregnant animal renders its fetus permitted to be eaten only if the fetus is of the same species as the mother. Accordingly, if the fetus has the form of a human, it is prohibited for consumption.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> with regard to a pigeon fetus, <b>there are no</b> split <b>hooves, and there is not</b> even <b>a hoof</b> at all. Since a pigeon is completely different from the slaughtered animal, the fetus is forbidden. By contrast, <b>here,</b> in the case of a human fetus, <b>although there are no</b> split <b>hooves, there is at least a hoof,</b> i.e., solid feet. Therefore, it is possible that the human fetus is permitted for consumption, and the dilemma remains unresolved.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And the Rabbis say: Any</b> discharged entity <b>that is not</b> of human form does not render the woman impure. <b>Rav Yirmeya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rav says: All concede</b> that if a woman discharged an entity <b>whose body is</b> that of <b>a goat and whose face is</b> that of <b>a human,</b> it is considered <b>a human</b> offspring, i.e., even the Rabbis rule that the woman is impure in this case. Likewise, if <b>its body is</b> that of <b>a human and its face is</b> that of <b>a goat,</b> Rabbi Meir concedes that <b>it is nothing,</b> and the woman is pure.
<b>They disagree only</b> in a case <b>where its face is</b> that of <b>a human, but it was created with</b> one human eye and <b>one eye like</b> that of <b>an animal. As Rabbi Meir says</b> that if the offspring has part <b>of the form of a human</b> face, even if one eye is not like that of a human, it is considered a human offspring, and the woman is impure. <b>And the Rabbis say</b> that it must have <b>the entire form of a human</b> face to be considered a human offspring, and otherwise the woman is not impure.
One of the Sages <b>said to Rav Yirmeya bar Abba: But isn’t the opposite taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Meir says</b> that a woman who discharged is impure if the fetus has <b>any</b> part of the <b>form</b> of a human face, <b>and the Rabbis say</b> that the woman is impure only if the fetus has a recognizable part <b>of the form of</b> a human face, e.g., half of a human face? According to this <i>baraita</i>, Rabbi Meir does not even require that a significant part of it must look human. In his opinion, even if it has only one human eye or one human cheek and the rest of the face is like that of an animal, the woman is impure. Rav Yirmeya bar Abba <b>said to</b> the Sages: <b>If this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is taught, it is taught,</b> and I cannot take issue with it. I have my tradition from Rav, and you should rule in accordance with the <i>baraita</i> that you received.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> A woman who discharges an entity is impure only if the entire face of the fetus has a human form. This includes its <b>forehead, and the eyebrows, and the eyes, and the cheeks, and</b> its <b>chin.</b> The woman is not impure <b>unless</b> these facial features <b>all as one</b> have the human form. <b>Rava</b> says that <b>Ḥasa says:</b> It is sufficient for the fetus to have the appearance of a human on one side of its face; its <b>forehead, and</b> one <b>eyebrow, and</b> one <b>eye, and</b> one <b>cheek, and</b> its <b>chin</b> are enough. The woman is not impure <b>unless</b> these facial features <b>all as one</b> have the human form.
<b>And</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan and Ḥasa <b>do not disagree</b> about whether the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir or that of the Rabbis, as they both accept the opinion of the Rabbis. The difference between them is that <b>this</b> <i>amora</i>, Rabbi Yoḥanan, holds <b>like the one who says</b> that the Rabbis require <b>the entire form of</b> the face to be human, and <b>that</b> <i>amora</i>, Ḥasa, holds <b>like the one who says</b> that the Rabbis require only a recognizable part <b>of the form of</b> a human face.
Ḥasa evidently interprets the version of the Rabbis’ statement that only part of a human face is required as referring to half of a human face. The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to this interpretation from a <i>baraita</i>: The miscarriage of a fetus with <b>the form of</b> a human <b>face, which</b> the Rabbis <b>said</b> renders the woman impure, includes <b>even one of the facial features, apart from the ear.</b> Apparently, <b>that is to say that</b> even <b>if</b> the fetus has only <b>one</b> facial feature of a human, this <b>is also sufficient</b> to render the woman impure.
<b>Abaye says: When that</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is taught, it is taught with regard to</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>rendering</b> all of the facial features <b>indispensable</b> for the fetus to be defined as human, except for the ear. <b>And</b> this ruling <b>is in accordance with the one who says</b> that the Rabbis require that <b>the entire form of</b> the face must be human. <b>And if you wish, say</b> that <b>actually</b> this ruling <b>is in accordance with the one who says</b> that the Rabbis require only a recognizable part <b>of the form of</b> a human face. <b>And what</b> is the meaning of the claim that it is sufficient for the fetus to have <b>one</b> facial feature of a human? It means <b>one of each</b> facial feature of which a human has two, i.e., one eye, one eyebrow, and so on.
<b>Rava says:</b> In a case where a fetus <b>was created with one eye or with one thigh,</b> if the eye is located <b>to the side</b> on the middle of the face, or the thigh is located at the side of the hip, where a human eye or thigh is normally located, the fetus is considered human, and <b>its mother is impure.</b> If it appears <b>in the middle</b> of the face or hip, the fetus is not considered human, and <b>its mother is pure.</b>
<b>Rava says:</b> If <b>its esophagus is punctured,</b> although the fetus is considered a <i>tereifa</i>, i.e., one that has a wound that will cause it to die within twelve months, <b>its mother is impure.</b> But if <b>its esophagus is sealed,</b> i.e., it is closed at one end, it does not have the status of a human fetus, and therefore <b>its mother is pure.</b>
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of a woman <b>who discharges</b> a fetus that has <b>a sealed body, its mother is not impure</b> with the impurity of a woman after <b>childbirth. And what is a sealed body? Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> It is a body which is lacking a limb that <b>when removed from a living</b> person would cause him to <b>die.</b>
<b>And how much</b> of the lower part of a person’s body <b>when removed from a living</b> person would cause him to <b>die,</b> because one cannot survive such a wound? <b>Rabbi Zakkai says:</b>

Daf 24a

<b>Until</b> above <b>the knee. Rabbi Yannai says: Until his orifices. Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Yosei ben Yehoshua: Until the location of his navel.</b>
The Gemara explains the dispute between the <i>amora’im</i>: The difference <b>between</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Zakkai and</b> that of <b>Rabbi Yannai</b> is whether <b>a <i>tereifa</i> can survive</b> beyond twelve months. One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yannai, <b>holds</b> that <b>a <i>tereifa</i> can survive</b> beyond twelve months. Therefore, although one whose legs were removed until above the knee has the status of a <i>tereifa</i>, if a woman discharges a fetus of this form she is impure. Only if the fetus lacks legs until his orifices is the woman pure, as such a person cannot survive. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Zakkai, <b>holds</b> that <b>a <i>tereifa</i> cannot survive</b> beyond twelve months. Therefore, even if the fetus lacks legs only from above the knee and not from his orifices, the woman is not impure.
The difference <b>between</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yannai and</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who both agree that a <i>tereifa</i> can survive, is with regard to a statement <b>of Rabbi Elazar, as Rabbi Elazar said:</b> If the <b>thigh,</b> i.e., the hind leg of the animal, <b>and its recess were removed</b> from an animal before slaughter, the animal is considered <b>an unslaughtered carcass;</b> consequently, it is forbidden in consumption and imparts ritual impurity even while still alive. Rabbi Yannai agrees with the statement of Rabbi Elazar, and accordingly holds that if the lower part of a person’s body until his orifices is missing or removed, the person immediately assumes the halakhic status of a corpse. Rabbi Yoḥanan disagrees with Rabbi Elazar and holds that one whose lower part of his body was missing or removed has the status of a corpse only if it is removed until his navel.
<b>Rav Pappa says:</b> The <b>dispute</b> between the <i>amora’im</i> is with regard to a fetus that is lacking part of its body <b>from below</b> to <b>above,</b> i.e., the lower part of his body; <b>but</b> if it is lacking part of its body <b>from above</b> to <b>below, even any amount</b> of its skull, the woman <b>is pure. And likewise, Rav Giddel says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> In the case of a woman <b>who discharges</b> a fetus <b>whose skull is sealed,</b> i.e., deficient, <b>its mother is pure.</b>
The Gemara cites another <i>halakha</i>: <b>And Rav Giddel says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> In the case of a woman <b>who discharges</b> a fetus that looks <b>like</b> the part <b>of a palm tree</b> that <b>branches out,</b> i.e., the lower part of its body is formless while the upper part has arms and legs coming out of its shoulders like branches, <b>its mother is pure.</b>
§ It <b>was stated</b> with regard to a woman <b>who discharges</b> a fetus <b>whose face is mashed</b> but not completely flattened, that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says its mother is impure,</b> and <b>Reish Lakish says its mother is pure.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan raised an objection to Reish Lakish</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of a woman <b>who discharges a shaped hand,</b> i.e., a hand whose fingers are discernible, <b>or a shaped foot, its mother is impure</b> with the impurity of a woman after <b>childbirth,</b> as it certainly came from a full-fledged fetus, <b>and we are not concerned</b> that <b>perhaps it came from</b> a fetus with <b>a sealed,</b> i.e., deficient, <b>body. And if it is so,</b> that a fetus with a mashed face does not render its mother impure, <b>let</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teach:</b> We are not concerned that <b>perhaps</b> it came <b>from</b> a fetus with <b>a sealed body or from one whose face is mashed.</b>
<b>Rav Pappi says: In</b> a case where <b>its face is mashed, everyone agrees that</b> the woman <b>is impure. When they disagree,</b> it is <b>in</b> a case where <b>its face is</b> completely <b>flat,</b> i.e., none of its features are discernible; <b>and the opposite was stated: Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that <b>its mother is pure, and Reish Lakish says</b> that <b>its mother is impure.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But</b> according to this version of the dispute, <b>let Reish Lakish raise an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan from this</b> <i>baraita</i>, from which Rabbi Yoḥanan raised an objection to the opinion of Reish Lakish according to the previous version of the dispute: If a woman who discharges a fetus whose face is flat is pure, the <i>baraita</i> should have stated that there is no concern that the hand or foot might have come from a fetus with a sealed body or one whose face is flat. The Gemara answers: Reish Lakish did not raise the objection, <b>because Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> would have <b>responded to him</b> that the status of <b>a sealed body is</b> the same as that of <b>one whose face is flat.</b> There is no reason to mention both types of deformities.
The Gemara relates: <b>The sons of Rabbi Ḥiyya went out to the villages</b> to inspect their father’s fields. When <b>they came</b> back <b>to their father, he said to them:</b> Wasn’t <b>any incident brought to you</b> for a halakhic ruling? <b>They said to him:</b> A case of a woman who discharged a fetus with <b>a flat face was brought to us, and we deemed her impure</b> with the impurity of a woman after childbirth.
Rabbi Ḥiyya <b>said to them: Go out and deem pure that which you have deemed impure. What was your thinking</b> when you ruled that she is impure? Did you reason that as the matter is subject to a dispute, one should rule <b>stringently?</b> But your ruling <b>is a stringency that leads to a leniency, as you have given</b> the woman thirty-three <b>days of purity</b> after the birth of a male, following her period of impurity, which are the minimum days of purity established in the Torah for a woman who gave birth.
§ <b>It was stated:</b> With regard to a woman or female animal <b>who discharges an entity that has two backs and two spines, Rav says</b> that <b>in</b> the case of the <b>woman,</b> her discharged fetus <b>is not</b> considered <b>an offspring,</b> as it cannot survive, and therefore the woman does not have the ritual impurity caused by childbirth, and <b>in</b> the case of the <b>animal,</b> its fetus <b>is prohibited for consumption. And Shmuel says: In</b> the case of <b>a woman,</b> the discharged fetus is considered <b>an offspring,</b> and the woman is impure, and <b>in</b> the case of <b>an animal,</b> the fetus is <b>permitted for consumption.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what do</b> Rav and Shmuel <b>disagree?</b> The Gemara answers: They disagree <b>concerning</b> the statement <b>of Rav Ḥanin bar Abba, as Rav Ḥanin bar Abba said:</b> The verse states: “Nevertheless these you shall not eat of them that only chew the cud, or of them that only have the hoof cloven [<i>umimafrisei haparsa hashesua</i>]: The camel, and the hare, and the rock badger” (Deuteronomy 14:7). The apparently superfluous term <b><i>hashesua</i></b> is not a redundant description of the cloven hoof; it is referring to a separate <b>entity that has two backs and two spines</b> and therefore looks like an entirely cloven animal.
It is with regard to this prohibition that Rav and Shmuel disagree. <b>Rav says</b> that <b>there is no</b> such living <b>entity in the world, and when the Merciful One taught</b> this prohibition <b>to Moses, he taught</b> it <b>to</b> him with regard to a fetus that has two backs and two spines that is found <b>in the womb of its mother</b> after slaughter. <b>And Shmuel says</b> that <b>there is</b> such <b>an entity in the world, and when the Merciful One taught</b> this prohibition <b>to Moses, he taught</b> it <b>to him</b> with regard to a living animal <b>in the world, but</b> a fetus that has two backs and two spines <b>in the womb of its mother is permitted</b> for consumption.
<b>Rav Shimi bar Ḥiyya raised an objection to Rav</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus says: Any</b> priest <b>who has two backs and two spines is disqualified from</b> the Temple <b>service,</b> as he is blemished. <b>Evidently,</b> an entity <b>that</b> has two backs and two spines <b>can survive, and</b> this is <b>difficult for</b> the opinion of <b>Rav.</b> Rav <b>said to him: You are</b> clearly <b>Shimi,</b> i.e., you asked well. Yet the statement of Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus is not referring to one who literally has two backs and two spines, but rather <b>to</b> one <b>whose spine is crooked</b> and therefore appears as though he has two spines. One who actually has two backs and two spines cannot survive.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: Among discharged animal <b>fetuses, there are those that are forbidden</b> in consumption, as they have the halakhic status of carcasses of unslaughtered animals. Specifically, if an animal fetus is <b>born</b> in the <b>fourth</b> month of pregnancy in the case <b>of small</b> domesticated animals, where the pregnancy is normally five months long, or it is <b>born</b> in the <b>eighth</b> month of pregnancy in the case <b>of large</b> livestock, where the pregnancy is normally nine months long, or if the miscarriage occurred <b>from this</b> stage of the pregnancy <b>and earlier,</b> i.e., if the pregnancy ended before this stage, the animal is <b>forbidden.</b> This <b>excludes one that has two backs and two spines.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> does the <i>baraita</i> mean when it states that an animal with two backs and two spines is <b>excluded?</b> Does it <b>not</b> mean that it is <b>excluded from the category of</b> those <b>fetuses,</b> which are permitted for consumption if found inside their mother’s womb, <b>as</b> such animals are <b>forbidden even</b> while they are <b>in the wombs of their mothers?</b> This contradicts the opinion of Shmuel, who holds that an animal fetus of that type is permitted for consumption.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rav explains</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>according to his</b> line of <b>reasoning, and Shmuel explains</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>according to his</b> line of <b>reasoning. Rav explains</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>according to his</b> line of <b>reasoning,</b> as was assumed above: If an animal fetus is <b>born</b> in the <b>fourth</b> month of pregnancy in the case <b>of small</b> domesticated animals, or it is <b>born</b> in the <b>eighth</b> month of pregnancy in the case <b>of large</b> livestock, or if it was born <b>from this</b> stage of the pregnancy <b>and earlier,</b> the animal is <b>forbidden.</b>
<b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> In a case <b>where</b> the animal <b>emerged into the airspace of the world; but</b> if it was found <b>in its mother’s womb</b> after its mother was slaughtered, <b>it is permitted for</b> consumption. This <b>excludes</b> the case of a fetus <b>that has two backs and two spines, as even</b> if it is found <b>in the womb of its mother it is prohibited.</b>

Daf 24b

<b>And Shmuel explains</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>according to his</b> line of <b>reasoning,</b> in the following manner: If an animal fetus is <b>born</b> in the <b>fourth</b> month of pregnancy in the case <b>of small</b> domesticated animals, or it is <b>born</b> in the <b>eighth</b> month of pregnancy in the case <b>of large</b> livestock, or if it was born <b>from this</b> stage of the pregnancy <b>and earlier,</b> the animal is <b>forbidden. In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> In a case <b>when</b> the fetus’s <b>months</b> of gestation <b>were not completed; but</b> in a case when <b>its months</b> of gestation <b>were completed, it is permitted</b> for consumption even outside the womb. This <b>excludes</b> a fetus <b>that has two backs and two spines, as even in</b> a case where <b>its months</b> of gestation <b>were completed, if it emerged into the airspace of the world, it is forbidden,</b> whereas if it is found <b>in the womb of its mother, it is permitted.</b>
<b>A <i>tanna</i> taught</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>before Rav:</b> In the case of a woman <b>who discharges an entity</b> that has <b>a shapeless body,</b> i.e., it does not have the outline of limbs, <b>or an entity</b> that has <b>a shapeless head,</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>its mother should be impure</b> with the impurity of a woman after <b>childbirth.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “If a woman bears seed and gives birth to a male,</b> she shall be impure seven days; as in the days of the menstruation of her sickness she shall be impure. <b>And on the eighth day</b> the flesh of his foreskin <b>shall be circumcised”</b> (Leviticus 12:2–3).
Those verses teach that the impurity of a woman after childbirth applies only to one who gave birth to a child <b>that is fit for circumcision</b> on the <b>eighth</b> day, <b>excluding these</b> cases, <b>where</b> the child <b>is not fit for circumcision</b> on the <b>eighth</b> day, as it cannot survive that long. Consequently, this woman does not have the impurity of a woman after childbirth. <b>Rav said to</b> the <i>tanna</i>: <b>And conclude</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>like this:</b> Excluding these cases, where the child is not fit for circumcision on the eighth day, <b>and</b> excluding the case of a woman who discharges a child <b>that has two backs and two spines.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba thought to perform an action,</b> i.e., to issue a ruling, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Shmuel,</b> that a woman who gives birth to a child with two backs and two spines is impure. <b>Rav Huna said to him: What is your thinking?</b> That as this matter is subject to a dispute, one should rule <b>stringently?</b> Your ruling <b>is a stringency that leads to a leniency, as you have given</b> the woman a period of thirty-three days following her period of impurity when any blood that emerges is <b>blood of purity. In any event,</b> you should <b>perform,</b> i.e., issue your ruling, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav, as we maintain</b> that <b>the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav with regard to ritual matters, whether</b> his opinion leads <b>to a leniency or to a stringency.</b>
§ <b>Rava says:</b> The Sages <b>said</b> that <b>a woman can give birth</b> to a viable offspring <b>after nine</b> months of pregnancy <b>or after seven</b> months of pregnancy; but if a woman gives birth after eight months of pregnancy, the child cannot survive and is stillborn. Similarly, <b>a large domesticated animal gives birth</b> to a viable offspring <b>after nine</b> months of pregnancy, and if it discharges a fetus after only eight months, the newborn animal cannot survive. With this in mind, Rava asked: Can a large domesticated animal <b>give birth</b> to a viable offspring <b>after seven</b> months of pregnancy, like a human, <b>or</b> can such an animal <b>not give birth</b> to a viable offspring after only seven months?
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to this dilemma from the aforementioned <i>baraita</i>: If an animal discharges <b>from this</b> stage of the pregnancy <b>and earlier,</b> the fetus is <b>forbidden</b> in consumption as an unslaughtered animal carcass. <b>What, is it not</b> referring <b>to large</b> livestock, which indicates that large livestock do not give birth to a viable offspring after only seven months of pregnancy? The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> the reference is specifically <b>to small</b> domesticated animals, which do not give birth to a viable offspring until after five months of pregnancy.
The Gemara raises a difficulty with regard to this answer: <b>What is this? Granted, if you say</b> that the reference is <b>to large</b> livestock, it is <b>necessary</b> for the <i>baraita</i> to state that an animal does not give birth to a viable offspring after less than a complete period of pregnancy, as otherwise it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since in</b> the case of <b>a woman</b> who gives birth after seven months the baby <b>survives,</b> it is logical that <b>in</b> the case of a large domesticated <b>animal</b> that gives birth after seven months the newborn <b>also survives,</b> and it is therefore permitted for consumption. Consequently, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us that</b> such an animal <b>does not survive.</b>
<b>But if you say</b> that the ruling in the <i>baraita</i>, that if an animal discharged a fetus before the period of gestation was completed then the fetus is prohibited, <b>was stated with regard to small</b> domesticated animals, isn’t it <b>obvious</b> that if a sheep or goat fetus was discharged at this stage it cannot survive? <b>Can it survive after</b> only <b>three months</b> of gestation?
The Gemara answers that in fact <b>it is necessary</b> for the <i>baraita</i> to state this <i>halakha</i> with regard to small domesticated animals, as otherwise it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>any</b> mammal that is born <b>two months less</b> than its complete gestation <b>survives,</b> just as a human born at seven months of gestation survives. Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that a sheep or goat that is born at three months of gestation cannot survive and is forbidden for consumption.
§ <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> In the case of a woman <b>who discharges</b> a fetus that has <b>the form of a lilith,</b> a female demon with wings and a human face, <b>its mother is impure</b> with the impurity of a woman after <b>childbirth,</b> as <b>it is</b> a viable <b>offspring, only it has wings. This is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yosei said: An incident</b> occurred <b>in Simoni involving a certain</b> woman <b>who discharged</b> a fetus that had <b>the form of a lilith, and</b> the <b>incident was brought before the Sages; and they said</b> that <b>it is</b> a viable <b>offspring, only it has wings.</b>
There was a case of a woman <b>who discharged</b> an item that had <b>the form of a snake. Ḥanina,</b> the <b>son of Rabbi Yehoshua’s brother, ruled</b> that <b>its mother is impure</b> with the impurity of a woman after <b>childbirth. Rabbi Yosef went and told</b> this <b>matter to Rabban Gamliel.</b> Rabban Gamliel <b>sent to Rabbi Yehoshua: Take</b> hold of <b>your nephew and come</b> to me, so that I may admonish him for his ruling.
<b>While they were going</b> to Rabban Gamliel, <b>Ḥanina’s daughter-in-law went out to greet</b> Rabbi Yehoshua, and <b>said to him: My teacher, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a woman <b>who discharges</b> an item that looks <b>like a snake?</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to her: Its mother is pure. She said to him: But my mother-in-law said to me in your name</b> that <b>its mother is impure</b> in such a case, <b>and</b> that you <b>said to her: For what reason</b> is she impure? It is <b>because the pupil of</b> a snake <b>is round like that of a human. Due to her statement, Rabbi Yehoshua remembered</b> that he had issued such a ruling. He subsequently <b>sent</b> a message <b>to Rabban Gamliel: Ḥanina issued the ruling based on my</b> own statement.
<b>Abaye said: Conclude from</b> this incident that <b>a Torah scholar [<i>tzurva merabbanan</i>] who says</b> a halakhic <b>matter should say the reason</b> for his statement, <b>so that when</b> his colleagues <b>remind him</b> of his reasoning, <b>he will remember</b> that ruling, as happened to Rabbi Yehoshua.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> A woman <b>who discharges a gestational sac full of fluid, full of blood,</b> or <b>full of</b> different <b>colors</b> need <b>not be concerned that</b> it was <b>an offspring. But if</b> the sac <b>was</b> one in which <b>tissue developed,</b> her halakhic status is that of a woman after childbirth. Since the sex of the embryo is unknown, the woman <b>observes</b> the strictures of a woman who gave birth both <b>to a male and to a female;</b> she is impure for fourteen days like a woman who gave birth to a female, but blood that she sees thereafter is pure only until forty days after birth, like a woman who gave birth to a male. A woman <b>who discharges a sandal</b> fetus, i.e., one that has the form of a sandal fish, <b>and</b> one who discharges <b>an afterbirth observes</b> the strictures of a woman who gave birth both <b>to a male and to a female.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Granted,</b> one can understand why a woman who discharges a gestational sac full of <b>blood or water</b> is pure, as such an item <b>is nothing,</b> i.e., it is not an offspring. <b>But</b> if the gestational sac was full of different <b>colors, let us be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps it was an offspring and</b> it <b>liquefied. Abaye says</b> in response: <b>How much undiluted wine,</b> which can be harmful to an embryo, <b>did the mother of this</b> purported embryo <b>drink, that her embryo was liquefied in her womb?</b> In other words, there is no such concern.
<b>Rava says</b> that there is a different explanation: <b>We learned</b> in the mishna that the gestational sac was <b>full</b> of different colors, <b>and if it is so,</b> that there was an embryo in the sac <b>that liquefied,</b> the sac would have been <b>lacking</b> some of the mass of the liquified portion. <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava says</b> that there is yet another explanation: <b>We learned</b> in the mishna that the gestational sac is full of different <b>colors, and if it is so,</b> that there was an embryo there <b>that liquefied, it would all be of one color.</b>
With regard to the effect of drinking wine on a person’s body, <b>it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Abba Shaul says: I used to be a gravedigger, and I would observe the bones of corpses.</b> I discovered that <b>the bones of one who drinks</b> too much <b>undiluted wine</b> during his lifetime look <b>burnt, the bones of</b> one who drinks too much <b>diluted</b> wine <b>are black,</b> and <b>the bones of</b> one who drinks the <b>appropriate</b> amount of wine <b>are fat,</b> i.e., full of marrow. <b>And</b> furthermore, I discovered that <b>the bones of anyone who drinks</b> much <b>more than he eats</b> look <b>burnt, the bones of</b> one who <b>eats</b> much <b>more than he drinks are black,</b> and <b>the bones of one who</b> eats and drinks <b>appropriate</b> amounts <b>are fat.</b>
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Abba Shaul says</b> the following, <b>and some say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> said it: <b>I used to be a gravedigger. Once I ran after a deer, and I entered the thighbone of a corpse; and</b> it was so large that <b>I ran after</b> the deer for <b>three parasangs</b> inside the thighbone, <b>and</b> although <b>I did not reach</b> the <b>deer,</b> the <b>thighbone did not end. When I came back</b> and related this to the Sages, <b>they said to me: It was</b> evidently the thighbone <b>of Og, king of Bashan,</b> a known giant.
<b>It is</b> likewise <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Abba Shaul says: I used to be a gravedigger. Once</b> a burial <b>cave opened up underneath</b> where I was standing, <b>and I</b> found myself <b>standing in the eye socket of a corpse until my nose. When I came back</b> and told this to the Sages, <b>they said to me: It was</b> evidently <b>the eye of Absalom.</b>
<b>And lest you say</b> that <b>Abba Shaul was a midget,</b> and therefore he was capable of standing in an eye socket until his nose, <b>Abba Shaul was the tallest</b> person <b>in his generation. And Rabbi Tarfon reached</b> only <b>his shoulder, and Rabbi Tarfon was the tallest</b> person <b>in his generation. And Rabbi Meir reached</b> only <b>the shoulder of</b> Rabbi Tarfon, and <b>Rabbi Meir was the tallest</b> person <b>in his generation. And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>reached</b> only <b>the shoulder of</b> Rabbi Meir, and <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>was the tallest</b> person <b>in his generation.</b>
The Gemara continues: <b>And Rabbi Ḥiyya reached</b> only <b>the shoulder of</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, <b>and Rabbi Ḥiyya was the tallest</b> person <b>in his generation. And Rav reached</b> only <b>the shoulder of</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya, and <b>Rav was the tallest</b> person <b>in his generation. And Rav Yehuda reached</b> only <b>the shoulder of</b> Rav, <b>and Rav Yehuda was the tallest</b> person <b>in his generation. And Adda the attendant [<i>dayyala</i>] reached</b> only <b>the shoulder of</b> Rav Yehuda,

Daf 25a

and when <b>the governor [<i>parashtevina</i>] of Pumbedita would stand</b> next <b>to Adda the attendant,</b> he would reach only <b>half of his</b> height. <b>And</b> when <b>everyone</b> else <b>in the world would stand</b> next <b>to the governor of Pumbedita,</b> they would reach only <b>his loins [<i>ḥartzeih</i>].</b>
§ The students <b>asked Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi: In the case of a woman <b>who discharges a gestational sac full of flesh, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Does she have the impurity of a woman after childbirth? Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to them: I have not heard</b> from my teachers the <i>halakha</i> in this case.
<b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei, said to him: This</b> is what <b>my father,</b> i.e., Rabbi Yosei ben Ḥalafta, one of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s teachers, <b>said:</b> If a woman discharged a gestational sac <b>full of blood, she is impure</b> with the impurity of <b>a menstruating woman.</b> If it is <b>full of flesh, she is impure</b> with the impurity of a woman after <b>childbirth.</b>
Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to him: If you had told us</b> an entirely <b>new statement in the name of your father,</b> no part of which was also stated by another Sage, <b>we would have listened to you,</b> i.e., we would have accepted the statement as <i>halakha</i>. But <b>now</b> that you stated two <i>halakhot</i>, one with regard to a woman who discharged a gestational sac full of blood, and the other with regard to a woman who discharged a gestational sac full of flesh, the entire statement cannot be accepted as <i>halakha</i>.
Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi explains: <b>From</b> the fact that Rabbi Yosei <b>said this first clause</b> of his statement, with regard to a gestational sac full of blood, <b>in accordance with an individual</b> opinion, i.e., <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Sumakhos, who said in the name of Rabbi Meir</b> that the woman is impure, contrary to the opinion of the other Sages, it follows that with regard to <b>this</b> latter statement <b>as well,</b> with regard to a gestational sac full of flesh, one can say that <b>perhaps</b> Rabbi Yosei <b>said it in accordance with</b> the opinion of another individual Sage, <b>Rabbi Yehoshua. And</b> the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of a woman <b>who discharges a gestational sac in which tissue did not develop, Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> It has the status of <b>an offspring,</b> and the woman has the impurity of a woman after childbirth; <b>and the Rabbis say: It is not an offspring,</b> and the woman is pure. The opinion of Rabbi Yosei that a woman who discharged a gestational sac full of flesh is impure might be in accordance with the ruling of Rabbi Yehoshua, which is not accepted as <i>halakha</i>, since the majority of the other Sages disagree with him. Therefore, the <i>halakha</i> cannot be decided in accordance with either part of the statement of Rabbi Yosei.
<b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says in the name of Rabbi Oshaya:</b> The <b>dispute</b> between Rabbi Yehoshua and the Rabbis applies <b>in</b> a case where the amniotic fluid is <b>turbid,</b> as Rabbi Yehoshua holds that the turbidity indicates that there was likely an embryo in the sac that liquefied. <b>But in</b> a case where the amniotic fluid is <b>clear, everyone agrees</b> that the discharged sac <b>is not</b> considered <b>an offspring. And Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says:</b> The <b>dispute</b> applies <b>in</b> a case where the amniotic fluid is <b>clear.</b>
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: What does Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi mean? Does he mean that the <b>dispute</b> applies only <b>in</b> a case where the amniotic fluid is <b>clear, but in</b> a case where it is <b>turbid, everyone agrees</b> that it has the halakhic status of <b>an offspring? Or perhaps</b> Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi means that the <b>dispute</b> applies <b>in this</b> case <b>and in that</b> case, i.e., the Rabbis hold that the sac does not have the status of an offspring even if the amniotic fluid is turbid. The Gemara concludes that the dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the opinion that the dispute between Rabbi Yehoshua and the Rabbis applies only in a case where the amniotic fluid is turbid. It is taught in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Ḥananya,</b> who is the same Rabbi Yehoshua who disagrees with the Rabbis with regard to the case of a woman who discharges a gestational sac in which tissue did not develop, <b>taught this</b> following proof for his opinion that the woman is impure: It is stated: <b>“And the Lord God made for Adam and for his wife garments of skins, and clothed them”</b> (Genesis 3:21). This <b>teaches that the Holy One, Blessed be He, does not make skin for a person unless he is</b> already <b>created,</b> as God first created Adam and Eve, and then gave them skin. Consequently, the existence of a gestational sac proves that there is an offspring.
<b>Evidently,</b> according to Rabbi Yehoshua <b>the matter</b> of whether or not an embryo is considered offspring <b>is dependent on</b> whether or not there is <b>skin,</b> and there <b>is no difference</b> whether the amniotic fluid is <b>turbid, and</b> there <b>is no difference</b> whether it is <b>clear.</b>
<b>Granted, if you say</b> that the <b>dispute</b> applies <b>in</b> a case where it is <b>clear, that is</b> why it <b>was necessary</b> for Rabbi Yehoshua to derive from <b>a verse</b> that an embryo that has skin is considered an offspring. <b>But if you say</b> that the <b>dispute</b> applies <b>in</b> a case where the amniotic fluid is <b>turbid,</b> but Rabbi Yehoshua concedes that the woman is pure if it is clear, <b>why do I</b> need <b>a verse</b> to teach that if the amniotic fluid is turbid the woman is impure? <b>It is logical</b> that where the amniotic fluid is turbid there was probably an embryo that liquefied. <b>Rather, conclude from it</b> that the <b>dispute</b> applies <b>in</b> a case where the amniotic fluid is <b>clear.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>Conclude from it</b> that this is correct.
<b>And likewise,</b> just as Rabbi Oshaya interprets the dispute between Rabbi Yehoshua and the Rabbis as referring to a case where the amniotic fluid is turbid, <b>Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh says:</b> The <b>dispute</b> between Rabbi Yehoshua and the Rabbis applies <b>in</b> a case where the amniotic fluid is <b>turbid; but in</b> a case where the amniotic fluid is <b>clear, everyone agrees</b> that the discharged sac <b>is not</b> considered <b>an offspring.</b>
<b>Rava raised an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Naḥman</b> from a mishna that specifies the obligations that apply to firstborn animals (<i>Bekhorot</i> 19b):<b>But</b> the Sages <b>said</b> that not only does a viable offspring exempt any subsequent offspring from being counted a firstborn, but the same applies to <b>an indication of the offspring</b> that is discharged from the womb. The indication <b>in a small animal</b> is a <b>murky discharge</b> from the womb, <b>in a large</b> animal it is the emergence of <b>an afterbirth,</b> and <b>in a woman</b> the indication is <b>a gestational sac or an afterbirth.</b>
Rava infers: <b>And yet</b> the miscarriage of <b>a gestational sac in</b> the case of a large <b>animal does not exempt</b> the animal’s subsequent offspring from being counted a firstborn. <b>Granted, if you say</b> that the <b>dispute</b> between Rabbi Yehoshua and the Rabbis applies <b>in</b> a case where the amniotic fluid is <b>clear,</b> it is <b>due to that</b> reason that the mishna differentiates between a large animal and a woman with regard to a gestational sac.
Rava explains: <b>With regard to a woman, as the</b> aforementioned <b>verse:</b> “And the Lord God made for Adam and for his wife garments of skins,” <b>includes</b> in the definition of offspring a gestational sac, i.e., skin, one can say that such <b>a gestational sac exempts</b> subsequent births from the obligations of primogeniture. By contrast, <b>in</b> the case of <b>an animal, as the verse does not include</b> a gestational sac in the definition of offspring, discharging <b>a gestational sac does not exempt</b> the animal’s subsequent offspring from being considered a firstborn.
<b>But if you say</b> that the <b>dispute</b> applies <b>in</b> a case where the amniotic fluid is <b>turbid,</b> and Rabbi Yehoshua deems the woman impure due to the likelihood that there was an embryo that liquefied, <b>since</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>is</b> based on <b>logic, what is different</b> in the case of <b>a woman, and what is different</b> in the case of <b>an animal?</b> Rabbi Yehoshua’s reasoning applies equally to both. Evidently, the dispute applies in a case where the amniotic fluid is clear.
The Gemara answers: <b>Do you hold</b> that <b>it is obvious to Rabbi Yehoshua</b> that a gestational sac in which the amniotic fluid is turbid has the halakhic status of an offspring? That is not so; rather, <b>Rabbi Yehoshua is uncertain</b> of its halakhic status, <b>and</b> therefore <b>here,</b> in this case, he rules <b>stringently, and there</b> he also rules <b>stringently.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: First of all, <b>with regard to</b> a situation where <b>a woman</b> discharged a gestational sac in which the amniotic fluid was turbid, in <b>which</b> case the obligation of primogeniture <b>is a monetary matter,</b> i.e., the obligation to redeem the newborn child by paying money to a priest, the subsequent births are exempt, in accordance with the principle that <b>uncertainty</b> with regard to <b>monetary matters</b> is treated <b>leniently.</b>
By contrast, <b>with regard to an animal,</b> in <b>which</b> case firstborn status <b>is a ritual matter, as there are</b> prohibitions <b>involving,</b> i.e., against, <b>shearing</b> the animal’s wool <b>and</b> using the animal for <b>labor</b> before it incurs a blemish, the discharged gestational sac is not considered an offspring and does not exempt subsequent births from the obligations of firstborn status, as <b>uncertainty</b> with regard to <b>ritual matters</b> is treated <b>stringently. So too, with regard to</b> the impurity of <b>a woman</b> who discharged a gestational sac, she is deemed impure, as <b>uncertainty</b> with regard to <b>impurity</b> is treated <b>stringently,</b> which means that for the purposes of this <i>halakha</i> a gestational sac is considered an offspring.
The Gemara asks: <b>And is</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>uncertain</b> about the <i>halakha</i> of a woman who discharges a gestational sac? <b>But doesn’t he cite a verse</b> as proof that the woman has the impurity of one who gave birth? The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yehoshua maintains that the woman is impure <b>by rabbinic</b> law, <b>and the verse</b> he cites <b>is a mere support</b> for this <i>halakha</i>; it is not the actual source.
<b>Rav Ḥanina bar Shelamya said to Rav: This</b> is the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, who told his students that he did not hear from his teachers the <i>halakha</i> in the case of a woman who discharged a gestational sac full of flesh; and <b>this</b> is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei,</b> who cited his father’s opinion that in such a case the woman is impure. <b>And this</b> is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Oshaya,</b> that the dispute between Rabbi Yehoshua and the Rabbis applies only in a case where the amniotic fluid is turbid; <b>and</b> finally <b>this</b> is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi,</b> who holds that the dispute applies if the amniotic fluid is clear. <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>does the Master hold?</b>
Rav <b>said to</b> Rav Ḥanina bar Shelamya: <b>I say</b> that <b>both</b> in <b>this</b> case, where the amniotic fluid is turbid, <b>and</b> in <b>that</b> case, where the fluid is clear, the woman does <b>not</b> need to be <b>concerned</b> that she has the status of a woman who gave birth to an offspring.
<b>And Shmuel says:</b> In <b>both this</b> case <b>and that</b> case, the woman must be <b>concerned</b> that the discharged gestational sac has the status of an offspring, and therefore she is considered impure like a woman who gave birth. <b>And Shmuel follows his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning</b> here, <b>as when Rav Dimi came</b> and transmitted many halakhic traditions, the latter <b>said: In Neharde’a</b> the Sages <b>never deemed</b> a woman who discharged <b>a gestational sac pure, except for</b> the case of <b>a certain gestational sac that came before Shmuel, who placed a hair on this side</b> of that sac, <b>and it was visible from that side.</b> Shmuel <b>said,</b> based on this test: <b>If it were so, that</b> there <b>was an offspring</b> in the sac, <b>it would not have been so transparent.</b> He therefore deemed the woman pure, but his ruling applied only in that extreme case.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>But if</b> the sac <b>was</b> one in which <b>tissue developed,</b> the halakhic status of the woman is that of a woman after childbirth. Since the sex of the embryo is unknown, she observes the strictures of a woman who gave birth both to a male and to a female; she is impure for fourteen days like a woman who gave birth to a female, but blood that she sees thereafter is pure only until forty days after birth, like a woman who gave birth to a male. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>What is</b> the definition of <b>a gestational sac</b> in which <b>tissue developed? Abba Shaul says: The beginning of the formation of</b> the embryo <b>is from its head, and its two eyes</b> look <b>like two drops,</b> similar to the eyes <b>of a fly. Rabbi Ḥiyya teaches:</b> These eyes must be <b>distant from each other.</b> Furthermore, <b>its two nostrils</b> look <b>like two drops,</b> similar to the nostrils <b>of a fly.</b>
<b>Rabbi Ḥiyya teaches: And</b> these eyes must be <b>close to each other. And its mouth stretches</b> along the width of its face <b>like a strand of hair. And its body is like</b> the size of <b>a lentil. And if it was female,</b> its vagina can be <b>discerned</b> by the appearance <b>of</b> a line like a cracked grain of <b>barley</b> oriented <b>along the length of</b> its body.
<b>And it does not have the shape of arms and legs</b> at this stage. <b>And it is said with regard to</b> an embryo at this stage, <b>in</b> the texts of <b>tradition,</b> the Prophets: <b>“Have You not poured me out as milk, and curdled me like cheese? You have clothed me with skin and flesh, and knit me together with bones and sinews. You have granted me life and favor, and Your providence has preserved my spirit”</b> (Job 10:10–12).
<b>And one does not examine it with water</b> to discover its sex, <b>as water is</b> too <b>strong,</b>

Daf 25b

<b>and dissolves it. Rather, one examines it with oil, as oil is soft and cleans</b> the embryo so that its sex can be discerned. <b>And one views</b> it <b>only in</b> the light of <b>the sun.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>How does one examine</b> the embryo? The Gemara expresses surprise at this question: <b>How does one examine it</b> to determine whether it has the halakhic status of an offspring? Clearly, one examines it <b>as we</b> just <b>said. Rather,</b> the question is as follows: <b>In what</b> manner <b>does one examine it to ascertain whether it is male or</b> whether <b>it is female?</b>
<b>Abba Shaul bar Nash, and some say Abba Shaul bar Remash, says: One brings a sliver of wood whose top is smooth, and he moves</b> it along the embryo <b>in that place,</b> i.e., the sex organ. <b>If</b> the sliver <b>is caught,</b> i.e., its movement is not smooth, <b>it is known that</b> the embryo <b>is male,</b> as its member interfered with the movement of the sliver. <b>And if</b> the sliver is <b>not</b> caught, <b>it is known that it is female.</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh says: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i>, that if the movement of the sliver is not smooth then the embryo is male, <b>only</b> if the sliver was moved along the sex organ of the embryo <b>from below to above; but</b> if it was moved <b>from the sides,</b> from one side to the other, the fact that it was not smooth does not prove that the embryo is male, as one can <b>say</b> that <b>the sides of the womb</b> interfered.
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava says:</b> The complete version of the <i>baraita</i> is <b>taught</b> as follows: <b>If it was female,</b> its vagina can be <b>discerned</b> by the appearance <b>of</b> a line like <b>a cracked</b> grain of <b>barley</b> oriented along the length of its body. <b>Rav Naḥman objects to this: But perhaps it is</b> not the vagina but <b>the recess between the testes,</b> and the embryo is male. <b>Abaye said</b> to him: <b>Now,</b> at this stage of development, <b>the testes</b> of the embryo <b>themselves are not discernible.</b> Is it possible that <b>the recess between the testes is discernible?</b>
The <i>baraita</i> teaches that at this stage an embryo does not have the shape of arms and legs. <b>Rabbi Amram says</b> that <b>it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that when an embryo’s arms and legs start to take shape, <b>its two thighs</b> look <b>like two strings of crimson</b> thread <b>[<i>zehorit</i>]. And Rabbi Amram says with regard to</b> this matter that the thighs look <b>like</b> two strings <b>of the woof,</b> which are thicker than those of the warp. The <i>baraita</i> adds: <b>And its two arms</b> look <b>like two strings of crimson</b> thread<b>. And Rabbi Amram says with regard to</b> this matter that the arms look <b>like</b> two strings <b>of the warp.</b>
<b>Shmuel said to Rav Yehuda: <i>Shinnana</i>, do not perform an action,</b> i.e., do not issue a practical ruling deeming a woman who discharges an embryo at this stage of development impure, <b>unless</b> the embryo <b>has grown hair.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And did Shmuel</b> actually <b>say that? But doesn’t Shmuel say</b> with regard to a woman who discharged a gestational sac that <b>both</b> in <b>this</b> case, where the amniotic fluid is turbid, <b>and</b> in <b>that</b> case, where the fluid is clear, the woman must be <b>concerned</b> that the discharged gestational sac might have the status of an offspring, which would mean that she is impure even without the growth of hair on the embryo?
<b>Rav Ami bar Shmuel says:</b> This matter was <b>explained to me by Mar Shmuel:</b> As for <b>being concerned</b> that perhaps she is impure, the woman must be <b>concerned,</b> due to the uncertainty whether she discharged an offspring. But <b>we do not give her</b> the <b>days of purity</b> that follow the period of impurity for a woman who gave birth, <b>unless</b> the embryo <b>has grown hair.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say that Shmuel is uncertain</b> whether a gestational sac has the halakhic status of an offspring? <b>But</b> there was an incident involving <b>a certain gestational sac that was brought before Mar Shmuel,</b> and Shmuel <b>said: This</b> embryo <b>is forty-one days old. And</b> Shmuel subsequently <b>calculated</b> the amount of time that had passed <b>from the day that</b> the woman <b>went to</b> perform <b>immersion</b> in a ritual bath <b>until that day, and it was only forty days.</b>
<b>And he said to</b> the local court: <b>This</b> husband <b>engaged in intercourse with</b> his wife when she was <b>a menstruating woman. They bound</b> the husband <b>and he confessed.</b> Since Shmuel was so proficient in embryology, why was he unsure about the halakhic status of a gestational sac? The Gemara answers: <b>Shmuel</b> himself <b>is different, as his strength,</b> i.e., his proficiency, was <b>great.</b> His general ruling that the halakhic status of a gestational sac is uncertain applies to people who are not as proficient as he is.
§ The mishna teaches that a woman <b>who discharges a sandal</b> fetus or one who discharges an afterbirth observes the strictures of a woman who gave birth both to a male and to a female. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A sandal</b> fetus has <b>a similar</b> appearance <b>to</b> a certain <b>fish of</b> the <b>sea</b> known as a sandal fish;it looks as though <b>it is</b> a full-fledged <b>offspring from the outset, but it was mashed. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: A sandal</b> fetus has an appearance that is <b>similar to the tongue of the large bull.</b> Students <b>testified in the name of our teachers</b> that for <b>a sandal</b> fetus to have the halakhic status of an offspring, it <b>requires the shape of a face.</b>
<b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is that <b>a sandal</b> fetus <b>requires the shape of a face</b> for it to have the status of an offspring. <b>Rav Adda says</b> that <b>Rav Yosef says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak says: A sandal</b> fetus <b>requires the shape of a face, but</b> the face does not need to be in its proper location; <b>even</b> if the face is <b>on the back of its</b> head, the fetus has the status of an offspring. <b>A parable to</b> which this situation can be compared is that of <b>a person who slapped another</b> in the face <b>and pushed his face back.</b> Here too, the face of the sandal fetus was pushed back due to external pressure.
The Gemara relates: <b>In the days of Rabbi Yannai,</b> the other Sages <b>wished to deem pure</b> a woman who discharges <b>a sandal</b> fetus <b>that does not have the shape of a face. Rabbi Yannai said to them: You have deemed pure</b> women who discharge <b>offspring.</b> Rabbi Yannai holds that even a sandal fetus that does not have the shape of a face is considered an offspring.
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that students <b>testified in the name of our teachers</b> that for <b>a sandal</b> fetus to have the halakhic status of an offspring it <b>requires the shape of a face? Rav Beivai bar Abaye says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> in response: <b>This mishna,</b> i.e., the ruling to which the students testified, <b>is taught from the testimony of Rabbi Neḥunya.</b> In other words, this ruling is the opinion of an individual <i>tanna</i>, which is not accepted. <b>Rabbi Zeira says: Rav Beivai merited that his</b> ruling of <b><i>halakha</i>,</b> which he transmitted in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan, was accepted. <b>As he and I were</b> both <b>sitting before Rabbi Yoḥanan when</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said this <i>halakha</i>, but</b> Rav Beivai <b>said it first</b> to the other Sages, <b>and</b> thereby <b>merited</b> that <b>it</b> was ascribed to him.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>Why</b> does the mishna <b>mention</b> that if a woman discharged <b>a sandal</b> fetus she observes the strictures of a woman who gave birth both to a male and to a female? Since <b>there is no</b> such thing as <b>a sandal</b> fetus <b>that</b> does <b>not</b> have another <b>offspring with it,</b> which mashed it and gave it the form of a sandal fish, in any case the woman has the impurity of a woman after childbirth.
The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> it is <b>a female</b> offspring that <b>is born with</b> the sandal fetus, it is <b>indeed</b> unnecessary to mention the <i>halakha</i> of the sandal fetus, as the woman is in any case impure for two weeks. But <b>here we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where a male is born with it,</b> on account of which the woman would be impure for only seven days were it not for the sandal fetus.
In this case, it is necessary for the mishna to state that the woman observes the strictures of one who gave birth both to a male and to a female, <b>lest you say</b> that <b>since Rav Yitzḥak bar Ami says</b> that the sex of a fetus is determined at the moment of conception, as, if the <b>woman emits seed first she gives birth to a male</b> and if the <b>man emits seed first she gives birth to a female,</b> therefore, it can be concluded <b>from</b> the fact <b>that this</b> offspring that was born with the sandal fetus <b>is male,</b> that <b>this</b> sandal fetus <b>is also male.</b>
Lest this reasoning be accepted, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that the woman must observe the strictures of a woman who gave birth to a female as well. This is because one can <b>say</b> that perhaps <b>both</b> the man and the woman <b>emitted seed at the same time,</b> and consequently <b>this</b> offspring <b>is male and that</b> sandal fetus <b>is female.</b>
<b>Alternatively,</b> it can be suggested that it is necessary for the mishna to state this <i>halakha</i> even with regard to a case where the twin of the sandal fetus is female, <b>as, if</b> the woman <b>gives birth to</b> the <b>female before sunset and</b> gives birth to the <b>sandal</b> fetus <b>after sunset,</b> which is considered the next day, the sex of the sandal fetus affects the count of the woman’s periods of impurity and purity.
If the sandal fetus is male, the woman’s status as a woman after childbirth ends after the eightieth day from the birth of the female offspring, and <b>she counts the beginning of</b> the period when seeing blood renders her impure as <b>a menstruating woman from</b> the birth of <b>the first</b> offspring, i.e., the female. <b>But</b> if the sandal fetus is female, the woman has the status of a woman after childbirth until after the eightieth day from its birth, which is the eighty-first day from the birth of the first offspring. If so, she counts <b>the beginning of</b> the period when seeing blood renders her impure as <b>a menstruating woman from</b> the birth of <b>the last</b> offspring, i.e., the sandal fetus.
The Gemara discusses why the case of a woman who discharged a sandal fetus is mentioned in other <i>mishnayot</i>, given that a sandal fetus always has a twin. First the Gemara discusses the <i>halakha</i> of a woman who discharged <b>a sandal</b> fetus <b>that we learned</b> in a mishna

Daf 26a

<b>with regard to firstborns</b> (<i>Bekhorot</i> 46a), which states that the son who is born after a sandal fetus has the status of a firstborn with regard to inheritance but not with regard to the obligation of redemption from a priest. The Gemara asks: <b>For what</b> matter is that <b><i>halakha</i></b> relevant? Since the sandal fetus has a twin that is born with it, the subsequent son is in any case exempt from redemption.
The Gemara answers: That <i>halakha</i> is relevant <b>for</b> a case where the sandal fetus’s twin <b>comes</b> out of the womb <b>after it.</b> The mishna teaches that as the sandal fetus was born first, its twin is considered <b>a firstborn with regard to inheritance, but</b> it is <b>not a firstborn with regard to</b> redemption from <b>a priest.</b>
The Gemara discusses the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a woman who discharged <b>a sandal</b> fetus <b>that we learned</b> in a mishna <b>in</b> tractate <b><i>Karetot</i></b> (7b), which states that such a woman brings the offering of a woman who gave birth. The Gemara asks: <b>For what</b> matter is that <b><i>halakha</i></b> relevant? In any case that woman is obligated to bring the offering of a woman who gave birth, due to the twin.
The Gemara answers: It is necessary for the mishna to state <b>that if</b> a woman <b>gives birth to</b> a full-fledged <b>offspring by means of caesarean section, and</b> to <b>a sandal</b> fetus in a regular manner <b>through</b> the <b>womb, in</b> such a case <b>she brings an offering for</b> giving birth to the <b>sandal</b> fetus, despite the fact that she does not bring an offering for the full-fledged offspring, as one does not bring an offering for a birth by caesarean section.
The Gemara asks: <b>But according to Rabbi Shimon, who said</b> that an offspring which is <b>delivered by means of caesarean section is</b> considered <b>a full-fledged offspring,</b> and its mother does bring an offering, <b>what is there to say?</b> Why is it necessary for the mishna to state this <i>halakha</i> if the woman must bring an offering regardless of the sandal fetus?
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya says:</b> It is necessary for the mishna to state <b>that if</b> a woman <b>gives birth to</b> the full-fledged <b>offspring while she is a gentile,</b> when the <i>halakhot</i> of a woman after childbirth do not apply to her, and she immediately converts to Judaism <b>and</b> gives birth to the <b>sandal</b> fetus <b>after she converted</b> and became obligated to observe the <i>halakhot</i> of a woman after childbirth, <b>that she brings an offering for the sandal</b> fetus.
<b>The Sages said</b> the answers to these questions <b>before Rav Pappa, and</b> they asked him: <b>And are these answers</b> correct? Can it be suggested that the sandal fetus was born before or after the twin fetus? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>when</b> a sandal fetus and the full-fledged offspring <b>exit</b> the womb, <b>they exit only wrapped</b> around one another?
<b>Rav Pappa said</b> in response: <b>Conclude from it</b> that the sandal fetus and its twin do not lie side by side, but rather the full-fledged <b>offspring encounters the sandal</b> fetus <b>at half its</b> height, i.e., the head of the full-fledged offspring presses into the abdomen of the sandal fetus. <b>And</b> when they are born, the full-fledged offspring <b>pushes</b> the sandal fetus <b>toward</b> the direction <b>its head</b> is pointing, to the entrance of the womb, causing the sandal fetus to be born first. Therefore, the mishna <b>with regard to firstborns</b> can be explained as referring to a case <b>where</b> the fetuses <b>exited</b> the womb <b>with their heads</b> first, <b>as</b> in such a case the <b>sandal</b> fetus <b>emerges first.</b> By contrast, the mishna <b>in</b> tractate <b><i>Karetot</i></b> is referring to a case <b>where they emerged with their feet</b> first, <b>as</b> in such a case the full-fledged <b>offspring emerges first.</b>
<b>Rav Huna bar Taḥlifa says in the name of Rava: You</b> may <b>even say</b> that the two fetuses lie <b>precisely</b> side by side, <b>and</b> you should <b>reverse</b> Rav Pappa’s <b><i>halakha</i></b> so that it reads as follows: <b>With regard to firstborns,</b> the reference is to a case <b>where</b> the fetuses <b>emerged with their feet</b> first. In such a case, the full-fledged <b>offspring, which has life, hangs on and does not emerge</b> so quickly, whereas the <b>sandal</b> fetus, <b>which does not have life, slides</b> out <b>and emerges</b> first. <b>In</b> tractate <b><i>Karetot</i>,</b> it is referring to a case <b>where</b> the fetuses <b>came out with their heads</b> first. In such an instance, with regard to the full-fledged <b>offspring, which has life, once its head emerges it is</b> considered <b>a birth,</b> whereas the <b>sandal</b> fetus is considered to have been born <b>only when the majority of its</b> body <b>emerges.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If there is <b>an afterbirth in the house, the house is ritually impure,</b> in the sense that everything under the roof contracts impurity imparted by a corpse. The reason is <b>not that</b> the status of <b>an afterbirth</b> is that of <b>an offspring; rather,</b> it is <b>that there is no afterbirth without an offspring.</b> It is clear that the afterbirth contained an offspring that disintegrated after the miscarriage. That offspring rendered the contents of the house impure.
<b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> The house does not become a tent over a corpse, as although there had been an offspring in the afterbirth, <b>the offspring disintegrated,</b> turning to blood, <b>before it emerged</b> from the womb, and it was negated by the majority of blood that accompanied the miscarriage.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the appearance of the afterbirth: At <b>the outset of</b> the pregnancy, the <b>afterbirth</b> is so thin that it is <b>similar to a string of the woof, and</b> at the <b>end of</b> the pregnancy it is much wider, <b>similar</b> in width <b>to a lupine. And</b> the afterbirth is <b>hollow like a trumpet, and there is no afterbirth</b> whose length is <b>less than a handbreadth. Rabbi Shimon ben Gamliel says: An afterbirth is similar to the craw of roosters, from which the small</b> intestine <b>emerges.</b>
Since the <i>baraita</i> states that the minimum length of an afterbirth is a handbreadth, the Gemara cites another <i>baraita</i> that lists different items whose halakhic status is dependent on a minimum measure of a handbreadth. <b>It is taught</b> by <b>Rabbi Oshaya, the youngest [<i>ze’eira</i>] of the company [<i>demin ḥavrayya</i>]</b> of Sages: There are <b>five</b> items <b>whose</b> minimum <b>measure</b> is one <b>handbreadth, and these are they: An afterbirth,</b> the <b>shofar</b> for blowing on Rosh HaShana, the <b>spine</b> of a <i>lulav</i> that must be taken on <i>Sukkot</i>, the width of <b>the wall of a <i>sukka</i>, and the hyssop [<i>veha’ezov</i>].</b> Hyssop is used for the purification of a leper and for the preparation of the ashes of a red heifer in order to sprinkle them with water on someone who is ritually impure due to impurity imparted by a corpse.
The Gemara elaborates: The <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>an afterbirth is that which we stated</b> above. The <i>halakha</i> of <b>a shofar</b> is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>How much is the measure</b> of the length <b>of a shofar</b> for blowing on Rosh HaShana? <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Gamliel explained:</b> It must be long <b>enough that when one holds it in his hand</b> with four fingers, <b>it can be seen</b> protruding <b>on one side</b> of his hand <b>and on the other side,</b> i.e., at least one <b>handbreadth.</b>
<b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a spine</b> of a <i>lulav</i>? It is <b>as Rabbi Parnakh said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: The spine of a <i>lulav</i> must protrude</b> at least one <b>handbreadth beyond the myrtle branch</b> that is tied together with it. The <i>halakha</i> of <b>the wall of a <i>sukka</i></b> is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: A <i>sukka</i> is valid only if it has <b>two</b> full-fledged partitions <b>in the standard sense,</b> completely closing each of those two sides and measuring at least seven handbreadths, <b>and a third</b> wall that measures <b>even</b> one <b>handbreadth.</b> If the third wall is less than a handbreadth long, the <i>sukka</i> is unfit. Finally, the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the <b>hyssop</b> is stated in a <i>baraita</i> <b>that Rabbi Ḥiyya teaches:</b> The <b>hyssop</b> used for the purification of a leper and for the preparation of the ashes of a red heifer must measure at least one <b>handbreadth.</b>
<b>Rabbi Ḥanina bar Pappa says</b> that <b>Sheila of Kefar Temarta taught</b> as a mnemonic: There are <b>three <i>baraitot</i>,</b> with regard to an afterbirth, a shofar, and the wall of a <i>sukka</i>, <b>and</b> there are <b>two</b> independent <b><i>halakhot</i></b> of <i>amora’im</i>, of the spine of a <i>lulav</i> and the hyssop, where the minimum <b>measure</b> of one <b>handbreadth</b> is required. The Gemara asks: Are there <b>two</b> <i>halakhot</i> of <i>amora’im</i> in this list? There <b>is</b> only <b>one</b> statement, with regard to the spine of a <i>lulav</i>. The <i>halakha</i> of the hyssop is taught in a <i>baraita</i> by Rabbi Ḥiyya. <b>Abaye says:</b> Revise the wording of that statement, so that it should not read that Rabbi Ḥiyya taught a <i>baraita</i>; rather, <b>say</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya says</b> himself that the <b>hyssop</b> must measure at least one <b>handbreadth,</b> i.e., that <i>halakha</i> is not taught in a <i>baraita</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And are there no more</b> cases where the minimum measure is one handbreadth, other than those five listed by Rabbi Oshaya? <b>But isn’t there</b> the following mishna (<i>Oholot</i> 3:7) that deals with the minimum size of a tent that transmits ritual impurity: <b>A cubic</b> space measuring one <b>handbreadth by</b> one <b>handbreadth with a height of</b> one <b>handbreadth transmits ritual impurity.</b> If a corpse is in that space, the impurity is transmitted to all people, vessels, and food in that space. <b>And</b> a space of that size <b>serves as a barrier before,</b> i.e., stops the spread of, <b>ritual impurity</b> beyond that space.
The Gemara answers: <b>We said</b> that there are five items whose minimum measure is one <b>handbreadth; we did not say</b> anything about a space whose measure is one <b>handbreadth by</b> one <b>handbreadth.</b>
The Gemara further asks: <b>But isn’t there</b> the following mishna (<i>Kelim</i> 5:2): <b>A stone that protrudes from the oven</b> by one <b>handbreadth,</b> which is used as a handle for lifting and carrying the oven, <b>and</b> similarly a stone that protrudes <b>from the stove three fingerbreadths</b> is considered as having <b>a connection</b> to the oven or stove with regard to ritual impurity. Consequently, if the oven or stove becomes impure, then the stone handle, which is classified as part of the oven, is likewise rendered impure. If the handle is longer than that, the additional length will be removed, so it is not considered to be part of the oven.
The Gemara answers: <b>When we said</b> that there are five items whose minimum measure is one handbreadth, we were referring to cases <b>where</b> if it <b>less than</b> one <b>handbreadth</b> it <b>is unfit</b> for the purpose of the item. <b>But here,</b> where a protruding stone one handbreadth long is considered a handle of the oven, it is <b>all the more so</b> the case <b>that</b> a protruding stone <b>less than</b> one <b>handbreadth</b> long <b>is</b> considered <b>a handle of</b> the <b>oven.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But aren’t there</b>

Daf 26b

toy <b>ovens with</b> which <b>girls</b> play, whose minimum measure with regard to ritual impurity is also one <b>handbreadth? As it is taught</b> in a mishna (<i>Kelim</i> 5:1): A clay <b>oven</b> in <b>its original,</b> unbroken, <b>state</b> is susceptible to ritual impurity if it is <b>four</b> handbreadths tall. <b>And</b> with regard to an oven that became impure and was subsequently broken, if <b>its remains</b> include a piece <b>four</b> handbreadths tall, that piece remains impure. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis say: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is said <b>in</b> the case of <b>a large</b> oven, made for regular use; <b>but with regard to a small</b> oven made for girls to play with, in <b>its original state, any size</b> is sufficient for it to be susceptible to contract impurity. <b>Once its construction is completed,</b> if the oven then becomes impure and is subsequently broken, if <b>its remains include</b> a piece that contains <b>the majority of</b> the oven, that piece remains impure.
The Gemara explains: <b>And how</b> small is the size defined by the mishna as <b>any size? Rabbi Yannai says:</b> One <b>handbreadth, as</b> people <b>fashion</b> toy <b>ovens for girls</b> one <b>handbreadth</b> high. This is another example of an item that has a minimum measure of one handbreadth, in addition to the five items listed by Rabbi Oshaya. The Gemara answers: Rabbi Oshaya <b>is not speaking of</b> matters that are subject to <b>dispute,</b> such as the minimum measure of an oven.
The Gemara adds: <b>Now that you have arrived at this</b> answer, the fact that Rabbi Oshaya does not mention a stone protruding from an oven can be explained in the same manner, since <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>is also</b> subject to <b>a dispute. As the latter clause</b> of that mishna (<i>Kelim</i> 5:2) <b>teaches</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda said:</b> When the Sages <b>said</b> that a stone protruding from an oven is considered a handle if it protrudes one <b>handbreadth,</b> they said so <b>only</b> with regard to a stone that protrudes <b>from the oven and toward the wall.</b> If the stone protrudes more than that, it is not considered a handle, as it is likely to be removed so that the oven can be moved closer to the wall. But if the stone protrudes toward the airspace of the house, it is considered an oven handle even if it protrudes more than one handbreadth.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But isn’t there</b> the <b>frame</b> of the Table in the Temple, which is one <b>handbreadth</b> wide, as stated in the Torah (Exodus 25:25)? The Gemara answers: Rabbi Oshaya <b>is not dealing with</b> matters <b>that are written</b> in the Torah. The Gemara further asks: <b>But isn’t there the Ark Cover,</b> which is one <b>handbreadth</b> thick, and its measure is not written explicitly in the Torah? The Gemara answers: Rabbi Oshaya <b>is not dealing with consecrated</b> items.
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t there</b> the <i>halakha</i> of a cross beam, which is placed over the entrance to an alleyway in order to permit carrying items in the alleyway on Shabbat, and the <i>halakha</i> is that <b>it is enough for</b> a cross <b>beam to be</b> one <b>handbreadth wide?</b> The Gemara answers: Rabbi Oshaya <b>is not dealing with matters of rabbinic law. Rather,</b> he is speaking only <b>of</b> matters <b>that are written</b> in the Torah <b>but whose measure is not explicit</b> in the Torah.
§ <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Shmuel bar Marta sat before Rav Kahana, and he sat and said</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> For <b>all of the first three days</b> after a woman gives birth, if she discharges afterbirth, <b>we attribute the afterbirth to</b> the <b>offspring.</b> There is no concern that this afterbirth indicates the miscarriage of another offspring. <b>From this</b> point <b>forward,</b> once three days have passed since the birth, if the woman discharges an afterbirth, <b>we are concerned that</b> there might have been <b>another offspring</b> in the afterbirth, and the <i>halakhot</i> of a woman who discharged an offspring apply to her.
Rav Kahana <b>said to</b> Rav Yitzḥak bar Shmuel: <b>And did Rav say this? But didn’t Rav say</b> that <b>an offspring does not remain</b> in the womb <b>at all after another</b> offspring was born? Rav Yitzḥak bar Shmuel <b>was silent.</b> Rav Kahana <b>said to him: Perhaps</b> there is no contradiction between Rav’s two statements, as <b>here,</b> where he indicates that a second offspring can emerge even three days after the first, the reference is <b>to</b> a case where the first offspring is <b>a non-viable newborn,</b> whereas <b>there,</b> in the statement that a second offspring does not remain in the womb after the first offspring was born, he is referring <b>to</b> a case where the first offspring is <b>a viable</b> offspring.
Rav Yitzḥak bar Shmuel <b>said to him:</b> Are <b>you</b> the one who <b>says</b> this explanation <b>of Rav’s <i>halakha</i></b> of your own accord? Indeed, <b>Rav said this explicitly:</b> If a woman <b>discharged a non-viable newborn and subsequently discharged an afterbirth,</b> for <b>all of the first three days we attribute the afterbirth to</b> the <b>offspring. From this</b> point <b>forward,</b> if she discharged an afterbirth <b>we are concerned that</b> it contained <b>another offspring.</b> If she <b>gave birth</b> to a viable offspring <b>and subsequently discharged an afterbirth, even from now until ten days</b> after the birth <b>we are not concerned that</b> the afterbirth contained <b>another offspring.</b>
The Gemara relates: <b>Shmuel, Rav’s students, and Rav Yehuda were sitting</b> together. <b>Rav Yosef, son of Rav Menashya of D’vil, was passing</b> by <b>and walking toward them,</b> i.e., he was walking in their direction, and <b>he was hurrying and coming</b> along. Shmuel <b>said</b> to his company: <b>A man is coming toward us whom one can knock</b> down <b>with a straw of wheat, and he falls and stays down.</b> In other words, he cannot refute even a minor challenge to his opinions.
<b>In the meantime,</b> Rav Yosef, son of Rav Menashya, <b>arrived. Shmuel said to him: What did Rav say with regard to an afterbirth?</b> Rav Yosef <b>said to him</b> that <b>this is what Rav said: One attributes an afterbirth only to a viable item,</b> i.e., a viable offspring. <b>Shmuel</b> subsequently <b>asked all of Rav’s students</b> who were present whether Rav actually said this, <b>and they said to him</b> that Rav indeed said <b>so.</b> Shmuel <b>then looked at Rav Yehuda harshly,</b> as Rav Yehuda was also a student of Rav, but he had not transmitted this <i>halakha</i> to Shmuel after Rav’s death.
§ <b>Rabbi Yosei ben Shaul asked Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi: In the case of a woman <b>who discharges</b> an item in <b>the form of a crow and</b> there is also <b>an afterbirth, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is the afterbirth attributed to the discharged item, or is there concern that the afterbirth might have contained another offspring? Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to him: One attributes</b> an afterbirth <b>only to an item whose species has an afterbirth.</b> Since crows do not have an afterbirth, the afterbirth cannot be associated with that discharged item.
Rabbi Yosei ben Shaul then asked Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi: If the afterbirth is <b>tied to</b> the item that has the form of a crow, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to him: You asked</b> about <b>a matter that does not exist.</b> Rabbi Yosei ben Shaul <b>raised an objection to</b> this response from a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to a woman <b>who discharges a type of domesticated animal, undomesticated animal, or bird, and</b> she discharges <b>an afterbirth with them,</b> in an instance <b>when</b> the <b>afterbirth is tied to them we are not concerned about</b> the possibility of <b>another offspring.</b> If the <b>afterbirth is not tied to them, we are concerned that</b> the afterbirth contained <b>another offspring.</b> And <b>I impose upon them</b>

Daf 27a

the <b>stringency of two offspring, as I say: Perhaps</b> the <b>gestational sac of</b> this <b>afterbirth,</b> which contained the offspring, <b>disintegrated, and</b> the <b>afterbirth of</b> the <b>gestational sac</b> containing the fetus shaped like an animal also <b>disintegrated.</b> If so, there are two offspring, and as it is possible that one is male and the other female, the mother must observe the strictures of one who gave birth to both a male and a female. In any event, this <i>baraita</i> is <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s claim that it is impossible for an afterbirth to be tied to a fetus that has the form of a bird.
§ <b>Rabba bar Sheila says</b> that <b>Rav Mattana says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: An incident</b> occurred where the Sages <b>attributed the afterbirth</b> that a woman discharged <b>to an offspring</b> that was born <b>up to ten days</b> beforehand. <b>And</b> Shmuel added that the Sages <b>said</b> that one <b>attributes</b> an afterbirth to an offspring that was born <b>only</b> in the case <b>of an afterbirth that emerges after the offspring</b> is born. By contrast, an afterbirth that emerges before the offspring is born is not attributed to that offspring.
