<b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> There was <b>an incident</b> where the Sages <b>attributed the afterbirth to an offspring</b> that was born <b>up to twenty-three days</b> beforehand. <b>Rav Yosef said to him</b> a correction of his statement: <b>You said to us</b> on another occasion that the offspring was born <b>up to twenty-four</b> days beforehand.
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Avira, says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak says:</b> There was <b>an incident</b> where a woman was pregnant with twins, <b>and</b> one <b>offspring remained</b> in the womb for <b>thirty-three days after the other</b> offspring was born. <b>Rav Yosef said to him: You said to us</b> on another occasion that the second offspring was born <b>thirty-four</b> days after the first.
The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to the one who says</b> that if a woman <b>gives birth</b> to a baby <b>in</b> her <b>ninth</b> month, <b>she can give birth prematurely</b> (see <i>Rosh HaShana</i> 11a). <b>You find</b> a situation where there could be such a difference between the births of the two twins if <b>the form of one</b> of the twin fetuses <b>was completed at the end of the seventh</b> month, and it is born at that stage, <b>and the form of</b> the other <b>one was completed at the beginning of the ninth</b> month, and it is born then. In such a case, there can be a difference of thirty-four days between the births. <b>But according to the one who says</b> that a woman who <b>gives birth</b> to a baby <b>in</b> her <b>ninth</b> month <b>cannot give birth prematurely,</b> but rather she gives birth at the end of the ninth month, <b>what is there to say?</b>
The Gemara answers that one should <b>reverse the statements:</b> The difference of <b>thirty-three</b> days was stated <b>with regard to</b> a case of <b>an afterbirth</b> that was discharged an extended period after the birth of the offspring, whereas the gap of <b>twenty-three</b> days was stated <b>with regard to</b> a case of an <b>offspring</b> that was born after its twin.
<b>Rabbi Avin bar Rav Adda says</b> that <b>Rav Menaḥem of the village of She’arim, and some say</b> that he was from <b>Beit She’arim, says: An incident</b> occurred where <b>one offspring remained</b> in the womb <b>after the other</b> was born for <b>three months, and</b> both twins <b>are sitting before us in the study hall. And who are they?</b> They are <b>Yehuda and Ḥizkiyya, the sons of Rabbi Ḥiyya.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t the Master say</b> that <b>a woman cannot become pregnant and again become pregnant</b> with another offspring while she is pregnant with the first? <b>Abaye says:</b> Both twins were conceived at the same time; <b>it was one drop</b> of semen <b>and it split into two. The form of one was completed at the beginning of the seventh</b> month, <b>and</b> the form of the other <b>one</b> was completed <b>at the end of the ninth</b> month.
§ The mishna teaches that if there is <b>an afterbirth in the house, the house is impure</b> in the sense that everything under the roof contracts impurity imparted by a corpse. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If there is <b>an afterbirth in the house, the house is impure.</b> The reason is <b>not that the</b> status of <b>an afterbirth</b> is that of <b>an offspring; rather,</b> it is <b>that there is no afterbirth without an offspring,</b> and the offspring rendered the contents of the house impure. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon deem</b> the contents of the house <b>pure.</b>
These Sages <b>said to Rabbi Meir: Do you not concede that if</b> people <b>removed</b> the afterbirth <b>to the outer room</b> of the house <b>in a basin, that</b> the room <b>is pure?</b> Rabbi Meir <b>said to them</b> in response: <b>Indeed,</b> that room is pure; <b>but why</b> so? <b>Because</b> the offspring <b>does not exist</b> anymore, i.e., it presumably disintegrated while it was moved from place to place.
These Sages <b>said to him: Just as</b> the offspring <b>does not exist</b> when the afterbirth is moved <b>to the outer room, so too, it does not exist</b> when the afterbirth is <b>in the inner room</b> either. In other words, the offspring presumably disintegrated while it was moved from the woman’s womb to the place in the house where it is located. Rabbi Meir <b>said to them:</b> A situation in which the offspring <b>disintegrated once,</b> when the afterbirth was moved to its first location in the house, <b>is not comparable to</b> a case where the offspring <b>disintegrated twice,</b> i.e., when the afterbirth was first moved to the interior room of the house and then moved to the outer room.
§ <b>Rav Pappa sat behind Rav Beivai</b> in the study hall <b>before</b> their teacher <b>Rav Hamnuna, and he sat and said: What is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Shimon,</b> that a house in which there is an afterbirth is pure? <b>He holds</b> that with regard to <b>any</b> item that has <b>ritual impurity with which</b> there <b>was mixed</b> an item <b>of another type,</b> it <b>is nullified</b> by the other item and is pure. Consequently, in the case of an offspring that disintegrated, the disintegrated offspring is nullified by the blood of the childbirth.
<b>Rav Pappa said to</b> Rav Beivai, who was a greater scholar than he, and to Rav Hamnuna his teacher: <b>This is also the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei,</b> who agree with Rabbi Shimon in the above <i>baraita</i>. Rav Beivai and Rav Hamnuna <b>laughed at him: What is different</b> about the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei? Since the statement of Rabbi Shimon is attributed to them as well, it is <b>obvious</b> that their reasoning is the same.
<b>Rav Pappa said</b> with regard to this incident: <b>A person should say a matter even</b> as obvious <b>as this</b> one, <b>and one should not be silent in the presence of his teacher,</b> despite the possibility that other people might laugh at him, <b>because it is stated: “If you have done foolishly in lifting up yourself, or if you have planned devices [<i>zammota</i>], lay your hand over your mouth”</b> (Proverbs 30:32). One who acts “foolishly” over matters of Torah by not hesitating to issue statements that might be ridiculed will ultimately be exalted and lifted up. Conversely, one who muzzles [<i>zamam</i>] himself due to embarrassment will end up with his hand over his mouth, unable to answer questions that are posed to him.
With regard to Rabbi Shimon’s opinion that the woman is pure because the offspring is nullified by the blood of childbirth, the Gemara notes: <b>And Rabbi Shimon follows his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>a ladleful [<i>melo tarvad</i>] of dust</b> from a corpse, which is the minimum amount that renders everything in a house impure, <b>into which any amount of dirt fell,</b> the house is <b>impure; and Rabbi Shimon deems</b> it <b>pure.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Shimon?</b> Why is the house pure when it contains a ladleful of dust from a corpse? <b>Rabba said: I found the Sages of the study hall of Rav sitting and saying:</b> The reason Rabbi Shimon deems the house pure is that <b>it is impossible for</b> there <b>not to be two grains of dirt</b> that are <b>more than one grain of dust</b> from the corpse, in a certain place in the mixture. <b>And</b> as that grain of dust from the corpse is nullified by the dirt, the amount of dust that remains <b>is insufficient</b> for rendering the house impure.
<b>And I said to them: On the contrary,</b> according to this reasoning the house should certainly be impure, as <b>it is impossible for</b> there <b>not to be two grains of dust</b> from the corpse that are <b>more than</b>

Daf 27b

<b>one grain of dirt</b> in a certain place in the mixture. That grain of dirt is thereby nullified by the dust of the corpse, <b>and</b> consequently <b>the measure</b> of the dust <b>increases.</b>
<b>Rather, Rabba said</b> that <b>this is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Shimon:</b> The <i>halakha</i> with regard to a corpse in <b>its ultimate state</b> of dust <b>is like</b> the <i>halakha</i> in <b>its initial state</b> of decomposition: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>its initial state,</b> if <b>another matter</b> is mixed with the decomposing corpse it <b>serves as a nullification [<i>gangilon</i>] of</b> the corpse’s impurity, as the dust of a decomposed corpse can impart impurity only if it is not mingled with the dust of any other substance, <b>so too,</b> in the corpse’s <b>ultimate state</b> of dust, if <b>another matter</b> is mixed with it, that <b>serves as a nullification of</b> the impurity of the dust.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the source for the <i>halakha</i> that the dust of a corpse imparts impurity only if it is not mingled with the dust of any other substance? The Gemara answers: <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Which is a corpse that has</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>dust,</b> i.e., whose dust imparts impurity; <b>and which is a corpse that does not have</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>dust?</b> If a corpse <b>was buried naked in a marble coffin or on a stone floor, that is a corpse that has</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>dust</b> that imparts impurity. Since any dust found there must have come from the corpse, it imparts impurity.
<b>And what is a corpse that does not have</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>dust?</b> If a corpse <b>was buried in its cloak, or in a wooden coffin, or on a brick floor, that is a corpse that does not have</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>dust</b> that imparts impurity, as it is assumed that some of the dust is from particles of the clothes, wood, or bricks, and the dust from a decomposed corpse imparts impurity only if it is not mingled with the dust of any other substance. The <i>baraita</i> adds another <i>halakha</i> with regard to the impurity of the dust of a corpse: <b>And</b> the Sages <b>said</b> that the <b>dust</b> of a corpse is impure <b>only with regard to</b> the corpse of a person who <b>died</b> naturally, <b>excluding one who was killed, whose</b> dust <b>is not</b> impure.
§ The Gemara returns to discuss <b>the</b> matter <b>itself,</b> i.e., the <i>baraita</i> cited above that clarifies the opinion of Rabbi Shimon: In the case of <b>a ladleful of dust</b> from a corpse <b>into which any amount of dirt fell,</b> the house <b>is impure; and Rabbi Shimon deems</b> it <b>pure.</b> The <i>baraita</i> continues: In the case of <b>a ladleful of dust</b> from a corpse <b>that was scattered in the house, the house is impure.</b> Provided that there is a sufficient amount of dust in the house, the house is impure, even if the dust is scattered. <b>And Rabbi Shimon deems</b> it <b>pure.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>And it is necessary</b> for the <i>baraita</i> to state both of these <i>halakhot</i>. <b>As, if</b> the <i>baraita</i> had <b>taught us</b> only <b>the first</b> <i>halakha</i>, with regard to dust from a corpse in which dirt was mixed, one might have thought that it is specifically <b>in that</b> case that <b>the Rabbis say</b> the house is impure, <b>because</b> the dust is <b>concentrated</b> in one place; <b>but</b> if the dust <b>was scattered,</b> one might <b>say</b> that the Rabbis <b>concede to Rabbi Shimon that</b> the house is pure. The reasoning is <b>that</b> if an item <b>overlies</b> a collection of dust of a corpse that is insufficient to render it impure <b>and also overlies</b> another collection of similar size, where together these collections constitute a sufficient amount to render the item and everything under it impure, it <b>is not</b> impure.
<b>And if</b> the <i>baraita</i> had <b>taught us</b> the <i>halakha</i> only <b>with regard to this</b> second case, where the dust of the corpse was scattered, one might have thought that it is specifically <b>in this</b> case that <b>Rabbi Shimon says</b> that the house is pure, <b>as</b> an item that <b>overlies</b> an insufficient collection of the dust of a corpse <b>and also overlies</b> another collection, where together these collections constitute a sufficient amount to render the item impure, <b>is not</b> impure. <b>But in that</b> first case, where dirt was mixed with the dust of the corpse, one might <b>say</b> that Rabbi Shimon <b>concedes to the Rabbis</b> that the house is impure. Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> for the <i>baraita</i> to teach both cases.
There is a different dispute between Rabbi Shimon and the Rabbis that <b>is taught</b> in <b>another</b> mishna (<i>Oholot</i> 2:2): If a house contains <b>a ladleful of dirt from a cemetery and</b> slightly <b>more,</b> the house <b>is impure; and Rabbi Shimon deems</b> it <b>pure.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of the Rabbis?</b> The Gemara answers: They deem the house impure <b>as it is impossible for</b> slightly <b>more than a ladleful of dirt from a cemetery not to contain a ladleful of dust</b> from a corpse.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>Now that you say</b> that <b>the reason that Rabbi Shimon</b> deems the house pure, in a case where it contains dust from a corpse in which dirt was mixed, is <b>that</b> in his opinion the <i>halakha</i> of a corpse in <b>its ultimate state</b> of dust <b>is like</b> the <i>halakha</i> in <b>its initial state</b> of decomposition, then <b>with regard to</b> a case where there is <b>an afterbirth</b> in the house, <b>what is the reason</b> that Rabbi Shimon deems the house pure? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The Sages <b>touched upon it,</b> i.e., deemed the house pure, <b>due to</b> the <b>nullification</b> of the disintegrated offspring <b>by</b> the <b>majority</b> of the blood that emerged during the miscarriage, in which the afterbirth was mixed.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan follows his</b> line of <b>reasoning</b> in this regard, <b>as Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Rabbi Shimon and Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov</b> both <b>said the same thing,</b> i.e., they both issued rulings based on the same principle. The relevant statement of <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> is <b>that which we said,</b> i.e., that if a woman discharged an afterbirth the house is pure, as the offspring is nullified by the blood that emerged during the miscarriage. <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> ben Ya’akov said that <b>which is taught</b> in a mishna (<i>Bekhorot</i> 21a): <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says:</b> In the case of <b>a large animal that expelled a mass of</b> congealed <b>blood, that</b> mass <b>must be buried,</b> as perhaps there was a male fetus there, which was consecrated as a firstborn when it emerged, <b>and</b> the animal <b>is exempt from</b> having any future offspring being counted <b>a firstborn.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Ḥiyya teaches</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>with regard to that</b> <i>halakha</i>: The mass of congealed blood <b>does not impart ritual impurity, neither through</b> physical <b>contact nor through carrying</b> it. It does not have the status of an unslaughtered animal carcass, which does impart impurity in such manners. The Gemara asks: <b>But since</b> the mass <b>does not impart impurity, neither through contact nor through carrying,</b> which indicates that it is not considered a fetus, <b>why</b> must it be <b>buried?</b> The Gemara answers: It must be buried <b>in order to publicize that</b> the animal <b>is exempt from</b> having its future offspring being counted <b>a firstborn.</b>
The Gemara asks: If the animal’s subsequent offspring is not counted a firstborn, <b>evidently</b> the mass <b>is</b> treated like <b>a full-fledged offspring. But</b> if so, <b>why does Rabbi Ḥiyya teach</b> that <b>it does not impart impurity, neither through</b> physical <b>contact nor through carrying? Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> It is <b>due to</b> the halakhic <b>nullification</b> of a foreign substance <b>in a majority</b> of permitted substances that the Sages <b>touched upon it,</b> to exclude it from impurity through contact or carrying. In other words, the fetus is considered a full-fledged offspring, but it does not impart impurity, because it is nullified by the rest of the congealed mass.
§ The Gemara resumes its discussion of the opinion of Rabbi Shimon that if a woman discharges an afterbirth in a house, the house is pure. <b>Rabbi Ami says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: And Rabbi Shimon concedes that its mother is impure</b> with the impurity of a woman after <b>childbirth.</b>
<b>A certain elder said to Rabbi Ami: I will explain to you the reason</b> for the statement <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan. As the verse states: “If a woman bears seed and gives birth to a male,</b> she shall be impure seven days, as in the days of the menstruation of her sickness she shall be impure” (Leviticus 12:2). This indicates that <b>even</b> if a woman <b>gives birth to</b> an offspring that is <b>similar only to the seed that she bore,</b> i.e., if the offspring liquefied and became similar to semen, the woman is <b>impure</b> with the impurity of a woman after <b>childbirth.</b>
§ <b>Reish Lakish says:</b> In the case of a fetus in <b>a gestational sac, that was mashed in its</b> amniotic <b>fluid</b> by being shaken violently, <b>it is rendered like a corpse that was deformed,</b> and therefore it does not impart impurity to other items that are under the same roof.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said to Reish Lakish: From where do we</b> derive <b>that a corpse that was deformed is pure? If we say</b> it is derived <b>from that which Rabbi Shabbtai says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak from Migdal [<i>Migdala’a</i>] says, and some say</b> from that which <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak from Migdal says</b> that <b>Rabbi Shabbtai says,</b> that cannot be correct. The Gemara cites the relevant statement: With regard to <b>a corpse that was burned but its form [<i>veshildo</i>]</b> still <b>exists,</b> i.e., it still has the form of a human corpse, it <b>is impure. There was an incident</b> involving such a corpse, <b>and</b> the Sages <b>deemed impure</b> all items that were under the <b>large openings</b> of the house where the corpse was located, as these openings were fit for the removal of the corpse from the house through them.

Daf 28a

<b>But they deemed pure</b> all items that were under the <b>small openings</b> to the house, i.e., those whose width was less than four handbreadths. <b>And you infer from</b> this statement that <b>the reason</b> the large openings are impure in such a case is <b>that the form of</b> the corpse still <b>exists; but otherwise,</b> i.e., if the corpse was deformed, then even the large openings are <b>pure.</b>
The Gemara explains why one cannot infer from here that a deformed corpse does not impart impurity to other items that are under the same roof: <b>On the contrary,</b> one can <b>infer from</b> this statement <b>in</b> the opposite <b>manner: It is</b> only because <b>the form of</b> the corpse still <b>exists that</b> the Sages <b>deemed pure</b> the <b>small openings</b> of the house; <b>but otherwise,</b> the <b>small openings are also impure, as each and every one</b> of them <b>is fit for taking out</b> the corpse through them, <b>each limb one</b> by <b>one.</b> Consequently, no proof can be derived from this statement in support of the opinion of Reish Lakish.
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi: In accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>did Rabbi Yoḥanan say</b> that a deformed corpse imparts impurity to items that are under the same roof? It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Oholot</i> 2:2): With regard to <b>the ashes of burned</b> corpses that are not mixed with other types of ashes or dirt, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says</b> that <b>its measure for</b> imparting impurity to items that are under the same roof is a <b>quarter</b> of a <i>kav</i>. Clearly, Rabbi Eliezer maintains that a deformed corpse imparts impurity to items that are under the same roof.
The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of this case of <b>a corpse that was burned but its form</b> still <b>exists?</b> How is this possible? <b>Abaye says:</b> It is possible in a case <b>where</b> one <b>burned</b> the corpse <b>on top of</b> a hard <b>leather spread [<i>katavla</i>],</b> which does not burn, and therefore the corpse retains its shape even after it is burned. <b>Rava says:</b> It is possible in a case <b>where</b> one <b>burned</b> the corpse <b>on top of a marble slate [<i>apoderim</i>]. Ravina says:</b> It is possible in a case <b>where</b> the corpse <b>was charred</b> without being reduced to ashes.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of a woman <b>who discharges a shaped hand,</b> i.e., its fingers are discernible, <b>or a shaped foot, its mother is impure</b> with the impurity of a woman after <b>childbirth,</b> as the hand or foot certainly came from a full-fledged fetus. <b>And we are not concerned</b> that <b>perhaps they came from</b> a fetus with <b>a sealed,</b> i.e., deficient, <b>body,</b> in which case the miscarriage does not have the status of childbirth with regard to ritual impurity. The reason is that most pregnant women give birth to a fully formed fetus, and therefore it is presumed that the hand or foot came from a whole fetus that was squashed during childbirth.
<b>Rav Ḥisda and Rabba bar Rav Huna both say:</b> Although the woman observes the period of impurity of a woman after childbirth, <b>we do not give her</b> the <b>days of purity</b> following the period of impurity. <b>What is the reason?</b> Although it is presumed that the discharged limbs came from a full-fledged fetus, it is unknown whether or when the woman discharged the rest of the fetus, and the principle is that a woman who discharges observes her periods of impurity and purity when the majority of the limbs of the fetus emerge. Therefore, one can <b>say</b> that perhaps <b>her childbirth was distant,</b> i.e., the woman discharged the majority of the limbs of the fetus long before she discharged this hand or foot, and consequently her period of purity has already ended.
<b>Rav Yosef raises an objection</b> from a mishna (29a): In the case of a woman <b>who discharges and it is not known what</b> sex fetus <b>she discharged, she shall observe</b> the strictures of a woman who gave birth both <b>to a male and to a female. And if it enters your mind</b> that in <b>any case like this</b> one should <b>say</b> that perhaps the woman’s <b>childbirth was distant, let</b> the mishna <b>teach</b> that the woman shall observe the strictures of a woman who gave birth to both a male and a female, <b>and</b> also observes the strictures <b>of a menstruating woman.</b> Since it is possible that the item she discharged was a limb from a fetus the majority of which she discharged a long time beforehand, then she must forgo the period of purity observed by a woman who gave birth, and treat any blood that emerges during this period like the blood of a menstruating woman.
<b>Abaye says</b> in response: <b>If</b> the mishna had <b>taught</b> that the woman observes the strictures <b>of a menstruating woman, I would say</b> that as her status as a woman after childbirth is uncertain, since she observes the strictures of a menstruating woman with regard to any blood that emerges, <b>she brings an offering</b> like any woman after childbirth, <b>but it is not eaten</b> by the priests. It might be thought that perhaps the woman did not give birth at all and is not obligated to bring the offering, and therefore her bird sin offering cannot be eaten. By omitting the <i>halakha</i> that the woman observes the strictures of a menstruating woman, the mishna <b>teaches us that</b> her offering <b>is eaten.</b> This indicates that she certainly discharged an offspring; the uncertainty is only about when she discharged it.
§ <b>Rav Huna says:</b> If <b>a fetus extended its hand out</b> of the womb <b>and</b> then <b>returned it, its mother is impure</b> with the impurity of a woman after childbirth. This is considered childbirth, <b>as it is stated</b> with regard to Tamar, Judah’s daughter-in-law: <b>“And it happened when she gave birth that one put out a hand</b>…and it happened that as he drew back his hand, his brother came out” (Genesis 38:28–29). Evidently, the fetus extending out its hand was considered childbirth, despite the fact that it subsequently drew back the hand.
<b>Rav Yehuda raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>a fetus extended its hand out</b> of the womb, <b>its mother</b> need <b>not be concerned</b> that she is considered a woman after childbirth <b>with regard to any matter. Rav Naḥman says</b> in response: The meaning of this statement <b>was explained to me</b> personally <b>by Rav Huna</b> himself: <b>With regard to being concerned</b> that she has the status of a woman after childbirth, the woman must be <b>concerned,</b> i.e., she must observe the strictures of a woman after childbirth. But <b>we do not give her</b> a period of <b>days of purity</b> like any woman after childbirth, <b>until most of</b> the fetus <b>emerges.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But doesn’t</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>say</b> that <b>its mother</b> need <b>not be concerned</b> that she is considered a woman after childbirth <b>with regard to any matter? Abaye says:</b> The <i>baraita</i> means that the woman need <b>not be concerned with regard to any matter by Torah law; but by rabbinic law</b> she must be <b>concerned,</b> i.e., she is required to observe the strictures of a woman after childbirth. The Gemara asks: <b>But doesn’t</b> Rav Huna <b>cite a verse</b> as proof for his statement that if a fetus extended its hand out it is considered childbirth? The Gemara answers: This <i>halakha</i> applies <b>by rabbinic law, and the verse is</b> cited as <b>mere support</b> for it, i.e., it is not an actual source.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> A woman <b>who discharges</b> or gives birth to <b>a <i>tumtum</i>,</b> whose sexual organs are obscured, <b>or</b> to <b>a hermaphrodite [<i>ve’androginos</i>],</b> who has both male and female sexual organs, <b>shall observe</b> the strictures of a woman who gave birth both <b>to a male and to a female.</b> She is impure for fourteen days like a woman who gave birth to a female, but blood that she sees thereafter is pure only until forty days after birth, like for a woman who gave birth to a male.
In a case where she gave birth to twins, if they are <b>a <i>tumtum</i> and a male,</b> or <b>a hermaphrodite and a male, she observes</b> the strictures of a woman who gave birth both <b>to a male and to a female.</b> But if the twins are <b>a <i>tumtum</i> and a female,</b> or <b>a hermaphrodite and a female, she shall observe</b> the periods of purity and impurity established by the Torah <b>for</b> a woman who gives birth to <b>a female alone.</b> Regardless of the status of the <i>tumtum</i> and the hermaphrodite, the woman’s seven days of impurity and her succeeding thirty-three days of purity are subsumed in the fourteen days of impurity and sixty-six days of purity for a female.
If the fetus <b>emerged in pieces, or</b> if it emerged <b>reversed,</b> i.e., feetfirst rather than headfirst, <b>when most of its</b> limbs <b>emerge,</b> its status <b>is like</b> that of a child <b>born,</b> with regard to the impurity of a woman after childbirth. If the fetus <b>emerged in</b> the <b>usual manner,</b> headfirst, it is not considered born <b>until most of its head emerges. And what is</b> considered <b>most of its head?</b> It is <b>from when its forehead emerges.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>Now</b> that with regard to a woman who gives birth to <b>a <i>tumtum</i> alone, or a hermaphrodite alone,</b> the mishna <b>states</b> that <b>she shall observe</b> the strictures of a woman who gave birth both <b>to a male and to a female,</b> as the sex of the offspring is uncertain, <b>is it necessary</b> for the mishna to rule that if a woman gives birth to twins, <b>a <i>tumtum</i> and a male,</b> or <b>a hermaphrodite and a male,</b> she shall observe the strictures of a woman who gave birth to both a male and a female?
The Gemara answers: <b>It was necessary</b> for the mishna to state this <i>halakha</i>, <b>lest you say</b> that <b>since Rabbi Yitzḥak says</b> that the sex of a fetus is determined at the moment of conception, in that if the <b>woman emits seed first she gives birth to a male,</b> and if the <b>man emits seed first she gives birth to a female,</b> therefore one might <b>say</b> that <b>since this</b> offspring that was born with the <i>tumtum</i> or hermaphrodite <b>is male, that</b> <i>tumtum</i> or hermaphrodite <b>is also male.</b> Consequently, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that the woman shall observe the strictures of a woman who gave birth to a female as well, as one can <b>say</b> that perhaps <b>both</b> the man and the woman <b>emitted seed at the same time,</b> which would mean that <b>this</b> offspring <b>is male and that</b> <i>tumtum</i> or hermaphrodite <b>is female.</b>
§ <b>Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> In the case of <b>a <i>tumtum</i> and a hermaphrodite who saw a white</b> gonorrhea-like discharge [<i>ziva</i>], for which a man is impure, <b>or</b> who emitted <b>a red</b> discharge that had the appearance of menstrual blood, for which a woman is impure, if they entered the Temple <b>they are not liable for entering the Temple</b> in a state of impurity, as perhaps they are pure, in accordance with their true sex. <b>And</b> if they touched <i>teruma</i> after such a discharge, <b>one does not burn the <i>teruma</i> due to their</b> contact, as although impure <i>teruma</i> must be burned, the impurity in this case is uncertain.
If a <i>tumtum</i> and a hermaphrodite <b>saw white</b> <i>ziva</i> <b>and red</b> blood <b>as one,</b> i.e., they emitted both <i>ziva</i> and blood and are therefore impure regardless of their sex, <b>they are</b> still <b>not liable for entering the Temple, but one does burn <i>teruma</i> due to their</b> contact. The reason they are not liable for entering the Temple, despite the fact that they are definitely impure, is <b>that it is stated: “Both male and female</b>

Daf 28b

<b>you shall send out,</b> out of the camp you shall send them, so that they not impurify their camp, in the midst of which I dwell” (Numbers 5:3). It is derived from the verse that only <b>a definite male</b> or <b>a definite female</b> is liable for entering the Temple in a state of impurity, <b>but not a <i>tumtum</i> or a hermaphrodite.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that the following <i>baraita</i> <b>supports</b> the opinion of Rav: In the case of <b>a <i>tumtum</i> and a hermaphrodite who saw white</b> <i>ziva</i> <b>or red</b> blood, <b>they are not liable for entering the Temple</b> in a state of impurity, <b>and</b> if they touch <i>teruma</i>, <b>one does not burn the <i>teruma</i> due to their</b> contact. If they <b>saw white</b> <i>ziva</i> <b>and red</b> blood <b>as one,</b> i.e., they emitted both <i>ziva</i> and blood, <b>they are</b> still <b>not liable for entering the Temple, but one burns <i>teruma</i> due to their</b> contact.
The Gemara reasons: <b>What is the reason</b> that they are not liable for entering the Temple despite the fact that they are definitely impure? Is it <b>not because it is stated</b> in the verse: <b>“Both male and female you shall send out,”</b> from which it is derived that only <b>a definite male</b> or <b>a definite female</b> could be liable for entering the Temple in a state of impurity, <b>but not a <i>tumtum</i> or a hermaphrodite? Ulla says: No,</b> Rav’s opinion cannot be proved from this <i>baraita</i>, as in accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer.</b>
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Shevuot</i> 14b) that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> With regard to the sliding-scale offering the verse states: “Or if a person touches any impure thing…or the carcass of a non-kosher <b>creeping animal, and it is hidden from him”</b> (Leviticus 5:2). A precise reading of this verse indicates that <b>if</b> one has <b>a lapse of awareness</b> that he contracted ritual impurity by touching a carcass of <b>a creeping animal,</b> he is <b>liable</b> to bring a sliding-scale offering for defiling the Temple or the sacrificial food, <b>but he is not liable</b> to bring such an offering <b>for a lapse of awareness</b> that he is entering the <b>Temple</b> or partaking of sacrificial food.
<b>Rabbi Akiva says</b> that it is derived from the phrase: <b>“And it is hidden from him, so that he is impure”</b> (Leviticus 5:2), that <b>for a lapse of awareness</b> that one had contracted <b>ritual impurity,</b> he is <b>liable</b> to bring a sliding-scale offering, <b>but</b> he <b>is not liable</b> to bring an offering <b>for a lapse of awareness</b> that he is entering the <b>Temple</b> or partaking of sacrificial food.
<b>And we say</b> with regard to this mishna: <b>What</b> is the difference <b>between</b> the opinions of Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Akiva? They are apparently stating the same <i>halakha</i>. <b>And Ḥizkiyya says: There is</b> a practical difference <b>between them</b> in a case where one initially knew that he had contracted ritual impurity, but he did not know whether the impurity was contracted from a carcass of <b>a creeping animal or</b> from <b>the carcass of an unslaughtered animal. As Rabbi Eliezer holds</b> that for one to be liable to bring an offering, <b>we require that he</b> initially <b>know whether he contracted impurity from</b> a carcass of <b>a creeping animal</b> or <b>whether he contracted impurity from an unslaughtered animal carcass,</b> and if he never knew this, he does not bring an offering. <b>And Rabbi Akiva holds</b> that for him to be liable to bring an offering, <b>we do not require</b> that he know this detail, since he knows in general terms that he contracted impurity.
The Gemara infers: <b>Doesn’t Rabbi Eliezer say there,</b> in that mishna, that <b>we require</b> one to bring an offering for entering the Temple in a state of impurity only <b>if he knew</b> initially <b>whether he contracted impurity from</b> a carcass of <b>a creeping animal</b> or <b>whether he contracted impurity from an unslaughtered animal carcass? Here, too,</b> with regard to a hermaphrodite or a <i>tumtum</i> who emitted both <i>ziva</i> and blood, they are not obligated to bring an offering according to Rabbi Eliezer, as <b>we require</b> one to bring an offering only <b>if he knew whether he became impure due to</b> the <b>white</b> <i>ziva</i> he emitted or <b>whether he became impure due to</b> the <b>red</b> blood he emitted.
<b>But according to Rabbi Akiva, who said</b> that one <b>is obligated</b> to bring an offering <b>due to</b> his initial knowledge of his <b>impurity</b> even if he did not know the exact cause of his impurity, <b>here too,</b> in the case of a hermaphrodite or a <i>tumtum</i> who emitted both <i>ziva</i> and blood, <b>he is obligated</b> to bring an offering <b>due to</b> his initial knowledge of his <b>impurity,</b> despite the fact that he does not know whether he is impure due to the blood or the <i>ziva</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>Rav,</b> who holds that an impure <i>tumtum</i> or hermaphrodite is not liable for entering the Temple but that any <i>teruma</i> that he touches is burned, <b>what is different</b> with regard to <b>entering the Temple,</b> for <b>which</b> he is <b>not</b> liable? The reason it is different is <b>that it is written: “Both male and female you shall send out,”</b> from which it is derived that <b>a definite male</b> or <b>a definite female</b> is liable for entering the Temple in a state of impurity, <b>but not a <i>tumtum</i> or a hermaphrodite.</b>
<b>If so, we should not burn <i>teruma</i></b> that he touches either, <b>as it is written</b> in a verse dealing with these types of impurity: “This is the law of the <i>zav</i>, and of one from whom the flow of semen emerges, so that he is thereby impure; and of her that is sick with her menstrual status, <b>and they who have an issue, whether a male or a female”</b> (Leviticus 15:32–33). It can similarly be derived from this verse that these types of impurity apply only to <b>a definite male</b> or <b>a definite female, but not</b> to <b>a <i>tumtum</i> or a hermaphrodite.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse <b>is necessary for</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>of Rabbi Yitzḥak, as Rabbi Yitzḥak said:</b> The term <b>“whether a male”</b> serves <b>to include a male leper</b> as a primary source of impurity <b>with regard to the sources of his</b> bodily emissions. In other words, the various emissions of a leper, e.g., his saliva and urine, have the status of a primary source of impurity, and therefore they transmit impurity to a person or utensil that touches them. And the term <b>“or a female”</b> serves <b>to include a female</b> as a primary source of impurity <b>with regard to the sources of her</b> bodily emissions.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>This</b> verse: “Both male and female you shall send out” (Numbers 5:3), from which Rav derives that the prohibition against an impure person entering the Temple does not apply to one whose sex is uncertain, <b>is also necessary</b> for another <i>halakha</i>. That <i>halakha</i> is that the obligation to remove from the Temple any impure person or item applies only <b>to one that has</b> the option of attaining ritual <b>purity</b> by immersing <b>in a ritual bath; this excludes</b> an impure <b>earthenware vessel,</b> which cannot be purified by immersing it in a ritual bath. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yosei.</b> Consequently, Rav’s <i>halakha</i> cannot be derived from that verse.
The Gemara answers: <b>If so,</b> that the verse serves to teach Rabbi Yosei’s <i>halakha</i> alone, <b>let the Merciful One write:</b> Any <b>person</b> you shall send out, as this would also exclude earthenware vessels. Rav’s <i>halakha</i> is derived from the fact that the wording of the verse is: “Both male and female.”
<b>And if you would say</b> in response that <b>if the Merciful One had written:</b> Any <b>person</b> you shall send out, <b>I would say</b> that impure <b>metal vessels</b> need <b>not</b> be removed from the Temple either, as they are not included in the term: Any person, this is not correct. The Gemara elaborates: The <i>halakha</i> that impure metal vessels must be removed from the Temple <b>is derived from</b> the previous verse: “That they put out of the camp every leper, and every one that has an issue, and <b>whatever is impure by the dead”</b> (Numbers 5:2). Therefore, <b>why do I</b> need the verse to write: <b>“Both male and female</b> you shall send out,” instead of simply stating: Any person you shall send out? Clearly, the phrase: “Both male and female,” is necessary <b>for</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>of Rav.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, one can <b>say</b> that <b>the entire</b> phrase <b>comes for Rav’s</b> <i>halakha</i>, and not the <i>halakha</i> of Rabbi Yosei. The Gemara answers: <b>If so, let</b> the verse <b>write: Male and female. What</b> is the meaning of the phrase: <b>“Both male and female”?</b> The verse is referring <b>to any</b> ritually impure <b>item that has</b> the same <i>halakha</i> that applies to both males and females, i.e., it can attain <b>purity by</b> being immersed in <b>a ritual bath;</b> this excludes earthenware vessels.
With regard to Rav’s <i>halakha</i> that the prohibition of entering the Temple in a state of ritual impurity does not apply to one who is a <i>tumtum</i> or a hermaphrodite, the Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> then even <b>when they become impure with other types of impurity,</b> in addition to the impurity of a <i>zav</i> or a menstruating woman, a <i>tumtum</i> and a hermaphrodite <b>should</b> likewise <b>not be sent out</b> of the Temple, as the passage from which a <i>tumtum</i> and a hermaphrodite are excluded is also referring to other types of impurity: “That they put out of the camp every leper, and every one that has an issue, and whatever is impure by the dead” (Numbers 5:2). The Gemara answers: <b>The</b> next <b>verse states: “Both male,”</b> which is referring <b>to impurity</b> caused by a substance <b>that is emitted from the male</b> organ, i.e., <i>ziva</i>.
The Gemara raises a difficulty with regard to Rav’s derivation: <b>And</b> is it correct that <b>anywhere that</b> the phrase <b>“both male and female” is written</b> in the Torah, this <b>comes to exclude a <i>tumtum</i> and a hermaphrodite? But isn’t</b> a similar expression stated <b>with regard to valuations, as it is written:</b> “For <b>the male…</b>fifty shekels of silver, after the shekel of the Sanctuary. And if she is a female, then your valuation shall be thirty shekels” (Leviticus 27:3–4).
<b>And it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that it is derived from the term <b>“the male”: But not a <i>tumtum</i> or a hermaphrodite.</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that a <i>tumtum</i> or a hermaphrodite <b>shall not be</b> valuated <b>according to the valuation of a man,</b> which is fifty shekels, <b>but shall be</b> valuated <b>according to the valuation of a woman,</b> which is thirty shekels. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “The male,”</b> and the following verse states: <b>“And if she is a female,”</b> indicating that these <i>halakhot</i> apply only to <b>a definite male</b> or <b>a definite female, but not</b> to <b>a <i>tumtum</i> or a hermaphrodite.</b>
The Gemara explains the difficulty: <b>The reason</b> a <i>tumtum</i> and a hermaphrodite are excluded is <b>that it is written: “The male…and if she is a female,”</b> which indicates <b>that</b> if the verse had written: <b>Male and female,</b> without the superfluous words “the” and “if,” it would <b>not</b> have been derived that the verse <b>excludes</b> a <i>tumtum</i> and a hermaphrodite. This apparently contradicts the opinion of Rav, who excludes a <i>tumtum</i> and a hermaphrodite from the prohibition of entering the Temple in a state of impurity merely due to the phrase: “Male and female” (Numbers 5:3). The Gemara answers: In <b>that</b> verse with regard to valuations, the words “male” and “female” are themselves <b>necessary</b>

Daf 29a

in order <b>to differentiate between the valuation of a man and the valuation of a woman.</b> Therefore, it could not have been derived from that verse that a <i>tumtum</i> and a hermaphrodite are excluded from the <i>halakha</i> of valuations, were it not for the superfluous words “the” and “if.”
§ The mishna teaches that if the fetus <b>emerged in pieces, or</b> if it emerged <b>reversed,</b> i.e., feetfirst rather than headfirst; when most of its limbs emerge, its status is like that of a child born, with regard to the impurity of a woman after childbirth. <b>Rabbi Elazar says: Even</b> if <b>the head is among</b> the limbs that emerged, provided that the majority of the limbs did not yet emerge, the fetus is not considered born.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: They taught</b> in the mishna that the woman is not impure unless most of the fetus’s limbs emerged <b>only</b> in a case <b>where the head is not among</b> the limbs that emerged; <b>but</b> if <b>the head is among them, the head exempts</b> the woman’s future offspring from the obligation of primogeniture, as the fetus is considered born.
The Gemara asks: <b>Shall we say</b> that these Sages <b>disagree with regard to</b> the opinion <b>of Shmuel? As Shmuel said</b> that if a woman is pregnant with twins, and <b>the head</b> of one of the fetuses emerges and then disappears back into the womb, this <b>does not exempt</b> the other fetus from the obligation of primogeniture should it be born first. Shmuel says this specifically <b>in</b> a case of <b>non-viable newborns,</b> i.e., where the fetus whose head emerged was a non-viable newborn and the one that was eventually born first is a viable offspring. But if both are viable offspring, the emergence of the head is considered birth. The suggestion is that Rabbi Elazar agrees with the opinion of Shmuel, whereas Rabbi Yoḥanan disagrees with the opinion of Shmuel and maintains that the emergence of the head is considered birth even in the case of a non-viable newborn.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion, as it is possible that <b>in</b> the case of <b>a whole</b> non-viable newborn, <b>everyone,</b> i.e., Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>agrees</b> that the emergence of the head is considered a birth, contrary to the opinion of Shmuel. <b>When they disagree,</b> it is <b>in</b> the case of a fetus that emerged <b>in pieces. As</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Elazar, <b>holds</b> that <b>it is</b> specifically <b>in</b> the case of <b>a whole</b> non-viable newborn <b>that</b> the emergence of the head <b>is considered</b> birth, whereas <b>with regard to</b> a fetus that emerged <b>in pieces</b> it <b>is not considered</b> birth; <b>and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>holds</b> that <b>in</b> the case of a fetus that emerged <b>in pieces as well,</b> the emergence of the head <b>is considered</b> birth.
The Gemara cites <b>another version</b> of this discussion. <b>The reason</b> it is necessary for most of the limbs of the fetus to emerge for it to be considered born is <b>that it emerged in pieces, or</b> that it emerged <b>reversed,</b> i.e., feet first. It may be inferred from here that if it emerged <b>in its proper manner,</b> headfirst and whole, it is considered born, even according to Rabbi Elazar. Therefore, if the woman is pregnant with twins, the emergence of <b>the head exempts</b> the other twin from the obligations of primogeniture. Evidently, <b>both</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Elazar <b>do not hold</b> in accordance with the opinion <b>of Shmuel, as Shmuel said</b> that the emergence of <b>the head</b> of one of the twins <b>does not exempt</b> the other <b>in</b> a case of <b>non-viable newborns.</b>
<b>There are those who teach this <i>halakha</i> by itself,</b> i.e., not in reference to the mishna: <b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> The emergence of <b>the head</b> of a non-viable newborn <b>is not</b> considered <b>like</b> the emergence of <b>most of the limbs; and Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The emergence of <b>the head</b> of a non-viable newborn <b>is</b> considered <b>like</b> the emergence of <b>most of the limbs. And they disagree with regard to</b> the opinion <b>of Shmuel;</b> Rabbi Elazar holds in accordance with Shmuel’s opinion, whereas Rabbi Yoḥanan does not accept the opinion of Shmuel.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>We learned</b> in the mishna that if the fetus <b>emerged in pieces or</b> if it emerged <b>reversed, when most of its</b> limbs <b>emerge,</b> its status <b>is like</b> that of a child <b>born.</b> The Gemara infers: <b>From the fact that</b> the mishna <b>states: Or reversed, by inference</b> in the case of a fetus <b>that</b> emerged <b>in pieces</b> it emerged <b>in its proper manner,</b> i.e., the head first and then the body, <b>and</b> nevertheless the mishna <b>states</b> that it is only <b>when most of its</b> limbs <b>emerge</b> that its status <b>is like</b> that of a child <b>born.</b> This is <b>difficult for</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> as he maintains that once the head emerges, the fetus is considered born.
The Gemara explains that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> could have <b>said to you: Say</b> that the mishna is referring to a case where the fetus <b>emerged in pieces and reversed,</b> whereas if it emerged with its head first, it is considered born even if most of its limbs did not emerge yet.
The Gemara asks: <b>But doesn’t</b> the mishna <b>teach</b> that the fetus emerged in pieces <b>or</b> reversed? If so, it cannot be explained as referring to a case where the fetus emerged both in pieces and reversed. The Gemara answers that <b>this</b> is what the mishna <b>is saying:</b> If the fetus <b>emerged in pieces or whole, and</b> in both <b>this</b> case <b>and that</b> case it emerged <b>reversed,</b> then <b>when most of its</b> limbs <b>emerge,</b> its status <b>is like</b> that of a child <b>born.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa says:</b> This dispute between Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Yoḥanan is <b>parallel to</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> as it is stated in a <i>baraita</i>: If the fetus <b>emerged in pieces or reversed, when most of its</b> limbs <b>emerge</b> its status <b>is like</b> that of a child <b>born. Rabbi Yosei says:</b> Its status is like that of a child born <b>when it emerges in its proper manner.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> Rabbi Yosei <b>saying?</b> His statement apparently indicates that if a fetus emerges with its feet first, then even after most of its limbs emerge it is not considered born.
<b>Rav Pappa says</b> that <b>this</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> If the fetus <b>emerged in pieces or reversed, when most of its</b> limbs <b>emerge</b> its status <b>is like</b> that of a child <b>born; but</b> by inference, if the fetus emerged <b>in its proper manner,</b> then the emergence of <b>the head exempts</b> its twin, should it eventually be born first, from the obligations of primogeniture. And <b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> The status of a fetus that emerged in pieces is like that of a child born <b>when most of its</b> limbs <b>emerge,</b> provided that it emerged <b>in its proper manner,</b> i.e., both requirements are necessary. The suggestion is that the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan is in accordance with the ruling of the first <i>tanna</i>, that even if a fetus emerges in pieces, once its head emerges it is considered born; whereas the opinion of Rabbi Elazar follows the ruling of Rabbi Yosei that even if such a fetus emerges headfirst, it is not considered born.
<b>Rav Zevid objects to</b> Rav Pappa’s interpretation of the <i>baraita</i>: Since Rabbi Yosei issued his statement that both requirements are necessary, i.e., a majority of limbs and emergence in the proper manner, with regard to the two cases mentioned by the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>by inference in</b> the other case, <b>where</b> the fetus emerged <b>reversed, even</b> when <b>most of its</b> limbs emerge <b>it does not exempt</b> its twin from the obligations of primogeniture. But this is difficult, as <b>we maintain that the majority of</b> an item is considered <b>like all</b> of it. Accordingly, when most of the fetus’s limbs emerge it should be considered born even if it came out feetfirst.
<b>Rather, Rav Zevid says</b> that <b>this</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> If the fetus <b>emerged in pieces and reversed, when most of its</b> limbs <b>emerge</b> its status <b>is like</b> that of a child <b>born; but</b> by inference, if the fetus emerged <b>in its proper manner</b> then the emergence of <b>the head exempts</b> its twin from the obligations of primogeniture, even if it was born in pieces. <b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> The fetus is considered born once its head emerges only in a case <b>when it emerges in its proper manner alive;</b> if it emerges in pieces, the fetus is considered born only when most of its limbs emerge.
<b>This</b> explanation <b>is also taught</b> explicitly in another <i>baraita</i>: If the fetus <b>emerged in pieces</b> and <b>reversed,</b> then <b>when most of its</b> limbs <b>emerge</b> its status <b>is like</b> that of a child <b>born; but</b> if the fetus emerged <b>in its proper manner,</b> the emergence of <b>the head exempts</b> its twin. <b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> The fetus is considered born once its head emerges only in a case <b>where it emerges in its proper manner alive.</b>
<b>And what is</b> the exact stage when a fetus that emerged <b>in its proper manner alive</b> is considered born? <b>When most of its head emerges. And what is</b> the stage when <b>most of its head</b> emerges? <b>Rabbi Yosei says: When its temples emerge. Abba Ḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua: When its forehead emerges. And some say: When the corners of its head,</b> i.e., the projection of the head above the neck, <b>are visible.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of a woman <b>who discharges and it is not known what is</b> the fetus’s sex, she <b>shall observe</b> the strictures of a woman who gave birth both <b>to a male and to a female.</b> She is impure for fourteen days, like a woman who gave birth to a female, and any blood the woman sees only until forty days after birth, not eighty days thereafter, is pure, like a woman who gave birth to a male. If <b>it is unknown whether it was</b> a male or female <b>offspring</b> or <b>whether</b> it was <b>not</b> an offspring at all, <b>she shall observe</b> the period of impurity <b>for</b> a woman who gave birth to <b>a male and for</b> a woman who gave birth to <b>a female; and for</b> any blood that she sees, she observes the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a menstruating woman.</b> Since it is possible that what she discharged was not an offspring at all, any blood she sees might be due to menstruation, not childbirth.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says:</b> With regard to a pregnant woman who <b>passed across a river and she discharged</b> her fetus into the river, and she does not know whether the fetus was fully formed, <b>she brings</b> the <b>offering</b> of a woman after childbirth, which is a burnt offering and a sin offering. <b>And</b> the sin offering, which is a bird, <b>is eaten</b> after the nape of its neck has been pinched, in the manner of a regular bird sin offering. This is the <i>halakha</i> despite the uncertainty that this fetus might not have been fully formed, in which case the woman would not be obligated to bring this offering, and a bird that is not an offering may not be eaten if its nape was pinched. Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi explains the reasoning behind this ruling: One must <b>follow the majority of</b> pregnant <b>women, and most</b> pregnant <b>women give birth to full-fledged offspring.</b>
The Gemara analyzes this claim. <b>We learned</b> in the mishna: If <b>it is unknown whether</b> what the woman discharged <b>was</b> a male or female <b>offspring</b> or whether it was not an offspring at all, <b>she shall observe</b> the period of impurity <b>for</b> a woman who gave birth to <b>a male and for</b> a woman who gave birth to <b>a female; and for</b> any blood that she sees, she observes the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a menstruating woman.</b> The Gemara asks: According to the statement of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, <b>why must</b> the woman <b>observe</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a menstruating woman? Let us say</b> that one must <b>follow the majority of women, and the majority of women give birth to full-fledged offspring.</b> If so, she should observe a period of purity, during which any blood she sees is pure, after her period of impurity, like all women after childbirth.
The Gemara answers: The <i>halakha</i> in <b>the mishna</b> is referring <b>to</b> a case <b>where</b> the woman <b>had not been presumed</b> to be <b>pregnant</b> prior to her miscarriage; <b>and when Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says</b> that a woman who discharges is presumed to have discharged an offspring, he was speaking of a case <b>where</b> the woman <b>had been presumed</b> to be <b>pregnant</b> prior to her miscarriage.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a difficulty with regard to the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi from a <i>baraita</i>: There is the case of a kosher <b>animal</b> that had not yet given birth, <b>which went</b> to the pasture <b>full,</b> i.e., pregnant, <b>and came</b> back the same day <b>empty,</b> i.e., with no live offspring.It clearly discharged, but it is unknown whether or not it discharged an offspring, which would exempt the animal’s subsequent offspring from the status of a firstborn. In this case, the offspring <b>that comes after it</b> is <b>a firstborn</b> of <b>uncertain</b> status.
The Gemara asks: <b>But why</b> is this the <i>halakha</i>? According to Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, one should <b>follow</b> the reality among <b>the majority of animals, and the majority of animals give birth to full-fledged offspring. And</b> if so, <b>this</b> subsequent offspring of the animal <b>is a regular</b> offspring, i.e., it is definitely not a firstborn.
<b>Ravina says</b> in response: In this case, the <i>halakha</i> does not follow the majority of animals, <b>because it can be said</b> that <b>the majority of animals give birth to an item that exempts</b> the animal’s subsequent offspring <b>from firstborn</b> status, <b>but a minority of</b> animals <b>give birth to an item that does not exempt</b> the animal’s subsequent offspring <b>from firstborn</b> status, i.e., an item that is not a full-fledged offspring. <b>And</b> an additional factor is that <b>all</b> animals <b>that give birth</b> to full-fledged offspring <b>discharge turbid liquids</b> one day before giving birth, <b>and since this</b> animal <b>did not discharge turbid liquids</b> before going to the pasture, <b>the</b> effect of the <b>majority is undermined.</b> Consequently, the status of the animal’s birth is uncertain, and for this reason its subsequent offspring is considered a firstborn of uncertain status.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If all</b> animals <b>that give birth</b> to full-fledged offspring <b>discharge turbid liquids</b> before giving birth, then it should be concluded <b>from</b> the fact <b>that this</b> animal <b>did not discharge turbid liquids</b> that it did not discharge a full-fledged offspring, and therefore the animal’s subsequent offspring <b>is a proper firstborn,</b> not a firstborn of uncertain status. <b>Rather,</b> one should <b>say</b> that Ravina meant the following: <b>The majority of</b> animals that <b>give birth discharge turbid liquids</b> beforehand, <b>and</b> therefore, <b>since this</b> animal <b>did not discharge turbid liquids, the</b> effect of the <b>majority is undermined.</b>
§ <b>When Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>he said: Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi from the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a forgetful woman; but I do not know what the objection is.</b> The Gemara asks: This <i>halakha</i> of a forgetful woman, which forms the basis of the objection, <b>what is it?</b> The Gemara explains: <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>:

Daf 29b

<b>A woman left</b> home for an extended period of time while she was <b>full,</b> i.e., pregnant, <b>and came</b> back when she was <b>empty,</b> as she discharged the fetus, but it is unknown exactly when and what she discharged; <b>and she spent three weeks in our presence</b> during which she was <b>pure,</b> i.e., she did not experience any bleeding, <b>and</b> for the following <b>ten weeks</b> she alternated between <b>one impure</b> week, in which she experienced bleeding every day, <b>and one pure</b> week, in which she did not experience bleeding at all.
In such a case, the woman <b>may engage in intercourse</b> with her husband at the end of the fifth week following her return, <b>on the eve of the thirty-fifth</b> day, after which she is again prohibited from engaging in intercourse with her husband. <b>And we require her to immerse</b> in a ritual bath a total of <b>ninety-five immersions.</b> This is <b>the statement of Beit Shammai. And Beit Hillel say</b> that she is required to immerse <b>thirty-five</b> times. <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says:</b> She is required to immerse only once, as <b>it is sufficient for the immersion to be at the end</b> of the period when she is required to immerse every day. The entire <i>baraita</i> will be explained below.
The Gemara explains the objection from the <i>baraita</i> to the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi: <b>Granted</b> in the <b>first week</b> following her arrival the woman <b>may not engage in intercourse</b> with her husband, despite the fact that she did not experience bleeding during that week, as one can <b>say</b> that perhaps <b>she is a woman who gave birth to a male</b> just before her arrival, which would mean that the first week is her seven-day period of impurity. Likewise, it is clear that the woman may not engage in intercourse with her husband during the <b>second week</b> after her arrival, as one can <b>say</b> that <b>she is a woman who gave birth to a female,</b> and consequently her period of impurity is two weeks long.
It is also clear why she may not engage in intercourse during the <b>third week,</b> as one can <b>say</b> that perhaps <b>she is a woman who gave birth to a female as a <i>zava</i>,</b> i.e., a woman who experienced a discharge of uterine blood after her menstrual period for three days without the pain of labor, and therefore assumed the status of a <i>zava</i> before giving birth. If so, she must count seven clean days after her two-week period of impurity, and subsequently immerse.
<b>But</b> in the <b>fourth week, even though</b> the woman <b>sees blood</b> during that period, <b>let her engage in intercourse</b> with her husband, <b>as it is pure blood.</b> At this stage the woman’s period of purity is certainly underway. Why does the <i>baraita</i> state that she may not engage in intercourse with her husband in this week? Is it <b>not due to</b> the concern <b>that</b> she might have discharged an item that was not a full-fledged offspring? Evidently, although most pregnant women give birth to full-fledged offspring, <b>we do not follow the majority,</b> which contradicts the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi.
The Gemara asks: <b>Rather,</b> as this is apparently a valid objection, <b>what</b> is the reason that Ravin said: <b>I do not know what the objection</b> to the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi <b>is?</b> The Gemara explains: Perhaps it is in fact assumed that the woman gave birth to a full-fledged offspring, in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, and the reason she is not considered pure in the fourth week after her arrival is that one can <b>say</b> that <b>her birth was distant,</b> i.e., she gave birth a long time before her arrival, and therefore her period of purity had already ended before the fourth week.
§ The Gemara further analyzes the above <i>baraita</i>: During <b>this fifth week, when</b> the woman <b>is pure,</b> as she did not experience any bleeding, <b>let her engage in intercourse</b> with her husband. Why is she permitted to do so only on the eve of the thirty-fifth day, at the end of the fifth week?
The Gemara answers: During <b>this fourth week,</b> when she experiences bleeding every day, <b>we are uncertain</b> with regard to <b>each and every day as</b> to whether it is <b>the end of</b> the woman’s period of purity as a woman after <b>childbirth, and that</b> it is therefore <b>the beginning of</b> the seven-day period that she must observe as <b>a menstruating woman. And</b> with regard to the <b>twenty-eighth</b> day <b>itself,</b> the last day of the fourth week, one can also <b>say</b> that <b>it is</b> after the last day of her period of purity and <b>the beginning of</b> her period as <b>a menstruating woman, and</b> therefore <b>she is required to observe seven</b> days <b>for her menstruation,</b> which end on the thirty-fourth day after her arrival. Consequently, the woman may engage in intercourse with her husband only on the eve of the thirty-fifth day.
The Gemara further inquires: As explained above, the reason it is prohibited for the woman to engage in intercourse during the third week is that she might have given birth just before arriving and had been a <i>zava</i> at the time, and therefore after observing the two weeks of impurity of a woman after childbirth, she must observe an additional seven days of impurity as a <i>zava</i>. A <i>zava</i> may undergo her purification process on the seventh day of her impurity, following which she is permitted to engage in intercourse. Accordingly, <b>let</b> the woman <b>engage in intercourse on</b> the <b>twenty-first</b> day after her arrival.
The Gemara answers: The <i>halakha</i> in this <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, who said</b> that <b>it is prohibited</b> for a woman <b>to do so,</b> i.e., to engage in intercourse on the seventh day of her <i>ziva</i> after immersing in a ritual bath, <b>lest she come to</b> a case of <b>uncertainty.</b> If she engages in intercourse on that seventh day after immersion, and subsequently experiences bleeding on that same day, it retroactively nullifies her entire seven clean days, and it turns out that she engaged in intercourse while she was impure. The Gemara continues to ask: Even so, <b>let her engage in intercourse that night,</b> after having completed seven clean days. The Gemara answers: The <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>when</b> the woman <b>saw</b> blood <b>in the evening,</b> i.e., her fourth week of experiencing bleeding started in the nighttime.
§ The Gemara analyzes the statement of Beit Shammai: <b>And we require</b> the woman <b>to immerse</b> in a ritual bath for a total of <b>ninety-five immersions.</b> The Gemara explains: During <b>the first week she</b> is required <b>to immerse at night,</b> every night of the week. The reason is that as the date of her childbirth and the sex of the offspring are unknown, one can <b>say</b> that <b>she is a woman who gave birth to a male.</b> If so, the seven days of impurity might have ended on any night of the first week, and therefore she must immerse in a ritual bath on each night.
During the <b>second week, she</b> is required <b>to immerse at night,</b> every night, as one can <b>say</b> that <b>she is a woman who gave birth to a female,</b> and therefore it is possible that her fourteen-day period of impurity ended on any of the nights of the second week. She must also immerse every day of the second week <b>in the daytime,</b> as one can <b>say</b> that <b>she is a woman who gave birth to a male as a <i>zava</i>.</b> If so, it is possible that her seven-day period of impurity as a woman after childbirth ended on any given day during the first week, after which she must start to count seven clean days as a <i>zava</i>. These seven days necessarily culminate during the second week, and the <i>halakha</i> is that a woman must immerse in a ritual bath on the morning when her seven clean days of <i>ziva</i> conclude.
During the <b>third week, she</b> is required <b>to immerse</b> every day <b>in the daytime,</b> as one can <b>say</b> that <b>she is a woman who gave birth to a female as a <i>zava</i>,</b> and consequently her fourteen-day period of impurity as a woman after childbirth ended during the second week. Therefore, the woman’s seven clean days as a <i>zava</i> might end on any day of the third week, and she is obligated to immerse on that morning.
She is also required to immerse <b>on</b> every <b>night</b> of the third week, according to Beit Shammai. <b>Beit Shammai</b> conform <b>to their</b> line of <b>reasoning, as they say</b> in a mishna (71b) that a woman who finished her period of purity after childbirth, referred to as <b>a woman who immersed that long day</b> and is waiting for her purification process to be completed, <b>requires immersion</b> at the end of this period. The woman must therefore immerse on every night of the third week, in case that night is the end of her period of purity, for a total of thirty-five immersions by the end of the week. She must continue to immerse every night until her period of purity is certainly over, no matter when she gave birth, i.e., until the eightieth day since her arrival.

Daf 30a

The Gemara asks: <b>Now</b> consider, <b>how many days of purity are there,</b> in the case of a woman who gave birth to a female? There are <b>sixty-six</b> days. Therefore, in order to account for all of the nights that might occur immediately after the woman’s period of purity, she must immerse on sixty-six nights, according to Beit Shammai. <b>Remove</b> from this sum the immersions of the <b>third week, when we require</b> the woman <b>to immerse</b> seven times, and <b>sixty less one are left.</b> These <b>sixty-less-one</b> times she immerses after the third week <b>and</b> the <b>thirty-five</b> times she immerses during the first three weeks <b>are</b> together <b>ninety-four</b> immersions. If so, those <b>ninety-five</b> immersions, required by Beit Shammai, <b>what is their purpose?</b> Why do they require an extra immersion?
<b>Rav Yirmeya of Difti says:</b> The <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where</b> the woman <b>came before us,</b> i.e., she returned from her journey, <b>during twilight,</b> when it is halakhically uncertain whether it is day or night. The ruling is <b>that</b> in this case <b>we give her another immersion,</b> i.e., she is obligated to immerse on an additional day, in case she completed her days of impurity on the day she arrived, and that night is the night she must immerse.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to Beit Hillel, who say</b> that <b>a woman who immersed that long day,</b> i.e., a woman observing her period of purity after childbirth, <b>does not require immersion</b> once her period of purity is over, those <b>thirty-five</b> immersions that they require, <b>what is their purpose?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Twenty-eight</b> immersions are required <b>as we said</b> above, i.e., due to the end of the period of impurity in case the woman gave birth to a male or to a female, and due to the completion of the woman’s seven clean days in case she gave birth as a <i>zava</i>. In addition, during <b>this fifth week we require</b> the woman <b>to immerse each and every night,</b> as one can <b>say</b> that <b>it is the end of</b> her seven-day period as <b>a menstruating woman.</b>
The Gemara raises a further difficulty: <b>Why do I</b> need the <i>baraita</i> to state that after the woman did not experience any bleeding for the first three weeks after arriving, she alternated for <b>ten weeks</b> between experiencing bleeding every day for a week and not experiencing any bleeding for a week. How does this detail contribute to Beit Shammai’s ruling that the woman must immerse ninety-five times? After all, <b>eight and a half</b> weeks <b>are sufficient.</b> Combined with the first three weeks after the woman’s arrival, this period amounts to eighty days, which is the number of days on which the woman must immerse according to Beit Shammai, as each day might be the last of her period of purity.
The Gemara answers: Although eight and a half weeks are sufficient, <b>since</b> the <i>baraita</i> must <b>teach half a week, it completes</b> that week, for a total of nine weeks. <b>And since</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> with regard to the ninth <b>week</b> that the woman is <b>impure, it also taught</b> with regard to the tenth <b>week</b> that the woman is <b>pure,</b> in accordance with the pattern of a week of purity following every week of impurity.
With regard to the opinion of Beit Hillel that the woman immerses only thirty-five times, the Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t there the immersion</b> that the woman is obligated to perform <b>due to</b> the possibility that she is <b>a <i>zava</i>?</b> It is possible that by the fourth week, the woman’s period of purity after childbirth has already ended, and the bleeding she experiences that week is menstrual blood, in which case the next week that she sees blood renders her a <i>zava</i>. If so, she must immerse at the end of that week, after counting seven clean days. The same applies to all the other weeks on which she experiences bleeding, apart from the fourth. Consequently, there are additional immersions not counted by Beit Hillel.
The Gemara answers: Beit Hillel <b>count</b> only the times <b>that</b> the woman is obligated to immerse <b>before</b> she is permitted to engage in <b>intercourse</b> with her husband, which amount to thirty-five. They <b>do not count</b> the times <b>that</b> she must immerse <b>after</b> she is permitted to engage in <b>intercourse</b> with her husband.
The Gemara asks: <b>But according to Beit Shammai, who count</b> the times <b>that</b> the woman is obligated to immerse <b>after</b> she is permitted to engage in <b>intercourse</b> in their total of ninety-five immersions, <b>let them also count</b> those <b>immersions</b> in which the woman is obligated <b>due to</b> the possibility that she is <b>a <i>zava</i>.</b> The Gemara answers: Beit Shammai <b>deal with</b> immersions that are due to the woman’s <b>childbirth;</b> they do <b>not deal with</b> immersions that are due to the possibility of <b><i>ziva</i>.</b>
The Gemara questions this response: <b>But there are</b> immersions counted by Beit Shammai that are due to the possibility that she is <b>a woman who gave birth as a <i>zava</i>.</b> These immersions serve to purify the woman from her status as a <i>zava</i>, not as a woman after childbirth. The Gemara answers: Beit Shammai <b>count</b> immersions that are due to the possibility that she is <b>a woman who gave birth as a <i>zava</i>.</b> In such a scenario, immersion is delayed due to the childbirth, and is performed when the woman’s impurity period of <i>ziva</i> following childbirth is over. Therefore, these immersions are considered as connected to the childbirth. But Beit Shammai <b>do not count</b> immersions that are due to <b><i>ziva</i> alone.</b>
§ With regard to the statement of the <i>baraita</i> that the woman immerses on every night of the first week in case her period of impurity after childbirth just ended, the Gemara asks: Besides immersing on every night of <b>the first week after she came before us, let</b> the woman <b>immerse during the daytime</b> of every day of that week as well, <b>as perhaps</b> she is a <i>zava</i>, and on <b>each and every day</b> it is possible that <b>her counting</b> of clean days <b>are completed,</b> and she must therefore immerse that morning. Accordingly, seven more immersions should be added to the count.
The Gemara answers: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> statement? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, who said</b> that <b>we require</b> that the seven clean days of a <i>zava</i> must be <b>counted in our presence,</b> i.e., they must actually be counted. Since she did not know she should count before she arrived, she did not begin counting prior to her arrival. Therefore, her seven clean days begin only once she arrives, and she cannot immerse from her status as a <i>zava</i> of uncertain status before the end of the first week.
The Gemara raises a further difficulty: Even so, <b>let her immerse</b> at <b>the end of the first week,</b> on the morning of the seventh day, after counting seven clean days following her return. This adds one more immersion to the count. The Gemara answers: The <i>baraita</i> <b>is not dealing with</b> immersions that the woman is obligated to perform <b>once a week.</b>
The Gemara further inquires: <b>Let</b> the woman <b>immerse</b> on <b>the first day that she came before us, as perhaps she is</b> a lesser <i>zava</i>, i.e., <b>a woman who</b> experienced a discharge of uterine blood after her menstrual period for one or two consecutive days, and who therefore <b>observes</b> a clean <b>day for a day</b> she experiences a discharge. The Gemara answers: The <i>baraita</i> <b>is dealing with a greater <i>zava</i></b> alone, i.e., one who experienced a discharge for three consecutive days and must therefore count seven clean days before immersing; <b>it is not dealing with a lesser <i>zava</i>.</b>
§ The Gemara summarizes its analysis of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Conclude from it three</b> conclusions. <b>Conclude from it</b> that the <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, who said</b> that <b>we require</b> that the seven clean days of a <i>zava</i> must be <b>counted in our presence.</b>
<b>And conclude from it</b> that the <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, who says</b> that it is permitted in principle for a <i>zava</i> to engage in intercourse with her husband on her seventh clean day after immersing in a ritual bath, <b>but</b> that <b>the Sages said</b> that <b>it is prohibited</b> for her <b>to do so, lest she come to</b> a case of <b>uncertainty,</b> i.e., in case she experiences a discharge of blood after engaging in intercourse, which retroactively nullifies her entire seven clean days and renders her impure.
<b>And</b> finally, <b>conclude from it</b> that <b>immersion at its proper time is a mitzva,</b> which is why the woman immerses every day despite the fact it remains prohibited for her to engage in intercourse. <b>But Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: It is sufficient for the immersion to be at the end, and we do not say</b> that <b>immersion at its proper time is a mitzva</b> in its own right. Consequently, the woman is obligated to perform only one immersion.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> A woman <b>who discharges on the fortieth day</b> since she immersed herself and engaged in intercourse with her husband need <b>not be concerned that</b> it might have been <b>an offspring</b> and she became impure with its miscarriage, as the formation of the offspring in the womb occurs only forty days after conception. But in the case of a woman who discharges <b>on the forty-first day</b> after immersion, there is concern that perhaps it was an offspring. Since its sex is unknown, <b>she shall observe</b> the period of impurity <b>for</b> a woman who gave birth to <b>a male and for</b> a woman who gave birth to <b>a female; and for</b> any blood that she sees, she observes the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a menstruating woman.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yishmael says:</b> A woman who discharges on the <b>forty-first day</b> after immersion <b>observes</b> the seven days of impurity <b>for</b> a woman who gave birth to <b>a male; and for</b> any blood that she sees after seven days, she observes the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a menstruating woman.</b> But a woman who discharges on the <b>eighty-first day</b> after immersion <b>observes</b> the strictures of a woman who gave birth both <b>to a male and to a female, and</b> also the strictures <b>of a menstruating woman, as</b> the formation of <b>the male</b> offspring <b>concludes on</b> the <b>forty-first</b> day <b>and</b> the formation of <b>the female</b> offspring concludes <b>on</b> the <b>eighty-first</b> day. <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> With regard to <b>both the formation of the male and the formation of the female, this and that</b> conclude on the <b>forty-first</b> day.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara discusses the statement of the mishna that a woman who discharges on the forty-first day after immersion observes the strictures of a woman who gave birth to both a male and a female, and the strictures of a menstruating woman. <b>Why</b> are the strictures of a woman who gave birth to <b>a male mentioned</b> in this statement? What additional strictures must the woman observe due to the possibility that she gave birth to a male, over and above those she observes for the birth of a female?
