<b>If</b> these strictures are mentioned due <b>to the days of impurity</b> that a woman who gave birth to a male must observe, <b>doesn’t</b> the mishna in any case <b>teach</b> that the woman observes the strictures of a woman who gave birth to <b>a female?</b> The seven days of impurity that are observed by a woman who gave birth to a male are included in the fourteen days of impurity that she observes for a female. <b>And if</b> these strictures are mentioned due <b>to the days of purity</b> that are observed by a woman who gave birth to a male, which are fewer than the days of purity that are observed for the birth of a female,

Daf 30b

<b>doesn’t</b> the mishna <b>teach</b> that the woman observes the strictures of <b>a menstruating woman,</b> i.e., she is considered ritually impure every time she experiences bleeding, and does not observe any period of purity at all?
The Gemara answers: The mishna mentions that the woman observes the strictures of a woman who gave birth to a male to teach <b>that if she sees</b> blood on the <b>thirty-fourth day</b> after her miscarriage <b>and again sees</b> blood on the <b>forty-first day,</b> her purity status <b>shall be ruined,</b> i.e., she shall be prohibited from engaging in intercourse, <b>until</b> the <b>forty-eighth</b> day. If she were not observing the strictures of a woman who gave birth to a male, but only those of a menstruating woman and one who gave birth to a female, she would not have to wait seven days after seeing blood on the forty-first day. Instead, she would wait only one day, as her possible seven-day period of menstruation began on the thirty-fourth day and ended on the fortieth. Yet, as she might have given birth to a male, the forty-first day might be the first day after her period of purity, and therefore the first of her seven days of menstruation. Consequently, she must consider herself impure until the forty-eighth day.
<b>And similarly, with regard to</b> the <i>halakha</i> that she observes the strictures of a woman who gave birth to <b>a female,</b> one ramification is <b>that if she sees</b> blood on the <b>seventy-fourth day and again sees</b> blood on the <b>eighty-first day,</b> her purity status <b>shall be ruined until</b> the <b>eighty-eighth</b> day. Although she observes ritual impurity after discovering bleeding on the seventy-fourth day, as perhaps she has the status of a menstruating woman, when she discovers bleeding on the eighty-first day she must begin the count of seven days of menstruation again, in case the seventy-fourth day was during her period of purity after having given birth to a female.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Yishmael says:</b> A woman who discharges on the <b>forty-first day</b> after immersion <b>observes</b> both the strictures of a woman who gave birth <b>to a male, and</b> those <b>of a menstruating woman,</b> but not the strictures of a woman who gave birth to a female, as the formation of a male offspring takes forty-one days, whereas the formation of a female offspring takes eighty-one days. <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yishmael says,</b> in explanation of his opinion: <b>In</b> the case of a woman who gave birth to <b>a male,</b> the verse <b>deems</b> her <b>impure</b> for seven days <b>and deems</b> her <b>pure</b> for an additional thirty-three days, for a total of forty days; <b>and with regard to</b> a woman who gave birth to <b>a female,</b> the verse <b>deems</b> her <b>impure</b> for fourteen days <b>and deems</b> her <b>pure</b> for another sixty-six days, for a total of eighty days.
It can therefore be inferred that <b>just as when</b> the verse <b>deems</b> a woman <b>impure and</b> then <b>deems</b> her <b>pure</b> for a total of forty days <b>in</b> the case of <b>a male, its</b> amount of time <b>is parallel to</b> the time of <b>the formation of</b> a male embryo; <b>so too, when</b> the verse <b>deems</b> a woman <b>impure and deems</b> her <b>pure</b> for a total of eighty days <b>in</b> the case of <b>a female, its</b> amount of time <b>is parallel to</b> the time of <b>the formation of</b> a female embryo. Accordingly, the formation of a female ends on the eighty-first day after conception. The Rabbis <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yishmael in response: <b>One cannot derive</b> the amount of time of the <b>formation</b> of an embryo <b>from</b> the extent of a woman’s period of <b>impurity</b> after giving birth.
Furthermore, the Rabbis <b>said to Rabbi Yishmael</b> that there is a proof against his opinion from <b>an incident involving Cleopatra, Queen of Alexandria. Since her maidservants were sentenced to death by the government, she</b> took advantage of the opportunity and <b>experimented on them</b> in order to examine the amount of time it takes for an embryo to develop. She had her maidservants engage in intercourse and operated on them following their execution in order to determine the stage at which an embryo is fully formed, <b>and found</b> that both in <b>this</b> case, when the embryo is male, <b>and that</b> case, when it is female, the formation is complete <b>on the forty-first</b> day after conception. Rabbi Yishmael <b>said to them</b> in response: <b>I bring you proof from the Torah, and you bring me proof from the fools?</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What proof from the Torah</b> does Rabbi Yishmael bring for his opinion? <b>If we say</b> that his proof is the aforementioned derivation that <b>in</b> the case of a woman who gave birth to <b>a male,</b> the verse <b>deems</b> her <b>impure</b> for seven days <b>and deems</b> her <b>pure</b> for an additional thirty-three days, for a total of forty days; <b>and in</b> the case of <b>a female,</b> the verse <b>deems</b> her <b>impure</b> for fourteen days <b>and deems</b> her <b>pure</b> for an additional sixty-six days, for a total of eighty days, <b>didn’t</b> the Rabbis <b>say to him</b> in response that <b>one cannot derive</b> the amount of time that the <b>formation</b> of an embryo takes <b>from</b> the extent of a woman’s period of <b>impurity</b> after giving birth?
The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yishmael’s derivation is that <b>the verse states:</b> “If a woman bears seed and gives birth to a male…and if <b>she gives birth</b> to a female” (Leviticus 12:2–5). <b>The verse adds another</b> explicit mention of <b>childbirth with regard to a female,</b> besides the mention of childbirth in the case of a male, when it could have simply stated: And if it is a female. Rabbi Yishmael derives from here that not only are the periods of ritual impurity and purity of one who gives birth to a female double those of a woman who gives birth to a male, but the formation of a female embryo also takes twice the time.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> for <b>what</b> reason does Rabbi Yishmael refer to the proof that the Rabbis cited from Cleopatra’s experiment as <b>a proof from the fools?</b> The Gemara answers: One can <b>say</b> that the maidservant who was pregnant with <b>a female</b> embryo <b>became pregnant first, forty days before</b> the maidservant who was pregnant with <b>a male</b> embryo. Consequently, it took the female embryo eighty days to be develop, not forty.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how would <b>the Rabbis</b> respond to this claim? The Gemara answers: Cleopatra <b>gave</b> the maidservants <b>a purgative medicine to drink</b> before they engaged in intercourse, which would have terminated any previous pregnancy. <b>And Rabbi Yishmael</b> would respond that <b>there are bodies that are not affected by</b> this <b>medicine,</b> i.e., certain pregnancies are not terminated by the medicine. Consequently, the maidservant who was pregnant with a female embryo might have been pregnant prior to the experiment.
The Gemara cites another <i>baraita</i> that presents a different version of this exchange between Rabbi Yishmael and the Rabbis: <b>Rabbi Yishmael said to</b> the Rabbis that there is a proof for his opinion from <b>an incident involving Cleopatra, the Greek queen, as her maidservants were sentenced to death by the government, and she experimented on them and found</b> that <b>a male</b> embryo is fully formed <b>on the forty-first</b> day after conception, <b>and a female</b> embryo is formed <b>on the eighty-first</b> day. The Rabbis <b>said to him: One does not bring proof from the fools.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>What is the reason</b> the Rabbis consider this a proof from the fools? They claim that it is possible that <b>this</b> woman <b>who</b> was pregnant with <b>a female</b> embryo did not conceive when Cleopatra had her engage in intercourse; rather, she <b>waited forty days, and then became pregnant</b> when she again engaged in intercourse. Therefore, the embryo was formed in forty days.
<b>And</b> how would <b>Rabbi Yishmael</b> respond to this claim? He would claim that the maidservants could not have conceived on a later date, as Cleopatra <b>transferred them to</b> the custody of <b>a steward,</b> who made sure that they did not engage in intercourse during the experiment. <b>And the Rabbis</b> would say that <b>there is no steward [<i>apotropos</i>] for</b> restraining <b>sexual intercourse,</b> and therefore one can <b>say</b> that the <b>warden himself engaged in intercourse with</b> the maidservant.
The Gemara raises a difficulty with regard to Rabbi Yishmael’s proof: <b>But</b> how can one be sure that the female embryo was formed after eighty-one days? <b>Perhaps if</b> the womb <b>of</b> the woman carrying <b>this female</b> embryo <b>would have been torn</b> open <b>on the forty-first</b> day after conception, the female embryo <b>would have</b> already <b>been found</b> in it, <b>just as</b> in the case of <b>a male</b> embryo. <b>Abaye says</b> in response: It was a case <b>where the indications of</b> the ages of the two embryos, e.g., their hairs and fingernails, <b>were identical.</b> Evidently, the female embryo developed in eighty days to the same degree that the male embryo developed in forty days.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And the Rabbis say: Both the formation of the male and the formation of the female</b> conclude on the forty-first day. The Gemara asks: The statement of <b>the Rabbis is</b> identical to the statement of <b>the first <i>tanna</i>.</b> Why does the mishna repeat this opinion in the name of the Rabbis?
<b>And if you would say</b> that the purpose is <b>to</b> teach that <b>the unattributed</b> opinion mentioned in <b>the first clause</b> of the mishna is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, and</b> therefore it is the <i>halakha</i>, as when there is a disagreement between <b>an individual</b> Sage <b>and many</b> Sages, the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of the <b>many,</b> this cannot be the reason. The Gemara explains: It is <b>obvious</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the unattributed opinion mentioned in the first clause of the mishna, as this is a general halakhic principle.
The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>from</b> the fact that <b>the explanation of</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael stands to reason, as the verses</b> apparently <b>support it,</b> the <i>halakha</i> should be in accordance with his opinion, therefore the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that the majority of Sages agree with the unattributed opinion mentioned in the first clause of the mishna.
§ <b>Rabbi Samlai taught: To what is a fetus in its mother’s womb comparable? To a folded notebook [<i>lefinkas</i>]. And it rests with its hands on its two sides</b> of its head, at the temples, <b>its two arms [<i>atzilav</i>] on its two knees, and its two heels on its two buttocks, and its head rests between its knees, and its mouth is closed, and its umbilicus is open. And it eats from what its mother eats, and it drinks from what its mother drinks, and it does not emit excrement lest it kill its mother. But once it emerges into the airspace of the world, the closed</b> limb, i.e., its mouth, <b>opens, and the open</b> limb, its umbilicus, <b>closes, as otherwise it cannot live</b> for <b>even one hour.</b>
<b>And a candle is lit for it above its head, and it gazes from one end of the world to the other, as it is stated: “When His lamp shined above my head, and by His light I walked through darkness”</b> (Job 29:3). <b>And do not wonder</b> how one can see from one end of the world to the other, <b>as a person can sleep here,</b> in this location, <b>and see a dream</b> that takes place <b>in</b> a place as distant as <b>Spain [<i>beAspamya</i>].</b>
<b>And there are no days when a person is in a more blissful state than those days</b> when he is a fetus in his mother’s womb, <b>as it is stated</b> in the previous verse: <b>“If only I were as in the months of old, as in the days when God watched over me”</b> (Job 29:2). <b>And</b> the proof that this verse is referring to gestation is as follows: <b>Which are</b> the <b>days that have months but do not have years? You must say</b> that <b>these are</b> the <b>months of gestation.</b>
<b>And</b> a fetus <b>is taught the entire Torah</b> while in the womb, <b>as it is stated: “And He taught me and said to me: Let your heart hold fast My words; keep My commandments, and live”</b> (Proverbs 4:4). <b>And it</b> also <b>states:</b> “As I was in the days of my youth, <b>when the converse of God was upon my tent”</b> (Job 29:4).
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the purpose of the statement: <b>And it</b> also <b>states:</b> “When the converse of God was upon my tent”? Why is it necessary to cite this verse in addition to the previously quoted verse from Proverbs? The Gemara explains: <b>And if you would say</b> that the verse in Proverbs is insufficient, as <b>it is a prophet who is saying</b> that he was taught the entire Torah in his mother’s womb, but this does not apply to ordinary people, <b>come</b> and <b>hear</b> the verse in Job: <b>“When the converse of God was upon my tent.”</b>
<b>And once</b> the fetus <b>emerges into the airspace of the world, an angel comes and slaps it on its mouth, causing it to forget the entire Torah, as it is stated: “Sin crouches at the entrance”</b> (Genesis 4:7), i.e., when a person enters the world he is immediately liable to sin due to his loss of Torah knowledge.
<b>And</b> a fetus <b>does not leave</b> the womb <b>until</b> the angels <b>administer an oath to it, as it is stated: “That to Me every knee shall bow, every tongue shall swear”</b> (Isaiah 45:23). The verse is interpreted as follows: <b>“That to Me every knee shall bow”; this is</b> referring to <b>the day of</b> one’s <b>death, as it is stated: “All those who go down to the dust shall kneel before Him”</b> (Psalms 22:30). <b>“Every tongue shall swear”; this is</b> referring to <b>the day of</b> one’s <b>birth, as it is stated</b> in description of a righteous person: <b>“He who has clean hands, and a pure heart, who has not taken My name in vain, and has not sworn deceitfully”</b> (Psalms 24:4), i.e., he has kept the oath that he took before he was born.
<b>And what is the oath that</b> the angels <b>administer to</b> the fetus? <b>Be righteous and do not be wicked. And even</b> if <b>the entire world says to you: You are righteous, consider yourself wicked. And know that the Holy One, Blessed be He, is pure, and His ministers are pure, and the soul that He gave you is pure. If you preserve it in</b> a state of <b>purity,</b> all is <b>well, but if</b> you do <b>not</b> keep it pure, <b>I,</b> the angel, <b>shall take it from you.</b>
<b>The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught a parable:</b> This matter is comparable <b>to a priest who gave <i>teruma</i>,</b> the portion of the produce designated for the priest, <b>to one who is unreliable with regard to ritual impurity [<i>am ha’aretz</i>],</b> and therefore it is suspected that he might not maintain the purity of the <i>teruma</i>. <b>And</b> the priest <b>said to him: If you keep it in</b> a state of <b>ritual purity,</b> all is <b>well, but if</b> you do <b>not</b> keep it pure, <b>I shall burn it before you.</b>
<b>Rabbi Elazar said:</b>

Daf 31a

<b>What is the verse</b> from which it is derived that a fetus is administered an oath on the day of its birth? “Upon You I have relied from birth; <b>You are He Who took me out [<i>gozi</i>] of my mother’s womb”</b> (Psalms 71:6). <b>From where may</b> it <b>be inferred that this</b> word: <b>“<i>Gozi</i>,” is a term of administering an oath? As it is written: “Cut off [<i>gozi</i>] your hair and cast it away”</b> (Jeremiah 7:29), which is interpreted as a reference to the vow of a nazirite, who must cut off his hair at the end of his term of naziriteship.
<b>And Rabbi Elazar says: To what is a fetus in its mother’s womb comparable?</b> It is comparable <b>to a nut placed in a basin</b> full <b>of water,</b> floating on top of the water. If <b>a person puts his finger on top of</b> the nut, <b>it sinks</b> either <b>in this direction or in that direction.</b>
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: During <b>the first three months</b> of pregnancy, the <b>fetus resides in the lower compartment</b> of the womb; in the <b>middle</b> three months, the <b>fetus resides in the middle compartment;</b> and during the <b>last</b> three months of pregnancy the <b>fetus resides in the upper compartment. And once its time to emerge arrives, it turns upside down and emerges; and this is</b> what causes <b>labor pains.</b>
With regard to the assertion that labor pains are caused by the fetus turning upside down, the Gemara notes: <b>And this is</b> the explanation for <b>that which we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The labor pains experienced by</b> a woman who gives birth to <b>a female are greater than</b> those <b>experienced by</b> a woman who gives birth to <b>a male.</b> The Gemara will explain this below.
<b>And Rabbi Elazar says: What is the verse</b> from which it is derived that a fetus initially resides in the lower part of the womb? <b>“When I was made in secret, and I was woven together in the lowest parts of the earth”</b> (Psalms 139:15). Since it <b>is not stated: I resided</b> in the lowest parts of the earth, <b>but rather: “I was woven together</b> in the lowest parts of the earth,” this teaches that during the initial stage of a fetus’s development, when it is woven together, its location is in the lower compartment of the womb.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about <b>the labor pains experienced by</b> a woman who gives birth to <b>a female,</b> that they <b>are greater than those experienced by</b> a woman who gives birth to <b>a male?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> one, a male fetus, <b>emerges in the manner in which it engages in intercourse.</b> Just as a male engages in intercourse facing downward, so too, it is born while facing down. <b>And that</b> one, a female fetus, <b>emerges in the manner in which it engages in intercourse,</b> i.e., facing upward. Consequently, <b>that</b> one, a female fetus, <b>turns its face around</b> before it is born, <b>but this</b> one, a male fetus, <b>does not turn its face around</b> before it is born.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: During <b>the first three months</b> of pregnancy, <b>sexual intercourse is difficult</b> and harmful <b>for the woman and is also difficult for the offspring.</b> During the <b>middle</b> three months, intercourse is <b>difficult for the woman but is beneficial for the offspring.</b> During the <b>last</b> three months, sexual intercourse is <b>beneficial for the woman and beneficial for the offspring; as a result of it the offspring is found to be strong and fair skinned.</b>
The Sages <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who engages in intercourse</b> with his wife <b>on the ninetieth day</b> of her pregnancy, <b>it is as though he spills</b> her <b>blood.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>How does one know</b> that it is the ninetieth day of her pregnancy? <b>Rather, Abaye says: One should go ahead and engage in intercourse</b> with his wife even if it might be the ninetieth day, <b>and</b> rely on God to prevent any ensuing harm, as the verse states: <b>“The Lord preserves the simple”</b> (Psalms 116:6).
§ <b>The Sages taught: There are three partners in</b> the creation of <b>a person: The Holy One, Blessed be He, and his father, and his mother. His father emits the white seed, from which</b> the following body parts are formed: The <b>bones,</b> the <b>sinews,</b> the <b>nails,</b> the <b>brain that is in its head, and</b> the <b>white of the eye. His mother emits red seed, from which</b> are formed the <b>skin,</b> the <b>flesh,</b> the <b>hair, and</b> the <b>black of the eye. And the Holy One, Blessed be He, inserts into him a spirit, a soul,</b> his <b>countenance [<i>ukelaster</i>], eyesight, hearing of the ear,</b> the capability of <b>speech</b> of <b>the mouth,</b> the capability of <b>walking</b> with <b>the legs, understanding, and wisdom.</b>
<b>And when</b> a person’s <b>time to depart from the world arrives, the Holy One, Blessed be He, retrieves His part, and He leaves the part of</b> the person’s <b>father and mother before them. Rav Pappa said: This</b> is in accordance with the adage <b>that people say: Remove the salt</b> from a piece of meat, <b>and</b> you may then <b>toss the meat to a dog,</b> as it has become worthless.
§ <b>Rav Ḥinnana bar Pappa taught: What</b> is the meaning of that <b>which is written: “Who does great deeds beyond comprehension, wondrous deeds without number”</b> (Job 9:10)? <b>Come and see that the attribute of flesh and blood is unlike the attribute of the Holy One, Blessed be He. The attribute of flesh and blood</b> is that if one <b>puts an article in a flask,</b> even if the flask is <b>tied and its opening</b> faces <b>upward, it is uncertain whether</b> the item <b>is preserved</b> from getting lost, <b>and it is uncertain whether it is not preserved</b> from being lost. <b>But the Holy One, Blessed be He, forms the fetus in a woman’s open womb, and its opening</b> faces <b>downward, and</b> yet the fetus <b>is preserved.</b>
<b>Another matter</b> that demonstrates the difference between the attributes of God and the attributes of people is that when <b>a person places his articles on a scale</b> to be measured, <b>the heavier</b> the item <b>is,</b> the more <b>it descends. But</b> when <b>the Holy One, Blessed be He,</b> forms a fetus, <b>the heavier the offspring gets,</b> the more <b>it ascends upward</b> in the womb.
<b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili taught: What</b> is the meaning of that <b>which is written: “I will give thanks to You, for I am fearfully and wonderfully made; wonderful are Your works, and that my soul knows very well”</b> (Psalms 139:14)? <b>Come and see that the attribute of flesh and blood is unlike the attribute of the Holy One, Blessed be He. The attribute of flesh and blood</b> is that when <b>a person plants seeds</b> of different species <b>in</b> one <b>garden bed, each and every one</b> of the seeds <b>emerges</b> as a grown plant <b>according to its species. But the Holy One, Blessed be He, forms the fetus in a woman’s womb, and all of</b> the seeds, i.e., those of both the father and the mother, <b>emerge</b> when the offspring is formed <b>as one</b> sex.
<b>Alternatively,</b> when <b>a dyer puts herbs in a cauldron [<i>leyora</i>], they all emerge as one color</b> of dye, <b>whereas the Holy One, Blessed be He, forms the fetus in a woman’s womb,</b> and <b>each and every one</b> of the seeds <b>emerges as its own type.</b> In other words, the seed of the father form distinct elements, such as the white of the eye, and the seed of the mother forms other elements, such as the black of the eye, as explained above.
<b>Rav Yosef taught: What</b> is the meaning of that <b>which is written:</b> “And on that day you shall say: <b>I will give thanks to You, Lord, for You were angry with me; Your anger is turned away, and You comfort me”</b> (Isaiah 12:1)? <b>With regard to what</b> matter <b>is the verse speaking?</b>
It is referring, for example, <b>to two people who left</b> their homes to go <b>on a business</b> trip. <b>A thorn penetrated</b> the body <b>of one of them,</b> and he was consequently unable to go with his colleague. <b>He started blaspheming and cursing</b> in frustration. <b>After a period of time, he heard that the ship of the other</b> person <b>had sunk in the sea,</b> and realized that the thorn had saved him from death. He then <b>started thanking</b> God <b>and praising</b> Him for his delivery due to the slight pain caused to him by the thorn. This is the meaning of the statement: I will give thanks to You, Lord, for You were angry with me. <b>Therefore, it is stated</b> at the end of the verse: <b>“Your anger is turned away, and You comfort me.”</b>
<b>And this</b> statement <b>is</b> identical to <b>that which Rabbi Elazar said: What</b> is the meaning of that <b>which is written:</b> “Blessed be the Lord God, the God of Israel, <b>Who does wondrous things alone; and blessed be His glorious name forever”</b> (Psalms 72:18–19)? What does it mean that God “does wondrous things alone”? It means that <b>even the one for whom the miracle was performed does not recognize the miracle</b> that was performed for <b>him.</b>
<b>Rabbi Ḥanina bar Pappa taught: What</b> is the meaning of that <b>which is written: “You measure [<i>zerita</i>] my going about [<i>orḥi</i>] and my lying down [<i>riv’i</i>], and are acquainted with all my ways”</b> (Psalms 139:3)? This verse <b>teaches that a person is not created from the entire drop</b> of semen, <b>but from its clear</b> part. <i>Zerita</i> can mean to winnow, while <i>orḥi</i> and <i>riv’i</i> can both be explained as references to sexual intercourse. Therefore the verse is interpreted homiletically as saying that God separates the procreative part of the semen from the rest. <b>The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught a parable:</b> This matter is comparable <b>to a person who winnows</b> grain <b>in the granary; he takes the food and leaves the waste.</b>
This is <b>in accordance with</b> a statement <b>of Rabbi Abbahu, as Rabbi Abbahu raises a contradiction: It is written</b> in one of King David’s psalms: <b>“For You have girded me [<i>vatazreni</i>] with strength for battle”</b> (II Samuel 22:40), without the letter <i>alef</i> in <i>vatazreni</i>; <b>and it is written</b> in another psalm: <b>“Who girds me [<i>hame’azreni</i>] with strength”</b> (Psalms 18:33), with an <i>alef</i> in <i>hame’azreini</i>. What is the difference between these two expressions? <b>David said before the Holy One, Blessed be He: Master of the Universe, You selected me [<i>zeiritani</i>],</b> i.e., You separated between the procreative part and the rest of the semen in order to create me, <b>and You have girded me [<i>zeraztani</i>] with strength.</b>
<b>Rabbi Abbahu taught: What</b> is the meaning of that <b>which is written</b> in Balaam’s blessing: <b>“Who has counted the dust of Jacob, or numbered the stock [<i>rova</i>] of Israel”</b> (Numbers 23:10)? The verse <b>teaches that the Holy One, Blessed be He, sits and counts the times that the Jewish people engage in intercourse [<i>revi’iyyoteihem</i>],</b> anticipating the time <b>when the drop from which the righteous person will be created will arrive.</b>
<b>And</b> it was <b>due to this matter</b> that <b>the eye of wicked Balaam went blind. He said: Should</b> God, <b>who is pure and holy, and whose ministers are pure and holy, peek at this matter? Immediately his eye was blinded</b> as a divine punishment, <b>as it is written: “The saying of the man whose eye is shut”</b> (Numbers 24:3).
<b>And this</b> statement <b>is</b> the same as that <b>which Rabbi Yoḥanan said: What</b> is the meaning of that <b>which is written,</b> with regard to Leah’s conceiving Issachar: <b>“And he lay with her that night”</b> (Genesis 30:16)? The verse <b>teaches that the Holy One, Blessed be He, contributed to that act.</b> The manner in which God contributed to this act is derived from another verse, <b>as it is stated: “Issachar is a large-boned [<i>garem</i>] donkey”</b> (Genesis 49:14). This teaches that God directed Jacob’s <b>donkey</b> toward Leah’s tent so that he would engage in intercourse with her, thereby <b>causing [<i>garam</i>]</b> Leah’s conceiving <b>Issachar.</b>
§ <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak says</b> that <b>Rabbi Ami says:</b> The sex of a fetus is determined at the moment of conception. If the <b>woman emits seed first, she gives birth to a male,</b> and if the <b>man emits seed first, she gives birth to a female, as it is stated: “If a woman bears seed and gives birth to a male”</b> (Leviticus 12:2).
<b>The Sages taught: At first,</b> people <b>would say</b> that if the <b>woman emits seed first she gives birth to a male,</b> and if the <b>man emits seed first, she gives birth to a female. But the Sages did not explain</b> from which verse this <b>matter</b> is derived, <b>until Rabbi Tzadok came and explained</b> that <b>it</b> is derived from the following verse: <b>“These are the sons of Leah, whom she bore to Jacob in Paddan Aram, with his daughter Dinah”</b> (Genesis 46:15). From the fact that the verse <b>attributes the males to the females,</b> as the males are called: The sons of Leah, <b>and</b> it attributes <b>the females to the males,</b>in that Dinah is called: His daughter, it is derived that if the woman emits seed first she gives birth to a male, whereas if the man emits seed first, she bears a female.
This statement is also derived from the following verse: <b>“And the sons of Ulam were mighty men of valor, archers, and had many sons and sons’ sons”</b> (I Chronicles 8:40). <b>Is it in a person’s power to have many sons and sons’ sons? Rather, because</b>

Daf 31b

<b>they delay</b> while <b>in</b> their wives’ <b>abdomen,</b> initially refraining from emitting semen <b>so that their wives will emit seed first,</b> in order <b>that their children will be male, the verse ascribes them</b> credit <b>as though they have many sons and sons’ sons. And this</b> statement <b>is</b> the same as that <b>which Rav Ketina said: I could have made all of my children males,</b> by refraining from emitting seed until my wife emitted seed first. <b>Rava says</b> another method through which one can cause his children to be males: <b>One who wishes to make all of his children males should engage in intercourse</b> with his wife <b>and repeat</b> the act.
§ <b>And Rabbi Yitzḥak says</b> that <b>Rabbi Ami says: A woman becomes pregnant only</b> by engaging in intercourse <b>close to the onset of her</b> menstrual <b>cycle, as it is stated: “Behold, I was brought forth in iniquity”</b> (Psalms 51:7). This iniquity is referring to intercourse close to the woman’s menstrual cycle, when intercourse is prohibited. Accordingly, David is saying that his mother presumably conceived him at this time.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> A woman becomes pregnant only by engaging in intercourse <b>near</b> the time of her <b>immersion</b> in a ritual bath, through which she is purified from her status as a menstruating woman, <b>as it is stated</b> in the continuation of the same verse: <b>“And in sin [<i>uvḥet</i>] did my mother conceive me”</b> (Psalms 51:7).
The Gemara explains this derivation: <b>From where may</b> it <b>be inferred that this term “<i>ḥet</i>” is</b> a reference <b>to purity?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>As it is written</b> with regard to leprosy of houses: <b>“<i>Veḥittei</i> the house”</b> (Leviticus 14:52), <b>and we translate</b> the verse into Aramaic as: <b>And he shall purify the house. And if you wish, say</b> that the interpretation is derived <b>from here: “Purge me [<i>teḥatte’eni</i>] with hyssop, and I shall be pure”</b> (Psalms 51:9). Evidently, the root <i>ḥet</i>, <i>tet</i>, <i>alef</i> refers to purification.
§ <b>And Rabbi Yitzḥak says</b> that <b>Rabbi Ami says: When a male comes into the world,</b> i.e., when a male baby is born, <b>peace comes to the world, as it is stated: “Send the lambs [<i>khar</i>] for the ruler of the land”</b> (Isaiah 16:1). This <i>khar</i>, or <i>kar</i>, a gift one sends the ruler, contributes to the stability of the government and peace, and the word <b>male [<i>zakhar</i>]</b> can be interpreted homiletically as an abbreviation of: <b>This is a <i>kar</i> [<i>zeh kar</i>].</b>
<b>And Rabbi Yitzḥak from the school of Rabbi Ami says: When a male comes into the world, his loaf</b> of bread, i.e., his sustenance, <b>comes into his possession.</b> In other words, a male can provide for himself. This is based on the aforementioned interpretation of the word <b>male [<i>zakhar</i>]</b> as an abbreviation of: <b>This is a <i>kar</i> [<i>zeh kar</i>],</b> and the term <i>kar</i> refers to sustenance, <b>as it is written: “And he prepared great provision [<i>kera</i>] for them”</b> (II Kings 6:23).
By contrast, <b>when a female comes into the world, nothing,</b> i.e., no sustenance, comes <b>with her.</b> This is derived from the homiletic interpretation of the word <b>female [<i>nekeva</i>]</b> as an abbreviation of the phrase: <b>She comes clean [<i>nekiya ba’a</i>],</b> i.e., empty. Furthermore, <b>until she says:</b> Give me <b>sustenance,</b> people <b>do not give her, as it is written</b> in Laban’s request of Jacob: <b>“Appoint me [<i>nokva</i>] your wages, and I will give it”</b> (Genesis 30:28). Laban used the word <i>nokva</i>, similar to <i>nekeva</i>, when he said that he would pay Jacob only if he explicitly demanded his wages.
<b>The students of Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai asked him: For what</b> reason <b>does the Torah say</b> that <b>a woman after childbirth brings an offering? He said to them: At the time that</b> a woman <b>crouches to give birth,</b> her pain is so great that <b>she impulsively takes an oath that she will not engage in intercourse with her husband</b> ever again, so that she will never again experience this pain. <b>Therefore, the Torah says</b> that <b>she must bring an offering</b> for violating her oath and continuing to engage in intercourse with her husband.
<b>Rav Yosef objects to this</b> answer: <b>But isn’t</b> the woman <b>an intentional violator</b> of her oath? <b>And</b> if she wishes that her oath be dissolved, so that she may engage in intercourse with her husband, <b>the matter depends on</b> her <b>regret</b> of her oath. One is obligated to bring an offering for violating an oath of an utterance only if his transgression is unwitting. <b>And furthermore,</b> if the purpose of the offering that a woman brings after childbirth is to atone for violating an oath, then <b>she</b> should be <b>required to bring</b> a female lamb or goat as <b>an offering,</b> which is the requirement of one who violated <b>an oath,</b> rather than the bird offering brought by a woman after childbirth.
<b>And</b> the students of Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai further inquired of him: <b>For what</b> reason <b>does the Torah say</b> that a woman who gives birth to <b>a male</b> is ritually impure <b>for seven</b> days, <b>but</b> a woman who gives birth to <b>a female</b> is impure <b>for fourteen</b> days? Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai answered them: When a woman gives birth to <b>a male, over which everyone is happy, she regrets</b> her oath, that she will never again engage in intercourse with her husband, already <b>seven</b> days after giving birth. By contrast, after giving birth to <b>a female, over which everyone is unhappy, she regrets</b> her oath only <b>fourteen</b> days after giving birth.
<b>And</b> the students further asked him: <b>For what</b> reason <b>does the Torah say</b> that <b>circumcision</b> is performed only <b>on the eighth</b> day of the baby’s life, and not beforehand? He answered them: It is <b>so that</b> there <b>will not be</b> a situation where <b>everyone</b> is <b>happy</b> at the circumcision ceremony <b>but the father and mother of</b> the infant <b>are unhappy,</b> as they are still prohibited from engaging in intercourse.
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Meir would say: For what</b> reason <b>does the Torah say</b> that <b>a menstruating woman</b> is prohibited from engaging in intercourse with her husband <b>for seven</b> days? It is <b>because</b> if a woman were permitted to engage in intercourse with her husband all the time, her husband would be too <b>accustomed to her, and</b> would eventually be <b>repulsed by her.</b> Therefore, <b>the Torah says</b> that a menstruating woman <b>shall be ritually impure</b> for <b>seven days,</b> during which she is prohibited from engaging in intercourse with her husband, <b>so that</b> when she becomes pure again <b>she will be dear to her husband as</b> at <b>the time when she entered the wedding canopy</b> with him.
§ <b>The students of Rabbi Dostai, son of Rabbi Yannai, asked him: For what</b> reason is it the norm that <b>a man pursues a woman</b> for marriage, <b>but a woman does not pursue a man?</b> Rabbi Dostai answered them by citing <b>a parable of a person who lost an item. Who searches for what?</b> Certainly <b>the owner of the lost item searches for his item;</b> the item does not search for its owner. Since the first woman was created from the body of the first man, the man seeks that which he has lost.
<b>And</b> the students of Rabbi Dostai further asked him: <b>For what</b> reason does <b>a man</b> engage in intercourse <b>facing down, and a woman</b> engage in intercourse <b>facing up toward the man?</b> Rabbi Dostai answered them: <b>This</b> man faces <b>the place from which he was created,</b> i.e., the earth, <b>and that</b> woman faces <b>the place from which she was created,</b> namely man.
<b>And</b> the students also inquired: <b>For what</b> reason is <b>a man</b> who is angry likely to <b>accept appeasement, but a woman</b> is <b>not</b> as likely to <b>accept appeasement?</b> Rabbi Dostai answered them: It is <b>because this</b> man behaves like <b>the place from which he was created,</b> i.e., the earth, which yields to pressure, <b>and that</b> woman behaves like <b>the place from which she was created,</b> i.e., from bone, which cannot be molded easily.
The students continued to ask Rabbi Dostai: <b>For what</b> reason <b>is a woman’s voice pleasant, but a man’s voice is not pleasant?</b> He answered: <b>This</b> man is similar to <b>the place from which he was created,</b> the earth, which does not issue a sound when it is struck, <b>and that</b> woman is similar to <b>the place from which she was created,</b> a bone, which makes a sound when it is struck. The proof that a woman’s voice is pleasant is <b>that it is stated</b> in Song of Songs that the man says to his beloved: <b>“For sweet is your voice, and your countenance is beautiful”</b> (Song of Songs 2:14).

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> Samaritan <b>girls</b> are considered <b>menstruating women from</b> the time they lie in <b>their cradle. And the Samaritan</b> men <b>impart ritual impurity</b> to the <b>lower bedding like the upper</b> bedding, i.e., all layers of bedding beneath them are impure, and their status is like the bedding above a man who experiences a gonorrhea-like discharge [<i>zav</i>]: The status of both levels of bedding is that of first-degree ritual impurity, which can impart impurity to food and drink. This is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> Samaritan men are considered men who <b>engage in intercourse with menstruating women.</b>
<b>And</b> they are considered men who engage in intercourse with menstruating women because Samaritan women <b>observe</b> the seven-day menstrual period of ritual impurity <b>for each and every</b> emission of <b>blood,</b> even for blood that does not render them impure. Accordingly, if a Samaritan woman has an emission of impure blood during the seven-day period, she will nevertheless continue counting seven days from the first emission. It is therefore possible that the Samaritan men will engage in intercourse with their wives while they are still halakhically considered menstruating women, as the seven-day period of impurity should have been counted from the emission of the impure blood.
<b>But</b> one who enters the Temple while wearing <b>those</b> garments upon which a Samaritan had lain <b>is not liable</b> to bring an offering <b>for entering the Temple</b> in a status of impurity, <b>nor does one burn <i>teruma</i></b> that came into contact with <b>those</b> garments, <b>because their impurity</b> is <b>uncertain.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that Samaritan girls are considered menstruating women from the time they lie in their cradle. The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of this statement? <b>If</b> the mishna is referring to girls <b>who</b> already <b>see</b> menstrual blood, then <b>even our own,</b> i.e., Jewish girls, are <b>also</b> considered menstruating women under such circumstances. <b>And if</b> it is referring to girls <b>who do not</b> yet <b>see</b> menstrual blood, then <b>their</b> girls, i.e., those of the Samaritans, should <b>also not</b> have the status of menstruating women.
<b>Rava, son of Rav Aḥa bar Rav Huna, says</b> that <b>Rav Sheshet says: Here we are dealing with an unspecified</b> case, i.e., it is unknown whether these girls have experienced their first menstrual period. <b>Since there is a minority</b> of girls <b>who see</b> menstrual blood, <b>we are concerned</b> with regard to each Samaritan girl that she might be from this minority. The Gemara asks: <b>And who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> who <b>taught that one must be concerned for the minority?</b>

Daf 32a

The Gemara responds: <b>It is Rabbi Meir, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A minor boy and a minor girl may not perform the ritual through which a <i>yavam</i> frees a <i>yevama</i> of her levirate bonds [<i>ḥalitza</i>], nor may they enter into levirate marriage.</b> In other words, a minor boy whose brother died childless may not perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with his brother’s widow, nor may he enter into levirate marriage with her, even if she is an adult. Likewise, a minor girl whose husband died childless may not perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with her husband’s brother, nor may she enter into levirate marriage with him, even if he is an adult. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
The Rabbis <b>said to Rabbi Meir: You have aptly stated that they may not perform <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> since <b>“man” is written in the passage</b> of the Torah discussing <i>ḥalitza</i> (Deuteronomy 25:7), <b>and we compare a woman to a man,</b> as the aforementioned verse states: “And if the man does not want to take his brother’s wife.” Consequently, neither a minor boy nor a minor girl may perform <i>ḥalitza</i>. <b>But what is the reason</b> that <b>they may not enter into levirate marriage?</b>
Rabbi Meir <b>said to them: A minor boy</b> may not enter into levirate marriage <b>lest,</b> once he is older, <b>he be found</b> to be <b>a sexually underdeveloped man,</b> who is incapable of fathering children. Likewise, <b>a minor girl</b> may not enter into levirate marriage <b>lest,</b> once she is older, <b>she be found</b> to be <b>a sexually underdeveloped woman. And</b> if a sexually underdeveloped boy or girl enters into levirate marriage <b>they will be found</b> to be <b>infringing upon</b> prohibitions against <b>forbidden sexual intercourse where no mitzva applies,</b> as the entire purpose of levirate marriage is to bear children in the name of the deceased.
The Gemara notes: <b>And the Rabbis</b> maintain that one <b>follows the majority of minor boys, and most minor boys are not</b> going to be <b>sexually underdeveloped men;</b> likewise, one <b>follows the majority of</b> minor girls, <b>and most</b> minor girls <b>are not</b> going to be <b>sexually underdeveloped women.</b> In any event, the <i>baraita</i> indicates that Rabbi Meir is concerned for the minority.
The Gemara objects: You can <b>say that you heard that Rabbi Meir</b> is concerned for <b>a common minority,</b> e.g., the minority of sexually underdeveloped men and sexually underdeveloped women. <b>But did you hear him</b> say that one is concerned for <b>an uncommon minority,</b> such as the minority of young girls who menstruate?
The Gemara explains: <b>This</b> minority of young girls who menstruate <b>is also a common minority. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei said:</b> There was <b>an incident in</b> the town of <b>Ein Bul</b> where <b>they immersed</b> a baby girl in a ritual bath <b>before her mother.</b> In other words, the baby girl experienced bleeding so soon after birth that her immersion in a ritual bath occurred before her mother immersed fourteen days after giving birth. <b>And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi likewise <b>said:</b> There was <b>an incident in Beit She’arim</b> where <b>they immersed</b> a baby girl <b>before her mother. And Rav Yosef said:</b> There was <b>an incident in Pumbedita</b> where <b>they immersed</b> a baby girl <b>before her mother.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> the immersions reported <b>by Rabbi Yosei and by Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi are understandable, <b>due to the <i>teruma</i> of Eretz Yisrael,</b> i.e., these incidents occurred in Eretz Yisrael, where the touch of a menstruating girl disqualifies <i>teruma</i>. <b>But</b> in the incident reported <b>by Rav Yosef,</b> which occurred in Babylonia, <b>why do I</b> need to immerse the baby girl? <b>But doesn’t Shmuel say:</b> The <b><i>teruma</i> of outside of Eretz Yisrael is prohibited only to one whose impurity</b> is due to <b>an emission from his body,</b> e.g., a menstruating woman, or one who experiences a gonorrhea-like discharge [<i>zav</i>]. <b>And this statement</b> applies only <b>with regard to eating</b> <i>teruma</i>, <b>but with regard to touching</b> <i>teruma</i>, there is <b>no</b> prohibition. Since the touch of a menstruating woman does not disqualify <i>teruma</i> outside Eretz Yisrael, why was it necessary to immerse the baby girl in the incident reported by Rav Yosef?
<b>Mar Zutra says:</b> That immersion <b>was necessary only for smearing oil of <i>teruma</i></b> of outside of Eretz Yisrael. Since smearing is equivalent to eating, it would have been prohibited to smear such oil on the baby girl, were it not for her immersion in a ritual bath. And from where is it derived that smearing is like eating with regard to <i>teruma</i>? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse discussing the prohibition against consuming <i>teruma</i> in a state of ritual impurity states: <b>“And they shall not desecrate the sacred items of the children of Israel, which they set apart for the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 22:15). The verse serves <b>to include</b> in this prohibition <b>one who smears and one who drinks.</b>
Mar Zutra continues: <b>Why do I</b> need <b>a verse</b> to teach that one who <b>drinks</b> <i>teruma</i> in a state of impurity is liable? Isn’t <b>drinking included</b> in the category of <b>eating? Rather,</b> the <i>baraita</i> means that the verse serves <b>to include one who smears,</b> teaching that he is <b>like one who drinks. And if you wish, say</b> that one may derive that smearing is like drinking <b>from here: “And it came into his innards like water, and like oil into his bones”</b> (Psalms 109:18).
As it stands, the <i>halakha</i> that Samaritan girls are considered menstruating women from the time they lie in their cradle is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir, who is concerned for the minority of young girls who menstruate. The Gemara objects: <b>If so,</b> let us be concerned for the same minority with regard to <b>our</b> girls <b>as well.</b>
The Gemara explains: There is no need to be concerned with regard to <b>our</b> young girls, <b>as we interpret</b> the verse: “And if a woman has an issue” (Leviticus 15:19), and derive from the fact that the verse does not merely state: <b>“A woman,”</b> but: <b>“And</b> if <b>a woman,”</b> that even minor girls are included in the <i>halakhot</i> of a menstruating woman. <b>And</b> consequently, <b>when</b> our girls <b>see</b> menstrual blood, <b>we separate them</b> in the manner of all menstruating women. Therefore, <b>the Sages did not decree with regard to them</b> that all young Jewish girls assume the status of menstruating women. By contrast, with regard to <b>them,</b> Samaritans, <b>who do not interpret</b> the difference between <b>“a woman”</b> and <b>“and</b> if <b>a woman,” when</b> their girls <b>see</b> menstrual blood <b>they do not separate them,</b> and therefore <b>the Sages decreed with regard to them</b> that all Samaritan girls assume the status of menstruating women.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is this interpretation of the difference between <b>“a woman”</b> and <b>“and</b> if <b>a woman”? As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that from <b>“a woman” I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that the <i>halakhot</i> of menstruation apply to an adult <b>woman. From where</b> do I derive <b>that</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a menstruating woman</b> also apply to <b>a one-day-old girl? The verse states: “And</b> if <b>a woman.”</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Apparently, when the verse includes</b> young girls through the word “and” it <b>includes</b> even <b>a one-day-old. But</b> you can <b>raise a contradiction</b> from another <i>baraita</i>, which discusses the verse: “And the woman with whom a man shall lie carnally, they shall both bathe themselves in water, and be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 15:18). From the word <b>“woman” I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that the sexual intercourse of an adult <b>woman</b> is considered intercourse that renders her impure. <b>From where</b> do I derive that the <b>sexual intercourse of a girl aged three years and one day</b> is also classified as intercourse? <b>The verse states: And the woman.</b> Evidently, the word “and” includes only a girl aged three years and one day.
<b>Rava said: These are <i>halakhot</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai, <b>and the Sages</b> merely <b>supported them with verses.</b> There is therefore no contradiction. The Gemara asks: <b>Which</b> <i>halakha</i> is derived from <b>a verse and which</b> is <b>a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai? <b>If we say</b> that the <i>halakha</i> that the status of a menstruating woman may apply to <b>a one-day-old</b> girl is <b>a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai, and the <i>halakha</i> that the intercourse of a girl <b>aged three years and one day</b> is considered intercourse is derived from <b>a verse,</b> then one may object: But <b>the verse is written</b> in <b>an unspecified</b> manner; consequently, a one-day-old girl should be included by the verse in the same manner as a three-year-old girl.
<b>Rather,</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the intercourse of a girl <b>aged three years and one day</b> is <b>a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai, whereas the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the menstruation of <b>a one-day-old</b> girl is derived from <b>a verse.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And now that</b> it has been established that the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the intercourse of a three-year-old girl is <b>a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai, <b>why do I</b> need <b>a verse?</b>

Daf 32b

The Gemara responds: The verse serves <b>to exclude a man from</b> contracting ritual impurity due to <b>red</b> semen.
The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> what about <b>that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to a woman who experiences a discharge of uterine blood after her menstrual period [<i>zava</i>]: The verse states: “And if a woman has an issue of her blood many days” (Leviticus 15:25). From the word <b>“woman” I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that <i>ziva</i> applies to an adult <b>woman. From where</b> do I derive <b>that a ten-day-old</b> girl is included in the <i>halakhot</i> of <b><i>ziva</i>? The verse states: “And</b> if <b>a woman.” Why do I</b> need the verse? <b>Let one derive</b> that a ten-day-old girl is included in the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>ziva</i> <b>from</b> the fact that a one-day-old girl is included in the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a menstruating woman,</b> as a woman may become a <i>zava</i> only after seven days of menstruation and three subsequent days of experiencing uterine discharge.
The Gemara responds: It was <b>necessary</b> for the verse to teach that the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>ziva</i> apply to a ten-day-old girl. <b>As, if the Merciful One had written</b> only that a one-day-old girl is included <b>in</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a menstruating woman, I would say:</b> The <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a menstruating woman</b> apply to a one-day-old girl <b>because</b> of their stringency, <b>as when</b> a woman <b>sees blood</b> on only <b>one day she is required to sit</b> for the <b>seven</b> days of menstruation. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>a <i>zava</i>,</b> since the <i>halakha</i> is <b>that if</b> a woman <b>sees</b> blood on only <b>one day</b> she has the status of a lesser <i>zava</i>, and it is <b>enough for her</b> to <b>observe</b> a clean <b>day for a day</b> she experiences a discharge, one might <b>say</b> that the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>ziva</i> do <b>not</b> apply to a ten-day-old girl. It was therefore <b>necessary</b> for the verse to indicate otherwise.
The Gemara objects: <b>And let the Merciful One write</b> that a ten-day-old girl is included <b>in</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a <i>zava</i>, and</b> it would <b>not</b> be <b>required</b> to write that a one-day-old girl is included <b>in</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of a <b>menstruating woman, and I would know that</b> as a girl <b>cannot</b> become <b>a <i>zava</i> without</b> first assuming the status of <b>a menstruating woman,</b> she must also be included in the <i>halakhot</i> of a menstruating woman. The Gemara responds: <b>Yes, it is indeed so;</b> the fact that a one-day-old girl is included in the <i>halakhot</i> of a menstruating woman can be derived from the fact that a ten-day-old girl is included in the <i>halakhot</i> of a <i>zava</i>. <b>Rather, why do I</b> need the <b>verse:</b> “And if a woman,” that is stated with regard to a menstruating woman? The verse serves <b>to exclude a man from</b> contracting ritual impurity due to <b>red</b> semen.
The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> the Torah already <b>excluded this</b> case on <b>another occasion,</b> as stated earlier. The Gemara explains: <b>One</b> verse serves <b>to exclude</b> a man <b>from</b> contracting ritual impurity due to red <b>semen, and one</b> verse <b>serves to exclude</b> a man <b>from</b> being rendered a <i>zav</i> due to <b>blood</b> that emanates from his penis.
§ The Gemara discusses the <i>halakha</i> of <i>ziva</i> with regard to a male: <b>And so with regard to males,</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of a <i>zav</i> apply even to minor boys. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states concerning a <i>zav</i>: “When <b>any man</b> has an issue out of his flesh, his issue is impure” (Leviticus 15:2). <b>What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states “any man”?</b> The verse serves <b>to include a one-day-old baby,</b> teaching <b>that</b> even <b>he is susceptible to impurity of <i>ziva</i>.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, says:</b> This derivation <b>is not necessary, as</b> the verse <b>states:</b> “And of them that have an issue, <b>whether it be a male or a female”</b> (Leviticus 15:33). <b>“Whether it be a male”</b> includes <b>anyone who is a male, whether he is an adult</b> or <b>whether he is a minor; “or a female”</b> includes <b>anyone who is a female, whether</b> she is <b>an adult</b> or <b>whether</b> she is <b>a minor. If so, what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states “any man”? The Torah spoke in the language of people,</b> and one is not meant to derive anything from this verse.
The Gemara asks: <b>Apparently, when the verse includes</b> a minor boy it <b>includes</b> even <b>a one-day-old. But raise a contradiction</b> from another <i>baraita</i>, which addresses the verse: “And if the flow of seed go out from a man, then he shall bathe all his flesh in water and be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 15:16). From the word <b>“man” I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that <b>a man</b> is rendered ritually impure through a seminal emission. <b>From where</b> do I derive that the seminal emission of a boy <b>aged nine years and one day</b> renders him impure as well? <b>The verse states: “And a man.”</b> Evidently, the verse does not include a one-day-old boy.
<b>Rava said: These are <i>halakhot</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai, <b>and the Sages</b> merely <b>supported them with verses.</b> Therefore, there is no contradiction. The Gemara asks: <b>Which is a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai, <b>and which</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>is</b> derived from <b>a verse? If we say</b> that the <i>halakha</i> that <b>a one-day-old</b> boy is included in the <i>halakhot</i> of a <i>zav</i> is <b>a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai, <b>and</b> the <i>halakha</i> that the seminal emission of a boy <b>aged nine years and one day</b> renders him impure is derived from <b>a verse,</b> then one may object: But <b>the verse is written</b> in <b>an unspecified</b> manner; consequently, even a one-day-old boy should be included in the verse.
<b>Rather,</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the seminal emission of a boy <b>aged nine years and one day</b> is <b>a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai, <b>and</b> the <i>halakha</i> that <b>a one-day-old</b> boy is included in the <i>halakhot</i> of a <i>zav</i> is derived from <b>a verse.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And now that</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the seminal emission of a boy aged nine years and one day renders <b>is a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai, <b>why do I</b> need <b>a verse?</b> The Gemara answers: The verse serves <b>to exclude a woman from</b> contracting the impurity of a <i>zava</i> due to <b>a white</b> discharge.
The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need for the Merciful One <b>to write</b> that a one-day-old is included in the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>ziva</i> <b>with regard to males, and why do I</b> need for the Merciful One <b>to write</b> that a one-day-old is included in the <i>halakhot</i> of a menstruating woman and a ten-day-old is included in the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>ziva</i> <b>with regard to females?</b>
The Gemara answers that both verses <b>are necessary. As, if the Merciful One had written</b> only <b>concerning males,</b> one might say: A one-day-old boy is included in the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>ziva</i> <b>because</b> the <i>halakha</i> is more stringent with regard to males, <b>as they are rendered impure through</b> three <b>sightings</b> of <i>ziva</i> on one day just <b>like through</b> sightings on three consecutive <b>days. But</b> with regard to <b>females, who are not rendered impure through</b> three <b>sightings</b> on one day <b>as</b> they are <b>through</b> sightings on three consecutive <b>days,</b> one might <b>say</b> that the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>ziva</i> do <b>not</b> apply to ten-day-old girls.
<b>And</b> by contrast, <b>if the Merciful One had written</b> only <b>with regard to females,</b> one might say: The <i>halakhot</i> of <i>ziva</i> apply to ten-day-old girls, <b>because</b> of the fact that <b>they are rendered impure</b> even on account of sightings that occur <b>due to circumstances beyond</b> their <b>control. But</b> with regard to <b>males, who are not rendered impure</b> on account of sightings that occur <b>due to circumstances beyond</b> their <b>control,</b> one might <b>say</b> that one-day-old boys are <b>not</b> included in the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>ziva</i>. Therefore, both verses are <b>necessary.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And the Samaritan</b> men <b>impart ritual impurity</b> to the <b>lower bedding like</b> the <b>upper</b> bedding. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the clause: The <b>lower bedding like</b> the <b>upper</b> bedding? <b>If we say</b> it means <b>that if there are ten mattresses</b> stacked one upon the other <b>and</b> a Samaritan man <b>sat upon them,</b> the lowest mattress, like the upper mattresses, is <b>rendered impure,</b> this <i>halakha</i> is <b>obvious, since he presses</b> on all of <b>them</b> when he sits on them. In other words, since Samaritan men impart impurity to the bedding beneath them because they are considered men who engage in intercourse with menstruating women, there is no reason to distinguish between the lowest mattress and the other mattresses above it.
<b>Rather,</b> the mishna means <b>that</b> the status of the lowest mattress <b>beneath</b> a man who <b>engages in intercourse with a menstruating woman is like</b> that of the bedding <b>above a <i>zav</i>,</b> i.e., the bedding beneath a Samaritan man assumes first-degree ritual impurity and does not become a primary source of impurity like the bedding beneath a <i>zav</i>. That is, <b>just as</b> the <b>upper</b> bedding <b>of a <i>zav</i></b> is not a primary source of impurity and <b>imparts impurity only</b> to <b>food and drink</b> but not people or vessels, <b>so too,</b> the bedding <b>beneath</b> a man who <b>engages in intercourse with a menstruating woman imparts ritual impurity only</b> to <b>food and drink.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that the bedding <b>above a <i>zav</i></b> imparts ritual impurity only to food and drink? <b>As it is written</b> with regard to a <i>zav</i>: <b>“And whoever touches any thing that was under him shall be impure”</b> (Leviticus 15:10). <b>What</b> is the meaning of the expression <b>“under him”?</b>

Daf 33a

<b>If we say</b> the verse is teaching that a mattress <b>beneath a <i>zav</i></b> is impure, this is already <b>derived from</b> the verse: <b>“And whoever touches his bed”</b> (Leviticus 15:5). <b>Rather,</b> the verse is referring to that <b>which touches any</b> item <b>under which the <i>zav</i> will be. And what is this</b> item? It is the bedding <b>above a <i>zav</i>.</b> The verse teaches that the bedding above a <i>zav</i> imparts ritual impurity.
The verse further states: “And he who bears [<i>vehanoseh</i>] these things shall wash his clothes and bathe himself in water, and be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 15:10), indicating that <b>he who bears also becomes impure. And what is this?</b> This is an item <b>borne [<i>nisa</i>]</b> by a <i>zav</i>. <b>What is the reason,</b> i.e., how is this indicated by the verse? The term <b><i>vehanisa</i> is written</b> in the verse.
The Gemara continues: <b>The verse removed</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the bedding above a <i>zav</i> <b>from</b> the status of <b>severe impurity and brought it to</b> the status of <b>lesser impurity, to tell you that it imparts impurity only</b> to <b>food and drink,</b> but not to people or garments.
The Gemara objects: <b>Say</b> that <b>the verse removed</b> the bedding above a <i>zav</i> <b>from severe impurity,</b> in the sense <b>that it does not impart impurity</b> to <b>a person to</b> the extent that he may in turn <b>impart impurity</b> to the <b>garments</b> he is wearing. <b>But let</b> the bedding above a <i>zav</i> <b>impart impurity</b> to <b>people or garments.</b> The Gemara explains that <b>the verse states:</b> “And whoever touches anything that was under him <b>shall be impure”</b> (Leviticus 15:10), which <b>indicates lesser impurity.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that Samaritan men are considered men who engage in intercourse with menstruating women, and consequently they impart impurity to the bedding beneath them. The Gemara asks: <b>And from where do we</b> derive that the bedding <b>beneath</b> one who <b>engages in intercourse with a menstruating woman</b> is impure? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to a menstruating woman: “And if any man lie with her, <b>and her impurity be upon him,</b> he shall be impure seven days, and every bed upon which he lies shall be impure” (Leviticus 15:24).
The <i>baraita</i> explains: One <b>might</b> have thought that the phrase: “And her impurity be upon him,” indicates that the man assumes the impure status of the menstruating woman with whom he engaged in intercourse, such that if they were together on the sixth day of her menstruation <b>he may elevate</b> himself <b>at her time,</b> i.e., he may immerse in a ritual bath the next day, just like the menstruating woman. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “He shall be impure seven days.”</b>
<b>But</b> if so, <b>what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “And her impurity be upon him”? As,</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that a man who engages in intercourse with a menstruating woman <b>will not impart impurity</b> to <b>people and earthenware vessels.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And her impurity be upon him,”</b> to teach that he imparts impurity like a menstruating woman. In other words, <b>just as she imparts impurity</b> to <b>people and earthenware vessels, so too, he imparts impurity</b> to <b>people and earthenware vessels.</b>
<b>If</b> so, i.e., that one who engages in intercourse with a menstruating woman is compared to the woman herself, then say: <b>Just as she renders</b> the <b>bedding</b> beneath her <b>and</b> the <b>seat</b> upon which she sits impure <b>to</b> the extent that they <b>impart impurity</b> to <b>a person to</b> in turn <b>impart impurity</b> to <b>the garments</b> he is wearing, <b>so too, he renders</b> the <b>bedding</b> beneath him <b>and</b> the <b>seat</b> upon which he sits impure <b>to</b> the extent that they <b>impart impurity</b> to <b>a person to</b> in turn <b>impart impurity</b> to <b>the garments</b> he is wearing. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And every bed upon which he lies shall be impure”</b> (Leviticus 15:24).
The <i>baraita</i> elaborates: <b>As,</b> there is <b>no</b> need for <b>the verse to state: “And every bed upon which he lies shall be impure,”</b> since it is already written: “And her impurity be upon him,” which indicates that just as a menstruating woman imparts impurity to her bedding, so too does one who has intercourse with her. <b>And</b> if so, <b>what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “And every bed upon</b> which he lies shall be impure”? <b>The verse separated</b> the <i>halakha</i> of one who has intercourse with a menstruating woman <b>from</b> the <b>severe impurity</b> of the menstruating woman herself, <b>and brought him to lesser impurity, to tell you that he imparts impurity only</b> to <b>food and drink,</b> but not to people or garments.
<b>Rav Aḥai refutes</b> this derivation: <b>Say</b> that <b>the verse removed</b> the <i>halakha</i> of one who has intercourse with a menstruating woman <b>from severe impurity and brought it to lesser impurity,</b> in the sense <b>that</b> his bedding <b>does not impart impurity</b> to <b>a person to</b> in turn <b>impart impurity</b> to the <b>garments</b> upon him. <b>But let</b> his bedding <b>impart impurity</b> to <b>people or garments. Rav Asi says:</b> The verse states: “And every bed upon which he lies <b>shall be impure,”</b> which <b>indicates a lesser impurity.</b>
The Gemara objects: But <b>say</b> that the phrase: <b>“And her impurity be upon him,”</b> is <b>a generalization,</b> and the phrase: <b>“And every bed</b> upon which he lies shall be impure,” is <b>a detail.</b> If so, the verse constitutes <b>a generalization and a detail,</b> and it is a hermeneutical principle that in such a case <b>the generalization</b> is referring <b>only</b> to <b>that which</b> is specified <b>in the detail.</b> Accordingly, with regard to the <b>bedding and seat</b> upon which the man rests, <b>yes,</b> they are rendered impure, but <b>other items</b> are <b>not.</b>
<b>Abaye says</b> that when the verse states: <b>“He shall be impure seven days,”</b> between the generalization and the detail, this <b>interrupts the matter.</b> Accordingly, <b>this is</b> a case of <b>a generalization and a detail that are distant from one another, and</b> with regard to <b>any generalization and detail that are distant from one another, one does not derive</b> a <i>halakha</i> from them in accordance with the principle <b>of a generalization and a detail.</b>
<b>Rava says: Actually, one may derive</b> a <i>halakha</i> from a generalization and a detail that are distant from one another. But this verse does not constitute a case of a generalization and a detail, as the verse states: “And every bed upon which he lies.” The term <b>“and every” is an amplification.</b>
<b>Rabbi Ya’akov objects to this: Say</b> that as the verse compares a man who engages in intercourse with a menstruating woman to the woman herself, the man should be <b>like her,</b> i.e., <b>just as</b> with regard to <b>her you did not differentiate between her touch and her bedding in terms of imparting impurity</b> to <b>a person and imparting impurity to garments,</b> as the <i>halakha</i> is <b>stringent</b> concerning both in that her touch and her bedding impart impurity to people to in turn impart impurity to their garments; <b>so too,</b> with regard to <b>him, you shall not differentiate between his touch and his bedding in terms of imparting impurity</b> to <b>a person and imparting impurity to garments,</b> and the <i>halakha</i> should be <b>lenient</b> in both cases: Neither his bedding nor his touch should impart impurity to people to in turn impart impurity to their garments.
<b>Rava says</b> in response that when the verse states: “And her impurity be <b>upon him,”</b> this <b>indicates</b> that the Torah intends for the impurity <b>to weigh upon him,</b> i.e., in a stringent manner.
§ The mishna teaches that the impurity of Samaritan men is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> Samaritan men are considered men who <b>engage in intercourse with menstruating women,</b> and this is because they observe the seven-day menstrual period of impurity for each and every emission of blood. The Gemara asks: <b>Is this to say</b> that <b>all</b> Samaritan men <b>are</b> considered men who <b>engage in intercourse with menstruating women?</b> Aren’t there some unmarried men who do not engage in intercourse with menstruating women? <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak of Migdal says: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> only <b>with regard to</b> men to whom women are <b>married.</b>
The mishna further teaches: <b>And</b> Samaritan men are considered men who engage in intercourse with menstruating women because <b>they observe</b> the seven-day menstrual period of impurity <b>for</b> each and every emission of <b>blood.</b> In this regard <b>it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Meir said: If</b> Samaritan women would begin <b>observing</b> a seven-day period of impurity <b>for each and every</b> emission of <b>blood, it</b> would be <b>a great remedy for them,</b> i.e., this practice would not lead to sin, as they would observe a seven-day period from each emission. But this is not their practice.
<b>Rather,</b> when Samaritan women see green blood, which does not render them impure, they begin counting seven days of impurity from that emission. <b>As,</b> if <b>they see red blood,</b> which is impure, during that period, they do not begin observing another seven days. Instead, they consider it an additional emission of blood <b>and they complete</b> the remaining days from the seven days they began observing <b>for</b> the <b>green blood.</b> Consequently, the women will have immersed in a ritual bath while still impure.
<b>Alternatively,</b> a Samaritan woman is considered ritually impure because she <b>counts</b> the <b>day</b> on <b>which she ceases</b> to experience three consecutive days of emissions of <i>ziva</i> <b>toward</b> the <b>total</b> of <b>seven</b> clean days that a <i>zava</i> must experience before being able to immerse in a ritual bath. Accordingly, she does not wait seven full days, as is required by <i>halakha</i>.
<b>Rami bar Ḥama objects to this: And let her count that</b> day on which she ceases to experience emissions of <i>ziva</i>, <b>and we,</b> i.e., Jewish women, <b>shall also count it, as we maintain</b> that the halakhic status of <b>part of the day is like</b> that <b>of an entire</b> day.
<b>Rava says</b> in response: <b>If so,</b> that even with regard to <i>ziva</i> the halakhic status of part of the day is like that of an entire day, one can object: It is taught in a <i>baraita</i> that if a <i>zav</i> experiences an emission of <b>semen</b> while counting seven clean days toward his purity, the seminal emission <b>negates</b> the day on which he experiences it. <b>How can you find the</b> circumstances of this <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to <i>ziva</i>? Isn’t</b> the halakhic status of <b>part of the day is like</b> that <b>of an entire</b> day? If so, let the remainder of the day on which he experiences the emission count as a day.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: Perhaps even with regard to <i>ziva</i> the halakhic status of part of the day is like that of an entire day, and <b>if</b> the <i>zav</i> <b>sees</b> the seminal emission <b>in the middle of the day,</b> the remainder of the day is <b>indeed</b> counted as a whole day. But <b>here we are dealing with</b> a <i>zav</i> <b>who sees</b> a seminal emission <b>adjacent to sunset,</b> when there is no remaining time in the day that can be counted as an entire day.
The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> the <i>halakha</i> that a seminal emission negates a day from the count of a <i>zav</i> is derived from the verse: “This is the law of the <i>zav</i>, and of him from whom the flow of seed goes out, so that he is impure thereby” (Leviticus 15:32). Is it right that one <b>will stand and say about the verse</b> that <b>when it is written, it is written</b> specifically with regard to a seminal emission that occurs <b>adjacent to sunset?</b> The Gemara explains: <b>Yes, perforce you must leave</b> aside the plain meaning <b>of</b> this <b>verse, as it compels itself to be established</b> as referring to such limited circumstances because it must conform to the principle that the halakhic status of part of the day is like that of an entire day.
§ The Gemara mentioned earlier that if a <i>zav</i> experiences a seminal emission while counting seven clean days toward his purity, the seminal emission negates the day on which he experiences it. On a similar note, <b>Rami bar Ḥama raises a dilemma:</b> In the case of a woman who <b>discharges semen</b> after engaging in intercourse with her husband, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>as to</b> whether <b>she negates</b> her counting <b>with regard to <i>ziva</i>?</b> Rami bar Ḥama elaborates: In general, a woman who discharges semen is impure, but the reason for this <i>halakha</i> is uncertain. Is it because <b>she was</b> considered one who <b>saw</b> semen, i.e., the emission of semen itself renders her impure just like a man who experiences a seminal emission? <b>And</b> if so, this woman <b>negates</b> her count.

Daf 33b

<b>Or perhaps</b> it is because <b>she was touching</b> the semen, <b>and</b> if so <b>she has not</b> thereby <b>negated</b> her count, just as a <i>zav</i> does not negate his count if he touches semen.
<b>Rava says: Commensurate with the sharpness</b> of Rami bar Ḥama is the extent of his <b>error,</b> as this is not a dilemma at all, since <b>even</b> if one could suggest <b>that</b> a <i>zava</i> who discharges semen has <b>indeed negated</b> her count, one must ask: <b>How much should she negate?</b> If one suggests <b>she should negate</b> all <b>seven</b> days of her counting, this is untenable, as <b>it is enough for her</b> that she should negate her count <b>like</b> the man who <b>engages in intercourse with her,</b> i.e., like a <i>zav</i> who discharges semen, who negates only one day.
And if one suggests that <b>she should negate one day</b> alone, this too is untenable, as <b>the Merciful One states:</b> “But if she is purified from her <i>ziva</i> then she shall count to herself seven days, <b>and after that she shall be pure”</b> (Leviticus 15:28). The word <b>“after”</b> indicates that she shall be pure only <b>after all of them,</b> i.e., after seven consecutive clean days, such <b>that there should be no impurity separating between them.</b> If so, there cannot be a situation where a <i>zava</i> negates a single day, and consequently it cannot be that a <i>zava</i> who discharges semen negates any part of her count.
The Gemara rejects Rava’s response: <b>And according to your reasoning, how does a <i>zav</i> himself negate</b> only one day from his count due to a seminal emission? After all, <b>the Merciful One states:</b> “And when the <i>zav</i> is purified of his <i>ziva</i>, then he shall count for himself seven days for his purification, and wash his clothes, and bathe his flesh in running water, and he shall be pure” (Leviticus 15:13). The phrase: “Seven days <b>for his purification,”</b> indicates <b>that there should be no impurity separating between them.</b>
<b>Rather, what have you to say?</b> The verse means only <b>that there should not be an impurity of <i>ziva</i> separating between them. Here too,</b> with regard to a <i>zava</i>, the verse means only <b>that there should not be an impurity of <i>ziva</i> separating between them;</b> a discharge of semen is not included in this restriction. It is therefore possible that a discharge of semen from a <i>zava</i> negates only one day from her count. Accordingly, the dilemma raised by Rami bar Ḥama remains in place.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>But</b> one who enters the Temple while wearing <b>those</b> garments upon which a Samaritan had lain <b>is not liable</b> to bring an offering <b>for entering the Temple,</b> nor does one burn <i>teruma</i> that came into contact with those garments, because their impurity is uncertain. In connection to these <i>halakhot</i>, the Gemara relates that <b>Rav Pappa happened</b> to come <b>to</b> the city of <b>Tavakh. He said: If there is a Torah scholar here I will go and greet him. A certain elderly woman said to him: There is a Torah scholar here and Rav Shmuel is his name, and he teaches <i>mishnayot</i>; may it be</b> God’s <b>will that you should be like him.</b>
Rav Pappa <b>said</b> to himself: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that they bless me through</b> this Rav Shmuel that I should be like him, I may <b>conclude from it</b> that <b>he is a God-fearing</b> individual. Rav Pappa <b>went to</b> visit <b>him,</b> and Rav Shmuel <b>raised a bull for him,</b> i.e., he slaughtered a bull in honor of Rav Pappa, and he also <b>raised</b> a difficulty between two <b><i>mishnayot</i></b> that apparently contradict <b>one another: We learn</b> in the mishna: One who enters the Temple while wearing <b>those</b> garments upon which a Samaritan had lain is <b>not liable</b> to bring an offering <b>for entering the Temple, nor does one burn <i>teruma</i></b> that came into contact with <b>those</b> garments, <b>because their impurity is uncertain. Evidently, we do not burn <i>teruma</i> due to uncertain</b> impurity.
<b>And</b> one can <b>raise a contradiction</b> from another mishna (<i>Teharot</i> 4:5): <b>For six</b> cases of <b>uncertain</b> impurity <b>one burns the <i>teruma</i></b> if it came into contact with them, or if a person came into contact with them and subsequently touched the <i>teruma</i>.
