One of these is <b>for the uncertain</b> case <b>of the garments of one who is unreliable with regard to ritual impurity [<i>am ha’aretz</i>].</b> Such garments impart impurity through contact and through carrying, due to a concern that the wife of the <i>am ha’aretz</i> might have sat on them while she was menstruating. Evidently, one burns <i>teruma</i> due to uncertain impurity.
<b>Rav Pappa</b> began his response with a supplication and <b>said: May it be</b> God’s <b>will that this bull shall be eaten peacefully,</b> i.e., that I will provide a satisfactory resolution of this contradiction. Since the bull was slaughtered in my honor, failing to resolve the contradiction might spoil the meal. Rav Pappa continued: <b>Here we are dealing with a Samaritan</b> who is <b>devoted to the meticulous observance of mitzvot, especially <i>halakhot</i> of ritual purity, <i>teruma</i>, and tithes [<i>ḥaver</i>].</b> There is therefore less concern with regard to his ritual purity than that of an <i>am ha’aretz</i>. Consequently, the mishna here states that <i>teruma</i> is not burned on account of him.
Rav Shmuel rejected this response: Since the mishna is referring to men who engage in intercourse with menstruating women, <b>are you equating a Samaritan <i>ḥaver</i></b> with a man who <b>engages in intercourse with a menstruating woman?</b>
Rav Pappa <b>left</b> Rav Shmuel in embarrassment <b>and came before Rav Shimi bar Ashi,</b> to whom he related this incident. Rav Shimi bar Ashi <b>said to him: What is the reason</b> that <b>you did not respond to him</b> that the ruling of the mishna is stated <b>with regard to a Samaritan who immersed</b> in a ritual bath <b>and arose</b> from his impure status, <b>and</b> subsequently <b>trod on the garments of a <i>ḥaver</i>,</b> which means they are now considered the bedding of the Samaritan, <b>and</b> then those <b>garments of</b> the <b><i>ḥaver</i> went and touched <i>teruma</i>?</b> In such a case one does not burn the <i>teruma</i>.
<b>As, if</b> one would say to burn it <b>due to the impurity of an <i>am ha’aretz</i>, he</b> has <b>immersed</b> in a ritual bath. <b>And if</b> one were to suggest that it should be burned <b>because</b> the Samaritan is one who <b>engages in intercourse with a menstruating woman,</b> this too is an unsatisfactory reason. This is because it is <b>uncertain</b> whether <b>he recently engaged in intercourse</b> with his wife, in which case his immersion does not remove his impurity; and it is <b>uncertain</b> whether <b>he did not recently engage in intercourse</b> with his wife, in which case he is in fact pure.
<b>And</b> even <b>if you say</b> that <b>he recently engaged in intercourse</b> with his wife, another uncertainty remains: It is <b>uncertain</b> whether his wife began counting seven days from an emission of green blood and ignored any subsequent emission of red blood and <b>completed</b> her count for the <b>green</b> blood, which would mean that she was in fact a menstruating woman when she engaged in sexual intercourse with her husband; and it is <b>uncertain</b> whether <b>she did not complete</b> a count of seven days from the emission of the green blood, rather from the emission of red blood, in which case she was not a menstruating woman when her husband engaged in intercourse with her. <b>And</b> therefore <b>this is a compound uncertainty, and</b> there is a principle that <b>one does not burn <i>teruma</i> on</b> account of <b>a compound uncertainty.</b>
Rav Pappa raised an objection to Rav Shimi bar Ashi: <b>And let</b> one <b>derive</b> that the garments of the <i>ḥaver</i> are impure <b>because</b> they came into contact with the <b>garments of an <i>am ha’aretz</i>. As the Master said:</b> The <b>garments of an <i>am ha’aretz</i></b> are considered impure with the ritual impurity imparted by the <b>treading</b> of a <i>zav</i>, which means they impart impurity to people and to garments, <b>for individuals who are scrupulous with regard to impurity [<i>perushin</i>].</b> Rav Shimi bar Ashi <b>said to</b> Rav Pappa: The mishna is referring <b>to a naked Samaritan.</b> Consequently, none of his garments came into contact with the garments of the <i>ḥaver</i>.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>Sadducee girls, when they were accustomed to follow in the ways of their</b> Sadducee <b>ancestors their</b> status <b>is like</b> that of <b>Samaritan women,</b> whose <i>halakha</i> was discussed in the previous mishna. If the Sadducee women <b>abandoned</b> the customs of their ancestors in order <b>to follow in the ways of the Jewish people</b> their status <b>is like</b> that of <b>a Jewish woman. Rabbi Yosei says: Their</b> status <b>is always like</b> that of <b>a Jewish woman, until they will abandon</b> the ways of the Jewish people in order <b>to follow in the ways of their</b> Sadducee <b>ancestors.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> in <b>an unspecified</b> case, i.e., when the custom of a Sadducee woman is unknown? The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> evidence from the mishna: With regard to <b>Sadducee girls, when they are accustomed to follow in the ways of their</b> Sadducee <b>ancestors their</b> status <b>is like</b> that of <b>Samaritan women.</b> It can be inferred from the mishna <b>that</b> in <b>an unspecified</b> case their status <b>is like</b> that of <b>a Jewish woman.</b> The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>Say the latter clause:</b> If the Sadducee women <b>abandoned</b> the customs of their ancestors in order <b>to follow in the ways of the Jewish people their</b> status <b>is like</b> that of <b>a Jewish woman.</b> One may infer from this <b>that</b> in <b>an unspecified</b> case their status <b>is like</b> that of <b>Samaritan women. Rather, no</b> inference is <b>to be learned from this</b> mishna.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> the last clause of the mishna, <b>as we learned</b> in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Yosei says: Their</b> status <b>is always like</b> that of <b>a Jewish woman, until they will abandon</b> the ways of the Jewish people in order <b>to follow in the ways of their</b> Sadducee <b>ancestors. By inference,</b> one may conclude <b>that the first <i>tanna</i> holds</b> that in <b>an unspecified</b> case their status <b>is like</b> that of <b>Samaritan women.</b> The Gemara affirms: <b>Conclude from it</b> that this is the case.
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> There was <b>an incident involving a certain Sadducee who was conversing with the High Priest in the marketplace, and</b> as he was speaking, <b>saliva [<i>tzinora</i>] sprayed from his mouth and fell onto the garments of the High Priest. And the face of the High Priest turned green,</b> as he feared that his garments had been rendered ritually impure. <b>And he rushed to</b> the Sadducee’s <b>wife</b> to inquire whether she properly observed the <i>halakhot</i> of menstruation, in which case his garments were not rendered impure by the saliva of her husband, as he is not considered one who engages in intercourse with a menstruating woman.
<b>She said to him: Even though</b> women such as myself <b>are the wives of Sadducees,</b> who do not follow in the ways of the <i>perushim</i>, <b>they are scared of the <i>perushim</i> and they show</b> their <b>blood to the Sages</b> when an uncertainty arises. The garments of the High Priest are therefore pure, as the Sadducee wives properly observe the <i>halakhot</i> of menstruation.
<b>Rabbi Yosei says: We are familiar with the</b> wives of Sadducees <b>more so than everyone</b> else, as they are our neighbors, <b>and</b> I can testify that <b>they</b> all <b>show</b> their <b>blood to the Sages, except for a certain woman who was</b> living <b>in our neighborhood who did not show</b> her <b>blood to the Sages, and she died,</b> as a punishment for her behavior.
The Gemara objects: <b>And let</b> the High Priest <b>derive</b> that his garments are impure <b>due to the saliva of an <i>am ha’aretz</i>,</b> which imparts impurity. <b>Abaye said:</b> That case involved <b>a Sadducee <i>ḥaver</i>,</b> who was particular with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual purity. <b>Rava said: Are you equating a Sadducee <i>ḥaver</i></b> with a man who <b>engages in intercourse with a menstruating woman?</b> After all, the High Priest was initially concerned that the Sadducee might engage in intercourse with his wife while she is still menstruating. <b>Rather, Rava said:</b>

Daf 34a

This incident occurred during <b>a pilgrimage Festival,</b> either Passover, <i>Sukkot</i>, or <i>Shavuot</i>, <b>and the Sages rendered the ritual impurity of an <i>am ha’aretz</i> during a pilgrimage Festival as purity. As it is written: “And all the men of Israel gathered to the city, like one man, united [<i>ḥaverim</i>]”</b> (Judges 20:11). Whenever all the Jewish people gather in a single place, such as on a pilgrimage Festival, <b>the verse renders all of them <i>ḥaverim</i>,</b> even one who is an <i>am ha’aretz</i>. There was therefore no concern for impurity due to the saliva of an <i>am ha’aretz</i>. Yet, the High Priest was concerned that this Sadducee was one who engages in intercourse with a menstruating woman.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to the <b>blood of</b> a menstruating <b>gentile woman</b> or a gentile <i>zava</i>, <b>and</b> the <b>blood</b> discharged <b>by</b> a female Jewish <b>leper</b> during the days <b>of purity</b> of a woman who gives birth, <b>Beit Shammai deem</b> them <b>ritually pure, and Beit Hillel say:</b> The halakhic status of the blood of the gentile woman is <b>like</b> that of <b>her saliva and her urine,</b> which impart impurity only while moist. Likewise, the blood discharged by a Jewish leper during the days of purity imparts impurity only when moist.
With regard to <b>the blood of a woman who gave birth</b> and reached the conclusion of her days of impurity, i.e., seven days after giving birth to a male or fourteen days after giving birth to a female, but <b>who did not</b> yet <b>immerse</b> in a ritual bath, <b>Beit Shammai say:</b> Although she has yet to immerse in a ritual bath, the blood does not retain the halakhic status of menstrual blood. Rather, the status of the blood is <b>like</b> that of <b>her saliva and her urine,</b> and it imparts impurity only while moist. <b>And Beit Hillel say:</b> Since she did not immerse in a ritual bath, her blood is considered like that of a menstruating woman, and it <b>imparts impurity</b> whether it is <b>moist or dry.</b>
<b>And</b> Beit Shammai <b>concede</b> to Beit Hillel <b>in</b> the case of <b>a woman who gives birth as a <i>zava</i>,</b> where the woman must count seven clean days from the conclusion of her days of impurity, <b>that</b> any blood <b>she</b> sees during those seven days <b>imparts impurity</b> whether it is <b>moist or dry.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that according to Beit Shammai the blood of a gentile woman does not impart impurity. The Gemara objects: <b>And do Beit Shammai not accept</b> that which is taught with regard to the verse: <b>“Speak to the children of Israel and say to them, when any man has an issue [<i>zav</i>]</b> out of his flesh, his issue is impure” (Leviticus 15:2), from which it is inferred: By Torah law, <b>the children of Israel become impure through <i>ziva</i> and gentiles do not become impure through <i>ziva</i>, but</b> the Sages <b>decreed concerning them that they shall be like <i>zavin</i> in all their matters</b> of ritual purity.
The Gemara responds: <b>Beit Shammai</b> could <b>say to you</b> that <b>this was stated</b> only <b>with regard to males,</b> not females. <b>As, if</b> it was stated even <b>with regard to females, how should one act</b> with regard to this impurity? <b>Should</b> their blood <b>impart impurity</b> whether it is <b>moist or dry?</b> If so, <b>you have rendered it like</b> blood that imparts impurity <b>by Torah</b> law, and people will mistakenly come to burn <i>teruma</i> that comes into contact with it. Perhaps one will suggest that it <b>should impart impurity</b> only while it is <b>moist and it should not impart impurity</b> when it is <b>dry.</b> But if so, <b>you</b> will have <b>differentiated</b> between moist and dry blood even <b>with regard to</b> blood <b>that</b> is impure by <b>Torah</b> law, i.e., one might mistakenly conclude that the blood of Jewish women imparts impurity only when it is moist, when in fact it imparts impurity whether it is moist or dry.
The Gemara objects: <b>If so,</b> then with regard to <b>the saliva and urine of</b> a gentile <i>zava</i>, which impart impurity by rabbinic law only when moist, Beit Shammai should <b>also</b> rule that they do not impart impurity at all, in order to distinguish their saliva and urine from that of a Jewish <i>zava</i>, which by Torah law impart impurity only when moist (see 54b). The Gemara responds: <b>Since we implement a conspicuous marker with regard to the blood of</b> a gentile woman, i.e., it is clear that her status is different from that of a Jewish woman in that her blood does not impart impurity whatsoever, everyone <b>will know that</b> the impurity of <b>her saliva and her urine</b> is only <b>by rabbinic</b> law, and there is no concern that people might come to mistakenly burn <i>teruma</i> that comes into contact with the saliva and urine of a gentile <i>zava</i>.
The Gemara persists: <b>And let them implement a conspicuous marker with regard to the saliva and urine of</b> a gentile woman, that they should not impart impurity whatsoever, <b>and let them deem her blood impure</b> even when dry. In this manner, everyone will know that the impurity of a gentile woman applies only by rabbinic law, and they will not come to treat that which is impure by Torah law in the same manner. The Gemara responds: With regard to <b>her saliva and her urine, which are</b> relatively <b>common, the Sages decreed</b> that <b>they</b> are impure, but with regard to <b>her blood, which is not</b> as <b>common, the Sages did not decree</b> that <b>it</b> is impure.
§ With regard to a gentile man, <b>Rava says: The <i>ziva</i> of</b> a gentile man is <b>ritually impure, even according to</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai,</b> who maintain that the <i>ziva</i> of a gentile woman does not impart impurity whatsoever. By contrast, <b>the semen of</b> a gentile is <b>pure, even according to</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Hillel,</b> who hold that the blood of menstruating gentiles and the blood of their <i>ziva</i> imparts impurity when it is moist.
Rava elaborates: <b>The <i>ziva</i> of</b> a gentile man is <b>impure, even according to</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai, as it is</b> possible <b>to implement a conspicuous marker with his semen,</b> i.e., since his semen does not impart impurity whatsoever, everyone will know that the impurity imparted by the <i>ziva</i> of a gentile applies by rabbinic law, and they will not come to burn <i>teruma</i> that comes in contact with the <i>ziva</i> of a gentile.
And <b>the semen of</b> a gentile is <b>ritually pure, even according to</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Hillel.</b> This is because <b>the Sages</b> had to <b>implement a conspicuous marker with regard to it</b> to indicate that the <i>ziva</i> of a gentile imparts impurity only by rabbinic law <b>in order that they will not</b> come <b>to burn <i>teruma</i> and consecrated</b> items <b>that</b> come into contact with their <i>ziva</i>, as must be performed with <i>teruma</i> and consecrated items that contract impurity by Torah law.
The Gemara objects: <b>And let</b> the Sages <b>implement a conspicuous marker with regard to the <i>ziva</i> of</b> a gentile man, that it should not impart impurity whatsoever, <b>and let them deem his semen impure.</b> The Gemara explains: With regard to <b>his <i>ziva</i>, which is not dependent on an action</b> he performs but is emitted on its own, <b>the Sages decreed</b> that <b>it</b> is impure; with regard to <b>his semen, which is dependent on an action</b> he performs, <b>the Sages did not decree</b> that <b>it</b> is impure.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that the following mishna (<i>Mikvaot</i> 8:4) <b>supports</b> Rava’s opinion: In the case of <b>a gentile woman who discharged semen</b> that came <b>from a Jew</b> who engaged in intercourse with her, the semen is <b>impure,</b> as it came from a Jew. <b>And</b> in the case of <b>a Jewish woman who discharged semen</b> that came <b>from a gentile,</b> the semen is <b>pure. What, is it not</b> correct to say that the mishna means the semen of the gentile is <b>entirely pure,</b> in accordance with the opinion of Rava? The Gemara refutes this suggestion: <b>No,</b> perhaps the mishna means that the semen of a gentile is <b>pure by Torah law</b> but <b>impure by rabbinic law,</b> whereas according to Rava, the semen of a gentile is pure even by rabbinic law.
The Gemara cites another source that possibly supports Rava’s opinion: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i>: <b>You are found</b> to <b>say the semen of a Jew is impure wherever</b> it is found,

Daf 34b

<b>even</b> if it is <b>in the womb of a gentile woman.</b> If she discharges this semen, it imparts ritual impurity. <b>And</b> by contrast, the semen <b>of a gentile is ritually pure wherever</b> it is found, <b>even</b> if it is <b>in the womb of a Jewish woman, except for</b> any <b>urine that</b> intermingled <b>with it.</b> In other words, if the semen of a gentile intermingled with his urine, the mixture is impure due to the urine it contains, as the Sages decreed that a gentile is considered like a <i>zav</i> in all matters. Consequently, his urine imparts impurity.
The Gemara continues: <b>And if you would say</b> in rejection of this proof: Here <b>as well,</b> the <i>baraita</i> means that the semen of a gentile is <b>ritually pure by Torah law but impure by rabbinic</b> law, one may respond: Since the <i>baraita</i> states that the urine of a gentile is impure, <b>is that to say</b> that <b>her urine,</b> i.e., the urine of the gentile that intermingled with his semen and is now inside the womb of the Jewish woman, is <b>ritually impure by Torah law?</b> Isn’t it impure only by rabbinic law? <b>Rather, conclude from</b> the <i>baraita</i> that the semen of a gentile is <b>pure even by rabbinic law.</b> The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>conclude from it</b> that this is so.
<b>The Master said</b> above in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The semen of a Jew is impure wherever</b> it is found, <b>even</b> if it is <b>in the womb of a gentile woman.</b> The Gemara suggests: <b>Let one resolve</b> from this <i>baraita</i> a dilemma <b>that Rav Pappa raises. As Rav Pappa raises a dilemma: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the <b>semen of a Jew in the womb of a gentile woman?</b> Let one conclude from the <i>baraita</i> that the semen is impure.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: Rav Pappa <b>does not raise his dilemma</b> with regard to the semen of a Jew that is in the womb of a gentile woman <b>within three</b> days of their intercourse, as such semen is impure. Rather, <b>when</b> Rav Pappa <b>raises his dilemma</b> it is with regard to semen in the womb of the gentile more than <b>three</b> days <b>after</b> their intercourse. <b>What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> in such a case?
The Gemara explains the sides of the dilemma: Do we say that as <b>Jewish</b> women <b>are concerned about</b> the proper fulfillment of <b>mitzvot, their bodies are hot and</b> semen in their wombs <b>becomes foul</b> within three days, whereas <b>gentile</b> women <b>are not concerned about</b> the proper fulfillment of <b>mitzvot</b> and therefore <b>their bodies are not hot and</b> semen in their wombs <b>does not become foul</b> within three days? <b>Or perhaps, since</b> gentiles <b>eat repugnant creatures and creeping animals, their bodies are</b> also <b>hot and</b> semen in their wombs <b>becomes foul</b> within three days? Since no resolution is found, the Gemara concludes: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ The mishna teaches: With regard to <b>blood</b> discharged <b>by</b> a female Jewish <b>leper</b> during the days <b>of purity</b> of a woman who gives birth, <b>Beit Shammai</b> deem it ritually pure and Beit Hillel say it imparts impurity only while moist. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reasoning of Beit Hillel,</b> i.e., from where is their opinion derived? <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak says:</b> The verse states at the conclusion of the passage discussing impure individuals: “Whether it be a male or a female” (Leviticus 15:33). <b>“Whether it be a male”</b> serves <b>to include the sources</b> of bodily emissions <b>of a male leper,</b> teaching that they also impart impurity. Likewise, the phrase <b>“or a female”</b> serves <b>to include the sources</b> of bodily emissions <b>of a female leper,</b> teaching that they too impart impurity.
<b>What</b> is meant by the <b>sources</b> of bodily emissions of a female leper? <b>If we say</b> that this is referring to <b>the rest of her sources,</b> e.g., her saliva and urine, this can be <b>derived from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a male</b> leper. <b>Rather,</b> it is referring <b>to her blood,</b> and the verse serves <b>to render impure</b> the <b>blood</b> of a leper discharged during the days of <b>her purity.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how do <b>Beit Shammai,</b> who maintain the blood is ritually pure, interpret the verse? They contend that the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the emissions of <b>a female</b> leper <b>cannot be derived from</b> that of <b>a male</b> leper, <b>as</b> such a comparison <b>can be refuted</b> as follows: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about a male</b> leper? He is unique <b>in that he is required to let his hair grow and rend his garments, and he is prohibited to</b> engage in <b>sexual intercourse.</b> Can <b>you say,</b> then, that the same <i>halakhot</i> should apply to the emissions <b>of a female</b> leper, <b>to</b> whom all the aforementioned requirements do <b>not</b> apply? Consequently, the verse is necessary to teach that the saliva and urine of a female leper are impure.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how do <b>Beit Hillel</b> respond? They respond as follows: If the verse serves to include only the saliva and urine of a female leper, then <b>let the Merciful One write</b> this <i>halakha</i> only <b>with regard to a female</b> leper. <b>And</b> there will be <b>no need</b> to write it with regard to <b>a male</b> leper, as <b>I will say</b> that the saliva and urine of a male leper are impure by an <i>a fortiori</i> inference: <b>And what,</b> if with regard to <b>a female</b> leper, <b>who is not required to let her hair grow and rend her garments, and</b> it <b>is not prohibited</b> for her <b>to</b> engage in <b>sexual intercourse, the Merciful One</b> nevertheless <b>includes her sources</b> of bodily emissions as impure, then in the case of <b>a male</b> leper, to whom all the aforementioned requirements apply, is it <b>not all the more so</b> that his emissions are impure?
Therefore, <b>if</b> the phrase “whether it be a male” <b>is not</b> needed for the <b>matter of a male</b> leper, as this <i>halakha</i> may be derived by an <i>a fortiori</i> inference, <b>apply it</b> to the <b>matter of a female</b> leper. <b>And if it is not</b> needed for the <b>matter of her</b> other <b>sources</b> of bodily emissions, as they are derived from the phrase “or a female,” <b>apply it</b> to the <b>matter of her blood,</b> i.e., <b>to render impure</b> the <b>blood of her</b> days of <b>purity.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how do <b>Beit Shammai</b> respond? They would answer that the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the emissions of <b>a male</b> leper <b>cannot be derived</b> by an <i>a fortiori</i> inference <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a female</b> leper, <b>as</b> it <b>can be refuted</b> as follows: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about a female?</b> She is unique <b>in that she is rendered impure</b> as a <i>zava</i> even by sightings that occur <b>due to circumstances beyond</b> her <b>control.</b> Can <b>you say</b> that the same <i>halakhot</i> should apply to the emissions <b>of a male,</b> for <b>whom</b> this is <b>not</b> the case?
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how do <b>Beit Hillel</b> respond? They respond as follows: Can it be that we are <b>standing</b> and dealing <b>with</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a leper, and</b> Beit Shammai are attempting to <b>refute</b> the <i>a fortiori</i> inference by citing <b>matters</b> pertaining <b>to a <i>zav</i>?</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>Beit Shammai?</b> According to Beit Shammai, this is a legitimate refutation of the <i>a fortiori</i> inference, as <b>they refute</b> it through the common <b>name of impurity</b> that applies to both a leper and a <i>zav</i>.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> that <b>Beit Shammai</b> could <b>say to you: That</b> phrase <b>“whether it be a male” is necessary to</b> teach another <i>halakha</i>, that the phrase <b>“whether it be a male”</b> serves to include <b>anyone who is a male, whether an adult or a minor,</b> in the <i>halakhot</i> of a <i>zav</i>. <b>And</b> how do <b>Beit Hillel</b> respond? <b>They derive</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the following verse: <b>“This is the law of the <i>zav</i>,</b> and of him from whom the flow of seed goes out, so that he is unclean through it” (Leviticus 15:32). The verse indicates that the <i>halakhot</i> of a <i>zav</i> apply to any male, <b>whether</b> he is <b>an adult or whether</b> he is <b>a minor.</b>
§ The Gemara mentioned earlier that a minor is included in the <i>halakhot</i> of a <i>zav</i>. In this regard <b>Rav Yosef says: When Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish taught</b> the <i>halakhot</i> <b>of a <i>zav</i>, he raised this dilemma:</b> With regard to the <b>first sighting</b> of <i>ziva</i> <b>of a <i>zav</i></b> who is a <b>minor, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>as to</b> whether <b>it imparts impurity through contact?</b> Does one say that as <b>the Merciful One states: “This is the law of the <i>zav</i>, and of him from whom the flow of seed goes out”</b> (Leviticus 15:32), one’s <i>ziva</i> is thereby compared to his semen?
Accordingly, with regard to <b>any</b> male <b>whose semen imparts impurity, his first sighting</b> of <i>ziva</i> <b>imparts impurity. And</b> with regard to <b>this</b> minor, <b>since his semen does not impart impurity, his first sighting does not impart impurity either. Or perhaps, since if</b> this minor <b>sees two</b> emissions of <i>ziva</i> the first sighting <b>combines</b> with the second sighting to render him impure as a <i>zav</i> for seven days, this indicates that the first sighting of a minor is significant, and consequently it should <b>render him impure</b> until the evening, just like an adult male.
<b>Rava says: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>“This is the law of the <i>zav</i>,” whether</b> he is <b>an adult</b> or <b>whether</b> he is <b>a minor.</b> Since the verse equates an adult and a minor, <b>just as</b> with regard to <b>an adult his first sighting imparts impurity, so too,</b> with regard to <b>a minor,</b> his <b>first sighting imparts impurity as well.</b>
The Gemara earlier stated that the phrase “whether it be a male” serves to include the sources of bodily emissions of a male leper, teaching that they impart impurity. In this regard <b>Rav Yosef raises a dilemma:</b> Granted, the first sighting of <i>ziva</i> of an otherwise ritually pure individual imparts impurity only through contact, as stated above, and only the second sighting imparts impurity through carrying. But with regard to the <b>first sighting</b> of <i>ziva</i> <b>of a leper, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>as to</b> whether <b>it imparts impurity</b> even <b>through carrying?</b> Does one say that the <b>place of <i>ziva</i></b> in one’s body <b>is</b> considered <b>a source, and</b> therefore his <i>ziva</i> <b>imparts impurity</b> through carrying, like all the sources of bodily emissions of a leper? <b>Or perhaps</b> the place of <i>ziva</i> <b>is not</b> considered <b>a source,</b> in which case the first sighting of <i>ziva</i> does not impart impurity through carrying.
<b>Rava says: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof from a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “When any man has an issue out of his flesh, <b>his issue [<i>zovo</i>] is unclean”</b> (Leviticus 15:2). The verse <b>teaches with regard to the <i>zov</i> that it is impure,</b> and that it imparts impurity through carrying. <b>To what</b> case is the verse referring? <b>If we say</b> it is referring <b>to</b> one who is <b>just a <i>zav</i></b> and not a leper as well, and the verse is teaching that any drop of <i>ziva</i> emitted by him imparts impurity through carrying,

Daf 35a

there is no need for the verse to teach this. After all, if this drop of <i>ziva</i> <b>causes impurity for others,</b> i.e., if the person emitting the drop imparts impurity through carrying, is it <b>not all the more so</b> that the drop <b>itself</b> imparts impurity through carrying? <b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that the verse is referring <b>to</b> a drop of <i>ziva</i> from <b>a <i>zav</i></b> who is also <b>a leper.</b> And it was necessary for the verse to teach this <i>halakha</i>, as it could not be derived by means of the <i>a fortiori</i> inference. This is because this drop of <i>ziva</i> is not what causes the leper to impart impurity through carrying; rather, it is his leprosy that causes him to impart impurity through carrying.
Rava concludes: <b>And</b> as the verse mentions the word “issue” twice, it is evident that it is referring to a second sighting of <i>ziva</i>. <b>From</b> the fact that <b>a verse was necessary to include a second sighting</b> of <i>ziva</i> of a leper, teaching that his <i>ziva</i> imparts impurity through carrying, <b>conclude from it</b> that the <b>place of <i>ziva</i> is not</b> considered <b>a source.</b> If it were a source, then even the first sighting of <i>ziva</i> would impart impurity through carrying.
<b>Rav Yehuda of Diskarta said to Rava: From where</b> do you know that the verse is referring to a <i>zav</i> who is also a leper? <b>Actually, perhaps I will say to you</b> that the verse is referring <b>to</b> the <i>ziva</i> of one who is <b>just a <i>zav</i>. And</b> as for <b>that</b> <i>a fortiori</i> inference <b>that you said:</b> If this drop of <i>ziva</i> <b>causes impurity for others,</b> is it <b>not all the more so</b> that the drop <b>itself</b> imparts impurity through carrying, one can counter that inference. The case of the <b>scapegoat</b> brought on Yom Kippur <b>will prove</b> that this <i>a fortiori</i> inference is not valid, <b>as it causes impurity to others,</b> since the dispatcher of the scapegoat is rendered ritually impure, <b>and</b> yet the goat <b>itself is pure,</b> as a living animal cannot be rendered impure.
With regard to the dilemma raised by Rav Yosef about the first sighting of <i>ziva</i> of a leper, <b>Abaye said: What</b> is the reason <b>he raises</b> such <b>a dilemma? But it was he who said</b> that when the verse states: <b>“This is the law of the <i>zav</i>”</b> (Leviticus 15:32), it thereby teaches that the <i>halakhot</i> of a <i>zav</i> apply <b>whether</b> he is <b>an adult</b> or <b>whether</b> he is <b>a minor. And since he derives</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from there,</b> the verse: “And of them that have an issue [<i>vehazav</i>] of <i>ziva</i>, whether it be a male or a female” (Leviticus 15:33), <b>remains</b> available <b>for him</b> to derive as follows: <b>“Whether it be a male”</b> serves <b>to include a male leper</b> with regard <b>to his sources</b> of bodily emissions, and “or <b>a female”</b> serves <b>to include a female leper</b> with regard <b>to her sources</b> of bodily emissions.
<b>And</b> as this verse discusses a full-fledged <i>zav</i>, and the word “issue” is mentioned twice, <b>the Merciful One compares a leper to a full-fledged <i>zav</i>: Just as a full-fledged <i>zav</i> imparts impurity through carrying, so too,</b> the <b>first sighting</b> of <i>ziva</i> <b>of a leper imparts impurity through carrying.</b>
§ <b>Rav Huna says:</b> The <b>first sighting</b> of <i>ziva</i> <b>of a <i>zav</i> imparts ritual impurity</b> to one who comes into contact with it, even if the emission occurred <b>due to circumstances beyond</b> his <b>control, as it is stated: “This is the law of the <i>zav</i>, and of him from whom the flow of seed goes out”</b> (Leviticus 15:32). The verse compares the first sighting of <i>ziva</i> to a seminal emission: <b>Just as semen imparts impurity</b> even if it occurs <b>due to circumstances beyond</b> his <b>control, so too,</b> the <b>first sighting of a <i>zav</i> imparts impurity</b> even if it occurs <b>due to circumstances beyond</b> his <b>control.</b>
The Gemara analyzes the statement of Rav Huna: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a mishna (<i>Zavim</i> 2:2): With regard to a man who <b>saw a first sighting</b> of <i>ziva</i>, <b>one examines him</b> to determine whether the discharge was caused by circumstances beyond his control. <b>What, is it not</b> that the purpose of this examination is <b>to</b> clarify that he does not have <b>ritual impurity,</b> i.e., if the discharge was due to circumstances beyond his control he remains pure, which contradicts the statement of Rav Huna? The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> the purpose of this examination is <b>to</b> determine whether he will be obligated to bring <b>an offering</b> if he experiences another two discharges of <i>ziva</i>. If the first sighting was caused by circumstances beyond his control, it is not counted toward the three sightings that render one liable to bring an offering.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> the latter clause of the same mishna: <b>When</b> he experiences <b>the second</b> sighting of <i>ziva</i>, <b>one examines him</b> to determine whether the discharge was caused by circumstances beyond his control. <b>For what</b> purpose does one examine him? <b>If we say</b> that it is <b>to</b> exempt him from bringing <b>an offering</b> in the event that he experiences a third discharge <b>but not to</b> clarify that he does not have <b>ritual impurity,</b> this is untenable, as one may <b>read here</b> the verse: “An issue <b>out of his flesh”</b> (Leviticus 15:2), from which it is derived that one is <b>not</b> rendered a <i>zav</i> if the discharge occurred <b>due to circumstances beyond his control. Rather, is it not</b> that the examination serves <b>to</b> clarify that he does not have <b>ritual impurity? And from</b> the fact <b>that</b> the examination in <b>the latter clause</b> is <b>for</b> purposes of <b>impurity,</b> one may conclude that the examination of <b>the first clause</b> is <b>also for</b> purposes of <b>impurity.</b>
The Gemara rejects this: <b>Are the cases comparable? This</b> case is <b>as it is, and that</b> case is <b>as it is.</b> In other words, it is possible that each examination is intended for a different purpose. In particular, the first examination is meant to exempt him from bringing an offering, and the second examination pertains to both the offering and ritual impurity.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> the same mishna, which states that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: Even</b> after <b>the third</b> discharge <b>one examines him, because of the offering.</b> In other words, if the third discharge occurred due to circumstances beyond his control, he is not liable to bring an offering. From the fact that according to Rabbi Eliezer the examination is due to the offering, one may conclude <b>by inference that the first</b> <i>tanna</i> <b>is saying</b> the examinations are <b>for ritual impurity.</b> If so, then according to the mishna one who has an initial discharge of <i>ziva</i> due to circumstances beyond his control remains pure.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>No,</b> this is not the proper explanation of the mishna. Rather, <b>everyone agrees</b> that the examination serves <b>to</b> exempt him from bringing <b>an offering. And here they disagree with regard to</b> whether one interprets instances of the word <b>“<i>et</i>”</b> in a verse. With regard to a <i>zav</i>, the verse states: “And of them that have an issue of <i>ziva</i> [<i>vehazav et zovo</i>], whether it be a male or a female” (Leviticus 15:33). <b>The Rabbis do not interpret</b> instances of the word <b>“<i>et</i>,” and Rabbi Eliezer interprets</b> instances of the word <b>“<i>et</i>.”</b>
The Gemara elaborates: <b>The Rabbis do not interpret</b> instances of the word <b>“<i>et</i>.”</b> Therefore, they explain the verse as follows: <b>“<i>Hazav</i>”</b> is referring to <b>one</b> sighting; <b>“<i>zovo</i>”</b> makes <b>two</b> sightings, and when the verse states: <b>“Whether it be a male,”</b> this indicates that <b>for the third</b> sighting <b>the Merciful One compares</b> the <i>halakha</i> of a male <b>to</b> that of <b>a female,</b> i.e., just as a woman is rendered impure even through an emission of <i>ziva</i> due to circumstances beyond her control, so too, the third sighting of <i>ziva</i> by a man renders him impure even if it occurs due to circumstances beyond his control. Accordingly, the Rabbis maintain that there is no need for an examination after the third sighting.
<b>And Rabbi Eliezer interprets</b> instances of the word <b>“<i>et</i>.”</b> Therefore, he explains the verse as follows: <b>“<i>Hazav</i>”</b> is referring to <b>one</b> sighting; <b>“<i>et</i>”</b> makes <b>two</b> sightings; <b>“<i>zovo</i>”</b> totals <b>three</b> sightings. Accordingly, even for the third sighting of <i>ziva</i> one must examine whether it was caused due to circumstances beyond his control. If it was, he is not liable to bring an offering. When the verse states: “Whether it be a male,” this indicates that <b>for the fourth</b> sighting <b>the Merciful One compares</b> the <i>halakha</i> of a male <b>to</b> that of <b>a female,</b> in that it is counted as a sighting even if it occurred due to circumstances beyond his control.
The Gemara attempts to refute the statement of Rav Huna: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> that which <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak says: But wasn’t a <i>zav</i> included in</b> the category of <b>one who experienced a seminal emission? Why,</b> then, <b>was he taken out</b> and discussed in a separate passage? In order <b>to be lenient with him and to be stringent with him</b> relative to the <i>halakhot</i> of one who experienced a seminal emission. Rabbi Yitzḥak elaborates: The separate passage serves <b>to be lenient with him, as he is not rendered impure through</b> an emission that occurs <b>due to circumstances beyond</b> his <b>control,</b> unlike one who experienced a seminal emission. <b>And</b> the separate passage serves <b>to be stringent with him,</b>

Daf 35b

<b>as he renders</b> impure the <b>bedding</b> upon which he lies <b>and</b> the <b>seat</b> upon which he sits, like a primary source of ritual impurity, which is not the case for one who experienced a seminal emission.
The Gemara analyzes Rabbi Yitzḥak’s statement: <b>When</b> does this statement apply, i.e., to which sighting of <i>ziva</i> is Rabbi Yitzḥak referring? <b>If we say</b> he is referring <b>to</b> the <b>second sighting</b> this is untenable, for <b>where</b> in the verse <b>was</b> such a person <b>included in</b> the category of <b>one who experienced a seminal emission?</b> After the second sighting one is considered a full-fledged <i>zav</i>. <b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that he is referring <b>to</b> the <b>first sighting. And</b> yet Rabbi Yitzḥak <b>teaches:</b> The separate passage discussing a <i>zav</i> serves <b>to be lenient with him, as</b> a <i>zav</i> <b>is not rendered impure through</b> an emission that occurs <b>due to circumstances beyond</b> his <b>control.</b> This contradicts the statement of Rav Huna.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>And how can you understand</b> that Rabbi Yitzḥak is referring <b>to</b> the first sighting of <i>ziva</i>? But Rabbi Yitzḥak also says: The separate passage serves <b>to be stringent with him, as he renders</b> impure the <b>bedding</b> upon which he lies <b>and</b> the <b>seat</b> upon which he sits. <b>With the first sighting</b> of <i>ziva</i> <b>is</b> one <b>fit</b> to render impure his <b>bedding or</b> his <b>seat?</b>
<b>Rather, this</b> is what <b>he is saying: Rabbi Yitzḥak says: But wasn’t a <i>zav</i> with</b> his <b>first sighting included</b> in the category of <b>one who experienced a seminal emission? Why,</b> then, <b>was he taken out</b> and discussed in a separate passage <b>with regard to</b> his <b>second sighting?</b> In order <b>to be lenient with him and to be stringent with him.</b> In other words, the passage serves <b>to be lenient with him, as he is not rendered impure</b> through an emission that occurs <b>due to circumstances beyond</b> his <b>control. And</b> it serves <b>to be stringent with him, as he renders</b> impure the <b>bedding</b> upon which he lies <b>and</b> the <b>seat</b> upon which he sits.
With regard to <i>ziva</i>, <b>Rav Huna says:</b> The discharge of <b><i>ziva</i> is similar to water of barley dough.</b> Whereas the discharge of <b><i>ziva</i> comes from dead flesh,</b> i.e., when one’s penis is flaccid, <b>semen comes from living flesh,</b> when one’s penis is erect. Moreover, the discharge of <b><i>ziva</i> is runny, and is similar</b> in appearance <b>to the white of a unfertilized egg.</b> By contrast, <b>semen is viscous, and</b> it <b>is similar</b> in appearance <b>to the white of an egg that is not unfertilized,</b> i.e., a fertilized egg.
§ The mishna teaches that Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel disagree with regard to <b>the blood of a woman who gave birth</b> and reached the conclusion of her days of impurity, but <b>did not</b> yet <b>immerse</b> in a ritual bath. Beit Shammai say: The blood does not retain the halakhic status of menstrual blood; rather, it imparts impurity only while moist. And Beit Hillel say: Since she did not immerse in a ritual bath, her blood is considered like that of a menstruating woman, and it imparts impurity whether it is moist or dry.
With regard to this dispute, it <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Beit Hillel said to Beit Shammai: Do you not concede with regard to a menstruating woman who did not immerse</b> after seven days <b>and</b> thereafter <b>saw blood, that she is impure</b> as a menstruating woman in every sense? If so, a woman who failed to immerse after childbirth should likewise be impure as a menstruating woman. <b>Beit Shammai said to them: No,</b> this is not a legitimate comparison. Even <b>if you say</b> this is true <b>with regard to a menstruating woman,</b> there the <i>halakha</i> is <b>that even</b> in a case where <b>she immersed and</b> immediately <b>saw</b> blood thereafter, she is <b>impure. Will you say</b> that this <i>halakha</i> applies <b>with regard to a woman who gave birth,</b> where the <i>halakha</i> is <b>that if she immersed and</b> then <b>saw</b> blood <b>she is pure?</b> Therefore, even if a woman who gave birth neglected to immerse and experienced bleeding, she is not considered a full-fledged menstruating woman, and the blood does not impart impurity whether it is moist or dry.
Beit Hillel <b>said to</b> Beit Shammai: The <i>halakha</i> of <b>a woman who gives birth as a <i>zava</i> will prove</b> this is in fact a legitimate comparison. A woman who gives birth as a <i>zava</i> may immerse only after experiencing seven clean days. The <i>halakha</i> is <b>that if she immersed</b> in her days of purity <b>and</b> then <b>saw</b> blood <b>after</b> the seven <b>days of counting</b> for <i>ziva</i>, she is <b>pure,</b> as she is in her days of purity. But if <b>she did not immerse and she saw</b> blood, she is <b>impure.</b> If so, the same should apply to a woman who gave birth and did not immerse at the conclusion of her days of impurity: She should be considered a full-fledged menstruating woman as long as she has not immersed.
Beit Shammai <b>said to them: The same is true and</b> this <b>is the refutation,</b> i.e., we maintain that even in the case of a woman who gave birth as a <i>zava</i> and failed to immerse after seven clean days, her blood imparts impurity only while moist. Accordingly, one cannot compare this case to that of a typical menstruating woman.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is this to say that</b> Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel <b>disagree</b> with regard to a woman who gave birth as a <i>zava</i> and counted seven clean days but did not immerse? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: <b>And</b> Beit Shammai <b>concede</b> to Beit Hillel <b>in</b> the case of <b>a woman who gives birth as a <i>zava</i>, that</b> any blood <b>she</b> sees <b>imparts impurity</b> whether it is <b>moist or dry?</b>
The Gemara responds: This is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> in the <i>baraita</i>, Beit Hillel and Beit Shammai disagree with regard to a woman <b>who counted</b> seven clean days for her <i>ziva</i>. In such a case Beit Shammai maintain that any blood she sees imparts impurity only when moist. <b>There,</b> in the mishna, they agree with regard to a woman <b>who did not</b> yet <b>count</b> seven clean days for her <i>ziva</i>. In such an instance, even Beit Shammai concede that her blood imparts impurity whether it is moist or dry.
The Gemara notes: <b>And it is taught</b> likewise in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a woman who gives birth as a <i>zava</i>, who counted</b> seven clean days after the conclusion of her days of impurity <b>but did not</b> yet <b>immerse, and</b> she subsequently <b>saw</b> blood, <b>Beit Shammai follow their opinion</b> with regard to any woman who gave birth and concluded her days of impurity but did not yet immerse, <b>and Beit Hillel</b> likewise <b>follow their opinion.</b> In other words, according to Beit Shammai her blood imparts impurity only while moist, whereas according to Beit Hillel it imparts impurity whether moist or dry.
§ With regard to blood emitted by a woman during her days of purity after childbirth, <b>it was stated</b> that there is a dispute between the Sages. <b>Rav says: It is</b> from <b>one source</b> in a woman’s body that pure and impure blood are emitted, but <b>the Torah rendered impure</b> the blood emitted during her days of impurity <b>and the Torah rendered pure</b> the blood emitted during her days of purity.
<b>And Levi says: There are two sources</b> in a woman’s body. Blood emitted during her days of impurity emerges from one source, while blood emitted during her days of purity emerges from the other, and these two sources are not active simultaneously. Rather, when <b>the</b> source of the <b>impure</b> blood <b>is closed,</b> i.e., following her days of impurity, <b>the</b> source of the <b>pure</b> blood <b>opens,</b> and when <b>the</b> source of the <b>pure</b> blood <b>is closed,</b> at the conclusion of her days of purity, either thirty-three days for a male child or sixty-six days for a female child, <b>the</b> source of the <b>impure</b> blood <b>is opened.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the practical difference <b>between</b> the opinions of Rav and Levi? The Gemara responds: <b>There is</b> a practical difference <b>between them</b> with regard to the following cases: A woman who <b>continuously discharges</b> menstrual blood <b>from within seven</b> days of giving birth to a male until sometime <b>after</b> those <b>seven</b> days, during her days of purity; <b>and</b> likewise, a woman who continuously discharges menstrual blood <b>from within fourteen</b> days of giving birth to a female until sometime <b>after</b> those <b>fourteen</b> days, during her days of purity; <b>and</b> a woman who continuously discharges menstrual blood <b>from within forty</b> days of giving birth to a male until sometime <b>after</b> those <b>forty</b> days, i.e., after the conclusion of her days of purity; <b>and</b> a woman who continuously discharges menstrual blood <b>from within eighty</b> days of giving birth to a female until sometime <b>after</b> those <b>eighty</b> days, i.e., after the conclusion of her days of purity.
The Gemara elaborates: <b>According to Rav,</b> who maintains that both pure and impure blood emerge from the same source, in the cases described in <b>the first clause,</b> i.e., if she continuously discharged menstrual blood from within her days of impurity until sometime during her days of purity, one is <b>to</b> be <b>lenient,</b> In other words, any blood emitted during her days of purity is pure, since the Torah rendered it pure. <b>And</b> in the cases described in <b>the latter clause,</b> when the discharge begins during her days of purity and continues until after the conclusion of her days of purity, one is <b>to</b> be <b>stringent,</b> as the Torah deemed impure any blood emitted after her days of purity.
<b>According to Levi,</b> who says that there are two different sources in the body, in the cases described in <b>the first clause</b> one is <b>to</b> be <b>stringent,</b> as the continuous flow of blood indicates this blood is emanating from the source of the impure blood, and the Torah deemed pure only the blood that emerges from the source of the pure blood. <b>And</b> in the cases described in <b>the latter clause</b> one is <b>to</b> be <b>lenient,</b> as the continuous flow of blood indicates this blood is from the source of the pure blood.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from the mishna: With regard to <b>the blood of a woman who gave birth</b> and reached the conclusion of her days of impurity but <b>did not</b> yet <b>immerse, Beit Shammai say:</b> The blood is <b>like her saliva and urine,</b> and it imparts impurity only while moist. <b>And Beit Hillel say:</b> Her blood is considered like that of a menstruating woman, and it <b>imparts impurity</b> whether <b>moist or dry.</b>
It <b>enters your mind</b> to explain <b>that</b> the mishna is referring to a case where a woman’s discharge of menstrual blood <b>ceased</b> during her days of impurity, and she subsequently experienced bleeding after the conclusion of her days of impurity. If so, <b>granted</b> the mishna is clear <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav, who said</b> pure and impure blood emanate from <b>one source,</b> as it is <b>due to that</b> reason that Beit Hillel maintain that the blood <b>imparts impurity</b> whether it is <b>moist or dry,</b> since she did not yet immerse. <b>But according to</b> the opinion of <b>Levi, who said there are two</b> separate <b>sources, why</b> do Beit Hillel maintain that the blood <b>imparts impurity</b> whether it is <b>moist or dry?</b> After all, blood emitted during her days of purity comes from the source of pure blood.
The Gemara explains that <b>Levi</b> could <b>say to you: Here we are dealing with</b> a woman who <b>continuously discharges</b> menstrual blood from within her days of impurity until sometime during her days of purity. Since the continuous flow of blood indicates that this blood emanates from the source of the impure blood, Beit Hillel rule that it imparts impurity whether it is moist or dry. The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> the mishna is dealing <b>with</b> a woman who <b>continuously discharges</b> menstrual blood, <b>what is the reason that Beit Shammai</b> maintain this blood imparts impurity only while moist? Isn’t it evident that it is impure menstrual blood? The Gemara responds: <b>Beit Shammai hold</b> that <b>it is</b> from <b>one source</b> that pure and impure blood emanate, and the Torah deemed pure any blood emitted during her days of purity.
The Gemara questions the opinion of Rav: <b>Granted,</b> the mishna is clear <b>according to Levi,</b> who maintains there are two separate sources, as <b>that is</b> how there is a practical difference <b>between</b> the opinions of <b>Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel.</b> Beit Hillel hold there are two sources, and the continuous flow of blood from her days of impurity into her days of purity indicates that the blood emanates from the source of the impure blood, whereas Beit Shammai contend that pure and impure blood emanate from one source, and the Torah deemed pure the blood of her days of purity. <b>But according to Rav, what is</b> the reason for the difference <b>between them?</b>
The Gemara responds: The difference <b>between them</b> is due to their opinions with regard to the significance of the <b>days and</b> the <b>immersion</b> at the conclusion of her days of impurity. <b>As, Beit Shammai hold</b> that <b>the Merciful One rendered</b> the purity of her blood <b>dependent on days,</b> which means that once she begins her days of purity her blood is pure regardless of whether or not she immersed. <b>And Beit Hillel hold</b> that it is dependent <b>on</b> both <b>days and immersion.</b> Accordingly, if she fails to immerse after her days of impurity, any blood she sees is impure.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof from the continuation of the mishna: <b>And</b> Beit Shammai <b>concede</b> to Beit Hillel <b>in</b> the case of <b>a woman who gives birth as a <i>zava</i>, that</b> any blood <b>she</b> sees <b>imparts impurity</b> whether it is <b>moist or dry.</b> It <b>enters your mind</b> to explain that <b>here too,</b> the mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> a woman’s discharge of menstrual blood <b>ceased</b> during her days of impurity, and she then experienced bleeding during her days of purity. Since she is still a <i>zava</i> at the beginning of her days of purity, the blood imparts impurity whether it is moist or dry.
The Gemara continues: If so, <b>granted,</b> the mishna is clear <b>according to Rav, who said</b> that pure and impure blood emanate from <b>one source,</b> as it is <b>due to that</b> reason that the blood <b>imparts impurity</b> whether it is <b>moist or dry,</b> since she is still a <i>zava</i> and the Torah has not yet deemed her pure. <b>But according to Levi, who said there are two sources, why</b> does the blood <b>impart impurity</b> whether it is <b>moist or dry?</b> Let it be considered like the saliva or urine of a <i>zava</i>, which imparts impurity only when moist.
The Gemara explains that <b>Levi</b> could <b>say to you: Here too,</b> we are dealing <b>with</b> a woman who <b>continuously discharges</b> menstrual blood from within her days of impurity until her days of purity. The continuous flow of blood indicates that the blood emanates from the source of the impure blood. The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> the mishna is dealing <b>with</b> a woman who <b>continuously discharges</b> menstrual blood, <b>for what</b> purpose <b>was</b> it <b>necessary</b> for the mishna to teach this <i>halakha</i>? It is obvious that this blood is impure.
The Gemara answers that it <b>was necessary for</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai.</b> The mishna is teaching that <b>even though Beit Shammai say</b> there <b>is one source, and the Merciful One rendered</b> the purity of her blood <b>dependent on days</b> alone, <b>that statement</b> applies only <b>in</b> the case of <b>a woman who only gave birth, as</b> her <b>days</b> of impurity <b>have been completed</b> at this point. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>a woman who gives birth as a <i>zava</i>, who requires</b> the <b>counting</b> of seven clean days from the end of her days of impurity, that statement does <b>not</b> apply, and blood emitted before she counted seven clean days imparts impurity whether moist or dry, like the blood of a menstruating woman.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i>, which addresses the verse: “If a woman be delivered, and bear a male, then she shall be impure seven days; as in the days of her menstrual sickness she shall be impure” (Leviticus 12:2). The superfluous phrase <b>“her</b> menstrual <b>sickness she shall be impure”</b> serves <b>to include</b> a man <b>who engages in intercourse with her,</b> teaching that he is rendered impure like a menstruating woman and imparts impurity like her.
Furthermore, the phrase <b>“Her</b> menstrual <b>sickness she shall be impure”</b> serves <b>to include the nights;</b> although the verse states: “As in the days,” she is impure during the night as well. Finally, <b>“her</b> menstrual <b>sickness she shall be impure”</b> serves <b>to include a woman who gives birth as a <i>zava</i>,</b> teaching <b>that she must observe seven clean days.</b> The Gemara analyzes this <i>baraita</i>: <b>Granted,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is clear <b>according to Rav, who said</b> there <b>is one source,</b> as it is <b>due to that</b> reason that a woman who gives birth as a <i>zava</i> <b>requires seven clean days.</b>

Daf 36a

<b>But according to Levi, who said there are two sources, why do I</b> need this woman to wait <b>seven</b> clean days? It should be <b>enough</b> for her to wait seven days after experiencing <b>any amount</b> of cleanliness from the conclusion of her days of impurity. After all, according to Levi, once the blood ceases to flow from her days of impurity, any blood emitted thereafter is from the source of pure blood. Consequently, even if she experiences a flow of blood during the seven clean days this should not negate her count.
The Gemara explains that <b>this</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying: She requires that</b> the blood flow <b>should stop</b> for <b>any amount</b> of time after her days of impurity, so <b>that</b> she will have entered her days of purity, and consequently, the next seven days <b>will be considered for her as</b> the <b>seven clean</b> days required by a <i>zava</i>.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i>: There are certain women with regard to whom the <i>halakha</i> is that if they notice an emission of menstrual blood they are deemed impure only from when they saw the blood, and one is not concerned they might have experienced the emission from an earlier time. Two such women are one who is pregnant and one who is nursing. This applies only to a pregnant woman who has been noticeably pregnant for three periods, each thirty days in length, and has not experienced bleeding during the three periods; and to a nursing woman who has been nursing for three periods, each also thirty days in length, and did not experience bleeding during that time. With regard to this the <i>baraita</i> teaches: <b>The days of her pregnancy</b> in which she saw no blood <b>count for her toward the days of her nursing</b> in which she saw no blood, to complete three periods, <b>and</b> likewise, <b>the days of her nursing count for her toward the days of her pregnancy.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> elaborates: <b>How</b> so? If a woman <b>stopped</b> experiencing bleeding for <b>two</b> periods <b>during her days of pregnancy and one</b> period <b>during her days of nursing;</b> or if she did not experience bleeding for <b>two</b> periods <b>during her days of nursing and one</b> period <b>during her days of pregnancy;</b> or if she did not experience bleeding for <b>one and a half</b> periods <b>during her days of pregnancy and one and a half</b> periods <b>during her days of nursing,</b> the days <b>count for her as three periods</b> in which she did not experience bleeding, and if she experiences bleeding she is deemed impure only from the hour that she saw the blood.
The Gemara analyzes this <i>baraita</i>: <b>Granted,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is clear <b>according to Rav, who said there is one source,</b> as it is <b>due to that</b> reason that the woman <b>requires a cessation</b> of menstrual emissions for <b>three periods</b> in order that she may be considered a woman whose menstrual emissions have ceased. <b>But according to Levi, who said there are two sources, why do I</b> need <b>a cessation</b> of menstrual emissions for <b>three periods?</b> Provided the woman’s menstrual emissions cease for <b>any amount</b> of time at the completion of her days of impurity, it should be <b>enough,</b> as any blood she may emit thereafter is pure and should not negate her count of three periods.
The Gemara explains that <b>this</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying: She requires that</b> the blood flow <b>should stop</b> for <b>any amount</b> of time at the conclusion of her days of impurity, <b>in order that</b> her days of purity <b>will be counted for her as</b> part of the <b>three periods,</b> even if she experiences bleeding during her days of purity.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i>: <b>And</b> although Shammai and Hillel disagree with regard to all women who experience bleeding (see 2a), as Shammai maintains they are impure only from when they saw the blood while Hillel holds that they assume ritual impurity status retroactively from the last time they examined themselves and were found to be pure, <b>they agree with regard to</b> a woman who <b>sees</b> blood <b>after</b> seeing <b>blood</b> during her days <b>of purity, that it is sufficient for her</b> to be considered impure from the <b>hour</b> of <b>her</b> seeing the blood.
The Gemara analyzes the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Granted,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is clear <b>according to Levi, who said there are two sources,</b> as it is <b>due to that</b> reason that <b>it is sufficient for her</b> to be considered impure from the <b>hour</b> of <b>her</b> seeing the blood. In other words, although she experienced bleeding during her days of purity, until this emission she was still considered a woman whose menstrual emissions have ceased. <b>But according to Rav, who said there is one source,</b> if this woman experienced bleeding during her days of purity, she cannot be considered a woman whose menstrual emissions have ceased. If so, <b>why is it sufficient for her</b> to be considered impure from the <b>hour</b> of <b>her</b> seeing the blood? <b>She should be</b> considered <b>impure</b> retroactively <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period,</b> like all other women.
The Gemara responds: The <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where there is no time</b> between the conclusion of her days of purity and the subsequent emission of blood. In such a situation, she cannot be considered impure retroactively for a twenty-four-hour period, as the previous twenty-four hours are part of her days of purity.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But</b> still, why is she impure only from when she sees the blood? <b>She should be</b> considered <b>impure from examination to examination,</b> i.e., from the last time she examined herself and found that she was pure. The Gemara responds: <b>Since there is no</b> possibility of her being impure retroactively <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period,</b> with regard to impurity <b>from examination to examination as well, the Sages did not decree</b> impurity <b>with regard to her.</b>
The Gemara further suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a woman who gives birth as a <i>zava</i>, who counted</b> seven clean days after the conclusion of her days of impurity <b>but did not</b> yet <b>immerse, and</b> subsequently <b>saw</b> blood, <b>Beit Shammai follow their opinion</b> with regard to any woman who gave birth and concluded her days of impurity but did not yet immerse, <b>and Beit Hillel</b> likewise <b>follow their opinion.</b> In other words, according to Beit Shammai her blood imparts impurity only while moist, whereas according to Beit Hillel it imparts impurity whether it is moist or dry.
The Gemara analyzes the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Granted,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is clear <b>according to Rav, who said there is one source,</b> as it is <b>due to that</b> reason Beit Hillel maintain that the blood <b>imparts impurity</b> whether it is <b>moist</b> or <b>dry.</b> In other words, as she has not yet immersed, the Torah does not deem pure her menstrual emissions. <b>But according to Levi, who said there are two sources,</b> any blood she may emit after counting seven clean days must have come from the source of pure blood. If so, <b>why does</b> it <b>impart impurity</b> whether it is <b>moist or dry?</b>
The Gemara explains that <b>Levi</b> could <b>say to you: I say</b> my opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the <i>tanna</i></b> of the <i>baraita</i> cited above, <b>that</b> Shammai and Hillel <b>agree</b> that with regard to a woman who experiences bleeding after experiencing bleeding during her days of purity, it is sufficient for her to be considered impure from the hour that she saw the blood. That <i>baraita</i> apparently indicates that there are in fact two sources.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that this <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to</b> a woman who <b>continuously discharges</b> menstrual blood from within her days of impurity into her days of purity. Accordingly, the blood she sees during her days of purity is still from the source of impure blood. The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> that the woman <b>counted</b> seven clean days.
The Gemara explains: <b>Here we are dealing with a woman who gave birth to a female as a <i>zava</i>,</b> and therefore her days of impurity are two weeks in length. And this is a case <b>where</b> in the <b>first week</b> her menstrual emissions <b>ceased,</b> and in the <b>latter week</b> her menstrual emissions <b>did not cease,</b> and they continued until her days of purity. <b>And</b> the <i>tanna</i> of this <i>baraita</i> <b>holds: The days of her birth,</b> i.e., the days of impurity, <b>in which she does not see</b> blood, <b>count for her toward the counting of her <i>ziva</i>.</b> Accordingly, although she is considered to have counted seven clean days, the blood emitted during her days of purity is from the source of impure blood.
§ With regard to the dispute between Rav and Levi, <b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Rav Shemen from Sikhra said to us: Mar Zutra happened to</b> come to <b>our locale, and he taught</b> that <b>the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav as a stringency, and the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Levi as a stringency.</b> In other words, if a woman continuously discharges menstrual blood from within her days of purity until sometime after the conclusion of her days of purity, the blood emitted after her days of purity is impure, in accordance with the opinion of Rav. By contrast, if she continuously discharges menstrual blood from within her days of impurity into her days of purity, the blood emitted during her days of purity is impure, in accordance with the opinion of Levi.
<b>Rav Ashi said: The <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav, whether as a leniency or as a stringency.</b> Likewise, <b>Mareimar taught: The <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav, whether as a leniency or as a stringency.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav, whether as a leniency or as a stringency.</b>

Daf 36b

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to a pregnant woman <b>who experiences</b> labor <b>pains,</b> and they are accompanied by an emission of blood<b>,</b> her status is that of <b>a menstruating woman.</b> If <b>she experienced</b> these <b>pains</b> accompanied by emissions of blood for <b>three</b> consecutive <b>days within the eleven days</b> between periods of menstruation<b>,</b> during which time emissions of blood render a woman a <i>zava</i>, <b>and she rested</b> from labor <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period, i.e.,</b> the pangs subsided<b>, and</b> she then <b>gave birth,</b> it indicates that the emissions were not due to her imminent labor<b>,</b> and <b>this</b> woman <b>is</b> considered <b>one who gives birth as a <i>zava</i>.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> She is considered a <i>zava</i> only if the pangs subsided for a twenty-four-hour period of <b>a night and</b> the following <b>day, like Shabbat evening and its</b> accompanying <b>day.</b> Additionally, she is considered a <i>zava</i> in a case <b>where she rested from the pain</b> of labor <b>but not</b> necessarily <b>from the</b> flow of <b>blood.</b> In other words, the presence of labor pangs determines whether this blood is due to labor or the impure blood of <i>ziva</i>. Accordingly, if the pangs cease for twenty-four hours, she is considered a <i>zava</i> even if blood was discharging continuously from when she experienced her labor pains.
<b>How long</b> before birth <b>is</b> pain attributable to <b>her</b> labor <b>pains,</b> which means that the blood is not considered blood of <i>ziva</i>? <b>Rabbi Meir says: Even forty or fifty days</b> before the birth, any blood she sees during the eleven days of <i>ziva</i> is not considered blood of <i>ziva</i>. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> It is <b>sufficient</b> that this <i>halakha</i> applies only from within one <b>month</b> of <b>her</b> due date. <b>Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon say:</b> Labor <b>pains</b> do <b>not</b> occur <b>more than two weeks</b> before birth. Accordingly, if she experiences bleeding for three consecutive days during eleven days of <i>ziva</i> that occur before this time, she is a <i>zava</i>.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that a pregnant woman who experiences an emission of menstrual blood due to labor pains is considered a menstruating woman. This statement apparently applies to all blood due to labor. The Gemara therefore asks: <b>Is this to say that any</b> woman <b>who experiences</b> an emission due to labor <b>pains is a menstruating woman?</b> But if a woman experiences an emission due to labor pains in the eleven days of <i>ziva</i>, she is not rendered a <i>zava</i>, nor can this render her a menstruating woman.
<b>Rav said:</b> It is correct that a woman who experiences an emission of blood due to labor during the eleven days of <i>ziva</i> is not rendered a <i>zava</i>, or even a lesser <i>zava</i>, who must observe one clean day for the day she experienced an emission. But she is <b>a menstruating woman for</b> one <b>day,</b> i.e., she is prohibited to her husband on the day of the emission, and in the evening she may immerse and become permitted to him. <b>And Shmuel said:</b> It is a rabbinic decree that she must observe a clean day, as <b>we are concerned lest she rest</b> from labor and thereby be rendered a lesser <i>zava</i>, as the cessation of pangs would indicate that her emission was not due to her imminent labor.
<b>And Rabbi Yitzḥak said:</b> A woman <b>who experiences</b> labor <b>pains</b> during the eleven days of <i>ziva</i> <b>is nothing,</b> i.e., she is completely pure and is permitted to her husband. The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in the mishna that a woman <b>who experiences</b> labor <b>pains</b> is <b>a menstruating woman?</b> This apparently includes all women who experience an emission due to labor, even if it occurs during the eleven days of <i>ziva</i>.
<b>Rava said:</b> The mishna means that if she experienced an emission due to labor <b>during the days of menstruation,</b> she is considered <b>a menstruating woman;</b> if she experienced the emission <b>during the days of <i>ziva</i>,</b> she is <b>pure. And it is taught</b> likewise in a <i>baraita</i>: A woman <b>who experiences</b> labor <b>pains during the days of menstruation</b> is a menstruating woman; if she experiences them <b>during the days of <i>ziva</i>,</b> she is <b>pure.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>How</b> so, i.e., when does an emission during the eleven days of <i>ziva</i> render a woman one who gives birth as a <i>zava</i>? If <b>she experienced</b> labor <b>pains</b> for <b>one day and</b> then <b>rested</b> from labor for <b>two</b> days, and she experienced an emission on all three days; <b>or</b> if <b>she experienced</b> labor <b>pains</b> for <b>two</b> days <b>and rested</b> from labor for <b>one day,</b> and she experienced bleeding on all three days; <b>or</b> if <b>she rested</b> from labor for one day <b>and she</b> then <b>experienced</b> labor <b>pains</b> for one day, <b>and again rested</b> from labor for one day, and she experienced bleeding on all three days; in each of these cases <b>this</b> woman <b>is</b> considered <b>one who gives birth as a <i>zava</i>,</b> as the cessation of labor pains indicates that the emission of blood is not due to her imminent labor.
<b>But</b> if she <b>rested</b> from labor for <b>one day and</b> then <b>experienced</b> labor <b>pains</b> for <b>two</b> days; <b>or</b> if <b>she rested</b> from labor for <b>two</b> days <b>and experienced</b> labor <b>pains</b> for <b>one day; or</b> if <b>she experienced</b> labor <b>pains</b> for one day <b>and</b> then <b>rested</b> from labor for one day, <b>and again experienced</b> labor <b>pains</b> for one day; <b>this</b> woman <b>is not</b> considered <b>one who gives birth as a <i>zava</i>,</b> since the labor pains indicate that the blood is due to her imminent labor. This is <b>the principle of the matter:</b> If she experienced labor <b>pains adjacent to</b> giving <b>birth, this</b> woman <b>is not</b> considered <b>one who gives birth as a <i>zava</i>;</b> if she was <b>resting</b> from labor <b>adjacent to</b> giving <b>birth, this</b> woman <b>is</b> considered <b>one who gives birth as a <i>zava</i>.</b>
<b>Ḥananya, son of Rabbi Yehoshua’s brother, says:</b> In <b>any</b> situation <b>where</b> she experiences an emission due to <b>her</b> labor <b>pains</b> that <b>occur on her third day,</b> she is not a <i>zava</i>. <b>Even</b> if she was in a state <b>of resting</b> from labor for <b>the entire</b> third <b>day,</b> with the exception of one hour of labor pains, <b>this</b> woman <b>is not</b> considered <b>one who gives birth as a <i>zava</i>,</b> since a woman is considered to be resting from labor on the third day only if she was resting for the entire day.
The Gemara asks: The statement that this is <b>the principle of the matter</b> serves <b>to add what?</b> The Gemara answers: It serves <b>to add</b> the ruling <b>of Ḥananya,</b> son of Rabbi Yehoshua’s brother, that for a woman to be considered one who gives birth as a <i>zava</i>, she must have rested from labor for the entire third day.
§ The mishna teaches that if a woman experiences bleeding due to labor pains during the eleven days of <i>ziva</i> she is not considered a <i>zava</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>As the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to a <i>zava</i>: “And if a woman has an issue of her blood many days” (Leviticus 15:25). The term <b>“her blood”</b> indicates that only <b>her blood</b> that comes <b>due to herself</b> is impure as blood of <i>ziva</i>, <b>but not</b> blood that comes <b>due to</b> her <b>child.</b>
The Gemara analyzes the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Do you say</b> the verse excludes blood that comes <b>due to</b> her <b>child? Or</b> is it <b>only</b> excluding blood that comes <b>due to circumstances beyond</b> her <b>control? When</b> the verse <b>states: “And if a woman has an issue of her blood,”</b> the inclusion of <i>ziva</i> due to <b>circumstances beyond</b> her <b>control is</b> already <b>stated</b> in the inclusive phrase: Has an issue. If so, <b>how do I realize</b> the meaning of the term <b>“her blood”?</b> The verse is teaching that only <b>her blood</b> that comes <b>due to herself</b> is impure as blood of <i>ziva</i>, <b>but not</b> blood that comes <b>due to</b> her <b>child.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> given that the verse contains both an inclusion and an exclusion, <b>what did you see to deem pure</b> the blood emitted due to <b>the child, and to deem impure</b> the blood she sees <b>due to circumstances beyond</b> her <b>control?</b> Perhaps the opposite is the case, that blood emitted due to circumstances beyond her control is pure, whereas blood caused by labor is impure. The Gemara answers: <b>I deem pure</b> the blood emitted <b>due to the child, as there is</b> a period of <b>purity after it,</b> i.e., her days of purity following her days of impurity; <b>and I deem impure</b> the blood she sees <b>due to circumstances beyond</b> her <b>control, as there is no</b> period of <b>purity after it.</b>
The Gemara objects: <b>On the contrary, I</b> should <b>deem</b> the blood <b>pure in</b> a case where it was emitted due to <b>circumstances beyond</b> her <b>control, as</b> an emission of <i>ziva</i> due <b>to circumstances beyond</b> one’s <b>control</b> in the case <b>of</b> a male <b><i>zav</i> is pure.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>Now, in any event, we are dealing with</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a woman, and in</b> the case of <b>a woman we do not find</b> that an emission caused by <b>circumstances beyond</b> her <b>control</b> is pure. It is therefore preferable to deem impure an emission caused by circumstances beyond her control, and to deem pure an emission due to childbirth.
The Gemara adds: <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>What is your opinion, that</b> one should <b>deem</b> the blood <b>pure in</b> a case where it was emitted due to <b>circumstances beyond</b> her <b>control, and deem</b> the blood <b>impure</b> in a case where it was emitted <b>due to the child?</b> But <b>you have no greater</b> instance of <b>circumstances beyond</b> her <b>control than this,</b> the experience of labor pains.
The Gemara objects: <b>If</b> it is <b>so</b> that the above verse is interpreted in such a manner, then in the case <b>a menstruating woman as well,</b> with regard to whom the verse states: “And a woman, if she has an issue, and her issue in her flesh is blood, she shall be in her menstruation seven days” (Leviticus 15:19), <b>let us say</b> that when the verse states <b>“her issue”</b> this indicates that only <b>her issue</b> that comes <b>due to herself</b> renders her a menstruating woman, <b>but not</b> an issue that comes <b>due to</b> her <b>child.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: <b>Do you say</b> that the verse excludes an issue that comes due to her <b>child? Or</b> is it excluding <b>only</b> an issue that comes due to <b>circumstances beyond</b> her <b>control? When</b> the verse <b>states: “And a woman if she has an issue,”</b> the inclusion of an issue due to <b>circumstances beyond</b> her <b>control is</b> already <b>stated.</b> If so, <b>how do I realize</b> the meaning of the term <b>“her issue”?</b> The verse is teaching that only <b>her issue</b> that comes <b>due to herself</b> renders her a menstruating woman, <b>but not</b> an issue that comes <b>due to</b> her <b>child.</b> If the verse can be interpreted in this manner, why does the <i>baraita</i> teach that a woman who experiences labor pains during the days of menstruation is considered a menstruating woman?
<b>Reish Lakish said:</b> The <b>verse states</b> with regard to the days of purity after childbirth: <b>“She shall observe</b> the blood of purity” (Leviticus 12:5). This indicates that <b>you have another</b> instance of an <b>observance that is like this one,</b> i.e., where the woman is not rendered impure by an emission of blood. <b>And which</b> is <b>this</b> other case? <b>This</b> is the case of blood that is emitted due to labor <b>pains during</b> the eleven <b>days of <i>ziva</i>.</b> An emission during the days of menstruation, by contrast, renders the woman a menstruating woman.
