The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> one can <b>say</b> that <b>this</b> other case is where a woman has an emission of blood due to labor <b>pains during the days of menstruation,</b> not where she experiences an emission during the days of <i>ziva</i>.
<b>Rather, Shmuel’s father said</b> the <b>verse states: “And she shall be impure two weeks, as in her menstruation”</b> (Leviticus 12:5), <b>and not: As in her <i>ziva</i>. By inference,</b> one may conclude <b>that</b> there is an instance in which an emission of blood that occurs during <b>her</b> days of <b><i>ziva</i></b> is <b>pure. And which</b> case is <b>this? This</b> is the case of blood that is emitted due to labor <b>pains during</b> the eleven <b>days of <i>ziva</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And now that it is written: “And she shall be impure two weeks as in her menstruation,” why do I</b> need the term <b>“her blood”</b> (Leviticus 15:25) from which it is likewise derived that blood emitted due to labor pains during the eleven days of <i>ziva</i> is pure? The Gemara answers: <b>If not</b> for the term <b>“her blood,” I would say</b> the verse is teaching that a woman who gives birth is impure <b>as in her menstruation, and not as in her <i>ziva</i>, and</b> therefore, <b>even</b> if she experienced bleeding during her days of <i>ziva</i> <b>in</b> a state of <b>resting</b> from labor pains, she remains pure. Consequently, the term “her blood” <b>teaches us</b> that this <i>halakha</i> applies only if she experiences bleeding due to labor pains.
§ According to Rav, a woman who emits blood during the eleven days of <i>ziva</i> due to labor pains is considered like a menstruating woman for that day, i.e., she is prohibited to her husband until she immerses in the evening. The Gemara relates that <b>Sheila bar Avina ruled</b> in an actual <b>case in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav.</b> The Gemara further relates that <b>when Rav was dying, he said to Rav Asi: Go</b> and <b>hide</b> this <i>halakha</i>, i.e., inform Sheila bar Avina that my ruling is incorrect. <b>And if he does not listen</b> to you, <b>drag him [<i>garyei</i>]</b> to your side with convincing claims. Rav Asi misheard and <b>thought</b> that Rav <b>said to him <i>gadyei</i>,</b> excommunicate him.
<b>After Rav died,</b> Rav Asi went to Sheila bar Avina and <b>said to him: Retract your</b> ruling, <b>as Rav</b> himself <b>retracted his</b> opinion. Sheila bar Avina <b>said to</b> Rav Asi: <b>If it is so, that he retracted his</b> opinion, <b>he would have told me,</b> as I was his student; he would not have sent a messenger to inform me of such a retraction. Consequently, Sheila bar Avina <b>did not listen</b> to Rav Asi. Rav Asi <b>excommunicated him,</b> as he thought that this was Rav’s instruction. Sheila bar Avina <b>said to</b> Rav Asi: <b>But is the Master not afraid of the fire,</b> i.e., of a punishment for offending me?
Rav Asi <b>said to him,</b> linking in a fanciful manner his own name to the various names of an important <i>tanna</i>: <b>I am Isi ben Yehuda, who is Isi ben Gur Arye, who is Isi ben Gamliel, who is Isi ben Mahalalel,</b> and this name alludes to <b>a copper mortar [<i>asita</i>], over which rot has no power,</b> i.e., no harm will befall me. Sheila bar Avina <b>said to</b> Rav Asi: <b>And I am Sheila bar Avina,</b> and my father’s name alludes to <b>an iron pestle [<i>bukhna</i>], which smashes a copper mortar,</b> i.e., harm may befall you through the merit of my ancestors.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Asi fell ill</b> and contracted one sickness after another, so that when <b>he entered the heat</b> of a fever, <b>he exited</b> a sickness where he felt <b>cold,</b> and when <b>he entered into</b> a sickness where he felt <b>cold, he exited the heat</b> of a fever. Eventually, <b>Rav Asi died.</b>

Daf 37a

Immediately upon Rav Asi’s death, <b>Sheila</b> bar Avina <b>went</b> and <b>said to his wife: Prepare for me provisions [<i>zevadata</i>],</b> i.e., shrouds for my burial, as I will soon die. This is in order <b>that</b> Rav Asi <b>will not go and tell Rav matters</b> of criticism <b>about me,</b> that I did not listen to Rav Asi and that I caused his death because I took offense when he excommunicated me. His wife <b>prepared for him</b> the <b>provisions,</b> and <b>Sheila passed away.</b> The biers of Rav Asi and Sheila bar Avina were brought together for burial. Those accompanying the dead <b>saw that</b> the <b>myrtle</b> that was customarily placed on a bier was <b>flying from this bier to that bier. They said: Conclude from it</b> that <b>the Sages,</b> i.e., Rav Asi and Sheila bar Avina, <b>have made peace</b> with one another.
§ The mishna teaches that a woman who experiences an emission of blood due to labor pains is not rendered a <i>zava</i> if she sees the blood in days when she can become a <i>zava</i>, but rather a menstruating woman if she sees the blood on days during which she can be a menstruating woman. In this regard <b>Rava raises a dilemma:</b> In general, if a <i>zava</i> experiences an emission of blood while counting seven clean days, her count is negated and she must begin a new count of seven clean days. But <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a <i>zava</i> who experienced an emission of blood due to labor <b>pains?</b> Does this emission <b>negate</b> her count <b>with regard to <i>ziva</i>?</b>
Rava elaborates: Does every <b>substance that imparts impurity negate</b> the count of seven clean days? If so, as <b>this</b> emission <b>imparts impurity like</b> blood of <b>the days of menstruation,</b> it negates her count as well. <b>Or perhaps</b> only <b>a substance that causes</b> a woman to become a <i>zava</i> <b>negates</b> her count, <b>and</b> as <b>this</b> blood <b>is not</b> a substance that <b>causes</b> her to become a <i>zava</i> it does not negate her count.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rava: The case of an emission <b>of <i>ziva</i></b> due to <b>circumstances beyond</b> one’s <b>control will prove</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to this dilemma, <b>as</b> such an emission <b>does not cause</b> one to be rendered a <i>zav</i>, <b>and</b> yet <b>it negates</b> one’s count of seven clean days.
Rava <b>said to him:</b> This is <b>not so [<i>la’ei</i>],</b> as <b>this</b> emission of <i>ziva</i> due to circumstances beyond one’s control <b>is also</b> a substance that <b>causes</b> one to be rendered a <i>zav</i>, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Zavim</i> 2:2): With regard to a man who <b>saw a first sighting</b> of <i>ziva</i>, <b>one examines him</b> to determine whether the discharge was caused by circumstances beyond his control. After the <b>second</b> sighting of <i>ziva</i> as well, <b>one examines him.</b> But after the <b>third</b> sighting <b>one does not examine him,</b> as even if the third sighting occurred due to circumstances beyond his control he is nevertheless rendered a <i>zav</i> on its account.
Abaye asked Rava: <b>And according to Rabbi Eliezer, who said: Even</b> after <b>the third</b> discharge <b>one examines him,</b> will you <b>indeed</b> say that <b>since</b> an emission of <i>ziva</i> due to circumstances beyond one’s control <b>does not cause</b> one to be rendered a <i>zav</i>, <b>it does not negate</b> his count? Rava <b>said to</b> Abaye: <b>According to Rabbi Eliezer,</b> this is <b>indeed</b> the case.
The Gemara attempts to reject Rava’s explanation of the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: Even</b> after <b>the third</b> discharge <b>one examines him</b> to establish whether he must bring an offering, but after <b>the fourth</b> discharge <b>one does not examine him. What, is it not</b> correct to say that as he was already rendered a <i>zav</i> after three discharges, an examination after the fourth discharge is <b>for</b> the matter of <b>negating</b> any clean days counted thus far? If so, Rabbi Eliezer maintains that an emission of <i>ziva</i> due to circumstances beyond one’s control negates one’s count.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>No,</b> it is possible that the purpose of the examination after the fourth discharge is to determine whether <b>to render impure that drop</b> of <i>ziva</i> such that it imparts impurity <b>through carrying.</b> According to Rabbi Eliezer, the discharge of a <i>zav</i> imparts impurity through carrying, even if the discharge occurred due to circumstances beyond his control.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another <i>baraita</i>: <b>With regard to the third</b> discharge, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says</b> that <b>one examines him,</b> but after <b>the fourth</b> discharge <b>one does not examine him.</b> The reason is as <b>I said,</b> that the purpose of these examinations is <b>to</b> determine liability to bring <b>an offering, and</b> they do <b>not</b> pertain <b>to</b> the matter of <b>negating</b> any clean days counted thus far. Since the fourth sighting does not affect liability to bring an offering there is no need for an examination. Evidently, Rabbi Eliezer maintains that a discharge that occurs due to circumstances beyond one’s control does negate his count.
The Gemara concedes: <b>Rather, according to Rabbi Eliezer,</b> one can <b>resolve</b> the dilemma and conclude <b>that</b> even <b>a substance that does not cause</b> one to be rendered a <i>zav</i> <b>negates</b> one’s count. But <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i> <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis?</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear that</b> which <b>the father of Rabbi Avin teaches</b> with regard to the question of why a discharge of <i>ziva</i> causes a <i>zav</i> to negate his entire count of clean days, whereas a seminal emission negates only the day of the emission itself: <b>What</b> did <b>his <i>ziva</i> cause for him?</b> An impurity of <b>seven</b> days. <b>Therefore,</b> a discharge of <i>ziva</i> causes him to <b>negate</b> his count of <b>seven</b> clean days. By contrast, <b>what</b> did <b>his seminal emission cause for him?</b> An impurity of <b>one day</b> alone. <b>Therefore,</b> a seminal emission causes him to <b>negate</b> only <b>one day</b> of his count.
The Gemara analyzes this statement: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the claim that <i>ziva</i> causes an impurity of <b>seven</b> days? <b>If we say</b> it means merely <b>that</b> <i>ziva</i> <b>renders him impure</b> for <b>seven</b> days, then the father of Rabbi Avin <b>should have</b> stated: <b>Just as his <i>ziva</i></b> causes him to be impure for <b>seven</b> days, so too, it negates his count of seven clean days. <b>Rather, is it not</b> that the mention of causation indicates that this is what he is saying: <b>A substance that causes</b> one to be rendered a <i>zav</i> <b>negates</b> one’s count of seven clean days, whereas <b>a substance that does not cause</b> one to be rendered a <i>zav</i>, e.g., an emission of blood due to labor pains, <b>does not negate</b> one’s count. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>conclude from it</b> that this is the opinion of the Rabbis.
With regard to the <i>halakha</i>, <b>Abaye said: We have a tradition</b> that blood emitted by a woman due to labor <b>pains does not negate</b> the seven clean days <b>of <i>ziva</i>,</b> in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis. <b>And if you a find <i>tanna</i> who said</b> that it does <b>negate</b> them, the statement of <b>that</b> <i>tanna</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer.</b>
§ It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Marinus says:</b> In the case of a <i>zava</i> who gave birth in the middle of counting seven clean days, the <b>birth does not negate</b> her count of seven clean days <b>of <i>ziva</i>.</b> With regard to this statement, <b>a dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> as to whether her days of impurity <b>may be counted</b> toward the seven clean days of <i>ziva</i>? <b>Abaye says:</b> The birth <b>does not negate</b> her count, <b>but it does not count</b> toward the seven clean days. <b>Rava says:</b> The birth <b>does not negate</b> her count <b>and</b> it also <b>counts</b> toward the seven days.
<b>Rava said: From where do I say</b> that the birth is counted toward the seven days? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “But if she is purified from her <i>ziva</i> then she shall count for herself seven days, <b>and after that she shall be pure”</b> (Leviticus 15:28). The word <b>“after”</b> indicates that she shall be pure only <b>after</b> counting <b>all of them,</b> i.e., <b>that there should not be an impurity separating between</b> any of the seven clean days.
Rava explains: <b>Granted, if you say</b> the birth <b>counts</b> toward the seven clean days, <b>this is</b> in accordance with the requirement <b>that there should not be an impurity separating</b> between any of the seven clean days, as they remain consecutive. <b>But if you say</b> the birth <b>does not count</b> toward the seven clean days, then the <b>birth separates between</b> the seven clean days. The Gemara notes: <b>And Abaye</b> could have <b>said to you</b> that the <i>baraita</i> means <b>that there should not be an impurity of <i>ziva</i> separating between them.</b> There is no problem with a separation due to birth.
<b>Rava</b> further <b>said: From where do I say</b> that the birth is counted toward the seven clean days? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “But if she is purified <b>from her <i>ziva</i></b> then she shall count for herself seven days” (Leviticus 15:28). This indicates that she counts seven clean days <b>from her <i>ziva</i> and not from her leprosy,</b> i.e., she begins counting seven days from the cessation of her <i>ziva</i>, even if she is a leper. Likewise, she counts seven clean days <b>from her <i>ziva</i> and not from her</b> giving <b>birth,</b> as she counts seven clean days even if they continue through her days of impurity. The Gemara notes: <b>And Abaye</b> could have <b>said to you:</b> From this verse <b>teach one</b> derivation, i.e., <b>from her <i>ziva</i> and not from her leprosy, but do not teach:</b> From her <i>ziva</i> <b>and not from her</b> giving <b>birth.</b>
<b>And Rava</b> would respond: <b>What is this</b> suggestion? <b>Granted, if you say</b> that the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> taught: <b>From her <i>ziva</i> and not from her</b> giving <b>birth,</b> one can understand why the <i>tanna</i> also teaches: From her <i>ziva</i> and not from her leprosy: <b>Since it was necessary for</b> the <i>tanna</i> to teach this <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>birth,</b> he <b>taught</b> it with regard to <b>her leprosy, due to</b> the fact that he taught it with regard to <b>birth. But if you say</b> that the <i>tanna</i> taught only: <b>From her <i>ziva</i> and not from her leprosy,</b> then the verse is unnecessary, as <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>is</b> already <b>derived from</b> another verse: <b>“And when the <i>zav</i> is purified of his <i>ziva</i>”</b> (Leviticus 15:13), i.e., <b>from his <i>ziva</i> and not from his leprosy.</b>
<b>And Abaye</b> could respond: <b>One</b> verse discusses the case <b>of a <i>zav</i> and</b> the other <b>one</b> discusses the case <b>of a <i>zava</i>, and</b> both verses <b>are necessary. As, if the Merciful One had written</b>

Daf 37b

this <i>halakha</i> only <b>with regard to a <i>zav</i>,</b> one might have thought that the Torah was lenient solely in the case of a <i>zav</i>, <b>because</b> a <i>zav</i> <b>is not rendered impure</b> on account of an emission that occurs <b>due to circumstances beyond</b> his <b>control. But</b> in the case of <b>a <i>zava</i>, who is rendered impure</b> on account of an emission that occurs <b>due to circumstances beyond</b> her <b>control,</b> one might <b>say</b> this <i>halakha</i> does <b>not</b> apply. It was therefore <b>necessary</b> for the verse to teach that a <i>zava</i> may count her seven clean days even if she is a leper.
<b>And if the Merciful One had written</b> this <i>halakha</i> only <b>with regard to a <i>zava</i>,</b> one might have thought that the Torah was lenient with regard to a <i>zava</i>, <b>because she is not rendered impure through</b> three <b>sightings</b> on one day, <b>as</b> she is <b>through</b> sightings on three consecutive <b>days. But</b> with regard to <b>a <i>zav</i>, who is rendered impure through</b> three <b>sightings</b> on one day, <b>as</b> he is <b>through</b> sightings on three consecutive <b>days,</b> one might <b>say</b> that this <i>halakha</i> does <b>not</b> apply. It was therefore <b>necessary</b> for the verse to teach that a <i>zav</i> may count his seven clean days even if he is a leper.
<b>Abaye says: From where do I say</b> that although the birth does not negate the count of a <i>zava</i>, it does not count toward the seven clean days? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> which addresses the verse: “If a woman be delivered, and bear a male, then she shall be impure seven days; as in the days of her menstrual sickness she shall be impure” (Leviticus 12:2). The superfluous phrase: <b>“Her</b> menstrual <b>sickness she shall be impure,”</b> serves <b>to include</b> a man <b>who engages in intercourse with her,</b> teaching that he is rendered impure as a menstruating woman and imparts impurity like her.
Furthermore, the phrase: <b>“Her</b> menstrual <b>sickness she shall be impure,”</b> serves <b>to include the nights,</b> i.e., although the verse states: “As in the days,” she is impure during the night as well. Finally, the phrase: <b>“Her</b> menstrual <b>sickness she shall be impure,”</b> serves <b>to include a woman who gives birth as a <i>zava</i>,</b> teaching <b>that she must observe seven clean days.</b>
Abaye continues: <b>What, is it not</b> correct that the <i>baraita</i> means she must observe seven days that are <b>clean from</b> the impurity of <b>birth?</b> Evidently, her days of impurity do not count toward her count of seven clean days. The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>No,</b> the <i>baraita</i> means that these days must be clean <b>of blood.</b> If she does not experience bleeding during her days of impurity, they may be counted toward her seven clean days.
<b>And Abaye said: From where do I say</b> that the birth does not count toward the seven clean days? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the aforementioned verse: The verse compares the <i>halakha</i> of the impurity of birth to the impurity of menstruation, indicating that <b>the days of her menstruation are like the days of her</b> giving <b>birth: Just as the days of her menstruation are unfit for <i>ziva</i>,</b> as a woman may be rendered a <i>zava</i> only through emissions during the eleven days following the seven days of menstruation, <b>and</b> the <b>counting of seven</b> clean days of <i>ziva</i> <b>is not reckoned from them</b> because as long as she remains a <i>zava</i> she cannot be deemed a menstruating woman; <b>so too,</b> with regard to <b>the days of her</b> giving <b>birth, which are unfit for <i>ziva</i></b> because a woman cannot be rendered a <i>zava</i> on account of blood emitted due to childbirth, the <b>counting of seven</b> clean days of <i>ziva</i> <b>is not reckoned from them.</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>And Rava,</b> who maintains that the days of impurity may be counted toward the seven clean days, could say to you: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, who said</b> that not only is the birth not counted toward the seven clean days, it <b>also negates</b> any days counted thus far.
The Gemara analyzes the aforementioned <i>baraita</i>, which compares the <i>halakha</i> of the impurity of birth to the impurity of menstruation, with regard to <i>ziva</i>: <b>But does one derive</b> the <b>possible from</b> the <b>impossible?</b> In other words, how can the <i>halakha</i> with regard to impurity after giving birth be derived from that of the days of menstruation? While it is possible for a woman to give birth as a <i>zava</i>, it is impossible for a <i>zava</i> to simultaneously attain the status of a menstruating woman.
<b>Rav Aḥadevoi bar Ami says:</b> This <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, who said</b> that <b>one derives</b> the <b>possible from</b> the <b>impossible. And Rav Sheshet says</b> a different explanation: Although generally one does not derive the possible from the impossible, <b>perforce the verse juxtaposed</b> the days of impurity after birth and those of menstruation, and a juxtaposition in the verse is expounded even if one case is possible while the other is not. <b>Some say</b> a different attribution of these answers, that <b>Rav Aḥadevoi bar Ami says</b> that <b>Rav Sheshet says:</b> This <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, who said</b> that <b>one derives</b> the <b>possible from</b> the <b>impossible. And Rav Pappa says: Perforce the verse juxtaposed</b> the days of impurity after birth and those of menstruation.
§ The mishna teaches that if a woman <b>experienced</b> labor <b>pains</b> accompanied by emissions of blood for <b>three</b> consecutive <b>days</b> within the eleven days between periods of menstruation, and the pangs subsided for a twenty-four-hour period, and she then gave birth, this indicates that the emissions were not due to her imminent labor, and this woman is considered one who gives birth as a <i>zava</i>. Additionally, the mishna states that she is considered a <i>zava</i> in a case where she rested from the pain of labor, but not necessarily from the flow of blood. Accordingly, if the pangs cease for twenty-four hours, she is considered a <i>zava</i> even if blood was discharging continuously.
In this regard, <b>a dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If <b>she rested from</b> both <b>this and that,</b> from labor pains and emissions of blood, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Rav Ḥisda says</b> that as she rested from labor pains it is evident that the emissions of blood were not due to her imminent labor, and she is <b>ritually impure. Rabbi Ḥanina says</b> that as the emissions of blood also ceased it is apparent that they were due to her imminent labor, and she is <b>ritually pure.</b>
<b>Rabbi Ḥanina says,</b> in explanation of his opinion: Hear <b>a parable;</b> to what is this case comparable? It is comparable <b>to a king who left</b> his palace, <b>and his soldiers</b> left <b>before him.</b> Although the king travels behind them, <b>it is known that they are the soldiers of the king.</b> Likewise, although both the labor pains and the blood subsided, it is clear that the blood she emitted was due to the approaching birth, and therefore she is not a <i>zava</i>.
<b>And Rav Ḥisda says:</b> By the same parable, i.e., assuming that the soldiers arrive before the king, <b>all the more so that</b> there <b>must</b> be <b>many more soldiers</b> accompanying the king upon his arrival. The lack of soldiers before the arrival of the king indicates that they are not in fact soldiers of the king. Likewise, the cessation of labor pains before the birth indicates that the previous emissions of blood were not due to her imminent labor. She is therefore rendered a <i>zava</i>.
The Gemara raises an objection against the opinion of Rav Ḥisda: <b>We learned</b> in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> She is considered a <i>zava</i> only if the pangs subsided for a twenty-four-hour period of <b>a night and</b> the following <b>day, like Shabbat evening and its</b> accompanying <b>day.</b> Additionally, she is considered a <i>zava</i> in a case <b>where she rested from the pain</b> of labor <b>but not from the</b> flow of <b>blood.</b> The Gemara infers: <b>The reason</b> she is rendered a <i>zava</i> is <b>that</b> she rested <b>from the pain</b> of labor <b>and not from the</b> flow of <b>blood. But</b> if she rested <b>from</b> both <b>this and that,</b> from labor pains and emissions of blood, she is <b>ritually pure.</b> The mishna is apparently <b>a conclusive refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Ḥisda.</b>
The Gemara explains that <b>Rav Ḥisda</b> could <b>say to you: It is not necessary</b> to teach <b>that</b> if she rested <b>from</b> both <b>this and that</b> she is <b>impure, as,</b> in terms of the above parable, the king’s <b>soldiers have ceased entirely,</b> i.e., both the labor pains and the blood have completely subsided. <b>But</b> with regard to a case where she rested <b>from the pain but not from the blood,</b> one might <b>say</b> that <b>just as she did not cease</b> emitting <b>blood, so too, she did not cease</b> experiencing labor <b>pains, and</b> the fact <b>that</b> she does not sense any pain <b>is</b> because <b>she was seized by a general disorientation,</b> i.e., she was so weakened by the labor that she was unable to discern pain. Consequently, she should remain pure. Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that if she does not feel labor pains, this is indicative that the previous emissions of blood were not due to her imminent labor, and she is a <i>zava</i>.
The Gemara poses a difficulty with regard to the opinion of Rabbi Ḥanina: <b>We learned</b> in the mishna: If a woman <b>experienced</b> labor <b>pains</b> for <b>three</b> consecutive <b>days within the eleven days</b> between periods of menstruation, <b>and she rested</b> from labor <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period, and</b> she then <b>gave birth, this</b> woman <b>is</b> considered <b>one who gives birth as a <i>zava</i>.</b>
The Gemara analyzes the mishna: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of the scenario described in the mishna? <b>If we say that</b> it is <b>as is taught,</b> i.e., she rested from labor pains but continued to emit blood, then <b>why do I</b> need for her to experience <b>three</b> days of labor pains accompanied by emissions of blood in order for her to be rendered a <i>zava</i>? If she experienced bleeding <b>during two</b> days <b>of</b> labor <b>pains</b> and <b>one</b> day <b>of resting,</b> it would be <b>sufficient</b> to render her a <i>zava</i>, as she experienced bleeding even on the day she rested from labor pains.
<b>Rather, is it not</b> correct that <b>this</b> is what the mishna <b>is saying:</b> If <b>she experienced</b> labor <b>pains</b> accompanied by emissions of blood for <b>three days and she</b> then <b>rested from</b> both <b>this and that, or if</b> she experienced labor <b>pains</b> for <b>two</b> days <b>and she</b> then <b>rested</b> from labor pains <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period, this</b> woman <b>is</b> considered <b>one who gives birth as a <i>zava</i>? And</b> if so, the mishna is <b>a conclusive refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥanina.</b>
The Gemara explains that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina</b> could <b>say to you: No, actually</b> the mishna is to be understood <b>as</b> it <b>is taught,</b> that she experienced labors pains for three days and then rested from the pain but continued to emit blood. <b>And this</b> is what the mishna <b>is teaching us: That even though</b> she <b>began</b> experiencing labor <b>pains</b> at beginning <b>of the third</b> day, <b>and she</b> then <b>rested</b> from labor pains <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period</b> during which she continued to emit blood, <b>she is impure.</b> And this serves <b>to exclude</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Ḥanina,</b> i.e., Ḥananya, son of Rabbi Yehoshua’s brother, who maintains that if a woman experiences labor pains during even part of her third day of experiencing emissions of blood she is not a <i>zava</i>, even if the pain then subsided for a twenty-four-hour period (see 36b).
The mishna teaches: <b>How long</b> before birth <b>is</b> pain attributable to <b>her</b> labor <b>pains,</b> such that the blood is not considered blood of <i>ziva</i>? <b>Rabbi Meir says:</b> Even forty or fifty days before the birth. The Gemara asks: <b>Now</b> that you have said that even <b>fifty</b> days before the due date a woman can experience labor <b>pains, is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to teach that she can experience them <b>forty</b> days before? <b>Rav Ḥisda says:</b> This is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> where the mishna states that she can experience labor pains fifty days before birth, it is referring <b>to a sick woman; there,</b> where the mishna states that she can experience labor pains forty days before birth, it is referring <b>to a healthy woman.</b>
§ With regard to the <i>halakha</i> that a woman who experiences labor pains does not contract the impurity of <i>ziva</i>, <b>Rabbi Levi says: The</b> birth of <b>a child renders</b> the mother <b>ritually pure</b> from <i>ziva</i> <b>only</b> if she experienced bleeding during the eleven <b>days that are fit</b> for her <b>to become a <i>zava</i>.</b> But if she experienced bleeding due to labor pains during the days of menstruation that precede or follow those eleven days, she is a menstruating woman. <b>And Rav says: Even</b> if she continued to experience bleeding <b>during</b> the <b>days that are fit for the counting of a <i>zava</i>,</b> i.e., in the seven days following the eleven days of <i>ziva</i>, which are also part of her days of menstruation, she remains pure. <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava says: And according to the reasoning of Rav,</b>

Daf 38a

<b>even</b> if she continues to experience bleeding <b>during</b> the <b>days that are fit for the</b> new <b>counting</b> following <b>the negation</b> of the days counted by <b>a <i>zava</i>,</b> she remains pure. If a woman experiences bleeding during her seven clean days, she negates any days counted thus far, and must begin a new count of seven clean days. Accordingly, all the days that follow her days of <i>ziva</i> are effectively considered days that are fit for the counting of a <i>zava</i>. Therefore, blood emitted due to labor pains during these days is also ritually pure. Consequently, the blood that accompanies labor pains is ritually impure only if she begins to emit it during her days of menstruation.
The Gemara poses a difficulty with regard to the opinion of Levi: <b>We learned</b> in the mishna: <b>How long</b> before birth <b>is</b> pain attributable to <b>her</b> labor <b>pains? Rabbi Meir says:</b> Even <b>forty or fifty days</b> before the birth. Rabbi Meir apparently maintains that a woman who experiences continuous labor pains accompanied by emissions of blood for forty or fifty days remains pure.
The Gemara explains the difficulty: <b>Granted,</b> the mishna is clear <b>according to Rav,</b> as <b>you find</b> that it is possible that she will remain pure for such a long period, i.e., <b>in accordance with</b> the explanation of <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava</b> that Rav deems the blood pure even during the days that are fit for the new counting following the negation of the days counted by a <i>zava</i>. Accordingly, as long as the woman begins to experience labor pains during her days of <i>ziva</i>, she remains pure until birth, provided the labor pains continue without a twenty-four-hour period of resting. <b>But according to Levi,</b> who maintains that blood accompanying labor pains is pure only during the days of <i>ziva</i>, the mishna is <b>difficult,</b> as it is impossible for her blood to remain pure due to labor pains for fifty days.
The Gemara explains that <b>Levi</b> could <b>say to you: Does</b> the mishna <b>teach</b> that she is <b>pure during all</b> these days, i.e., that she remains pure throughout the days of menstruation and <i>ziva</i>? Not so. Rather, if she emitted blood due to labor pains <b>during the days of menstruation</b> she has the status of <b>a menstruating woman,</b> whereas if she emitted the blood <b>during the days of <i>ziva</i></b> she is <b>pure.</b> The mishna is teaching only that she will not be deemed a <i>zava</i> on account of this blood.
Some Sages <b>state another version</b> of the above disagreement: <b>Rabbi Levi says: The</b> birth of <b>a child renders</b> the mother <b>ritually pure only</b> if she experienced bleeding during the eleven <b>days that are fit</b> for her <b>to become a greater <i>zava</i>,</b> i.e., if she experienced bleeding on three consecutive days during that time. But if she experienced bleeding on only one or two days she is rendered a lesser <i>zava</i>, and she must observe a clean day for each day she experiences a discharge. <b>What is the reason?</b> It <b>is written:</b> “And if a woman has an issue of <b>her blood many days</b>…all the days of the issue of her impurity she shall be as in the days of her menstruation: She is impure” (Leviticus 15:25). The verse is referring specifically to a greater <i>zava</i>, indicating that the <i>halakha</i> that a woman is not rendered a <i>zava</i> on account of an emission of blood caused by labor pains applies only to a greater <i>zava</i>.
<b>Abba Shaul says in the name of Rav:</b> The birth of a child renders the mother ritually pure <b>even</b> if she experienced bleeding on the <b>days that are fit</b> for her <b>to become a lesser <i>zava</i>. What is the reason? “Days” and “many days” are written there,</b> from which the impurity of a lesser <i>zava</i> is derived. Accordingly, the verse includes a lesser <i>zava</i> in this <i>halakha</i> as well.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>We learned</b> in the mishna: <b>How long</b> before birth <b>is</b> pain attributable to <b>her</b> labor <b>pains? Rabbi Meir says: Even forty or fifty days</b> before the birth. Rabbi Meir apparently maintains that a woman who experiences continuous labor pains accompanied by emissions of blood for forty or fifty days remains pure. If so, the mishna is <b>difficult according to both</b> opinions, as all agree that only emissions of blood due to labor pains that occur during her days of <i>ziva</i> are pure. The Gemara responds: <b>Does</b> the mishna <b>teach</b> that <b>she is pure during all</b> fifty days? Not so. Rather, if <b>she experienced</b> labor <b>pains</b> accompanied by emissions of blood <b>during the days of menstruation</b> she has the status of <b>a menstruating woman,</b> whereas if she experienced them <b>during the days of <i>ziva</i> she is pure.</b>
With regard to the above statement of Rabbi Meir, it <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Meir would say: There is</b> a scenario in which a woman <b>experiences</b> labor <b>pains</b> accompanied by emissions of blood for <b>one hundred and fifty days, and</b> the impurity of <b><i>ziva</i> is not included in those</b> days, i.e., she will not be rendered a greater <i>zava</i>. <b>How</b> so? First, a woman emits blood for <b>two</b> days <b>not at the time</b> of her menstruation, e.g., she experiences bleeding on the tenth and eleventh days of <i>ziva</i>. She is not rendered a menstruating woman by these emissions, as they occurred during the days of <i>ziva</i>, nor does she become a greater <i>zava</i>, since she experienced bleeding on only two days.
Rabbi Meir continues: <b>And</b> then she continues to experience bleeding throughout the <b>seven</b> days of <b>menstruation.</b> She is not considered to have experienced bleeding of <i>ziva</i> for three consecutive days, as the third emission occurred during her days of menstruation. <b>And</b> she then experiences bleeding for the first <b>two</b> days <b>after the</b> days of <b>menstruation,</b> i.e., on the first and second days of the eleven days of <i>ziva</i>. <b>And</b> on the third day of <i>ziva</i> she begins the period of <b>fifty</b> days before giving birth, during <b>which the child renders</b> her <b>pure.</b> This constitutes a period of sixty-one days during which she is not rendered a greater <i>zava</i>.
Rabbi Meir continues: <b>And</b> this period is followed by <b>eighty</b> days <b>of</b> purity from <i>ziva</i> after giving birth to <b>a female,</b> for a total of 141 days during which she does not become a greater <i>zava</i> on account of blood emitted. <b>And</b> there are then <b>seven</b> days of <b>menstruation</b> following her days of purity, <b>and</b> another <b>two</b> days <b>after the</b> days of <b>menstruation,</b> i.e., the first and second days of <i>ziva</i>, during which she experiences bleeding, for a total of 150 days during which she does not become a greater <i>zava</i> on account of blood emitted.
The Rabbis <b>said to</b> Rabbi Meir: <b>If so, there is</b> also a scenario in which a woman <b>experiences</b> emissions of blood due to labor <b>pains</b> for <b>all the days of her</b> life, <b>and</b> the impurity of <b><i>ziva</i> is not included in them.</b> For example, she gives birth to a female, and at the conclusion of her days of impurity engages in intercourse with her husband and becomes pregnant. She continues to experience bleeding throughout her days of purity, after which she experiences bleeding during the seven days of menstruation and the first two days of the next cycle of <i>ziva</i>. She then experiences labor pains accompanied by blood for fifty days, after which she miscarries a female. She subsequently becomes pregnant again within eighty days of the miscarriage, and the above process repeats itself. In this manner, she will never become a greater <i>zava</i>.
Rabbi Meir <b>said to them: What is your opinion,</b> that a woman is not rendered a <i>zava</i> <b>due to</b> the birth of <b>non-viable newborns?</b> The <i>halakha</i> that blood emitted due to labor <b>pains</b> does not render a woman a <i>zava</i> does <b>not</b> apply <b>to non-viable newborns.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>There is</b> a scenario in which a woman <b>sees</b> blood for <b>one hundred days, and</b> the impurity of greater <b><i>ziva</i> is not included in them. How</b> so? She emits blood for <b>two</b> days <b>not at the time</b> of her menstruation, <b>and</b> then throughout the <b>seven</b> days of <b>menstruation, and</b> then for the first <b>two</b> days <b>after the</b> days of <b>menstruation. And</b> this period is followed by <b>eighty</b> days <b>of</b> purity from <i>ziva</i> after giving birth to <b>a female, and seven</b> days of <b>menstruation</b> following her days of purity, <b>and</b> another <b>two</b> days <b>after the</b> days of <b>menstruation.</b> This amounts to one hundred days.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> this <i>baraita</i> <b>teaching us?</b> The Gemara responds: The <i>baraita</i> serves <b>to exclude</b> the opinion of <b>the one who said</b> that <b>it is impossible for</b> there to be <b>an opening of the womb [<i>hakever</i>] without</b> an emission of <b>blood.</b> According to this opinion, if a woman gives birth after experiencing bleeding on the first two days after the days of menstruation, it is certain she experienced bleeding on the third day as well, as every birth is accompanied by an emission of blood. Consequently, she has experienced bleeding on three consecutive days during the days of <i>ziva</i> and is rendered a greater <i>zava</i>. The <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us that it is possible for</b> there to be <b>an opening of the womb without</b> an emission of <b>blood.</b> Therefore, if she gave birth on the third day of <i>ziva</i> and she did not experience bleeding, she is not rendered a greater <i>zava</i>.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> It is <b>sufficient</b> that a woman is not rendered a <i>zava</i> on account of blood that is emitted due to labor pains only from within one month of her due date. In this regard, it <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Tarfon:</b> It is <b>sufficient for her</b> not to be rendered a <i>zava</i> from within one <b>month</b> of <b>her</b> due date. <b>And there is</b> an aspect of <b>leniency and</b> an aspect of <b>stringency in the matter.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> explains: <b>How</b> so? If <b>she experienced</b> labor <b>pains</b> accompanied by an emission of blood for <b>two</b> days <b>at the end of</b> her <b>eighth</b> month of pregnancy, which are days in which she can be rendered a <i>zava</i>, <b>and</b> for <b>one</b> day <b>at the beginning of</b> her <b>ninth</b> month, then <b>even</b> if she <b>gave birth</b> at <b>the beginning of</b> the <b>ninth</b> month, the one day from the ninth month joins together with the two days from the eighth month, and <b>this</b> woman is considered <b>one who gives birth as a <i>zava</i>.</b> This is an aspect of stringency.
<b>But</b> if <b>she experienced</b> labor <b>pains</b> accompanied by an emission of blood for <b>one day at the end of</b> her <b>eighth</b> month, <b>and</b> for only <b>two</b> days <b>at the beginning of</b> her <b>ninth</b> month, then <b>even</b> if she <b>gave birth at the end of</b> the <b>ninth</b> month, <b>this</b> woman <b>is not</b> considered <b>one who gives birth as a <i>zava</i>,</b> and she is pure. This is an aspect of leniency.
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava says: Conclude from</b> the <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda holds</b> that the blast of <b>the shofar</b> at the beginning of the ninth month <b>causes</b> the blood emitted during that month to be pure. That is to say, once the ninth months begins, any blood emitted does not render her a <i>zava</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so,</b> that the entire ninth month of pregnancy is suitable for giving birth, and therefore any blood seen during the ninth month is attributed to the imminent labor? <b>But doesn’t Shmuel say</b> that <b>a woman becomes pregnant and gives birth only after 271 days,</b> which is a full nine months, <b>or after 272 days, or after 273</b> days? She will not, however, give birth during the ninth month itself.
The Gemara responds: Shmuel <b>said</b> his statement <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the early</b> generations of <b>pious</b> men. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The early</b> generations of <b>pious</b> men <b>would engage in sexual intercourse only on a Wednesday, so that their wives should not come</b>

Daf 38b

<b>to a desecration of Shabbat.</b> If they were to engage in sexual intercourse on a Sunday, Monday, or Tuesday, their wives might give birth on Shabbat, either 271, 272, or 273 days after conception either. The Gemara asks: If this was indeed the concern of the early generations of pious men, why would they engage in intercourse only <b>on a Wednesday, and nothing more?</b> After all, if they engaged in intercourse on a Thursday, Friday, or Shabbat, they would likewise avoid any desecration of Shabbat. The Gemara answers: <b>Say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> means that the early generations of pious men would engage in intercourse each week only <b>from Wednesday onward.</b>
<b>Mar Zutra said: What is the reasoning of the early</b> generations of <b>pious</b> men, who state that a woman does not give birth before 271 days have passed from the time of insemination? <b>As it is written</b> with regard to Boaz and Ruth: “And he went in unto her, <b>and the Lord gave her conception [<i>herayon</i>]”</b> (Ruth 4:13). The letters that constitute the word <b><i>herayon</i> are 271 in numerical value.</b>
<b>Mar Zutra says: Even according to the one who said,</b> e.g., Shmuel and the early generations of pious men, that a woman <b>who gives birth at nine</b> months <b>does not give birth after an incomplete</b> number of months, i.e., she carries for a full nine months, nevertheless, a woman <b>who gives birth at seven months can give birth after an incomplete</b> number of months. <b>As it is stated</b> with regard to the birth of Samuel: <b>“And it came to pass, when the seasons of the days had come, that Hannah conceived, and bore a son”</b> (I Samuel 1:20). <b>The minimal</b> number of <b>“seasons”</b> is <b>two,</b> and as each season of the year is three months, this amounts to six months. And <b>the minimal</b> number of <b>“days” is two.</b> If so, Samuel was born in the seventh month of Hannah’s pregnancy.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon say:</b> Labor <b>pains</b> do <b>not</b> occur <b>more than two weeks</b> before birth. <b>Shmuel said: What is the reasoning of the Rabbis,</b> i.e., Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon? <b>As it is written</b> with regard to a woman who gives birth to a female: <b>“And she shall be impure two weeks, as in her menstruation”</b> (Leviticus 12:5). The verse indicates that she is impure <b>as in her menstruation but not as in her <i>ziva</i>. By inference,</b> one may conclude <b>that her <i>ziva</i> is pure,</b> i.e., if she emits blood accompanied by labor pains she is not rendered a <i>zava</i>. <b>And</b> for <b>how</b> long is this the case? For <b>two weeks.</b>
With regard to the <i>halakha</i> that blood emitted due to labor pains does not impart impurity of <i>ziva</i>, <b>the Sages taught: There is</b> a scenario in which a woman <b>experiences</b> labor <b>pains</b> accompanied by emissions of blood for <b>twenty-five days</b> before birth, <b>and</b> the impurity of greater <b><i>ziva</i> is not included in them. How</b> so? She emits blood for <b>two</b> days <b>not at the time</b> of her menstruation, i.e., on the tenth and eleventh days of <i>ziva</i>, <b>and</b> then for the <b>seven</b> days of <b>menstruation, and</b> then for the first <b>two</b> days of <i>ziva</i> <b>that</b> come <b>after</b> the days of <b>menstruation. And</b> this period is followed by <b>fourteen</b> days during <b>which the</b> impending birth of <b>a child renders pure</b> the blood she sees.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And it is impossible for</b> a woman <b>to experience</b> labor <b>pains</b> accompanied by emissions of blood for <b>twenty-six days without a child,</b> such that <b>she will not be</b> a woman <b>who gives birth as a <i>zava</i>.</b> Since a span of twenty-six days includes at least five days of <i>ziva</i>, there will inevitably be three consecutive days of <i>ziva</i> during which she experienced bleeding, therefore rendering her a greater <i>zava</i>.
The Gemara analyzes the <i>baraita</i>: Is the <i>baraita</i> really dealing with a case <b>without a child,</b> i.e., where she is not even pregnant? If there is no child, then experiencing bleeding <b>on three</b> consecutive days after the days of menstruation <b>is also sufficient</b> to render her a greater <i>zava</i>. <b>Rav Sheshet said</b> one should <b>say</b> the <i>baraita</i> as follows: Twenty-six days <b>in a case where there is a child,</b> i.e., where she is pregnant. <b>Rava said to</b> Rav Sheshet: <b>But</b> the <i>baraita</i> explicitly <b>teaches: Without a child.</b>
<b>Rather, Rava said</b> that <b>this</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying: It is impossible for</b> a woman <b>to experience</b> labor <b>pains</b> accompanied by emissions of blood for <b>twenty-six days in a case where there is a child,</b> such that <b>she will not be</b> a woman <b>who gives birth as a <i>zava</i>. And in a case where there is no child</b> born <b>but</b> there is <b>a non-viable newborn, with three</b> consecutive days of emissions <b>she also becomes a <i>zava</i>. What is the reason?</b> The <i>halakha</i> that blood emitted due to labor <b>pains</b> does not render a woman a <i>zava</i> does <b>not</b> apply <b>to non-viable newborns.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> A woman <b>who experiences</b> labor <b>pains within eighty</b> days <b>of</b> giving birth to <b>a female,</b> e.g., she conceived during the sixty-six days of purity, or she initially conceived twins and she gave birth to a female and the birth of the second fetus was delayed, <b>all blood that she sees is ritually pure,</b> as she is currently within her days of purity. And this remains the <i>halakha</i> <b>until the child emerges</b> from the womb, at which point she is rendered impure as a woman who gives birth. <b>And Rabbi Eliezer deems ritually impure</b> the blood that occurs due to these labor pains.
The Rabbis <b>said to Rabbi Eliezer: And what,</b> if <b>in an instance where</b> the verse <b>was stringent with regard to blood</b> emitted while <b>resting,</b> namely if a pregnant woman emits blood after her days of purity without any labor pains she is rendered impure, the verse <b>was lenient with regard to blood</b> that accompanies <b>the</b> labor <b>pains;</b> then in <b>an instance where</b> the verse <b>was lenient with regard to blood</b> emitted while <b>resting,</b> i.e., during a woman’s days of purity, <b>is it not right that we will be lenient with regard to blood</b> that accompanies <b>the</b> labor <b>pains?</b>
Rabbi Eliezer <b>said to them:</b> When deriving a <i>halakha</i> by means of an <i>a fortiori</i> inference, there is a principle that <b>it is sufficient for the</b> conclusion that <b>emerges from</b> an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference to be like</b> its <b>source.</b> In other words, the status of blood emitted due to labor pains during her days of purity should not be more lenient than that of blood emitted due to labor pains after her days of purity. Rabbi Eliezer elaborates: <b>Concerning what</b> type of impurity <b>was</b> the verse <b>lenient with regard to</b> a woman who experiences an emission of blood due to labor pains? <b>Concerning the impurity of <i>ziva</i>. But she</b> may still be rendered <b>ritually impure</b> with <b>the impurity of a menstruating woman.</b> So too, if a woman experiences emissions of blood due to labor pains during her days of purity, she is rendered a menstruating woman.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the dispute between Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis concerning a woman who emits blood due to labor pains during her days of purity, <b>the Sages taught</b> a <i>baraita</i> that addresses a verse discussing a woman who gives birth to a female: “And sixty-six days she shall observe the blood of purity” (Leviticus 12:5). The term <b>“She shall observe”</b> serves <b>to include</b> a woman <b>who experiences</b> labor <b>pains within eighty</b> days <b>of</b> giving birth to <b>a female,</b> teaching <b>that all blood that she sees is ritually pure.</b> And this remains the case <b>until the child emerges</b> from the womb. <b>And Rabbi Eliezer deems ritually impure</b> the blood that occurs due to these labor pains.
The Rabbis <b>said to Rabbi Eliezer: And what,</b> if <b>in an instance where</b> the verse <b>was stringent with regard to</b> blood that is emitted while <b>resting before</b> the birth of <b>the child,</b> as such blood renders her a <i>zava</i>, the verse <b>was lenient with regard to</b> blood that is emitted while <b>resting after</b> the birth of <b>the child,</b> i.e., during her days of purity; then in <b>an instance where</b> the verse <b>was lenient with regard to</b> blood emitted due to labor <b>pains before</b> the birth of <b>the child, is it not right that we will be lenient with regard to</b> blood that is emitted due to labor <b>pains after</b> the birth of <b>the child?</b>
Rabbi Eliezer <b>said to them: It is sufficient for the</b> conclusion that <b>emerges from</b> an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference to be like</b> its <b>source.</b> Rabbi Eliezer elaborates: <b>Concerning what</b> type of impurity <b>was</b> the verse <b>lenient with regard to</b> a woman who experiences an emission of blood due to labor pains? <b>Concerning the impurity of <i>ziva</i>. But</b> an emission of blood <b>renders her impure</b> with <b>the impurity of a menstruating woman.</b> So too, if a woman experiences emissions of blood due to labor pains during her days of purity, she is rendered a menstruating woman.
The Rabbis <b>said to him: But we</b> will <b>respond to you</b> with <b>another version</b> of the <i>a fortiori</i> inference: <b>And what,</b> if <b>in an instance where</b> the verse <b>was stringent with regard to</b> blood that is emitted while <b>resting before</b> the birth of <b>the child</b> the verse <b>was lenient with regard to</b> blood that is emitted due to labor <b>pains that</b> come <b>with it,</b> i.e., which precede the birth of the child; then in <b>an instance where</b> the verse <b>was lenient with regard to</b> blood emitted while <b>resting,</b> namely during a woman’s days of purity, <b>is it not right that we will be lenient with regard to</b> blood that accompanies <b>the</b> labor <b>pains that</b> come <b>with it?</b>
Rabbi Eliezer <b>said to them: Even</b> if <b>you respond</b> by citing <i>a fortiori</i> inferences of that type throughout <b>the entire day,</b> the principle remains that <b>it is sufficient for the</b> conclusion that <b>emerges from</b> an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference to be like</b> its <b>source. Concerning what</b> type of impurity <b>was</b> the verse <b>lenient with regard to</b> a woman who experiences an emission of blood due to labor pains? <b>Concerning the impurity of <i>ziva</i>. But</b> an emission of blood <b>renders her impure</b> with <b>the impurity of a menstruating woman.</b>
<b>Rava said: With this</b> response <b>Rabbi Eliezer triumphed over the Rabbis: Didn’t you say</b> that the reason why a woman is not rendered a <i>zava</i> on account of blood that is emitted due to labor pains before birth is because the verse states: “And if a woman has an issue of her blood many days” (Leviticus 15:25)? The term <b>“her blood”</b> indicates that only <b>her blood</b> that comes <b>due to herself</b> is impure due to <i>ziva</i>, <b>but not</b> blood that comes <b>due to</b> her <b>child. So too,</b> one can say that as the verse states with regard to a woman who gives birth: <b>“And she shall be purified from the fountain of her blood”</b> (Leviticus 12:7), this indicates that only <b>her blood</b> that comes <b>due to herself</b> is pure from <i>ziva</i>, <b>but not</b> blood that comes <b>due to</b> her <b>child.</b>
This Gemara raises a difficulty against the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer: If so, one can <b>say</b> that if she emits blood due to labor pains <b>during the days of menstruation</b> she is <b>a menstruating woman,</b> but if she emits blood <b>in the days of <i>ziva</i>,</b> i.e., after the days of menstruation, she is <b>pure.</b> The Gemara explains that <b>the verse states: “She shall observe</b> the blood of purity” (Leviticus 12:5), which indicates that there is <b>one observance for all</b> the days of her purity, i.e., all the blood she emits due to labor pains during her days of purity is either pure or impure.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> For <b>all</b> the <b>eleven days</b> of <i>ziva</i> that follow the seven days of menstruation, a woman <b>has the presumptive status of ritual purity,</b> as it is unusual for her to experience bleeding on these days.

Daf 39a

If a woman <b>sat and did not examine</b> herself every morning and evening to determine whether she emitted blood and is impure, it makes no difference whether she failed to examine herself <b>unwittingly</b> or due to <b>circumstances beyond her control,</b> or even if she acted <b>intentionally and did not examine</b> herself; she remains <b>ritually pure.</b> She is rendered impure only if she examined herself and was found to have emitted blood.
By contrast, if <b>the time of her</b> menstrual <b>cycle arrived,</b> when she is required to examine herself, <b>and she did not examine</b> herself, <b>that</b> woman <b>is ritually impure,</b> as it is typical for a woman to discharge blood at that time. <b>Rabbi Meir says:</b> If a woman <b>was in hiding</b> from danger, <b>and the time of her</b> menstrual <b>cycle arrived and she did not examine</b> herself on that day, <b>that</b> woman <b>is pure, because fear drives away blood.</b> There is therefore no concern that she might have emitted blood.
<b>But</b> with regard to the seven clean <b>days of the <i>zav</i> and the <i>zava</i>, and</b> with regard to a woman who <b>observes</b> a clean <b>day for a day</b> she experiences a discharge during her days of <i>ziva</i>, if she fails to examine herself on those days, <b>these</b> women <b>have a presumptive status of ritual impurity,</b> as they already experienced a discharge.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that throughout the eleven days of <i>ziva</i> that follow the seven days of menstruation, a woman has the presumptive status of ritual purity. The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what <i>halakha</i></b> is this stated? <b>Rav Yehuda says:</b> This serves <b>to say that she does not require an examination</b> during these days. The Gemara objects: <b>But from</b> the fact <b>that the latter clause teaches:</b> If <b>she sat and did not examine</b> herself she remains ritually pure, <b>it can be inferred that she requires examination <i>ab initio</i>.</b>
The Gemara explains: In <b>the latter clause we arrive at</b> the case of a woman who is in the <b>days of menstruation,</b> not in the days of <i>ziva</i>. <b>And this</b> is what the mishna <b>is saying:</b> For <b>all</b> the <b>eleven days</b> of <i>ziva</i> that follow the days of menstruation, a woman <b>has the presumptive status of ritual purity and she does not require examination. But during the days of her menstruation she requires examination.</b> Nevertheless, if <b>she sat and did not examine</b> herself, whether <b>unwittingly</b> or due to <b>circumstances beyond her control,</b> or even if she acted <b>intentionally and did not examine</b> herself, she remains <b>ritually pure.</b>
<b>Rav Ḥisda said</b> a different answer: The first clause of the mishna <b>is necessary only for</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who said:</b> With regard to <b>a woman who does not have</b> a fixed menstrual <b>cycle,</b> she is <b>forbidden to engage in intercourse,</b> lest she emit blood during intercourse. The mishna is teaching that <b>this statement</b> applies only <b>during the days of her menstruation, but during the days of her <i>ziva</i></b> even Rabbi Meir concedes that she <b>stands in</b> her <b>presumptive status of purity</b> and may engage in intercourse with her husband.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> that even according to Rabbi Meir there are days in which a woman who does not have a fixed menstrual cycle is permitted to engage in sexual intercourse with her husband, <b>why did Rabbi Meir say</b> that her husband <b>must divorce</b> her <b>and he may never take</b> her <b>back,</b> even if she eventually develops a fixed menstrual cycle? Let them engage in intercourse during the eleven days of <i>ziva</i>. The Gemara answers: He must divorce her <b>lest</b> the matter <b>lead to failure during the days of menstruation,</b> i.e., in case they come to engage in intercourse during the days of menstruation, when she might experience regular menstrual bleeding.
The Gemara objects: But <b>from</b> the fact <b>that the latter clause teaches:</b> If <b>the time of her</b> menstrual <b>cycle arrived and she did not examine</b> herself, that woman is ritually impure, <b>it can be inferred that we are dealing with a woman who has</b> a fixed menstrual <b>cycle.</b> The Gemara explains: The mishna <b>is incomplete and this</b> is what <b>it is teaching:</b> For <b>all</b> the <b>eleven</b> days of <i>ziva</i> that follow the days of menstruation, a woman <b>has the presumptive status of ritual purity and she is permitted to her husband, but during the days of menstruation she is prohibited</b> to her husband.
<b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said? In</b> the case of <b>a woman who does not have</b> a fixed menstrual <b>cycle,</b> where there is a concern she might experience bleeding during any of the days of menstruation. <b>But</b> in the case of a woman who <b>has</b> a fixed menstrual <b>cycle, she is permitted</b> to engage in sexual intercourse with her husband, <b>and she requires examination.</b> Nevertheless, if <b>she sat and did not examine</b> herself, whether <b>unwittingly</b> or due to <b>circumstances beyond her control,</b> or even if she acted <b>intentionally and did not examine</b> herself, she remains <b>ritually pure.</b> If <b>the time of her</b> menstrual <b>cycle arrived and she did not examine</b> herself, she is <b>impure.</b>
The Gemara objects: But <b>from</b> the fact that <b>the last clause</b> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> it can be inferred that <b>the first clause</b> is <b>not</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir.</b> The Gemara explains that <b>the entire</b> mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, and this</b> is what it <b>is saying: If she was not in hiding and the time of her</b> menstrual <b>cycle arrived and she did not examine</b> herself, she is <b>impure, as Rabbi Meir says:</b> If a woman <b>was in hiding and the time of her</b> menstrual <b>cycle arrived and she did not examine</b> herself, she is <b>pure, as fear drives away blood.</b>
<b>Rava says</b> a different explanation of the first clause of the mishna: The mishna is coming <b>to say that</b> if a woman experiences bleeding during the eleven days of <i>ziva</i>, as she previously had the presumptive status of purity <b>she does not impart impurity</b> retroactively <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period</b> to any ritually pure items she touched. It is assumed that she did not emit any blood before this emission.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a menstruating woman, and a <i>zava</i>, and a woman who observes a day for a day, and a woman who gave birth, they all impart impurity</b> retroactively <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period.</b> A woman who observes a day for a day is one who experiences bleeding for one or two days during her days of <i>ziva</i>, and the <i>baraita</i> teaches that even such a woman imparts impurity retroactively for a twenty-four-hour period. If so, this is <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of Rava’s explanation.
<b>Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya says</b> another explanation of the first clause of the mishna in the name of <b>Shmuel:</b> The mishna is coming <b>to say that</b> a woman <b>does not fix</b> a menstrual <b>cycle for herself during the days of her <i>ziva</i>.</b> In other words, a sighting during these days does not combine with sightings during the previous two periods of <i>ziva</i> to establish a fixed menstrual cycle. The Gemara relates that this statement was recited before <b>Rav Yosef,</b> who <b>said: I did not hear this <i>halakha</i></b> from Shmuel.
<b>Abaye said to him:</b> But <b>you</b> yourself <b>told us</b> this <i>halakha</i>, <b>and</b> it was <b>with regard to that</b> mishna <b>you told</b> it to <b>us,</b> as we learned in a mishna (63b): If the woman <b>was accustomed to see</b> an emission of blood on the <b>fifteenth day,</b> so that this was her fixed menstrual cycle, <b>and she deviated</b> from her cycle <b>to</b> see an emission on the <b>twentieth day,</b> then on both <b>this</b> day, the fifteenth, <b>and that</b> day, the twentieth, it is <b>prohibited</b> for her to engage in sexual intercourse due to the concern that she might have an emission on either day. If <b>she deviated</b> from her cycle <b>twice, to</b> see an emission on the <b>twentieth day,</b> then on both <b>this</b> day <b>and that</b> day it is <b>prohibited</b> for her to engage in intercourse. If she deviates a third time to see on the twentieth she has established for herself a new fixed menstrual cycle.
Abaye continues: <b>And you said to us with regard to this</b> mishna that <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> with regard to a woman who normally experiences bleeding <b>fifteen</b> days <b>from her immersion, which are twenty-two</b> days <b>from her sighting</b> of menstrual blood. This means <b>that there, she stands in her days of menstruation. But</b> if she normally experiences bleeding <b>fifteen</b> days <b>from her sighting</b> of menstrual blood, so <b>that she stands in her days of <i>ziva</i>,</b> she <b>has not fixed</b> a menstrual cycle, and the previous cycle is uprooted even if she deviates from it only once.
§ With regard to the ruling that a woman’s menstrual cycle cannot be fixed during her days of <i>ziva</i>, <b>Rav Pappa said: I said</b> this <b><i>halakha</i> before Rav Yehuda of Diskarta,</b> and I asked him for a clarification of the following matter: Granted, <b>she does not fix</b> a menstrual cycle during the days of <i>ziva</i>, and there is no need for three deviations to uproot her cycle; rather, it is uprooted by even one deviation. But <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to whether <b>we should be concerned</b> that <b>she</b> might experience bleeding? In other words, if she normally experiences bleeding on a particular day during her days of <i>ziva</i>, must she avoid engaging in sexual intercourse with her husband on that day out of concern that she might emit blood?
Rav Yehuda of Diskarta <b>was silent and did not say anything to</b> Rav Pappa. Therefore, <b>Rav Pappa said: Let us see</b> and try to resolve this <b>ourselves.</b> The mishna cited above states: If the woman <b>was accustomed to see</b> an emission of blood <b>on the fifteenth day, and she deviated</b> from her cycle <b>to</b> see an emission on the <b>twentieth day,</b> then on both <b>this</b> day <b>and that</b> day it is <b>prohibited</b> for her to engage in sexual intercourse.

Daf 39b

<b>And</b> with regard to this mishna, <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> with regard to a woman who normally experiences bleeding <b>fifteen</b> days <b>from her immersion, which are twenty-two</b> days <b>from her sighting</b> of menstrual blood, which means that there, she stands in her days of menstruation.
<b>And</b> when the mishna states that <b>she deviated</b> from her cycle and experienced bleeding on the twentieth day, it means she experienced bleeding twenty days from her immersion, i.e., <b>twenty-seven days from</b> her previous sighting, not twenty-two. This means <b>that when twenty-two days again elapse</b> from when she usually experiences bleeding, <b>she stands within</b> what is now the eleven <b>days of her <i>ziva</i>. And</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> that both <b>this,</b> the twenty-second day, <b>and that,</b> the twenty-seventh day, <b>are prohibited,</b> despite the fact that the twenty-second day now stands during her days of <i>ziva</i>. <b>Evidently, we are concerned</b> for an emission of blood during the days of <i>ziva</i> if she is accustomed to experiencing bleeding on that day.
The Gemara elaborates: <b>And Rav Pappa holds</b> that <b>we count twenty-two</b> days of her menstrual cycle <b>from twenty-two</b> days, i.e., from when she usually begins to menstruate, whereas <b>we count the beginning</b> of the days of <b>menstruation from</b> day <b>twenty-seven,</b> when she actually experiences bleeding. Consequently, the twenty-second day of her normal menstrual cycle falls during the days of <i>ziva</i>, according to the actual day of menstruation.
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said to Rav Pappa: From where</b> do you know this is the correct reckoning of her days? <b>Perhaps one also counts</b> those <b>twenty-two</b> days <b>from</b> day <b>twenty-seven,</b> such <b>that when twenty-two days again arrive</b> from day twenty-seven, <b>she stands within her days of menstruation.</b> Accordingly, there is no proof from the mishna with regard to a sighting during the days of <i>ziva</i>.
Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, adds: <b>And so too, it is reasonable</b> that the twenty-two days are counted from when she actually experiences bleeding. <b>As if you do not say so,</b> then consider the case of <b>this chicken that</b> normally <b>lays</b> an egg on one <b>day and withholds</b> an egg the next <b>day, and lays</b> an egg on the third <b>day and withholds</b> an egg on the fourth <b>day. And</b> the chicken deviated from its routine, so that after laying eggs on the first day and third day, it <b>withheld</b> an egg for <b>two days and</b> then <b>laid</b> an egg on <b>one day,</b> i.e., on the sixth day.
When this chicken <b>again takes hold</b> of its previous routine and starts laying an egg on one day and withholding an egg on the next, does <b>it take hold of</b> the order of the routine <b>ahead of it,</b> i.e., will it withhold an egg on the next day, <b>or</b> does <b>it take hold</b> of its routine <b>as it</b> was <b>from the outset,</b> so that it will lay an egg on the seventh day, as if there had been no deviation? <b>Perforce it takes hold of</b> the order of the routine <b>ahead of it.</b> Likewise, a woman who deviated from her normal menstrual cycle counts the days of her cycle according to the order of the cycle ahead of her, i.e., from the time that she experiences bleeding.
<b>Rav Pappa said to</b> Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua: <b>But</b> if so, a question arises with regard to <b>that which Reish Lakish said: A woman fixes</b> a menstrual <b>cycle for herself during the days of her <i>ziva</i>, but a woman does not fix</b> a menstrual <b>cycle for herself during the days of her menstruation,</b> i.e., when she is already a menstruating woman. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: A woman fixes</b> a menstrual <b>cycle for herself during the days of her menstruation.</b> One could ask: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of this dispute? Rabbi Yoḥanan cannot be referring to a case where all her sightings occurred while she was a menstruating woman, as everyone agrees that a woman’s menstrual cycle is not fixed in such a situation (see 11a).
Rather, <b>is it not</b> referring to a case <b>where she saw</b> blood on the <b>first of the month; and</b> then again on <b>the fifth of</b> that same <b>month,</b> when she was a menstruating woman; <b>and</b> subsequently she saw blood on the <b>first of the</b> next <b>month and</b> then again on <b>the fifth of</b> that <b>month; and now</b> in the third month she <b>saw</b> blood <b>on the fifth of the month but on the first of the month she did not see</b> blood? In such a situation, the woman experienced an emission of blood on the fifth of the month for three consecutive months.
Rav Pappa concludes: <b>And</b> it is with regard to this case that Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>says: A woman fixes</b> a menstrual <b>cycle for herself during the days of her menstruation.</b> Although she was not actually a menstruating woman before she experienced bleeding on the fifth day of the third month, this is nevertheless considered a sighting during her days of menstruation. <b>Evidently, one counts</b> her menstrual cycle <b>from the first of the month,</b> despite the fact that she did not actually experience bleeding. Likewise, with regard to the case involving twenty-two days, one counts from when she generally experiences bleeding, not from the day she emitted blood in practice.
Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, <b>said to</b> Rav Pappa: These are <b>not</b> the circumstances of the dispute. Rather, <b>this</b> is what <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> The dispute is referring to a case <b>where she saw</b> blood on the <b>first of the month; and</b> then again on the <b>first of the</b> next <b>month, and</b> then again on <b>the twenty-fifth</b> day <b>of</b> that <b>month; and</b> again on the <b>first of the</b> next <b>month,</b> which occurs during her days of menstruation. Rabbi Yoḥanan maintains that although she is in her days of menstruation, this sighting on the first of the third month serves to fix her menstrual cycle, <b>as we say</b> with regard to the sighting on the twenty-fifth day of the previous month that <b>it is extra blood that gathered inside her.</b> Therefore, it does not negate her regular cycle.
The Gemara notes: <b>And likewise, when Ravin and all</b> the <b>sea-farers came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia and transmitted statements of Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>they said</b> this statement of Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>in accordance with</b> the explanation of <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua.</b><br/>.

Daf 40a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> After the birth of an offspring by <b>caesarean section,</b> the mother <b>does not observe</b> seven or fourteen <b>days of impurity and</b> thirty-three or sixty-six <b>days of purity for</b> male and female offspring, respectively, <b>and she is not obligated to</b> bring <b>for it</b> the <b>offering</b> brought by a woman after childbirth. <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> The halakhic status of <b>that</b> offspring is <b>like</b> that of an offspring <b>born</b> in a standard birth.
<b>All women become ritually impure</b> with the flow of blood from the uterus <b>into the outer chamber,</b> i.e., the vagina, although it did not leave the woman’s body, <b>as it is stated: “And her issue in her flesh shall be blood,</b> she shall be in her menstruation seven days” (Leviticus 15:19), indicating that even if her menstrual blood remains in her flesh, she becomes impure. <b>But one who experiences a gonorrhea-like discharge [<i>zav</i>] and one who experiences a seminal emission do not become ritually impure until their</b> emission of <b>impurity emerges outside</b> the body.
If a priest <b>was partaking of <i>teruma</i>,</b> the portion of the produce designated for the priest, <b>and sensed a quaking of his limbs</b> indicating that a seminal emission was imminent, he should firmly <b>hold</b> his <b>penis</b> to prevent the emission from leaving his body, <b>and swallow the <i>teruma</i></b> while ritually pure. <b>And</b> the emission of a <i>zav</i> and a seminal emission <b>impart impurity in any amount, even like</b> the size of <b>a mustard seed or</b> even <b>smaller than that.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna cites a dispute as to whether or not a birth by caesarean section is considered a birth with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> pertaining to childbirth. <b>Rabbi Mani bar Patish said: What is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of the Rabbis,</b> who say that it is not considered a birth? It is because <b>the verse states: “If a woman emitted seed and gave birth to a male,</b> then she shall be impure seven days…And when the days of her purification are fulfilled, for a son, or for a daughter, she shall bring a lamb of the first year for a burnt offering, and a pigeon or a dove for a sin offering” (Leviticus 12:2–6). It is derived from here that the <i>halakhot</i> mentioned in that passage do not apply <b>unless she gives birth through the place where she emits seed.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> interpret the term “emitted seed”? The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> word serves to teach <b>that even</b> if <b>she gave birth only</b> to a fluid that <b>resembles the seed that she emitted,</b> i.e., the fetus died and entirely decomposed and dissolved before emerging, <b>its mother is ritually impure</b> due to <b>childbirth.</b>
The Gemara further asks: <b>And Rabbi Shimon, what is</b> the <b>reason</b> for <b>his</b> opinion that the <i>halakhot</i> of childbirth apply in the case of a caesarean section? <b>Reish Lakish said</b> that it is because the <b>verse states:</b> “But if <b>she gives birth</b> to a female” (Leviticus 12:5). The term “she gives birth” is superfluous in the context of the passage, as it was mentioned previously, and it therefore serves <b>to include</b> the birth of an offspring by <b>caesarean section.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what do <b>the Rabbis</b> derive from this superfluous expression? The Gemara answers: In their opinion, <b>that</b> expression <b>is necessary to include</b> the birth of a child <b>whose sexual organs are indeterminate [<i>tumtum</i>] or a hermaphrodite. As</b> it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that as the words <b>“male”</b> (Leviticus 12:2) <b>and “female”</b> (Leviticus 12:5) are <b>written</b> in the passage, these <i>halakhot</i> apply only to <b>a definite male</b> and <b>a definite female, but not</b> to <b>a <i>tumtum</i> or a hermaphrodite.</b> Therefore, the term “she gives birth” <b>teaches us</b> that it is the birth itself, not the sex of the offspring, that matters.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> from where does <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> derive that these <i>halakhot</i> apply to a <i>tumtum</i> and a hermaphrodite? The Gemara answers: <b>He derives it from</b> that <b>which bar Livai teaches, as bar Livai teaches</b> a <i>baraita</i> that discusses the verse: “And when the days of her purity are fulfilled, for a son, or for a daughter” (Leviticus 12:6). Since the verse uses the terms “son” and “daughter,” rather than male and female, it is derived from the term <b>“for a son”</b> that these <i>halakhot</i> apply <b>to a son in any case,</b> even if his masculinity is not definite. Similarly, the term <b>“for a daughter”</b> teaches that these <i>halakhot</i> apply <b>to a daughter in any case,</b> even if her femininity is not definite.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what do <b>the Rabbis</b> derive from the terms “for a son” and “for a daughter”? The Gemara answers: In their opinion, <b>that</b> term <b>is necessary to obligate</b> the mother to bring an offering <b>for each and every son</b> to whom she gives birth, rather than one offering after having given birth to several sons; <b>and likewise to obligate</b> her to bring an offering <b>for each and every daughter</b> to whom she gives birth.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> from where does <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> derive this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers that <b>he derives it from</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>that a <i>tanna</i> taught before Rav Sheshet:</b> The verse states: <b>“This is the law for one who gives birth,</b> whether to a male or a female” (Leviticus 12:7). This <b>teaches that</b> a woman <b>brings a single offering for many offspring</b> born within a short time, e.g., after a multiple birth. One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>she may bring</b> an offering <b>for</b> her <b>childbirth and</b> an offering <b>for</b> an irregular <b>discharge</b> of blood from the uterus [<i>ziva</i>], in a case where she is required to bring one, <b>as one,</b> i.e., that she may fulfill her two obligations with a single offering.
The Gemara interrupts the <i>baraita</i> to raise a difficulty: <b>But</b> how could it possibly enter your mind that a woman may bring one offering for two obligations? In the case of <b>a woman after childbirth who consumed blood, or a woman after childbirth who ate</b> forbidden <b>fat,</b> is <b>one offering sufficient for her?</b> One who eats blood or forbidden fat is obligated to bring a sin offering for atonement (see Leviticus 7:25–27). There is no reason to think that a woman after childbirth, who is required to bring a sin offering for a reason other than her childbirth, may bring one offering for both obligations. Similarly, there are no grounds for suggesting that a single offering might suffice for both childbirth and <i>ziva</i>.
<b>Rather,</b> the statement of the <i>baraita</i> should be revised, as follows: One <b>might</b> have thought that a woman <b>may bring</b> an offering <b>for a childbirth that</b> occurred <b>before the completion</b> of her term of postpartum purity, <b>and for</b> a second <b>childbirth that</b> happened <b>after the completion</b> of that period, <b>as one,</b> i.e., she may fulfill her two obligations with a single offering. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “This</b> is the law for one who gives birth” (Leviticus 12:7), indicating that each birth, unless it occurred within the period of purity following another birth, requires its own offering.
