The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how do <b>the Rabbis</b> respond to this derivation? The Gemara answers that in their opinion, <b>even though it is written: “This</b> is the law,” <b>it was</b> still <b>necessary</b> for the verse to state: <b>“For a son, or for a daughter.”</b>
The Gemara explains: Had the Torah stated only the verse: “This is the law,” it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that one offering does not suffice for two births that occurred as a result <b>of two pregnancies,</b> as the second one was a miscarriage whose conception occurred during the woman’s period of purity following the first birth. <b>But</b> if both births occurred as a result <b>of one pregnancy, such as</b> in the case of <b>Yehuda and Ḥizkiyya,</b> the twin <b>sons of Rabbi Ḥiyya,</b> who were born three months apart (see 27a), <b>I would say that one offering</b> for both births is <b>sufficient for her.</b> Therefore, the verse “for a son, or for a daughter” <b>teaches us</b> otherwise.
§ <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: And Rabbi Shimon,</b> who maintains that childbirth by caesarean section has the halakhic status of regular childbirth, <b>concedes in</b> the case of <b>consecrated</b> animals <b>that</b> if one attempts to consecrate an animal born by caesarean section, it <b>is not consecrated. What is the reason</b> for this opinion? <b>He derives</b> it by means of a verbal analogy <b>from</b> the word <b>birth</b> that is written with regard to consecrated animals (see Leviticus 22:27), and the word <b>birth</b> that is written in connection with a <b>firstborn</b> animal (see Deuteronomy 15:19). <b>Just as there,</b> in the case of the firstborn, the <i>halakhot</i> apply specifically to one who <b>“opens the womb”</b> (Exodus 13:15), <b>so too here,</b> in the case of consecrated animals, the <i>halakhot</i> apply only to one who <b>opens the womb.</b>
The Gemara objects: <b>And let</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>derive</b> a different conclusion by a similar verbal analogy, as the word <b>birth</b> is written with regard to consecrated animals, and the word <b>birth</b> is also written <b>with regard to a person,</b> i.e., a woman who gives birth (see Leviticus 12:2): <b>Just as there,</b> in the case of humans, childbirth by <b>caesarean section</b> has the status of childbirth according to Rabbi Shimon, <b>so too here,</b> in the case of consecrated animals, an animal born by <b>caesarean section</b> is considered the same as an animal born via a natural birth.
The Gemara answers: It <b>is</b> more <b>reasonable for</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>to derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of a consecrated animal <b>from a firstborn</b> animal, rather than from the <i>halakha</i> of childbirth, <b>as</b> it is written with regard to a consecrated animal: <b>“Its mother”</b> (Leviticus 22:27), and it is likewise written <b>with regard to</b> a firstborn animal: <b>“Its mother”</b> (Exodus 22:29). The Gemara objects: <b>On the contrary, he should derive</b> it <b>from human</b> births, <b>as</b> that would be a derivation of the <i>halakha</i> concerning consecrated animals that are <b>ordinary,</b> i.e., not firstborns, <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> concerning human births of children that are <b>ordinary,</b> and not firstborns.
The Gemara adopts a different line of reasoning: <b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>should derive</b> it <b>from a firstborn</b> animal, <b>as</b> they both share the following five characteristics: In both cases it is written: “its <b>mother”;</b> both are cases of <b>a sacrificial animal;</b> both are subject to <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> the disqualification of an offering through improper intent during its sacrificial rites; both are subject to <b><i>notar</i>,</b> the disqualification of sacrificial meat after a prescribed time; <b>and</b> finally, both are subject to disqualification by becoming <b>ritually impure.</b> By contrast, humans do not share any of these characteristics.
The Gemara objects: <b>On the contrary, he should derive</b> it <b>from human</b> births, <b>as</b> both cases share the following four characteristics: They are both instances of <b>ordinary,</b> non-firstborn offspring; they both apply to the offspring of either sex, and are not exclusively <b>males;</b> they are both dealing with offspring that are not automatically <b>sacred</b> at birth; and they both apply <b>to</b> offspring that are not <b>a gift</b> to a priest, but belong to an individual non-priest. By contrast, firstborn animals do not share any of these characteristics. The Gemara answers that the comparison to firstborn animals is preferable to the comparison to human childbirth because <b>these</b> shared characteristics <b>are more</b> numerous. The comparison to consecrated animals includes five shared characteristics, whereas the comparison to human births involves only four.
<b>Rav Ḥiyya, son of Rav Huna, said in the name of Rava:</b> A <i>baraita</i> <b>is taught which supports</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan: Rabbi Yehuda says: “This is the law of the burnt offering; that is the burnt offering</b> that goes up on the pyre upon the altar” (Leviticus 6:2). It is derived from this verse that the <i>halakha</i> is that if a part of a disqualified offering is taken up to the altar it should be burned there, rather than taken down, despite its unfit status. <b>There are three</b> expressions which indicate <b>exclusion</b> in this verse: The term “this is,” which indicates this one and not another one; the term “that is,” indicating that one and not another one; and the term “the burnt offering” instead of “a burnt offering.”

Daf 40b

These three expressions allude <b>to the exclusion of</b> the following three cases from the above principle: An offering that was disqualified because it was <b>slaughtered at night, and</b> an offering <b>whose blood spilled</b> before it could be sprinkled on the altar, <b>and</b> an offering <b>whose blood</b> was disqualified because it <b>was taken outside the curtains [<i>lakela’im</i>]</b> surrounding the courtyard of the Tabernacle in the wilderness, i.e., it left the Temple courtyard. These three cases are excluded, <b>as</b> in these instances, <b>if</b> parts of the disqualified offering <b>ascended,</b> i.e., were brought upon the altar, <b>they must descend,</b> i.e., be taken down.
<b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> From the verse’s reference to <b>a burnt offering, I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that <b>a valid burnt offering</b> should not be taken down from the altar. <b>From where</b> is it derived that the verse also serves <b>to include</b> the following disqualified offerings: An offering <b>that</b> is invalid because it <b>was slaughtered at night; and</b> one <b>whose blood spilled</b> before sprinkling; <b>and</b> one <b>whose blood was taken outside the curtains,</b> i.e., the Temple courtyard; <b>and</b> one whose blood <b>was left overnight; and</b> one <b>that was</b> itself <b>taken out</b> of the Temple courtyard; <b>and</b> one <b>that</b> became <b>ritually impure; and</b> one <b>that was left overnight; and</b> one <b>that was slaughtered</b> with the intent to eat its flesh <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time or outside its</b> designated <b>area.</b>
<b>And</b> likewise, from where is it derived that the verse serves to include offerings <b>that</b> those who are <b>unfit</b> for performing the Temple service <b>collected or sprinkled their blood; and</b> offerings <b>whose</b> blood is supposed to be <b>placed above</b> the red line of the altar but <b>which one placed below</b> that line; <b>and</b> offerings <b>whose</b> blood is supposed to be <b>placed below</b> the red line of the altar but <b>which one placed above</b> it; <b>and</b> offerings <b>whose</b> blood should be <b>placed</b> on the altar situated <b>outside</b> the Sanctuary but <b>which one</b> instead <b>placed</b> on the altar <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary; <b>and</b> offerings <b>whose</b> blood should be <b>placed</b> on the altar <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary but <b>which one placed</b> on the altar <b>outside; and a Paschal offering and a sin offering that one slaughtered not for their</b> own <b>sake,</b> i.e., while slaughtering he actually intended to sacrifice a different offering? <b>From where</b> is it derived that although these offerings are disqualified, if they were brought up to the altar they are not taken down?
<b>The verse states: “This is the law of the burnt offering.”</b> The verse thereby <b>included</b> in <b>one law all</b> items <b>that ascend</b> upon the altar, even disqualified offerings, teaching <b>that if they ascended</b> the altar, <b>they shall not descend.</b>
Rabbi Shimon continues: One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that I</b> should also <b>include an animal that copulated with a person; and an animal that was the object of bestiality; and</b> an animal <b>that</b> was <b>set aside</b> for idol worship; <b>and</b> an animal <b>that was worshipped</b> as a deity; <b>and</b> an animal that was given as <b>payment</b> to a prostitute <b>or</b> as <b>the price</b> of a dog; <b>and</b> an animal that is an offspring of <b>diverse kinds,</b> i.e., crossbreeding; <b>and an animal with a wound that will cause it to die within twelve months [<i>tereifa</i>]; and</b> an animal born by <b>caesarean section.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “This,”</b> to exclude these disqualifications.
Rabbi Shimon elaborates: <b>And what did you see,</b> i.e., what is the reason <b>to include these</b> particular cases <b>and to exclude those</b> particular cases?

Daf 41a

Rabbi Shimon explains: <b>After the verse</b> both <b>included</b> some disqualified offerings in this principle <b>and excluded</b> others, <b>you should say: I include</b> in the items that should not be taken down if they had been placed on the altar <b>those whose disqualification</b> occurred <b>in the sacred</b> area, i.e., the Temple courtyard, in the course of the sacrificial service, e.g., an offering that was slaughtered at night, or whose blood spilled before sprinkling. <b>And I exclude those whose disqualification was not in the sacred</b> area, such as an animal that copulated with a person, as these animals were disqualified before their sacrificial process began. This concludes the <i>baraita</i>.
The Gemara explains how this <i>baraita</i> supports the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan. The <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches, in any event, that</b> an animal <b>born by caesarean section</b> is <b>not</b> fit for sacrifice. <b>What, is it not</b> referring to one who consecrates an animal born by <b>caesarean section</b> and renders it <b>a sacrificial</b> animal? Evidently, although Rabbi Shimon maintains that a human birth by caesarean section has the halakhic status of a regular birth, he concedes that animals born in this manner are unfit for sacrifice. <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Natan, said: No,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is dealing <b>with a firstborn</b> animal born by <b>caesarean section,</b> and it is this animal that is disqualified as an offering. A firstborn animal is sacred only if it emerged from the womb.
The Gemara objects to this interpretation of the <i>baraita</i>: How can it be referring to <b>a firstborn</b> animal? The <i>halakha</i> that firstborn status does not apply to an animal born by caesarean section is <b>derived from</b> the phrase <b>“opens the womb,”</b> which teaches that only animals born in the natural manner are endowed with the sanctity of firstborn animals and may be sacrificed on the altar. Since an animal born by caesarean section is not sacred at all, and it is clear that a non-sacred animal cannot be sacrificed upon the altar, it is obvious that the animal must be taken down if it was placed there in error.
The Gemara responds to this objection: <b>Rather, what</b> would you say? Would you say that the <i>baraita</i> is referring to an ordinary animal, not a firstborn, <b>that</b> had been consecrated as <b>a sacrificial</b> animal? But this animal is not sacred either, as <b>derived from</b> the verbal analogy of the term <b>“its mother”</b> stated with regard to the firstborn and the term <b>“its mother”</b> stated in connection with consecrated animals, as Rabbi Yoḥanan taught earlier. If one seeks to consecrate as an offering an animal that was born by caesarean section, it is not rendered sacred at all. Accordingly, the same reasoning applies as before: It is evident that a non-sacred animal may not be placed on the altar, and it must be removed if placed there in error.
The Gemara rejects this response: <b>What is this</b> comparison between firstborn animals and consecrated animals? <b>Granted, if you say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is referring to animals <b>that are consecrated</b> to be offerings, <b>that is why two verses are necessary: One</b> verse, the verbal analogy between consecrated animals and firstborn animals, teaches <b>that a non-sacred animal</b> whose mother <b>gave birth</b> to it <b>by caesarean section and</b> whose owner subsequently <b>consecrated it</b> as an offering is not sacred at all, and must therefore be removed from the altar if it was placed there in error.
<b>And one</b> verse: “This is the law of the burnt offering; that is the burnt offering that goes up on the pyre upon the altar” (Leviticus 6:2), teaches <b>with regard to a sacrificial animal that gave birth by caesarean section,</b> that although the offspring is sacred by virtue of its mother’s sanctity, it may not be sacrificed and must be removed from the altar if placed there in error. <b>And</b> the <i>tanna</i> of this <i>baraita</i> <b>maintains</b> that the <b>offspring of sacrificial animals are</b> automatically <b>sacred upon their emergence</b> from the womb. <b>But if you say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to a firstborn</b> animal that was born by caesarean section, the <i>halakha</i> that this animal is not sacred <b>is derived from</b> the phrase <b>“opens the womb.”</b>
The Gemara adds: <b>So too, it is reasonable</b> to interpret the <i>baraita</i> in this manner, that it is referring to an offspring born to a sacrificial animal by caesarean section, <b>from</b> the fact <b>that</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> that <b>an animal that copulated with a person, and an animal that was the object of bestiality, and</b> an animal <b>that</b> was <b>set aside</b> for idol worship, <b>and</b> an animal <b>that was worshipped</b> as a deity, <b>and</b> an animal that is an offspring of <b>diverse kinds,</b> must all be removed from the altar if placed there in error.
The Gemara explains: Now <b>are these</b> disqualifications <b>derived from here,</b> from the verse adduced by the <i>baraita</i>? No, they are <b>derived from elsewhere,</b> as taught in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “You shall bring your offering from the cattle, even from the herd or from the flock” (Leviticus 1:2). The expression <b>“from the cattle”</b> serves <b>to exclude</b> from eligibility as an offering <b>an animal that copulated with a person and an animal that was the object of bestiality.</b> The expression <b>“from the herd”</b> serves <b>to exclude</b> an animal <b>that was worshipped</b> as a deity. <b>“From the flock”</b> serves <b>to exclude</b> an animal <b>set aside</b> for idol worship. The word “or” in the expression <b>“or from the flock”</b> serves <b>to exclude</b> an animal <b>that gored</b> a person, killing him. In all these cases the animal cannot be consecrated at all, and therefore it is not necessary for the Torah to teach that they must be removed from the altar if placed there in error.
<b>And furthermore,</b> is the disqualification of an animal born of a mixture of <b>diverse kinds derived from here?</b> No, it is <b>derived from elsewhere,</b> as taught in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “When <b>a bull or a sheep or a goat</b> is born, it shall be seven days under its mother; but from the eighth day and onward it may be accepted for an offering” (Leviticus 22:27). The term <b>“a bull”</b> serves <b>to exclude</b> an offspring of <b>diverse kinds</b> from being used as an offering, The phrase <b>“or a goat”</b> serves <b>to exclude</b> an animal that <b>resembles</b> another, i.e., a sheep that is the offspring of sheep but that looks like a goat, or vice versa. Once again, as these animals cannot be consecrated at all, it is not necessary for the Torah to teach that they must be removed from the altar if placed there in error.
<b>Rather,</b> it must be that <b>two verses are necessary</b> for each of these cases: <b>One to</b> teach that <b>a non-sacred animal</b> that is subject to any of these disqualifications cannot be consecrated, <b>and</b> the other <b>one to</b> teach that with regard to <b>a sacrificial animal</b> that was born with this status by virtue of its mother’s sanctity, if it is subject to one of these disqualifications it may not be sacrificed and must be removed from the altar if placed there in error. Accordingly, it stands to reason that <b>here too,</b> in the case of an animal born by caesarean section, <b>two verses</b> are <b>necessary</b> for the same reason: One for a non-sacred animal, to teach that it cannot be consecrated, and another for the offspring of a sacrificial animal.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Although a woman who experiences a discharge of uterine blood after her menstrual period is rendered a <i>zava</i> and must count seven clean days before immersing and purifying herself, if a pregnant woman <b>experiences</b> birth <b>pangs</b> accompanied by bleeding for <b>three days</b> after her menstrual period, at the end of which she gives birth, she is not rendered a <i>zava</i>, as the bleeding is attributed to the childbirth. <b>And</b> if the <b>offspring emerged by caesarean section, she is</b> considered <b>one who has given birth during</b> a period of <b><i>ziva</i>. But Rabbi Shimon says: She is not</b> considered <b>one who has given birth during</b> a period of <b><i>ziva</i>. And</b> the <b>blood that emerges from there is ritually impure, but Rabbi Shimon deems</b> it <b>pure.</b>
The Gemara analyzes the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Granted, the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> is clear: <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> conforms <b>to his</b> line of <b>reasoning,</b> cited in the mishna, that birth via caesarean section has the halakhic status of childbirth; <b>and the Rabbis,</b> i.e., the first <i>tanna</i>, conform <b>to their</b> line of <b>reasoning,</b> that birth via caesarean section does not have the halakhic status of childbirth. <b>But</b> in <b>the latter clause, with regard to what</b> matter <b>do they disagree? Ravina said:</b> The latter clause is referring to a case <b>where the offspring emerged by caesarean section,</b>

Daf 41b

<b>and blood</b> emerged <b>through the womb,</b> i.e., vaginally, during the three days preceding the birth. <b>And Rabbi Shimon</b> conforms <b>to his</b> line of <b>reasoning,</b> that a caesarean birth is a full-fledged birth, and therefore the blood that emerged prior to the birth is ritually pure, <b>and the Rabbis</b> conform <b>to their</b> line of <b>reasoning,</b> that a caesarean birth is not halakhically considered a birth, which means that the blood which emerged beforehand is considered the blood of <i>ziva</i>, and is ritually impure.
<b>Rav Yosef objects to this</b> explanation: <b>One</b> difficulty is that according to this interpretation, the latter clause of the <i>baraita</i> is superfluous, <b>as</b> the dispute recorded there <b>is</b> identical to that of <b>the first clause. And furthermore,</b> the words: <b>From there,</b> in the phrase: The blood that emerges from there, <b>indicate</b> that this is referring to a place already mentioned in the <i>baraita</i>, i.e., the <b>place</b> from which the <b>offspring</b> emerged, which is the abdominal incision of the caesarean section, not the vagina.
<b>Rather, Rav Yosef said</b> that this is the explanation of the latter clause of the <i>baraita</i>: It is referring to a situation <b>where</b> both the <b>offspring and blood emerged through</b> the incision in the <b>abdomen.</b> It is in such a case that the first <i>tanna</i> deems the blood which emerged impure and Rabbi Shimon deems it pure.
<b>And</b> the matter <b>with regard to</b> which they <b>disagree</b> is whether or not <b>the location</b> of a woman’s <b>source,</b> i.e., her uterus, is ritually <b>impure.</b> One <b>Sage,</b> the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>holds</b> that <b>the location</b> of a woman’s <b>source</b> is ritually <b>impure,</b> and therefore any blood that emerges from it, regardless of how it came out of her body, is impure as well. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon, <b>holds</b> that <b>the location</b> of a woman’s <b>source</b> is <b>pure,</b> and blood that emerges from there is also pure. Only uterine blood which emerges vaginally is impure.
§ <b>Reish Lakish says: According to the statement of the one who deems the blood impure,</b> the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>he deems the woman impure</b> as well, as though it were blood of menstruation. Likewise, <b>according to the statement of the one who deems the blood pure,</b> Rabbi Shimon, <b>he deems the woman pure</b> as well. <b>But Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Even according to the statement of the one who deems the blood impure,</b> the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>he deems the woman pure.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan follows his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning</b> here, <b>as Rabbi Yoḥanan said in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai: From where</b> is it derived <b>that a woman does not become impure</b> due to menstruation <b>unless the flow</b> of blood <b>emerges from her nakedness,</b> i.e., genitalia? <b>As it is stated: “And a man who lies with a woman having her flow, and shall uncover her nakedness, he has made naked her source”</b> (Leviticus 20:18) This <b>teaches that a woman is not impure</b> due to menstruation <b>unless</b> the <b>flow emerges from her nakedness.</b>
<b>Reish Lakish says in the name of Rabbi Yehuda Nesia:</b> If a woman’s <b>source,</b> i.e., her uterus, <b>became dislodged and fell</b> out of her body <b>onto the ground, she is ritually impure, as it is stated: “Because your foundation was poured out, and your nakedness was uncovered”</b> (Ezekiel 16:36). The word “foundation” alludes to the uterus, and the verse is referring to it after it has been “poured out,” i.e., detached, as an uncovering of nakedness, which indicates that it is still a source of impurity even after it has been detached from its place.
The Gemara asks: <b>To what</b> kind of impurity is this woman subject in this situation? <b>If we say</b> that she is subject <b>to the impurity of seven</b> days of menstruating women, that is impossible, as <b>the Merciful One states</b> in the Torah that such impurity is caused by <b>“blood”</b> (Leviticus 15:19), <b>and not a piece</b> of flesh. <b>Rather,</b> she is subject <b>to impurity</b> that lasts until the <b>evening,</b> as a result of the surface of her body having come into contact with the uterus, which is a source of impurity.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> In the case of a woman’s <b>source that discharged two</b> whitish, clear, <b>pearl-like [<i>margaliyyot</i>] drops, she is impure.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>To what</b> kind of impurity is this woman subject in this situation? <b>If we say</b> that she is subject <b>to the impurity of seven</b> days of menstruating women, that is impossible, as the mishna (<i>Nidda</i> 19a) states that there are <b>five</b> distinct colors of <b>ritually impure blood in a woman, but no more,</b> and pearly white is not one of those colors. <b>Rather,</b> she is subject <b>to impurity</b> that lasts until the <b>evening,</b> as a result of her body having come into contact with a discharge from the uterus, which is a source of impurity. <b>And</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>specifically</b> if there were <b>two</b> drops, <b>but</b> if there was only <b>one</b> such drop she is not impure, as <b>I can say</b> that the drop <b>came from elsewhere,</b> not from the uterus.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>All women become ritually impure</b> with the flow of blood from the uterus <b>into the outer chamber,</b> i.e., the vagina, as it is stated: “And her issue in her flesh shall be blood” (Leviticus 15:19). The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> exactly <b>is the outer chamber? Reish Lakish says: Any</b> place <b>which can be seen when a little girl sits</b> with her legs spread. When the blood reaches that area in the vagina, the woman becomes ritually impure.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said to</b> Reish Lakish in objection: <b>That place is</b> considered <b>exposed</b> even <b>with regard to</b> contact with the carcass of a <b>creeping animal.</b> If one comes into contact with the carcass of a creeping animal he becomes impure. This is the <i>halakha</i> only if the animal touches a part of the body that is exposed, not an internal cavity such as the inside of the mouth. Since the area of the vagina described by Reish Lakish is considered an exposed part of the body for the purposes of the impurity imparted by the carcass of a creeping animal, it should not be necessary for the mishna to derive the <i>halakha</i> of her impurity from the expression “in her flesh.” <b>Rather, Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The term outer chamber extends <b>until</b> the area <b>between the teeth-</b>like projections inside the vagina.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: Is the area <b>between the teeth-</b>like projections itself considered <b>as internal,</b> which would mean that blood there would not render the woman impure, <b>or as external? Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution, <b>as Rabbi Zakkai teaches</b> a <i>baraita</i>: The term outer chamber extends <b>to</b> the area <b>between the teeth-</b>like projections, but the area <b>between the teeth-</b>like projections <b>themselves</b> is considered <b>as internal.</b>
<b>It was taught in a <i>baraita</i></b> that a woman becomes impure when the blood reaches the <b>place of threshing,</b> which is a euphemism. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of this euphemism, the <b>place of threshing? Rav Yehuda says:</b> It is referring to the <b>place</b> in the vagina <b>where the penis threshes,</b> i.e., reaches, during intercourse.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: It is written concerning a menstruating woman: “And if a woman has an issue, and her flow in her flesh shall be blood, she shall be in her menstruation seven days” (Leviticus 15:19). The term <b>“in her flesh” teaches that she becomes impure</b> while the blood is still <b>inside</b> her flesh just <b>as</b> when the blood emerges <b>outside</b> her body. <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that this applies in the case of <b>a menstruating woman. From where</b> is it derived that it applies to <b>a <i>zava</i></b> as well? <b>The</b> same <b>verse states: “Her flow [<i>zovah</i>] in her flesh.”</b>
<b>From where</b> is it derived that this also applies to a woman who <b>discharges semen</b> after intercourse? <b>The</b> same <b>verse states</b> the apparently superfluous term <b>“shall be.” And Rabbi Shimon says:</b> In the case of discharging semen, <b>it is sufficient for her</b> to be <b>like the man who engaged in intercourse with her: Just as the man who engaged in intercourse with her does not become impure until</b> the source of <b>impurity,</b> the semen, <b>emerges outside</b> his body, <b>so too, she does not become impure until her</b> source of <b>impurity,</b> the semen, <b>emerges outside</b> her body. It does not render her impure while it is still inside her body.
The Gemara asks: <b>And does Rabbi Shimon</b> in fact <b>hold</b> that <b>it is sufficient for her</b> to be <b>like the man who engaged in intercourse with her? But isn’t it taught</b> to the contrary in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “The woman also with whom a man shall lie carnally, <b>they shall both bathe themselves in water, and be impure until the evening”</b> (Leviticus 15:18). <b>Rabbi Shimon said: And what does this</b> verse <b>come to teach us? If</b> it teaches <b>with regard to</b> one who <b>comes into contact with semen</b> that they are impure, <b>it is already stated below</b> (Leviticus 22:4): <b>“Or a man</b> from whom the flow of seed goes out,” from which it is derived that coming into contact with semen renders one impure.
<b>Rather,</b> this verse is necessary <b>because</b> in the case of intercourse the contact with the source of <b>impurity</b> occurs in <b>a concealed part</b> of the body, <b>and</b> contact with <b>impurity</b> by <b>a concealed part</b> of the body generally <b>does not render</b> one <b>impure. But</b> here <b>it is a Torah edict</b> that the woman does become impure in this manner. This <i>baraita</i> proves that according to Rabbi Shimon a woman is rendered impure by semen even when it is inside her body.
The Gemara answers that this is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> this second <i>baraita</i> is dealing <b>with</b> a woman who <b>engages in intercourse,</b> whereas <b>there,</b> the first <i>baraita</i> is dealing <b>with</b> a woman who <b>discharges</b> semen after intercourse. It is only during the act of intercourse that a woman becomes impure due to the semen. If she later discharges semen, she does not become impure, according to Rabbi Shimon, until the semen leaves her body and touches her on the outside.
The Gemara objects: But in the case of a woman who <b>discharges</b> semen, one can <b>derive</b> that she is impure <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that she engaged in intercourse</b> prior to the discharge. The Gemara answers: Rabbi Shimon is referring to a case <b>where she immersed herself,</b> thereby purifying herself <b>from</b> the impurity <b>from her intercourse,</b> and she subsequently discharged semen.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is this to say that</b> in the case of a woman who <b>engages in intercourse it is sufficient for her</b> to simply immerse herself, and then she is <b>in</b> a state of <b>impurity</b> only until <b>evening? But didn’t Rava say:</b> A woman who <b>engages in intercourse is prohibited from partaking of <i>teruma</i>,</b> even if she is married to a priest, for <b>the entire three days</b> following the intercourse, <b>as it is impossible for her not to discharge</b> semen throughout this period, and <i>teruma</i> may not be consumed by one who is impure?
The Gemara answers: <b>Here we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where</b> others <b>immersed</b> the woman while she was still <b>in bed,</b> and she remained there. If she remains lying down, it is possible for her not to discharge semen following intercourse, and the immersion after intercourse purifies her. The Gemara asks: <b>By inference,</b> one can conclude <b>that when Rava said</b> that a woman is in a constant state of impurity for three days after intercourse, he was referring to a case <b>where she walked</b> to the ritual bath <b>by foot and immersed</b> herself. But if so, <b>perhaps while she was walking she released</b> all the semen in her body even before the three days were over, and therefore will not subsequently become impure.

Daf 42a

<b>And if you would say</b> that it is certainly possible that she released all the semen, but Rava’s concern was that <b>perhaps</b> some of it might have <b>remained, if so, he should have</b> said: <b>We are concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> some semen <b>remained</b> and will be discharged, rather than: It is impossible for her not to discharge semen throughout this period.
<b>Rather, according to Rava too,</b> this is referring even to a case <b>where</b> others <b>immersed her</b> while she was still <b>in bed</b> and she remained there for three days. <b>And</b> the contradiction is <b>not difficult: Here,</b> in the statement of Rava, he is referring to a woman <b>who turns around</b> in bed from side to side. It is therefore certain that she will discharge semen over the course of three days. <b>There,</b> in the statement of Rabbi Shimon, he is speaking of a woman lying in bed <b>who does not turn around</b> from side to side. Such a woman will not discharge semen at all.
<b>And</b> the statement of <b>Rava is referring to a verse</b> in the Torah, <b>and this</b> is what <b>he is saying: When the Merciful One writes</b> in the Torah, with regard to a man and woman who engaged in intercourse: <b>“They shall both bathe themselves in water, and be impure until the evening”</b> (Leviticus 15:18), which indicates that when evening comes the woman’s purification is complete, it is dealing with a case <b>where she</b> is in bed and <b>does not turn around</b> from side to side. <b>But</b> in a case <b>where she does turn around, she is prohibited from partaking of <i>teruma</i></b> for <b>the entire three days</b> following the intercourse, <b>as it is impossible for her not to discharge</b> semen throughout this period.
<b>Rav Shmuel bar Bisna asked Abaye:</b> With regard to a woman who <b>discharges semen, is her</b> status that of <b>one who experienced</b> an emission of an impure substance, <b>or is her</b> status that of <b>one who came into contact</b> with an impure substance?
The practical <b>difference</b> between these two possibilities is threefold: Whether or not the discharge <b>negates</b> her counting of seven clean days at the end of the <i>ziva</i> period, whether or not it <b>renders</b> her <b>impure by any amount, and</b> whether or not it <b>renders</b> her <b>impure</b> while still <b>inside</b> her body <b>as</b> it would after emerging <b>out</b> of her body. If it is considered an emission of an impure substance, it negates her count of seven clean days, and it renders her impure even in the slightest amount, and it renders her impure even before it emerges from her body. If it renders her impure because she came into contact with it, it does not negate her count, it renders her impure only if a certain minimum amount emerges, and it renders her impure only after touching the outside of her body.
Before addressing the dilemma, the Gemara raises a difficulty with Rav Shmuel bar Bisna’s question itself: <b>Whichever</b> way <b>you</b> look at it, the question is problematic. <b>If he had heard the <i>baraita</i></b> cited above, the answer is obvious: <b>According to the Rabbis, her status is</b> that of one who <b>experienced</b> an emission of an impure substance, as the <i>baraita</i> clearly states that in the Rabbis’ opinion the woman is rendered impure even before the semen emerges from her body. <b>And according to Rabbi Shimon, her status is</b> that of one who <b>came into contact with</b> the impure substance, as Rabbi Shimon states that the woman is impure only when the semen emerges from her body.
<b>And if</b> Rav Shmuel bar Bisna <b>did not hear the <i>baraita</i></b> and was unaware of it, it <b>is</b> certainly more <b>reasonable</b> to assume that <b>her</b> status should be that of one who <b>came into contact</b> with the semen. Why would he think otherwise, as after all, the emitted substance did not originate in her body?
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> Rav Shmuel bar Bisna <b>had heard the <i>baraita</i>, and he did not raise the dilemma according to</b> the opinion <b>of the Rabbis.</b> According to their opinion it is clear that the woman has the status of one who experienced an emission of an impure bodily substance. Rather, <b>when he raises the dilemma,</b> it is <b>according to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Shimon.</b>
<b>And he does not raise the dilemma with regard to</b> the question of whether or not the semen <b>renders</b> her <b>impure</b> when it is <b>inside</b> the body <b>as</b> it would after emerging <b>outside</b> the body, as Rabbi Shimon states explicitly that the woman is impure only when the semen leaves her body. Rather, <b>when he raises the dilemma,</b> it is only with regard to the other two issues mentioned above: Whether or not the discharge <b>negates</b> her counting of seven clean days at the end of the <i>ziva</i> period, <b>and</b> whether or not it <b>renders</b> her <b>impure in any amount.</b> He therefore asked: <b>What</b> is the status of her discharge of semen with respect to these two matters?
The Gemara explains the sides of the dilemma: It is possible that <b>when Rabbi Shimon says: It is sufficient for her</b> to be <b>like the man who engaged in intercourse with her, this statement</b> applies only with regard to the question of whether or not the semen <b>renders</b> her <b>impure</b> when it is <b>inside</b> the body <b>as</b> it would after emerging <b>outside</b> the body. It does not render her impure unless it touches her body on the outside. <b>But</b> with regard to the question of whether or not the discharge <b>negates</b> her counting of seven clean days at the end of the <i>ziva</i> period <b>and</b> whether or not it <b>renders</b> her <b>impure in any amount,</b> perhaps <b>she is</b> considered impure as one who <b>experienced</b> an emission of an impure substance. <b>Or perhaps</b> there <b>is no difference.</b> Rather, with regard to all three issues she has the status of one who came into contact with an impure substance.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> a different explanation of Rav Shmuel bar Bisna’s dilemma: <b>Actually, he did not hear the <i>baraita</i></b> and was unaware of it. <b>And</b> as for the question of why he would think that the woman should have the status of one who experienced an emission of an impure bodily substance, <b>this was his dilemma: Since the Merciful One was stringent</b> before the giving of the Torah <b>on</b> Mount <b>Sinai with regard to</b> men <b>who had experienced a seminal emission,</b> in that they were prohibited from attending that event, as it is stated: “Be ready on the third day; do not come near a woman” (Exodus 19:15), whereas those who had come into contact with other impure items were not prohibited from attending, perhaps the stringency of this particular source of impurity should likewise be applied to a woman who discharges semen. If so, <b>her</b> status should be like one who <b>experienced</b> a seminal emission, rather than one who merely came into contact with semen.
The Gemara explains the other side of the dilemma: <b>Or perhaps we should not derive</b> any <i>halakhot</i> <b>from</b> the instructions given before the revelation at <b>Sinai, as that</b> was <b>a novelty.</b> The Gemara cites a proof for this claim: <b>As</b> that was the case with regard to <b><i>zavin</i> and lepers, whose</b> impurity is even more <b>stringent</b> than that of one who experiences a seminal emission, <b>but</b> nevertheless <b>the Merciful One was not stringent with regard to them,</b> as He permitted them to attend the ceremony of the giving of the Torah.
After clarifying Rav Shmuel bar Bisna’s dilemma, the Gemara cites Abaye’s answer to him. Abaye <b>said to him:</b> The woman’s status <b>is</b> that of one who <b>experienced</b> an emission of semen. Rav Shmuel bar Bisna <b>came</b> and <b>asked Rava</b> the same question, and <b>he</b> too <b>said to him:</b> The woman’s status <b>is</b> that of one who <b>experienced</b> an emission. <b>He came before Rav Yosef,</b> and <b>he</b> too <b>said to him: Her</b> status <b>is</b> that of one who <b>experienced</b> an emission. Rav Shmuel bar Bisna <b>came back to Abaye</b> and <b>said to him: You are all spewing the same saliva.</b> None of you are teaching anything new, as you all repeat the same unsatisfactory answer.
Abaye <b>said to him: I said well to you,</b> i.e., my response was correct. <b>Rabbi Shimon says</b> that <b>it is sufficient for</b> the woman to be <b>like the man who engaged in intercourse with her only with regard to</b> the question of whether or not the semen <b>renders</b> her <b>impure</b> while still <b>inside</b> her body <b>as</b> it would after emerging <b>out</b> of her body. Rabbi Shimon rules that it does not render her impure until it touches her on the outside. <b>But with regard to</b> the other two issues, i.e., <b>negating</b> the woman’s count of seven clean days at the end of a <i>ziva</i> period <b>and rendering</b> her <b>impure in any amount,</b> Rabbi Shimon maintains that the woman’s status <b>is</b> that of one who <b>experienced</b> an emission. Therefore, the discharge negates her count and renders her impure by any amount.
§ The Gemara continues to discuss types of ritual impurity that apply whether the impure substance is still inside the body or has been discharged from it. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a menstruating woman, a <i>zava</i>,</b> a woman <b>who observes</b> a clean <b>day for a day</b> she experiences a discharge, <b>and a woman after childbirth, they all become impure</b> while the blood is still <b>inside</b> their bodies just <b>as</b> they would be when the blood emerges <b>outside</b> their bodies.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> with regard to <b>all those</b> other cases, <b>it is well,</b> i.e., one can understand this ruling with regard to blood that has not left the body. <b>But</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a woman after childbirth</b> is puzzling, since <b>if</b> this is referring to blood that she discharges <b>in</b> her <b>days of menstruation,</b> then she is <b>a menstruating woman,</b> and she is included in the earlier category. Likewise, <b>if</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to blood that she discharges <b>in</b> her <b>days of <i>ziva</i>,</b> she has the status of <b><i>ziva</i>,</b> and once again is included in a previously mentioned category.
The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> the mention of a woman after childbirth is <b>necessary</b> only in a case <b>where</b> the days of ritual impurity after childbirth, which are seven for a male and fourteen for a female, have passed, and the woman <b>descended to immerse</b> in a ritual bath in order to emerge <b>from</b> her status of <b>impurity to purity.</b>
<b>And</b> the <i>halakha</i> here is <b>like that which Rabbi Zeira said</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Ashi said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> In the case of <b>a woman after childbirth who descended to immerse</b> in a ritual bath in order to emerge <b>from</b> her status of <b>impurity to purity, and blood was uprooted from her</b> uterus but it did not leave her body, her status is as follows: If this occurred <b>on</b> her <b>descent</b> to the ritual bath, she remains <b>impure,</b> as the immersion is ineffective. If it happened <b>on</b> her <b>ascent</b> from the bath, she is <b>pure,</b> as her period of purity, which is thirty-three days for a male and sixty-six for a female, has commenced.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya said to Rabbi Zeira,</b> with regard to this <i>halakha</i>: If the blood emerged <b>on</b> her <b>descent</b> to immerse, <b>why</b> is she <b>impure?</b> After all, the blood <b>is</b> a substance of <b>impurity</b> that is <b>encapsulated</b> inside a body, and there is a <i>halakha</i> that an encapsulated source of impurity does not impart impurity to other items (see <i>Ḥullin</i> 71a). Rabbi Zeira <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yirmeya: <b>Go</b> and <b>ask Rabbi Avin, as I explained to him</b> the reason for this <i>halakha</i>, <b>and he nodded [<i>vekharkish</i>] his head to me</b> in <b>the study hall,</b> in affirmation of my explanation.
The Gemara relates that Rabbi Yirmeya indeed <b>went</b> and <b>asked</b> Rabbi Avin the reason, and Rabbi Avin <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yirmeya: The Sages <b>rendered</b> this blood <b>like the unslaughtered carcass of a kosher bird, which imparts impurity</b> even <b>to</b> the <b>garments</b> of the one who eats it, when there is an olive-bulk of it <b>in</b> his <b>throat,</b> despite the fact that this source of impurity is encapsulated in his body. Rabbi Yirmeya asked Rabbi Avin: <b>Are</b> these cases <b>comparable?</b> How can one compare the impurity of a woman after childbirth to the impurity of one who eats the unslaughtered carcass of a kosher bird?

Daf 42b

Rabbi Yirmeya elaborates: <b>There,</b> with regard to the impurity contracted by swallowing an unslaughtered bird carcass, this unusual type of impurity <b>does not have</b> an equivalent form of <b>impurity outside,</b> since if one merely touches an unslaughtered bird carcass, he and his garments remain pure. By contrast, <b>here,</b> with regard to the blood of a woman after childbirth, <b>let it become impure</b> only <b>when it emerges outside</b> her body, like all other items that impart impurity by contact once they are no longer encapsulated. Rather, due to this difficulty one must explain that <b>here too,</b> Rabbi Zeira is referring to a case <b>where</b> the blood <b>emerged outside</b> her body after her immersion; otherwise she remains pure.
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> the reason that the woman is pure is that the blood <b>emerged outside</b> her body, <b>what</b> is the purpose <b>of stating</b> this <i>halakha</i>? Certainly, this blood renders the woman impure upon contact. The Gemara answers that this ruling is necessary, <b>lest you say: Since</b> the woman’s <b>immersion is effective for</b> any <b>blood that is inside</b> her, i.e., it prevents that blood from rendering her impure, <b>let it also be effective for this</b> blood, which did not leave her body until after the immersion. Therefore, Rabbi Zeira <b>teaches us</b> that this is not the <i>halakha</i>.
The Gemara objects: <b>We have resolved our <i>halakha</i>,</b> the statement of Rabbi Zeira, <b>but</b> the difficulty remains with regard to the case of <b>a woman after childbirth.</b> In light of the explanation of Rabbi Zeira’s opinion, the <i>baraita</i> cited at the beginning of the discussion, which states that a woman after childbirth becomes impure by blood that is still inside her body, cannot be interpreted in accordance with his opinion, as Rabbi Zeira maintains that the blood does not render her impure unless it emerges outside her body. Accordingly, the original difficulty remains: <b>If</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to blood that she discharges <b>in</b> her <b>days of menstruation,</b> then she is <b>a menstruating woman,</b> and <b>if</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to her <b>days of <i>ziva</i>,</b> it has the status of <b><i>ziva</i>,</b> both are which are already listed in the <i>baraita</i>.
The Gemara explains: <b>Here we are dealing with a dry birth,</b> without the emission of blood, and the <i>baraita</i> is teaching that the woman is rendered impure despite the fact that no blood emerged. The Gemara asks: If the <i>baraita</i> is referring to <b>a dry birth, what</b> blood <b>is there</b> that <b>becomes impure</b> while still <b>inside</b> the woman’s body just <b>as</b> it would when emerging <b>outside</b> her body? There is no blood at all in the case of a dry birth.
The Gemara answers that this clause is not referring to blood; rather, this is a situation <b>where</b> the <b>offspring put his head out of the corridor,</b> in which case it is considered born and renders its mother impure, despite the fact that the rest of its body has not emerged. <b>And</b> this is <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Rav Oshaya, as Rav Oshaya said:</b> If a midwife inserted her hand into the womb of a woman whose fetus is dead, she is rendered impure due to contact with a corpse. This is a rabbinic <b>decree lest</b> the midwife touch it after <b>the offspring puts his head out of the corridor</b> and it dies afterward, in which case the fetus is considered born and therefore she would be ritually impure by Torah law.
The Gemara adds: <b>And</b> this is <b>similar to</b> an incident involving <b>a certain</b> man <b>who came before Rava</b> and <b>said to him: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to</b> whether one <b>may circumcise on Shabbat?</b> Rava <b>said to him:</b> One may <b>well</b> do so. <b>After</b> that man <b>left, Rava said</b> to himself, perplexed: Can it <b>enter your mind that that man did not know that</b> it is <b>permitted to circumcise on Shabbat,</b> and he approached me to inquire about such a basic matter? There must be an unstated aspect to his question. Rava therefore <b>went after him</b> and <b>said to him: Say to me, my friend [<i>izi</i>], how did the incident itself happen?</b>
The man <b>said to</b> Rava: <b>I heard</b> the <b>child making a noise at nightfall on Shabbat eve,</b> before Shabbat began, <b>but it was not born until Shabbat.</b> Rava <b>said to him: This is</b> a baby who <b>put his head out of the corridor,</b> as otherwise his voice would not have been heard. Consequently, it is considered born already on Friday, which means that it should be circumcised on the following Friday, the eighth day after its birth. <b>And</b> if it is circumcised afterward, this <b>is a circumcision</b> performed <b>not at its</b> appointed <b>time, and</b> there is a <i>halakha</i> that although circumcision on the eighth day overrides Shabbat, nevertheless, with regard to <b>any circumcision</b> performed <b>not at its</b> appointed <b>time, one does not desecrate Shabbat for its</b> performance.
§ <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: With regard to <b>that place in a woman,</b> i.e., her vagina, how is it defined? <b>Is</b> an impure substance located there considered <b>encapsulated, or is it</b> considered to be located in <b>a concealed part</b> of the body?
The Gemara explains: <b>What is the</b> practical <b>difference</b> as to whether it is considered encapsulated or concealed? The difference is in a case <b>where another</b> woman <b>inserted an olive-bulk of an animal carcass,</b> which is the size that imparts impurity, <b>into that place. If you say</b> that <b>it is</b> considered <b>encapsulated, an encapsulated</b> source of <b>impurity does not impart impurity. But if you say</b> that <b>it is</b> considered located in <b>a concealed part</b> of the body, <b>although</b> the woman <b>does not become impure by contact, she at least becomes impure by carrying</b> the olive-bulk of the carcass.
<b>Abaye said: It is</b> considered <b>encapsulated. Rava said: It is</b> considered located in <b>a concealed part</b> of the body. <b>Rava</b> further <b>said: From where do I say</b> this? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “The woman also with whom a man shall lie carnally, they shall both bathe themselves in water, and be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 15:18). Rabbi Shimon said: Now what does this verse teach? If it teaches that one who touches semen is rendered impure, this is derived from the verse: “Or a man from whom the flow of seed goes out” (Leviticus 22:4). <b>Rather,</b> it must be teaching that a woman who engages in intercourse is rendered impure by the man’s semen, despite the fact that the semen did not touch her on the outside of her body.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: This is a novelty <b>because</b> the semen <b>is</b> a source of <b>impurity</b> located in <b>a concealed part</b> of the body, <b>and</b> ordinarily contact with a source of <b>impurity</b> by <b>a concealed part</b> of the body <b>does not render</b> one <b>impure. But</b> here <b>it is a Torah edict</b> that the woman does become impure in this manner. Evidently, an impure substance in the vagina is considered located in a concealed part of the body.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Abaye,</b> how does he respond to Rava’s proof? The Gemara answers that Abaye would explain that the <i>tanna</i> of this <i>baraita</i>, Rabbi Shimon, <b>states one</b> reason <b>and</b> adds <b>another: One</b> reason <b>that</b> this <i>halakha</i> is a novelty is that semen in the vagina <b>is an encapsulated</b> substance of <b>impurity, and another</b> reason is that <b>even if you were to say</b> that the semen <b>is</b> considered located in <b>a concealed part</b> of the body, which ordinarily <b>does not render</b> one <b>impure, but</b> here, <b>it is a Torah edict</b> that the woman does become impure in this manner.
§ A similar <b>dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: With regard to the <b>place</b> in a person’s throat where <b>an unslaughtered carcass of a kosher bird</b> renders him ritually impure, how is it defined? <b>Is</b> the meat of the carcass considered <b>encapsulated, or is it</b> considered located in <b>a concealed part</b> of the body?
The Gemara explains: <b>What is the</b> practical <b>difference?</b> The difference is in a case <b>where another</b> individual <b>inserted an olive-bulk of an animal carcass into his mouth. If you say</b> that an impure item located in one’s throat <b>is</b> considered <b>encapsulated, an encapsulated</b> source of <b>impurity does not impart impurity.</b> But if <b>you say</b> that <b>it is</b> considered located in <b>a concealed part</b> of the body, <b>although</b> the one swallowing the meat of the carcass <b>indeed does not become impure by contact, he at least becomes impure by carrying</b> the meat.
Abaye and Rava disagree with regard to this issue as well. <b>Abaye said: It is</b> considered <b>encapsulated, and Rava said: It is</b> considered located in <b>a concealed part</b> of the body. <b>Abaye</b> further <b>said: From where do I say</b> that it is considered encapsulated? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>an animal carcass should impart impurity to garments</b> when it is <b>in</b> one’s <b>throat,</b> like an unslaughtered carcass of a kosher bird. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “That which dies of itself, or is torn of animals, he shall not eat to render himself impure through it”</b> (Leviticus 22:8).
The <i>baraita</i> continues: This verse, which is dealing with impurity through eating, applies to <b>that which has impurity only</b> by means of <b>its consumption,</b> i.e., an unslaughtered carcass of a kosher bird, which imparts impurity solely when it is in one’s throat. Therefore, the verse <b>excludes this</b> animal carcass from impurity by consumption, <b>as it is impure,</b> i.e., it imparts impurity, even <b>before one eats it,</b> by touch and carrying. This ruling, that other sources of impurity do not impart impurity in the throat, supports Abaye’s opinion that an item located in the throat is considered encapsulated, which is why it does not impart impurity.
The Gemara raises a difficulty with regard to the <i>baraita</i>: <b>And let it be derived</b> that an animal carcass imparts impurity to garments when it is in one’s throat <b>by an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>an unslaughtered carcass of a kosher bird,</b> in the following manner: <b>If an unslaughtered carcass of a kosher bird,</b> whose status is relatively lenient, <b>as it does not have impurity outside</b> the body, since if one touched it or carried it he is not rendered impure, and yet <b>it has impurity inside</b> the throat, then with regard to <b>this</b> animal carcass, whose status is more stringent, <b>as it does have impurity outside</b> the body, <b>is it not right that it</b> should <b>have impurity inside</b> the throat?
The Gemara answers that <b>the verse states:</b> “That which dies of itself, or is torn of animals, he shall not eat to become impure <b>through it,”</b> which indicates that one becomes impure when the item is in the throat only <b>through it,</b> i.e., an unslaughtered carcass of a kosher bird, <b>and not through another,</b> i.e., an animal carcass.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states</b> with regard to an animal carcass: <b>“And he who eats</b> of its carcass shall wash his clothes and be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 11:40), which indicates that an animal carcass does impart impurity by means of consumption?
The Gemara explains that this verse is written <b>to provide a measure</b> for the impurity of an animal carcass, but this measure applies only <b>to one who touches and to one who carries</b> it, not to one who eats the carcass. This measure is <b>like</b> the amount that one <b>eats. Just as</b> the minimum amount that one <b>eats</b> is <b>an olive-bulk,</b> i.e., this is the minimum measure that has the halakhic status of consumption, <b>so too,</b> the minimum measure of an animal carcass that imparts impurity to one who <b>touches or carries</b> it is <b>an olive-bulk.</b>
§ The Gemara further discusses the impurity of a concealed part of the body. <b>Rava says:</b> If the carcass of a <b>creeping animal</b> is found <b>in the folds [<i>bekometo</i>] of</b> one’s body, e.g., the armpit, he is <b>ritually pure.</b> If the flesh of <b>an animal carcass</b> is found <b>in the folds of</b> one’s body, he is <b>impure.</b>
Rava elaborates: If the carcass of a <b>creeping animal</b> is found <b>in the folds of</b> one’s body he is <b>ritually pure,</b> as <b>it is through contact that a creeping animal imparts impurity, and a concealed part</b> of the body <b>is not susceptible to</b> impurity through <b>contact.</b> By contrast, if the flesh of <b>an animal carcass</b> is found <b>in the folds of</b> one’s body he is <b>impure,</b> as <b>although it does not impart impurity through contact,</b> since it is in a concealed part of the body, <b>it at least imparts impurity by carrying,</b> and he is considered to be carrying the animal carcass.
Rava further said: If there was the carcass of <b>a creeping animal in the folds of</b> one’s body, <b>and he brought</b> the creeping animal that was in the fold <b>into the airspace of</b> a large earthenware vessel, such as <b>an oven,</b> the oven is thereby rendered <b>impure,</b> as is the <i>halakha</i> when a creeping animal is placed in its airspace. The Gemara asks: Isn’t this <b>obvious?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say</b> that as <b>the Merciful One states</b> with regard to the impurity of creeping animals: “And any earthenware vessel into <b>whose interior</b> any of them fall, whatever is in it shall be impure, and it you shall break” (Leviticus 11:33), this teaches that impurity applies only if the creeping animal fell inside the vessel itself,

Daf 43a

<b>and not</b> if it was in <b>the interior of its interior,</b> i.e., contained within something else, such as a fold, which is inside the vessel, therefore Rava <b>teaches us</b> that a fold in one’s body is not considered like the interior of the interior of a vessel. Rather, this definition applies only when the carcass of the creeping animal was actually inside another vessel whose opening was outside the oven.
§ The Gemara continues to discuss the folds in the body with regard to ritual impurity. <b>Reish Lakish says:</b> If there was <b>a pole</b> or a stick placed <b>in the folds of</b> an individual impure with the impurity of <b>a <i>zav</i>, and he moved a ritually pure</b> person <b>with it,</b> that individual is <b>pure,</b> despite the fact that a <i>zav</i> imparts impurity by moving an item. If the <b>pole</b> was placed <b>in the folds of one who is pure, and he moved the <i>zav</i> with it,</b> the pure individual is thereby rendered <b>impure,</b> as is the <i>halakha</i> of one who carries a <i>zav</i>.
The Gemara explains: <b>What is the reason</b> that if a <i>zav</i> moved another with a pole in his own folds he does not render the other person impure? <b>As the verse states: “And whoever a <i>zav</i> touches, without having rinsed his hands in water,</b> he shall wash his clothes, and bathe himself in water” (Leviticus 15:11). <b>This is</b> referring to the impurity imparted by <b>the movement of a <i>zav</i>, as we have not found an impurity</b> similar <b>to it in the entire Torah.</b> Only a <i>zav</i> imparts impurity to items by moving them.
<b>And the Merciful One expresses</b> this impurity imparted <b>by</b> movement using <b>the language of touch,</b> in order <b>to say that</b> the <b>moving and touch</b> of a <i>zav</i> <b>are like his hands: Just as there,</b> with regard to the impurity imparted by contact with the hands, it occurs <b>external</b> to the body, <b>so too here,</b> impurity by means of movement applies only to moving an item with the <b>external</b> portions of the body of the <i>zav</i>.
§ The mishna teaches that a woman becomes ritually impure with the flow of blood from the uterus into the vagina, even if it did not leave the woman’s body. <b>But the <i>zav</i> and one who experiences a seminal emission do not become ritually impure</b> until their emission of impurity emerges outside the body. The Gemara explains: This is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a <i>zav</i>, as it is written: “When</b> any man <b>has an issue out of his flesh”</b> (Leviticus 15:2). The verse teaches that a <i>zav</i> is not impure <b>until his issue emerges out of his flesh.</b> With regard to <b>one who experiences a seminal emission,</b> the reason is <b>that it is written: “And if the flow of seed goes out from a man”</b> (Leviticus 15:16), which indicates that the flow must exit his body.
§ The mishna further states that if a priest <b>was partaking of <i>teruma</i> and sensed</b> a quaking in his limbs, indicating that a seminal emission was imminent, he should firmly hold his penis to prevent the emission from leaving his body, and swallow the <i>teruma</i> while ritually pure. The Gemara asks: May one <b>hold</b> his penis? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: Anyone who holds</b> his <b>penis and urinates</b> is considered <b>as though he is bringing a deluge to the world,</b> as masturbation was one of the sins that led to the flood?
<b>Abaye said,</b> in resolution of this difficulty, that the mishna is referring to one who holds his penis <b>with a coarse cloth. Rava said: You</b> may <b>even say</b> that the mishna is referring to a priest who holds his penis <b>with a soft cloth,</b> and the reason it is permitted is that <b>once</b> the semen <b>has</b> already <b>been uprooted</b> from his body, it is <b>uprooted,</b> and his subsequent holding of the penis, even with a soft cloth, does not increase the flow of semen. <b>And Abaye</b> prohibits the use of a soft cloth, as he is <b>concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> one might <b>come to increase</b> the emission of semen, due to the contact of this cloth. <b>But Rava is not concerned</b> that one might <b>come to increase</b> the emission.
The Gemara raises a difficulty with regard to the opinion of Rava. <b>Isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>To what is this</b> holding of a penis <b>comparable?</b> It is comparable <b>to</b> one who <b>places a finger in</b> his <b>eye,</b> in <b>that as long as</b> the <b>finger</b> is <b>in the eye,</b> the eye <b>will tear and continue to tear.</b> Here too, the priest’s action will lead to an increased emission of semen.
The Gemara answers that <b>Rava</b> would maintain that if the priest’s limbs were not quaking and the semen was coming out in drops, there is indeed a concern that holding the penis might increase the emission. But when he feels his limbs quaking, this concern does not apply. The reason is that <b>any</b> such event, i.e., <b>a heating</b> of the body that leads to a seminal emission <b>and</b> which is <b>then</b> followed by another <b>heating</b> of that kind <b>at the time</b> when the semen has been uprooted, is <b>uncommon.</b> Consequently, in this case the priest may hold his penis even with a soft cloth.
<b>Shmuel says: Any</b> emission of <b>semen that is not felt by one’s entire body does not render</b> him <b>impure. What is the reason? The Merciful One states: “The flow of seed”</b> (Leviticus 15:16), which indicates that it is referring to an emission <b>that is fit to fertilize,</b> i.e., it is referring only to the kind of emission which is felt as it exits the body.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a mishna (<i>Mikvaot</i> 8:3): If one <b>was having</b> sexual <b>thoughts at night and he arose and found</b> that <b>his flesh</b> was <b>warm, he is ritually impure,</b> despite the fact that he did not sense the emission of semen. This shows that the impurity of a seminal emission applies even if one did not feel it in his entire body. The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Huna interpreted</b> this mishna as referring <b>to</b> one who <b>engaged in intercourse in his dream. Since it is impossible to engage in intercourse without</b> the accompanying <b>sensation,</b> he certainly must have felt it, despite the fact that he was unaware of this when he awoke.
The Gemara cites <b>another version</b> of the above statement. <b>Shmuel says: Any semen that is not shot like an arrow does not render</b> one <b>impure.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> practical difference <b>is there between this version</b> of Shmuel’s ruling <b>and that version</b> of Shmuel’s ruling? The Gemara answers that the difference <b>between them</b> is a case where the semen <b>was uprooted</b> accompanied <b>by a sensation, but it emerged without a sensation.</b> According to the first version the man is rendered impure, as he sensed the uprooting of the semen, whereas according to the second version he is not impure, as this is not considered semen shot like an arrow.
The Gemara notes that this <b>matter, which</b> is <b>obvious to Shmuel, is raised as a dilemma by Rava. As Rava raises a dilemma:</b> If semen <b>was uprooted</b> accompanied <b>by a sensation but it emerged without a sensation, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is the man ritually impure or not?
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a mishna (<i>Mikvaot</i> 8:3): With regard to <b>one who experienced a seminal emission,</b> and <b>who</b> subsequently <b>immersed but did not urinate</b> before doing so, <b>when he</b> later <b>urinates</b> he is rendered <b>impure,</b> as some semen will also be emitted. The reason that he is rendered impure by this emission, which he does not sense, must be because the uprooting of the semen was accompanied by a sensation. The Gemara refutes this proof: <b>There it is different, as the majority</b> of the semen <b>emerged</b> accompanied <b>by a sensation,</b> and therefore he is rendered impure by this small amount even without a sensation.
<b>Some say another version</b> of the previous discussion. <b>Shmuel says: Any semen that is not shot like an arrow cannot fertilize,</b> i.e., impregnate a woman. The Gemara infers: <b>It cannot fertilize, but it does render</b> the man who emits it <b>ritually impure, as it is stated: “If there be among you any man who is not ritually pure by reason of that which happened to him</b> by night” (Deuteronomy 23:11). This teaches that <b>even mere semen</b> which cannot fertilize renders one impure.
<b>Rava raises</b> a similar <b>dilemma:</b> With regard to <b>a gentile who had</b> sexual <b>thoughts,</b> on account of which semen was uprooted but not emitted from his body, <b>and he</b> subsequently <b>descended and immersed</b> for the purpose of conversion, which means that he is now Jewish, and he then emitted semen, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to his status of ritual purity?
The Gemara explains the dilemma: Even <b>if you say</b> that <b>we follow</b> the moment of <b>uprooting,</b> at which point he was still a gentile, one can maintain that <b>this statement</b> applies only when it entails <b>a stringency,</b> as is the case with regard to a born Jew. <b>But here, where</b> this would lead <b>to a leniency,</b> as the gentile would be ritually pure, perhaps <b>we do not say</b> that one follows the moment of uprooting. <b>Or perhaps</b> there <b>is no difference</b> in the application of this principle between a born Jew and a convert, but rather, one always follows the moment of uprooting. The Gemara concludes that the dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rava raises</b> a further <b>dilemma:</b> With regard to <b>a woman who experienced a discharge of uterine blood after her menstrual period [<i>zava</i>], whose urine,</b> which imparts impurity like all liquids that she discharges vaginally, <b>was uprooted</b> but not emitted from her body, <b>and she descended</b> to the ritual bath <b>and immersed</b> to purify herself from her <i>ziva</i>, and urinated afterward, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
The Gemara explains the sides of the dilemma: Even <b>if you say</b> that generally <b>we follow</b> the moment of <b>uprooting,</b> and therefore she should be impure, since the urine was uprooted when she was a <i>zava</i>, nevertheless one can claim that <b>this statement</b> applies only with regard to <b>semen, as</b> the man <b>cannot hold it</b> back from emission. <b>But</b> with regard to the <b>urine of</b> a <i>zava</i>, <b>which she can hold in,</b> one does <b>not</b> follow the moment of uprooting. <b>Or perhaps</b> there <b>is no difference</b> in the application of this principle between urine and semen, but rather, in both cases one follows the moment of uprooting. Here too, the Gemara concludes that the dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rava raises</b> yet another <b>dilemma:</b> With regard to <b>a gentile <i>zava</i>,</b> who is not impure by Torah law, although by rabbinic law she is considered a <i>zava</i> in all regards, <b>whose urine was uprooted</b> when she was a gentile,

Daf 43b

<b>and she descended</b> to the ritual bath <b>and immersed</b> for the sake of conversion, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
Once again, the Gemara explains the dilemma: <b>If you say</b> that <b>we follow</b> the moment of <b>uprooting even though she can hold in</b> the urine, nevertheless one can claim that <b>this statement</b> applies specifically to <b>a Jewish woman, who is impure by Torah law. But</b> with regard to <b>a gentile <i>zava</i>, who is impure by rabbinic law,</b> it is possible that one does <b>not</b> follow the moment of uprooting. <b>Or perhaps</b> there <b>is no difference</b> in the application of this principle between the case of a Jewish woman and a gentile woman, as in both cases one follows the moment of uprooting. The Gemara again concludes that the dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ The mishna teaches that the emission of a <i>zav</i> and a seminal emission <b>impart impurity in any amount. Shmuel says:</b> In order for <b>a <i>zav</i></b> to become ritually impure, he <b>must</b> experience a discharge substantial enough <b>to</b> cause <b>a blockage of the tip of the penis, as it is stated:</b> “And this shall be his impurity in his issue: Whether his flesh run with his issue, <b>or his flesh be stopped from his issue,</b> it is his impurity” (Leviticus 15:3).
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna that the emission of a <i>zav</i> and a seminal emission <b>impart impurity in any amount?</b> The Gemara answers that Shmuel <b>said</b> his ruling <b>in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Natan, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Natan says in the name of Rabbi Yishmael:</b> In order for <b>a <i>zav</i></b> to become ritually impure, he <b>must</b> experience a discharge substantial enough <b>to</b> cause <b>a blockage of the tip of the penis, but</b> the Rabbis <b>did not concede to his</b> opinion, as they maintain that any amount is sufficient. The <i>tanna</i> of the mishna agrees with the opinion of the Rabbis, whereas Shmuel agrees with the statement of Rabbi Natan in the name of Rabbi Yishmael.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yishmael,</b> i.e., what is the source in the Torah for his ruling? The Gemara answers: His source is, as mentioned above, <b>that the verse states:</b> “And this shall be his impurity in his issue: Whether his flesh run with his issue, <b>or his flesh be stopped from his issue,</b> it is his impurity” (Leviticus 15:3). This verse indicates that the emission must be enough to cause a blockage of his penis.
The Gemara asks: <b>And the Rabbis,</b> who disagree with Rabbi Yishmael, what do they derive from this verse? The Gemara explains that according to the Rabbis, <b>that</b> verse <b>is necessary</b> to teach a different <i>halakha</i> with regard to a <i>zav</i>, that it is only a discharge which is <b>moist,</b> and which therefore could cause a blockage of the organ, that <b>imparts impurity, but a dry</b> discharge does <b>not impart impurity.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> from where does <b>Rabbi Yishmael</b> derive that only a moist discharge imparts impurity? The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>is derived from</b> the word <b>“run”</b> in the verse “And this shall be his impurity in his issue: Whether his flesh run with his issue.”
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what do <b>the Rabbis</b> derive from this word? The Gemara explains that according to the Rabbis, <b>that</b> verse <b>comes to</b> teach the <b>number</b> of emissions by which a <i>zav</i> is rendered impure, as follows: The term <b>“his issue”</b> is <b>one</b> emission, the term <b>“his flesh run”</b> is another emission so that there are <b>two</b> emissions, and the term <b>“with his issue”</b> makes a total of <b>three</b> emissions. The verse thereby <b>teaches with regard to a <i>zav</i> who experienced three emissions that</b> he <b>is obligated to</b> bring <b>an offering</b> as part of his purification process.
The Gemara continues: From the last section of the verse: <b>“Or his flesh be stopped from his issue,</b> it is his <b>impurity,”</b> it is derived that one is <b>impure</b> even by means of <b>part of his issue,</b> i.e., even if he did not experience three emissions. Here the verse <b>teaches with regard to a <i>zav</i> who experienced two emissions that</b> although he is not obligated to bring an offering, he <b>renders</b> a surface designated for <b>lying and</b> a surface designated for <b>sitting ritually impure</b> by lying or sitting on them, even without touching them directly. The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Yishmael, from where does he</b> derive this <i>halakha</i> of the requisite <b>number</b> of emissions? The Gemara answers that <b>he derives it from that</b> which <b>Rabbi Simai</b> said.
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Simai says: The verse enumerated two</b> emissions <b>and called</b> the <i>zav</i> <b>impure:</b> “When any man has an emission out of his flesh, due to his issue he is impure” (Leviticus 15:2). And yet, another verse enumerates <b>three</b> emissions <b>and it</b> too <b>called him impure:</b> “And this shall be his impurity in his emission: Whether his flesh runs with his emission, or his flesh be stopped from his emission, it is his impurity” (Leviticus 15:3). <b>How</b> can <b>these</b> verses be reconciled? If one is impure after two emissions, for what purpose does the Torah mention three? It is to teach that <b>two</b> emissions are necessary <b>to</b> establish <b>impurity, and three</b> are necessary <b>to</b> render a <i>zav</i> liable to bring <b>an offering.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to the one who derives both</b> the <i>halakha</i> of impurity and the obligation to bring an offering <b>from</b> the single verse: “And <b>this shall be his impurity in his issue,” what do they,</b> i.e., the Rabbis, <b>do with</b> the other verse: <b>“When any man has an emission out of his flesh”?</b> The Gemara answers that this verse is <b>necessary</b> to teach the <i>halakha</i> that a <i>zav</i> is not impure <b>unless</b> the discharge <b>emerges from his flesh.</b>
The Gemara further asks: <b>Why do I</b> need the last part of the previous verse, which can be read as: <b>His issue is impure</b> (Leviticus 15:2)? The Gemara explains that this <b>teaches with regard to the issue</b> itself <b>that it is impure,</b> i.e., not only does it render the man who emitted it impure, but the substance itself is impure and imparts impurity to others by contact.
§ With regard to the statement of the mishna that the issue of the <i>zav</i> and a seminal emission render them impure in any amount, <b>Rav Ḥanilai says in the name of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon: Semen</b> imparts impurity <b>to</b> the man who <b>emits</b> it <b>in any amount,</b> whereas <b>with regard to one who touches</b> semen, it imparts impurity only <b>in</b> the amount of <b>a lentil-bulk.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna that the emission of a <i>zav</i> and a seminal emission <b>impart impurity in any amount? What, is it not</b> referring to <b>one who touches</b> semen? The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> the mishna is referring <b>to</b> the man who <b>emits</b> it.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a <i>baraita</i>: There is an element of <b>stringency</b> which applies <b>to</b> the impurity of <b>semen that</b> does not apply <b>to</b> the impurity of the carcass of <b>a creeping animal, and</b> likewise there is an element of <b>stringency</b> which applies <b>to</b> the impurity of the carcass of <b>a creeping animal that</b> does not apply <b>to</b> the impurity of <b>semen.</b> The <i>baraita</i> elaborates: The <b>stringency</b> which applies <b>to</b> the carcass of <b>a creeping animal</b> but not to semen is <b>that</b> with regard to the carcass of <b>a creeping animal there is no differentiation in its impurity, which is not the case with regard to semen,</b> as certain types of semen impart impurity while others do not. The <b>stringency</b> which applies <b>to semen</b> but not to the carcass of a creeping animal is <b>that semen imparts impurity in any amount, which is not the case with regard to</b> the carcass of <b>a creeping animal,</b> which must be at least a lentil-bulk.
The Gemara analyzes this <i>baraita</i>: <b>What, is it not</b> referring <b>to one who touches</b> semen, and the <i>baraita</i> rules that he is rendered impure by any amount? The Gemara again answers: <b>No,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is speaking <b>of</b> the man who <b>emits</b> semen, whereas one who touches it becomes impure only if it is at least as large as a lentil-bulk.
The Gemara raises a difficulty with regard to this answer: <b>But</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> the case of semen as <b>similar to</b> that of the carcass of <b>a creeping animal,</b> which indicates that <b>just as</b> the impurity of the carcass of <b>a creeping animal</b> is imparted <b>by contact, so too,</b> the impurity discussed in the <i>baraita</i> with regard to <b>semen</b> is imparted <b>by contact. Rav Adda bar Ahava said</b> in response: The <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches the category of</b> the carcass of <b>a creeping animal, and</b> it likewise <b>teaches the category of semen,</b> i.e., it is referring to these types of impurity in general, but this does not mean that these types of impurity are contracted in the same manner.
The Gemara asks: <b>And does</b> the carcass of <b>a creeping animal not impart impurity in any amount? But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Oholot</i> 1:7): <b>The limbs</b> of impure bodies that are whole <b>have no</b> minimum <b>measure</b> with regard to imparting ritual impurity. Even if a limb is <b>less than an olive-bulk of</b> a human <b>corpse, or less than an olive-bulk of an animal carcass, or less than a lentil-bulk of</b> the carcass of <b>a creeping animal,</b> it imparts ritual impurity. If so, how can the <i>baraita</i> state that there is a minimum measure of a lentil-bulk with regard to the impurity of a creeping animal?
