The Gemara answers that the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a limb is different, as</b> when <b>all of it</b> is intact <b>it stands in place of a lentil</b>-bulk, i.e., a whole limb is considered like a lentil-bulk of the carcass of a creeping animal, regardless of its actual size. The proof is <b>that if</b> it were <b>lacking</b> any slight <b>bit,</b> thereby causing this <b>limb</b> of a creeping animal to be less than a lentil-bulk, <b>would it impart impurity?</b> Certainly not. Clearly, then, the impurity of a limb is due to its wholeness, not its size.
The <i>baraita</i> teaches: The stringency that applies to the carcass of a creeping animal but not to semen is that with regard to a creeping animal there is no differentiation concerning its impurity, which is not the case with regard to semen. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the differentiation</b> with regard to <b>the impurity of semen? If we say</b> that this is referring to the difference <b>between</b> the semen of <b>Jews,</b> to which this impurity applies, <b>and</b> the semen <b>of gentiles,</b> to which it does not apply, <b>there is also</b> a differentiation with regard to the impurity of the carcass of a creeping animal between <b>a sea mouse,</b> which is not impure, and <b>a land mouse,</b> which is impure.
<b>Rather,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to the differentiation <b>between</b> the emission of <b>a minor,</b> which is not classified as semen and which does not render him impure, <b>and</b> that of <b>an adult,</b> which does render him impure. By contrast, there is no such differentiation with regard to the impurity of the carcass of a creeping animal, as it imparts impurity regardless of its age and size.
§ <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> The amount of semen which imparts impurity to one who touches it is <b>subject to</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> as it is stated in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that</b> the Torah <b>includes one who touches semen,</b> in addition to one who emits semen, as impure? <b>The verse states</b> with regard to the impurity of the carcass of a creeping animal: <b>“Or whoever</b> touches any creeping animal, whereby he may become impure” (Leviticus 22:5). It is inferred from the inclusive phrase “or whoever” that one who touches semen is also impure.
<b>And in general, <i>tanna’im</i> disagree</b> with regard to the possibility of deriving a <i>halakha</i> in this manner. <b>As some say</b> with regard to a <i>halakha</i> that is inferred from another <i>halakha</i>: <b>Infer from it, and</b> derive the details of the <i>halakha</i> <b>from it</b> as well. <b>And some say</b> with regard to such a <i>halakha</i>: <b>Infer from it, but interpret</b> the <i>halakha</i> according <b>to its</b> own <b>place,</b> i.e., not all aspects of the source case are applied to this <i>halakha</i>.
The Gemara explains how this general dispute applies to the case at hand. <b>According to the one who says</b> that one <b>infers from it and</b> again <b>from it,</b> the derivation is as follows: <b>Just as</b> the carcass of <b>a creeping animal</b> imparts impurity <b>by contact, so too, semen</b> imparts impurity <b>by contact. And</b> one again infers <b>from</b> the impurity of the carcass of a creeping animal that <b>just as</b> the carcass of <b>a creeping animal</b> imparts impurity <b>in</b> the amount of <b>a lentil-bulk, so too, semen</b> imparts impurity <b>in</b> the amount of <b>a lentil-bulk.</b>
<b>And according to the one who says: Infer from it, but interpret</b> the <i>halakha</i> according <b>to</b> its own <b>place,</b> one derives as follows: <b>Just as</b> the carcass of <b>a creeping animal</b> imparts impurity <b>by contact, so too, semen</b> imparts impurity <b>by contact. But</b> one must <b>interpret</b> the <i>halakha</i> according <b>to</b> its own <b>place: Just as semen</b> imparts impurity <b>to the one who emits</b> it <b>in any amount, so too,</b> it imparts impurity <b>to the one who touches</b> it <b>in any amount.</b>
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Natan, said to Rav Pappa: From where</b> do you infer <b>that</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>derives</b> the impurity of one who touches semen <b>from</b> the phrase <b>“or whoever”</b> that is stated with regard to the impurity <b>of</b> the carcass of <b>a creeping animal? Perhaps he derives it from</b> the previous verse: <b>“Or from whoever the flow of seed goes out”</b> (Leviticus 22:4), <b>and everyone</b> agrees that when a <i>halakha</i> is derived from a verse dealing with the same matter, one should <b>infer from it and</b> derive the details of the <i>halakha</i> <b>from it</b> as well. If so, the amount of semen that imparts impurity by contact should be derived from the amount that renders the one who emitted it impure, which is any amount.
The Gemara relates that the Sages <b>asked the <i>tanna’im</i>,</b> i.e., those who recite <i>mishnayot</i> and <i>baraitot</i>, whether the derivation of the <i>baraita</i> is from the verse dealing with the carcass of a creeping animal or from the one dealing with semen. They discovered that <b>there are those who teach</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the assumption of <b>Rav Pappa,</b> that it is derived from a creeping animal, <b>and there are those who teach</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Natan,</b> that the source is the verse referring to semen.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A baby girl,</b> even one who is <b>one day old,</b> who experiences an emission of blood, <b>becomes impure with</b> the impurity of <b>a menstruating woman.</b> A baby girl who is <b>ten days old</b> who experiences an emission of blood for three consecutive days after the conclusion of the seven days fit for menstruation <b>becomes impure with</b> the impurity of <b><i>ziva</i>,</b> and is therefore obligated to observe seven clean days before immersion.
<b>A baby boy,</b> even one who is <b>one day old, becomes impure with</b> the impurity of <b><i>ziva</i>; and becomes impure with</b> the impurity of <b>leprous marks; and becomes impure with impurity</b> imparted by <b>a corpse; and he creates</b> a levirate bond requiring the widow of his childless brother <b>to</b> enter into <b>levirate marriage</b> with him; <b>and he exempts</b> his widowed mother <b>from the</b> obligation of <b>levirate marriage,</b> freeing her to marry anyone she chooses; <b>and he enables</b> his mother, an Israelite woman who is no longer married to his father, a priest, to continue <b>to partake of <i>teruma</i>; and he disqualifies</b> his mother, the daughter of a priest who is no longer married to his father, an Israelite man, <b>from</b> continuing to partake of <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> because the child is unfit to partake of <i>teruma</i>;

Daf 44a

<b>and he inherits</b> the estate of his mother if she died on the day of his birth; <b>and</b> if he dies, <b>he bequeaths</b> that inheritance to his paternal brothers; <b>and one who kills him is liable</b> for his murder, as it is written: “And he that smites any man mortally shall be put to death” (Leviticus 24:17), i.e., any man, including a child who is one day old; <b>and</b> if he dies, <b>his</b> status in relation <b>to his father and to his mother and to all his relatives,</b> in terms of the <i>halakhot</i> of mourning, is <b>like</b> that of <b>a full-fledged groom [<i>keḥatan shalem</i>],</b> whose death is deeply mourned.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>From where is this matter,</b> that the <i>halakhot</i> of menstruation apply even to a one-day-old baby girl, derived? <b>As the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “And if a woman has an issue, and her issue in her flesh is blood, she shall be in her impurity seven days” (Leviticus 15:19). When the verse states <b>“a woman,” I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that the <i>halakhot</i> of menstruation apply to an adult <b>woman. From where</b> do I derive that the impurity <b>of a menstruating woman</b> also applies to <b>a one-day-old</b> baby? <b>The verse states: “And a woman,”</b> to include even a baby girl.
The mishna further teaches that a baby girl who is <b>ten days old</b> who experiences an emission of blood for three consecutive days after the conclusion of the seven days fit for menstruation, becomes impure with the impurity <b>of <i>ziva</i>.</b> Again, the Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>As the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “And if a woman has an issue of her blood many days not in the time of her menstruation…she shall be as in the days of her menstruation: She is impure” (Leviticus 15:25). When the verse states <b>“a woman,” I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that the <i>halakhot</i> of a <i>zava</i> apply to an adult <b>woman. From where</b> do I derive that the impurity <b>of <i>ziva</i></b> also applies to <b>a ten-day-old</b> baby? <b>The verse states: “And a woman,”</b> to include even a baby girl.
The mishna further teaches that <b>a baby boy,</b> even one who is <b>one day old,</b> can become impure with the impurity of <i>ziva</i>. Once again, the Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>As the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to a <i>zav</i>: “When <b>any man</b> has an issue out of his flesh, his issue is impure” (Leviticus 15:2). It would have been enough for the verse to state “a man.” <b>Why</b> must <b>the verse state “any man”?</b> It is in order <b>to include</b> even <b>a one-day-old</b> baby boy who has such a discharge, to teach <b>that he becomes impure with</b> the impurity of <b><i>ziva</i>.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, says</b> that this derivation <b>is not necessary, as</b> the verse <b>states: “And of those who have an issue, whether it be a male or a female”</b> (Leviticus 15:33). The phrase <b>“whether it be a male”</b> includes <b>anyone</b> who is a male, <b>whether</b> he is <b>an adult</b> or <b>whether</b> he is <b>a minor; “or a female”</b> includes <b>anyone</b> who is a female, <b>whether</b> she is <b>an adult</b> or <b>whether</b> she is <b>a minor. If so, why</b> must <b>the</b> earlier <b>verse state “any man”? The Torah spoke in the language of people,</b> i.e., this emphasis is not unusual and therefore one should not derive a <i>halakha</i> from the superfluous word.
The mishna teaches: <b>And</b> a one-day-old baby <b>becomes impure with</b> the impurity of <b>leprous marks.</b> The Gemara explains that this is derived from that <b>which is written</b> with regard to leprous marks: <b>“When a person shall have in the skin of his flesh”</b> (Leviticus 13:2). This serves to include <b>anyone who is a person,</b> irrespective of age.
The mishna further teaches: <b>And</b> a one-day-old baby <b>becomes impure with impurity</b> imparted by <b>a corpse.</b> The Gemara explains that this is derived from that <b>which is written</b> in the context of purification from impurity imparted by a corpse: “And a pure person shall take hyssop, and dip it in the water, and sprinkle it upon the tent, and upon all the vessels, <b>and upon the people that were there”</b> (Numbers 19:18). This apparently superfluous mention of “people” serves to include <b>anyone who is a person,</b> irrespective of age.
The mishna also teaches: <b>And</b> a one-day-old baby <b>creates</b> a levirate bond requiring the widow of his childless brother <b>to</b> enter into <b>levirate marriage</b> with him. The Gemara explains that this is derived from that <b>which is written: “If brothers dwell together</b> and one of them dies, and he has no child, the wife of the dead man shall not be married outside of the family to one not of his kin. Her brother-in-law will have intercourse with her and take her to him to be his wife, and consummate the levirate marriage” (Deuteronomy 25:5). This verse is referring to <b>brothers who had one dwelling in the world,</b> i.e., who were alive at the same time, which includes a baby who was born the day his brother died.
The mishna teaches: <b>And</b> a one-day-old baby <b>exempts</b> his widowed mother <b>from the</b> obligation of <b>levirate marriage.</b> The Gemara explains the derivation: <b>The Merciful One states:</b> “And one of them dies, <b>and he has no child”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:5), <b>and this</b> late husband <b>has</b> a child, albeit one who is one day old.
The mishna teaches: <b>And</b> a one-day-old baby <b>enables</b> his mother, an Israelite woman who is no longer married to his father, a priest, to continue <b>to partake of <i>teruma</i>.</b> The Gemara explains that this is <b>as it is written,</b> with regard to those who are entitled to partake of <i>teruma</i> on account of a priest: <b>“And those who are born in his house, they may eat [<i>yokhelu</i>] of his bread”</b> (Leviticus 22:11). <b>Read into</b> the verse: Those who are born in his house <b>enable others to eat [<i>ya’akhilu</i>] of his bread,</b> i.e., on account of her son the priest, the Israelite mother may continue to partake of <i>teruma</i> even after the death of his father.
§ The mishna also teaches: <b>And</b> a one-day-old baby <b>disqualifies</b> his mother, the daughter of a priest who is no longer married to his father, an Israelite man, <b>from</b> continuing to partake of <b><i>teruma</i>.</b> The Gemara explains that the reason is that <b>the Merciful One states:</b> “But if a priest’s daughter becomes a widow, or divorced, <b>and has no child,</b> and is returned to her father’s house, as in her youth, she may eat of her father’s bread” (Leviticus 22:13), <b>and this</b> daughter of a priest <b>has</b> a child.
The Gemara asks: <b>Why</b> state <b>specifically</b> that she has <b>a child? Even</b> if she has <b>a fetus</b> in her womb from an Israelite man, the same <i>halakha</i> applies, <b>as it is written: “As in her youth,”</b> which <b>excludes a pregnant woman,</b> since her pregnancy has changed her physical state from that of her youth.
The Gemara answers that both derivations <b>are necessary. As, if the Merciful One had written</b> only: <b>“And has no child,”</b> I would say that the reason the daughter of a priest who has a child from an Israelite man may no longer partake of <i>teruma</i> is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that at the outset,</b> before she married, she was <b>one body, and now</b> she has developed into <b>two bodies,</b> herself and her child. <b>But here,</b> in a case when she is merely pregnant, <b>when at the outset</b> she was <b>one body and now</b> she remains <b>one body,</b> one might <b>say</b> that <b>she should</b> be permitted to <b>partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>. Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes: “As in her youth.”</b>
<b>And</b> by contrast, <b>if the Merciful One had written</b> only: <b>“As in her youth,”</b> I would say that the reason that the daughter of a priest who is pregnant from an Israelite man may no longer partake of <i>teruma</i> is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that at the outset</b> she had <b>an empty body and now</b> she has <b>a full body,</b> and consequently she is not returning to her father’s household in her initial state. <b>But here,</b> after she has given birth, <b>where at the outset</b> she had <b>an empty body and now</b> she still has <b>an empty body,</b> one might <b>say</b> that <b>she should</b> be permitted to <b>partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>. Therefore, the Merciful One writes: “And has no child.” Therefore, both derivations are <b>necessary.</b>
The Gemara asks: The need for both <b>verses</b> has been <b>resolved, but the mishna</b> remains difficult: <b>What</b> is the reason the mishna is referring <b>specifically</b> to a baby who is <b>one day old,</b> when, as stated above, the same <i>halakha</i> applies <b>even</b> to <b>a fetus? Rav Sheshet said: Here we are dealing with a priest who has two wives: One</b> who is <b>a divorcée,</b> as she was previously divorced from another man, and who was therefore married to this priest in violation of <i>halakha</i>, <b>and one who is not a divorcée. And he has sons from</b> the wife <b>who is not a divorcée, and he has</b> a baby boy who is <b>one day old from the</b> wife who is <b>a divorcée.</b> This son is disqualified from the priesthood and may not partake of <i>teruma</i>.
Rav Sheshet continues: The mishna is teaching <b>that</b> this baby <b>disqualifies his father’s</b> Canaanite <b>slaves from partaking of <i>teruma</i></b> again. Since this child is entitled to a portion of his father’s inheritance, which includes his slaves, they may no longer partake of <i>teruma</i> due to his presence in the world. <b>And</b> the mishna teaches this <b>to exclude</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yosei, who said</b> that <b>a fetus also disqualifies</b> his father’s slaves from partaking of <i>teruma</i>. For this reason, the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that with regard to <b>a one-day-old</b> baby boy, <b>yes,</b> he disqualifies his father’s slaves from partaking of <i>teruma</i>, but <b>a fetus</b> does <b>not.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that this baby <b>inherits and he bequeaths.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From whom does he inherit?</b> It must be <b>from his father. And to whom does he bequeath?</b> Presumably, he bequeaths <b>to his paternal brother,</b> in a case where the baby inherited his father’s property and then died on the same day, as maternal half-brothers do not inherit from each other. The Gemara raises a difficulty with regard to this interpretation: What is the novelty of the <i>halakha</i> that the brother of this one-day-old baby inherits from him? After all, <b>if</b> the surviving brother <b>wants, let him inherit from his father, and if he wants, let him inherit from</b> the one-day-old baby. Either way, he receives his late father’s property.
<b>Rav Sheshet said:</b> The mishna is teaching that a one-day-old baby <b>inherits his mother’s property</b> if she died on the day he was born, so that he is able <b>to bequeath</b> it, even if he dies after a day, <b>to</b> his heirs who are not the mother’s heirs, e.g., <b>a paternal half-brother. And</b> in such a case it is <b>specifically</b> when he is at least <b>one day old</b> that he inherits from his mother and bequeaths the property to his paternal half-brothers, <b>but a fetus,</b> whose mother died before he emerged, does <b>not</b> inherit from his mother. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? The reason is <b>that</b> presumably the fetus <b>died first,</b> before its mother died, <b>and</b> there is a <i>halakha</i> that <b>a son does not inherit from his mother</b>

Daf 44b

while <b>in the grave,</b> i.e., after death, <b>in order to bequeath to his paternal half-brother.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so,</b> that it is presumed that the fetus died before its mother? <b>But wasn’t there an incident</b> in which the mother died <b>and</b> the fetus <b>made up to three spasmodic motions</b> afterward? <b>Mar, son of Rav Ashi, said:</b> That is <b>just as it is with the tail of the lizard, which twitches</b> after being severed from the lizard, but it is merely a spasmodic motion which does not indicate that it is still alive.
<b>Mar, son of Rav Yosef, said</b> a different explanation of the mishna’s ruling <b>in the name of Rava:</b> The mishna teaches that a one-day-old baby inherits in order <b>to say that</b> such a child <b>reduces the portion of the firstborn.</b> A firstborn is entitled to a double portion of the inheritance, which is calculated by taking into account the portion due to his dead brother. <b>And Mar, son of Rav Yosef,</b> further <b>said in the name of Rava: A son who was born after his father’s death does not reduce the portion of the firstborn.</b> Therefore, the <i>halakha</i> in the mishna does not apply to a fetus. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>We require</b> fulfillment of the verse: “If a man has two wives, the one beloved, and the other hated, <b>and they bore him children”</b> (Deuteronomy 21:15), and this does not apply to a fetus not yet born at the time of the father’s death.
The Gemara notes: <b>In Sura they taught</b> Mar’s statement <b>that</b> way, whereas <b>in Pumbedita they taught</b> it <b>this</b> way: <b>Mar, son of Rav Yosef, said in the name of Rava: A firstborn who was born after his father’s death does not receive a double</b> portion. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>We require</b> fulfillment of the verse: “But <b>he shall acknowledge</b> the firstborn…by giving him a double portion” (Deuteronomy 21:17), <b>and</b> in this case the father <b>is not</b> there to acknowledge him.
The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with all these versions of</b> the statement of <b>Mar, son of Rav Yosef, in the name of Rava,</b> i.e., a one-day-old baby reduces the portion of the firstborn, a son born after his father’s death does not reduce the portion of the firstborn, and a firstborn born after his father’s death does not receive a double portion.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And one who kills</b> a one-day-old baby is <b>liable</b> for his murder. The Gemara explains that the reason for this is <b>as it is written: “And he who smites any man mortally</b> shall be put to death” (Leviticus 24:17), where the phrase “any man” indicates that this verse applies <b>in any case,</b> even in the case of a one-day-old baby.
The mishna further teaches: <b>And</b> if a one-day-old baby dies, <b>his</b> status in relation <b>to his father and to his mother and to all his relatives</b> is <b>like</b> that of <b>a full-fledged groom.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what <i>halakha</i></b> is this stated? <b>Rav Pappa said: With regard to mourning.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion is this stated? It is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, who said: With regard to humans, any</b> child <b>that remained</b> alive <b>thirty days</b> after birth <b>is not</b> considered <b>a non-viable newborn.</b> It can be inferred from this statement that if <b>he did not remain</b> alive for thirty days after birth, <b>he is</b> of <b>uncertain</b> status. The Gemara refutes this proof: <b>Here we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where one is certain that its months</b> of gestation <b>were completed,</b> and therefore it is certainly a viable newborn.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A girl</b> who is <b>three years and one day old,</b> whose father arranged her betrothal, <b>is betrothed through intercourse,</b> as the halakhic status of intercourse with her is that of intercourse in all halakhic senses. <b>And</b> in a case where the childless husband of a girl three years and one day old dies, <b>if</b> his brother the <b><i>yavam</i> engages in intercourse with her, he acquires her</b> as his wife; <b>and</b> if she is married, a man other than her husband <b>is liable for</b> engaging in intercourse with <b>her due to</b> violation of the prohibition against intercourse with <b>a married woman.</b>
<b>And</b> if she is impure due to menstruation, <b>she imparts impurity to one who engages in intercourse with her</b> who then <b>renders impure</b> all the layers of <b>bedding beneath</b> him, rendering them impure <b>like the upper</b> bedding covering a <i>zav</i>, in the sense that it assumes first-degree ritual impurity and does not become a primary source of ritual impurity, and it renders impure food and drink, but it does not render impure people and vessels.
If <b>she marries a priest, she may partake of <i>teruma</i>,</b> like any other wife of a priest; if she is unmarried and <b>one</b> of the men <b>who are unfit</b> for the priesthood, e.g., a <i>mamzer</i> or <i>ḥalal</i>, <b>engaged in intercourse with her, he disqualifies her from</b> marrying into <b>the priesthood,</b> and if she is the daughter of a priest, she is disqualified from partaking of <i>teruma</i>. Finally, if <b>one of all those with whom relations are forbidden,</b> as <b>stated in the Torah,</b> e.g., her father or her husband’s father, <b>engaged in intercourse with her, they are executed</b> by the court <b>for</b> engaging in intercourse with <b>her, and she is exempt,</b> because she is a minor.
If the girl is <b>less than that</b> age, younger than three years and one day, the status of intercourse with her is not that of intercourse in all halakhic senses; rather, it is <b>like placing a finger into the eye.</b> Just as in that case, the eye constricts, sheds tears, and then returns to its original state, so too, in a girl younger than three years and one day old, the hymen returns to its original state.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A girl</b> who is <b>three years</b> old <b>is betrothed through intercourse;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say:</b> She must be <b>three years and one day old.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the difference <b>between</b> their opinions, as both agree that she cannot be betrothed before the age of three? The Sages <b>of the school of Rabbi Yannai said:</b> There is a difference <b>between</b> their opinions in the case of a girl on <b>the eve of the first day of</b> the fourth <b>year</b> of her life. According to Rabbi Meir, she can be betrothed through intercourse, as on this day three years are complete, whereas the Rabbis maintain that she cannot be betrothed in this manner, as she has not yet entered the first day of her fourth year.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> There is a difference <b>between</b> their opinions with regard to the issue of whether <b>thirty days in a year are considered</b> equivalent to <b>a year.</b> Rabbi Meir maintains that thirty days in a year are considered equivalent to a year, and therefore a girl aged two years and thirty days is already considered like a three-year-old and may be betrothed through intercourse. By contrast, the Rabbis contend that thirty days in a year are not considered equivalent to a year, and she may be betrothed through intercourse only upon reaching the age of three years and one day.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> against the explanation of Rabbi Yannai from a <i>baraita</i>: A girl who is <b>three years old, and even</b> one who is <b>two years and one day old, is betrothed through intercourse;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say:</b> She must be <b>three years and one day old.</b>

Daf 45a

The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan, just as there is a <i>tanna</i> who says</b> that <b>one day in a year is considered</b> equivalent to <b>a year, so too, there is a <i>tanna</i> who says</b> that <b>thirty days in a year are considered</b> equivalent to <b>a year.</b>The <i>baraita</i> states that according to Rabbi Meir, a girl two years and one day old is considered like a three-year-old, following the opinion that one day in a year is equivalent to a full year. Similarly, Rabbi Yoḥanan maintains that there is a second <i>tanna</i> who says that thirty days in a year are considered equivalent to a full year, and therefore a girl can be betrothed by intercourse from the age of two years and thirty days.
<b>But according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yannai,</b> that Rabbi Meir requires a full three years, this <i>baraita</i> is <b>difficult,</b> as it explicitly states that in Rabbi Meir’s opinion even a girl aged two years and one day can be betrothed by intercourse. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, this <i>baraita</i> is <b>difficult</b> according to the opinion of Rabbi Yannai.
§ The last clause of the mishna teaches that if the girl is <b>less than that</b> age, i.e., younger than three years and one day, the status of intercourse with her is <b>like placing a finger into the eye. A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: What happens to <b>this hymen,</b> i.e., to the hymen of a girl under three with whom a man engaged in intercourse? Does it <b>disappear and come</b> back again later, <b>or perhaps it is not removed at all until after</b> she reaches the age of <b>three?</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What difference is</b> there in <i>halakha</i> between these two suggestions? The Gemara answers that there is a practical ramification in a case <b>where</b> a priest <b>engaged in intercourse</b> with a girl to whom he is married <b>within</b> her first <b>three</b> years, <b>and found blood</b> on her due to that intercourse, <b>and</b> again <b>engaged in intercourse</b> with her many times, including <b>after</b> she turned <b>three, but</b> on that occasion <b>he did not find blood. If you say</b> that after engaging in intercourse when the girl is younger than three, the hymen <b>disappears and comes</b> back again, here one can maintain that it disappeared due to the first time they engaged in intercourse and did not grow back because <b>there was not enough time</b> without intercourse <b>for it</b> to grow back.
<b>But if you say</b> that the hymen <b>is not removed</b> at all <b>until after</b> she reaches the age of <b>three,</b> the fact that <b>this</b> girl did not emit blood after three years must be because <b>another</b> man <b>engaged in intercourse with her</b> after she turned three, in which case she is classified as a <i>zona</i>, a woman who has engaged in sexual intercourse with a man forbidden to her by the Torah, and is forbidden to her husband the priest. The Gemara reiterates: <b>What,</b> then, is the resolution of the dilemma?
<b>Rav Ḥiyya, son of Rav Ika, objects to this</b> explanation of the practical ramifications of the dilemma: <b>But</b> even if one maintains that the hymen of a girl younger than three disappears and grows back, one can still contend that this girl engaged in intercourse with another man, as <b>who will say to us that a wound that</b> was inflicted <b>within three years</b> of a girl’s birth <b>is not restored</b> and healed <b>immediately? Perhaps it is restored immediately, and this</b> girl did not emit blood because <b>another</b> man <b>engaged in intercourse with her</b> previously, and she is therefore a <i>zona</i> who is forbidden to a priest.
<b>Rather,</b> the practical <b>difference</b> between the two suggestions relates to a case <b>where</b> the husband <b>engaged in intercourse</b> with this girl <b>within</b> her first <b>three</b> years, <b>and found blood, and engaged in intercourse</b> with her again <b>after</b> she turned <b>three, and</b> again <b>found blood. If you say</b> that the hymen <b>disappears and comes</b> back again, <b>this</b> blood emitted when she is less than three years old <b>is blood</b> from the tearing of <b>the hymen,</b> which does not render her impure. <b>But if you say</b> that the hymen <b>is not removed</b> at all <b>until after</b> she reaches the age of <b>three,</b> then <b>this</b> blood she emitted when she was younger than three <b>is menstrual blood,</b> which renders her impure. <b>What,</b> then, is the resolution of the dilemma?
<b>Rav Ḥisda said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> the mishna: If the girl is <b>less than that</b> age of three years and one day, intercourse with her is <b>like placing a finger into the eye. Why do I</b> need the mishna <b>to teach: Like placing a finger into the eye? Let</b> it <b>teach</b> simply: If she is <b>less than that</b> age, intercourse with her is <b>nothing. What, is it not</b> correct that <b>this</b> is what the mishna <b>teaches us,</b> by its comparison to an eye: <b>Just as</b> placing a finger in <b>an eye</b> causes it to <b>tear and tear again,</b> when another finger is placed in it, <b>so too</b> after the intercourse of a girl under three the <b>hymen disappears and comes</b> back again?
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: There was <b>an incident involving</b> a gentile woman called <b>Yusteni, the daughter of Asveirus, son of Antoninus,</b> a Roman emperor, <b>who came before Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>She said to him: My teacher, at what</b> age is <b>a woman</b> fit to <b>marry,</b> i.e., at what age is it appropriate for a woman to engage in intercourse, which would therefore be the appropriate time to marry? Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to her:</b> She must be at least <b>three years and one day old.</b>
Yusteni further inquired: <b>And at what</b> age is <b>she</b> fit to <b>become pregnant?</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to her:</b> When she is at least <b>twelve years and one day old. She said to him: I married when</b> I was <b>six, and gave birth</b> a year later, <b>when</b> I was <b>seven. Woe for</b> those <b>three years,</b> between the age of three, when I was fit for intercourse, and the age of six, when I married, <b>as I wasted</b> those years <b>in my father’s house</b> by not engaging in intercourse.
The Gemara asks: <b>And can</b> a minor of that age <b>become pregnant? But didn’t Rav Beivai teach</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>before Rav Naḥman: Three women</b> may <b>engage in intercourse</b> while <b>using</b> a contraceptive absorbent <b>cloth,</b> a soft fabric placed at the entrance to the womb to prevent conception, despite the fact that this practice generally is prohibited. They are <b>a minor; a pregnant woman; and a nursing woman.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> specifies the reason for allowing these women to use contraceptive absorbent cloths: <b>A minor, lest she become pregnant and</b> perhaps <b>die</b> from this pregnancy; <b>a pregnant woman, lest</b> she be impregnated a second time and <b>her</b> older <b>fetus become</b> deformed into the shape of <b>a sandal</b> fish, by being squashed by the pressure of the second fetus; and <b>a nursing woman, lest</b> she become pregnant and her milk dry up, in which case <b>she weans her son</b> too early, thereby endangering him, <b>and he dies.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And who is</b> considered <b>a minor?</b> It is a girl <b>from the age of eleven years and one day until</b> the age of <b>twelve years and one day.</b> If she was <b>younger than that or older than that, she may go ahead and engage in intercourse</b> in her usual manner, i.e., without contraception. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b> Since it is assumed that a minor who is less than eleven years old cannot become pregnant, she is considered to be in no danger.
<b>And the Rabbis say: Both</b> in <b>this</b> case of a minor girl who can become pregnant <b>and</b> in <b>that</b> case of a minor girl who cannot become pregnant, she <b>may go ahead and engage in intercourse in her usual manner, and Heaven will have mercy</b> upon her and prevent any mishap, <b>as it is stated: “The Lord preserves the simple”</b> (Psalms 116:6). In light of the statement of Rabbi Meir, how could Yusteni have become pregnant at age seven?
The Gemara answers: <b>If you wish, say</b> that Yusteni was able to become pregnant at such a young age because she was a gentile, and the verse states with regard to gentiles: <b>“Their flesh is the flesh of donkeys”</b> (Ezekiel 23:20). <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that Yusteni was lying when she said she became pregnant at age seven, as it is stated with regard to gentiles: <b>“Whose mouth speaks falsehood, and their right hand is a right hand of lying”</b> (Psalms 144:8).
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: There was <b>an incident involving a certain woman who came before Rabbi Akiva</b> and <b>said to him: My teacher, I engaged in intercourse within three years</b> of my birth; <b>what</b> is <b>my</b> status with regard to marrying <b>into the priesthood?</b> Rabbi Akiva <b>said to her: You are fit</b> to marry <b>into the priesthood.</b>
<b>She said to him: My teacher, I will tell you a parable; to what is this matter comparable?</b> It is comparable <b>to a baby whose finger</b> one forcibly <b>dipped in honey.</b> On the <b>first time and</b> the <b>second</b> time, <b>he moans at</b> his mother for doing so, but on the <b>third</b> occasion, once he is used to the taste of honey, he willingly <b>sucks</b> the finger dipped in honey. She was insinuating to Rabbi Akiva that she engaged in intercourse several times, and although the first couple of times were against her will, the third incident was with her consent. Rabbi Akiva <b>said to her: If so, you are disqualified</b> from marrying <b>into the priesthood.</b>
Rabbi Akiva <b>saw</b> his <b>students looking at each other,</b> puzzling over this ruling. <b>He said to them: Why is this matter difficult in your eyes? They said to him: Just as the entire Torah is a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted <b>to Moses from Sinai, so too</b> this <i>halakha</i> of a girl who engaged in intercourse when she was <b>less than three years old,</b> i.e., that she is <b>fit</b> to marry <b>into the priesthood,</b> is <b>a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted <b>to Moses from Sinai,</b> and it applies whether she engaged intercourse against her will or with her consent. The Gemara notes: <b>And even Rabbi Akiva did not say</b> to the woman that she was unfit to marry into the priesthood because that is the <i>halakha</i>; rather, he did so <b>only to sharpen</b> the minds of his <b>students with</b> his statement, to see how they would respond.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of a boy, <b>nine years and one day old,</b> whose brother had died childless, <b>who engaged in intercourse with his <i>yevama</i>,</b> his brother’s widow, the status of the intercourse is that of halakhic intercourse and <b>he acquires her</b> as his wife; <b>but he cannot give</b> her <b>a bill of divorce,</b> if he chooses to end the marriage, <b>until he reaches majority.</b>
<b>And he becomes ritually impure</b> after engaging in intercourse <b>with a menstruating woman to</b> the degree that he <b>renders impure</b> all the layers of <b>bedding beneath</b> him, such that they become impure <b>like the upper</b> bedding covering a <i>zav</i>. Accordingly, the bedding assumes first-degree ritual impurity status and does not become a primary source of ritual impurity, and it renders impure food and drink and does not render impure people and vessels.
<b>And</b> if he is disqualified from the priesthood and the woman with whom he engages in intercourse is the daughter of a priest, <b>he disqualifies</b> her from partaking of <i>teruma</i>; <b>but</b> if he is a priest who marries an Israelite woman, <b>he does not enable</b> her <b>to partake of <i>teruma</i>. And</b> if he engages in bestiality, <b>he disqualifies the animal from</b> being sacrificed <b>upon the altar, and</b> the animal <b>is stoned due to his</b> act. <b>And if he engaged in intercourse with one of all those with whom relations are forbidden,</b> as <b>stated in the Torah,</b> e.g., his aunt or his mother, <b>they are executed</b> by the court <b>due to</b> having engaged in intercourse with <b>him,</b> because they are adults; <b>but he is exempt,</b> as he is a minor.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that a boy aged nine years and one day cannot give his <i>yevama</i> a bill of divorce until he reaches majority. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> even <b>when he reaches majority, is a bill of divorce enough to</b> enable <b>her</b> to marry any man? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that the Sages <b>rendered the</b> halakhic status of the act of <b>intercourse of</b> a boy <b>nine</b> years and one day <b>old like</b> that of <b>levirate betrothal</b> by means of money or a document performed <b>by an adult man,</b> which is an acquisition by rabbinic law? Accordingly, she is not his full-fledged wife.
Therefore, one can assert as follows: <b>Just as</b> after <b>a levirate betrothal</b> performed <b>by an adult man,</b> the <i>yavam</i> <b>must</b> give the <i>yevama</i> <b>a bill of divorce to</b> release her from <b>his levirate betrothal and</b> perform <b><i>ḥalitza</i> to</b> release her from <b>his</b> levirate <b>bond, so too</b> with regard to <b>the intercourse of</b> a boy <b>nine</b> years and one day <b>old,</b> the <i>halakha</i> should be that he <b>must</b> give her <b>a bill of divorce for his levirate betrothal and</b> perform <b><i>ḥalitza</i> to</b> release her from <b>his</b> levirate <b>bond.</b>
<b>Rav said</b> in response that <b>this</b> is what the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>is saying:</b>

Daf 45b

<b>When he reaches majority he may engage in intercourse with her,</b> and thereby acquire her as his full-fledged wife, <b>and</b> if he wished to divorce her <b>he</b> can then <b>give her a bill of divorce</b> without having to perform <i>ḥalitza</i>.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to a girl who is <b>eleven years and one day old, her vows are examined</b> to ascertain whether she is aware of the meaning of her vow and in Whose name she vowed. Once she is <b>twelve years and one day old</b> and has grown two pubic hairs, which is a sign of adulthood, even without examination <b>her vows are in effect. And one examines</b> her vows throughout <b>the entire twelfth</b> year until her twelfth birthday.
With regard to a boy who is <b>twelve years and one day old, his vows are examined</b> to ascertain whether he is aware of the meaning of his vow and in Whose name he vowed. Once he is <b>thirteen years and one day old</b> and has grown two pubic hairs, even without examination <b>his vows are in effect. And one examines</b> his vows throughout <b>the entire thirteenth</b> year until his thirteenth birthday.
<b>Prior to that time,</b> eleven years and one day for a girl and twelve years and one day for a boy, <b>even if they said: We know in Whose name we vowed</b> and <b>in Whose name we consecrated, their vow is not</b> a valid <b>vow and their consecration is not</b> a valid <b>consecration. After that time,</b> twelve years and one day for a girl and thirteen years and one day for a boy, <b>even if they said: We do not know in Whose name we vowed</b> and <b>in Whose name we consecrated, their vow is</b> a valid <b>vow and their consecration is</b> a valid <b>consecration.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>But since</b> the mishna <b>teaches:</b> With regard to a girl who is <b>eleven years and one day old her vows are examined, why do I</b> need the mishna to further state: Once she is <b>twelve years and one day old her vows are in effect?</b> After all, by this stage she is already an adult. The Gemara answers that this ruling is necessary, as it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>one examines</b> her vows <b>forever,</b> even when she is an adult. Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that the vows of an adult are valid even without examination.
The Gemara further asks: <b>And since</b> the mishna <b>teaches:</b> Once she is <b>twelve years and one day old her vows are in effect, why do I</b> need it to further state: <b>One examines</b> her vows throughout <b>the entire twelfth</b> year? The Gemara answers that this ruling is necessary, as it might <b>enter your mind to say: Since the Master says</b> that <b>thirty days in a year are considered</b> equivalent to <b>a year,</b> in a case <b>where we examine her</b> for <b>thirty</b> days after she turned eleven <b>and she did not know</b> how <b>to utter</b> a vow <b>properly,</b> i.e., she did not have a clear understanding of the meaning of the vow, one might <b>say</b> that <b>one should examine</b> her <b>no further</b> until she reaches the age of twelve. Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that she is examined throughout her twelfth year.
The Gemara asks: <b>And let</b> the mishna <b>teach</b> only <b>these two clauses:</b> Once she is <b>twelve years and one day old her vows are in effect, and one examines</b> her vows throughout <b>the entire twelfth</b> year. Once both of these have been taught, <b>why do I</b> need the ruling: With regard to a girl who is <b>eleven years and one day old, her vows are examined?</b>
The Gemara answers that this clause <b>was necessary,</b> as it might <b>enter your mind to say:</b> In <b>an ordinary</b> case, a girl <b>requires examination in</b> her <b>twelfth</b> year, whereas <b>in</b> her <b>eleventh</b> year she <b>does not require examination. But</b> in a case <b>where we discern about her that she</b> has <b>a very sharp</b> mind, perhaps <b>she should be examined</b> already <b>in</b> her <b>eleventh</b> year. Therefore, the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches us</b> that she is not examined in her eleventh year irrespective of how intelligent she is, as she is too young.
The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need the mishna to teach that <b>prior to that time</b> their vows and consecration are always not valid <b>and after that time</b> they are always valid? These <i>halakhot</i> can be inferred from the previous statements of the mishna. The Gemara answers that these rulings are necessary, as it might <b>enter your mind to say: These matters</b> apply only in a case <b>where they do not say:</b> We know in Whose name we vowed, when they are younger than the periods mentioned in the mishna, or: We do not know in Whose name we vowed, when they are older. <b>But</b> in a case <b>where they do say</b> such statements, perhaps <b>we rely on their</b> claim. Therefore, the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches us</b> that when they are younger than the periods stated in the mishna their vows are never valid, and when they are older, their vows are always valid.
§ The mishna indicates that the intellectual development of a girl is faster than that of a boy. In this regard, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>This</b> opinion, with regard to the periods of vows for girls and boys, is in accordance with <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. But <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says</b> the opposite, that the <b>matter stated</b> here <b>with regard to a girl is</b> actually <b>stated with regard to a boy,</b> whereas the <b>matter stated with regard to a boy is</b> in fact <b>stated with regard to a girl,</b> as the intellectual development of males is faster than that of females.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said: What is the reason of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi? <b>As it is written,</b> with regard to the creation of woman: <b>“And the rib,</b> which <b>the Lord God</b> had taken from the man, <b>He made [<i>vayyiven</i>]</b> a woman, and brought her to the man” (Genesis 2:22). This <b>teaches that the Holy One, Blessed be He, granted a woman a greater understanding [<i>bina</i>] than</b> that <b>of a men.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what does <b>the other</b> <i>tanna</i>, Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar, derive from this verse? The Gemara answers: <b>He requires that</b> verse <b>for that which Reish Lakish</b> taught, <b>as Reish Lakish said in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya</b> with regard to the verse: <b>“And the rib, which the Lord God had taken from the man, He made a woman, and brought her to the man.”</b> This <b>teaches that the Holy One, Blessed be He, braided</b> the hair of <b>Eve, and</b> then <b>brought her to Adam the first</b> man. <b>As in the cities overseas [<i>bikhrakei hayyam</i>] they call braiding</b> hair, <b>building [<i>benayita</i>].</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar, what is the reason</b> that he maintains that the intellectual development of males is faster than that of females? <b>Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak says: Since a boy frequents his teacher’s house, cleverness enters his</b> mind <b>first.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that there are three periods in the development of girls and boys: When their vows are examined, i.e., the twelfth year for a girl and the thirteenth year for a boy, which will be termed below: During the time; the period beforehand, when their vows are entirely invalid, called: Before the time; and after that period, when their vows are always valid, known as: After the time. But the mishna does not address the issue of their physical development during these periods, with regard to the appearance of two pubic hairs. In this regard, <b>a dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If a boy or girl developed pubic hairs <b>during</b> the <b>time,</b> is this year considered <b>like</b> the development of signs indicating puberty <b>before</b> the <b>time</b> that the child reaches majority, and therefore they are not treated as signs indicating puberty, <b>or</b> is it considered <b>as after</b> the <b>time?</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what <i>halakha</i></b> is this dilemma raised? <b>If</b> it is <b>with regard to vows,</b> the development of pubic hairs <b>is not considered as before</b> the <b>time, but</b> it <b>is not considered as after</b> the <b>time</b> either. Instead, the status of the vow is determined in accordance with the examination of the child’s understanding, as stated in the mishna.
<b>Rather,</b> the dilemma is raised <b>with regard to punishments,</b> i.e., whether such a boy or girl is punished like an adult for violating the prohibitions of the Torah. <b>What,</b> then, is the <i>halakha</i>? The Sages disagree. <b>Rav and Rabbi Ḥanina both say:</b> The development of pubic hairs <b>during</b> that <b>time</b> is considered <b>as before</b> the <b>time,</b> and therefore the boy or girl is not liable to receive punishment for his or her actions. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi both say:</b> The development of pubic hairs <b>during</b> that <b>time</b> is considered <b>as after</b> the <b>time,</b> and they are punished.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak says: And your mnemonic,</b> to remember which Sages said which ruling, is the verse: <b>“Now this [<i>vezot</i>] was the custom in former times in Israel”</b> (Ruth 4:7). The Sage whose name has a feminine form like the word <i>vezot</i>, namely, Rav Ḥanina, maintains that the development of pubic hairs during the time is considered as before the time, like the former times mentioned in the verse.
<b>Rav Hamnuna raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi from the mishna: <b>After that time,</b> twelve years and one day for a girl and thirteen years and one day for a boy, <b>even if they say: We do not know in Whose name we vowed</b> and <b>in Whose name we consecrated, their vow is</b> a valid <b>vow and their consecration is</b> a valid <b>consecration.</b> Rav Hamnuna infers from this ruling that if they issued this statement <b>during</b> the <b>time,</b> it is considered <b>as before</b> the <b>time,</b> even if they had developed two hairs.
<b>Rava said to</b> Rav Hamnuna, in rejection of this proof: <b>Say the former clause</b> in the mishna: <b>Prior to that time,</b> eleven years and one day for a girl and twelve years and one day for a boy, <b>even if they said: We know in Whose name we vowed</b> and <b>in Whose name we consecrated, their vow is not</b> a valid <b>vow and their consecration is not</b> a valid <b>consecration.</b> One can infer the opposite from here, that if they issued this statement <b>during</b> the <b>time,</b> it is considered <b>as after</b> the <b>time.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>And</b> that <b>is not so,</b> as <b>Rava erred. He thought</b> that <b>Rav Hamnuna inferred from the superfluous</b> statement of the <b>mishna,</b> i.e., that the clause Rav Hamnuna cites is unnecessary for the <i>halakha</i> it states, which is why Rav Hamnuna inferred his conclusion from it. <b>And</b> therefore Rava responded that <b>rather than inferring from the latter clause</b> of the mishna that if the boy or girl claims not to know in Whose name he or she vowed during the time, it is considered as before the time, <b>let him infer from the former clause</b> that it is considered as after the time, as Rava demonstrated.
The Gemara continues: <b>But it is not so;</b> rather, <b>Rav Hamnuna inferred</b> that it is considered as before the time <b>from the</b> statement of <b>the mishna itself,</b> without assuming that it is superfluous, as follows: In <b>that</b> mention in the mishna of: <b>After</b> that <b>time, what are the circumstances? If</b> it is referring to a case <b>where</b> the boy <b>has not</b> yet <b>developed two</b> pubic <b>hairs, he is a minor. Rather, is it not</b> referring to a case <b>where</b> the boy <b>has developed two</b> pubic <b>hairs,</b>

Daf 46a

<b>and the reason</b> that the development of two hairs renders him an adult is <b>that</b> the onset of <b>his matter,</b> i.e., his reaching puberty, <b>was completed for him after</b> the <b>time?</b> Rav Hamnuna infers from here that if the child developed two hairs <b>during</b> the <b>time,</b> it is considered <b>as before</b> the <b>time,</b> and he or she is not classified as an adult.
<b>And furthermore, Rabbi Zeira raises an objection</b> to the opinion that the development of signs indicating puberty during the time is equivalent to their development after the time. It is taught in a <i>baraita</i> which deals with the verse: “Speak to the children of Israel and say to them: <b>When</b> either <b>man</b> or a woman <b>shall clearly utter a vow”</b> (Numbers 6:2). <b>What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states “man,”</b> after it has already stated “the children of Israel”? This serves <b>to include</b> anyone who is <b>thirteen years and one day old, that even if he does not know</b> how <b>to utter clearly</b> and articulate the meaning of his statements, <b>his vows are in effect.</b>
Rabbi Zeira analyzes this <i>baraita</i>. <b>What are the circumstances? If</b> it is referring to a case <b>where</b> the boy <b>has not</b> yet <b>developed two</b> pubic <b>hairs,</b> then <b>he is a minor,</b> and the <i>halakha</i> with regard to him cannot be derived from the word “man.” <b>Rather, is it not</b> referring to a case <b>where</b> the boy <b>has developed two</b> pubic <b>hairs? And</b> by inference, <b>the reason that he is</b> considered <b>a man</b> due to his development of pubic hairs <b>is that he is thirteen years and one day old, but</b> if the boy developed two hairs <b>during</b> the <b>time,</b> it is considered <b>as before</b> the <b>time.</b> The Gemara concludes: This is indeed <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi that developing pubic hairs during the time is equivalent to developing hairs after the time.
<b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is not a refutation of the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, as this matter is <b>subject to</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> since there is another <i>baraita</i> which teaches the following: Everyone agrees with regard to <b>a nine-year-old</b> boy <b>who developed two hairs</b> that this is not considered a sign of puberty, as they are treated as hairs that grow on <b>a mole. From nine</b> years <b>of age until</b> the age of <b>twelve years and one day,</b> even if the hairs have not fallen out, this is still considered <b>a mole. Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says:</b> At this stage it is <b>a sign</b> indicating puberty. If he is <b>thirteen years and one day old</b> and has grown two hairs, <b>all agree</b> that it is <b>a sign</b> indicating puberty.
Rav Naḥman analyzes the <i>baraita</i>. <b>This</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>itself</b> is <b>difficult,</b> as <b>you</b> initially <b>said</b> that <b>from nine</b> years <b>of age until</b> the age of <b>twelve years and one day</b> it is <b>a mole,</b> from which it can be inferred that if he developed two pubic hairs in <b>the thirteenth year itself,</b> it is <b>a sign</b> indicating puberty. <b>And then</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> that if he is <b>thirteen years and one day old</b> and has grown two hairs, this is <b>a sign</b> indicating puberty, which indicates that if he developed the hairs in <b>the thirteenth year itself,</b> it is <b>a mole.</b>
Rav Naḥman concludes: <b>What, is it not</b> correct to say that there <b>is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>, as</b> one <b>Sage,</b> the <i>tanna</i> who states the first line of the <i>baraita</i>, <b>holds</b> that <b>during</b> that <b>time</b> is considered <b>as after</b> the <b>time, and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the last line of the <i>baraita</i>, <b>holds</b> that <b>during</b> that <b>time</b> is considered <b>as before</b> the <b>time?</b> If so, the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi is one side of a dispute between <i>tanna’im</i>.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>No, everyone,</b> i.e., the <i>tanna’im</i> of both clauses of the <i>baraita</i>, agrees that <b>during</b> that <b>time</b> is considered <b>as before</b> the <b>time, and this</b> clause <b>and that</b> clause of the <i>baraita</i> are both referring <b>to a young girl. And</b> the difference between them is that <b>the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, who maintains that the thirteenth year for a female is considered after the time, and therefore the development of two pubic hairs at this stage is a sign of maturation; <b>and the last clause</b> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar,</b> who holds that the thirteenth year for a female is considered before the time.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> that <b>this</b> clause <b>and that</b> clause are both dealing <b>with a young boy, and the first clause</b> is in accordance with <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar and the last clause</b> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, who maintains that the thirteenth year for a boy is considered before the time.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> that both <b>this</b> clause <b>and that</b> clause are in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, and the difference between them is that <b>this</b> last clause of the <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to a young boy,</b> whereas <b>that</b> first clause is referring <b>to a young girl. And if you wish, say</b> that both <b>this</b> clause <b>and that</b> clause are in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar,</b> and <b>that</b> first clause of the <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to a young boy,</b> whereas <b>this</b> last clause is referring <b>to a young girl.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> further teaches that <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says</b> with regard to hairs from nine years of age until the age of twelve years and one day, that it is <b>a sign</b> indicating puberty. In explanation of this opinion, <b>Rabbi Keruspedai, son of Rabbi Shabbtai, says: And</b> this <b>is</b> the <i>halakha</i> only <b>when</b> the hairs <b>are still upon him,</b> i.e., they had not fallen out when he reached the age of puberty, as otherwise they are considered a mole.
The Gemara notes that <b>this</b> opinion <b>is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to a boy <b>nine years and one day old who developed two hairs,</b> this is considered <b>a mole.</b> If the boy is <b>from nine</b> years <b>of age until</b> the age of <b>twelve years and one day, and</b> the hairs <b>are still upon him,</b> it is still considered <b>a mole. Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says:</b> It is <b>a sign</b> indicating puberty.
§ In summary of the rulings cited above, <b>Rava said: The <i>halakha</i></b> is that the development of two hairs <b>during</b> the <b>time</b> is considered <b>as before</b> the <b>time,</b> and it does not render one an adult. <b>Rav Shmuel bar Zutra teaches this <i>halakha</i> of Rava in this formulation: Rava says:</b> With regard to <b>a minor girl</b> whose father has passed away and whose mother or brothers accepted betrothal on her behalf, a form of betrothal instituted by the Sages, throughout her <b>entire twelfth year she</b> has the <b>continuous</b> right to <b>perform refusal with regard to</b> this marriage and thereby annul it. <b>From that</b> point <b>forward,</b> when she is already an adult, <b>she may no</b> longer <b>perform refusal, and she may not perform <i>ḥalitza</i></b> with the brother of her husband, if he died without children.
The Gemara asks: <b>This</b> statement of Rava <b>itself</b> is <b>difficult: You</b> first <b>said</b> that once she is twelve <b>she may not perform refusal. Evidently, she is an adult woman.</b> But <b>if she is an adult woman, let her perform <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> like any other adult woman.
<b>And if you would say</b> that Rava <b>is uncertain</b> whether a twelve-year-old girl is presumed to have developed two hairs and is therefore an adult, or whether it is presumed that she has not yet grown two hairs and remains a minor, and consequently he is stringent on both counts, that she may not perform refusal, like an adult, but she may also not perform <i>ḥalitza</i>, like a minor, this suggestion is problematic, as <b>is</b> Rava actually <b>uncertain</b> in this regard? <b>But doesn’t Rava say: A minor girl who reached her full age</b> of maturity, i.e., twelve years and one day, <b>does not require examination</b> to determine whether she has grown two hairs, as there is <b>a presumption</b> that <b>she has developed signs</b> indicating puberty.
The Gemara answers that <b>this statement,</b> that it is presumed that a twelve-year-old girl has developed two hairs, applies only <b>in an ordinary</b> situation. <b>But here</b> Rava is referring to a case <b>where they examined</b> her <b>and did not find</b> hairs. In such an instance, Rava did <b>not</b> say that the presumption is in effect.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> that she was actually examined, she should be considered a minor in all regards and <b>she should</b> be able to <b>perform refusal.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>We are concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> the girl had already developed pubic hairs but <b>they fell out.</b> Consequently, although the girl is not treated with the presumption that she is an adult, she does not have the certain status of a minor either, and cannot perform refusal.
The Gemara objects: <b>This works out well according to the one who says</b> that <b>we are concerned</b> that the pubic hairs fell out. <b>But according to the one who says</b> that <b>we are not concerned</b> that they have fallen out, <b>what is there to say? As it was stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> disagreed with regard to this matter. <b>Rav Pappa says: We are not concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> the pubic hairs <b>fell out; Rav Pappi says: We are concerned</b> that they might have fallen out. The Gemara answers that <b>this statement</b> of Rav Pappa, that there is no concern that perhaps the pubic hairs fell out, applies only <b>with regard to <i>ḥalitza</i>, but with regard to refusal</b> everyone agrees that <b>we are concerned</b> that they might have fallen out.
The Gemara asks: <b>By inference, does the one who says</b> that <b>we are concerned</b> that perhaps the hairs fell out maintain that this twelve-year-old <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i>? But</b> this cannot be correct, as <b>he says</b> that <b>we are merely concerned</b> that the hairs might have fallen out, not that this is certainly the case. How, then, can she perform <i>ḥalitza</i> like an adult?
<b>Rather,</b> Rava is <b>actually</b> referring to a case <b>where one did not examine</b> the girl, <b>and with regard to <i>ḥalitza</i> we are concerned</b> that she might not have developed hairs and is still a minor. <b>And when Rava said</b> that there is <b>a presumption</b> that a twelve-year-old has developed signs indicating puberty, he was referring <b>to refusal, but with regard to <i>ḥalitza</i> she requires examination.</b>
With regard to the issue of whether there is concern that hairs might have fallen out, <b>Rav Dimi of Neharde’a said: The <i>halakha</i></b> is that if a girl reached the age of twelve and she was examined and the signs of puberty were not found, <b>we are concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> the pubic hairs <b>fell out.</b> Consequently, if her mother or brothers had accepted betrothal for her when she was a minor, she cannot perform refusal at that stage.
The Gemara adds: <b>And this statement</b> applies only in a case <b>where</b> her husband <b>betrothed her during</b> the <b>time,</b> before she reached the age of twelve years and one day, <b>and engaged in intercourse</b> with her <b>after</b> the <b>time,</b> when she was already twelve years and one day old. This is a situation <b>where there is an uncertainty</b> with regard to <b>Torah law,</b> since if she had developed two hairs and is an adult, the marriage applies by Torah law, due to the intercourse. <b>But</b> if he engaged in intercourse with her only <b>at the outset,</b> before she turned twelve, there is <b>no</b> concern that perhaps she developed pubic hairs and they fell out, as this marriage applies by rabbinic law.
§ With regard to a minor who vowed, <b>Rav Huna says:</b> If the minor is aware of the meaning of his vow and in Whose name he or she vowed, and the minor’s age is during the time, i.e., the twelfth year for a girl or the thirteenth year for a boy, and he <b>consecrated</b> an item of food <b>and</b> subsequently <b>ate</b> it, <b>he is flogged,</b> which is the punishment for one who eats consecrated food.
Rav Huna explains: <b>As it is stated: “When</b> either <b>a man</b> or a woman <b>shall clearly utter a vow”</b> (Numbers 6:2), from which it is derived that if one on the brink of adulthood is able to articulate that his vow is in the name of God, his vows are valid. <b>And</b> another verse states: <b>“He shall not profane his word”</b> (Numbers 30:3). This indicates that <b>any</b> person <b>who is</b> included <b>in explicitness</b> of intent <b>is</b> also included <b>in</b> the prohibition: <b>“He shall not profane</b> his word,” <b>and anyone who is not</b> included <b>in explicitness</b> of intent <b>is not</b> included <b>in</b> the prohibition: <b>“He shall not profane</b> his word.”
<b>Rav Huna bar Yehuda raises an objection</b> to Rava, <b>in support</b> of the opinion <b>of Rav Huna:</b>

Daf 46b

<b>Since we find that the verse equates a minor,</b> i.e., one on the brink of adulthood, <b>to an adult with regard to an intentional</b> violation of <b>an oath and with regard to</b> a vow of <b>prohibition,</b> where one renders an item prohibited to himself through a vow, <b>and with regard to</b> the prohibition of <b>he shall not profane</b> his word, one <b>might</b> have thought that this minor, like an adult, <b>should</b> also <b>be liable</b> to bring <b>an offering for</b> misuse of <b>his consecrated</b> property, e.g., if he ate an item that he consecrated.
Therefore, <b>the verse states</b> with regard to vows: <b>“This is the matter</b> which the Lord has commanded. When a man vows a vow to the Lord, or takes an oath” (Numbers 30:2–3). The emphasis of “this” indicates that it is only with regard to this matter, i.e., prohibitions resulting from vows, that a discriminating minor on the brink of adulthood is considered an adult, but he is not rendered liable to bring an offering for his misuse.
The Gemara analyzes the <i>baraita</i>. <b>In any event,</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> that a discriminating minor on the brink of adulthood is considered an adult <b>with regard to</b> a vow of <b>prohibition and with regard to</b> the prohibition of <b>he shall not profane</b> his word, which indicates that he is <b>liable</b> for violating this prohibition. This supports the opinion of Rav Huna that a minor is flogged for eating food he consecrated. The Gemara refutes this proof: There is room to <b>say</b> that the word: And, in the phrase: With regard to a vow of prohibition and with regard to the prohibition of he shall not profane his word, should be omitted, and the <i>baraita</i> is comparing a minor to an adult <b>with regard to the prohibition</b> of <b>he shall not profane</b> his word, but it does not indicate that he is liable to receive lashes for violating this prohibition.
The Gemara asks: Can the <i>baraita</i> actually mean that a minor is compared to an adult with regard to <b>the prohibition</b> of <b>he shall not profane</b> his word, but he is not flogged? <b>Whichever way you</b> look at it, this is problematic: <b>If a discriminating</b> minor <b>on the brink of adulthood</b> is considered an adult <b>by Torah law, he should be flogged too,</b> for his violation. <b>And if a discriminating</b> minor <b>on the brink of adulthood</b> is <b>not</b> considered an adult <b>by Torah law, there is no prohibition</b> violated here <b>either.</b> The Gemara answers that according to the <i>baraita</i> the prohibition does not apply to the minor himself, but <b>to those who are warned to</b> keep <b>him</b> away from the prohibited item.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: If so, one can <b>conclude from</b> the <i>baraita</i> that if <b>a minor eats</b> meat from unslaughtered <b>animal carcasses</b> or violates other prohibitions, <b>the court is commanded to prevent him</b> from doing so. This is problematic, as elsewhere it is stated that this matter is subject to dispute (see <i>Yevamot</i> 114a). The Gemara explains: <b>Here we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where</b> the minor <b>consecrated</b> the food item <b>and others ate</b> it. They are liable to receive lashes for their consumption, but if he ate it he is not liable.
The Gemara raises another difficulty: <b>This works out well according to the one who said</b> that if a minor <b>consecrated</b> a food item <b>and others ate</b> it, <b>they are flogged. But according to the one who said</b> that in such a case <b>they are not flogged, what can be said? As it was stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> disagreed with regard to this issue: If a minor <b>consecrated</b> a food item <b>and others ate</b> it, <b>Rav Kahana says</b> that <b>they are not flogged; Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish both say</b> that <b>they are flogged.</b>
The Gemara therefore reverts to the interpretation that the <i>baraita</i> is referring to the prohibition of he shall not profane his word, not the punishment for violation of the vow. And the reason lashes are not administered is that the prohibition is <b>by rabbinic law. And</b> as for the <b>verse</b> mentioned in the <i>baraita</i>, when it states that the verse equates a minor to an adult, which indicates that it is dealing with Torah law, this verse is <b>a mere support</b> for a rabbinic law.
§ The Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself,</b> i.e., the dispute cited above. If a minor <b>consecrated</b> a food item <b>and others ate</b> it, <b>Rav Kahana says</b> that <b>they are not flogged; Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish both say</b> that <b>they are flogged. With regard to what</b> principle <b>do</b> these Sages <b>disagree?</b> One <b>Sage,</b> i.e., Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish, <b>holds</b> that <b>a discriminating</b> minor <b>on the brink of adulthood</b> is considered an adult <b>by Torah law,</b> which is why others are liable for eating an item he consecrated; <b>and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rav Kahana, <b>holds</b> that <b>a discriminating</b> minor <b>on the brink of adulthood</b> is considered an adult <b>by rabbinic law.</b>
<b>Rav Yirmeya raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of a minor girl who is <b>an orphan</b> from her father and her mother or brothers accepted betrothal on her behalf, <b>who vowed, her husband may nullify her</b> vow, like any other husband, despite the fact that this marriage is valid merely by rabbinic law. Rav Yirmeya analyzes this <i>baraita</i>: <b>Granted, if you say</b> that <b>a discriminating</b> minor <b>on the brink of adulthood</b> is considered an adult <b>by rabbinic law,</b> one can explain that a husband whose <b>marriage</b> is <b>by rabbinic law comes and negates a vow</b> that also applies <b>by rabbinic law. But if you say</b> that a discriminating minor on the brink of adulthood is considered an adult <b>by Torah law,</b> can a husband whose <b>marriage</b> is <b>by rabbinic law come and negate a vow</b> that applies <b>by Torah law?</b>
<b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: Her husband may nullify her</b> vows, <b>whichever</b> way <b>you</b> look at it: <b>If</b> the validity of the vows of such a minor applies <b>by rabbinic law,</b> the husband may nullify her vows, as the validity of their marriage <b>is</b> likewise <b>by rabbinic law.</b> And <b>if</b> the validity of a vow by a discriminating minor on the brink of adulthood is <b>by Torah law,</b> which means she would be violating a Torah prohibition, this <b>is</b> the same as the case of <b>a minor</b> who <b>may eat</b> meat from unslaughtered <b>animal carcasses</b> or violate other prohibitions, <b>and the court</b> or any other adult, including her husband in this case, <b>is not commanded to prevent him</b> from doing so,and it does not matter if his nullification was not effective.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But</b> there is still concern for a violation, as <b>when she grows</b> and becomes an adult <b>she will eat</b> the food that she rendered forbidden to herself, relying <b>on the initial nullification</b> of her vow by her husband, which was not valid. At that stage she is an adult, whom the court is certainly commanded to prevent from violating prohibitions.
<b>Rabba bar Livai said</b> that this is not a concern, as <b>her husband nullifies her</b> vows <b>each and every moment,</b> and therefore when she reaches majority he will nullify her vow in a manner that is valid by Torah law. <b>And</b> this <b>is</b> the <i>halakha</i>, that the nullification takes effect by Torah law, only in a case <b>where</b> her husband <b>engaged in intercourse</b> with her after she became an adult, thereby rendering their marriage valid by Torah law.
The Gemara raises another difficulty: <b>But</b> there is a principle that <b>a husband cannot nullify</b> vows of his wife that <b>preceded</b> their marriage; and as she is considered his wife by Torah law only when she becomes an adult, her vow when she was a minor preceded their marriage. The Gemara answers that he can still nullify her vow, <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Rav Pineḥas in the name of Rava, as Rav Pineḥas said in the name of Rava: Any</b> woman <b>who takes a vow,</b> it is from the outset contingent <b>on her husband’s consent</b> that <b>she takes the vow.</b> Since the minor was married by rabbinic law, she vowed on the condition that her husband should agree to her vow, and therefore the nullification is valid by Torah law.
§ The Gemara continues to discuss the validity of the vows of a discriminating minor on the brink of adulthood. <b>Abaye said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a mishna (<i>Terumot</i> 1:3): With regard to <b>a minor who has not grown two hairs, Rabbi Yehuda says: His <i>teruma</i> is not</b> valid <b><i>teruma</i>. Rabbi Yosei says: Until he has reached the age of vows,</b> i.e., when he does not yet have the status of a discriminating minor on the brink of adulthood, <b>his <i>teruma</i> is not</b> valid <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> but <b>once he has reached the age of vows, his <i>teruma</i> is <i>teruma</i>.</b>
The Sages <b>assumed</b> that <b>Rabbi Yosei holds</b> that <b><i>teruma</i> in the present</b> applies <b>by Torah law.</b> They therefore objected: <b>Granted, if you say</b> that <b>a discriminating</b> minor <b>on the brink of adulthood</b> is an adult <b>by Torah law,</b> one can understand that one who is <b>a man by Torah law</b> with regard to vows <b>can come and prepare untithed produce [<i>tivla</i>]</b> for consumption by tithing it, which also applies <b>by Torah law. But if you say</b> that a discriminating minor on the brink of adulthood is an adult <b>by rabbinic law,</b> can one who is <b>a man by rabbinic law come and prepare untithed produce,</b> which is prohibited <b>by Torah law?</b> The Gemara refutes this proof: <b>No,</b> perhaps <b>Rabbi Yosei holds</b> that <b><i>teruma</i> in the present</b> applies <b>by rabbinic law,</b> and this is why he rules that a minor on the brink of adulthood can set aside <i>teruma</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And does Rabbi Yosei hold</b> that <b><i>teruma</i> in the present</b> applies <b>by rabbinic law? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in</b> the anthology called <b><i>Seder Olam</i>:</b> The verse that states with regard to the Jewish people’s return to Eretz Yisrael following their exile: “And the Lord your God will bring you into the land <b>that your fathers possessed, and you shall possess it”</b> (Deuteronomy 30:5).
These two expressions of possession indicate that the Jewish people had <b>a first possession</b> of Eretz Yisrael in the days of Joshua, when Eretz Yisrael was first sanctified with regard to the obligation of its mitzvot, <b>and they had a second</b> possession at the time of Ezra and the return of the Babylonian exile. In other words, the sanctity of the land lapsed when the First Temple was destroyed and the Jews were exiled to Babylonia, and therefore a second sanctification was necessary when they returned to their land. But <b>they</b> will <b>not have a third</b> possession. That is, it will never be necessary to sanctify the land a third time, as the second sanctification was permanent.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> that <b>taught <i>Seder Olam</i>? Rabbi Yosei.</b> Since Rabbi Yosei maintains that the second sanctification of Eretz Yisrael did not lapse even after the destruction of the Second Temple, he must also maintain that <i>teruma</i> in the present applies by Torah law.
The Gemara answers that <b>Rabbi Yosei taught</b> <i>Seder Olam</i> <b>but he does not maintain</b> in accordance with <b>its</b> ruling here. The Gemara adds: <b>So too, it is reasonable</b> that this is so, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to non-sacred <b>dough that became mixed</b> with <i>teruma</i> dough, <b>or which was leavened with leaven of <i>teruma</i>,</b>

Daf 47a

it is <b>subject to the obligation</b> of separating <b><i>ḥalla</i>,</b> the portion of the dough designated for the priest. <b>And</b> although <i>teruma</i> fell into it, that produce does not have the status of <i>teruma</i>, as the <i>teruma</i> was nullified by a majority of non-sacred produce. Consequently, <b>it is not rendered unfit</b> for consumption, i.e., rendered ritually impure, <b>by one</b> who was ritually impure <b>who immersed that day</b> and is waiting for nightfall for his purification process to be completed. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon deem</b> the dough <b>exempt from the</b> obligation of separating <b><i>ḥalla</i>,</b> as this obligation does not apply to <i>teruma</i>, and the entire dough is exempt due to the mixture of <i>teruma</i> it contains.
The Sages <b>assumed</b> that <b>the one who said</b> that <b><i>teruma</i></b> in the present applies <b>by Torah law</b> maintains that <b><i>ḥalla</i></b> likewise applies in the present <b>by Torah law,</b> whereas <b>the one who said</b> that <b><i>teruma</i></b> in the present applies <b>by rabbinic law</b> holds that <b><i>ḥalla</i></b> also applies <b>by rabbinic law.</b> If so, <b>granted, if you say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yosei holds</b> that <b><i>ḥalla</i> in the present</b> applies <b>by rabbinic law,</b> one can understand that <b>a mixture</b> which has the status of <i>teruma</i> <b>by rabbinic law comes and abrogates</b> the obligation of separating <b><i>ḥalla</i>,</b> which also applies <b>by rabbinic law.</b>
