The Gemara analyzes the exchange cited above. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri says</b> that this <i>halakha</i> can be derived by <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>If</b> the carcass of a kosher bird <b>transmits severe</b> ritual <b>impurity without thought,</b> should it <b>not transmit lenient impurity without thought?</b>
The Rabbis <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri: <b>No,</b> this is not a valid <i>a fortiori</i> inference. <b>If you said</b> so <b>with regard to severe ritual impurity, that</b> is because it <b>does not assume</b> its status <b>with that</b> requirement of thought.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the clause: It <b>does not assume</b> its status <b>with that</b> requirement of thought? In what manner is thought required for the lenient impurity of food it imparts in the case of a bird carcass but not required for the severe impurity it imparts when it is in the throat? <b>Rava said</b> that <b>this is what</b> the Rabbis <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri: <b>No, if you said</b> that there is no requirement of thought

Daf 51a

<b>in</b> a case of <b>severe</b> ritual <b>impurity,</b> i.e., when the carcass of a kosher bird renders one’s garments impure while it is in his throat, <b>which does not render</b> impure another item <b>similar to it,</b> i.e., a person who is rendered impure by the carcass does not render another man impure; <b>shall you</b> also <b>say</b> that there is no requirement of thought <b>in</b> the case of <b>lenient impurity,</b> i.e., when the carcass transmits impurity as food, <b>which does render</b> impure another item <b>similar to it?</b> Food that became impure transmits impurity to other food, albeit by rabbinic law.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rava: But in that case, <b>all the more so</b> impurity as food should apply without thought. <b>If severe impurity,</b> i.e., the unique impurity of the carcass of a kosher bird, <b>which is lenient</b> in the sense <b>that it does not render</b> impure another item <b>similar to it,</b> nevertheless <b>imparts impurity without thought,</b> i.e., without one knowing what is in his throat, then with regard to <b>lenient impurity,</b> i.e., the carcass’s impurity as food, <b>which is</b> more <b>severe</b> in the sense <b>that it renders</b> impure another item <b>similar to it, isn’t it logical that it</b> should <b>impart impurity without thought?</b>
<b>Rather, Rav Sheshet said</b> that <b>this</b> is what the Rabbis, who replied to Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri, <b>are saying: No, if you said</b> that thought is not required <b>with regard to severe impurity,</b> i.e., the carcass of a kosher bird in the throat, <b>as it does not require</b> contact with a liquid for it to be rendered <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity, <b>shall you</b> also <b>say</b> that thought is not required <b>with regard to lenient impurity,</b> i.e., its impurity as food, <b>where</b> it <b>does require</b> contact with a liquid for it to be rendered <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity?
The Gemara asks: <b>And does</b> the carcass of a kosher bird <b>require</b> contact with a liquid for it to be rendered <b>susceptible</b> to impurity as food? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Three matters were stated with regard to the carcass of a kosher bird:</b> In order for it to be susceptible to impurity as food, it <b>requires</b> a person’s <b>intent</b> to eat it; <b>and it transmits impurity</b> to garments by rendering one who swallows it ritually impure <b>only</b> when an olive-bulk of it is <b>in the throat; and it does not require</b> contact with a liquid for it to be rendered <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity?
The Gemara answers: <b>Although it does not require</b> contact <b>with a creeping animal</b> for it to be rendered <b>susceptible</b> to impurity, i.e., it is inherently impure, nevertheless <b>it does require</b> contact with <b>water</b> or another liquid for it to be rendered <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about being rendered <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity by contact with <b>a creeping animal that it does not require</b> this contact? This ruling is <b>in accordance with that which the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught.</b> If so, it should <b>also not require</b> contact with <b>water</b> or another liquid for it to be rendered <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity, likewise <b>in accordance with that which the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught.</b>
<b>As the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states that seeds contract impurity from the carcass of a creeping animal only if they first come into contact with water: “And if any part of their carcass fall <b>upon any sowing seed that is to be sown,</b> it is pure. But if water be put upon the seed, and any part of their carcass fall thereon, it is impure unto you” (Leviticus 11:37–38). This passage teaches that as long as water did not fall on the seeds, they are not susceptible to ritual impurity. This <i>halakha</i> applies to all items similar to seeds.
Accordingly, <b>just as seeds, which will never transmit impurity severe</b> enough to transmit to humans, like any food, <b>require</b> contact with liquid to be rendered <b>susceptible</b> to impurity, <b>so too, all</b> items <b>that will never transmit severe impurity require</b> contact with liquid to be rendered <b>susceptible</b> to impurity. This <b>excludes the carcass of a kosher bird, which will ultimately transmit impurity severe</b> enough to be transmitted to a human, i.e., when it is in his throat, and therefore <b>it does not require</b> contact with liquid for it to be rendered <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity.
<b>Rather, Rava said, and some say</b> that it was <b>Rav Pappa</b> who said: The Rabbis’ rejection of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri’s <i>a fortiori</i> inference is not based on the specific <i>halakha</i> of impurity of food imparted by the carcass of a bird. Rather, they are referring to the fact that <b>in general</b> there is no item under the common <b>name of severe impurity</b> that requires contact with a liquid for it to be rendered susceptible to ritual impurity. By contrast, with regard to the common <b>name of lenient impurity</b> as food, <b>in general</b> the items in this category require contact with a liquid for them to be rendered susceptible to impurity, despite the fact that the particular case of the carcass of a kosher bird is an exception. Therefore, intent is required for lenient impurity even in the case of a carcass of a kosher bird.
§ <b>Rava says: And Rabbi Yoḥanan concedes with regard to</b> the obligation to <b>tithe, that intent</b> while the produce is <b>attached</b> to the ground <b>is considered intent. Rava said: From where do I say</b> that <b>this</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? It is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Ma’asrot</i> 3:9) that deals with the obligation to tithe: <b>Savory, hyssop [<i>veha’ezov</i>], and thyme [<i>vehakoranit</i>],</b> i.e., various types of hyssop plants, that were growing <b>in a courtyard,</b> are eaten by some people although they are not specifically intended for human consumption. Therefore, <b>if they were protected</b> by the owners, those owners are <b>obligated</b> to separate tithes from them.
The Gemara clarifies the mishna: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of this ruling? <b>If we say</b> that it is referring to a case <b>where one initially planted them for human</b> consumption, does it <b>need to be said</b> that there is an obligation to tithe if they are protected by the owners? It is clear that in such a situation the criteria for the obligation to tithe, i.e., that it is human food which is protected, have been met. <b>Rather,</b> is it <b>not</b> referring to a case <b>where one initially planted them</b> to be fed <b>to an animal,</b> and nevertheless the mishna <b>teaches: If</b> the owner reconsidered their designation and decided to use them for human consumption and <b>they were protected</b> by the owners, the owners are <b>obligated</b> to tithe them. This apparently indicates that intent while the produce is attached to the ground is considered intent.
<b>Rav Ashi said</b> that Rava’s proof is inconclusive, for the following reason: <b>Here we are dealing with a courtyard where</b> these various types of hyssop plants <b>grew by themselves, and</b> where they are <b>unspecified,</b> they are <b>intended for human</b> consumption. Therefore, they meet the first criteria for the obligation to tithe, as they are considered food. <b>And</b> the mishna addresses the second requirement, that the food must be protected, and <b>this</b> is what it <b>is saying: If the courtyard protects its produce,</b> the owners <b>are obligated</b> in tithes, <b>and if not, they are exempt.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi raises</b> a further <b>objection</b> to Rava’s explanation from a mishna (50a): <b>Any</b> food from <b>which</b> one is <b>obligated to</b> separate <b>tithes becomes impure with the ritual impurity of food. But if it is so,</b> as Rava claimed, that intent while the produce is attached to the ground is considered intent with respect to the obligation to tithe, despite the fact that it is not considered intent with regard to impurity, then the mishna’s blanket statement is inaccurate. Rav Ashi elaborates: After all, <b>there are these</b> endives that were initially planted in order to feed to an animal and later the owner reconsidered their designation and decided to use them for human consumption, from <b>which</b> one is <b>obligated to</b> separate <b>tithe, but which do not become impure with the ritual impurity of food.</b>
<b>Rava said</b> in response that <b>this</b> is what the mishna <b>is saying: Any type</b> of food from <b>which</b> one is <b>obligated to</b> separate <b>tithe becomes impure with the ritual impurity of food.</b> In other words, this is referring to types of food, not to all situations. It is possible for a particular circumstance to be an exception to this principle.
The Gemara adds that <b>this too stands to reason,</b> that the mishna is referring only to types of food, not situations, <b>from</b> the fact <b>that the latter clause teaches</b> (51b): With regard to <b>any</b> animal from <b>which</b> the owner is <b>obligated to</b> give <b>the first shearing</b> of its wool, he is <b>obligated to</b> have <b>gifts</b> of the priesthood taken from it, i.e., the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw, if it was slaughtered. <b>And there are</b> animals from <b>which</b> one is <b>obligated to</b> have <b>gifts</b> of the priesthood taken from it, <b>but</b> from which he is <b>not obligated to</b> give <b>the first shearing.</b>
<b>And if it is so,</b> that the principles of the mishna are all-inclusive, one can raise the following difficulty: <b>But there is</b> the specific case of <b>an animal with a wound that will cause it to die within twelve months [<i>tereifa</i>],</b> from <b>which</b> one is <b>obligated to</b> give <b>the first shearing, but one is not obligated to</b> have <b>gifts</b> of the priesthood taken from it, as it may not be eaten. This proves that Rava is correct, that the mishna is not referring to all circumstances, but only to general categories.
<b>Ravina said,</b> rejecting this proof: It is possible that the mishna is referring to all circumstances, and as for the difficulty with regard to a <i>tereifa</i>, one can say that in accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> mishna? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, as we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon exempts the</b> owner of <b>a <i>tereifa</i> from</b> the mitzva of <b>the first shearing.</b>
<b>Rav Shimi bar Ashi said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a <i>baraita</i> that the mishna is not referring to all circumstances, but only to general categories: With regard to <b>one who declares his vineyard ownerless, and who arose the</b> next <b>morning and picked grapes</b> from the vineyard before anyone else took possession of them, he is <b>obligated in</b> the mitzva of leaving for the poor <b>individual fallen</b> grapes <b>[<i>peret</i>], and in</b> the mitzva of leaving for them <b>incompletely formed clusters</b> of grapes <b>[<i>uve’olelot</i>], and in</b> the mitzva of <b>forgotten</b> clusters, <b>and in <i>pe’a</i>.</b> The Torah includes such cases in the phrase: “Leave them for the poor and for the stranger” (Leviticus 19:10, 23:22), which is written with regard to all these mitzvot. <b>And he is exempt from</b> the obligation to separate <b>the tithe</b> from the grapes. Since the vineyard is ownerless, there is no obligation to tithe the produce.
The Gemara explains the proof: <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna (50a): With regard to <b>any</b> produce from <b>which</b> one is <b>obligated to</b> designate <b><i>pe’a</i>,</b> one is likewise <b>obligated to</b> separate <b>tithes? Rather,</b> must one <b>not conclude from</b> the mishna that Rava is correct in asserting that the mishna <b>is teaching</b> only principles with regard to each <b>type</b> of produce, but there are exceptions in certain circumstances? The Gemara answers that one should in fact <b>conclude from</b> the mishna that Rava is correct.
§ With regard to the obligations of <i>pe’a</i> and tithes, the Gemara notes that <b>we learned</b> in a mishna <b>elsewhere</b> (<i>Pe’a</i> 3:2): The Rabbis and Rabbi Akiva disagree with regard to a case where one harvested several separate patches in a field. Rabbi Akiva rules that each patch requires its own <i>pe’a</i>, whereas the Rabbis maintain that one <i>pe’a</i> is required for all of the patches. Nevertheless, <b>the Rabbis concede to Rabbi Akiva in</b> the case of <b>one who sows dill or mustard in two or three</b> separate <b>locations</b> in a single field, <b>that he leaves <i>pe’a</i> for each and every one</b> of these plots on its own, rather than one corner for all of them.

Daf 51b

The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> with regard to <b>dill,</b> from <b>which</b> one is <b>obligated to</b> designate <b><i>pe’a</i>,</b> as stated in the mishna, one must also <b>be obligated to</b> separate <b>tithe,</b> since if the obligation of <i>pe’a</i> applies then the obligation of tithes likewise applies. <b>As we learned</b> in the mishna (50a): With regard to <b>any</b> produce from <b>which</b> one is <b>obligated to</b> designate <b><i>pe’a</i>,</b> one is likewise <b>obligated to</b> separate <b>tithe.</b>
<b>And from</b> the fact that with regard to dill one is <b>obligated to</b> separate <b>tithe,</b> it follows that it <b>becomes impure with the ritual impurity of food.</b> As the mishna on 50a states: Any food that is obligated in tithes becomes impure with the ritual impurity of food. <b>Apparently, any item that is prepared</b> in order <b>to</b> add <b>taste</b> to food, such as dill, <b>becomes impure with the ritual impurity of food, as this dill is prepared</b> in order <b>to</b> add <b>taste</b> to food.
<b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> to this conclusion from a mishna (<i>Okatzin</i> 3:5), which deals with the ritual impurity of food: With regard to spices such as <b>costus, amomum, chief spices, root of crowfoot, asafoetida, peppers, and a cake of safflower,</b> although their function is merely to add taste to food, they are considered food for the purposes of the following <i>halakha</i>: They <b>may be bought with</b> second-<b>tithe money,</b> which must be taken to Jerusalem and used to purchase food. <b>But</b> they are not considered food insofar as <b>they do not become impure with the ritual impurity of food.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri said to</b> Rabbi Akiva: <b>If</b> they are considered food to the extent that <b>they may be bought with</b> second-<b>tithe money, for what</b> reason are <b>they not</b> considered food in terms of <b>becoming impure with the ritual impurity of food? And if they do not become impure</b> with the ritual impurity of food because they are not considered food, then <b>they should also not be bought with</b> second-<b>tithe money.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri said</b> with regard to this <i>halakha</i>: <b>They counted</b> the opinions of the Sages, <b>and they concluded that</b> these spices <b>may not be bought with</b> second-<b>tithe money, and</b> they do <b>not become impure</b> with the ritual <b>impurity of food.</b> This apparently contradicts the previous claim that dill, which is a spice, becomes impure with the ritual impurity of food.
<b>Rav Ḥisda says</b> the following resolution of the difficulty: <b>When that</b> <i>baraita</i>, which indicates that dill is considered food and can contract the impurity of food, <b>is taught,</b> it is referring <b>to dill that is prepared for a spice dish [<i>likhmakh</i>],</b> i.e., to be ground and placed in a Babylonian spice, <i>kutaḥ</i>, which is used as a dip.
<b>Rav Ashi said: I said this <i>halakha</i> of</b> Rav Ḥisda’s <b>before Rav Kahana,</b> and he commented: <b>Do not say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is referring specifically to a case <b>where</b> the <b>dill</b> was prepared <b>for a spice dish</b> from the outset, which would indicate that if dill is <b>undesignated</b> then it is intended to be an ingredient <b>in a pot</b> of food. <b>Rather, undesignated dill</b> is also <b>prepared for a spice dish. As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Okatzin</i> 3:4): With regard to <i>teruma</i> <b>dill, once it imparted flavor in a pot</b> of food and was removed from the pot, it <b>is no</b> longer <b>subject to</b> the prohibition of a non-priest partaking of <b><i>teruma</i>, and it can no</b> longer <b>become impure with the ritual impurity of food.</b>
Rav Kahana explains the proof: It can be inferred from this mishna that <b>until</b> the dill has <b>imparted flavor in a pot</b> of food it <b>is subject to</b> the prohibition of a non-priest partaking of <b><i>teruma</i>, and it can become impure with the ritual impurity of food. And if</b> it <b>enters your mind</b> that <b>undesignated</b> dill is intended as an ingredient <b>in a pot</b> of food, then <b>even when</b> one did <b>not place</b> the dill in a pot, the same <i>halakha</i> with respect to <i>teruma</i> and impurity should apply, as when it is <b>undesignated</b> the dill is intended as an ingredient <b>in a pot</b> of food. <b>Rather,</b> must one <b>not conclude from</b> the mishna that <b>undesignated</b> dill is <b>prepared for a spice dish?</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>Learn from</b> the mishna that this is the case.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>any</b> animal, i.e., sheep and rams, from <b>which one is obligated</b> by Torah law (see Deuteronomy 18:4) <b>to</b> give <b>the first shearing</b> of its wool to a priest, he <b>is obligated to</b> have <b>gifts</b> of the priesthood, i.e., the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw, which must be removed from slaughtered animals, taken from it (see Deuteronomy 18:3). <b>And there are</b> animals from <b>which one is obligated to</b> have <b>gifts</b> of the priesthood taken from them, e.g., cattle and goats, <b>but</b> from which <b>he is not obligated to</b> give <b>the first shearing.</b>
The mishna teaches a similar principle: For <b>all</b> Sabbatical-Year produce <b>to which there</b> applies the obligation of <b>eradication</b> from the house when it ceases to be available to the animals in the field, <b>there is</b> the sanctity of <b>Sabbatical-</b>Year produce upon <b>it,</b> i.e., it may not be used for commerce and is ownerless while it is attached to the ground. <b>And there</b> is produce <b>for which there is</b> the sanctity of <b>Sabbatical-</b>Year produce, <b>but for</b> which <b>there is no</b> obligation of <b>eradication</b> from the house, e.g., produce that is preserved in the ground and does not cease to be available in the field.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that the sanctity of Sabbatical-Year produce applies to any produce upon which there is an obligation of eradication, but the converse is not necessarily the case. The Gemara cites an example of plants whose various parts illustrate these <i>halakhot</i>: Plants <b>such as the wild arum leaf and the ceterach,</b> which cease to be available in the field during the rainy season, are subject to eradication and to the sanctity of the Sabbatical Year. Examples of the second <i>halakha</i> of the mishna, that <b>there is</b> produce <b>for which there is</b> the sanctity of <b>Sabbatical-</b>Year produce <b>but</b> for which <b>there is no</b> obligation of <b>eradication</b> from the house, include the <b>root of the wild arum and the root of the ceterach.</b>
The Gemara explains <b>that it is written</b> in connection to the Sabbatical Year: <b>“And for the cattle and the beasts that are in your land, all its produce may be eaten”</b> (Leviticus 25:7), from which it is derived: <b>As long as the undomesticated animals eat</b> a type of produce <b>from the field, you may feed</b> that type of produce <b>to your domesticated animal in the house,</b> as it still remains in the field. But if that type of produce <b>has ceased for the undomesticated animals in the field, you must cease</b> feeding it <b>to your domesticated animal in the house.</b> This is the obligation of eradication. <b>And these,</b> the root of the wild arum and the ceterach, <b>have not ceased for undomesticated animals</b> in the field, and therefore there is no obligation of eradication.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> It is written: “Whatever has fins and scales in the waters, in the seas, and in the rivers, you may eat them” (Leviticus 11:9). There is a principle with regard to the signs indicating that fish are kosher: <b>Any</b> fish <b>that has scales has fins; and there are</b> fish <b>that have fins but do not have scales.</b> Similarly, with regard to kosher animals it is written: “Whatever parts the hoof, and is wholly cloven-footed, and chews the cud, among the beasts, that you may eat” (Leviticus 11:3). <b>Any</b> animal <b>that has horns has hooves; and there are</b> animals <b>that have hooves but do not have horns.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that <b>any</b> fish <b>that has scales</b> also has fins and therefore is <b>a kosher fish.</b> The mishna also stated that <b>there are</b> fish <b>that have fins but do not have scales.</b> Such a fish is <b>a non-kosher fish.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Since we rely</b> exclusively <b>upon</b> the sign of the <b>scales,</b> as a fish that has scales necessarily has fins as well, <b>why do I</b> need the sign of <b>fins that the Merciful One writes</b> in the Torah as one of the criteria of kosher fish?
The Gemara answers: <b>If the Merciful One</b> had <b>not</b> also <b>written</b> the sign of <b>fins</b> in the Torah, <b>I would say: What</b> does the word <b><i>kaskeset</i>,</b> scales, <b>that is written</b> in the Torah mean? It does not mean scales, but <b>fins. And</b> I would therefore say that <b>even a non-kosher fish,</b> which has fins but no scales, is permitted. Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes</b> both signs, <b>fins and scales.</b>
The Gemara further asks: <b>But now that the Merciful One wrote</b> in the Torah <b>fins and <i>kaskeset</i>, from where do we</b> derive that <b><i>kaskeset</i></b> denotes <b>clothing,</b> i.e., scales, rather than fins? The Gemara answers: We derive it from a verse, <b>as it is written</b> about Goliath the Philistine: <b>“And he was clad with a coat of mail [<i>kaskasim</i>]”</b> (I Samuel 17:5).
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if there is proof that <i>kaskeset</i> means scales, the question returns: <b>Let the Merciful One write</b> only <b>“scales” and</b> then there would be <b>no need</b> to write <b>“fins.” Rabbi Abbahu says, and likewise</b> a Sage of <b>the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught,</b> that this is in accordance with the verse: “The Lord was pleased, for His righteousness’ sake, <b>to make Torah great and glorious”</b> (Isaiah 42:21).In this context, this means that it is fitting for the Torah to state all the characteristics of a kosher animal rather than merely state that which is absolutely necessary.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> This mishna teaches a generalization that is similar to the previous ones: <b>Anything that requires a blessing after</b> one partakes of <b>it requires a blessing beforehand. And there exist</b> items <b>that require a blessing before but</b> do <b>not require a blessing thereafter.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that there are items that require a blessing before but not after. The Gemara inquires: <b>What</b> case does this <i>halakha</i> in the mishna <b>add?</b> The Gemara answers: It serves <b>to add</b> the case of <b>vegetables,</b> as one recites a blessing before eating them but not afterward. The Gemara asks: <b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak, who</b> maintains that one <b>recites a blessing on vegetables</b> after eating them, <b>what</b> case does this <i>halakha</i> in the mishna <b>add?</b> The Gemara answers: It serves <b>to add</b> the case of <b>water,</b> as one recites a blessing before drinking it but not afterward.
The Gemara further asks: <b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Pappa, who</b> rules that <b>one recites a blessing on water</b> after drinking it, <b>what</b> case does this <i>halakha</i> in the mishna serve <b>to add?</b> The Gemara answers that the mishna, which does not explicitly mention food, serves <b>to add mitzvot.</b> In other words, one recites a blessing before performing a mitzva, e.g., wearing ritual fringes or taking the <i>lulav</i> and the like, but one does not recite a blessing after its fulfillment. The Gemara asks: <b>And according to</b> the <b>residents of the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>who recite</b> the following <b>blessing after they remove their phylacteries: Who sanctified us with His mitzvot and commanded us to keep His laws, what</b> does this <i>halakha</i> in the mishna <b>come to add?</b> The Gemara answers: It serves <b>to add</b> the case of

Daf 52a

fragrant <b>spices.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A young girl who</b> reached the age of puberty and <b>grew two</b> pubic <b>hairs</b> is an adult. If her childless husband dies, <b>she either performs <i>ḥalitza</i></b> and is thereby permitted to marry anyone, <b>or enters into levirate marriage</b> with her husband’s brother. <b>And</b> furthermore, such a girl is <b>obligated to</b> fulfill <b>all the mitzvot stated in the Torah</b> in which women are obligated.
<b>And likewise, a young boy who</b> reached the age of puberty and <b>grew two</b> pubic <b>hairs</b> is an adult and is <b>obligated to</b> fulfill <b>all the mitzvot stated in the Torah. And he is fit to be</b> declared <b>a stubborn and rebellious son</b> if he performs the actions that warrant that designation, <b>from when he grows two</b> pubic <b>hairs until</b> his <b>beard will form a circle.</b> During that period, although he is an adult and punishable for his actions, he is incapable of fathering a child. Consequently, as he is a son and not a father, he can be designated a stubborn and rebellious son.
The mishna explains that the reference is to <b>the lower,</b> pubic, hair, <b>and not to the upper,</b> facial, hair. <b>But</b> the term beard is used, despite its being subject to misinterpretation, due to the fact <b>that the Sages spoke euphemistically.</b>
<b>A young girl who</b> reached the age of puberty and <b>grew two</b> pubic <b>hairs can no</b> longer <b>perform refusal</b> to end a marriage with a husband to whom she was married as a minor by her mother and brothers after her father’s death. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> She retains the right to perform refusal <b>until</b> the pubic hair will grow to the extent <b>that the black</b> hair <b>will be preponderant</b> in the pubic area.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara raises an objection: <b>But since we learned</b> in the mishna that a young girl who reached the age of puberty and grew two pubic hairs is considered an adult and is <b>obligated to</b> fulfill <b>all the mitzvot stated in the Torah, why do I</b> need the mishna to also teach: <b>She either performs <i>ḥalitza</i> or enters into levirate marriage.</b> These specific examples are included in the broader statement.
The Gemara explains: This emphasis serves <b>to exclude</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yosei, who said: Man,</b> i.e., an adult man, <b>is written in the passage</b> of <i>ḥalitza</i>: “And if the man does not wish to take his brother’s wife” (Deuteronomy 25:7). <b>But</b> with regard to the <b>woman, whether</b> she is <b>an adult or whether</b> she is <b>a minor,</b> she can be released by <i>ḥalitza</i>, as the Torah does not specify her age. The mishna <b>teaches us that</b> the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yosei. Rather, <b>if</b> she <b>grew two</b> pubic <b>hairs,</b> then <b>yes,</b> she can perform <i>ḥalitza</i>, whereas <b>if</b> she did <b>not</b> grow two hairs, she may <b>not</b> perform <i>ḥalitza</i> or enter into levirate marriage. <b>What is the reason</b> for this ruling? It is that the <i>halakha</i> of the <b>woman</b> is <b>like</b> that of the <b>man,</b> as a woman is juxtaposed to man in this passage.
The Gemara asks further: <b>And since we learned</b> in the continuation of the mishna: <b>And likewise, a young boy who</b> reached the age of puberty and <b>grew two</b> pubic <b>hairs</b> is an adult, <b>why do I</b> need the mishna to add explicitly: Is <b>obligated to</b> fulfill <b>all the mitzvot stated in the Torah?</b>
<b>And if you would say</b> that the mishna specified this <b>because</b> it <b>wanted to teach</b> the particular <i>halakha</i>: <b>And he is fit to be</b> declared <b>a stubborn and rebellious son,</b> that cannot be the reason, as <b>we</b> already <b>learned</b> that <b><i>halakha</i></b> on <b>another occasion</b> in a mishna (<i>Sanhedrin</i> 68b): <b>When</b> is such a boy liable to receive the death penalty imposed upon <b>a stubborn and rebellious son? From when he grows two</b> pubic <b>hairs until</b> his <b>beard will form a circle.</b> The reference is to <b>the lower,</b> pubic, hair <b>and not to the upper,</b> facial hair, <b>but</b> the term beard is used, due to the fact <b>that the Sages spoke euphemistically.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Yes,</b> it <b>is indeed so,</b> i.e., it is not necessary for the mishna to specify with regard to a boy that he is obligated to fulfill all the mitzvot stated in the Torah. <b>But since</b> the mishna <b>specified</b> this <b>matter</b> in the case <b>of a young girl,</b> it <b>also specified</b> this <b>matter</b> in the case <b>of a young boy.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: <b>A young girl who</b> reached the age of puberty and <b>grew</b> two pubic hairs can no longer perform refusal to end a marriage with a husband to whom she was married as a minor by her mother and brothers after her father’s death. Rabbi Yehuda maintains that she retains the right of refusal until the pubic hair grows to the extent that the black hair is preponderant in the pubic area. <b>Rabbi Abbahu says</b> that <b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Yehuda concedes</b> to the Rabbis <b>that if she engaged in intercourse</b> with her husband <b>after she grew two</b> pubic <b>hairs,</b> she <b>can no longer perform refusal.</b> This is because the act of intercourse renders her betrothed to him by Torah law, and refusal is a rabbinic enactment that is effective only with regard to a betrothal that applies by rabbinic law.
<b>Rav Kahana’s colleagues thought to perform an action in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> in the mishna, <b>and</b> to permit a young girl who had grown two pubic hairs to perform refusal, <b>even though she</b> had <b>engaged in intercourse</b> with her husband after growing two hairs. They held that until the pubic hair grows to the extent that the black hair is preponderant in the pubic area, her betrothal does not apply by Torah law.
<b>Rav Kahana said to</b> his colleagues: <b>Didn’t the incident involving Rabbi Yishmael’s daughter,</b> who was married as a minor by her mother and brothers after her father’s death, transpire <b>in that manner? As she came to the study hall to refuse</b> her marriage, <b>and her son was riding on her shoulders. And on that</b> very <b>day, Rabbi Yishmael’s statement,</b> that a young girl may perform refusal even if she engaged in intercourse with her husband after growing two hairs, <b>was mentioned in the study hall. And she cried</b> with <b>a great weeping in the study hall,</b> as a result of the incident.
The Sages who were in the study hall <b>said:</b> Could it be that with regard to <b>a matter that that righteous</b> Rabbi Yishmael <b>said,</b> i.e., that she can perform refusal, <b>his offspring would stumble upon it?</b> The consequence of her refusal is that she is considered to have borne the child retroactively out of wedlock.
<b>As Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel says in the name of Rabbi Yishmael:</b> The verse states with regard to a <i>sota</i>: <b>“And neither was she taken”</b> (Numbers 5:13), i.e., raped. In this case <b>she is prohibited</b> to her husband. It may be inferred that if she <b>was taken</b> forcefully <b>she is permitted</b> to her husband. <b>And there is</b> a case of <b>another</b> woman <b>where, even though she was not taken</b> forcefully, but was willing, she nevertheless remains <b>permitted. And which</b> case <b>is this?</b> This is referring to one <b>whose betrothal</b> was <b>a mistaken betrothal, as, even if her son</b> from this marriage <b>is riding on her shoulders she may perform refusal and go</b> off as pleases <b>her.</b> Although she engaged in intercourse with her husband after growing two pubic hairs, she was relying on the original betrothal, which was a mistaken betrothal, and did not intend to become betrothed to him by means of this intercourse, which would have rendered her betrothed by Torah law. She may therefore nullify the betrothal by means of refusal.
<b>And</b> the Gemara relates that as a result of the event involving Rabbi Yishmael’s daughter, the Sages assembled, <b>counted</b> the votes, <b>and concluded: Until when may</b> a young <b>girl perform refusal? Until</b> she <b>grows two</b> pubic <b>hairs.</b> Once Rav Kahana’s colleagues heard this, they <b>retracted</b> and <b>did not perform an action</b> in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda in the mishna, to permit the girl to perform refusal as they had originally planned.
The Gemara further relates that <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak and the disciples of Rabbi Ḥanina performed an action in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> in the mishna, <b>and</b> permitted a young girl who had grown two pubic hairs to perform refusal, <b>even though she</b> had <b>engaged in intercourse</b> with her husband after growing two hairs. <b>Rav Shemen bar Abba</b> subsequently <b>went</b> and <b>stated</b> this story <b>before Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> and <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan went</b> and <b>stated it before Rabbi Yehuda Nesia.</b> Rabbi Yehuda Nesia <b>sent a constable [<i>ballasha</i>] and removed</b> that girl from her second husband.
With regard to Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion, that the black hair must be preponderant in the pubic area, <b>Rav Ḥisda says</b> that <b>Mar Ukva says:</b> This does <b>not</b> mean <b>that</b> the <b>black</b> hair must <b>literally be preponderant</b> in the pubic area. <b>Rather, there must be two hairs lying down, so that it appears as though the black</b> hairs in the pubic area cover an area <b>greater than the white</b> area uncovered by hair. <b>Rava says:</b> Rabbi Yehuda means that there are <b>two hairs that surround</b> the pubic area <b>from end to end.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that the growth of two hairs is a sign of becoming an adult. The Gemara clarifies the details of this <i>halakha</i>. <b>Rabbi Ḥelbo says</b> that <b>Rav Huna says:</b> These <b>two hairs that</b> the Sages <b>said</b> are a sign of adulthood <b>must have follicles at their roots. Rav Malkiyyu says</b> that <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava</b> says: If there are two <b>follicles</b> next to each other, they constitute a sign of adulthood <b>even if there are no hairs</b> in them. The assumption is that follicles do not exist without hair, and therefore there must have been hairs there that fell out.
This <i>halakha</i> was stated by a Sage by the name of Rav Malkiyyu. To prevent confusion between his rulings and those of the similarly named Rav Malkiyya, <b>Rabbi Ḥanina, son of Rav Ika, says:</b> The <i>halakha</i> involving <b>a skewer,</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>maidservants, and</b> the <i>halakha</i> involving hair <b>follicles</b> were all stated by <b>Rav Malkiyyu.</b> By contrast, the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the <b>forelock [<i>belorit</i>],</b> the <i>halakha</i> involving <b>burnt ashes, and</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>cheese</b> were all stated by a different Sage named <b>Rav Malkiyya.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa says:</b> The aforementioned <i>halakhot</i> that relate to <b>a mishna or a <i>baraita</i></b> were stated by <b>Rav Malkiyya,</b> whereas <b><i>halakhot</i></b> that do not refer to a mishna or <i>baraita</i> but are independent statements of <i>amora’im</i> were taught by <b>Rav Malkiyyu. And a mnemonic</b> to remember this is: <b>The mishna is a queen [<i>malketa</i>],</b> i.e., the comments that are referring to a mishna were issued by Rav Malkiyya, whose name is similar to the Aramaic term for queen.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the difference <b>between</b> the opinion of Rabbi Ḥanina, son of Rav Ika, and Rav Pappa? The Gemara answers: The difference <b>between them</b> is with regard to which Sage taught the <i>halakha</i> involving <b>maidservants.</b> Rav Pappa maintains that it was taught by Rav Malkiyya, as it is referring to a dispute in a mishna. By contrast, according to Rabbi Ḥanina, this <i>halakha</i> was stated by Rav Malkiyyu.
With regard to the <i>halakha</i> of Rav Malkiyyu itself, concerning follicles, <b>Rav Ashi says: Mar Zutra told me</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina of Sura</b> posed the following <b>difficulty:</b> If it is correct that follicles suffice as a sign of adulthood, <b>let</b> the <b><i>tanna</i></b> of the mishna <b>not evade</b> the issue, <b>but</b> rather let him <b>teach us</b> explicitly that <b>follicles</b> are a sign of adulthood even if they do not contain hair. The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> the mishna had <b>taught us</b> the case of <b>follicles, I would say</b> that they are not considered a sign of adulthood <b>until there are two hairs in two follicles.</b> By omitting any mention of follicles in the mishna, the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches us that even two hairs in one follicle</b> are a sign of adulthood.
The Gemara asks: <b>And is there</b> actually <b>a case like this,</b> of two hairs in one follicle? <b>But isn’t it written: “He crushes me with a tempest, and multiplies my wounds without cause”</b> (Job 9:17); <b>and Rava said</b> with regard to this verse: <b>Job blasphemed with a tempest,</b> and <b>with a tempest he was answered. He blasphemed with a tempest,</b> as Job <b>said before</b> God: <b>Master of the Universe, perhaps a tempest passed before You and You confused Iyyov,</b> Job, <b>with <i>oyev</i>,</b> enemy. <b>With a tempest he was answered,</b> as the verse states: <b>“Then the Lord answered</b>

Daf 52b

<b>Job out of the tempest, and said”</b> (Job 38:1–3) <b>to him:</b> Greatest <b>imbecile in the world! I have created many hairs on a person’s head, and for each and every hair I created</b> its own <b>distinct follicle, so that two hairs should not draw</b> sustenance <b>from one follicle. As, were two</b> hairs <b>to draw</b> sustenance <b>from one follicle,</b> it would <b>weaken a man’s vision.</b> Now if <b>I did not confuse one follicle with another, would I confuse</b> a man named <b>Iyyov with <i>oyev</i>?</b> This indicates that two hairs do not grow from one follicle.
The Gemara answers: It is <b>not difficult; that</b> statement above, that two hairs in one follicle is a valid sign of adulthood, is referring to the hairs <b>in</b> the rest of a person’s <b>body,</b> whereas <b>this</b> statement, that there cannot be two hairs in one follicle, is referring to the hairs <b>on</b> a person’s <b>head.</b>
<b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> The <b>two hairs that</b> the Sages <b>said</b> are signs of adulthood are valid signs <b>even if</b> they are not adjacent; but rather <b>one</b> hair is <b>on the spoon-</b>shaped area above his organ <b>and one</b> is <b>on the</b> young boy’s <b>testicles.</b>
The Gemara notes <b>that</b> this <b>is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The <b>two hairs that</b> the Sages <b>said</b> are signs of adulthood are valid signs <b>even</b> if <b>one</b> hair is <b>on</b> the young girl’s <b>back,</b> below her pubic area, <b>and one on her lower abdomen.</b> The same applies if <b>one</b> hair is <b>on the finger joints of her hand and one</b> hair is <b>on the toe joints of her foot.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda, of the village of Akko, who said</b> it <b>in the name of Rabbi Shimon. And</b> what do <b>the Rabbis</b> say about this matter? <b>Rav Ḥisda says:</b> According to the Rabbis, they are not a valid sign of adulthood <b>unless</b> the <b>two hairs are in one place.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis disagree with regard to when a young girl can perform refusal. According to the Rabbis, it is until she grows two pubic hairs after she reaches the age of twelve years and one day. According to Rabbi Yehuda she still retains the right to perform refusal at that point, until the majority of the pubic area is filled with hair. In this regard, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Until when can a young girl perform refusal? Until she grows two</b> pubic <b>hairs;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> She can perform refusal <b>until</b> the area covered by the <b>black</b> pubic hairs <b>is greater</b> than the white skin of the genital area. <b>Rabbi Yosei says: Until the nipple is surrounded</b> by hair. <b>Ben Shelakot says: Until</b> the pubic area is <b>filled with hair.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Shimon said: Ḥanina ben Ḥakhinai found me in</b> the city of <b>Tzaidan and said</b> to me: <b>When you reach Rabbi Akiva, say to him: Until when can a young girl perform refusal? If he says to you</b> that she may perform refusal <b>until she grows two</b> pubic <b>hairs, say to him: But didn’t ben Shelakot testify in the presence of all of you in Yavne</b> that she may perform refusal <b>until</b> the pubic area <b>is filled with hair [<i>shetekhalkel</i>], and you did not say anything to him,</b> thereby indicating that you conceded to him?
Rabbi Shimon continued: <b>When I reached Rabbi Akiva,</b> and I said what I had been told to say to him, <b>he said to me: I do not know what this filling with hair [<i>kilkul</i>] is, I don’t know</b> any <b>ben Shelakot,</b> and my opinion with regard to your question, <b>until when can a young girl perform refusal,</b> is that she can perform refusal <b>until she grows two</b> pubic <b>hairs.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The <b>two</b> white or black <b>hairs that are mentioned with regard to</b> disqualification of a red <b>heifer; and</b> the two white hairs mentioned <b>with regard to leprous marks,</b> i.e., that if they grow within a white leprous mark, it is impure; <b>and</b> the two hairs <b>that are mentioned in every place,</b> i.e., with regard to a young boy and girl, are significant only if they are long <b>enough to bend the top</b> of the hairs <b>to</b> reach <b>their roots.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> They must be long <b>enough to</b> grasp them and <b>cut</b> them <b>with a fingernail. Rabbi Akiva says:</b> They must be long <b>enough to be cut with a pair [<i>bezug</i>]</b> of scissors.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Ḥisda says</b> that <b>Mar Ukva says</b> with regard to the various opinions in the mishna on the measure of hairs: The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with the statements of all of them to be stringent.</b> One should consider it hair only if all of the criteria are met, or consider it to be hair if any one condition is met, depending on which standard yields the more stringent result.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to a woman <b>who sees</b> a red <b>stain</b> on her garment, <b>that</b> woman’s reckoning <b>is distorted.</b> Since she does not know when the blood that caused the stain appeared, she does not know when the seven days of menstrual flow end and when the eleven days of the flow of the <i>zava</i> begin.
<b>And</b> therefore she must be <b>concerned due to</b> the possibility that it might have been caused by the <b>flow of a <i>zava</i>.</b> If she wore the same garment for three days on which she can assume the status of a <i>zava</i>, and subsequently discovered a stain with an area that is the size of at least three split beans, the concern is that on each of those three days a stain with the area of at least one split bean, the minimum area that transmits impurity, was formed. The result is that she is a greater <i>zava</i> and is required to count seven clean days before immersion. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: No</b> configuration <b>of stains</b> leads to concern <b>due to the flow of a <i>zava</i>.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>Who</b> are <b>the Rabbis</b> in this mishna? <b>It is Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus says: Stains do not</b> lead to concern <b>due to the flow of a <i>zava</i>, but stains can sometimes lead to <i>ziva</i>.</b>
<b>How so,</b> i.e., how can stains lead to <i>ziva</i> according to Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus? If a woman <b>wore three</b> different <b>robes that</b> had been <b>examined by her</b> for blood stains, <b>and</b> she then <b>found a stain on</b> each of <b>them; or</b> if she <b>saw</b> blood flowing from her body on <b>two</b> consecutive <b>days and</b> on the third day she saw a stain on <b>one</b> of the <b>robes</b> that she wore that day, <b>those are the stains that lead to <i>ziva</i>.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty with regard to the above statement: According to the opinion of Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus, <b>now</b> that in a case where she sees stains on <b>three robes we</b> are <b>concerned</b> for <i>ziva</i>, despite the fact <b>that</b> she <b>does not see</b> the blood flowing <b>from her body, is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to state that we are concerned if she experiences bleeding from her body on <b>two days and</b> sees a stain on <b>one</b> of the <b>robes?</b>
The Gemara answers: It is necessary to state that, <b>lest you say</b> that in <b>any case like this,</b> where she experiences bleeding from her body on two days and on the third day she sees a stain on one of the robes, <b>she brings an offering and it is consumed,</b> like one who is definitely a <i>zava</i>. Therefore, Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus <b>teaches us</b> that her status as a <i>zava</i> is uncertain, and consequently she brings a bird for a sin offering that is due to uncertainty, which is not eaten.
<b>Rava said: With this</b> claim <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus bested the</b> other <b>Rabbis,</b> who agree with the opinion of Rabbi Meir in the mishna: <b>What is different</b> about a stain that is <b>less than three split beans in one place, that we are not concerned</b> she might be a <i>zava</i>? The reason is <b>that we say</b> she <b>saw</b> blood <b>on</b> only <b>two days.</b> But in a case where she discovered a stain on her robe with the area of at least <b>three split beans in one place,</b> one can <b>also say:</b> The area of <b>two and a half</b> split beans should be attributed to blood <b>seen from her body, but the other is</b> the <b>blood of a louse that</b> was there <b>due to the dirt</b> associated with her bleeding.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how do <b>the Rabbis</b> respond to this claim? The Gemara answers: They maintain that <b>since it is possible to divide</b> the stain into <b>at least one split bean for each</b> of the three <b>days, we do not attribute</b> the stain to the blood of a louse.
The Gemara raises a difficulty with regard to the statement of Rava: <b>And</b> according to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus,</b> one can infer that <b>it is</b> specifically in the case of a stain with the area of at least <b>three split beans in one place that we are not concerned</b> she might be a <i>zava</i>. It can be inferred from here that if it is <b>in three places, we are concerned.</b> But <b>didn’t you say</b> that if she discovered stains <b>in three robes, yes,</b> we are concerned, which indicates that if it is <b>in three places</b> on a single robe we are <b>not</b> concerned.
The Gemara answers that it was <b>in accordance with the statement of the Rabbis</b> that Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus <b>stated</b> his opinion <b>to them,</b> as follows: <b>According to my</b> opinion, if she discovered stains <b>in three robes, yes</b> we are concerned, whereas if it is <b>in three places</b> we are <b>not</b> concerned. <b>But according to your</b> opinion, <b>at least concede to me that where</b> she <b>saw</b> a stain on her robe with the area of at least <b>three split beans in one place, that we say</b> that the area of <b>two and a half</b> split beans can be attributed to blood <b>seen from her body, and the other is</b> the <b>blood of a louse</b> that was there <b>due to the dirt</b> associated with her bleeding.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how do <b>the Rabbis</b> respond to this claim? The Gemara answers: They maintain that <b>since it is possible to divide</b> the stain into <b>at least one split bean for each</b> of the three <b>days, we do not attribute</b> the stain to the blood of a louse.
§ With regard to a woman who finds a stain on her robe, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of a woman <b>who sees</b> a red <b>stain</b> on her garment that she wore for a number of days and she does not know when and where it is from, what is her status? <b>If</b> the area is large <b>enough to be divided</b> into three parts, where the total area is the size of <b>three split beans,</b> each of <b>which is</b> the minimum measure to render her a <i>zava</i>, i.e., an area the size of <b>at least a split bean,</b> she must be <b>concerned</b> that she is a <i>zava</i>, as this stain might be the result of seeing a sufficient measure of blood on each of three occasions. <b>But if</b> the stain is <b>not</b> that size, she does <b>not</b> need to <b>be concerned.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Agra says in the name of Rabbi Yosei: Both</b> in <b>this</b> case, where she saw a stain large enough to be divided into three parts, where the total area is the size of three split beans, <b>and that</b> case, where the stain was not that large, she must be <b>concerned</b> that she might be a <i>zava</i>. This is due to the fact that she possibly saw stains of sufficient size on only two occasions, but one was during twilight, which counts as two days, amounting to a total of three days.

Daf 53a

<b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says</b> that the dispute between Rabbi Yehuda ben Agra and the Rabbis should be decided as follows: <b>The statement of Rabbi Yehuda ben Agra,</b> who maintains that there is a concern for the possibility that the woman might have seen blood at twilight, <b>appears</b> to be correct <b>in</b> a case <b>where she did not examine. And the statement of the Rabbis,</b> who are not concerned about that possibility, appears to be correct <b>in</b> a case <b>where she did examine.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> did Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi mean by: Where she <b>did examine, and what</b> did he mean by: Where she <b>did not examine? Rava says: I found the Sages in the study hall of Rav sitting and saying</b> the following explanation of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Here we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where</b> the woman <b>examined herself but did not examine her robe. And even</b> with regard to <b>herself, she examined</b> herself <b>only</b> during <b>twilight [<i>bein hashemashot</i>]</b> as defined <b>by Rabbi Yehuda,</b> i.e., the time it takes to walk a half <i>mil</i> before the emergence of the stars. <b>But during twilight</b> as defined <b>by Rabbi Yosei,</b> i.e., the blink of an eye before the emergence of the stars, <b>she did not examine</b> herself.
<b>As the Rabbis hold</b> that <b>during</b> the period of <b>twilight</b> as defined <b>by Rabbi Yosei it is</b> already <b>night,</b> and therefore it does not matter that she did not examine herself then. <b>And</b> as <b>she did examine</b> herself <b>during</b> the period of <b>twilight</b> as defined <b>by Rabbi Yehuda,</b> and she found no blood, there is no concern that she saw during twilight, which would count as two sightings. <b>And Rabbi Yosei</b> conforms <b>to his</b> line of <b>reasoning, as</b> Rabbi Yosei, in whose name Rabbi Yehuda ben Agra said his ruling, <b>stated</b> that the time that he defines as <b>twilight is</b> considered <b>uncertain,</b> i.e., it is not definitely night or day, and therefore there is a concern that she might have seen blood at that time, which would count as seeing twice.
Rava continues: <b>And I said to</b> those Sages: <b>Had</b> the woman’s <b>hands</b> been <b>in her eyes,</b> a euphemism for her private parts, for <b>the entire twilight</b> period, what <b>you say</b> would be <b>fine.</b> But <b>now</b> that this is not the case, <b>perhaps when she removed her hands</b> from examining herself <b>she saw</b> blood. <b>And</b> those Sages <b>said to me:</b> The case about which <b>we said</b> that opinion <b>was where she placed her hands in her eyes</b> for <b>the entire twilight</b> period.
The Gemara further clarifies the <i>baraita</i>. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: The statement of Rabbi Yehuda ben Agra</b> in the name of Rabbi Yosei, who maintains that one needs to be concerned for the possibility that the woman saw blood at twilight, which would count as though she saw blood twice, <b>appears</b> to be correct <b>in</b> a case <b>where she did not examine.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is meant by: Where she did <b>not examine?</b>
<b>If we say that she examined</b> herself <b>during</b> the period <b>that is</b> defined by <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> as twilight, <b>but</b> she <b>did not examine</b> herself <b>during</b> the time period <b>that is</b> defined by <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> as twilight, this is difficult: If Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi accepted the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda ben Agra only in such a case, this indicates, <b>by inference, that Rabbi Yehuda</b> ben Agra himself, whose ruling is more strict than that of the Rabbis, <b>holds</b> that <b>even though</b> she <b>examined</b> herself <b>during</b> the twilight period as defined by <b>both</b> Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei, <b>she must be concerned.</b> This conclusion is untenable, as <b>she examined</b> herself throughout twilight and there was no blood.
<b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that when Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi referred to a case where she did not examine herself, he meant <b>that she examined</b> herself <b>neither during</b> the period <b>that Rabbi Yehuda</b> defines as twilight, <b>nor during</b> the period <b>that Rabbi Yosei</b> defines as twilight. <b>But</b> if she <b>examined</b> herself <b>during</b> the period <b>that Rabbi Yehuda</b> defines as twilight, <b>but</b> she <b>did not examine</b> herself <b>during</b> the period <b>that Rabbi Yosei</b> defines as twilight, then she does <b>not</b> need to be <b>concerned.</b>
<b>Evidently,</b> the time period <b>that Rabbi Yosei</b> defines as <b>twilight is</b> considered <b>nighttime</b> according <b>to Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. But if so, <b>say the latter clause: And the statement of the Rabbis</b> appears to be correct <b>in</b> a case <b>where she did examine. What</b> is meant by: Where she did <b>examine?</b>
<b>If we say that she examined</b> herself <b>during</b> the period <b>that is</b> defined <b>by Rabbi Yehuda</b> as twilight, <b>but</b> she <b>did not examine</b> herself <b>during</b> the period <b>that is</b> defined <b>by Rabbi Yosei</b> as twilight, this is difficult: If Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi accepted the opinion of the Rabbis only in such a case, this indicates <b>by inference that the Rabbis</b> themselves <b>hold</b> that <b>even though</b> she <b>did not examine</b> herself <b>during</b> the twilight period as defined by <b>both</b> Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei, nevertheless, <b>we are not concerned. But</b> in such a case, <b>she did not examine</b> herself at twilight at all.
<b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious that</b> she <b>examined</b> herself <b>both during</b> the period <b>that Rabbi Yehuda</b> defines as twilight, <b>and during</b> the period <b>that Rabbi Yosei</b> defines as twilight. <b>But</b> if she <b>examined</b> herself <b>during</b> the period <b>that Rabbi Yehuda</b> defines as twilight, <b>and</b> she <b>did not examine</b> herself <b>during</b> the period <b>that Rabbi Yosei</b> defines as twilight, then <b>we</b> are <b>concerned.</b>
<b>Evidently,</b> the time period <b>that Rabbi Yosei</b> defines as <b>twilight is</b> considered to be of <b>uncertain</b> status regarding whether it is day or night <b>according to Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. The Gemara asks: If so, one statement <b>of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi poses <b>a difficulty for</b> another statement <b>of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, as the inferences from the two parts of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s observation contradict one another.
The Gemara explains that <b>this</b> is what Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>is saying: The statement of Rabbi Yehuda ben Agra appears</b> correct <b>to the Rabbis</b> in a case <b>where she did not examine</b> herself <b>at all, neither during</b> the period <b>that Rabbi Yehuda</b> defines as twilight, <b>nor during</b> the period <b>that Rabbi Yosei</b> defines as twilight. <b>As, even the Rabbis disagree with</b> Rabbi Yehuda ben Agra <b>only</b> in a case <b>where</b> she <b>examined</b> herself <b>during</b> the period <b>that Rabbi Yehuda</b> defines as twilight <b>but</b> she <b>did not examine</b> herself <b>during</b> the time period <b>that Rabbi Yosei</b> defines as twilight. <b>But</b> in a case <b>where</b> she <b>did not examine</b> herself <b>at all, they concede to him</b> that we are concerned that she might have emitted blood at twilight.
<b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of a woman <b>who sees</b> a red <b>stain,</b> if she <b>saw a large</b> stain, covering an area the size of at least three split beans, she must be <b>concerned</b> that she might be a <i>zava</i>. But if she <b>saw a small</b> stain, covering an area of less than the size of three split beans, she does <b>not</b> need to <b>be concerned</b> that she is a <i>zava</i>. <b>This</b> is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda ben Agra, who said</b> it <b>in the name of Rabbi Yosei.</b>
<b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said: I heard from</b> Rabbi Yosei <b>that</b> with regard to both <b>this one and that one,</b> i.e., whether it is a large or small stain, she <b>must be concerned</b> that she is a <i>zava</i>. <b>And</b> Rabbi Yosei <b>said</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>to me based on this reasoning: And what</b> would be the case <b>if a menstruating woman did not</b> perform the examination marking the first step in her <b>transition</b> from ritual impurity <b>to ritual purity</b> on the seventh day <b>from <i>minḥa</i></b> time <b>onward?</b> Would she <b>not</b> have <b>a presumptive status of ritual impurity?</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi added: <b>And</b> Rabbi Yosei’s <b>statement appears</b> to be correct <b>with regard to</b> the case <b>where she examined.</b>
Once again, the Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is meant by the term: Where she <b>examined? If we say that she examined</b> herself <b>during</b> the period <b>that is</b> defined <b>by Rabbi Yehuda</b> as twilight, <b>but</b> she <b>did not examine</b> herself <b>during</b> the period <b>that is</b> defined <b>by Rabbi Yosei</b> as twilight, this indicates <b>by inference that Rabbi Yehuda ben Agra,</b> who disagrees in the second <i>baraita</i> with this version of Rabbi Yosei’s opinion and rules more leniently, <b>holds</b> that <b>even though</b> she <b>did not examine</b> herself <b>during</b> the twilight period as defined by <b>both Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei,</b> nevertheless, <b>she</b> does <b>not</b> need to <b>be concerned</b> that she is a <i>zava</i>. <b>But</b> this conclusion is untenable, as <b>she did not examine</b> herself at twilight at all.
<b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious that</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi is referring to a case <b>where</b> she examined herself <b>both during</b> the period <b>that Rabbi Yehuda</b> defines as twilight <b>and during</b> the period <b>that Rabbi Yosei</b> defines as twilight. This indicates, <b>by inference, that Rabbi Yehuda ben Agra holds</b> that if she <b>examined</b> herself <b>during</b> the period <b>that Rabbi Yehuda</b> defines as twilight, <b>but</b> she <b>did not examine</b> herself <b>during</b> the time period <b>that Rabbi Yosei</b> defines as twilight, then she does <b>not</b> need to be <b>concerned,</b> as a sighting at that time would not count as two.
<b>Evidently,</b> the period <b>that Rabbi Yosei</b> defines as <b>twilight is</b> considered to be <b>nighttime according to Rabbi Yehuda ben Agra.</b> If so, one statement <b>of Rabbi Yehuda ben Agra</b> poses <b>a difficulty with regard to</b> another statement <b>of Rabbi Yehuda ben Agra,</b> as earlier it was stated that according to Rabbi Yehuda ben Agra twilight is not definitely night.
<b>Granted, without</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, the apparent contradiction between these statements of Rabbi Yehuda ben Agra in the two <i>baraitot</i> is <b>not difficult,</b> as one could explain as follows: <b>There,</b> with regard to the first <i>baraita</i>, it is referring to a case <b>where she examined</b> herself <b>during</b> the period <b>that is</b> defined <b>by Rabbi Yehuda</b> as twilight, <b>but</b> she <b>did not examine</b> herself <b>during</b> the period <b>that is</b> defined <b>by Rabbi Yosei</b> as twilight. By contrast, <b>here</b> it is referring to a case <b>where she examined</b> herself <b>both during</b> the period <b>that is</b> defined <b>by Rabbi Yehuda</b> as twilight <b>and during</b> the period <b>that is</b> defined <b>by Rabbi Yosei</b> as twilight. <b>But in</b> light of the statement <b>of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, one cannot explain in this manner, and therefore the contradiction poses <b>a difficulty.</b>
The Gemara answers: This is not a contradiction, as there are <b>two <i>tanna’im</i> and</b> they disagree <b>with regard to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda ben Agra. This <i>tanna</i> holds</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda’s twilight ends,</b>

Daf 53b

<b>and</b> only <b>thereafter</b> the twilight <b>of Rabbi Yosei begins,</b> when there is uncertainty, and there is a concern that perhaps she saw blood at that time. <b>And that <i>tanna</i></b> of the second <i>baraita</i> <b>holds</b> that the <b>twilight of Rabbi Yosei is subsumed within</b> and occurs at the end of the twilight <b>of Rabbi Yehuda.</b> According to the opinion of this <i>tanna</i>, since she examined herself throughout the twilight of Rabbi Yehuda, she also necessarily examined herself throughout the twilight of Rabbi Yosei and therefore there is no need to be concerned about her status.
§ On the topic of a woman seeing a stain, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: A woman <b>who sees</b> a red <b>stain</b> on her garment <b>renders herself and consecrated items</b> that she touched <b>impure retroactively,</b> from the time when that garment was last laundered. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi.
<b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says:</b> She does <b>render consecrated items</b> that she touched <b>impure</b> retroactively, but she <b>does not render herself impure</b> with regard to rendering impure objects that she touched since the time the garment was last laundered. The reason is <b>that her stain should not be more stringent than her</b> actual <b>seeing</b> of blood. If she experiences bleeding, she renders impure only objects that she touched during the previous twenty-four-hour period.
The Gemara asks: <b>But don’t we find</b> that Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar himself holds that <b>her stain</b> is <b>more stringent than her</b> actual <b>seeing</b> of blood <b>with regard to consecrated</b> items? Her stain renders such items impure retroactively from the time that the garment was laundered, whereas her actually seeing blood renders impure only those items that she touched during the past twenty-four-hour period.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rather, teach</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>like this: Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says</b> that she does <b>not even render consecrated</b> items that she touched <b>impure</b> retroactively from the time that the garment was laundered, but only those items that she touched during the past twenty-four-hour period. The reason is <b>that her stain should not be more stringent than her</b> actual <b>seeing</b> of blood <b>with regard to any matter.</b>
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of a woman <b>who saw</b> a red <b>stain</b> on her garment, <b>and afterward saw blood,</b> what is the <i>halakha</i>? She <b>attributes her stain to her seeing</b> blood, i.e., the stain is treated as part of the seeing of blood, which means that she is impure only from when she found the stain, as it assumed that it appeared no earlier. This is the <i>halakha</i> provided that she saw the blood within a twenty-four-hour <b>period</b> of her discovery of the stain. But if more than twenty-four hours passed, she cannot attribute the stain to her sighting. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi.
<b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says:</b> She may attribute the stain to the sighting only if she experienced bleeding on the <b>day of</b> discovering the stain. If she experienced bleeding after that day, even if it was within twenty-four hours, she may not attribute the stain to the sighting, which means that she is impure retroactively from when she found the stain, in case it appeared earlier. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said: The statement of</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar <b>appears</b> to be more correct <b>than mine, as he fixes her</b> situation, i.e., he is lenient, <b>and I ruin her</b> situation, as my ruling is stringent. Since the impurity of a stain applies by rabbinic law, one should follow the more lenient opinion.
The Gemara asks: But does Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar actually <b>fix her</b> situation? Does he not <b>ruin her</b> situation? If she experiences bleeding the day after she found the stain, but within twenty-four hours of finding the stain, according to Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar she renders items impure retroactively. By contrast, according to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi she renders objects impure only from when she discovered the stain. <b>Ravina says: Reverse</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s statement, so that it states: My statement appears to be more correct than that of Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar, as I fix her situation and he ruins her situation.
<b>Rav Naḥman says: Actually, do not reverse</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s statement, as Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi meant the following: Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar’s opinion appears to be more correct, <b>as he fixes her <i>halakhot</i> with regard to <i>ziva</i>.</b> If she experiences bleeding on the day after discovering the stain, the count of her seven days of menstrual flow begins on that day of her actual sighting, not from when she saw the stain. This is due to the fact that the stain is not attributable to the seeing of the blood. Therefore, if she experiences bleeding on the seventh day after first experiencing bleeding, which is the eighth day after discovering the stain, she is not considered a lesser <i>zava</i>, and she can be purified from her status as a menstruating woman.
<b>But I,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, <b>ruin her <i>halakhot</i> with regard to <i>ziva</i>.</b> Since the stain is attributable to the seeing of the blood within twenty-four hours, her counting starts from when she found the stain, and therefore the blood that she sees on the eighth day after discovering the stain is considered <i>ziva</i>. Consequently, she is considered a lesser <i>zava</i> and must observe a clean day for each day she experiences a discharge.
§ <b>Rabbi Zeira asked Rabbi Asi:</b> Are <b>stains</b> like the actual sight of blood, in that they <b>require</b> an examination in which she is clean of blood, marking the first step in her <b>transition</b> from impurity to <b>purity</b> before immersion on the night following the seventh day, <b>or not?</b> Rabbi Asi <b>was silent and said nothing to</b> Rabbi Zeira.
The Gemara relates that on another <b>occasion</b> Rabbi Zeira <b>found</b> Rabbi Asi <b>sitting and saying</b> that a woman who sees a stain and afterward experiences bleeding <b>attributes her stain to her seeing</b> blood, if she saw the blood within a twenty-four-hour <b>period</b> of when she discovered the stain. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi.
Rabbi Asi added that there is a dispute with regard to the details of this <i>halakha</i>. <b>Reish Lakish says:</b> This applies only in a case <b>where she examined</b> herself at the end of the seventh day from the discovery of the stain. This examination indicates that the stain is related to her experiencing bleeding, and therefore the standard <i>halakha</i> of a woman who becomes pure at the end of her seven menstrual days applies to her. By contrast, if she examined herself only at the end of the eighth day, the stain is not attributable to her bleeding. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The stain is attributable to her bleeding under all circumstances, <b>even if she did not examine</b> herself until the eighth day.
Upon hearing this, Rabbi Zeira <b>said to</b> Rabbi Asi: Does that mean, <b>by inference, that stains require</b> an examination marking the first step in her <b>transition</b> from impurity to <b>purity?</b> Rabbi Asi <b>said to</b> Rabbi Zeira: <b>Yes,</b> that is the <i>halakha</i>. Rabbi Zeira further said to Rabbi Asi: <b>But</b> on <b>many occasions I asked you</b> about this matter <b>and you did not say anything to me. Perhaps in the course</b> of your studies this <i>halakha</i> <b>came</b> back <b>to you?</b> Rabbi Asi <b>said to him: Yes, in the course</b> of my studies this <i>halakha</i> <b>came</b> back <b>to me.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of a woman <b>who sees</b> an emission of blood during <b>twilight</b> on the <b>eleventh day</b> of the days in which she can assume the status of a <i>zava</i>, as there is uncertainty whether the emission was during the day and it is the flow of a <i>zava</i> or whether it was at night and it is menstrual flow, she observes seven days of impurity like <b>the beginning of</b> the seven days of <b>menstruation and the end of menstruation.</b> If she experienced an emission on the two previous days as well, she observes seven clean days before immersion like <b>the beginning of the flow of <i>ziva</i> and the end of the flow of <i>ziva</i>.</b>
Similarly, in the case of a woman who experiences an emission of blood during twilight on <b>the fortieth day</b> after the birth <b>of a male or the eightieth day</b> after the birth <b>of a female,</b> there is uncertainty whether it is considered daytime and therefore part of the final day of the blood of purity, or night that is part of the following day when the blood is impure. With regard to experiencing bleeding during <b>twilight in all</b> those cases, <b>these</b> women <b>are mistaken</b> in their calculation of the days of menstrual flow and the flow of a <i>zava</i>. Consequently, if they experience bleeding for three consecutive days at the beginning or at the end of the eleven days of <i>ziva</i>, they bring the offering of a <i>zava</i> but it is not eaten, as it was brought based on uncertainty.
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua said: Instead of</b> making provisions to <b>remedy</b> the uncertainties <b>of the misguided, come and remedy</b> the uncertainties of <b>the competent</b> women who know what day they saw the blood but require guidance, due to the multitude of emissions that they experienced.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that if a woman experiences bleeding during twilight on the eleventh day of the days on which she can assume the status of a <i>zava</i>, the flow is considered to be <b>the beginning of</b> the seven days of <b>menstruation and the end of menstruation.</b> The Gemara raises a difficulty: But the concern <b>is</b> only that this flow might be either <b>the beginning of</b> the seven days of <b>menstruation,</b> if twilight is treated as night, <b>or the end of <i>ziva</i>,</b> if twilight is treated as day.
<b>Rav Ḥisda says</b> that <b>this</b> is what the mishna <b>is saying:</b> A woman <b>who sees</b> an emission of blood during <b>twilight</b> on the <b>eleventh day</b> of the days on which she can assume the status of a <i>zava</i> must be concerned both for the possibility that it is <b>the beginning of</b> the seven days of <b>menstruation and</b> for the possibility that it is <b>the end of the flow of <i>ziva</i>.</b> If she had also seen an emission on the two previous days, she observes seven clean days before immersion, due to uncertainty.
With regard to the continuation of the mishna, which states: The beginning of the flow of <i>ziva</i> and the end of the flow of <i>ziva</i>, this should be understood as follows: <b>And</b> in the case of a woman who experiences an emission of blood during twilight <b>on the seventh</b> day of the seven days of the flow <b>of her menstruation,</b> she must be concerned both for the possibility that it is <b>the end of</b> the seven days of <b>menstruation and</b> for the possibility that it is <b>the beginning of the flow of <i>ziva</i>.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua said</b> to the Rabbis: <b>Instead of</b> making provisions to <b>remedy</b> the uncertainties <b>of the misguided,</b> come and remedy the uncertainties of the competent women. The Gemara asks: <b>Are these</b> women who experience bleeding during twilight

Daf 54a

actually <b>misguided?</b> Since they are in doubt as to their status, would it not be more accurate to say that <b>they are mistaken?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Rather,</b> this is how one should <b>teach</b> the statement of Rabbi Yehoshua in the mishna: Instead of making provisions to remedy the uncertainties of the <b>mistaken,</b> come and remedy the uncertainties of the competent women.
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to these competent women: What is the <i>halakha</i> in the case of a woman who consistently has the following pattern for each pair of days: <b>One day</b> she is <b>impure,</b> i.e., she experiences bleeding, <b>and one day</b> she is <b>pure,</b> she does not experience bleeding? In what manner is it permitted for her to engage in intercourse with her husband? She <b>may engage in intercourse</b> with her husband on the <b>eighth day</b> from the first time that she experienced bleeding <b>and its accompanying night.</b> At that time she is pure from her menstruation, as she immersed and purified herself on the night of the seventh day. It is permitted for her to engage in intercourse during the eighth day and the following night, as she will not experience bleeding until the ninth day.
In addition, she may engage in intercourse <b>four nights out of</b> the cycle of <b>eighteen days,</b> which consist of the seven menstrual days and the eleven days of the flow of the <i>zava</i>. This woman will never become a greater <i>zava</i>, as she does not emit blood on consecutive days. Since she must observe a day of purity during the eleven days of <i>ziva</i> each time she experiences bleeding, she may engage in intercourse with her husband on the night following the tenth, twelfth, fourteen, and sixteenth days. The night after the eighteenth day is considered part of the next cycle of menstruation and <i>ziva</i>. <b>But if</b> she <b>sees</b> blood <b>in the evening,</b> she <b>may engage in intercourse</b> with her husband <b>only</b> on the <b>eighth</b> night and its day. During the eleven days of <i>ziva</i> she either experiences bleeding at night or is observing a day of purity for the blood she had emitted earlier.
If in every set of four days, <b>two days</b> she is <b>impure,</b> i.e., experiences bleeding, <b>and two days</b> she is <b>pure,</b> she <b>may engage in intercourse</b> with her husband on the <b>eighth</b> day, in the day or at night, <b>and</b> also on the <b>twelfth</b> day, after observing the eleventh as a day of purity for the sightings of the ninth and tenth days, <b>and</b> by a similar calculation on the <b>sixteenth</b> day <b>and</b> on the <b>twentieth</b> day, as she has not yet seen the blood of menstruation in this new cycle.
The Gemara objects: <b>And let her also engage in intercourse</b> with her husband on the <b>nineteenth</b> day, as the eleven days of the flow of the <i>zava</i> have already passed at the end of the eighteenth day, and she is no longer required to observe a clean day for each day she experiences a discharge. <b>Rav Sheshet says: That is to say that when we learned</b> in a mishna (72a) that a husband who could not wait for the conclusion of the day after the last day of <i>ziva</i> before engaging in intercourse is <b>a glutton,</b> it means that it is actually <b>prohibited</b> for them to engage in intercourse.
<b>Rav Ashi says:</b> In fact, it is not prohibited for a woman to engage in intercourse with her husband on the day after the end of the days of the flow of the <i>zava</i> even by rabbinic decree, as it is already the beginning of her menstrual days, and she is no longer required to observe a clean day for each day she experiences a discharge. But <b>although</b> there is <b>no requirement</b> to <b>observe</b> a clean day <b>for</b> the <b>eleventh day</b> of <i>ziva</i>, which is the eighteenth day of the full cycle, <b>in any event</b> there is <b>a requirement</b> to <b>observe</b> a clean day for the <b>tenth day,</b> i.e., the seventeenth of the entire cycle. Since she did not observe a clean day on the eighteenth day, as she saw blood on that day as well, she must observe the nineteenth day in purity.
If out of every set of six days, <b>three days</b> she is <b>impure, and three days</b> she is <b>pure,</b> she <b>may engage in intercourse</b> with her husband during <b>two</b> of the <b>days, and thereafter</b> she may <b>never again engage in intercourse</b> with him. The eighth and ninth days, which are the first days of the flow of <i>ziva</i>, are the second and third of the three days on which she experiences bleeding.
