Therefore, she can immerse and purify herself on the night of the eleventh, and engage in intercourse with her husband on the eleventh and twelfth days. These are the only two days on which she is permitted to engage in intercourse with her husband, as afterward she will experience bleeding for three days during the days of the flow of the <i>zava</i>, and is thereby rendered a greater <i>zava</i>. Accordingly, she requires seven clean days to become pure again, which she will never attain, as she never has more than three clean days.
If out of every set of eight days, <b>four days</b> she is <b>impure, and four days</b> she is <b>pure,</b> she <b>may engage in intercourse</b> with her husband during <b>one</b> of the <b>days,</b> the eighth, after her purification for menstruation, as it is the last of her first set of four days without blood, <b>and thereafter</b> she may <b>never again engage in intercourse</b> with him, as she will be rendered a greater <i>zava</i> by experiencing bleeding on the next three days.
If out of every set of ten days, <b>five days</b> she is <b>impure, and five days</b> she is <b>pure,</b> she <b>may engage in intercourse</b> with her husband during <b>three</b> of the <b>days,</b> i.e., the eighth, ninth, and tenth, as she has completed her menstruation period and has not yet emitted the blood of <i>ziva</i>, <b>and thereafter</b> she may <b>never again engage in intercourse</b> with him. Similarly, if out of every set of twelve days, <b>six days</b> she is <b>impure, and six days</b> she is <b>pure,</b> she <b>may engage in intercourse</b> with her husband during <b>five</b> of the <b>days,</b> i.e., the eighth to the twelfth, <b>and thereafter</b> she may <b>never again engage in intercourse</b> with him.
If out of every set of fourteen days, <b>seven days</b> she is <b>impure, and seven days</b> she is <b>pure,</b> she <b>may engage in intercourse</b> with her husband during <b>a quarter</b> of the <b>days of her</b> life, i.e., seven <b>out of</b> every <b>twenty-eight days.</b> In the first seven days she is a menstruating woman, but during the next seven days she is pure. In the third set of seven days, when she again experiences bleeding, she becomes a <i>zava</i>, which means that in her last seven days, which are without blood, she counts the clean days for her <i>ziva</i>, after which this cycle of twenty-eight days begins afresh.
If out of every set of sixteen days, <b>eight days</b> she is <b>impure, and eight days</b> she is <b>pure,</b> she <b>may engage in intercourse</b> with her husband <b>fifteen days out of</b> every <b>forty-eight</b> days. The first eight days during which she experiences bleeding are the seven days of menstruation and one day of <i>ziva</i>, which renders her a lesser <i>zava</i>. Therefore, she must observe one clean day, after which she is pure for seven days. The first two days of the third set of eight are her last days of <i>ziva</i>, and the bleeding she experiences renders her again a lesser <i>zava</i>, while the next six are during her days of menstruation. Then she starts her fourth set of eight days, which are without blood. The first of these completes her days of menstruation, after which she may engage in intercourse for the subsequent seven days. During the fifth set of eight days she experiences bleeding, rendering her a greater <i>zava</i>. She counts her clean days in the sixth set, leaving her one day of purity, after which the cycle of forty-eight days starts again.
The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> the days during which she is permitted <b>are</b> actually only <b>fourteen,</b> not fifteen. This objection is based on the assumption that a woman cannot count her clean days for <i>ziva</i> during days that are fit for menstruation. Consequently, the last four days of the fifth cycle are actually part of her days of menstruation, as her eleven days of <i>ziva</i> ended after the fourth day of that cycle. If so, the sixth set of eight days consists of three menstrual days followed by five days of <i>ziva</i>. Although she is not a menstruating woman in those three days, as she did not previously count seven clean days, they still do not count for her seven clean days of <i>ziva</i>, since they are fit to be menstrual days. She can start counting her seven clean days only on day forty-four, but on day forty-nine, before the seven clean days are finished, she will again experience bleeding. Therefore, it should not be permitted for her to engage in intercourse with her husband on the forty-eighth night.
<b>Rav Adda bar Yitzḥak says</b> that this premise should be rejected: <b>That is to say</b> that <b>her menstrual days on which she does not</b> actually <b>see</b> blood <b>do count toward her counting of her</b> seven clean days of <b><i>ziva</i>.</b> In other words, she begins counting the seven clean days during these menstrual days. <b>As a dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages with regard to this issue:

Daf 54b

<b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> in the case of a woman who gave birth when she was a <i>zava</i>? There are seven <b>days of</b> impurity following the <b>birth</b> of a son and fourteen days of impurity following the birth of a daughter, during which the mother is impure even if she did not experience bleeding. With regard to those days during this period <b>on which she does not see</b> blood, are they <b>reckoned in the counting of her</b> seven clean days required to become purified from the status of <b><i>ziva</i>?</b>
<b>Rav Kahana says: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i>: A woman <b>saw</b> blood on <b>two</b> consecutive days during the period of <i>ziva</i>, <b>and on the third</b> day <b>she miscarried, but she does not know what she miscarried,</b> i.e., whether it was a stillborn human fetus for which a woman contracts the impurity of childbirth, or whether she discharged an amorphous piece of tissue. In addition, she does not know whether she emitted blood during the miscarriage.
In such a case, <b>it is uncertain</b> whether <b>she</b> has the status of one who experienced <b><i>ziva</i> or</b> whether she has the status of a woman who gave <b>birth.</b> If she gave birth to a fetus and did not emit blood, she is a woman after childbirth but not a <i>zava</i>. If the discharge was an amorphous piece of tissue and she saw blood, she is a <i>zava</i>. If it was a human fetus and she saw blood, she is one who gives birth as a <i>zava</i>. Finally, if she did not emit blood and it was a discharge of an amorphous piece of tissue, she is not obligated to bring an offering at all.
Consequently, <b>she brings an offering but it is not eaten</b> by the priests, as it is uncertain whether it is an offering of <i>ziva</i> or an offering for her childbirth, or whether it is non-sacred. <b>And</b> the <b>days of</b> impurity following this uncertain <b>birth, on which she does not see</b> blood, <b>are reckoned in the counting of her</b> seven clean days required to become purified from the status of <b><i>ziva</i>.</b> This resolves the dilemma raised by the Sages.
<b>Rav Pappa says</b> that this does not resolve the dilemma, as it <b>is different there, since it can be said</b> that <b>she is a woman who gave birth to a male, and</b> it is only for that reason that <b>all of these additional seven</b> days <b>that we give her</b> due to the concern that she might have given birth to a female, which would render her impure for fourteen days, <b>are reckoned in the counting of her</b> seven clean days of <b><i>ziva</i>.</b> But if it was certain that she gave birth to a female, those days after the birth would not count toward her period of <i>ziva</i>.
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said to Rav Pappa:</b> Is <b>there uncertainty that</b> perhaps she is <b>a woman who gave birth to a male,</b> but <b>there</b> is <b>no uncertainty that</b> she might be <b>a woman who gave birth to a female?</b> In fact, both possibilities must be taken into account. And yet, despite the fact that she might have given birth to a female, these seven days are included in the counting of her seven clean days. <b>Rather, isn’t it</b> correct to <b>conclude from</b> it that such days <b>are reckoned</b> in the counting? The Gemara comments: Indeed, <b>conclude from</b> the <i>baraita</i> that these days do count.
The Gemara concludes its citation of the <i>baraita</i>: In the case of a woman whose set pattern is that <b>nine days</b> she is <b>impure,</b> i.e., experiences bleeding, <b>and nine days</b> she is <b>pure,</b> she <b>may engage in intercourse</b> with her husband during <b>eight days out of eighteen.</b> The last two days of the nine with blood are part of her <i>ziva</i> period, after which she must observe one clean day, leaving her with eight days when she may engage in intercourse before the cycle begins again.
In the case of a woman whose set pattern is that <b>ten days</b> she is <b>impure and ten days</b> she is <b>pure,</b> the number of <b>days of her</b> being permitted to <b>engage in intercourse</b> with her husband <b>is equivalent to</b> the number of <b>days of her</b> experiencing the flow of <b><i>ziva</i>.</b> In the first seven days she is a menstruating woman, followed by three days of blood that render her a <i>zava</i>. She must count seven of the ten days without blood to be purified from her <i>ziva</i>, which leaves her three days in which she may engage in intercourse, exactly the same as the three days of <i>ziva</i> on which she saw blood. <b>And so too,</b> the same applies in the case <b>of one hundred</b> days, as she experiences bleeding of <i>ziva</i> for ninety-three days, and is subsequently permitted to her husband for ninety-three days, <b>and so too</b> in the case <b>of one thousand</b> days.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>The blood of a menstruating woman and the flesh of a corpse transmit impurity</b> by contact and by carrying when they are <b>moist, and</b> likewise <b>transmit impurity</b> when they are <b>dry. But</b> with regard to <b>the</b> gonorrhea-like <b>discharge of a <i>zav</i> [<i>ziva</i>], and the mucus and the saliva</b> of a <i>zav</i>, <b>and</b> the carcass of <b>a creeping animal, and an animal carcass, and semen,</b> all <b>transmit impurity</b> when they are <b>moist but do not transmit impurity</b> when they are <b>dry. And if one could soak</b> those dry substances in water <b>and</b> thereby <b>restore</b> them <b>to their</b> previous <b>state, they transmit impurity</b> when <b>moist and transmit impurity</b> when <b>dry.</b>
The mishna asks: <b>And how long is the</b> process of <b>soaking these</b> substances that determines whether they can be restored to their previous state? This is referring to soaking them <b>in lukewarm</b> water <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period. Rabbi Yosei says:</b> With regard to <b>the flesh of a corpse</b> that is <b>dry and cannot be soaked to restore</b> it <b>to</b> its <b>previous state,</b> it is <b>ritually pure,</b> in the sense that an olive-bulk of the flesh does not transmit impurity imparted by a corpse. But a ladleful of the flesh transmits the impurity of the decayed flesh of a corpse.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that the blood of a menstruating woman transmits impurity by contact and by carrying both when moist and when dry. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>Ḥizkiyya says:</b> They are derived from a verse, <b>as the verse states</b> with regard to a menstruating woman: “This is the law of him that has an issue…<b>And of her who experiences the flow of her menstrual impurity”</b> (Leviticus 15:32–33). The verse compares the status of the menstrual flow to that of the menstruating woman. This teaches that the status of <b>the menstrual flow is like</b> the status of the woman <b>herself: Just as she transmits impurity</b> by contact and by carrying, <b>so too, the menstrual flow transmits impurity</b> by contact and by carrying.
The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> a source for the impurity of the menstrual blood when it is <b>moist,</b> since it is called the menstrual flow; <b>from where do we</b> derive that <b>dry</b> menstrual blood also transmits impurity? <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak says</b> that <b>the verse states</b> with regard to menstrual impurity: “And if a woman should have an issue, and her issue in her flesh <b>shall be</b> blood, she shall be in her impurity seven days, and whoever touches her shall be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 15:19). The term “shall be” indicates that the blood <b>shall</b> remain <b>in its</b> impure <b>status</b> even once it is dry.
The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> one may <b>say</b> that <b>this statement</b> applies only <b>to</b> blood that was initially <b>moist and</b> subsequently <b>became dry,</b> as it retains its initial status. With regard to blood that was <b>dry at the outset, from where do we</b> derive that it too transmits impurity? <b>And furthermore,</b> this inference does not provide a source for <b>that which we learned</b> in a mishna (21a): In the case of a woman <b>who discharges</b> an item whose shape is <b>similar to a type of shell, similar to a type of soil, similar to a type of hair,</b> or <b>similar to a type of mosquito,</b> if such items are <b>red, she should cast</b> them <b>into water</b> to ascertain their nature. <b>If they dissolved,</b> it is blood, and the woman is <b>impure. From where do we</b> derive that even this type of blood is impure? The Gemara explains: The term <b>“shall be” is an amplification,</b> indicating that menstrual blood in all these forms is impure.
The Gemara objects: <b>If</b> so, one can likewise infer the following: <b>Just as she,</b> a menstruating woman, <b>renders</b> an item designated for <b>lying or sitting</b> impure <b>to</b> the extent that it <b>transmits impurity to a person and</b> to the extent that that person <b>transmits impurity to</b> his <b>garments,</b> despite the fact that the garments did not come into contact with the couch, <b>so too, her blood also renders</b> items designated for <b>lying or sitting</b> impure <b>to</b> the extent that they <b>transmit impurity to a person and</b> to the extent that he <b>transmits impurity to</b> his <b>garments,</b> in the manner of a primary source of ritual impurity. The Gemara replies: <b>Is that to say</b> that the concepts of <b>lying and sitting apply</b> to <b>her</b> menstrual <b>blood?</b> These categories of impurity are limited to people.
The Gemara asks: <b>But according to your reasoning</b> that this category of impurity is limited to people, <b>do</b> the concepts of <b>lying and sitting apply</b> to <b>a stone afflicted</b> with leprosy, so <b>that a verse was necessary to exclude</b> it? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>a stone afflicted</b> with leprosy <b>should render</b> an item designated for <b>lying or sitting</b> impure <b>to</b> the extent that it <b>transmits impurity to a person and</b> to the extent that he <b>transmits impurity to</b> his <b>garments.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> explains: <b>And</b> this ruling might be derived by <b>logical inference:</b> If one enters a house where there is a stone afflicted with leprosy he becomes impure, but one who enters a house together with a man who experienced a gonorrhea-like discharge [<i>zav</i>] does not become impure. One may therefore infer as follows: <b>If a <i>zav</i>, who does not transmit impurity by entering</b> a house, nevertheless <b>renders</b> an item designated for <b>lying or sitting</b> impure <b>to</b> the extent that it <b>transmits impurity to a person</b> and to the extent that that person <b>transmits impurity to</b> his <b>garments,</b> then with regard to <b>a stone afflicted</b> with leprosy, <b>which does transmit impurity by entering</b> a house, <b>is it not logical that</b> it <b>renders</b> an item designated for <b>lying or sitting impure to</b> the extent that it <b>transmits impurity to a person</b> and to the extent that he <b>transmits impurity to</b> the <b>garments</b> he is wearing?
The <i>baraita</i> concludes: Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “Every bed upon which the <i>zav</i> lies shall be impure, and every item upon which he sits shall be impure” (Leviticus 15:4). The term <b>“the <i>zav</i>”</b> indicates that only <b>the <i>zav</i>, and not a stone afflicted</b> with leprosy, renders items designated for lying or sitting impure. The Gemara infers from the <i>baraita</i>: <b>The reason</b> a stone afflicted with leprosy does not transmit impurity to items designated for lying or sitting is <b>that the verse excluded it, but</b> were it <b>not so,</b> the stone <b>would transmit impurity</b> to items designated for lying or sitting, despite the fact that the concepts of lying and sitting do not apply to a stone.
The Gemara replies that <b>from this</b> same derivation one can infer that menstrual blood does not render items designated for lying or sitting impure: <b>Didn’t you say</b> that the term “the <i>zav</i>” teaches that only <b>the <i>zav</i>, and not a stone afflicted</b> with leprosy, renders items designated for lying or sitting impure? <b>So too,</b> a verse excludes menstrual blood from this category of impurity, as <b>the verse states:</b> “And he if is on the bed, or on any item <b>upon which she sits,</b> when he touches it, he shall be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 15:23). The term “she” indicates that <b>she,</b> the menstruating woman, <b>but not her blood,</b> transmits impurity to items designated for lying or sitting.

Daf 55a

The Gemara raises an objection: There is a unique <i>halakha</i> with regard to the impurity of a <i>zav</i> and a menstruating woman: In a case where one of them sits on an item, including one that cannot become ritually impure, e.g., a stone, and beneath that item is a vessel, that vessel becomes impure, even if their weight has no effect on the vessel, as in the case of a very heavy stone. <b>If</b> the verse compares the status of the menstrual blood to the status of the menstruating woman, as derived above, one can infer as follows: <b>Just as</b> a menstruating woman <b>transmits impurity to</b> items that lie beneath <b>a very heavy stone, so too, her menstrual flow also transmits impurity to</b> items that lie beneath <b>a very heavy stone.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said</b> in response: Items designated for lying or sitting also transmit impurity to items that lie beneath a very heavy stone. <b>The verse states</b> with regard to an item of this kind, which was rendered impure by a <i>zav</i>: “And whoever touches anything that was under him shall be impure until the evening, <b>and he that carries them</b> shall wash his clothes, and bathe himself in water, and he shall be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 15:10). The term <b>“them” is an exclusion,</b> indicating that items designated for lying or sitting transmit impurity to items that lie beneath a very heavy stone, but menstrual blood does not.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And the flesh of a corpse</b> transmits impurity both when moist and when dry. The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive this <i>halakha</i>? <b>Reish Lakish said</b> that this is as <b>the verse states:</b> “Or whoever touches any creeping thing by which he may be made impure, or a man from whom he may be made impure, <b>from any impurity that he has”</b> (Leviticus 22:5). The term “from any” is an amplification, indicating that one may become impure <b>from any impurities that come from</b> a dead person, whether they are moist or dry.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> that this <i>halakha</i> is derived from the verse: “And whoever touches in the open field one who is slain with a sword, or one who died, <b>or the bone of a man, or a grave,</b> shall be impure seven days” (Numbers 19:16). The verse indicates that the impurity of a dead <b>man</b> is <b>similar to</b> the impurity of <b>a bone: Just as a bone</b> is <b>dry, so too here,</b> with regard to the impurity of a corpse, it transmits impurity even when it is <b>dry.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the practical difference <b>between</b> the inferences of Reish Lakish and Rabbi Yoḥanan? The Gemara answers that the practical difference <b>between them</b> is the case of a corpse which is so dry <b>that it crumbles.</b> Reish Lakish maintains it is impure, as the term “from any” indicates that a corpse transmits impurity in any form, whereas Rabbi Yoḥanan maintains it is ritually pure, as it is unlike a bone, which does not crumble.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Reish Lakish from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The flesh of a corpse that crumbled</b> is <b>ritually pure.</b> The Gemara answers that this is not difficult, as the <i>baraita</i> <b>there</b> is referring to where the flesh is so dry <b>that it has become</b> like <b>flour and is</b> therefore classified as <b>dust.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the opinions of both Reish Lakish and Rabbi Yoḥanan from a mishna (<i>Oholot</i> 3:3): <b>Everything that is in a corpse transmits impurity, except for the teeth, and the hair, and the nails.</b> This is the <i>halakha</i> only when these items are separated from the body, <b>but when they are attached</b> to the corpse they are <b>all impure.</b> According to Rabbi Yoḥanan teeth should transmit impurity because they are similar to bones, while according to Reish Lakish they should be included in the term “from any.”
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said:</b> Only items that are <b>similar to a bone</b> transmit impurity: <b>Just as a bone</b> is an item <b>that was created with him</b> at the time of birth, <b>so too, all</b> items that transmit impurity are those <b>that were created with him,</b> whereas teeth are not present at the time of birth. The Gemara asks: <b>But are there not</b> the cases of <b>hair and nails, which were created with him, and</b> yet the mishna states that <b>they are ritually pure?</b>
<b>Rather, Rav Adda bar Ahava said</b> a different explanation: Only those items that are <b>similar to a bone</b> transmit impurity: <b>Just as a bone</b> is an item <b>that was created with him and its root does not renew</b> itself, i.e., if a bone is removed a new bone does not grow in its place, <b>so too, any item that was created with him and whose root does not renew</b> itself transmits impurity. <b>The teeth were excluded</b> from this category, <b>as they were not created with him.</b> The <b>hair and nails were excluded, as even though they were created with him</b> their <b>roots renew</b> themselves, since they grow again after they are cut off.
The Gemara objects: <b>But isn’t there</b> the case of <b>skin, whose root renews</b> itself, <b>and</b> this is as <b>we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Ḥullin</i> 54a): In the case of an animal <b>whose hide was removed [<i>hageluda</i>], Rabbi Meir deems</b> it <b>kosher,</b> as the skin renews itself, <b>and the Rabbis deem</b> it an animal with a wound that will cause it to die within twelve months [<i>tereifa</i>] and <b>unfit</b> for consumption. The Gemara explains: <b>And even the Rabbis deem</b> it <b>unfit only</b> due to the fact <b>that in the meantime,</b> between the removal of the old hide and the growth of the new one, <b>the air affects it and</b> as a result <b>it</b> will <b>die, but</b> they concede that <b>actually</b> the skin’s <b>root renews</b> itself. <b>And</b> nevertheless <b>we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Ḥullin</i> 122a): <b>These</b> are the entities <b>whose skin</b> has the same halakhic status <b>as their flesh: The skin of a</b> dead <b>person,</b> and the skin of a domesticated pig…and the skin of the hump of a young camel, etc.
The Gemara explains that <b>it was stated with regard to that</b> mishna that <b>Ulla said: By Torah law, the skin of</b> a dead <b>person is ritually pure. And what is the reason</b> the Sages <b>said</b> that it is <b>impure?</b> It is a rabbinic <b>decree lest a person should fashion rugs for a donkey</b> out of <b>the skins of his</b> deceased <b>father and mother.</b>
<b>And some say</b> a different version of the above discussion: <b>Isn’t there</b> the case of <b>skin, whose root does not renew</b> itself, <b>and</b> this is as <b>we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Ḥullin</i> 54a): In the case of an animal whose hide was removed, Rabbi Meir deems it kosher, <b>and the Rabbis deem</b> it a <i>tereifa</i> and <b>unfit</b> for consumption, as its skin does not regrow? The Gemara explains: <b>And even Rabbi Meir deems</b> it <b>fit only because the flesh cools and</b> the animal <b>heals, but</b> he concedes that <b>actually</b> the skin’s <b>root does not renew</b> itself. Accordingly, the skin of a corpse should be impure. <b>But Ulla said: By Torah law, the skin of</b> a dead <b>person is ritually pure.</b>
The Gemara answers that <b>when</b> the opinion <b>of Ulla was stated, it was stated with regard to the latter clause</b> of that mishna: <b>And</b> for <b>all of</b> these skins, in a case <b>where one tanned them or where one</b> spread them on the ground and <b>trod on them</b> for the same amount of time it takes <b>for tanning,</b> they are no longer classified as flesh and <b>are ritually pure, except for the skin of</b> a dead <b>person,</b> which maintains the status of flesh. <b>And</b> with regard to this <b>Ulla said</b> that <b>by Torah law the skin of</b> a dead <b>person, when one tanned it, is ritually pure. And what is the reason</b> the Sages <b>said</b> it is <b>impure?</b> It is a rabbinic <b>decree lest a person should fashion rugs</b> out of <b>the skin of his</b> deceased <b>father and mother.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t there</b> the case of <b>flesh, whose root renews</b> itself, as when one’s flesh is cut it regrows and heals, <b>and</b> yet it is <b>impure? Mar bar Rav Ashi says: Flesh</b> does not renew itself, as although when someone is cut his flesh regrows and heals, <b>a scar is formed</b> in <b>its place.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: <b>But <i>ziva</i></b> transmits impurity when moist, although not when dry. The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that <b><i>ziva</i></b> transmits impurity? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that discusses the verse: “When any man has an issue out of his flesh, <b>his issue,</b> it is <b>impure”</b> (Leviticus 15:2). This <b>taught with regard to <i>ziva</i> that it is impure.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> asks: Why is this derivation necessary? <b>Could this not</b> be derived through an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference?</b> Since <i>ziva</i> <b>causes impurity to others,</b> i.e., to the one who emitted the discharge, is it <b>not all the more so</b> that <i>ziva</i> <b>itself</b> is impure? The <i>baraita</i> replies that the case of the <b>scapegoat</b> brought on Yom Kippur <b>may prove</b> that this inference is not valid, <b>as it causes impurity to others,</b> i.e., the dispatcher of the scapegoat is rendered impure, <b>and</b> yet the goat <b>itself is pure. So too, you should not be surprised about this,</b> the discharge of <i>ziva</i>, <b>that even though it causes impurity to others,</b> <i>ziva</i> <b>itself is pure.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “His issue,</b> it is <b>impure.”</b> This <b>taught with regard to <i>ziva</i> that it is impure.</b>
The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> one <b>may say</b> that <b>this statement,</b> that the discharge of <i>ziva</i> transmits impurity, applies only to transmitting impurity <b>by contact. But</b> with regard to transmitting impurity <b>by carrying</b> it does <b>not</b> transmit impurity, <b>just as it is with regard to</b> the carcass of <b>a creeping animal,</b> which transmits impurity by contact but not by carrying. <b>Rav Beivai bar Abaye said: A verse was not necessary</b> to teach that <i>ziva</i> transmits ritual impurity <b>by contact, as</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <i>ziva</i> is <b>no less</b> stringent <b>than</b> with regard to <b>semen,</b> which transmits impurity by contact.

Daf 55b

<b>When the verse was necessary,</b> it was <b>to</b> teach that <i>ziva</i> transmits impurity by <b>carrying.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> yet one may <b>say</b> that <i>ziva</i> <b>transmits impurity</b> to <b>a person and</b> to his <b>garments</b> only <b>by carrying, but</b> as for impurity <b>by contact,</b> although <i>ziva</i> <b>transmits impurity</b> to the <b>person</b> who touches it, <b>it does not transmit impurity</b> to his <b>garments, just as is</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to contact</b> with an unslaughtered <b>animal carcass.</b> If one touches a carcass he is rendered impure but his garments remain pure, despite the fact that if one carries a carcass his garments are also rendered impure.
The Gemara answers: This could <b>not enter your mind, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b><i>Aḥerim</i> say,</b> with regard to the verse: “This is the law of him that has an issue…And of her who experiences the flow of her menstrual impurity, and <b>of one who emits his issue [<i>zovo</i>], in the case of a male or a female”</b> (Leviticus 15:32–33). The verse <b>juxtaposes</b> the impurity of <b>the issue of the <i>zav</i> to</b> the impurity of the <i>zav</i> <b>himself: Just as</b> with regard to <b>him you did not distinguish between</b> impurity transmitted by <b>contact with him and</b> impurity transmitted by <b>carrying him, as</b> in both cases the <i>zav</i> <b>transmits impurity to a person and transmits impurity to</b> his <b>garments, so too,</b> with regard to <b>the issue of the <i>zav</i></b> the <i>halakha</i> is <b>the same.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And now that we have derived</b> the impurity of the discharge of a <i>zav</i> <b>from</b> the verse: “And <b>of one who emits his issue”</b> (Leviticus 15:33), <b>why do I</b> need the verse: “When any man has an issue out of his flesh, <b>his issue,</b> it is <b>impure”</b> (Leviticus 15:2)?
<b>Rav Yehuda of Diskarta said:</b> This verse <b>was necessary,</b> as it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that the case of the <b>scapegoat may prove</b> that the discharge of a <i>zav</i> is not impure, <b>as</b> the scapegoat <b>causes impurity to others and</b> yet the goat <b>itself is pure.</b> Likewise, one might conclude that although the discharge of a <i>zav</i> causes impurity to others, <i>ziva</i> itself is pure. <b>And if</b> one were to dismiss this possibility, <b>due to</b> the verse: “And <b>of one who emits his issue [<i>zovo</i>],</b> in the case of a male or a female” (Leviticus 15:33), one could reply <b>that</b> it does not indicate the impurity of <i>ziva</i>. Rather, <b>it comes to</b> teach the <b>number</b> of emissions by which one becomes impure with the impurity of a <i>zav</i>.
Rav Yehuda of Diskarta clarifies this interpretation of the verse. The term: <b>An issue [<i>zov</i>],</b> would indicate <b>one</b> emission of <i>ziva</i>. Since the verse uses the term <b>“his issue [<i>zovo</i>],”</b> the superfluous addition indicates <b>two</b> emissions of <i>ziva</i>. With regard to these two emissions, the verse states: “In the case of a male,” indicating that the status of a male <i>zav</i> differs from the status of a female <i>zava</i> in that he is not rendered impure if the emission occurred due to an accident, which would render a female impure. <b>But in</b> the case of <b>the third</b> emission of <i>ziva</i> <b>the Merciful One juxtaposed</b> the status of a male <i>zav</i> <b>to</b> that of <b>a female,</b> as the verse states: “Or a female,” indicating that even if the third emission was due to an accident he is nevertheless obligated to bring an offering.
Since one would not have derived the impurity of <i>ziva</i> from this verse, <b>the Merciful One wrote: “His issue,</b> it is <b>impure”</b> (Leviticus 15:2). <b>And now that the Merciful One states: “His issue, it is impure,”</b> one <b>may derive from</b> the verse “and of one who emits his issue” not only the number of emissions, but <b>also this</b> interpretation, that there is no difference between the impurity imparted by <i>ziva</i> by contact and by carrying.
§ The mishna teaches: And the mucus <b>and the saliva</b> of a <i>zav</i> transmit impurity when moist but not when dry. The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive the ritual impurity of the <b>saliva</b> of a <i>zav</i>? The Gemara answers that this is derived <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“And if</b> one who has an issue <b>spits</b> on the pure person, then he shall wash his clothes, and bathe himself in water, and he is impure until the evening” (Leviticus 15:8). One <b>might</b> have thought that the saliva transmits impurity even if the <i>zav</i> merely spat in the direction of a pure person, <b>despite</b> the fact <b>that it did not</b> come into <b>contact</b> with him. Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “And if one who has an issue spits <b>on the pure person,”</b> which teaches that <b>unless</b> the saliva comes into <b>contact with the pure person</b> he is not rendered impure.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that <b>his saliva</b> is impure. <b>From where</b> is it derived that <b>his phlegm, his mucus, and his nasal fluids</b> are also impure? <b>The verse states: “And if</b> one who has an issue <b>spits.”</b> The superfluous “and” is an amplification, indicating that these substances also transmit impurity.
<b>The Master said</b> above: One <b>might</b> have thought that the saliva transmits impurity even if the <i>zav</i> merely spat in the direction of a pure person, <b>despite</b> the fact <b>that it did not</b> come into <b>contact</b> with him. The Gemara asks: <b>From where would this be derived?</b> Why would one think that a person becomes impure from saliva that did not come into contact with him, making it necessary for a verse to exclude this possibility?
The Gemara explains: It might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>we should derive</b> a verbal analogy <b>from</b> the term <b>saliva</b> in the verse “and if one who has an issue spits,” and the term <b>saliva</b> stated in connection with <b>a <i>yevama</i>,</b> a widow whose husband died childless and who participates in <i>ḥalitza</i>, as the verse states: “His <i>yevama</i> shall approach him, before the Elders, and remove his shoe from on his foot and spit before him” (Deuteronomy 25:9). <b>Just as there,</b> with regard to <i>ḥalitza</i>, the ritual is valid <b>even though</b> the saliva <b>did not touch</b> her brother-in-law, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to the saliva of a <i>zav</i>, it transmits impurity despite the fact <b>that it did not</b> come into <b>contact</b> with the pure person. Therefore, the verse <b>teaches us</b> that the saliva of a <i>zav</i> transmits impurity only if it comes into contact with the pure person.
The Gemara objects: <b>And</b> yet one <b>may say</b> that <b>this statement,</b> that the saliva of a <i>zav</i> transmits impurity, applies only to transmitting impurity <b>by contact. But</b> with regard to transmitting impurity <b>by carrying</b> it does <b>not</b> transmit impurity, <b>just as is</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to</b> the carcass of <b>a creeping animal,</b> which transmits impurity by contact but not by carrying. <b>Reish Lakish said</b> that <b>the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The verse states:</b> “And if one who has an issue spits <b>on the pure person.”</b> The term “on the pure person” is interpreted to mean that in any case where <b>something</b> of the saliva <b>is in the hand of</b> the <b>pure person I deemed</b> him <b>impure for you,</b> even if he did not come into direct contact with the saliva but merely carried it.
The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> one may <b>say</b> that although the saliva of a <i>zav</i> transmits impurity both by carrying and by contact, nevertheless there is the following difference between them: <b>By carrying</b> the saliva of a <i>zav</i>, <b>it transmits impurity</b> to <b>a person and</b> to his <b>garments,</b> but <b>by contact,</b> although it <b>transmits impurity</b> to the <b>person</b> who touches it, <b>it does not transmit impurity</b> to his <b>garments, just as is</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to contact</b> with an unslaughtered <b>animal carcass.</b>
<b>Reish Lakish said, and so</b> too <b>the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught,</b> that <b>the verse states:</b> “And if one who has an issue spits <b>on the pure person.”</b> The term “on the pure person” teaches that a case of <b>purity,</b> i.e., that <b>which I deemed pure for you in a different case, I have deemed impure for you here. And which</b> case <b>is this? This is</b> referring to <b>contact</b> with <b>an animal carcass,</b> which renders only the one touching it impure, but not his garments, whereas the saliva of a <i>zav</i> renders them both impure.
The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> one can <b>say</b> that the case deemed pure elsewhere but deemed impure here is that <b>of carrying</b> the carcass of <b>a creeping animal.</b> Perhaps the verse is teaching that whereas a creeping animal does not transmit impurity by carrying, the saliva of a <i>zav</i> does transmit impurity by carrying. By contrast, contact with the saliva of a <i>zav</i> renders only the one touching it impure, but not his garments, as is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to an animal carcass. The Gemara responds: <b>If that is so, let the verse write:</b> If one who has an issue spits <b>on the person. What</b> is the reason the verse states specifically: <b>“On the pure person”? Conclude two</b> conclusions <b>from it,</b> both that the saliva of a <i>zav</i> transmits impurity by carrying and that contact with the saliva renders impure both the person and his garments.
§ The aforementioned <i>baraita</i> teaches: <b>And the nasal fluids</b> of a <i>zav</i> also transmit impurity. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> are these <b>nasal fluids? Rav says:</b> This is referring to fluids <b>that are emitted via the mouth</b> of a person. They are impure <b>because</b> it is <b>impossible for the nasal fluids</b> to flow through the mouth <b>without</b> containing <b>traces of saliva,</b> which are impure. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>even</b> to fluids <b>that are emitted via the nose. Evidently,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>maintains</b> that nasal fluids <b>are</b> categorized as <b>a flow</b> of bodily fluids, <b>and the Merciful One included it</b> among the impure bodily fluids of a <i>zav</i>, by the amplification: “And if one who has an issue spits.”
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> according to <b>Rav,</b> who maintains that nasal fluids are impure because they contain traces of saliva, this is difficult: <b>Let</b> the mishna <b>also count</b> among the impure bodily fluids of the <i>zav</i> <b>the tears of his eye, as Rav said: He who desires to blind his eye should have a gentile paint [<i>likhḥol</i>]</b> his eye, as the gentile is apt to add a substance that causes blindness. <b>And Levi said: He who desires to die should have a gentile paint</b> his eye, as the gentile is apt to add poison to the paint.
The Gemara continues: <b>And Rav Ḥiyya bar Gurya said: What is the reasoning of Rav, that he did not say</b> like Levi: <b>He who desires to die</b> should have a gentile paint his eye? Rav did not say this because he maintains one can prevent the poisonous substances from killing him, <b>since he can suck</b> the poisonous substances into his mouth by inhaling <b>and emit them via the mouth.</b> This indicates that the fluids of the eye can also be emitted through the mouth, and if so, the tears of a <i>zav</i> should likewise transmit impurity. The Gemara answers: <b>And Rav</b> would say that <b>although the poison [<i>dezihara</i>]</b> placed in one’s eye can <b>exit</b> the body via the mouth, <b>the tears themselves do not exit</b> the body through the mouth.
The Gemara states: With regard to the above dispute between Rav and Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i>: <b>There are nine</b> types of <b>fluids</b> of <b>the <i>zav</i>. The sweat, the foul secretion</b> from an infected wound, <b>and the excrement are pure from any</b> form of impurity. The <b>tears</b> that emerge <b>from his eye,</b> the <b>blood from his wound, and the milk of a woman</b> who is a <i>zava</i> all <b>transmit the ritual impurity of liquids,</b> i.e., they render food and liquids impure, as other impure liquids do, in a situation <b>where</b> there is at least <b>a quarter</b>-<i>log</i> of the fluid. <b>But his <i>ziva</i>, his saliva, and his urine</b> all <b>transmit a severe</b> form of <b>ritual impurity.</b> The Gemara comments: The <i>baraita</i> lists many substances, <b>and yet it does not teach</b> that <b>nasal fluids</b> are impure.
<b>Granted, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav,</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>does not teach</b> that nasal fluids are impure, <b>as he could not teach it categorically,</b> since <b>sometimes</b> the nasal fluid <b>comes via the mouth,</b> and is impure, <b>and sometimes it comes via the nose,</b> and is not impure. <b>But according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan, let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teach</b> that nasal fluids are impure.
The Gemara responds: <b>And according to your reasoning, does</b> this <i>tanna</i> <b>teach</b> that <b>his phlegm and his mucus</b> are impure? <b>Rather, he taught</b> that <b>saliva</b> is impure, <b>and</b> this includes the impurity of <b>all</b> substances <b>that are derived from</b> its <b>amplification,</b> e.g., his phlegm and his mucus. <b>Here too,</b> with regard to nasal fluids, the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>his saliva, and</b> this includes <b>all</b> substances <b>that are derived from</b> its <b>amplification,</b> including nasal fluids.
The <i>baraita</i> teaches that in the case of a <i>zav</i> or <i>zava</i>, the tears of their eyes and the blood from their wounds, as well as the milk of a <i>zava</i>, all transmit the ritual impurity of liquids. The Gemara cites the source for these cases of impurity: <b>The tears of his eye</b> are classified as a liquid, <b>as it is written:</b> “You have fed them with the bread of tears, <b>and given them tears to drink in great measure”</b> (Psalms 80:6). <b>And</b> the <b>blood from his wound</b> is classified as a liquid, <b>as it is written: “And he shall drink the blood of the slain”</b> (Numbers 23:24). Although the verse is referring to the blood of a dead person, and not to the blood of a wound, <b>what</b> difference does it make <b>to me</b> if one <b>killed all of him,</b> and <b>what</b> difference does it make <b>to me</b> if one <b>killed part of him,</b> i.e., wounded him? With regard to the <b>milk of a woman,</b> it too is classified as a liquid, <b>as it is written: “And she opened the bottle of milk, and gave him to drink”</b> (Judges 4:19).
The <i>baraita</i> teaches that the urine of a <i>zav</i> transmits a severe form of ritual impurity, as do his <i>ziva</i> and his saliva. The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that the <b>urine</b> of a <i>zav</i> is impure? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “When any man has an issue out of his flesh, <b>his issue,</b> it is <b>impure. And this</b> shall be his impurity” (Leviticus 15:2–3). The term “and this” comes <b>to include his urine with regard to</b> a severe form of <b>ritual impurity.</b> The <i>baraita</i> asks: <b>And could this not be</b> derived through an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference? If saliva, which comes from a place of purity,</b> i.e., one’s mouth, whose secretions are not usually impure, is nevertheless <b>impure,</b> then with regard to <b>his urine, which comes</b>

Daf 56a

<b>from a place of impurity,</b> the same place that emits <i>ziva</i>, <b>is it not logical that it should be impure?</b> The <i>baraita</i> answers: The case of <b>blood that issues from the opening of the penis may prove</b> that this inference is invalid, <b>as</b> the blood <b>comes from a place of impurity and</b> yet <b>it is pure. Likewise, you should not be surprised about this,</b> the urine of a <i>zav</i>, <b>that even though it comes from a place of impurity it should be pure.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “When any man has an issue out of his flesh, <b>his issue,</b> it <b>is impure. And this</b> shall be his impurity” (Leviticus 15:2–3). The term “and this” comes <b>to include his urine with regard to</b> the severe form of <b>ritual impurity.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive <b>that blood that issues from the opening of the penis is pure? As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> concerning a <i>zav</i>: One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>blood that issues from his mouth or from the opening of the penis is impure,</b> like his saliva and urine. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “His issue, it is impure”</b> (Leviticus 15:2). The term “it” is an exclusion, indicating that <b>it,</b> <i>ziva</i>, <b>is impure, but blood that issues from his mouth or from the opening of the penis is not impure; rather, it is pure.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>But</b> perhaps <b>I should reverse</b> the <i>halakhot</i>. One could derive from the amplification “and this” that blood issuing from the penis of the <i>zav</i> is impure, and from the exclusion “it” that his urine is pure. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai:</b> Urine, rather than blood, should be included among the impure fluids of the <i>zav</i>, as it is <b>similar to saliva: Just as saliva</b> is a fluid <b>that</b> first <b>gathers together and</b> then <b>comes out</b> of the mouth, <b>so too, all</b> impure fluids are those <b>that gather together and</b> then <b>come out</b> of the body. <b>Blood</b> is therefore <b>excluded, as</b> it <b>does not</b> first <b>gather together and</b> then <b>come out</b> of the body.
The Gemara objects: <b>But there is</b> the case of the <b>milk that</b> is emitted <b>from a woman, which</b> first <b>gathers together and</b> then <b>comes out</b> of the body, and it should therefore transmit a severe form of ritual impurity, like saliva and <i>ziva</i>. <b>And</b> yet <b>the Master said</b> in the aforementioned <i>baraita</i>: The <b>milk of a woman transmits the ritual impurity of liquids.</b> One may infer that with regard to <b>the ritual impurity of liquids, yes,</b> it transmits impurity, <b>but</b> it does <b>not</b> transmit <b>a severe</b> form of <b>ritual impurity.</b>
<b>Rather, Rabbi Yoḥanan said in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai:</b> In order to transmit a severe form of impurity the fluid must be <b>similar to saliva: Just as saliva</b> first <b>gathers together and</b> then <b>comes out</b> of the mouth, <b>and</b> if it is not expectorated <b>it is reabsorbed, so too, all</b> impure fluids first <b>gather together and</b> then <b>come out</b> of the body, <b>and are reabsorbed</b> by the body if they are not emitted. <b>Blood</b> is therefore <b>excluded, as</b> it <b>does not</b> first <b>gather together and</b> then <b>come out</b> of the body. The <b>milk that</b> is emitted <b>from a woman</b> is also <b>excluded, as even though it gathers together and</b> then <b>comes out</b> of the body <b>it cannot be reabsorbed.</b>
The Gemara further objects: <b>But let us derive from</b> the case of <b><i>ziva</i></b> that both blood and breast milk transmit impurity: <b>Just as his <i>ziva</i> does not</b> first <b>gather together and</b> then <b>come out</b> of the body, and yet it <b>transmits impurity, so too, all</b> the fluids of a <i>zav</i> should transmit impurity, even if they do not gather together before they are emitted from the body. <b>Rava said</b> in explanation: <b>One cannot derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the blood and breast milk of a <i>zav</i> or <i>zava</i> <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>his <i>ziva</i>, as</b> the case of <i>ziva</i> is unique <b>in that</b> it <b>causes impurity to others,</b> i.e., to the one who emitted <i>ziva</i>.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And the</b> carcass of <b>a creeping animal</b> transmits impurity when moist but not when dry. <b>Reish Lakish says:</b> With regard to the carcass of <b>a creeping animal that dried up but its skeleton is intact,</b> i.e., its bone structure remains in place, it <b>is ritually impure.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna that the items it lists, including the creeping animal, all <b>transmit impurity</b> when they are <b>moist, but they do not transmit impurity</b> when they are <b>dry? Rabbi Zeira said:</b> It is <b>not difficult. This</b> statement of Reish Lakish, that creeping animals transmit impurity even when dry, is referring <b>to</b> a case where <b>all of</b> the bones are intact. By contrast, <b>that</b> ruling of the mishna, that they do not transmit impurity when dry, is referring <b>to</b> a situation where only <b>part of</b> the bones are intact.
This is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak, son of Rabbi Bisna, says</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai says:</b> The verse states with regard to creeping animals: “Whoever touches <b>them</b> when they are dead shall be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 11:31). One <b>might</b> have thought that the carcasses of creeping animals transmit impurity only if one comes into contact <b>with all of them,</b> i.e., with creeping animals that are completely intact. Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “And upon whatever any <b>of them</b> falls when they are dead shall be impure” (Leviticus 11:32). The term “any of them” indicates that this <i>halakha</i> applies even if one comes into contact with only part of a creeping animal.
<b>If</b> the <i>halakha</i> is derived from the term <b>“of them,”</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that even if one comes into contact <b>with a part of them</b> he is rendered impure. Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “Whoever touches <b>them,”</b> which indicates completely intact creeping animals. The <i>baraita</i> concludes: <b>How</b> can <b>these</b> texts be reconciled? <b>Here,</b> where the verse indicates that even part of them transmits impurity, it is referring <b>to a moist</b> creeping animal. <b>There,</b> where the verse teaches that only a complete creeping animal transmits impurity, it is speaking <b>of a dry</b> creature.
<b>Rava said:</b> With regard to <b>these lizards of</b> the city of <b>Meḥoza, when their skeleton is intact</b> they <b>are impure.</b> The dab lizard is one of the creeping animals listed in the Torah. <b>And Reish Lakish says:</b> With regard to the carcass of <b>a creeping animal that was burned but its skeleton is intact,</b> it <b>is ritually impure.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a mishna that indicates a burnt carcass of a creeping animal is pure (<i>Teharot</i> 9:9): In a case where <b>a burnt creeping animal was found on top of</b> a pile of <b>olives, and likewise,</b> if the <b>tattered rag</b> of a <i>zav</i> was found on a pile of olives, the olives and the rag <b>are pure.</b> One is not concerned that the carcass of the creeping animal touched the olives or rag before it was burned, because <b>with regard to all</b> matters of <b>impurity,</b> it is assumed that when the item in question came into contact with the potential sources of impurity, the potential sources of impurity were in the same state <b>as</b> they were at <b>the time they were found,</b> and a burnt carcass does not transmit impurity. <b>Rabbi Zeira said:</b> It is <b>not difficult; this</b> statement of Reish Lakish refers <b>to</b> a case where <b>all of</b> the bones are intact, whereas <b>that</b> ruling of the mishna is referring <b>to</b> a situation where only <b>part of</b> the bones are intact.
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak, son of Rabbi Bisna, says in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai:</b> When the verse states: “Whoever touches <b>them</b> when they are dead shall be impure” (Leviticus 11:31), one <b>might</b> have thought that creeping animals transmit impurity only if one comes into contact <b>with all of them,</b> i.e., with creeping animals that are completely intact. Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “And upon whatever any <b>of them</b> falls when they are dead shall be impure” (Leviticus 11:32), indicating that even a part of them transmits impurity.
<b>If</b> the <i>halakha</i> is derived from the term <b>“of them,”</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that even contact <b>with a part of them</b> transmits impurity. Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “Whoever touches <b>them.” How</b> can <b>these</b> texts be reconciled? <b>Here,</b> where the verse teaches that only the complete carcass of a creeping animal transmits impurity, it is referring <b>to a burnt</b> creeping animal. <b>There,</b> where the verse indicates that even a part of them transmits impurity, it is referring <b>to</b> the carcass of a creeping animal <b>that is not burnt.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that the <i>ziva</i> of a <i>zav</i>, the mucus and saliva of a <i>zav</i>, the carcass of a creeping animal, an animal carcass, and semen all <b>transmit impurity</b> when they are <b>moist,</b> but they do not transmit impurity when they are dry. The Gemara cites the sources for these <i>halakhot</i>: The <i>ziva</i> of <b>a <i>zav</i></b> transmits impurity only when moist, <b>as it is written: “His flesh runs</b> with his issue” (Leviticus 15:3), which is referring to a moist discharge. <b>His phlegm and his mucus and his saliva</b> likewise transmit impurity only when moist, <b>as it is written:</b> “And <b>if one who has an issue spits”</b> (Leviticus 15:8), which is referring to a substance <b>that is like saliva,</b> which is moist.
The carcass of <b>a creeping animal</b> transmits impurity only when moist, as <b>the Merciful One states:</b> “Whoever touches them <b>when they are dead</b> shall be impure” (Leviticus 11:31). This indicates that they transmit impurity when they are in a state <b>similar to</b> their state at the time of <b>death,</b> when creatures are still moist. <b>Semen</b> transmits impurity only when moist, as it must be <b>fit to inseminate. An animal carcass</b> transmits impurity only when moist, <b>as it is written:</b> “And <b>if</b> any animal of which you may eat <b>dies,</b> he who touches its carcass shall be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 11:39), which teaches that the carcass transmits impurity when it is in a state <b>similar to</b> its state at the time of <b>death.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that <b>if one could soak</b> those dry substances in water and restore them to their previous state they would transmit impurity both when moist and when dry. The mishna further teaches that this is referring to soaking them in lukewarm water for a twenty-four-hour period. <b>Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma:</b> Does the mishna mean that the soaking must be performed <b>in lukewarm</b> water from <b>the beginning of</b> the soaking until <b>its end, or perhaps</b> it is sufficient if the water is lukewarm at <b>the beginning of</b> the soaking, <b>even if</b> at <b>the end of</b> the soaking the water <b>is not</b> lukewarm?
The Gemara explains: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>How much</b> time <b>is their soaking in lukewarm</b> water? <b>Yehuda ben Nekosa says:</b> This is referring to a twenty-four-hour <b>period,</b> and it is sufficient if the water is lukewarm at <b>its beginning, even if it is not</b> lukewarm <b>at its end. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> The water <b>must be lukewarm for</b> the entire twenty-four-hour <b>period.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> With regard to <b>the flesh of a corpse</b> that is dry and cannot be soaked to restore it to its previous state, it is ritually pure. <b>Shmuel says:</b> It <b>is pure from transmitting impurity by</b> the amount of <b>an olive-bulk, but</b> if there is a ladleful of the flesh it <b>transmits the impurity of</b> the <b>decayed</b> flesh of a corpse. <b>This is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> With regard to <b>the flesh of a corpse that dried up and cannot be soaked and restored to</b> its <b>previous state,</b> it <b>is ritually pure from transmitting impurity by</b> the amount of <b>an olive-bulk, but it is impure</b> with the <b>impurity of</b> the <b>decayed</b> flesh of a corpse.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The carcass of <b>a creeping animal that was found in an alleyway renders</b> pure items <b>impure retroactively.</b> All items that passed through that alleyway <b>from</b> the time about which <b>one may state: I examined this alleyway and there was no</b> carcass of <b>a creeping animal in it, or from</b> the <b>time of</b> the <b>sweeping</b> of the alleyway, are impure.
<b>And likewise,</b> a blood <b>stain that was discovered on</b> the <b>robe</b> of a woman <b>renders</b> her <b>impure retroactively.</b> Any pure items that she handled <b>from</b> the time about which <b>one may state: I examined this robe and there was no</b> blood <b>stain on it, or from the time of the laundering</b> of the robe, are impure.
<b>And</b> the carcass of a creeping animal or a blood stain <b>renders</b> items <b>impure</b> retroactively <b>whether</b> they are still <b>moist</b> or are already <b>dried out. Rabbi Shimon says: The dry</b> one <b>renders</b> items <b>impure retroactively, but the moist</b> one <b>does not render</b> items <b>impure</b> from the aforementioned times, <b>but</b> only <b>from</b> such <b>a time that it could still be moist</b> from then up to the moment it was discovered.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the case of the carcass of a creeping animal that was found in an alleyway, <b>a dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: The mishna teaches that any pure items that passed through that alleyway <b>from</b> the <b>time of</b> the <b>sweeping</b> of the alleyway are impure. Does this mean that once the alleyway is swept <b>its presumptive status</b> is that it has been <b>examined,</b> as it is examined during the sweeping and any impure item would have been discovered, and therefore any pure items that passed through the alleyway beforehand remain pure? <b>Or perhaps</b> the mishna means that once the alleyway is swept <b>its presumptive status</b> is that it has been entirely <b>swept,</b> and therefore any creeping animal would have been removed by the sweeping.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is the</b> practical <b>difference</b> that arises from this dilemma? The Gemara answers: There is a difference in a case <b>where</b> the one who swept the alleyway <b>said he swept</b> it <b>but did not examine</b> it. <b>If you say</b> that items that were present in the alleyway before it was swept remain pure because <b>the presumptive status of</b> a swept alleyway is that it has been <b>examined,</b> in <b>this</b> case the man explicitly said that <b>he did not examine</b> it, so it does not have this presumptive status. By contrast, <b>if you say</b> that the items remain pure because <b>the presumptive status of</b> the alleyway is that it has been completely <b>swept,</b> in <b>this</b> case too it has been <b>swept,</b> and therefore the items that were present earlier remain pure.

Daf 56b

<b>Alternatively,</b> there is a difference between these explanations in a case <b>where</b> the creeping animal <b>was found in a hole</b> in the ground. <b>If you say the presumptive status of</b> a swept alleyway is that it has been <b>examined,</b> it is clear that <b>one who examines</b> the alleyway <b>also examines</b> any <b>holes,</b> and any items that were in the alleyway beforehand should remain pure. By contrast, <b>if you say its presumptive status</b> is that it has been completely <b>swept,</b> this applies only to items that are on the ground, whereas <b>a hole is not</b> considered to have been <b>swept.</b> Consequently, even items that passed through the alleyway before it was swept should be deemed impure.
The mishna teaches: <b>And likewise,</b> a blood <b>stain</b> that was discovered on the robe of a woman renders her impure retroactively. With regard to this <i>halakha</i> as well <b>a dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: The mishna states that any pure items the woman handled <b>from</b> the <b>time of laundering</b> are impure. Does this mean that once the robe has been laundered <b>its presumptive status</b> is that it has been <b>examined,</b> as when it is laundered it is examined thoroughly, and any blood stain would have been discovered? <b>Or perhaps</b> the mishna means that <b>its presumptive status</b> is that <b>it is</b> thoroughly <b>laundered,</b> and any blood stain would have been removed by the laundering.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the</b> practical <b>difference</b> that arises from this dilemma? The Gemara replies: There is a difference in a case <b>where</b> the person who laundered the robe <b>said he laundered</b> it <b>but did not examine</b> it. <b>If you say its presumptive status</b> is that it has been <b>examined,</b> in <b>this</b> case the man explicitly said that <b>he did not examine</b> the robe, so it does not have this presumptive status. By contrast, <b>if you say its presumptive status</b> is that <b>it is</b> thoroughly <b>laundered,</b> in <b>this</b> case too it has been <b>laundered.</b>
<b>Alternatively,</b> there is a difference between these explanations in a case <b>where</b> the blood stain <b>was found on the side</b> of the robe, in an area where there are folds and stitches. <b>If you say its presumptive status</b> is that it has been <b>examined,</b> it is clear that <b>one who examines</b> the robe <b>also examines the side</b> of the robe, and therefore any items that the woman handled before the robe was laundered should remain pure. By contrast, <b>if you say its presumptive status</b> is that <b>it is</b> thoroughly <b>laundered,</b> this applies only to the main part of the robe, but <b>on</b> its <b>side</b> it <b>is not laundered</b> thoroughly enough to remove a blood stain.
<b>What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to these two dilemmas? <b>Come</b> and <b>hear, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Meir says: For what</b> reason <b>did</b> the Sages <b>say</b> that the carcass of <b>a creeping animal that was found in an alleyway renders</b> pure items <b>impure retroactively from</b> the time about which <b>one may state: I examined this alleyway and there was no creeping animal in it, or from</b> the <b>time of</b> the <b>sweeping</b> of the alleyway? It is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> there is <b>a presumption with regard to Jewish people</b> that <b>they examine their alleyways at the time of their sweeping. And</b> therefore, <b>if they did not examine</b> the alleyway <b>they retroactively lose</b> the purity of any items that were there from the last time it was examined.
<b>And</b> similarly, <b>for what</b> reason <b>did</b> the Sages <b>say</b> that a blood <b>stain that was found on</b> the <b>robe</b> of a woman <b>renders</b> her <b>impure retroactively from</b> the time about which <b>one may state: I examined the robe and there was no</b> blood <b>stain on it, or from the time of the laundering</b> of the robe? It is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> there is <b>a presumption with regard to the Jewish women</b> that <b>they examine their robes at the time of their laundering. And</b> therefore, <b>if they did not examine</b> the robe <b>they retroactively lose</b> the purity of any items they handled since it was last examined.
<b>Rabbi Aḥa says:</b> Even in a case where the robe was not examined when it was laundered and a blood stain was subsequently found on it, and it is unknown whether the stain was present before the laundering, there is a remedy to the dilemma: <b>Let her launder it again. If the appearance of</b> the blood stain <b>changes</b> as a result of this laundering <b>it is known that</b> the robe became stained <b>after</b> the previous <b>laundering,</b> which is why the present laundering affected its appearance. Consequently, those pure items that the woman handled before the earlier laundering remain pure. <b>And if</b> the blood stain’s appearance does <b>not</b> change due to the second laundering <b>it is known that</b> the robe became stained <b>before the</b> previous <b>laundering,</b> and therefore the items that she handled before the laundering are impure.
<b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> One can differentiate between a blood stain that was on the robe before it was laundered and one that stained the robe afterward by inspecting the stain itself. This is because the appearance of a blood <b>stain after the laundering is not similar to</b> the appearance of a blood <b>stain before the laundering, as this</b> stain, from after the laundering, <b>penetrates [<i>makdir</i>]</b> the garment, <b>and that</b> stain, from before the laundering, <b>forms a crust [<i>maglid</i>]</b> that can be scraped off the robe. With regard to the Gemara’s dilemma, one may <b>conclude from</b> Rabbi Meir’s statement that <b>the presumptive status of</b> a swept alleyway or a laundered robe is that it has been <b>examined.</b> The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>conclude from it</b> that this is so.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And</b> the carcass of a creeping animal or a blood stain <b>renders</b> items <b>impure</b> retroactively <b>whether</b> they are still <b>moist</b> or are already dried out. Rabbi Shimon says: The dry one renders items impure retroactively, whereas the moist one does not render items impure since the aforementioned times, but only from such a time that it could still be moist from then up to the moment it was discovered. With regard to the opinion of Rabbi Shimon, <b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> The mishna <b>taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> with regard to the carcass of <b>a creeping animal, but</b> Rabbi Shimon concedes that <b>a moist</b> blood <b>stain also renders</b> the woman <b>impure retroactively</b> from the time that the robe was examined. This is because one can <b>say</b> the blood stain <b>was dry</b> beforehand <b>and water fell upon it,</b> causing it to become moist.
The Gemara asks: With regard to the moist carcass of <b>a creeping animal as well,</b> one can <b>say it was dried out</b> beforehand <b>and water fell on it.</b> It should therefore render items impure retroactively from the time that the alleyway was swept. The Gemara answers: <b>If it is so, that this is</b> what occurred, the dead creeping animal <b>would be sundered apart</b> and would not have its current appearance.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Any</b> blood <b>stains</b> on garments <b>that come from</b> the town of <b>Rekem are ritually pure,</b> as most of the residents there are gentiles, and the blood stains of gentile women are not ritually impure. <b>Rabbi Yehuda deems</b> those stains <b>impure because</b> in his opinion the residents of Rekem are not gentiles; rather, <b>they are converts</b> whose halakhic status is that of Jews, <b>but they are misguided</b> and do not put away their bloodstained garments. The blood stains on garments <b>that come from among the gentiles are ritually pure.</b> With regard to blood stains on garments that come <b>from among the Jews and from among the Samaritans, Rabbi Meir deems</b> them <b>impure,</b> as they may have come from the Jews. <b>And the Rabbis deem</b> them <b>ritually pure due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> Jews <b>are not suspected of</b> failing to put away <b>their</b> garments on which there are blood <b>stains.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna <b>categorically teaches</b> that any blood stains on garments that come from among the gentiles are ritually pure, thereby indicating that this applies <b>even</b> to garments that come <b>from</b> among the gentile population of <b>Tarmod. Rabbi Yoḥanan says: That is to say, one may accept converts from Tarmod,</b> i.e., there is no concern with regard to whether they are actually Jews of flawed lineage, who may not marry Jews of fit lineage.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? But</b> aren’t there <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan and the Elders who both say</b> that <b>one may not accept converts from Tarmod?</b> This is due to a concern that the daughters of the ten tribes exiled during the First Temple period might have intermingled with them, and according to Rabbi Yoḥanan the offspring of a Jewish woman and a gentile is a <i>mamzer</i>, who may not marry a Jew of fit lineage.
<b>And if you would say</b> that Rabbi Yoḥanan merely infers that this is the opinion of the mishna, as indicated by the term: <b>That</b> is to say, <b>but he</b> himself <b>does not hold accordingly,</b> that is not so. <b>Didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say</b> a principle that the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the ruling of <b>an unattributed mishna,</b> as is the case here?
The Gemara answers: <b>They are <i>amora’im</i>, and</b> they disagree <b>with regard to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan.</b> According to one <i>amora</i>, Rabbi Yoḥanan maintains that converts from Tarmod are not accepted, and he did not state that it is a principle that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the ruling of an unattributed mishna. According to another <i>amora</i>, Rabbi Yoḥanan holds that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the unattributed mishna, and therefore one may accept converts from Tarmod.
§ The mishna teaches with regard to blood stains on garments that come <b>from among the Jews</b> and from among the Samaritans that Rabbi Meir deems them impure, and the Rabbis deem them ritually pure. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> with regard to the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, if they deem</b> stains that come <b>from a Jewish</b> woman <b>pure, whose</b> stains <b>do they deem impure?</b>
The Gemara answers: The mishna <b>is incomplete and this</b> is what <b>it is teaching:</b> Everyone agrees that blood stains on garments that come <b>from among the Jews are impure.</b> With regard to blood stains that come <b>from among the Samaritans, Rabbi Meir deems</b> them <b>impure, as</b> he maintains the <b>Samaritans are true converts</b> and have the halakhic status of Jews, whose blood stains are impure. <b>And the Rabbis deem</b> them <b>ritually pure, as</b> they maintain the <b>Samaritans are converts</b> who converted under duress <b>due to</b> the threat posed by <b>lions,</b> and therefore their conversion is void, and their halakhic status is that of gentiles.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> why does the mishna state that according to the Rabbis the blood stains of the Samaritans are ritually pure due to the fact <b>that they are not suspected of</b> failing to put away <b>their</b> garments on which there are blood <b>stains?</b> The mishna <b>should</b> state that their blood stains are pure, as they are <b>converts</b> who converted <b>due to</b> the threat of <b>lions.</b>
<b>Rather, this</b> is what the mishna <b>is saying:</b> Blood stains on garments that come <b>from among the Jews and from among the Samaritans are ritually impure, as</b> everyone agrees the <b>Samaritans are true converts.</b> With regard to blood stains <b>that are found in</b> the <b>towns of Jews, they are pure, as they are not suspected of</b> failing to put away <b>their</b> garments on which there are blood <b>stains, and they</b> certainly <b>put them away.</b> Therefore, the stains necessarily come from gentiles.
The Gemara continues paraphrasing the mishna: With regard to blood stains <b>that are found in</b> the <b>towns of Samaritans, Rabbi Meir deems</b> them <b>impure, as</b> the inhabitants <b>are suspected of</b> failing to put away <b>their</b> garments on which there are blood <b>stains. And the Rabbis deem</b> them <b>pure, as</b> they maintain that even Samaritans <b>are not suspected of</b> failing to put away <b>their</b> garments on which there are blood <b>stains,</b> and the stains are necessarily from gentiles.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>All</b> blood <b>stains</b> on garments <b>that are found anywhere</b> where Jews and gentiles reside <b>are ritually pure,</b> since they must not belong to Jews, who put away their stained garments. This is the <i>halakha</i> <b>except for</b> the stained garments <b>that are found in the</b> inner <b>rooms</b> of the house, as these might be garments that the Jews put away there; <b>and</b> except for the stained garments found <b>in proximity to the house of impurity,</b> i.e., the room that women used when they were impure due to menstruation.
<b>The house of impurity of Samaritans imparts</b> the <b>impurity</b> that is imparted by a corpse <b>by means of a tent, due to</b> the fact <b>that they bury the stillborn</b> children <b>there. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The house of impurity of Samaritans does not impart that impurity, as <b>they would not bury</b> a stillborn child there. <b>Rather, they would cast</b> it outside <b>and an animal would drag it</b> away.
Samaritans <b>are deemed credible to state: We buried the stillborn</b> children <b>there,</b> in a certain place, and it transmits ritual impurity; <b>or</b> to state: <b>We did not bury</b> the stillborn children there, and it does not transmit ritual impurity. <b>They are</b> likewise <b>deemed credible to state about an animal whether it</b> previously <b>gave birth</b> or <b>whether it did not</b> previously <b>give birth;</b> and their testimony is accepted with regard to determining whether the animal’s offspring has the status of a firstborn animal, which is sacred. They <b>are</b> also <b>deemed credible</b> to testify <b>about the marking of graves,</b> i.e., that where they marked is deemed a grave and where they did not mark is deemed a place where there is no grave.
<b>But</b> with regard to the following cases, in which the exact location of a grave is unknown, the Samaritans <b>are not deemed credible</b> to testify: They are <b>not</b> deemed credible to testify <b>about the overhanging boughs, nor about the protrusions</b> that jut out of stone fences and cover the ground. If it is unknown which bough or protrusion hangs over a grave, forming a tent that transmits the impurity of a corpse, and if a Samaritan testifies that the grave is not beneath a particular bough or protrusion his testimony is not accepted. <b>And</b> likewise they are <b>not</b> deemed credible to testify <b>about a <i>beit haperas</i>.</b> The Sages issued a decree that in such a case, the area that was plowed is impure as far as one hundred cubits from the original grave, due to the concern that the bones were dispersed by the plow.
<b>This is the principle</b> governing the credibility of Samaritans: In the case of any <b>matter</b> of <i>halakha</i> <b>that they are suspected</b> of not fulfilling, <b>they are not deemed credible</b> to testify <b>about it.</b>

Daf 57a

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that the Samaritans do not observe burial customs for stillborn children. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> verse <b>did they interpret</b> as a source for this practice? The Gemara replies that they interpreted the verse: <b>“You shall not remove your fellow’s boundary marker, which was bounded by the first ones, in your inheritance</b> that you shall inherit, in the land that the Lord your God gives you to possess it” (Deuteronomy 19:14).
The Gemara explains: The Sages derived from this verse that it is prohibited to sell one’s ancestral burial ground. In accordance with this interpretation of the verse, the Samaritans derived that <b>any</b> individual <b>who has an inheritance,</b> i.e., who stands to inherit land, <b>has a boundary,</b> i.e., a burial place, whereas <b>any</b> individual <b>who does not have an inheritance</b> in the land, e.g., a stillborn child, <b>does not have a boundary,</b> i.e., a burial place. The Samaritans therefore concluded that the mitzva of burial does not apply to stillborn children.
The mishna teaches that Samaritans <b>are deemed credible to state: We buried</b> the stillborn children in a certain place, or to state that they did not bury the stillborn children there, and that place does not transmit ritual impurity. The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> the Samaritans <b>do not accept</b> the Sages’ interpretation of the verse: <b>“And you shall not put a stumbling block before the blind”</b> (Leviticus 19:14), that one may not cause another to sin. Since they are not concerned about misleading others, why is their testimony accepted? <b>Rabbi Abbahu says:</b> The mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> a Samaritan <b>priest is standing there,</b> on that spot, which indicates that he genuinely maintains it is not impure with the impurity of a corpse.
The Gemara objects: <b>But perhaps he is an impure priest</b> and therefore he does not refrain from standing in an impure place. The Gemara explains: The mishna is referring to a situation <b>where</b> the priest <b>is holding <i>teruma</i> in his hand,</b> which indicates he is ritually pure. The Gemara further objects: <b>But perhaps it is impure <i>teruma</i>.</b> The Gemara explains: The mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> the priest <b>is partaking of</b> the <i>teruma</i>, which indicates that it is not impure, as it is prohibited to consume impure <i>teruma</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> i.e., if this is the circumstance, it is obvious that the Samaritan priest’s testimony can be accepted. Then <b>what</b> is the purpose <b>of stating</b> this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers: The ruling of the mishna is necessary, <b>lest you say</b> that the Samaritans <b>are not knowledgeable with regard to</b> the stages of the <b>formation</b> of an embryo, and they might bury a fetus believing that it is an unformed fetus that does not transmit impurity, when it is actually a forty-day-old fetus, which is impure. Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that they are sufficiently knowledgeable, and their testimony is accepted.
The mishna teaches that the Samaritans are <b>deemed credible</b> to state <b>with regard to an animal</b> that it previously gave birth, and its subsequent offspring does not have the sacred status of a firstborn animal. The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> the Samaritans <b>do not accept</b> the Sages’ interpretation of the verse: <b>“And you shall not put a stumbling block before the blind,”</b> that one may not cause another to sin. Why, then, is their testimony accepted? <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> the Samaritan <b>is shearing and working</b> the offspring of the animal. Since the Samaritans are meticulous with regard to Torah law, it is evident that it is not a firstborn.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> i.e., if this is the circumstance, <b>what</b> is the purpose <b>of stating</b> this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers: The ruling of the mishna is necessary, <b>lest you say</b> that the Samaritans <b>are not knowledgeable with regard to a murky</b> discharge emitted from the uterus, which is indicative of a fetus and exempts subsequent births from the mitzva of the firstborn (see <i>Bekhorot</i> 21a). It is possible that the Samaritan mistakenly believes the animal previously emitted a murky discharge and therefore its offspring is not a firstborn.
