Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that they are sufficiently knowledgeable, and their testimony is accepted.
The mishna further teaches that the Samaritans <b>are deemed credible</b> to testify <b>with regard to</b> the <b>marking</b> of graves, as the Samaritans mark their graves, and we rely on their marking as an indication that a corpse is buried there. Therefore, any place where there is no marking is considered ritually pure. The Gemara explains: <b>Even though</b> the marking of graves <b>is</b> required only <b>by rabbinic law,</b> and Samaritans generally do not observe rabbinic law, <b>since it is written</b> in the Bible, the Samaritans <b>are meticulous with regard to it, as it is written:</b> “And those that pass through shall pass through the land, <b>and when one sees a human bone he shall set up a marking by it,</b> until the buriers have buried it in the valley of Hamon-gog” (Ezekiel 39:15).
The mishna teaches: <b>But</b> with regard to the following cases in which the exact location of a grave is unknown, the Samaritans <b>are not deemed credible</b> to testify: They are <b>not</b> deemed credible to testify <b>about overhanging boughs,</b> nor about the protrusions that jut out of stone fences. The Gemara explains these terms: The term <b>overhanging boughs</b> should be understood <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Oholot</i> 8:2): <b>These are overhanging boughs: A tree that hangs over the ground.</b> The term <b>protrusions</b> should be understood <b>as we learned</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i> (<i>Oholot</i> 9:4): <b>Protruding stones that jut out of a fence.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that the Samaritans are not deemed credible to testify about <b>a <i>beit haperas</i>.</b> With regard to a <i>beit haperas</i>, <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav Shmuel says:</b> The reason the Sages deemed a <i>beit haperas</i> impure is due to the concern that the bones, but not the flesh of the corpse, were dispersed by the plow throughout the field. The <i>halakha</i> is that a bone transmits impurity by carrying or by contact, if it is at least the size of a barley grain, but it does not transmit impurity by means of a tent. Therefore, if <b>a person</b> is carrying ritually pure items, or if he wishes to remain ritually pure so that he may consume consecrated items, and yet he must pass through a <i>beit haperas</i>, he <b>may blow</b> on the earth of the <b><i>beit haperas</i></b> before each step, so that if there is a bone beneath the dust he will expose it and avoid it. <b>And</b> in this manner he may <b>walk</b> across the area while remaining ritually pure, even though he might step over a bone.
<b>Rav Yehuda bar Ami says in the name of Rav Yehuda: A <i>beit haperas</i> that has been trodden</b> underfoot by many people <b>is pure,</b> as it may be assumed that any bone fragments at least as large as a barley grain that were on the surface were either broken or removed. <b>And it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>one who plows a graveyard, this</b> individual thereby <b>renders</b> it <b>a <i>beit haperas</i>. And to what</b> extent <b>does he render</b> it a <i>beit haperas</i>, i.e., how far does the concern apply that bones might have been dispersed? The field is rendered a <i>beit haperas</i> to the extent of <b>a full furrow [<i>ma’ana</i>], one hundred cubits</b> by one hundred cubits, which is the <b>area</b> required for sowing <b>four <i>se’a</i></b> of seed. <b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> The area rendered a <i>beit haperas</i> is the area required for sowing <b>five</b> <i>se’a</i> of seed.
With regard to the ruling of the mishna that the Samaritans are not deemed credible to testify about a <i>beit haperas</i>, the Gemara asks: <b>And aren’t they deemed credible? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a field in which a grave was lost,</b> which has the status of a <i>beit haperas</i>, <b>a Samaritan is deemed credible to say: There is no grave there?</b>
The <i>baraita</i> explains: This is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that he is not</b> considered to be <b>testifying</b> about a case of uncertain impurity; <b>rather,</b> he is testifying <b>about</b> the location of the <b>grave itself,</b> which is a matter of Torah law, and the Samaritans are deemed credible with regard to a matter of Torah law. Likewise, in the case of <b>a tree that is hanging over the ground,</b> a Samaritan <b>is deemed credible to say: There is no grave beneath it, as he is testifying only about</b> the location of the <b>grave itself.</b> This indicates that the Samaritans are deemed credible with regard to overhanging boughs and protrusions.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> in explanation: The <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where</b> the Samaritan <b>is walking</b> to <b>and fro over the entire</b> area, and therefore if there was a grave there he would certainly have become impure. Consequently, one may rely on his statement with regard to the purity of the place. By contrast, the mishna is speaking of a case where the Samaritan did not traverse the entire area, and therefore his testimony is not accepted, as they are not meticulous with regard to cases of uncertainty.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> it is obvious that his testimony is credible, and <b>what</b> is the purpose <b>of stating</b> this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers: The ruling of the <i>baraita</i> is necessary, <b>lest you say</b> that perhaps a narrow <b>strip</b> of land, which is called by the same name as this field, <b>extends</b> into a nearby field, and the Samaritan presumes the grave is located in that strip of land. If so, even if the Samaritan traversed the entire field his testimony cannot be accepted, as he traversed the field because he considered it merely a case of uncertain impurity. The <i>baraita</i> therefore <b>teaches us</b> that if the Samaritan traverses the entire field his testimony is accepted, as this concern is not an issue.
The mishna teaches: <b>This is the principle</b> governing the credibility of Samaritans: In the case of any matter of <i>halakha</i> that they are suspected of not fulfilling, they are not deemed credible to testify about it. The Gemara asks: <b>What is added</b> by the term: <b>This is the principle?</b> The Gemara answers: It serves <b>to add</b> that Samaritans are not deemed credible with regard to Shabbat <b>boundaries,</b> i.e., to say that a Shabbat boundary extends until a certain point, as the <i>halakha</i> of Shabbat boundaries applies by rabbinic law. <b>And</b> likewise, the Samaritans are not deemed credible with regard to the status of <b>wine</b> used for <b>a libation</b> in idol worship, as the Samaritans do not refrain from drinking wine touched by a gentile.

Daf 57b

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> A woman <b>who sees</b> a blood <b>stain on her flesh adjacent to</b> her <b>vagina [<i>beit haturpa</i>],</b> i.e., a place where blood that originated in her vagina could be found, <b>becomes ritually impure,</b> as there is a concern that it originated in the uterus and is menstrual blood. <b>And</b> if it was discovered on her flesh in an area <b>not adjacent to</b> her <b>vagina</b> she remains <b>ritually pure,</b> as it certainly did not originate in the uterus. If the stain was discovered <b>on her heel or on the tip of her large toe,</b> although it is not adjacent to her vagina she is <b>ritually impure,</b> as blood from the uterus could have reached there.
In a case where the stain was discovered <b>on her leg or on her feet,</b> if it was <b>on the inner</b> side she is <b>ritually impure,</b> as blood from the uterus could have reached there. If it was <b>on the outer</b> side she is <b>ritually pure, and</b> if it was <b>on the sides,</b> either <b>from here,</b> i.e., on the front of her leg or foot, <b>or from there,</b> i.e., on the back of her leg or foot, she is also <b>ritually pure,</b> as blood from the uterus could not have reached there.
In a case where the woman <b>saw</b> a blood stain <b>on her robe,</b> if it was <b>from the belt and below</b> she is <b>ritually impure,</b> as blood from the uterus could have reached there; if it was <b>from the belt and above</b> she is <b>ritually pure.</b> In a case where <b>she saw</b> the stain <b>on the</b> end of the <b>sleeve of the robe, if</b> the sleeve can <b>reach adjacent to</b> her <b>vagina</b> she is <b>ritually impure; and if not,</b> i.e., if the stain is in a place on the sleeve that does not reach adjacent to the vagina, she is <b>ritually pure.</b>
If it was a robe which <b>she would remove and with which she would cover</b> herself <b>at night, wherever</b> on the robe <b>that the stain is found,</b> the stain renders her <b>ritually impure, due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the robe <b>moves</b> while the woman is asleep and therefore the blood could have originated in the uterus. <b>And likewise with regard to a kerchief [<i>bapoleyos</i>],</b> no matter where the blood is found on the kerchief, the woman is impure.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the cases discussed in the mishna concerning a blood stain found on a woman, <b>Shmuel says:</b> If a woman <b>examined the ground</b> beneath her to see if it was clean from blood and other substances, and she found nothing, <b>and</b> subsequently she <b>sat upon it and</b> then <b>found blood on it,</b> although it might be assumed that this blood came from her, <b>she is ritually pure.</b> The reason is <b>as it is stated:</b> “And her issue <b>in her flesh</b> shall be blood, she shall be in her menstrual state seven days” (Leviticus 15:19). This verse teaches that a woman does not become impure <b>unless she senses,</b> i.e., experiences some type of sensation, <b>in her flesh</b> that she emitted blood from her uterus. Since this woman did not sense an emission of blood, she is pure.
The Gemara asks: How can Shmuel interpret the verse in this manner? After all, <b>he requires this</b> term: <b>“In her flesh,”</b> to teach a different <i>halakha</i>, <b>that</b> a woman <b>becomes impure</b> by finding blood <b>inside</b> her body <b>just as</b> by seeing blood <b>outside</b> her body, i.e., provided that the blood is uterine blood, even if it is currently situated inside her vaginal canal, she is impure. The Gemara answers: <b>If so,</b> if it serves to teach only that blood inside is like blood outside, <b>let the verse say: In the flesh. What</b> is the reason that the verse states: <b>“In her flesh”? Conclude from</b> this term that a woman does not become impure <b>unless she senses in her flesh.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And still,</b> Shmuel <b>requires</b> the term <b>“in her flesh”</b> to teach that she is impure only if the blood touches her flesh, <b>and not</b> through blood found <b>in a gestational sac, nor</b> through blood found <b>in</b> an amorphous <b>piece</b> of tissue that she emitted. The Gemara answers: <b>Conclude two</b> conclusions <b>from</b> this verse, as the plain meaning of the term teaches all these <i>halakhot</i>.
With regard to the opinion of Shmuel, the Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a mishna at the beginning of the next chapter (59b): In the case of <b>a woman who is urinating and sees blood</b> intermingled with the urine, <b>Rabbi Meir says: If</b> she urinates while <b>she is standing</b> she is <b>ritually impure,</b> as the blood could have originated in the uterus. <b>And if she is sitting</b> she is <b>ritually pure,</b> as it is clear that the blood is from a wound.
The Gemara analyzes this mishna: <b>What are the circumstances? If she sensed</b> while urinating, then in the case where <b>she is sitting, why is she ritually pure,</b> according to Shmuel? <b>Rather, is it not</b> referring to a case <b>where she did not sense</b> while urinating? <b>And</b> yet the mishna <b>teaches</b> that if she urinates while <b>she is standing</b> she is <b>ritually impure.</b> This indicates that her status does not depend on her sensing, which contradicts the statement of Shmuel.
The Gemara answers: This affords no proof, as the mishna is <b>actually</b> referring to a case <b>where she sensed</b> while urinating, <b>and</b> yet since this feeling accompanied urination, one might <b>say</b> it <b>was the sensation of urine.</b> Consequently, if she urinated while <b>standing,</b> the <b>urine would return to</b> her <b>uterus and bring blood</b> with it. <b>But</b> if she urinated while <b>sitting</b> the urine cannot return to the uterus and therefore she is <b>pure,</b> as the sensation is attributed to her urine.
The Gemara further suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> the mishna below (58b): With regard to <b>an examination cloth that was placed beneath the pillow and blood was</b> later <b>found on</b> the cloth, and it is unclear whether it is the blood of an examination or the blood of a louse that was crushed beneath it, <b>if</b> the stain is <b>round</b> it is <b>ritually pure.</b> There is no concern that this blood might have come from her examination, as a woman examines through an act of wiping and a stain produced in this manner would not be round. <b>And if</b> the stain is <b>elongated</b> it is <b>ritually impure,</b> as this shape can be formed by an examination.
The Gemara analyzes the mishna: <b>What are the circumstances? If she sensed,</b> then in the case where the stain is <b>round why</b> is it <b>pure? Rather, is it not</b> referring to a case <b>where she did not sense? And</b> yet the mishna <b>teaches</b> that <b>an elongated</b> stain is <b>impure.</b> This contradicts the opinion of Shmuel that a woman is rendered impure only if she sensed.
The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> the mishna is <b>actually</b> referring to a case <b>where she sensed, but</b> since she also performed an examination one might <b>say</b> this <b>was the sensation of the examination cloth.</b> Consequently, if the stain was <b>elongated,</b> as appropriate for a stain produced by an examination, the blood <b>certainly came from her body,</b> whereas if the stain was <b>round</b> it is <b>pure,</b> as this is not the usual appearance of a stain from an examination.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another mishna (14a): If blood <b>was found on his,</b> i.e., the husband’s, examination cloth following intercourse, the woman and her husband are both <b>ritually impure</b> for seven days, in accordance with the <i>halakha</i> of a menstruating woman and one who engages in intercourse with her, <b>and they are</b> each <b>liable to</b> bring a sin <b>offering</b> for unwittingly performing an action punishable with excision from the World-to-Come [<i>karet</i>]. If blood <b>was found on her</b> cloth <b>immediately</b> after intercourse, the woman and her husband are likewise <b>ritually impure</b> for seven days <b>and are</b> each <b>liable to</b> bring a sin <b>offering.</b> If blood <b>was found on her</b> swatch <b>after time</b> passed, they are both <b>ritually impure due to uncertainty,</b> as it is possible that the blood appeared only after intercourse, <b>and they are exempt from</b> bringing <b>the</b> sin <b>offering.</b>
The Gemara analyzes this mishna: <b>What are the circumstances? If</b> it is referring to a situation <b>where she sensed,</b> then in the case where blood was found on her cloth <b>after time</b> passed, <b>why are they exempt from</b> bringing <b>the</b> sin <b>offering? Rather, is it not</b> referring to a case <b>where she did not sense? And</b> yet the mishna <b>teaches</b> that if blood <b>was found on her</b> cloth <b>immediately</b> after intercourse, they are <b>ritually impure</b> for seven days <b>and are</b> each <b>liable to</b> bring a sin <b>offering.</b> Once again, this contradicts the opinion of Shmuel. The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> the mishna is <b>actually</b> referring to a case <b>where she sensed, but</b> since she was engaging in intercourse at the time, one might <b>say</b> this <b>was the sensation</b> of the male <b>organ.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>You are found</b> to <b>say</b> that there are <b>three uncertainties</b> involving cases where blood is found <b>on a woman</b> or her garments. If a stain is discovered <b>on her flesh</b> and there is <b>uncertainty whether it is impure or pure,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is that it is <b>impure.</b> If it is found <b>on her robe</b> and there is <b>uncertainty whether it is impure or pure,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is that it is <b>pure. And</b> in the case of a woman whose status as a menstruating woman is uncertain, <b>with regard to</b> her <b>touching</b> items <b>and with regard to</b> her <b>moving</b> items, one should <b>follow the majority.</b>
The Gemara analyzes the <i>baraita</i>: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the phrase: <b>Follow the majority,</b> with regard to this woman of uncertain status? Does this <b>not</b> mean that <b>if</b> for <b>the majority of her days</b> she is in a state of <b>ritual impurity,</b> as she emits impure blood on many days, then <b>she is</b> considered <b>impure</b> even when her status is uncertain? <b>And</b> since this <i>baraita</i> does not differentiate between cases where she did and did not sense, the ruling that one follows the majority, and that she is impure, evidently applies <b>even though she did not sense,</b> which contradicts the opinion of Shmuel.
The Gemara answers: <b>No</b> proof may be brought from here, as this is what the <i>baraita</i> means: <b>If</b> on <b>the majority of her days</b> this woman <b>sees</b> blood accompanied <b>by a sensation, she is impure,</b> despite the fact that she is uncertain whether she had a sensation, <b>as</b> one can <b>say she sensed</b> on this occasion as well, <b>but</b> it was <b>not on her mind,</b> i.e., she did not pay attention to it at the time.
Before returning to the opinion of Shmuel, the Gemara analyzes the other clauses of this <i>baraita</i>. <b>The Master said</b> above: If a stain is discovered <b>on her flesh</b> and there is <b>uncertainty whether it is impure or pure,</b> it is <b>impure;</b> if it is found <b>on her robe</b> and there is <b>uncertainty whether it is impure or pure,</b> it is <b>pure.</b> The juxtaposition of these two cases indicates that the blood is found in the same area in both instances.
The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances? If</b> the blood was discovered <b>from the belt and below,</b> then when it was found <b>on her robe why is she pure? But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: In a case where the woman saw a blood stain on her robe, if it was <b>from the belt and below</b> she is <b>ritually impure? And if</b> the blood was <b>from the belt and above,</b> then if it was discovered <b>on her flesh why is she impure? But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna that if <b>she saw blood on her flesh</b> in an area <b>not adjacent to</b> her <b>vagina</b> she remains <b>ritually pure?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>If you wish, say</b> that the blood was discovered <b>from the belt and below, and if you wish, say</b> instead that it was found <b>from the belt and above.</b> The Gemara elaborates: <b>If you wish, say</b> that the blood was found <b>from the belt and below,</b> as the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a situation where the blood can be attributed to an external factor, <b>e.g.,</b> a case <b>where she passed through a marketplace of butchers [<i>tabbaḥim</i>].</b> Consequently, if the blood is found <b>on her flesh</b> it is assumed that <b>it came from her body, as, if it came from the</b> outside <b>world, it should have been found on her robe</b> as well. If it is discovered <b>on her robe</b> it is assumed that <b>it came from the</b> outside <b>world, as, if it came from her body, it should have been found on her flesh</b> as well.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that the blood was found <b>from the belt and above,</b> and the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a situation where it is possible the blood came from her body, <b>e.g.,</b> a case <b>where she jumped</b> backward. Therefore, if the blood is found <b>on her flesh it certainly came from her body, as, if it came from the</b> outside <b>world, it should have been found on her robe</b> as well. And if it is discovered <b>on her robe</b> the assumption is that <b>it came from</b> the outside <b>world, as, if it came from her body, it should have been found on her flesh</b> as well.
The Gemara raises an objection from the <i>baraita</i> to the opinion of Shmuel: <b>In any event,</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> that if a stain is discovered <b>on her flesh</b> and there is <b>uncertainty whether it is impure or pure,</b> it is <b>impure, and</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even though she did not sense,</b> which contradicts the opinion of Shmuel. <b>And furthermore, we learned</b> in the mishna that a woman <b>who sees</b> a blood <b>stain on her flesh adjacent to</b> her <b>vagina becomes ritually impure, and</b> this is apparently the <i>halakha</i> <b>even though she did not sense. Rav Yirmeya of Difti says:</b> The ruling of Shmuel that a woman must sense in order to be rendered impure applies only by Torah law. But <b>Shmuel concedes that</b> in all the cases cited above, where it is indicated that a woman is impure despite the fact that she did not sense, <b>she is impure</b>

Daf 58a

<b>by rabbinic law.</b> Accordingly, Shmuel agrees that if she examined the ground, found it clean, sat upon it, and later found blood, even if she did not sense that she emitted blood she is impure by rabbinic law.
<b>Rav Ashi said: Shmuel said</b> this woman is pure even by rabbinic law, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Neḥemya, as we learned</b> in a mishna (59b) that <b>Rabbi Neḥemya says: Any item that is not susceptible to ritual impurity,</b> e.g., the ground, <b>is not susceptible to</b> ritual impurity due to blood <b>stains.</b> This is because the decree of impurity of blood stains was limited to items susceptible to ritual impurity. According to Rav Ashi, all the sources cited above that indicate she is impure even if she did not sense an emission are referring to cases where the stain was found on an item that is susceptible to ritual impurity.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Ashi</b> with regard to Shmuel’s opinion, <b>that is</b> why Shmuel <b>says</b> the woman examined <b>the ground</b> beneath her, as the ground is not susceptible to ritual impurity. <b>But according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Yirmeya, why</b> does Shmuel refer <b>specifically</b> to <b>the ground?</b> The same <i>halakha</i> should apply <b>even</b> if she sat on <b>a cloak</b> and did not sense an emission of blood. The Gemara answers that Shmuel <b>is speaking</b> utilizing the style of: <b>It is not necessary.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: <b>It is not necessary</b> to state that if a woman examined <b>a cloak,</b> found it pure, sat upon it, and then saw a blood stain on it, she is pure. The reason is <b>that</b> it is <b>not</b> easy to <b>examine</b> a cloak <b>well,</b> due to its creases, <b>and</b> therefore <b>there is</b> room <b>to say</b> the stain on the cloak <b>came from the</b> outside <b>world,</b> i.e., from some external factor. <b>Rather, even</b> in the case of the <b>ground, which</b> one can <b>examine well</b> and therefore <b>there is</b> room <b>to say</b> the stain on the ground must have <b>come from her body</b> when she sat upon it, Shmuel teaches that the blood is nevertheless <b>ritually pure.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: If a stain was discovered on her heel or on the tip of her large <b>toe,</b> although it is not adjacent to her vagina <b>she is ritually impure,</b> as blood from the uterus could have reached there. The Gemara comments: <b>Granted,</b> when blood is found on <b>her heel</b> she is impure, as <b>it is wont to touch that place,</b> her vagina, when she kneels. <b>But</b> if the blood is discovered <b>on the tip of her large toe, what is the reason</b> she is thereby rendered impure? <b>And if you would say</b> the reason is that <b>sometimes</b> the tip of one large toe might <b>touch her heel,</b> i.e., the heel of the other foot, <b>do we presume</b> that <b>ritual impurity</b> travels <b>from place to place?</b> Since that is not presumed, the stain on the large toe of one foot cannot be presumed to come from the heel of the other foot.
The Gemara cites the source of this principle. <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If a woman <b>had a wound on her neck</b> in an area <b>where she can attribute</b> the blood she found adjacent to her vagina to that wound, <b>she may attribute</b> the blood to the wound and she is pure. But if the wound was <b>on her shoulder,</b> which is a place <b>where she cannot attribute</b> the blood she found adjacent to her vagina to that wound, <b>she may not attribute</b> it to the wound, and she is ritually impure.
The Gemara explains the proof from the <i>baraita</i>: <b>And</b> it is clear from this <i>baraita</i> that <b>we do not say</b> that <b>perhaps she took</b> blood from her wounded shoulder <b>in her hand and brought it there,</b> near her vagina. <b>Rather,</b> this is the reason for the ruling of the mishna: <b>The tip of her large toe is different, as when she walks it might happen</b> that the tip of this toe is positioned under her vagina and blood drips onto it from there. For this reason she is rendered impure by a stain on that toe.
The Gemara asks: <b>And do we not presume</b> that <b>ritual impurity</b> travels <b>from place to place? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If blood <b>was found on the joints of her fingers</b> on the back of her hand <b>she is impure,</b> despite the fact that blood from her source is not usually found on that part of her hand <b>because hands are active?</b>
The Gemara analyzes the <i>baraita</i>: <b>What is the reason</b> for this <i>halakha</i>? Is it <b>not due to</b> the fact <b>that we say she examined with one hand and</b> then <b>touched</b> the back <b>of the other hand?</b> If so, this indicates that ritual impurity is presumed to travel from place to place. The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> the reason she is impure when blood is found on the back of her hand is that <b>her hand is different, as</b> with regard to the <b>entire</b> hand, including the back, it might <b>happen that it touched</b> the vagina,as one’s hands are active.
§ The mishna teaches: In a case where the stain was discovered <b>on her leg or on her feet,</b> if it was <b>on the inner</b> side she is ritually impure, as blood from the uterus could have reached there. If it was on the outer side of the leg or foot she is ritually pure. The Gemara asks: With regard to the term: <b>On the inner</b> side, <b>until where</b> does it extend? The students of <b>the school of Rabbi Yannai said: Until the place of the joint [<i>mekom ḥavak</i>]</b> of the thigh and shin, the ligaments on the inside of the kneecap.
In this regard, <b>a dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: Is <b>the place of the joint</b> itself considered <b>as</b> part of <b>the inner</b> side <b>or as</b> part of <b>the outer</b> side? <b>Come</b> and <b>hear, as Rav Ketina</b> explicitly <b>teaches:</b> The inner side extends <b>until the place of the joint, and the joint itself</b> is considered <b>as</b> part of <b>the inner</b> side. The Gemara adds that <b>Rav Ḥiyya, son of Rav Avya, teaches it explicitly</b> that the students of <b>the school of Rabbi Yannai</b> themselves <b>said:</b> The inner side extends <b>until the place of the joint, and the joint itself</b> is considered <b>as</b> part of <b>the inner</b> side.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma:</b> If the stain on a woman’s body was in the shape <b>of a bracelet, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Likewise, if it was in the shape <b>of a straight line, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? If it was not in a single defined shape but was <b>a series of drops, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Furthermore, if the stain extended <b>along the width of her thigh, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is there a concern in these cases that the blood might have come from her uterus?
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i>: If a stain is discovered <b>on her flesh</b> and there is <b>uncertainty whether it is impure or pure,</b> it is <b>impure. What, is it not</b> that the case of blood found <b>on her flesh</b> is referring to <b>a case like this,</b> i.e., those cases mentioned by Rabbi Yirmeya, and therefore she is impure? The Gemara answers: There is <b>no</b> proof from here, as <b>perhaps</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a stain <b>shaped like a strip</b> along the length of her thigh, as this is the usual form of a stain from the vagina.
The Gemara relates that there was <b>a certain woman who discovered blood in the warp</b> on the loom where she was weaving. She was concerned that while she was weaving, the threads of the warp might have come between her legs and been stained. <b>She came before Rabbi Yannai</b> to inquire about the status of this blood. Rabbi Yannai <b>said to her: Let her go and come,</b> i.e., she should go and weave in her usual manner. Since this involves a repetitive action, it will soon become clear whether the threads stretch between her legs.
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>one does not</b> rely on <b>repeated</b> actions <b>with regard to ritually pure</b> items? Since the second action might not precisely mimic the first it cannot be relied upon to determine ritual-purity status. The Gemara answers that <b>when we say one does not</b> rely on <b>repeated</b> actions it is only in cases where it would lead <b>to a leniency. But</b> if it leads <b>to a stringency,</b> as in this case where the woman is currently pure, since the blood was not found on her body or her garments <b>one does</b> rely on <b>repeated</b> actions. If the repeated action indicates that the threads of the warp come between her legs while weaving, she is impure.
§ The mishna teaches: If it was a robe that <b>she would remove</b> and cover herself with at night, no matter where on the robe the stain is found, she is ritually impure because the robe moves while the woman is asleep, and therefore the blood could have originated in the uterus. The Gemara comments: It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Yosei, said:</b> With regard to <b>this matter</b> of blood found on a robe worn at night, <b>I issued a prohibitive ruling in the city of Rome. And when I came to the Sages in the south</b> of Eretz Yisrael <b>they said to me: You issued a proper ruling.</b>
With regard to blood discovered on a robe, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>a tall</b> woman <b>who wore the robe of a short</b> woman without first examining it to see if it was clean of stains, <b>and</b> likewise <b>a short</b> woman <b>who wore the robe of a tall</b> woman, if a stain was subsequently found on the robe and it is unknown from which woman it came, the <i>halakha</i> is as follows: <b>If</b> the location of the stain <b>reaches adjacent to the vagina of the tall</b> woman <b>they are both ritually impure.</b> The reason is that in this case it certainly reached that area of the short woman. <b>And if</b> it does <b>not</b> reach adjacent to the vagina of the tall woman, <b>the tall</b> woman <b>is pure,</b> as the stain is definitely not from her, <b>and the short</b> woman <b>is impure.</b>
It <b>is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: If a woman <b>examined her robe</b> and did not find a stain, <b>and</b> then <b>lent it to another</b> woman, after which a stain was discovered on the robe, what is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>She,</b> the woman who lent the robe, <b>is pure, and the other</b> woman, the one who borrowed the robe, <b>may attribute</b> the stain <b>to</b> the woman who lent the robe to her, i.e., she may say that she does not rely on the lender’s examination. <b>Rav Sheshet said</b> in explanation of this <i>baraita</i>: <b>And we learn</b> this ruling that the borrower can say she does not rely on the lender only <b>with regard to the matter of</b> a monetary <b>judgment</b> as to which of the women must pay for the laundering of the robe. <b>But with regard to the matter of ritual impurity, she,</b> the lender, <b>is pure, and the other</b> woman, the borrower, <b>is impure.</b>

Daf 58b

The Gemara asks: In <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> this case <b>different from that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>two women who were occupied with one</b> slaughtered <b>bird, and</b> the bird <b>contained only</b> an amount of <b>blood</b> capable of producing a stain as big <b>as a <i>sela</i></b> coin, <b>and</b> blood the size <b>of a <i>sela</i> was found on this</b> woman <b>and</b> blood the size <b>of a <i>sela</i></b> was found <b>on that</b> woman, <b>they are both impure,</b> despite the fact that the blood of one of them can be attributed to the bird. Likewise, in the case of Rav Sheshet the lender should be impure as well, as she might not have examined the robe properly. The Gemara answers: <b>There it is different, as there is an additional <i>sela</i>.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of a woman who <b>wore three robes,</b> one on top of the other, <b>that had been examined by her</b> for blood stains, and she subsequently found a stain on one of the robes, <b>if she can attribute</b> the blood on the robe to an external source, <b>she may attribute</b> it to that source, and she is pure. <b>And</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even</b> if the stain was <b>on the lower</b> robe, closest to her skin. But if she <b>cannot</b> reasonably <b>attribute</b> the blood to an external factor <b>she may not attribute</b> it to an external factor, and she is impure, <b>and</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even</b> if the stain was <b>on the upper</b> robe.
The <i>baraita</i> elaborates: <b>How so?</b> If <b>she passed through a marketplace of butchers,</b> where blood could have sprayed on her clothes, <b>she may attribute</b> a stain on her garment to the butchers and she is pure, <b>even</b> if the stain was <b>on the lower</b> robe. If <b>she did not pass through a marketplace of butchers</b> or anywhere else with a lot of blood, then <b>even</b> if the stain was <b>on the upper</b> robe she <b>may not attribute</b> the blood to an external source and she is impure.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>And</b> a woman who discovers a blood stain on her body or her garment <b>may attribute</b> its existence <b>to any matter to which she can attribute</b> it: If she <b>slaughtered a domesticated animal, an undomesticated animal, or a bird;</b> or if she <b>was occupied with</b> the removal of blood <b>stains</b> from the garments of other women or from her own garment, from any source, such as blood that originated from a wound elsewhere on her body or even her own menstrual blood from a prior menstrual cycle; <b>or if she sat alongside</b> others <b>who were occupied with</b> removing blood stains; or if <b>she killed a louse;</b> in all of these cases, <b>that</b> woman <b>may attribute</b> the blood stain <b>to it.</b>
<b>How large</b> a stain may a woman <b>attribute</b> to a louse? <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus says:</b> It can be <b>up to</b> the area <b>of a split bean. And</b> she may attribute the stain to a louse <b>even if she does not</b> remember that <b>she killed</b> it. <b>And she may attribute</b> the blood stain <b>to her son or to her husband</b> in a case where one of them is near her and has a wound. Furthermore, <b>if</b> the woman herself <b>has a wound,</b> even if the wound scabbed over and is no longer bleeding, <b>but it can reopen and bleed, that</b> woman <b>may attribute</b> the blood stain to that wound.
There was <b>an incident involving one woman who came before Rabbi Akiva. She said to him: I saw</b> a blood <b>stain.</b> Rabbi Akiva <b>said to her: Perhaps</b> there <b>was a wound on your</b> body? <b>She said to him: Yes,</b> there was a wound <b>and it healed. He said to her:</b> Was it <b>perhaps</b> a wound that <b>could reopen and bleed? She said to him: Yes</b> it was. <b>And Rabbi Akiva deemed her ritually pure.</b>
Rabbi Akiva <b>saw his students looking at each other,</b> wondering why he ruled leniently in this case. Rabbi Akiva <b>said to them: What</b> in this <b>matter is difficult in your eyes?</b> The reason I ruled this way is <b>that the Sages did not state the matter</b> of the impurity of blood stains in order <b>to be stringent; rather,</b> they instituted this impurity in order <b>to be lenient, as it is stated: “And if a woman has an issue, and her issue in her flesh shall be blood”</b> (Leviticus 15:19), from which it is derived that by Torah law, <b>“blood”</b> deems her impure, <b>but not a stain.</b> Impurity from a blood stain was instituted by the Sages, and they rule leniently in any case where the stain can be attributed to another source.
With regard to <b>an examination cloth that was placed beneath the pillow and blood was found on</b> the cloth, and it is unclear whether it is the blood of an examination or the blood of a louse that was crushed beneath it, if the stain is <b>round</b> the woman is <b>ritually pure,</b> as an examination to determine whether a woman is menstruating would not leave a round stain. If the stain is <b>elongated</b> the woman is <b>ritually impure;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Tzadok.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that a woman who discovers a blood stain on her body or her garment may attribute its existence to any matter to which she can attribute it. The Gemara notes: <b>We learn</b> in the mishna <b>that which the Sages taught</b> explicitly in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>An incident</b> occurred involving a blood stain found on a woman’s garment, <b>and Rabbi Meir attributed</b> it <b>to an eye salve [<i>bekilor</i>]</b> that the woman had previously handled, <b>and</b> likewise, <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>attributed</b> a stain <b>to the sap of a sycamore</b> tree the woman had touched.
§ The mishna teaches: Or if she was occupied with the removal of blood stains from the garments of other women or from her own garment, from any source, such as blood that originated from a wound elsewhere on her body or even her own menstrual blood from a prior menstrual cycle; <b>or if she sat</b> alongside others who were occupied with removing blood stains. The Gemara infers: If she knows for certain that <b>she sat</b> alongside those occupied with removing blood stains, <b>yes,</b> she may attribute blood to this source. But if she does <b>not</b> know for certain that <b>she sat</b> alongside those who were removing blood stains, but knows only that she was in the same area as they were, she may <b>not</b> attribute blood to this source.
Again the Gemara comments: <b>We learn</b> in the mishna <b>that which the Sages taught</b> explicitly in a <i>baraita</i>: If a woman <b>passed through a marketplace of butchers</b> and it is <b>uncertain whether</b> blood from the marketplace <b>sprayed on her</b> or <b>whether</b> it did <b>not spray on her, she may attribute</b> a stain to the butchers. But if she is <b>uncertain whether she passed by</b> the marketplace or <b>whether</b> she did <b>not pass by, she is</b> deemed <b>impure</b> and may not attribute it to that source. In this case as well, only if she is certain that she was in a circumstance to which she can attribute the blood may she attribute it to that cause.
§ The mishna teaches that if <b>she killed a louse</b> she may attribute the blood stain to it. The Gemara infers: If she <b>killed</b> a louse, <b>yes,</b> she may attribute blood to it, but if she <b>did not kill</b> a louse she may <b>not</b> attribute blood to it. The Gemara asks: <b>Whose</b> opinion is expressed in <b>the mishna?</b> The Gemara answers that <b>it is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If a woman <b>killed</b> a louse before finding blood, <b>she may attribute</b> blood to it. If <b>she did not kill</b> a louse <b>she may not attribute</b> blood to it; this is <b>the statement of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel. And the Rabbis say: Both</b> in <b>this</b> case <b>and</b> in <b>that</b> case <b>she may attribute</b> blood to a louse.
<b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said</b> there is a difficulty with regard to both his opinion and that of the Rabbis: <b>According to my statement,</b> that a woman may attribute a stain only to a creature she actually killed, <b>there is no limit; and according to the statement of my colleagues,</b> who rule that she may attribute a stain to a louse even if she had not killed one, <b>there is no end.</b>
Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel explains: <b>According to my statement, there is no limit</b> to the size of the stain she found, <b>as</b> she is impure even if it is as small as a mustard seed. Consequently, <b>you have no woman who is pure to her husband, as you have no bed of any sort on which there are not several drops of blood of a louse.</b> Since I rule that a woman may attribute blood to a louse only if she previously killed one, all women will be in a state of impurity to their husbands.
By contrast, <b>according to the statement of my colleagues there is no end</b> to the advantage their ruling provides to women, <b>because</b> if their ruling is accepted <b>you have no woman who is not pure to her husband, as you have no sheet of any sort on which there are not several blood drops,</b> and every woman can attribute all these drops to a louse, even if she had not killed one.
Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel continues: <b>But the statement of Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus appears</b> to be more correct <b>than my statement and their statement, as</b> Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus <b>would say: How large</b> a stain may a woman <b>attribute</b> to a louse? It can be <b>up to</b> the area <b>of a split bean. And</b> therefore <b>we concede to</b> his opinion and accept <b>his statement.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, who say</b> that a woman <b>may attribute</b> blood to a louse whether or not she killed one, <b>how large</b> can the stain be? After all, some stains are far bigger than those produced by a louse. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak says: She may attribute</b> a stain <b>to a bedbug,</b> which has more blood than a louse, <b>and</b> this applies to any stain whose size is <b>up to</b> the width <b>of a lupine</b> seed<b>.</b>
The Gemara continues to discuss the matter of the bedbug. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>This bedbug, its length</b> is <b>equal to its width, and its taste is like its</b> foul <b>smell. A covenant is made with it,</b> i.e., it is a law of nature, <b>that anyone who squeezes it</b> will <b>smell its</b> foul odor. The Gemara explains with regard to which <i>halakhot</i> these characteristics of the bedbug were mentioned. The fact that <b>its length</b> is equal <b>to its width</b> was stated <b>with regard to the matter of stains,</b> i.e., if a stain is found whose length is the same as its width, one may attribute it to the blood of a bedbug even if the stain is larger than the area of a split bean.
The statement that <b>its taste is like its</b> foul <b>smell</b> is applicable <b>with regard to the matter of</b> the partaking of <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> the portion of the produce designated for the priest, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Terumot</i> 8:2): <b>Or if he tasted the taste of a bedbug in his mouth,</b> which is prohibited for consumption, <b>this</b> person <b>must spit out</b> the contents of his mouth, despite the fact that it is generally prohibited to waste <i>teruma</i>. <b>How does he know</b> that there is a bedbug in his mouth? He knows because <b>its taste is like its</b> foul <b>smell. And still, how does he know</b> the smell of a bedbug? In answer to this question the <i>baraita</i> explains that one does not err with regard to the smell of the bedbug, as <b>a covenant is made with it that anyone who squeezes it</b> will <b>smell its</b> foul odor, and therefore it is a well-known smell.
The mishna teaches that a woman may attribute a blood stain as having come from another entity and remain pure. In this regard <b>Rav Ashi says:</b> In the case of <b>a town in which there are pigs, one</b> need <b>not be concerned for stains</b> found on the body or clothes of a woman living there. Since pigs wander the streets and often have stains of blood on them, and their living areas attract bugs of all kinds, any blood stain found on a woman can be attributed to the pigs. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: And this</b> town <b>of Dukeret,</b> where there are many slaughterhouses, garbage heaps, and bugs, <b>is</b> considered <b>like a town in which there are pigs.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: <b>How large</b> a stain may a woman <b>attribute</b> to a louse? Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus says: It can be up to the area of a split bean. The Gemara notes that the meaning of the statement of Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus is a matter of dispute among the Sages. <b>Rav Huna says:</b> If the stain was the size <b>of a split bean she may not attribute</b> it to the blood of a louse; if it was <b>less than</b> the size <b>of a split bean she may attribute</b> it to the blood of a louse. <b>And Rav Ḥisda says:</b> Even if it was the size <b>of a split bean she may</b> still <b>attribute</b> it to the blood of a louse; but if the stain was <b>more than</b> the size <b>of a split bean she may not attribute</b> it to the blood of a louse.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that these Sages <b>disagree with regard to</b> the matter of: <b>Up to and including. As Rav Huna maintains</b> that the term: Up to, means: <b>Up to</b> the measure <b>but not including</b> the measure, and since Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus said that a stain can be up to the area of a split bean, this does not include the size of a bean itself. <b>And Rav Ḥisda maintains</b> that the term means: <b>Up to and including</b> the measure.
The Gemara responds: <b>Rav Huna</b> could <b>say to you</b> that <b>there are</b> instances where the term means <b>up to and including</b> the measure, <b>and there are</b> instances where it means <b>up to and not including</b> the measure. <b>And</b> both <b>here,</b> where it means up to and not including the measure, it is intended <b>as a stringency,</b> as in the statement of Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus; <b>and there,</b> where it means up to and including the measure, it is likewise intended <b>as a stringency.</b>
<b>And Rav Ḥisda</b> could <b>say to you</b> that <b>in general I will say to you</b> that when it leads <b>to a stringency, we say</b> that the term: Up to, means up to and including the measure, whereas if it leads <b>to a leniency we do not say</b> so. <b>And here,</b> with regard to stains, I interpret the term in this manner despite the fact that it entails a leniency, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Abbahu. As Rabbi Abbahu says: All measures of the Sages</b> must be interpreted <b>stringently, except for</b> the measure <b>of a split bean</b> as a standard <b>for stains</b> of blood found on a woman’s clothing, which is interpreted <b>leniently.</b> Therefore, even if the stain is exactly the size of a bean the woman remains pure.
<b>Some say this <i>halakha</i> as a distinct</b> matter, not specifically as an explanation of the mishna: <b>Rav Huna says</b> the area <b>of a split bean</b> is considered the same <b>as</b> the area of <b>greater than a split bean. And Rav Ḥisda says</b> the area <b>of a split bean</b> is considered the same <b>as</b> the area of <b>less than a split bean. And</b> these two <i>amora’im</i> <b>disagree with regard to</b> the matter of <b>up to,</b> whether it means including or not including the measure itself, as discussed <b>in</b> this case <b>here,</b> with regard to stains. The Gemara <b>raises an objection:</b>

Daf 59a

If <b>there were on</b> a woman’s body <b>small drops of blood and large drops of blood, she may attribute</b> these drops to an external source, even <b>with regard to the largest</b> drop, provided that it is <b>up to</b> the size <b>of a split bean. What, is it not</b> that a drop the size <b>of a split bean</b> itself is considered <b>small,</b> like a drop that is less than the size of a bean, which contradicts the opinion of Rav Huna? The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> it means that a drop exactly the size <b>of a split bean</b> is like <b>a large</b> drop, i.e., a drop greater than a bean.
It <b>was stated:</b> If a stain <b>was found on</b> a woman and it was the size <b>of a split bean and</b> slightly <b>more,</b> which is too large to be attributed to a louse, <b>and</b> in <b>that</b> area that was slightly <b>more</b> than a bean there was <b>a squashed louse,</b> what is the status of that woman? <b>Rabbi Ḥanina says she is ritually impure,</b> as the stain is not attributed to a louse; <b>Rabbi Yannai says she is pure.</b> The Gemara explains their opinions: <b>Rabbi Ḥanina says she is impure,</b> in accordance with the <i>halakha</i> <b>that</b> a woman <b>may attribute</b> a stain to a louse only <b>with regard to</b> a stain whose area is up to the area <b>of a split bean,</b> whereas <b>with regard to</b> a stain the size <b>of a split bean and</b> slightly <b>more, she may not attribute</b> it to a louse.
By contrast, <b>Rabbi Yannai says she is pure,</b> as he maintains that <b>this statement</b> that one may not attribute a stain larger than a bean to a louse applies only <b>where</b> there is <b>no louse squashed</b> on the stain. <b>But</b> in a case <b>where</b> there is <b>a louse squashed</b> on the stain <b>it is apparent that this</b> blood that causes the stain to be slightly <b>more</b> than the size of a bean <b>is the blood of a louse.</b> Since it is visibly squashed there, there is no uncertainty in this regard. When that area is subtracted one <b>is left</b> with a stain that is the size <b>of a split bean,</b> and one may say that <b>since in general</b> a woman <b>attributes</b> a stain the size of a bean to a louse, <b>here too, she may attribute</b> the stain to another, second louse.
With regard to the dispute between Rabbi Ḥanina and Rabbi Yannai, <b>Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma:</b> If a woman <b>was occupied with</b> an item the size <b>of a split bean,</b> e.g., the blood of a slaughtered bird, or eye salve, <b>and</b> then a stain <b>was found on her</b> the size <b>of a split bean and</b> slightly <b>more, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Rabbi Yirmeya elaborates: <b>The dilemma can be raised according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥanina,</b> who maintained in the previous case that she is impure, <b>and</b> the <b>dilemma can be raised according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yannai,</b> who ruled that she is pure.
<b>The dilemma can be raised according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥanina,</b> as perhaps <b>Rabbi Ḥanina states there</b> that <b>she is impure only where she was not occupied</b> with a louse, and there is no reason to attribute the stain to that cause. <b>But here, where she was occupied</b> with an item that can stain her, it can be claimed that <b>she may attribute</b> the stain to that source. <b>Or perhaps, even according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yannai, who said</b> in the previous case that <b>she is pure, that statement</b> applies only <b>where a louse</b> was found <b>squashed on</b> the stain; <b>but</b> in a case <b>where there is no louse squashed on</b> the stain and there is no certainty that part of the stain came from another source, <b>she may not attribute</b> part of the stain to the item she was occupied with and part of the stain to a louse. In this situation everyone agrees she is impure.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution from a <i>baraita</i>: If a woman <b>was occupied with a red</b> item <b>she may not attribute a black</b> stain <b>to it.</b> Likewise, if she was dealing <b>with a small</b> item <b>she may not attribute a large</b> stain <b>to it. What are the circumstances</b> of the second clause of this <i>baraita</i>? Is it <b>not</b> referring to <b>a case like this</b> dilemma raised by Rabbi Yirmeya where she was occupied with an item the size of a bean and a stain was found on her that was the size of a bean and slightly more? If so, the <i>baraita</i> teaches that in such a situation she may not attribute the stain to the item.
The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where she was occupied with</b> an item the size <b>of a split bean, and</b> subsequently a stain <b>was found on her</b> the size of <b>two split beans and</b> slightly <b>more.</b> In this situation she may not attribute the stain to the item she was occupied with. The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so, what</b> is the purpose <b>of stating</b> this case? Even if as much of the stain as possible is attributed to the item, a stain larger than a bean remains, and that part cannot be attributed to that source.
The Gemara answers that the ruling of the <i>baraita</i> is necessary <b>lest you say</b> that one should <b>take</b> the blood stain the size <b>of a split bean</b> that came from the blood of <b>the bird</b> she was previously occupied with and <b>cast</b> it <b>into the middle</b> of the stain. In other words, assume the blood from the bird is in the middle of the large stain, joining together two smaller stains. Consequently, one could say: <b>Go here</b> and measure the stain on this side, and <b>there is no measure</b> that transmits impurity, as it is less than the size of a bean, and likewise, <b>go there,</b> to the other side, and <b>there is no measure</b> that transmits impurity. Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that this is not so, and in such a case she is impure.
<b>Rava says:</b> If <b>one type</b> of a stain <b>was found on</b> a woman, e.g., a stain from the sap of a sycamore tree or an eye salve, <b>she may attribute</b> other stains <b>to</b> that source, even if the stains are of <b>several types,</b> i.e., if they differ in color from the first stain. The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Rava from the aforementioned <i>baraita</i>: If a woman <b>was occupied with a red</b> item <b>she may not attribute a black</b> stain <b>to it.</b> The Gemara answers: A situation where she <b>was occupied is different</b> from Rava’s case. Since she was occupied with a red item, there is no reason to attribute a black stain to that source. In Rava’s case, by contrast, she was not occupied with any item, and therefore one can say that just as a stain of one type was sprayed upon her without her knowledge, the same occurred with regard to the other types of stains.
<b>Some say</b> a different version of the above discussion. <b>Rava says:</b> If a woman <b>was occupied with</b> an item <b>of one type, she may attribute</b> stains of <b>several types to it.</b> The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Rava: If a woman <b>was occupied with a red</b> item <b>she may not attribute a black</b> stain <b>to it.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>When Rava said</b> his ruling he was referring to a situation <b>where she was occupied with</b> a slaughtered <b>chicken, which has several types of blood,</b> and therefore she may attribute stains of different types to that cause.
§ The mishna teaches that there was <b>an incident involving</b> one <b>woman</b> who came before Rabbi Akiva and he deemed her pure, to the surprise of his students. He explained to them that the Sages did not state the matter of the impurity of blood stains in order to be stringent; rather, they instituted this impurity in order to be lenient. The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>the Sages did not state the matter</b> of the impurity of blood stains <b>to be lenient, but</b> rather <b>to be stringent?</b>
<b>Ravina says</b> that there is no contradiction between these two statements: The very institution of the impurity of blood stains was enacted so as <b>not to be</b> more <b>lenient than Torah law,</b> but <b>rather to be stringent beyond Torah law. But</b> since the impurity of blood <b>stains themselves is by rabbinic law,</b> the Sages were lenient in specific cases.
§ The mishna teaches with regard to <b>an examination cloth that was placed</b> beneath the pillow and blood was later found on the cloth, that Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Tzadok, maintains that if the stain is round it is ritually pure and if it is elongated it is ritually impure. Concerning this <b>a dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>Do the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Tzadok, or not?</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>An elongated stain combines</b> with other elongated stains, so that if together they form the area of slightly more than a bean the woman is impure. But <b>a series of drops do not combine</b> to constitute a stain that renders her impure. <b>Whose</b> opinion is stated in this <i>baraita</i>? <b>If</b> it is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Tzadok, why do I</b> need <b>a combination</b> in the case of an elongated stain? <b>Didn’t he say</b> that <b>an elongated</b> stain of <b>any</b> size renders her <b>impure?</b>
<b>Rather, is it not</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> and should one not <b>conclude from it</b> that the Rabbis <b>disagree</b> with Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Tzadok? The Gemara responds: <b>No, actually</b> the <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Tzadok, and when Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Tzadok, said</b> an elongated stain is ritually impure he was referring to a stain found <b>on an examination cloth; but with regard to</b> a regular <b>stain</b> of an elongated shape, he does <b>not</b> hold it is impure regardless of its size.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear, as Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Tzadok.</b> Since Shmuel rules that the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is in accordance with his opinion, it may be derived <b>by inference that</b> the Rabbis <b>disagree</b> with his opinion, as otherwise there would be no need for a ruling of <i>halakha</i>. The Gemara affirms: Indeed, <b>conclude from it</b> that this is correct.

Daf 59b

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>a woman who is urinating and saw blood</b> intermingled with the urine, <b>Rabbi Meir says: If</b> she urinated while <b>standing</b> she is <b>ritually impure,</b> as the blood could have originated in the uterus. <b>And if she is sitting,</b> she is <b>ritually pure,</b> as it is clear that the blood is from a wound. <b>Rabbi Yosei says: Whether</b> she urinates in <b>this</b> manner, i.e., standing, <b>or whether</b> she urinates in <b>that</b> manner, i.e., sitting, she is <b>ritually pure.</b>
In the case of <b>a man and a woman who urinated into a basin [<i>hasefel</i>], and blood is found on the water</b> in the basin, <b>Rabbi Yosei deems her ritually pure.</b> Even when it is clear that it is the blood of a woman who urinated, and there is only one uncertainty, Rabbi Yosei deems her ritually pure. In this case, there is a compound uncertainty: Did the blood originate with the man or with the woman, and did the blood come from the uterus or from a wound? <b>And Rabbi Shimon deems her ritually impure,</b> because there is only one uncertainty, <b>as it is not</b> the typical <b>manner of the man to discharge blood</b> with his urine; <b>rather, the presumptive status of</b> the <b>blood</b> is that it was discharged <b>from the woman.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that in a case where a woman finds blood in her urine Rabbi Meir distinguishes between a case where she is standing and a case where she is sitting. The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about a situation where she is <b>standing?</b> The difference is <b>that we say</b> that while she was urinating the <b>urine returned to the uterus and brought blood</b> from there, which renders her impure. But if so, when she is <b>sitting as well, let us say</b> that the <b>urine returns to the uterus and brings blood.</b> Why does Rabbi Meir deem her ritually pure in that case?
<b>Shmuel says,</b> in answer to this question: This mishna is referring specifically to a case <b>where</b> the urine <b>flows</b> in a steady stream, without the woman straining. In such a situation, when she is sitting and the urine flows in a steady stream, the stream of urine does not return to the uterus and bring blood. By contrast, if she is standing the urine does not flow in a steady stream, and she must strain to urinate. When she strains to urinate, the urine can bring blood from the uterus with it, whether she is standing or sitting. The Gemara objects: But in a case where she is sitting <b>as well,</b> when the urine <b>flows</b> in a steady stream, <b>perhaps after the urine has finished, blood will come</b> naturally from the uterus, and the flow of blood will mix with the urine?
<b>Rabbi Abba says:</b> This is no concern, as the mishna is referring to a case <b>where she is sitting on the edge of the basin and</b> urinates in a steady <b>flow into the basin, and</b> the <b>blood is found</b> only <b>inside the basin. As, if it is so that after</b> the stream of <b>urine finished</b> the blood <b>came</b> naturally from her uterus, the blood <b>should have been found on the edge of the basin.</b> Since the blood is found only inside the basin it is clear that it came with the urine, not separately.
<b>Shmuel said, and some say</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei. And similarly, Rabbi Abba ruled for</b> a Sage called <b>Kala,</b> who inquired into this matter, that the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: In the case of <b>a man and a woman</b> who urinated into a basin, and blood is found on the water in the basin, Rabbi Yosei deems her ritually pure. <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: In a case where <b>a man and a woman were standing</b> and they urinated into the same basin, and blood was found in the basin, <b>what</b> would <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> who distinguishes between a woman who was sitting and a woman who was standing, <b>say</b> the <i>halakha</i> is?
The Gemara clarifies the dilemma: <b>When Rabbi Meir said</b> that a woman who sees blood in her urine while standing is impure, does this apply <b>when</b> there is only <b>one uncertainty,</b> i.e., whether the blood came from a wound or from the uterus? <b>Whereas</b> in a case <b>of a compound uncertainty,</b> i.e., whether the blood came from the man or from the woman, and even if it came from the woman, whether it came from a wound or from her uterus, perhaps Rabbi Meir <b>does not deem</b> her <b>impure? Or perhaps there is no difference</b> between the two cases according to Rabbi Meir.
<b>Reish Lakish said:</b> Rabbi Meir would rule in <b>this</b> case of a compound uncertainty exactly as he rules in <b>that</b> case of a single uncertainty, i.e., there is no difference between the two cases. Reish Lakish clarifies: <b>From where</b> do I know that this is Rabbi Meir’s opinion? <b>From</b> the fact <b>that</b> the latter clause of the mishna <b>does not teach: Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yosei deem her pure.</b> Instead, the mishna states merely that Rabbi Yosei deems her pure. This indicates that Rabbi Meir deems her impure even if a man and a woman both urinated into the same basin where the blood was found.
The Gemara raises a difficulty with regard to Reish Lakish’s opinion: <b>If so,</b> i.e., if according to Rabbi Meir a woman is impure even when a man also urinates into the same basin, <b>now</b> that <b>Rabbi Meir deems her impure in</b> a case of <b>compound uncertainty, is it necessary</b> for the mishna to teach his opinion <b>in</b> a case of <b>one uncertainty?</b> The Gemara answers: The mishna formulated the <i>halakha</i> in that manner <b>to convey the far-reaching</b> nature of the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yosei,</b> i.e., <b>that he deems her pure even in</b> a case of <b>one uncertainty.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, <b>rather than</b> stating the <b>dispute in</b> a case of <b>one uncertainty,</b> which serves <b>to convey the far-reaching</b> nature of the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yosei, let</b> the <i>tanna</i> teach the <b>dispute in</b> a case of <b>compound uncertainty,</b> in order <b>to convey the far-reaching</b> nature of the opinion <b>of Rabbi Meir.</b> The Gemara answers: It is <b>preferable for the</b> <i>tanna</i> to teach <b>the strength of a lenient</b> ruling. If a <i>tanna</i> can formulate a dispute in a manner that emphasizes the extent of the more lenient opinion, he will do so.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> disagreed with Reish Lakish, and <b>said: When Rabbi Meir says</b> that the woman is impure, that applies only to a case <b>of one uncertainty, but</b> in a case <b>of compound uncertainty</b> Rabbi Meir <b>did not say</b> that she is impure. The Gemara raises a difficulty with regard to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s opinion: <b>If so,</b> i.e., if Rabbi Meir deems her pure when both a man and a woman urinate into the same basin, <b>let</b> the mishna <b>teach: Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yosei deem her pure.</b> Why does the <i>tanna</i> mention only Rabbi Yosei? The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, it is indeed so,</b> that Rabbi Meir agrees with this ruling, <b>but since</b> the mishna <b>left off</b> with the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yosei</b> at the end of the first clause of the mishna, the <i>tanna</i> <b>opened</b> the latter clause <b>with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yosei</b> as well.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> as <b>Rabbi Yosei deems</b> her <b>pure</b> in a case <b>of one uncertainty, is it necessary</b> for the mishna to teach his opinion a case <b>of a compound uncertainty?</b> The Gemara answers: It is necessary for the <i>tanna</i> to state that Rabbi Yosei deems her pure in a case of compound uncertainty, <b>lest you say</b> that <b>this statement,</b> that Rabbi Yosei deems her pure, applies only <b>after the fact,</b> if the woman has already touched pure items, <b>but</b> he does <b>not</b> deem her pure <b><i>ab initio</i>.</b> Therefore, the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches us</b> that Rabbi Yosei deems her pure even <i>ab initio</i>.
It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> In the case of <b>a man and a woman who urinated into a basin, and blood is found on the water</b> in the basin, <b>Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yosei deem her ritually pure, and Rabbi Shimon deems her ritually impure,</b> as there is only one uncertainty.
§ The mishna teaches that Rabbi Shimon deems her ritually impure because there is only one uncertainty, as it is not the typical manner of the man to discharge blood with his urine. <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: In a case where <b>a woman</b> was <b>sitting</b> and she urinated into a basin, and blood was found in the basin, <b>what</b> would <b>Rabbi Shimon say?</b> The Gemara explains the dilemma: <b>When Rabbi Shimon stated</b> his opinion, was he referring specifically <b>to</b> a woman who <b>is standing, who in general must strain</b> to urinate in such a position, and perhaps as a result the blood came from the uterus? <b>Whereas</b> if <b>she</b> is <b>sitting</b> without straining, in which case Rabbi Meir deems her pure, perhaps Rabbi Shimon agrees that she is <b>not</b> impure. <b>Or perhaps there is no difference</b> between the two cases according to the opinion of Rabbi Shimon.
The Gemara answers: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If a woman urinates while <b>sitting</b> and blood is found in the basin, she can <b>attribute</b> the blood to a wound and she is pure, but if she is <b>standing she cannot attribute</b> the blood to a wound, and therefore she is impure; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yosei said: Both</b> in <b>this</b> case <b>and</b> in <b>that</b> case <b>she</b> can <b>attribute</b> the blood to a wound and she is pure. <b>Rabbi Shimon said: Both</b> in <b>this</b> case <b>and</b> in <b>that</b> case <b>she cannot attribute</b> the blood to a wound, and she is impure.
Another <b>dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages with regard to the opinion of Rabbi Shimon: In a case where <b>a man and a woman</b> were <b>sitting</b> and urinated into the same basin, and blood was found in the basin, <b>what</b> would <b>Rabbi Shimon say?</b> The Gemara clarifies the dilemma: <b>When Rabbi Shimon stated</b> his opinion, was he referring to a woman who <b>is standing, who in general must strain</b> to urinate in such a position and perhaps as a result the blood came from the uterus, <b>or</b> to a case where <b>she</b> alone <b>is sitting, which</b> are cases of only <b>one uncertainty? Whereas</b> in a case of <b>compound uncertainty,</b> i.e., uncertainty whether the blood came from the man or from the woman, and even if it did come from the woman, whether it was from a wound or from her uterus, perhaps <b>he does not say</b> that she is impure. <b>Or perhaps there is no difference</b> between the cases, as it is entirely atypical for a man to discharge blood.
The Gemara answers: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> the mishna: <b>Since Rabbi Shimon said</b> that <b>the presumptive status of</b> the <b>blood</b> is that it was discharged <b>from the woman,</b> evidently there <b>is no difference</b> in his opinion whether she was <b>standing or</b> whether she was <b>sitting.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In a case where a woman <b>lent her garment to a gentile woman or to a menstruating</b> Jewish <b>woman,</b> and after the borrower returned the garment the owner wore it and then discovered a blood stain, she <b>attributes</b> the blood stain <b>to</b> the gentile or the menstruating woman.
In a case of <b>three women who wore one garment or who sat on one bench [<i>safsal</i>],</b> one after the other, and the garment, or bench, was examined before the first of them donned it, or sat on it, and it was clean, and after the third one removed the garment, or stood up, <b>a blood</b> stain <b>was discovered on</b> the garment or on the bench, <b>all</b> the women <b>are ritually impure.</b>
If <b>they sat on a stone bench or on the bench [<i>ha’itzteva</i>] of a bathhouse,</b> neither of which can become ritually impure, the first because it is stone and the second because it is attached to the floor of the bathhouse, and a blood stain was found on one of those benches, <b>Rabbi Neḥemya deems</b> all three women <b>ritually pure, as Rabbi Neḥemya would say: Any item that is not susceptible to ritual impurity is not susceptible to</b> ritual impurity due to blood <b>stains.</b> The decree of impurity due to blood stains was limited to items susceptible to ritual impurity.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav says:</b> The ruling of the mishna is stated <b>with regard to a gentile woman</b>

Daf 60a

<b>who is</b> of age and already <b>seeing</b> a flow of menstrual blood, i.e., she has had a flow of menstrual blood.
The Gemara explains: <b>From where</b> does Rav know that this is referring to a gentile woman who once experienced a flow of blood? He infers from the mishna that the gentile woman it mentions is <b>similar to a menstruating woman: Just as a menstruating woman</b> is one <b>who sees,</b> i.e., who has already experienced bleeding, <b>so too,</b> the mishna is referring to an adult <b>gentile woman who</b> already <b>sees</b> menstrual blood.
<b>Rav Sheshet says: I say</b> that <b>when Rav was dozing or sleeping he said that <i>halakha</i>,</b> i.e., it is an error. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If a woman loaned her garment to a gentile and subsequently found a blood stain on it, <b>she attributes</b> the stain <b>to the gentile woman.</b> This <i>tanna</i> deems it permitted for her to attribute the blood to any gentile woman, regardless of her age or her likelihood of bleeding. <b>Rabbi Meir</b> disagrees and <b>says:</b> This applies specifically <b>to a gentile woman who is fit to see</b> menstrual blood. <b>And</b> the Gemara adds that <b>even Rabbi Meir says only that</b> the gentile woman must be <b>fit to see</b> menstrual blood, <b>but</b> he too agrees that <b>it is not necessary</b> for her to be <b>seeing</b> blood at that time. She does not have to have actually experienced bleeding at some point.
<b>Rava said</b> in response to Rav Sheshet’s challenge: <b>And</b> how can <b>you understand</b> that <b>Rabbi Meir</b> is coming <b>to be stringent?</b> Rav Sheshet maintains that according to the first <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> she can attribute the blood stain to any gentile, whereas Rabbi Meir rules stringently that she may attribute it only to a gentile who is fit to experience bleeding. This is incorrect, as <b>Rabbi Meir</b> is actually coming <b>to be lenient.</b> In other words, the first <i>tanna</i> is more stringent, as he deems it permitted for her to attribute the blood stain only to a gentile woman who had experienced a menstrual flow at least once. By contrast, Rabbi Meir rules that she may attribute the stain to a gentile woman who is old enough to experience bleeding, even if she has never experienced a menstrual flow.
The Gemara provides the reason for Rava’s opinion. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: A woman who loaned her garment to a gentile woman and subsequently finds a blood stain on it <b>may not attribute</b> the stain <b>to</b> the <b>gentile woman. Rabbi Meir says</b> that <b>she may attribute</b> the blood stain to the gentile woman. <b>But if so,</b> the first <i>baraita</i>, which states that according to the first <i>tanna</i> she may attribute the blood stain to any gentile woman, is <b>difficult.</b> You must <b>answer like this:</b> According to the first <i>tanna</i> she may attribute the blood to any gentile woman provided that <b>she sees,</b> i.e., that she once experienced bleeding. By contrast, <b>Rabbi Meir says</b> a more lenient opinion, <b>that</b> she may attribute it to the gentile woman provided that <b>she is fit to see</b> menstrual blood, <b>and</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even though she has not</b> actually <b>seen</b> menstrual blood yet.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> a <i>baraita</i> with regard to a woman who loaned her garment to another woman who was a lesser <i>zava</i>: The lender <b>may attribute</b> the blood stain on the loaned garment <b>to a woman who observes</b> a clean <b>day for</b> each <b>day</b> she experiences a discharge, if the blood is found <b>on her second</b> day, i.e., the day after she had a discharge, despite the fact that she does not have a presumptive status of seeing blood. It is nevertheless considered that her uterus is open and the likelihood is that she will experience bleeding.
<b>And</b> likewise, she may also attribute the blood stain if she loaned her garment <b>to a woman counting seven</b> clean days <b>who did not immerse</b> in a ritual bath, and who will now have to count another seven clean days. <b>Therefore,</b> the status of the one who loaned the garment <b>is fixed, and</b> the status of <b>the other</b> woman <b>is ruined</b> and she must begin her counting again; this is <b>the statement of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: She may not attribute</b> the blood flow to either of these women. <b>Therefore,</b> the statuses of <b>both</b> the woman who loaned the garment and the one who borrowed it <b>are ruined,</b> in that both women are deemed impure.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And</b> both Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel and Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>agree that</b> a woman who lends her garment <b>may attribute</b> any blood stain found on it <b>to a woman</b> who <b>observes a day for a day</b> if it is <b>on her first</b> day of the discharge. In this case the status of the woman who borrowed the garment is no more ruined than it was already, as either way she can become pure on the following day.
<b>And</b> they also agree <b>in</b> a case where the woman who borrowed the garment was a woman after childbirth <b>who is observing</b> the period <b>of</b> the <b>blood of purity.</b> During these days, attributing the blood to her does not ruin her status, as any blood she emits is pure and does not affect her status. <b>And</b> similarly, the lender may attribute the blood stain <b>to a virgin</b> who engages in intercourse for the first time, <b>as her blood is pure,</b> as there is an assumption that it is hymenal bleeding rather than menstrual blood.
The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need the clause starting with: <b>Therefore,</b> mentioned <b>by Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel?</b> It is obvious that the status of only one woman is ruined, so what information does this observation add? The Gemara answers that this clause does not add any new information; rather, the <i>baraita</i> taught it <b>because</b> of the use of the similar clause beginning with: Therefore, stated <b>by Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi in the latter part of the <i>baraita</i>.
The Gemara persists: But <b>why do I</b> need the clause starting with: <b>Therefore,</b> in the statement <b>of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi? That too is apparently superfluous. The Gemara explains: It is necessary, <b>lest you say</b> that the status of the woman <b>who has</b> the blood <b>stain found with her</b> when she is wearing the garment, should be <b>ruined,</b> whereas the status of <b>the other</b> woman should <b>not be ruined,</b> as the garment was not with her when the blood stain was discovered. Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> the clause beginning with: Therefore, to stress that both women are impure.
§ With regard to the dispute between Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel and Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, <b>Rav Ḥisda says:</b> In a case of two individuals, one of whom was <b>ritually impure and</b> the other of whom was <b>pure, who walked on two paths, one</b> of which was <b>pure and</b> the other <b>one impure</b> due to a corpse buried there, and neither remembers which path he took, and afterward they handled items of ritual purity, e.g., the portion of produce designated for the priest [<i>teruma</i>] or consecrated items, <b>we have arrived at the dispute</b> between <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>and Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel.</b> According to Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, if one of the two individuals was already impure it can be assumed that he was the one who walked along the ritually impure path, and the other individual remains pure. Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi claims that there is no assumption that the one who was pure retains that state, as it is equally possible that he walked along the ritually impure path.
<b>Rav Adda objects to this</b> suggestion of Rav Ḥisda, claiming that one cannot compare the two cases.
