<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>It was stated:</b> If a woman <b>saw</b> menstrual blood on the <b>fifteenth of this month, and</b> on the <b>sixteenth of</b> the <b>month</b> after <b>that, and</b> on the <b>seventeenth of</b> the <b>month</b> after <b>that, Rav says: She has</b> thereby <b>determined her</b> menstrual <b>cycle by skipping,</b> i.e., as a month and a day. <b>And Shmuel says:</b> Her menstrual cycle is not determined <b>until she skips</b> a day <b>three times.</b> According to Shmuel, as the cycle is established in this case not by the date itself but by the pattern of one additional day every month, the pattern is established only when this occurs three consecutive times, i.e., when she menstruates on the fourth occasion.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Shall we say</b> that <b>Rav and Shmuel disagree with regard to</b> the issue that is the subject of <b>the dispute between Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>and Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel? As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If a woman <b>was married to</b> her <b>first</b> husband <b>and he died,</b> and was then married <b>to a second</b> one <b>and he</b> too <b>died, she may not marry a third</b> husband; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: She may marry a third</b> husband, but if he also dies <b>she may not marry a fourth</b> husband. The suggestion is that Rav and Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi hold that after two instances she has established a presumption and a pattern, whereas Shmuel and Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel maintain that the presumption is established only after three occurrences.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>No, everyone agrees</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel,</b> that a presumption is established only after three times, <b>and here they disagree with regard to this</b> matter: <b>Rav holds</b> that when she experienced bleeding on the <b>fifteenth</b> of the month, that occasion is also one <b>of the number,</b> i.e., it counts as the first of the pattern, which therefore has three elements. <b>And Shmuel holds</b> that <b>since she did not see</b> the first time after <b>skipping,</b> i.e., after having experienced bleeding on the fourteenth of the previous month, <b>it is not</b> part of <b>the number,</b> which means that she has experienced bleeding only twice in accordance with that pattern.
Shmuel <b>raised an objection to</b> the opinion of Rav from a <i>baraita</i>: If a woman <b>was accustomed to see</b> a flow of blood on the <b>fifteenth day</b> of the month, <b>and deviated</b> and instead experienced bleeding <b>on the sixteenth day</b> of the month, on both <b>this</b> day, the fifteenth, <b>and that</b> day, the sixteenth, it is <b>prohibited</b> for her to engage in intercourse with her husband. If she then <b>deviated</b> and experienced bleeding <b>on the seventeenth day</b> of the following month, <b>the sixteenth</b> day becomes <b>permitted, and the fifteenth and seventeenth</b> days of the following month <b>are prohibited.</b>
If she subsequently <b>deviated</b> and experienced bleeding <b>on</b> the <b>eighteenth day</b> of the following month, <b>all</b> the days <b>are permitted.</b> The fifteenth is permitted because she has now experienced bleeding three times on a different day, while the other days are permitted because she experienced bleeding only once on each day. <b>And</b> it is <b>prohibited</b> for her to engage in intercourse in the following month <b>only from</b> the <b>eighteenth</b> day <b>and onward,</b> i.e., on the nineteenth day, since she has now established a pattern of bleeding after one month and one day. This is <b>difficult for Rav,</b> as he maintains that twice is sufficient to establish a pattern, whereas this <i>baraita</i> requires three instances. <b>Rav</b> could have <b>said to you</b> in response: Since she <b>was accustomed</b> to experience bleeding on the fifteenth <b>it is different.</b> In that particular case the fifteenth does not count as the beginning of a new pattern because it was already her regular established time.
The Gemara expresses surprise at Shmuel’s question: <b>And he who asked [<i>udeka’arei</i>] it, why did he ask it?</b> The <i>baraita</i> clearly stresses the fact that the woman began with an established fixed menstrual cycle that was not part of the pattern. Shmuel could answer: <b>It was necessary</b> for the <i>baraita</i> to teach the case where she <b>was accustomed</b> to experience bleeding on a specific day, <b>lest you say</b> that <b>since she was accustomed</b> to experience bleeding on a specific day <b>and displaced</b> that pattern by bleeding on a different day, it should be sufficient that <b>with two times she displaces it.</b> For this reason, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that an established pattern is displaced only after three occasions where she experiences bleeding on a different day. If it is not established, one displacement is enough.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: If a woman <b>saw</b> a flow of blood on the <b>twenty-first day of this month,</b> the <b>twenty-second day of that month,</b> i.e., of the next month, and the <b>twenty-third day of that month,</b> i.e., of the third month, <b>she established a fixed</b> pattern of bleeding after one month and one day. If in the third month she instead <b>varied</b> and experienced bleeding <b>on</b> the <b>twenty-fourth day</b> of the month, <b>she has not established a fixed</b> pattern, as this last interval was one month and two days long. This is apparently <b>a conclusive refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel,</b> as according to the <i>baraita</i> the pattern is established after only two equidistant intervals, whereas Shmuel requires three.
The Gemara answers that <b>Shmuel</b> could have <b>said to you: Here, we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where</b> the woman <b>was accustomed to see</b> a flow of blood <b>on</b> the <b>twentieth day</b> of the month, <b>and she deviated</b> and experienced bleeding <b>on the twenty-first day</b> of the month. Consequently, there were in fact a total of three equidistant intervals of one month and one day. The Gemara adds that the language of the <i>baraita</i> <b>is also precise, as</b> for what other reason would the <i>baraita</i> <b>leave</b> aside the <b>twentieth day</b> of the month and not use that date as the example, <b>and</b> instead <b>take</b> for its example the <b>twenty-first day</b> of the month? <b>Learn from this</b> that she had an established pattern of bleeding on the twentieth of every month before the events described in the <i>baraita</i>.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>As a woman establishes a fixed</b> menstrual <b>cycle only after she establishes it</b> three times. <b>Rav Pappa says,</b> in explanation: <b>We said</b> that she must experience bleeding three times <b>only with regard to establishing</b> a fixed menstrual cycle, <b>but with regard to</b> being <b>concerned</b> for a pattern, even <b>after one time she must be concerned</b> that this might be the beginning of a fixed pattern.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> Rav Pappa <b>teaching us? We learn</b> this in the mishna: If the woman <b>was accustomed to see</b> the flow of blood on the <b>fifteenth day and she deviated</b> from the norm <b>to see</b> the flow of blood <b>on</b> the <b>twentieth day,</b> on both <b>this</b> day, the fifteenth, <b>and that</b> day, the twentieth, it is <b>prohibited</b> for her to engage in intercourse. This clearly demonstrates that even after bleeding only once on a certain day she must be concerned that this could be the start of a new fixed menstrual cycle.
The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> this <i>halakha</i> was derived only <b>from there, I would say</b> that <b>this statement</b> applies in a case <b>where</b> she experiences bleeding on the twentieth day while <b>she is standing in her days</b> suitable for <b>menstruation,</b> i.e., the days following the eleven days after her last period, when she is most likely to menstruate. <b>But</b> in a case <b>where she is not standing in her days</b> suitable for <b>menstruation,</b> but rather during the eleven days when uterine bleeding would render her a <i>zava</i>, <b>I would say</b> that she does <b>not</b> need to be concerned that she might experience bleeding again at that time. Therefore, Rav Pappa <b>teaches us</b> that even during these eleven days she must be concerned.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And</b> a woman <b>is purified from the</b> existing fixed menstrual <b>cycle,</b> in the sense that intercourse is permitted on that day, <b>only</b> when she has been displaced from that day three times. <b>Rav Pappa says,</b> in explanation: <b>We said</b> this <b>only</b> in the case of a set cycle <b>that she established</b> by <b>three times.</b> With regard to such a cycle, we said <b>that</b> a different <b>three times are necessary to displace</b> that cycle. <b>But</b> with regard to a cycle that is established with only <b>two times, it is displaced by one time</b> of bleeding on a different day.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> Rav Pappa <b>teaching us? We learn</b> this in the mishna: <b>A woman establishes</b> a fixed menstrual <b>cycle only after she establishes it three times.</b> The Gemara answers that it was necessary for Rav Pappa to teach his <i>halakha</i>, <b>lest you say</b> that a cycle is displaced by bleeding <b>one</b> time on a different day <b>for</b> a cycle that was set <b>one</b> time, but by bleeding on <b>two</b> different days <b>for</b> a cycle that was established with <b>two</b> times, <b>and</b> likewise by bleeding on <b>three</b> different days <b>for</b> a cycle that was established with <b>three</b> times. Therefore, Rav Pappa <b>teaches us</b> that whether she experiences bleeding once or twice, she displaces it by bleeding once on a different day.
It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Pappa:</b> If a woman <b>was accustomed to see</b> the flow of blood on the <b>twentieth day</b> after her previous flow, <b>and she deviated</b> from the norm to experience bleeding <b>on</b> the <b>thirtieth day,</b> on both <b>this</b> day, the twentieth, <b>and that</b> day, the thirtieth, it is <b>prohibited</b> for her to engage in intercourse. If the <b>twentieth day arrived,</b> counting from the previous flow, which had occurred on day thirty, <b>and she did not see</b> a flow of blood, <b>it is permitted for her to engage</b> in intercourse <b>until</b> the <b>thirtieth day</b> after the previous flow, <b>and she</b> must be <b>concerned on</b> the <b>thirtieth day.</b>
If the <b>thirtieth day arrived and she saw</b> a flow of blood, and then the <b>twentieth day</b> after that <b>arrived and she did not see</b> a flow of blood, <b>and</b> the <b>thirtieth day</b> from her previous flow <b>arrived and she did not see</b> blood on that day but saw on a later day, <b>and</b> then the <b>twentieth day</b> after her previous flow <b>arrived and she saw</b> a flow of blood, the <b>thirtieth day becomes permitted,</b> as she experienced bleeding after an interval of thirty days only twice. This is in accordance with the opinion of Rav Pappa that a cycle of bleeding that has occurred twice is displaced by a single time of not bleeding on that day.

Daf 64b

<b>And</b> she is <b>prohibited</b> on the <b>twentieth day, because</b> it is the <b>manner</b> of women that their blood flow <b>comes at its</b> usual <b>time.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Women, with regard to</b> the blood that flows when <b>their hymens</b> are ruptured, <b>are like grapevines: There is a vine that</b> produces <b>wine</b> that <b>is red, and there is a vine that</b> produces <b>wine</b> that <b>is black; and there is a vine that</b> produces <b>wine in abundance, and there is a vine that</b> produces only <b>a meager</b> amount of <b>wine. Rabbi Yehuda says: In every vine, there are</b> grapes fit to produce <b>wine, but</b> any vine in <b>which there are no</b> grapes fit to produce <b>wine, this is a dry vine [<i>durkati</i>].</b> Likewise, any woman who experiences bleeding is capable of giving birth, whereas one who does not experience bleeding is like a dry vine, unable to give birth.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the term <i>durkati</i>, the Gemara explains that this means <b>truncated generation [<i>dor katua</i>].</b> As <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya teaches: Just as leaven is good for dough, so too, blood is good for a woman.</b> It was likewise <b>taught in the name of Rabbi Meir: Any woman whose blood is plentiful, her children are plentiful.</b>

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>a young girl whose time to see</b> a menstrual flow, i.e., the age of puberty, <b>has not</b> yet <b>arrived, and she married</b> and engaged in intercourse and her hymen was torn, <b>Beit Shammai say:</b> The Sages <b>give her four nights</b> after intercourse during which the blood is attributed to the torn hymen and she remains ritually pure. Thereafter, any blood is assumed to be menstrual blood and renders her impure. <b>And Beit Hillel say:</b> The blood is attributed to the torn hymen <b>until the wound heals.</b>
In the case of a young woman <b>whose time to see</b> a menstrual flow <b>has arrived</b> but she has not yet begun to menstruate, <b>and she married</b> and engaged in intercourse and her hymen was torn, <b>Beit Shammai say:</b> The Sages <b>give her the first night</b> during which the blood is attributed to the torn hymen. Thereafter, any blood is assumed to be menstrual blood. <b>And Beit Hillel say:</b> The blood is attributed to the torn hymen <b>until the conclusion of Shabbat,</b> and she may engage in intercourse with her husband for <b>four nights,</b> as it was customary for a virgin to marry on Wednesday.
In the case of a young woman who <b>saw</b> menstrual blood before marriage while <b>she was still in her father’s house, Beit Shammai say:</b> The Sages <b>give her</b> permission to engage only in <b>relations</b> that consummate a marriage, which are <b>a mitzva,</b> after which she is ritually impure due to the blood. <b>And Beit Hillel say:</b> The husband and wife may engage even in several acts of intercourse, as any blood seen <b>throughout the entire night</b> is attributed to the torn hymen.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna first addresses the case of a young girl who has not yet reached puberty. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak says: And</b> this <i>halakha</i> applies to her <b>even</b> if <b>she has seen</b> menstrual blood. He explains his reasoning: <b>From where</b> do I derive this? I derive it <b>from</b> the fact <b>that</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>distinguishes in the latter clause</b> of the mishna <b>between</b> a young girl who has <b>seen</b> menstrual blood <b>and</b> a young girl who has <b>not seen</b> menstrual blood. <b>By inference,</b> in <b>the first clause</b> of the mishna the <i>halakha</i> <b>is no different</b> in <b>this</b> case, where the young girl has experienced menstrual bleeding, <b>and</b> it <b>is no different</b> in <b>that</b> case, where she has not yet experienced menstrual bleeding.
<b>This</b> explanation of Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak <b>is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Beit Hillel say:</b> With regard to a young girl who has not yet reached puberty, the blood she emits is attributed to the torn hymen <b>until the wound heals,</b> regardless of <b>whether she has seen</b> menstrual blood beforehand or <b>whether she has not</b> yet <b>seen</b> menstrual blood.
§ The mishna teaches that Beit Hillel say: The blood is attributed to the torn hymen <b>until the wound heals.</b> The Gemara clarifies: <b>Until when</b> can the blood be attributed to the torn hymen? <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: All the time that she is <i>noḥeret</i>.</b> Rav Yehuda continues: <b>When</b> I subsequently <b>said this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>before Shmuel, he said to me: This <i>noḥeret</i>, I do not know what it is,</b> nor do I know what Rav means by it. <b>Rather, all the time that the saliva is in</b> her <b>mouth due to sexual intercourse,</b> she may attribute the blood to the torn hymen. Shmuel is using a euphemism, i.e., as long as there is blood in her vagina resulting from sexual intercourse.
The Gemara clarifies: This <b><i>noḥeret</i> that Rav says; what is it like?</b> What did he mean? <b>Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak said: It was explained to me by Rav</b> as follows: If the young girl <b>stands</b> up <b>and sees</b> blood, but she <b>sits and does not see</b> blood, <b>it is known that the wound has not</b> yet <b>healed,</b> and the blood is still attributed to the torn hymen. Similarly, if she sits <b>on the ground and sees</b> blood, but she sits <b>on cushions and blankets and does not see</b> blood, <b>it is known that the wound has not</b> yet <b>healed</b> and she may attribute the blood to the torn hymen, as the blood flows due to the strain of sitting on the ground. But if she sometimes sits <b>on all of them,</b> i.e., the ground, cushions, and blankets, <b>and sees</b> blood, and on other occasions she sits <b>on all of them and does not see</b> blood, <b>it is known that the wound has healed,</b> and this blood must now be menstrual blood.
§ The mishna teaches: In the case of a young woman <b>whose time</b> to see a menstrual flow <b>has arrived,</b> Beit Hillel say: The blood is attributed to the torn hymen until the conclusion of Shabbat and she may engage in intercourse with her husband for four nights. <b>It was stated</b> that there is a dispute between <i>amora’im</i> with regard to the following case: If <b>she engaged in intercourse</b> with her husband <b>during the daytime,</b> in addition to engaging in intercourse at night, <b>Rav says: She has not lost</b> her <b>nights,</b> and the blood is still attributed to the torn hymen for four nights. <b>Levi says: She has lost</b> her <b>nights,</b> since she has engaged in intercourse twice during the daytime and twice at night, and therefore she has already used up the equivalent of four nights.
The Gemara explains: <b>Rav says</b> that <b>she has not lost</b> her <b>nights,</b> as <b>we learned</b> in the mishna that the blood is attributed to the torn hymen <b>until the conclusion of Shabbat,</b> and it does not limit the number of times she may engage in intercourse during that time. <b>And Levi says: She has lost</b> her <b>nights,</b> as <b>what</b> is the meaning of the term: <b>Four nights, that is taught</b> in the mishna? It means <b>four</b> twelve-hour <b>periods,</b> either days or nights.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav, why do I</b> need the mishna <b>to teach: Four nights?</b> The mishna should have stated four days, which would include both days and nights. Rav would respond that the mishna <b>teaches us proper conduct, as it is proper that intercourse</b> should be performed only <b>at night.</b> The Gemara suggests: <b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Levi, let</b> the mishna <b>teach</b> only: <b>Four nights. Why do I</b> need the mishna to specify: <b>Until the conclusion of Shabbat?</b> Levi would answer that <b>this teaches us that it is permitted to engage in intercourse for the first</b> time <b>on Shabbat.</b> Since the custom was for a virgin to marry on Wednesday, which means that one of the four first nights is Shabbat, it is permitted to engage in intercourse on that night, despite the fact that it may cause her to bleed.
The Gemara notes that Levi’s ruling is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Shmuel, as Shmuel said: It is permitted to enter into a narrow opening</b> in a wall <b>on Shabbat, and</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even though</b> doing so <b>causes pebbles to fall</b> from the wall. Similarly, although engaging in intercourse might cause a wound and bleeding, it is permitted on Shabbat.
It <b>was stated</b> that the <i>amora’im</i> engaged in a dispute: If a husband <b>engaged in intercourse</b> with a virgin <b>and did not find blood, and</b> he <b>went back</b> within the first four nights <b>and</b> again <b>engaged in intercourse</b> with her <b>and</b> this time he <b>found blood, Rabbi Ḥanina says:</b> The wife is <b>ritually impure,</b> as this is menstruation blood. <b>And Rabbi Asi says: She is ritually pure,</b> as it is blood from the wound resulting from the act of intercourse.
<b>Rabbi Ḥanina says: She is ritually impure, as if it is so that it is blood</b> from her hymen, i.e., the blood of her <b>virginity, it would have come at the outset,</b> after the first time they engaged in intercourse. <b>And Rabbi Asi said: She is ritually pure,</b> as <b>perhaps it happened for him</b> that he engaged in intercourse <b>like Shmuel</b> described. <b>As Shmuel said: I can engage in intercourse several times without</b> the appearance of <b>blood.</b> In other words, I can engage in intercourse with a virgin while leaving her hymen intact. <b>And the other</b> Sage, Rabbi Ḥanina, does not allow for that possibility, since he maintains that <b>Shmuel is different, as his strength</b> was <b>great.</b> Shmuel was particularly skilled at this, while others cannot accomplish this.
§ The mishna teaches the <i>halakha</i> of a young girl. The Gemara discusses the case of a girl who is older than twelve and a half. <b>Rav says:</b> The Sages <b>give a grown woman,</b> who engaged in intercourse on her wedding night, <b>the</b> entire <b>first night,</b> during which she may engage in intercourse with her husband several times. <b>And this statement</b> applies only <b>if she did not see</b> any blood. <b>But</b> if <b>she saw</b> blood, <b>she has only the relations</b> that consummate a marriage, which are <b>a mitzva, and nothing more.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to Rav’s statement from a <i>baraita</i>: There was <b>an incident</b> involving a virgin who married, <b>and Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>gave her four nights</b> in which to engage in intercourse <b>within twelve months</b> of her wedding when the blood is considered to be like blood resulting from the torn hymen. The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of this case? <b>If we say that</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>gave her all of</b> those nights of purity <b>in</b> her <b>days</b> as <b>a minor,</b>

Daf 65a

in accordance with the ruling of the mishna: The Sages give her four nights, then he should have given her longer, as <b>we learned</b> in the mishna that according to Beit Hillel the blood may be attributed to the torn hymen <b>until the wound heals.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> you will say <b>that he gave her</b> these four nights <b>all</b> during her <b>days</b> as <b>a young woman. Are there twelve months</b> when one has the status of <b>a young woman? But didn’t Shmuel say: The difference</b> in time <b>between</b> becoming <b>a young woman and</b> becoming <b>a grown woman is only six months? And if you would say</b> that Shmuel is saying that it is in <b>less than</b> six months <b>that there is no</b> transition from young woman to grown woman status, but <b>there is</b> such a transition in <b>more</b> than six months, as women develop differently, that is not so, <b>as</b> Shmuel <b>said: Only,</b> which indicates that the period is neither less nor more than six months.
<b>Rather,</b> you will suggest <b>that</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>gave her two</b> days <b>during</b> her <b>days as a minor, and</b> he gave her <b>two</b> days <b>during</b> her <b>days as a young woman.</b> This too is difficult, as <b>Rav Ḥinnana bar Shelamya asked Rav:</b> With regard to a young girl who married before she reached puberty, and then <b>her time to see</b> menstrual blood <b>arrived</b> while she was <b>under</b> the authority of <b>her husband, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Does she have the four nights when the blood is considered to be from her torn hymen?
And Rav <b>said to him: All the acts of intercourse that you engage in</b> while she is still too young <b>are</b> considered as <b>only one</b> act of intercourse, <b>and the remainder,</b> i.e., three more acts of intercourse, <b>complete</b> the total number of <b>four nights.</b> If so, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi could not have given her two nights as a minor, since at most those acts of intercourse count as one.
<b>Rather,</b> you will suggest <b>that he gave her one</b> night <b>during her days as a minor, and two</b> nights <b>during her days as a young woman, and one</b> night <b>during her days as a grown woman.</b> But this is also difficult: <b>Granted, if you say</b> that <b>we generally give a grown woman more</b> than one night, then one can understand why Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi gave her one night in this case: <b>Just as</b> all the acts of intercourse she engaged in as <b>a minor have the effect to deduct one</b> night <b>for</b> her <b>days as a young woman,</b> similarly all the acts of intercourse she engaged in while <b>a young woman have the effect to deduct one</b> night <b>for</b> her days as <b>a grown woman,</b> leaving her with one.
<b>But if you say</b> that <b>we generally do not give a grown woman more</b> than one night, then in this case Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>should</b> have <b>given her</b> as a grown woman <b>only</b> the one act of <b>relations</b> that consummate a marriage, which are <b>a mitzva,</b> i.e., merely a single act of intercourse, <b>and nothing more,</b> as otherwise the acts of intercourse before she became a grown woman would not have affected her status.
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> the correct explanation is <b>that</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>gave her one</b> night <b>during her days as a minor and three</b> nights <b>during her days as a young woman.</b> And as for the fact that she has the status of a young woman for only exactly six months, <b>do you maintain</b> that <b>every three months</b> was counted as <b>one period</b> of the husband’s absence, such that she had only two nights in six months? This is not the case. Rather, <b>every two months</b> was counted as <b>one period,</b> and therefore she had three nights during these six months when she could attribute the blood to her torn hymen.
The Gemara relates that the Sage <b>Minyamin Saksana was coming and walking to the place of Shmuel. He thought</b> that he <b>would perform an action in accordance</b> with the opinion <b>of Rav,</b> in that he would permit a grown woman to attribute blood to her torn hymen for the entire first night, <b>even</b> though she had already <b>seen</b> menstrual blood before she was married. Minyamin mistakenly <b>said</b> to himself: <b>Rav does not distinguish between</b> a woman who <b>has seen</b> menstrual blood <b>and</b> a woman who <b>has not seen</b> menstrual blood.
<b>Before</b> Minyamin reached Shmuel’s place, <b>he passed away on the road,</b> and he never completed the journey. Upon hearing this, <b>Shmuel recited</b> this verse <b>about Rav: “No mishap shall befall the righteous”</b> (Proverbs 12:21), i.e., God does not allow prohibited acts to come from the statements of the righteous. In this case, Minyamin ruled incorrectly, based on a misunderstanding of Rav’s statement.
Since the Gemara cited Rav Ḥinnana bar Shelamya, it cites another of his statements: <b>Rav Ḥinnana bar Shelamya said in the name of Rav: Once a person’s teeth fall out</b> and he has difficulty eating, <b>his food diminshes</b> accordingly, <b>as it is stated: “And I also have given you cleanness of teeth in all your cities, and lack of bread in all your places”</b> (Amos 4:6). The term “cleanness of teeth” is here a euphemism for having no teeth at all, which leads to a lack of bread.
§ The mishna teaches: In the case of a young woman who <b>saw</b> menstrual blood before marriage, while <b>she was still</b> in her father’s house, Beit Hillel say: They may engage in several acts of intercourse, as any bleeding throughout the entire night is attributed to the torn hymen. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of a young woman who <b>saw</b> menstrual blood while <b>she was still in her father’s house, Beit Hillel say: All the night is hers, and</b> the Sages <b>give her</b> one <b>complete period</b> of time during which she may attribute all bleeding to her torn hymen. <b>And how long is a complete period</b> of time in this context? <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel explained</b> that it is one <b>night and half</b> of the next <b>day.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But do we require all this</b> time of one night and half of a day for a complete period? <b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of one <b>whose winepresses or olive presses were impure and he wished to prepare</b> his grapes and olives <b>in</b> a state of <b>ritual purity, how does he act?</b> He should <b>rinse the planks</b> used to press the grapes in the winepress, <b>and the palm branches</b> used as brooms, <b>and the troughs,</b>

Daf 65b

and he should <b>clean the</b> pressing <b>baskets</b> with ashes and water if they were made <b>of palm leaves or of hemp [<i>bitzbutz</i>], or leave them dormant</b> if they were made <b>of bast [<i>shifa</i>] or of reeds,</b> because these absorb more of the wine. <b>And how long</b> must one <b>leave them dormant?</b> He must leave them for <b>twelve months. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: He can lay them aside from</b> one <b>wine-pressing</b> season <b>to</b> the next <b>wine-pressing</b> season, <b>or from</b> one <b>olive-pressing</b> season <b>to</b> the next <b>olive-pressing</b> season.
The Gemara interrupts its citation to analyze the <i>baraita</i>: Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel’s statement <b>is</b> the same as that of <b>the first <i>tanna</i>,</b> as there are twelve months between one wine-pressing season and the next. The Gemara responds: The difference <b>between them</b> is the matter of the <b>early and late</b> ripening season for grapes. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel does not require a precise measure of twelve months, as the difference in time between ripening seasons can be slightly more or less than that.
The Gemara continues its citation of the <i>baraita</i>. <b>Rabbi Yosei says: One who wishes to purify</b> the baskets <b>immediately,</b> without waiting a year, <b>purges them in boiling water or scalds them in olive water. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says in the name of Rabbi Yosei: One sets them under a pipe whose water flows</b> constantly <b>or in a spring with rapid waters. And how much</b> time should he leave them there? He should leave them for <b>a period</b> of time. <b>In the</b> same <b>way that</b> the Sages <b>stated</b> this time frame <b>with regard to wine</b> used for <b>a libation</b> in idol worship, <b>so too</b> the Sages <b>stated</b> this time frame <b>with regard to matters of ritual purity.</b>
The Gemara expresses surprise at this last clause: <b>Isn’t it the opposite [<i>kelapei layya</i>]? We are dealing with matters of purity</b> in this <i>baraita</i>. <b>Rather,</b> the <i>baraita</i> means: <b>In the</b> same <b>way that</b> the Sages <b>stated</b> this time frame <b>with regard to matters of ritual purity, so too</b> the Sages <b>stated</b> this time frame <b>in</b> the case of <b>wine</b> used for <b>a libation</b> in idol worship.
The Gemara asks: <b>And how long is</b> the <b>period</b> of time referred to in the <i>baraita</i>? <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Either</b> the <b>day or</b> the <b>night. Rabbi Ḥana She’ona, and some say Rabbi Ḥana bar She’ona, say</b> that <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Half a day and half a night.</b>
<b>And Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak said: And</b> the Sages <b>do not disagree.</b> The ruling of <b>this</b> one, who says either a day or a night, is stated <b>with regard to</b> the equinox of the <b>season of Nisan or Tishrei,</b> when the days and night are equal; whereas the ruling of <b>that</b> one, who says half a day and half a night, is stated <b>with regard to</b> the solstice of the <b>season of Tammuz,</b> i.e., summer, <b>or Tevet,</b> i.e., winter, which have the longest day or night respectively, so that half the day and half the night together amount to twelve hours. This <i>baraita</i> apparently contradicts the statement of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, who says that the woman may attribute the blood to her hymen for a night and half the day.
The Gemara answers: <b>Here too,</b> one can <b>say with regard to a menstruating woman</b> that he meant <b>half a day and half a night.</b> The Gemara raises a difficulty. <b>But</b> Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel <b>said a night and half a day.</b> The Gemara clarifies: <b>Rather,</b> this is what Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel meant: <b>Either a night during Nisan or Tishrei,</b> which is twelve hours, <b>or half a day and half a night during Tevet or Tammuz,</b> which also equals twelve hours.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: With regard to the purity of wine, a period is twelve hours. But in the case of marriage the time frame <b>is different,</b> due to the <b>marriage contract,</b> which is signed before the marriage is consummated, <b>as</b> there are those <b>who delay for a lengthy</b> period <b>until they</b> complete and <b>sign it.</b> Consequently, the Sages extended the period in this case to a night and half a day.
§ Although the mishna provides a certain period of time for both a minor and a young woman during which they may attribute any blood to the torn hymen, nevertheless <b>Rav and Shmuel both say</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is that the groom <b>engages in relations</b> that consummate a marriage, which are <b>a mitzva, and</b> then he <b>separates</b> from his wife.
<b>Rav Ḥisda raises an objection</b> from the <i>baraita</i>: There was <b>an incident</b> involving a virgin who married, <b>and Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>gave her four nights</b> to engage in intercourse <b>within twelve months</b> of her wedding. This indicates that the husband does not have to separate from his wife immediately after the first act of intercourse is completed.
<b>Rava said to</b> Rav Ḥisda: <b>Why do I</b> need <b>to search for a refutation</b> from a <i>baraita</i>, which is not necessarily known by all? One can <b>raise a difficulty from</b> an explicit statement of <b>the mishna,</b> which states that the first blood a woman sees on her wedding night is attributed to her torn hymen. The Gemara explains that Rav Ḥisda raises his objection from the <i>baraita</i>, as he <b>holds</b> that a practical <b>incident</b> ruled upon by <b>a Sage</b> is a preferable source.
The Gemara returns to the objection: <b>In any case,</b> this <i>baraita</i> is <b>difficult for Rav and Shmuel.</b> The Gemara answers that <b>they acted in accordance with</b> the opinion attributed to <b>our Sages, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Our Sages returned and were counted</b> again, i.e., they voted and decided, that the groom <b>engages in relations</b> that consummate a marriage, which are <b>a mitzva, and</b> subsequently he <b>separates</b> from his wife.
The Gemara proves that this ruling of Rav and Shmuel, based on the <i>baraita</i>, is also the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish. <b>Ulla said: When we were</b> learning the topic <b>of a young girl</b> who saw blood on her wedding night with <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish, they brought up from it only</b> the amount <b>of</b> earth <b>that the fox brings up from a plowed field,</b> i.e., they did not establish the <i>halakha</i> as stated in the mishna. <b>And they concluded</b> the discussion in <b>this</b> manner: The groom <b>engages in relations</b> that consummate a marriage, which are <b>a mitzva, and</b> then he <b>separates</b> from his wife.
<b>Rabbi Abba said to Rav Ashi,</b> in light of this ruling that the groom must separate from his bride after completing the act of intercourse: <b>If that is so, a pious person</b> should <b>not complete his</b> act of <b>intercourse,</b> lest he unintentionally continue longer than is permitted. Rav Ashi <b>said to him</b> in reply: The Sages did not issue such a decree, because <b>if so, his heart will strike him</b> with fear that perhaps his wife will begin to bleed while he is engaged in the act of intercourse, <b>and he will separate</b> from his wife completely and will not consummate the marriage.
§ The mishna teaches that a young girl is given four nights during which any bleeding is attributed to her torn hymen. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>all of them,</b> i.e., all the women who are given four nights, <b>if they were discharging blood continually, from four nights</b> until <b>after</b> those <b>four nights,</b> or in the case of those women who are given only one night, if they discharge blood <b>from that</b> one <b>night</b> until <b>after that night,</b> they may not attribute the blood to the torn hymen. Rather, <b>all of them must examine themselves,</b> in the manner that will be explained.
<b>And with regard to all of</b> these women, <b>Rabbi Meir is stringent in accordance with the statement of Beit Shammai,</b> and therefore a minor girl who bleeds for more than four nights must examine herself, despite the fact that Beit Hillel say she remains ritually pure until the wound has healed. Similarly, Rabbi Meir holds that with regard to a young girl who has reached puberty, if she continues to bleed after the first night she must examine herself.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>But</b> with regard to the <b>other</b> cases of <b>seeing</b> blood, when she does not discharge blood continuously but bleeds again the following day, concerning <b>which</b> there is a dispute <b>between Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel,</b> Rabbi Meir holds that one <b>follows the appearance of the blood.</b> In other words, he does not maintain entirely in accordance with the opinion of Beit Shammai. Beit Hillel rule that the woman is ritually pure even if the color of the blood has changed, whereas Beit Shammai hold that she is ritually impure even if the color of the blood has not changed.
<b>As Rabbi Meir would say: The appearances of</b> impure and pure <b>blood differ from one another. How so?</b> The <b>blood of a menstruating woman is red,</b> whereas <b>blood</b> that comes from a torn hymen, indicating that she was <b>a virgin, is not red.</b> The <b>blood of a menstruating woman is cloudy; blood</b> that indicates that she was <b>a virgin is not cloudy.</b> Finally, the <b>blood of a menstruating woman comes from the uterus; blood</b> that indicates that she was <b>a virgin comes from the sides</b> of the vaginal wall.
<b>Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Rabbi Yosei says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: This is the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b> According to Rabbi Meir, it is possible to examine the color of blood to determine whether it is menstrual blood or hymenal blood. <b>But the Rabbis say</b> that <b>all appearances of blood are one,</b> i.e., there is no distinction between the appearance of menstrual blood and blood indicating one’s loss of virginity.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: A woman <b>who sees blood due to sexual intercourse may engage in intercourse</b> before the <b>first time</b> this occurs, before the <b>second</b> time this occurs, <b>and</b> before the <b>third</b> time this occurs. <b>From this</b> point <b>forward,</b> i.e., after three consecutive occurrences of bleeding due to intercourse, <b>she may not engage in intercourse until she is divorced</b> from her husband

Daf 66a

<b>and is married to another</b> man. She is permitted to engage in intercourse with her second husband because it is possible that the bleeding was caused by engaging in intercourse with her first husband, and the issue will not reoccur when she engages in intercourse with a different man.
If <b>she married another</b> man <b>and</b> again <b>saw blood due to sexual intercourse, she may engage in intercourse</b> before the <b>first time</b> this occurs, before the <b>second</b> time this occurs, <b>and</b> before the <b>third</b> time this occurs. <b>From this</b> point <b>forward she may not engage in intercourse until she is divorced</b> from her second husband <b>and is married to</b> yet <b>another</b> man. If <b>she married another</b> man <b>and</b> again <b>saw blood due to sexual intercourse, she may engage in intercourse</b> the <b>first time</b> this occurs, the <b>second</b> time this occurs, <b>and</b> the <b>third</b> time this occurs. <b>From this</b> point <b>forward</b> there is a presumption that she always bleeds due to engaging in intercourse, and therefore <b>she may not engage in intercourse</b> or marry someone else <b>until she examines herself.</b>
<b>How</b> does <b>she examine herself? She brings a tube, inside of which</b> she places a cosmetic <b>brush</b> so that it is long enough to reach deeply into her vagina, <b>and</b> an absorbent <b>cloth is placed on the tip</b> of the brush. She inserts the tube with the brush and cloth within herself and then removes it. <b>If blood is found on the top of the</b> absorbent <b>cloth, it is known that</b> the blood <b>comes from the uterus</b> and she is ritually impure. If <b>blood is not found on the top</b> of the cloth, <b>it is known that</b> the blood <b>comes from the sides</b> of the vaginal walls and she is ritually pure, and she may resume engaging in intercourse with her husband.
<b>And if she has a wound in that place,</b> i.e., her vagina, <b>she attributes</b> the blood <b>to her wound,</b> and she is ritually pure, as it is assumed to not be uterine blood. <b>And if she has a</b> fixed menstrual <b>cycle,</b> i.e., she does not bleed every time she engages in intercourse with her husband, but only at fixed times, <b>she attributes</b> the blood <b>to her</b> fixed menstrual <b>cycle,</b> and she is permitted to engage in intercourse at other times.
<b>And if the blood of her wound differed from the blood that she sees</b> due to sexual intercourse, <b>she may not attribute</b> the blood to her wound. <b>And a woman is deemed credible to say: I have a wound in</b> my <b>uterus, from where</b> the <b>blood is emerging.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi.
<b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Blood of a wound that comes from the uterus is ritually impure</b> as a primary category of impurity. Although this blood does not render it prohibited for her to engage in intercourse with her husband, it does render her impure with regard to eating ritually pure food. <b>But our Sages testified</b> that they had a tradition <b>with regard to</b> the <b>blood of a wound that comes from the uterus, that it is ritually pure.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the difference <b>between</b> the opinion of those Sages and the opinion of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel? <b>Ulla said:</b> The difference <b>between them is</b> whether the <b>place of</b> a woman’s <b>uterus is impure,</b> which means that any blood that passes through there is impure, even if it is blood from a wound. According to Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, even the blood of a wound becomes impure if it passes through the uterus, whereas those Sages hold that only blood that originates in the uterus is impure.
With regard to the <i>baraita</i> that states that the test for a woman who experiences bleeding due to sexual intercourse is to insert <b>a tube,</b> the Gemara asks: But won’t a tube <b>scratch her</b> and cause her to bleed regardless? <b>Shmuel said:</b> The <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to a tube of lead, and the mouth,</b> i.e., the end that is inserted, <b>is folded inward</b> so that it will not scratch her.
The <i>baraita</i> says that if a woman experiences bleeding on three occasions due to intercourse with her husband he must divorce her. <b>Reish Lakish said to Rabbi Yoḥanan: But let her examine herself after the third</b> act of <b>intercourse with her first husband,</b> so that he need not divorce her. Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him:</b> It is preferable for her not to test herself and risk becoming forbidden to all men and instead to be divorced and remarry another, <b>because not all fingers,</b> i.e., penises, <b>are equal.</b> Since it is possible that sexual intercourse with her second husband might not cause her to bleed, she should not risk becoming forbidden to all men by performing the examination.
Reish Lakish further <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan: Why does she examine herself only after the third time she experiences bleeding due to sexual intercourse with her third husband? <b>But let her examine herself after the first</b> act of <b>intercourse with her third husband.</b> After the first occurrence this woman already has a presumptive status that all acts of intercourse cause her to bleed. Rabbi Yoḥanan answered: She does not perform the examination then, <b>because not all forces are equal.</b> It is possible that the manner in which the couple has intercourse causes her to bleed, and therefore it is only after three times that she has a presumptive status of bleeding after every act of intercourse.
The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain</b> woman who experienced bleeding due to sexual intercourse <b>who came before Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi and asked him what she should do. Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to</b> the Sage <b>Abdon,</b> who was present at the time: <b>Go</b> and suddenly <b>frighten</b> this woman. Abdon <b>went</b> and <b>frightened her, and a mass</b> of congealed <b>blood fell from her</b> vagina. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said: This</b> woman is now <b>cured.</b> She will no longer experience bleeding due to sexual intercourse, as this mass of blood was the source of the blood.
The Gemara relates a similar incident: There was <b>a certain</b> woman who experienced bleeding due to sexual intercourse <b>who came before Shmuel.</b> Shmuel <b>said to Rav Dimi bar Yosef: Go</b> and <b>frighten</b> this woman. Rav Dimi <b>went</b> and <b>frightened her, but nothing fell from her at all. Shmuel said: This</b> woman <b>is filled</b> with blood, <b>which falls</b> out of her during intercourse. <b>And any</b> woman who <b>is filled</b> with blood <b>that falls</b> out during intercourse <b>has no cure.</b>
The Gemara relates another incident: There was <b>a certain</b> woman <b>who came before Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> and told him <b>that every time she emerged from immersion</b> in a ritual bath, after completing the <b>mitzva</b> of purifying herself for her husband, <b>she would see blood</b> before she engaged in intercourse with him. Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to her: Perhaps the gossip</b> of the women <b>in your city,</b> who are jealous of the love between you and your husband, <b>has reached you,</b> and this evil eye causes you to bleed before you engage in intercourse. <b>Go and</b> immerse in the river and <b>engage in intercourse with</b> your husband <b>on the bank of the river,</b> so that the other women will not see you leaving the ritual bath and gossip about you.
<b>Some say</b> that Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to her: Reveal</b> this fact <b>to your friends, so that</b> those women <b>who were</b> against <b>you on this side,</b> and gossiped about you, <b>will be</b> with <b>you on that side,</b> and be kind to you. <b>And some say</b> that Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to her: Reveal</b> this fact <b>to your friends, in order that they will pray for mercy for you, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> discussing the verse: “And the leper in whom the mark is, his clothes shall be ripped and the hair of his head shall grow long and he will put a covering upon his upper lip <b>and will cry: Impure, impure”</b> (Leviticus 13:45). The leper publicizes the fact that he is ritually impure, as he <b>must announce his pain to the masses, and</b> then <b>the masses will pray for mercy on his</b> behalf.
<b>Rav Yosef said: There was</b> a similar <b>incident in Pumbedita</b> of a woman who experienced bleeding immediately after immersing in a ritual bath, and she followed the advice given by Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>and she was cured.</b>
§ <b>Rav Yosef says</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>decreed</b> that <b>in the fields,</b> i.e., in those distant places where there were no Torah scholars and whose residents were not well versed in the <i>halakhot</i> of menstruating women and did not know how to distinguish between the days of menstruation and the days of <i>ziva</i>, if <b>she saw</b> blood on <b>one day, she must sit</b> and count <b>six</b> days <b>and that</b> first day. She must observe six clean days without a discharge despite the possibility that she might have experienced bleeding only in her period of <i>ziva</i>, in which case she would be impure for only one day.
If she experiences bleeding for <b>two</b> days, <b>she must sit</b> and count <b>six</b> days <b>and</b> both of <b>those</b> first two days, for a total of eight days, in case the first day on which she bled was the last day of <i>ziva</i>, while the next day was the first day of her menstruation period. If she experiences bleeding for <b>three</b> days <b>she must sit</b> and count <b>seven clean</b> days, as she might be a greater <i>zava</i>, who must count seven clean days.
The Gemara cites a related statement. <b>Rabbi Zeira says: Jewish women were stringent with themselves</b> to the extent <b>that even if they see a drop of blood</b> the size <b>of a mustard</b> seed, they <b>sit seven clean</b> days <b>for it.</b> By Torah law, a woman who experiences menstrual bleeding waits seven days in total before immersing, regardless of whether she experienced bleeding on those days. If she experiences bleeding during the eleven days when she is not expected to experience menstrual bleeding, she is a lesser <i>zava</i> and waits one day without bleeding and then immerses. The Jewish women accepted upon themselves the stringency that if they experience any bleeding whatsoever, they treat it as the blood of a greater <i>zava</i>, which obligates one to count seven clean days before immersing (see Leviticus 15:25).
<b>Rava authorized Rav Shmuel, and he taught:</b> If a pregnant woman experienced <b>labor pains</b> for <b>two days, and on the third</b> day <b>she miscarried, she must sit</b> and count <b>seven clean</b> days. The Gemara explains that Rava <b>holds</b> that the principle that blood that emerges while the woman experiences <b>labor pains</b> is not ritually impure does <b>not</b> apply <b>to miscarriages. And</b> Rava further maintains that <b>it is impossible for the womb to open without blood</b> emerging. Therefore, when she miscarried she must have experienced a flow of blood, even if she did not notice it.
<b>Rav Pappa said to Rava:</b> For <b>what</b> reason did you teach this <i>halakha</i> <b>specifically</b> with regard to a woman who experiences <b>labor pains</b> for <b>two days? Even</b> if she <b>merely</b> discharges <b>any amount</b> of blood she should be impure, <b>as Rabbi Zeira says: The Jewish women were stringent with themselves</b> to the extent <b>that even if they see a drop of blood of</b> the size of <b>a mustard</b> seed, that woman <b>sits seven clean</b> days <b>for it.</b> Since it is impossible for the womb to open without the emergence of blood, when this woman miscarried there must have been blood, and therefore she must count seven clean days.
Rava <b>said to</b> Rav Pappa: <b>I speak to you</b> of <b>a prohibition,</b> i.e., that by Torah law a woman who experiences difficulty in childbirth for two days and on the third miscarries must count seven clean days as a greater <i>zava</i>, <b>and you speak to me</b> of <b>a custom,</b> a mere stringency. The stringency you mention does not apply in this case. <b>Where</b> the Jewish women <b>were stringent, they were stringent,</b> i.e., if they saw a drop of blood the size of a mustard seed. <b>Where they were not stringent,</b> i.e., in a case of blood due to labor, <b>they were not stringent.</b> By contrast, in the case I described the woman is obligated to count seven clean days by Torah law.
The Gemara provides <b>a mnemonic</b> for the following discussions: <b>One who proposed to her; natron; with hot</b> water; <b>to immerse; folds; on top of; a port. Rava says:</b> With regard to <b>one who proposed marriage to</b> a woman <b>and she accepted it,</b> the emotional excitement might have caused her to have a flow of menstrual blood, which would render her ritually impure and prohibit her from engaging in intercourse. Even if she was unaware of any flow, she must consider the possibility that it occurred. Therefore, to purify herself <b>she must wait seven</b> consecutive days that are <b>clean</b> from any flow of menstrual blood and then immerse in a ritual bath. Only after that process may she marry.
The Gemara cites a related incident: <b>Ravina arranged for his son</b> to marry into <b>the family of Rav Ḥanina,</b> i.e., to marry Rav Ḥanina’s daughter. Rav Ḥanina <b>said to</b> Ravina: <b>Does the Master hold</b> that it is appropriate <b>to write the marriage contract</b> as stating that the wedding will take place <b>in four days,</b> i.e., on Wednesday? Ravina <b>said: Yes. When</b> the <b>fourth</b> day, i.e., Wednesday <b>arrived, he waited until another fourth</b> day before marrying her, until the following Wednesday, i.e., <b>he delayed seven days after that day</b> when he had planned to marry her.
Rav Ḥanina <b>said to</b> Ravina: <b>What is this?</b> Why did you delay the wedding by an extra week? Ravina <b>said to</b> Rav Ḥanina: <b>Doesn’t the Master hold in accordance with this</b> statement <b>of Rava, as Rava said:</b> With regard to <b>one who proposed marriage to</b> a woman <b>and she accepted it, she must wait seven</b> consecutive days that are <b>clean</b> from any flow of menstrual blood and then immerse in a ritual bath? Rav Ḥanina <b>said to</b> Ravina: One can <b>say that Rava said</b> this statement <b>with regard to an adult woman, who has seen</b> menstrual <b>blood. But did</b> Rava actually <b>say</b> this <b>with regard to a minor girl, who has not</b> yet <b>seen</b> menstrual <b>blood?</b>
Ravina <b>said to</b> Rav Ḥanina: <b>Rava said explicitly</b> that there is <b>no difference</b> whether she is <b>an adult woman</b> and <b>no difference</b> whether she is <b>a minor girl. What is the reason</b> that <b>an adult woman</b> must wait for seven days? She must wait <b>because she desires</b> to marry her husband, and this might cause her to have a flow of blood. <b>A minor girl also desires</b> to marry her husband, which could cause a flow of blood.
§ <b>Rava says: A woman</b> who is about to immerse herself in a ritual bath for purification

Daf 66b

<b>may not wash</b> her hair <b>with natron or with sand.</b> The reason she may not wash her hair <b>with natron</b> is <b>because</b> natron <b>pulls out</b> hair, and that hair may remain sitting on her head and serve as an interposition between her and the water of the ritual bath. <b>And</b> similarly, she may not wash her hair <b>with sand, because it sticks</b> to her hair and it also serves as an interposition.
<b>And Ameimar said in the name of Rava: A woman washes</b> her hair <b>only with hot</b> water, <b>but not with cold</b> water. <b>But</b> she may wash her hair <b>even with hot</b> water that was heated in the <b>sun. What is the reason</b> that she may <b>not</b> wash her hair with <b>cold</b> water? <b>Because it is cold and</b> causes the <b>hair to harden,</b> and the dirt will remain in the hair.
<b>And Rava says: A man should always teach in his house that a woman should rinse any place with creases,</b> e.g., her armpits, <b>in water</b> before she immerses in a ritual bath, to ensure that they are clean. The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Places with creases and</b> any <b>concealed part</b> of the body <b>do not require immersion in water.</b> In other words, the immersion is valid even if the water does not touch those parts of the body. If so, why must she rinse them before immersing?
The Gemara answers: <b>Granted that they do not require immersion in water,</b> but <b>we require</b> that they must be <b>a place that is suitable for immersion in water.</b> This is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Zeira, as Rabbi Zeira says:</b> For <b>any</b> amount of flour <b>suitable for mingling</b> with oil in a meal offering, <b>mingling is not indispensable for it,</b> i.e., it is valid even if it is not mixed. <b>But</b> for <b>any</b> amount of flour <b>not suitable for mingling,</b> e.g., if the quantity of flour is so great that the ingredients cannot be properly mixed, <b>mingling is indispensable for it,</b> and such a meal offering is invalid. This teaches a halakhic principle: There are certain actions that prevent the fulfillment of a mitzva if they are impossible, even if the actual performance of those actions are not indispensable to the mitzva.
<b>Ravin bar Rav Adda says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak says:</b> There was <b>an incident involving a maidservant of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>who immersed</b> herself, <b>and she ascended</b> from her immersion <b>and a bone was found interposed between her teeth, and Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>required her</b> to perform <b>another immersion.</b> This demonstrates that according to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi one may not have a foreign object even inside one’s mouth.
<b>And Rava says:</b> If a woman <b>immersed</b> in a ritual bath <b>and ascended</b> from the water, <b>and</b> she then <b>found on her</b> hair <b>an item that interposes</b> between her and the water, what is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>If she immersed soon</b> after <b>washing</b> her hair, <b>she does not need to wash</b> her hair <b>and immerse</b> in the ritual bath a second time, as it can be assumed that this item was not there when she immersed, since her hair had been cleaned. <b>But if</b> she did <b>not</b> wash her hair immediately before immersing, <b>she must wash</b> her hair <b>and immerse</b> in the ritual bath a second time.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who state</b> a slightly different version of Rava’s statement: <b>If she immersed on the same day that she washed</b> her hair, <b>she does not need to wash</b> her hair <b>and to immerse</b> in a ritual bath a second time. <b>But if</b> she did <b>not</b> wash her hair on the same day that she immersed, <b>she must wash</b> her hair <b>and immerse</b> in the ritual bath a second time.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the practical difference <b>between</b> these two versions of Rava’s statement? The Gemara answers: The practical difference <b>between them</b> is <b>with regard to washing</b> her hair <b>close to immersion.</b> According to the first version of Rava’s statement, she must wash her hair immediately before immersing, whereas according to the second version she has more time. Another difference between the two versions is <b>with regard to washing</b> her hair <b>during the day and immersing at night</b> immediately afterward. According to the first version of Rava’s statement, provided that she washed her hair immediately before immersing, it makes no difference whether or not she washed and immersed on the same day. Conversely, according to the second version she must wash her hair on the same day or night as her immersion.
§ <b>Rava says: A woman may not stand on top of earthenware utensils</b> that are submerged in the ritual bath <b>and immerse. Rav Kahana thought to say: What is the reason</b> for this? It is <b>because</b> the Sages issued <b>a decree</b> against immersing in this manner, as it appears like immersing in <b>bathhouses,</b> i.e., the purpose of the decree is to prevent women from thinking that it is permitted to immerse in a bathhouse, which contains drawn water and is not valid as a ritual bath. It can be inferred from this reasoning that it is <b>permitted</b> for a woman to stand <b>on top of a plank of wood</b> that is in the ritual bath.
<b>Rav Ḥanan from Neharde’a said to</b> Rav Kahana that this is not the reason for Rava’s statement. Rather, <b>there,</b> in the case of submerged earthenware utensils, <b>what is the reason</b> that she may not immerse? She may not immerse <b>because she</b> will be <b>afraid</b> that she might fall off, and consequently she will not immerse herself properly. By the same logic, <b>she</b> will <b>also</b> be <b>afraid</b> when she is standing on top of <b>a plank of wood,</b> and therefore this is also prohibited.
<b>Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak says: A woman may not immerse</b> herself

Daf 67a

<b>in a port [<i>banamal</i>],</b> where the boats are drawn up onto shore, as there is a lot of mud there, which can stick to her and interpose between her and the water. <b>Even though now,</b> after the immersion, <b>there is no</b> mud stuck to her feet or body, one can <b>say</b> that perhaps <b>while she walked</b> back after immersing the mud <b>fell</b> off. Since one cannot be certain that there was no mud stuck to her body while she immersed, she may not immerse in a port.
The Gemara relates that <b>Shmuel’s father prepared ritual baths for his daughters in the days of Nisan,</b> by digging holes and letting them fill with natural rainwater, <b>and</b> he placed <b>mats</b> in the Euphrates River <b>in the days of Tishrei.</b> Since the water was shallow and the riverbed was muddy, he placed mats on the riverbed so that they could immerse without getting dirty.
The Gemara cites a similar <i>halakha</i> involving the interposition of an item during immersion. <b>Rav Giddel says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> If a woman <b>gave a cooked</b> dish <b>to her son, and</b> afterward she <b>immersed</b> in a ritual bath <b>and ascended</b> from the ritual bath, the <b>immersion is ineffective for her.</b> The reason is that <b>even though now,</b> after the immersion, <b>there is no</b> food stuck to her body, one can <b>say</b> that perhaps <b>as she walked</b> back after immersing the food <b>fell</b> off. Since one cannot be certain that there was no food stuck to her body while she immersed, she should not handle food immediately before immersing.
<b>Rami bar Abba said:</b> With regard to <b>these bloodletting incisions [<i>ravdei dekhusilta</i>], until three days</b> have passed since the bloodletting, when they have not yet formed a hard scab, they do <b>not interpose</b> and invalidate an immersion. <b>From this</b> point <b>forward they interpose,</b> as the scab is too hard for the water to penetrate.
<b>Mar Ukva said:</b> With regard to <b>mucus that is in the eye,</b> if it is <b>moist, it does not interpose</b> and invalidate an immersion. But if the mucus is <b>dry</b> and hard <b>it interposes. When is it called dry?</b> It is called dry <b>from the time that it begins to turn yellow.</b>
<b>Shmuel says: Eye shadow that is in the eye does not interpose</b> and invalidate an immersion. <b>But</b> eye shadow <b>that is on</b> or around <b>the eye interposes.</b> And <b>if</b> the woman’s <b>eyes were</b> constantly <b>blinking,</b> then <b>even</b> eye shadow <b>that is on</b> or around <b>the eye does not interpose,</b> as the constant blinking removes the eye shadow.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> If a woman <b>opened her eyes very</b> wide <b>or closed her eyes very</b> tightly while immersing, this <b>immersion is ineffective for her.</b> Such open or closed eyelids prevent the water from reaching the creases around the eyes.
<b>Reish Lakish says: A woman may immerse</b> herself in a ritual bath <b>only in the manner that she grows,</b> i.e., she may not force her arms to her sides or close her legs tightly. She is not obligated to spread her limbs widely, but simply stand in her normal manner. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Nega’im</i> 2:4): When <b>a man</b> has a leprous mark between his legs and stands before a priest for inspection, he should <b>appear like</b> one who is <b>hoeing,</b> i.e., with his legs slightly apart, <b>and</b> if it is under his arm, he should appear like one who is <b>harvesting olives,</b> with his arms slightly raised. If the mark is not visible when he is standing in that manner, it is not impure. By contrast, <b>a woman</b> with a leprous mark between her legs should <b>appear like</b> one who is <b>weaving, and</b> if the mark is beneath her breast she should appear <b>like</b> a woman who is <b>nursing her son.</b>
<b>Rabba bar Rav Huna says: A single hair tied</b> in a knot <b>interposes</b> and invalidates an immersion.

Daf 67b

<b>Three</b> hairs tied together in a knot <b>do not interpose,</b> as three hairs cannot be tied so tightly that water cannot penetrate them. With regard to <b>two</b> hairs tied together in a knot, <b>I do not know</b> the <i>halakha</i>. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: We have</b> a tradition that <b>only one</b> hair interposes, but two or more do not prevent the water from reaching the body.
§ <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak says: By Torah law,</b> if there is an interposition between a person and the water, and it covers <b>the majority of his</b> body, and <b>he is particular</b> and wants the interposing substance removed, <b>it interposes</b> and invalidates an immersion in a ritual bath. But if it covers the <b>majority of his</b> body <b>but he is not particular about</b> that substance, <b>it does not interpose. But</b> the Sages <b>issued a decree</b> prohibiting substances covering <b>the majority</b> of <b>his</b> body with regard to <b>which he is not particular, due to</b> substances covering <b>the majority</b> of <b>his</b> body about <b>which he is particular. And</b> likewise, they issued a decree against substances covering <b>the minority</b> of <b>his</b> body with regard to which he is <b>particular, due to</b> substances covering <b>the majority</b> of <b>his</b> body about which he is <b>particular.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But let them also issue a decree</b> prohibiting substances covering <b>the minority</b> of <b>his</b> body with regard to <b>which he is not particular, due to</b> substances covering <b>the minority</b> of <b>his</b> body about which he is <b>particular.</b> The Gemara answers: The Sages did not issue such a decree, as that prohibition <b>is itself</b> a rabbinic <b>decree, and will we arise and issue a decree to</b> prevent the violation of another <b>decree?</b>
§ The Gemara returns to discuss the issue of the correct time for immersion. <b>Rav says: A menstruating woman</b> who wishes to immerse to complete her purification process <b>at her time,</b> i.e., at the end of seven days, <b>may immerse only at night,</b> i.e., on the night after the seventh day, the night of the eighth day. <b>But</b> a woman who wishes to immerse <b>not at her time,</b> i.e., on the eighth day or afterward, <b>may immerse either during the day or at night. Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Whether</b> she is immersing <b>at her time or not at her time,</b> she <b>may immerse only at night.</b> This is <b>because her daughter</b> might <b>follow</b> her example when she is old enough, and also immerse in the daytime, but she may do so on the seventh day, when immersion is not valid.
<b>And even Rav retracted</b> his opinion and ruled that a woman who is immersing after menstruation may never do so during the day. <b>As Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Ashi said</b> that <b>Rav said: A menstruating woman</b> who wishes to immerse to complete her purification process, <b>whether at her time</b> or <b>whether not at her time, may immerse only at night, because her daughter</b> might <b>follow</b> her example and immerse during the daytime of the seventh day.
The Gemara cites examples of Sages who permitted immersion on the eighth day due to exceptional circumstances. <b>Rav Idi decreed in Neresh that</b> the women <b>may immerse</b> during the daytime <b>on the eighth day due to the lions</b> that roamed the area at night and posed a threat to women who immersed at that time. <b>Rav Aḥa bar Yaakov</b> decreed <b>in Pappunya</b> that the women should immerse during the daytime on the eighth day <b>due to thieves</b> who posed a threat to women who immersed at that night.
Similarly, <b>Rav Yehuda</b> decreed <b>in Pumbedita</b> that the women should immerse in the daytime on the eighth day <b>due to</b> the <b>cold</b> of the night. <b>Rava</b> decreed <b>in Meḥoza</b> that the women should immerse in the daytime on the eighth day <b>due to</b> the <b>gatekeepers [<i>abula’ei</i>],</b> who were untrustworthy and might hurt the women on their way to and from immersion.
§ <b>Rav Pappa said to Rava and to Abaye: Since nowadays the Sages have given</b> all women who menstruate the status of <b>an uncertain</b> greater <b><i>zava</i>, may they immerse on the seventh day</b> during the daytime? A greater <i>zava</i>, after counting seven clean days, may immerse on the seventh day. Since all women who menstruate now count seven clean days after the bleeding ceases, more than seven days from the onset of her menstruating have passed by the seventh clean day.
Rava and Abaye replied that they may nevertheless not immerse on the seventh day, <b>due to</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Shimon. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “But if she be purified of her <i>ziva</i>, then she shall count to herself seven days, <b>and after that she shall be pure”</b> (Leviticus 15:28). The purification of a <i>zava</i> must be <b>after</b> the seven days, i.e., <b>after all of the</b> days, which must be consecutive so <b>that there are no</b> days of <b>impurity separating between</b> the seven clean days. <b>Rabbi Shimon says</b> that the phrase <b>“And after that she shall be pure”</b> teaches that <b>after the action</b> of counting seven clean days <b>she shall be pure.</b> In other words, once she has examined herself at the beginning of the seventh day she may immerse on that day.
Rabbi Shimon continues: <b>But the Sages said: It is prohibited to do so,</b> i.e., to immerse on the seventh day, <b>lest she come to</b> a case of <b>uncertainty.</b> If she were to engage in intercourse with her husband on that seventh day after immersion, and afterward on the same day she experiences bleeding, it would retroactively nullify her entire seven clean days, which would mean that she engaged in intercourse with her husband while she was impure, rendering them both liable to receive the punishment of <i>karet</i>.
§ <b>Rav Huna says: A woman may wash</b> her hair <b>on the first</b> day <b>of the week,</b> Sunday, <b>and immerse on the third</b> day <b>of the week,</b> i.e., Monday night. The proof of this is <b>that</b> sometimes <b>a woman washes</b> her hair <b>on the eve of Shabbat, but</b> she does not <b>immerse</b> until <b>the conclusion of Shabbat,</b> which is the same interval as from Sunday to Monday night.
Similarly, <b>a woman may wash</b> her hair <b>on the first</b> day <b>of the week,</b> Sunday, <b>and immerse on the fourth</b> day <b>of the week,</b> Tuesday night. The proof of this is <b>that</b> sometimes <b>a woman washes</b> her hair <b>on the eve of Shabbat, but</b> she does not <b>immerse</b> until <b>the conclusion of the Festival that occurs after Shabbat,</b> which is the same interval as from Sunday to Tuesday night.
Furthermore, <b>a woman may wash</b> her hair <b>on the first</b> day <b>of the week,</b> Sunday, <b>and immerse on the fifth</b> day <b>of the week,</b> Wednesday night. The proof of this is <b>that</b> sometimes <b>a woman washes</b> her hair <b>on the eve of Shabbat, but</b> she does not <b>immerse</b> until <b>the conclusion of two days of Rosh HaShana that occurs after Shabbat,</b> which is the same interval as from Sunday to Wednesday night.
<b>But Rav Ḥisda said: We say</b> that <b>all of these</b> long gaps between a woman washing her hair and immersing are permitted. But <b>we do not say</b> as proof <b>that</b> since a woman washes her hair before Shabbat and immerses only several days later, she may do so during a regular week as well. One cannot learn this <i>halakha</i> from those situations involving Shabbat, as one cannot derive cases where alternatives are possible from those cases where alternatives are not possible. <b>Where it is possible</b> for a woman to wash her hair and immerse immediately, <b>it is possible,</b> and she is not allowed to do so any earlier. But <b>where it is not possible</b> for a woman to wash her hair immediately before immersion, e.g., when she must immerse after the conclusion of Shabbat or a festival, <b>it is impossible,</b> and for this reason she is permitted to wash her hair in advance.
<b>And Rav Yeimar said: We even say</b> the proof <b>that</b> since a woman washes her hair before Shabbat and immerses only several days later, she may do so during a regular week as well. Rav Yeimar agrees with Rav Huna in all cases <b>apart from</b> that of <b>a woman who washes</b> her hair <b>on the first</b> day <b>of the week,</b> Sunday, <b>and immerses on the fifth</b> day <b>of the week,</b> Wednesday night. He maintains that Rav Huna’s proof <b>from the conclusion of two days of Rosh HaShana that is after Shabbat is not</b> a sufficient proof, <b>as</b> even in such a case a woman may not wait so long. Rather, <b>it is possible</b> for her <b>to wash</b> her hair <b>at night</b> after the conclusion of Rosh HaShana <b>and immerse</b> on <b>that</b> same <b>night,</b> so that she should not have such a long gap between washing her hair and immersing.
<b>Mareimar taught: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Ḥisda,</b> that a woman should not wash her hair many days before immersing except when there is no other possibility. <b>And</b> the <i>halakha</i> is also <b>in accordance with</b> the manner in <b>which Rav Yeimar explains</b> that if Rosh HaShana occurs after Shabbat a woman should wash her hair on the night of her immersion.
§ <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to whether <b>a woman may wash</b> her hair <b>at night and immerse on</b> that same <b>night? Mar Zutra deems it prohibited</b> for her to do so. Since she will be in a hurry to immerse and return to her husband, there is a concern that she will not wash and examine her hair thoroughly. <b>And Rav Ḥinnana from Sura deems it permitted</b> for a woman to wash her hair on the night of her immersion.
<b>Rav Adda said to Rav Ḥinnana from Sura: Was</b> there <b>not an incident</b> like <b>this involving the wife of Abba Mari, the Exilarch, who quarreled</b> with her husband, and as a result she did not want to immerse in a ritual bath to become permitted to him; and <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak went to appease her</b> and to persuade her to immerse, <b>and she said to him: What is there</b> that can be done <b>now?</b> There is no reason for me to hurry and immerse now.

Daf 68a

Rather, <b>it is sufficient if you come</b> back again <b>tomorrow</b> and speak with me then about this matter. <b>And</b> Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak <b>knew what she was saying to him.</b> She was alluding to the fact that she had not washed her hair while it was still daylight, and therefore she could not immerse that evening. Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak <b>said</b> to her: <b>Are you lacking kettles [<i>dudei</i>]</b> to heat water to wash your hair? <b>Are you lacking buckets [<i>tashtekei</i>]</b> to bring the water to wash your hair? <b>Are you lacking servants,</b> who can help you prepare to wash your hair? It can be inferred from this story that Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak holds that it is permitted for a woman to wash her hair and immerse on the same night.
§ <b>Rava taught: A woman may wash</b> her hair <b>on the eve of Shabbat and immerse at the conclusion of Shabbat. Rav Pappa said to Rava: But didn’t Ravin send</b> the following <i>halakha</i> <b>in his letter: A woman may not wash</b> her hair <b>on the eve of Shabbat and immerse at the conclusion of Shabbat?</b> Instead, she should wash her hair after the conclusion of Shabbat immediately before she immerses.
<b>And</b> furthermore, you should <b>be astounded with yourself: How</b> did the Sages deem it permitted for a woman on a weekday to <b>wash</b> her hair <b>during the day and immerse at night? Don’t we require</b> that her <b>immersion</b> must be <b>immediately</b> after <b>washing</b> her hair? <b>And</b> if she washes her hair during the day, this requirement will <b>not</b> be fulfilled. The Sages reluctantly permitted a woman to wash her hair during the day, and they permitted this only due to the concern that she might not wash her hair properly if she would wait until night. Consequently, with regard to an immersion on the conclusion of Shabbat, she should avoid washing her hair a day or more in advance.
As a result of Rav Pappa’s comments, <b>Rava then appointed an interpreter before him</b> to publicize his retraction, <b>and</b> he <b>taught: The statement I said to you was a mistake of mine. But</b> in fact <b>this</b> is what the Sages <b>said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: A woman may not wash</b> her hair <b>on the eve of Shabbat and immerse after the conclusion of Shabbat. And</b> furthermore you should <b>be astounded with yourself. How</b> can a woman <b>wash</b> her hair <b>during the day and immerse at night? Don’t we require:</b> Her <b>immersion</b> must be <b>immediately</b> after <b>washing</b> her hair? <b>And</b> if she washes her hair on the eve of Shabbat, this principle will <b>not</b> be fulfilled.
The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is that <b>a woman may wash</b> her hair <b>during the day and immerse at night. And the <i>halakha</i></b> is that <b>a woman may wash</b> her hair <b>only at night.</b> The Gemara comments: This is <b>difficult,</b> as one <b><i>halakha</i></b> contradicts <b>the</b> other <b><i>halakha</i>.</b>
The Gemara answers: It is <b>not difficult. This</b> ruling that she may wash her hair during the day is referring to a case <b>where it is possible,</b> e.g., when she immerses on a weeknight and can wash her hair shortly beforehand during the daytime. <b>That</b> ruling that she is permitted to wash her hair only at night is referring to a case <b>where it is not possible,</b> e.g., when her time for immersion is after the conclusion of Shabbat. Since she may not wash her hair on the eve of Shabbat for an immersion after the conclusion of Shabbat, she must wash her hair at night, after Shabbat has ended, immediately before she immerses.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>a menstruating woman who examined herself</b> on the <b>seventh day</b> of menstruation in <b>the morning and found</b> that <b>she is ritually pure</b> and eligible to immerse in a ritual bath that evening, <b>but</b> during <b>twilight</b> of the seventh day she <b>did not</b> perform an examination that marks the <b>transition</b> between the days when she has a flow of blood and the days when she no longer has a flow of blood but immersed despite not having performed the examination, <b>and after</b> several <b>days she examined</b> herself and <b>found</b> that <b>she is ritually impure, the presumptive status of that</b> woman is one of <b>ritual purity</b> from the time of her immersion until her examination, and all ritually pure items that she handled in the interim remain pure.
