If <b>she examined herself on</b> the <b>seventh day</b> of menstruation in <b>the morning and found</b> that <b>she is ritually impure,</b> i.e., her menstrual flow continued, <b>and</b> during <b>twilight</b> of the seventh day she <b>did not</b> perform an examination to confirm the <b>transition</b> from ritual impurity to ritual purity but immersed nonetheless, <b>and after</b> several <b>days she examined</b> herself and <b>found</b> that <b>she is ritually pure, the presumptive status of that</b> woman is one of <b>ritual impurity</b> from the time of her immersion until her examination, and all ritually pure items that she handled in the interim are impure. Since she found blood during her last examination in her days of menstruation, the concern is that the flow of blood continued during the days that followed, and therefore her immersion on the eve of the eighth day was ineffective.
In a case where there was no blood found during the examination on the seventh morning and she did not examine herself during twilight, and several days later she discovered blood, where the mishna says that a woman’s presumptive status is one of ritual purity, that is the <i>halakha</i> only for the days following immersion. <b>But she transmits ritual impurity</b> to the ritually pure items that she handled before the examination in which she found blood <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period and from examination to examination,</b> in accordance with the <i>halakha</i> of a woman who experiences bleeding (see 2a). <b>And if she has</b> a fixed menstrual <b>cycle,</b> on the day that she examined herself and found blood, <b>her time is sufficient,</b> i.e., it is assumed that the bleeding began then, and she does not transmit impurity retroactively.
<b>And Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> With regard to <b>any</b> woman <b>who did not</b> perform the examination marking her <b>transition</b> from ritual impurity to ritual purity on the seventh day <b>from <i>minḥa</i></b> time <b>onward,</b> even if she performed an examination and found no blood that morning, <b>the presumptive status of that</b> woman is one of <b>ritual impurity. And the Rabbis say: Even</b> if <b>on the second</b> day <b>of her menstruation she performed the examination and found</b> that <b>she is ritually pure, and</b> she <b>did not</b> perform the examination marking her <b>transition</b> from ritual impurity to ritual purity on the seventh day <b>during twilight, and after</b> several <b>days she examined</b> herself <b>and found</b> that <b>she is ritually impure, the presumptive status of that</b> woman is one of <b>ritual purity</b> from the time of her immersion until her examination.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara cites a dispute between <i>amora’im</i> with regard to a case where a woman did not perform an examination indicating her transition from ritual impurity to ritual purity, and three days passed in which it is possible that she received the status of a <i>zava</i>, and then she found that she was ritually impure. It <b>was stated</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> This woman is <b>a definite</b> greater <b><i>zava</i>. And Levi says:</b> She is <b>an uncertain</b> greater <b><i>zava</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>To which</b> clause of the mishna does this dispute apply? <b>If we say</b> that Rav and Levi are referring <b>to the first clause,</b> i.e., a woman who examined herself on the morning of the seventh day and found herself to be ritually pure, but she did not examine herself at twilight, and several days later she examined herself and found herself to be impure, this cannot be correct, as the mishna <b>teaches: The presumptive status of that woman</b> is one of <b>ritual purity.</b> She is not a <i>zava</i> at all.
<b>Rather,</b> say that they are referring <b>to the latter clause</b> of the mishna, when she examined herself on the morning of the seventh day and found herself to be ritually impure. If so, <b>granted</b> Levi’s opinion is reasonable, as <b>we say</b> that this woman is <b>an uncertain</b> greater <b><i>zava</i>. But</b> how can one explain Rav’s opinion that she is <b>even a definite</b> greater <b><i>zava</i>?</b> After all, <b>she examined</b> herself <b>and found</b> that <b>she is ritually pure.</b> If so, how can she be a definite <i>zava</i>?
<b>Rather, when</b> the dispute <b>of Rav and Levi was stated,</b> it <b>was stated</b> as <b>a distinct <i>halakha</i></b> unrelated to the mishna, as follows: With regard to <b>a menstruating woman who examined herself on the seventh day</b> in <b>the morning and found</b> that she was <b>ritually impure, and</b> at <b>twilight</b> of the seventh day she <b>did not</b> perform an examination to confirm her <b>transition</b> from ritual impurity to ritual purity, <b>and after</b> several <b>days she examined</b> herself <b>and found</b> that <b>she is ritually impure, Rav says:</b> This woman is <b>a definite</b> greater <b><i>zava</i>. And Levi says:</b> She is <b>an uncertain</b> greater <b><i>zava</i>.</b>
The Gemara explains their opinions. <b>Rav says:</b> This woman is <b>a definite</b> greater <b><i>zava</i>, since from the outset she found</b> herself to be <b>ritually impure, and now she found</b> herself to also be <b>ritually impure.</b> Consequently, she is <b>definitely impure. And Levi says:</b> This woman is <b>an uncertain</b> greater <b><i>zava</i>,</b> as one can <b>say</b> that perhaps <b>she stopped</b> experiencing bleeding <b>in between</b> the morning of her seventh day of menstruation when she first found herself to be impure and several days later, on the second occasion that she found herself to be impure.

Daf 68b

<b>And Levi taught similarly in a <i>baraita</i>:</b> If a woman examined herself on the seventh day of menstruation and found herself to be impure, and she did not perform the examination to confirm her transition from ritual impurity to ritual purity, and <b>after</b> several <b>days</b> she examined herself, <b>whether she examined</b> herself <b>and found</b> herself to be <b>ritually pure</b> or <b>whether she examined</b> herself <b>and found</b> herself to be <b>ritually impure, she is an uncertain</b> greater <b><i>zava</i>.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: <b>But she transmits ritual impurity</b> to the ritually pure items that she handled before the examination in which she found blood <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period.</b> The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say that it is a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion <b>of Rava, as Rava said,</b> with regard to the statement in the mishna on 38b that a woman has a presumptive status of ritual purity during the eleven days of potential <i>ziva</i>: This serves <b>to say that a woman does not transmit ritual impurity for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period</b> before experiencing bleeding <b>during her days of <i>ziva</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t</b> the Gemara already cite <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion <b>of Rava one time,</b> on 39a? The Gemara explains that <b>this is</b> what <b>we are saying: Let us say that</b> there <b>is a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion <b>of Rava from this</b> mishna <b>as well.</b>
The Gemara responds that <b>Rava</b> could have <b>said to you</b> that <b>when</b> the mishna <b>teaches: She transmits ritual impurity for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period,</b> it is <b>referring to the beginning of our chapter.</b> Specifically, it is speaking <b>of</b> the mishna on 64b, which discusses the case of a young woman who <b>saw</b> menstrual blood before marriage while <b>she was still in her father’s house.</b> According to Beit Hillel she may engage in intercourse only the first night, during which the blood is considered the blood from the torn hymen rather than the blood of menstruation. This mishna is teaching that from that point onward, when she experiences bleeding she renders items impure retroactively for a twenty-four-hour period, like other women.
The Gemara explains that this ruling is necessary, as it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since</b> her cycle of menstruation and <i>ziva</i> is <b>interrupted</b> by <b>days</b> when any blood she discharges is considered to be <b>ritually pure,</b> she now reverts back as though it is <b>considered like the beginning of her</b> days of <b>menstruation, and she does not transmit ritual impurity</b> retroactively <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period.</b> Therefore, this mishna <b>teaches us</b> that she does transmit impurity retroactively.
§ The mishna teaches: And <b>if she has a fixed</b> menstrual <b>cycle</b> on the day that she examined herself and found blood, her time is sufficient and she does not transmit impurity retroactively. The Gemara asks: <b>Shall we say</b> that this <b>is a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion <b>of Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya,</b> with regard to the ruling he says that <b>Shmuel says? As Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya says</b> that <b>Shmuel says,</b> with regard to the mishna on 38b that teaches that a woman has a presumptive status of ritual purity during the eleven days of potential <i>ziva</i>: This serves <b>to say that a woman does not establish a fixed</b> menstrual <b>cycle during her days of <i>ziva</i>.</b>
The Gemara answers that <b>Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya</b> could have <b>said to you: When we say</b> that <b>a woman does not establish</b> a fixed menstrual <b>cycle during her days of <i>ziva</i>,</b> we meant this only as a leniency, <b>that</b> she does <b>not require three times to uproot</b> any such cycle. Rather, she uproots it after one time when she does not experience bleeding in accordance with that cycle. <b>As we say</b> that <b>her</b> menstrual <b>blood is removed</b> during her days of <i>ziva</i>, and she is unlikely to discharge menstrual blood during that time. <b>And since her blood is removed,</b> if she established a fixed menstrual cycle it <b>is sufficient for her</b> to be deemed impure from the <b>hour</b> that she saw the menstrual flow. There is no decree of retroactive impurity on items that she previously touched due to the concern that the blood flow might have started earlier.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> With regard to any woman who did not perform the examination indicating her transition from ritual impurity to ritual purity on the seventh day from <i>minḥa</i> time onward, even if she performed an examination and found no blood that morning, the presumptive status of that woman is one of ritual impurity. It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that the Rabbis <b>said to Rabbi Yehuda:</b> If the <i>halakha</i> <b>had</b> been that a woman who will immerse must keep her <b>hands placed in her eyes,</b> a euphemism for her vagina, for <b>the entire twilight</b> period, what <b>you say is fine.</b> It would be reasonable to assume that since she did not examine herself at the end of the day she has a presumptive status of ritual impurity.
But <b>now</b> that you say that it is insufficient to examine herself in the morning, what is your reasoning? Evidently, you <b>say</b> that <b>when she removed her hand</b> from examining herself perhaps <b>she saw</b> blood and is impure. If so, <b>what</b> difference is it <b>to me</b> if she performed the examination indicating her <b>transition</b> from ritual impurity <b>to ritual purity on the seventh</b> day <b>from <i>minḥa</i></b> time <b>onward,</b> and <b>what</b> difference is it <b>to me</b> if she performed the examination indicating her <b>transition</b> from ritual impurity <b>to ritual purity on the first</b> day of her counting?
The Gemara asks: Why do the Rabbis mention an examination <b>on the first</b> day of her counting? <b>Is there one who said</b> that if a woman examines herself only on the first day that is sufficient?
The Gemara answers: <b>Yes,</b> there is such an opinion, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: I asked Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon</b> the following question <b>when they were walking on the road:</b> With regard to <b>a menstruating woman who examined herself</b> on the <b>seventh day</b> in <b>the morning and found</b> herself to be <b>ritually pure, but at twilight</b> she did <b>not</b> perform the examination indicating her <b>transition</b> from ritual impurity to ritual purity, <b>and after</b> several <b>days she examined</b> herself <b>and found</b> herself to be <b>ritually impure, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon <b>said to him: She has a presumptive status of ritual purity</b> up until the moment that she discovered that she was impure. Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi asked them additional questions: If she examined herself on the <b>sixth</b> day, or the <b>fifth</b> day, or the <b>fourth</b> day, or the <b>third</b> day, or even the <b>second</b> day, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon <b>said to him:</b> The <i>halakha</i> <b>is no different.</b> In all of these cases she has a presumptive status of ritual purity until she discovers that she is impure.
Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi comments: <b>I did not ask</b> about a woman who examined herself <b>on the first</b> day, <b>and I erred</b> in <b>that I did not ask</b> them. If I would have asked them they would have told me that even if she examined herself only on the first day, she still has a presumptive status of ritual purity. Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi explains his reasoning: <b>Is that to say</b> that on <b>all</b> of these other days <b>she was not standing with a presumptive</b> status <b>of ritual impurity? And</b> nevertheless, <b>once</b> she performed the examination and her blood is found to have <b>stopped,</b> it is considered to have <b>stopped,</b> and she now has the presumptive status of a woman whose bleeding has stopped. If so, on the <b>first</b> day <b>too, once</b> she performed the examination and her blood is found to have <b>stopped,</b> it is considered to have <b>stopped,</b> and she now has a presumptive status of a woman whose bleeding has stopped.
The Gemara asks: <b>And initially, what</b> did Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>hold?</b> Why didn’t he ask them about a woman who examined herself only on the first day? The Gemara answers that he held that <b>since she has a presumptive status</b> that her <b>spring,</b> i.e., her uterus, <b>is open,</b> as she had just begun experiencing bleeding, an examination conducted on that day is ineffective. In any event, this <i>baraita</i> teaches that there is an opinion that even if a woman examined herself only on the first day, she has a presumptive status of ritual purity.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>a <i>zav</i> and a <i>zava</i>,</b> who are required to count and examine themselves on each of seven clean days before purification in a ritual bath, <b>who examined themselves on</b> the <b>first day and found</b> themselves <b>ritually pure,</b> i.e., with no blood, <b>and</b> they examined themselves <b>on the seventh day and found</b> themselves <b>ritually pure, and on the rest of the intervening days they did not examine</b> themselves, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: The presumptive status of</b> the <i>zav</i> and the <i>zava</i> is one of <b>ritual purity. Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> In that case, the <i>zav</i> and the <i>zava</i> <b>have</b> counted <b>only the first day and the seventh day,</b> two of the seven clean days, and they must count another five days to complete the tally. <b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> The <i>zav</i> and the <i>zava</i> <b>have</b> counted <b>only</b> the <b>seventh day,</b> and they must count another six days to complete the tally.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer said to Rabbi Yehoshua: According to your statement,</b> that the first day is included in her count of seven, <b>you are counting at intervals,</b> i.e., with days in-between that do not count, <b>and the Torah states:</b> “But if she be purified of her <i>ziva</i>, then she shall count to herself seven days, <b>and after that she shall be pure”</b> (Leviticus 15:28). This teaches that the purification of a <i>zava</i> must be <b>after</b> the seven days, i.e., <b>after all of the</b> days, which must be consecutive so <b>that there are no days of impurity separating between</b> the seven clean days.
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua says: And you</b> too, <b>do you not concede with regard to a <i>zav</i> who experienced a seminal emission</b> during his count of seven clean days, <b>and with regard to a nazirite who walked</b> under <b>overhanging boughs and protrusions</b> that have items whose status of impurity is uncertain beneath them, <b>that</b> they <b>count at intervals,</b> as both are impure for one day before resuming their counting? <b>And</b> yet <b>the Torah states</b> with regard to a nazirite who definitely contracted ritual impurity from a corpse: <b>“But the former days shall be void,</b> because his consecration was defiled” (Numbers 6:12). This indicates that even in cases where the Torah says that one must count consecutively, it is permitted to count with intervals in between countings.
<b>And</b> how would <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> respond to Rabbi Yehoshua’s claim? He would say: <b>Granted, there</b> in the cases of the <i>zav</i> and the nazirite, <b>the Merciful One states:</b> “This is the law of him that has an issue, and of him from whom an emission of semen goes out, <b>so that he is thereby impure”</b> (Leviticus 15:32). This teaches <b>that</b> when a <i>zav</i> experiences a seminal emission it <b>overturns</b> the counting of <b>only that</b> one <b>day. And if</b> one would claim that the Sages should issue a decree <b>due to</b> the concern that one might <b>confuse</b> the <i>halakha</i> of one who had an emission of <i>ziva</i> during the seven clean days with a <i>zav</i> who had a seminal emission during the seven clean days, that is not a concern. The reason is that an emission of a <b><i>ziva</i></b> will <b>not be confused with</b> the case of <b>one who experienced a seminal emission.</b>
Similarly, Rabbi Eliezer would say that in the case of <b>a nazirite who walked under overhanging boughs and protrusions</b> that have items whose status of impurity is uncertain beneath them, there is <b>also</b> no need to overturn all the previous days of counting, as <b>by Torah law we require a full-fledged tent</b> over a corpse, <b>and</b> it was <b>the Sages who decreed</b> that one who walks under overhanging boughs and protrusions is ritually impure. <b>And</b> a <i>halakha</i> that applies <b>by rabbinic law will not be confused</b> with a <i>halakha</i> that is mandated <b>by Torah law.</b>
<b>But here,</b> in the case of a <i>zava</i> who counts only the first and seventh day, <b>if we are concerned</b> that as she did not count the five intermediate days <b>perhaps she saw</b> blood during those days, and since what occurred on those days is <b>uncertain,</b> only the first day counts for her, then one might <b>come to confuse</b> this situation <b>with</b> a case where she is <b>certain</b> that she saw blood during the intermediate days. One might mistakenly think that even if she definitely experiences bleeding during the intermediate days she can still count the first day as one of her seven clean days before immersing.
It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon say: The statement of Rabbi Eliezer appears</b> more correct <b>than the statement of Rabbi Yehoshua, and the statement of Rabbi Akiva</b> appears more correct <b>than the statement of all of them. But</b> nevertheless, the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer.</b>
§ <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: With regard to <b>a <i>zav</i> and a <i>zava</i> who examined themselves</b> on the <b>first day</b> of their seven clean days and found themselves to be pure, <b>and</b> they examined themselves again on the <b>eighth day and found</b> themselves to be <b>pure, but</b> they did <b>not examine</b> themselves on <b>the remainder of the days,</b>

Daf 69a

<b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> that if they examined themselves on the first and seventh days they are considered to be pure during the intermediate days as well, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Do we require the first and last</b> days <b>of</b> the seven, <b>and</b> if so, <b>here there is</b> an examination on the <b>first</b> day, and yet <b>there is no</b> examination on the <b>last</b> day, but only on the eighth day? <b>Or perhaps</b> Rabbi Eliezer requires an examination only on the <b>first of</b> the days, and this is sufficient <b>even though there is no</b> examination on the <b>last</b> of the seven days.
<b>Rav said: This</b> case of examining on the first and eighth days <b>is</b> the same as <b>that</b> of examining on the first and seventh days, i.e., Rabbi Eliezer requires an examination only on the <b>first of</b> the days, and this examination is sufficient <b>even though there is no</b> examination on the <b>last of</b> the days. <b>And Rabbi Ḥanina said: We require</b> an examination on <b>the first and last</b> days <b>of</b> the seven, and <b>here there is</b> an examination on the <b>first</b> day but <b>there is no</b> examination on the <b>last</b> day. Consequently, Rabbi Eliezer would not permit a <i>zav</i> or a <i>zava</i> to count any of the days in this case.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Rav from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>And</b> the Sages <b>agree with regard to a <i>zav</i> and a <i>zava</i> who examined themselves</b> on the <b>first day and</b> on the <b>eighth day and found</b> themselves to be <b>ritually pure, that they have only</b> the <b>eighth</b> day as part of their count. The Gemara asks: <b>Who</b> are the Sages who <b>agree</b> to this? Are they <b>not Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua?</b> These two Sages, who disagree in a case where the <i>zav</i> and <i>zava</i> examined themselves on the first and seventh days, are evidently the ones who agree in the case of a woman who performed an examination on the first and the eighth days. This seems to contradict Rav’s opinion.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>No,</b> the Sages referred to here are <b>Rabbi Yehoshua and Rabbi Akiva.</b> Both of them agree that in this case the first day is not included in the count. Conversely, Rabbi Eliezer would say that the first seven days are included in the count and the eighth day is unnecessary, as there is a presumptive status of ritual purity from her examination on the first day.
§ The Gemara cites another discussion with regard to which days are included in the count of seven clean days. <b>Rav Sheshet says</b> that <b>Rav Yirmeya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rav says: A menstruating woman who</b> performed the examination marking the first step in her <b>transition</b> from ritual impurity <b>to ritual purity on her third</b> day <b>counts</b> that day as part <b>of the number of seven clean</b> days.
The Gemara asks: <b>Why does a menstruating woman</b> require any kind of <b>counting?</b> If this is during her days when she is expected to menstruate she may immerse after the conclusion of seven days, whether or not those days were clean. <b>Rather, say</b> that Rav meant as follows: <b>A <i>zava</i> who</b> performed the examination marking the first step in her <b>transition</b> from ritual impurity to <b>ritual purity on her third</b> day <b>counts</b> that day as part <b>of the number of seven clean</b> days.
<b>Rav Sheshet said to Rav Yirmeya bar Abba:</b> Did <b>Rav say his <i>halakha</i> in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Samaritans, who say</b> that <b>the day on which</b> a <i>zava</i> <b>ceases</b> to experience the emission of <i>ziva</i> <b>counts toward</b> the <b>number</b> of <b>seven</b> clean days, and she does not need to count seven complete days?
Rav Yirmeya bar Abba replied: <b>When Rav says</b> his <i>halakha</i>, he meant <b>apart from</b> the <b>third</b> day. Rav Sheshet challenged: If Rav meant <b>apart from</b> the <b>third</b> day, that is <b>obvious;</b> there is no need for him to issue such a statement at all. Rav Yirmeya bar Abba replied: <b>No,</b> the statement that she begins counting immediately after the third day is <b>necessary</b> for a case <b>where</b> once she saw that she was clean after the third day of her <i>ziva</i> emissions <b>she did not examine</b> herself again <b>until</b> the <b>seventh</b> day.
<b>And</b> Rav is <b>teaching us</b> two <i>halakhot</i>. <b>There,</b> in the previous discussion with regard to the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer, Rav stated that an examination <b>at the beginning</b> is sufficient, <b>even though there is no</b> examination at the <b>end</b> of the seven days. <b>And here he teaches us</b> that an examination at the <b>end of</b> the seven days is sufficient, <b>even though there is no</b> examination at the <b>beginning of</b> the seven days, but only on the day when she ceased experiencing bleeding.
Rav Yirmeya adds <b>that</b> it is necessary to teach both <i>halakhot</i>, <b>lest you say</b> that <b>we say</b> that an examination <b>at the beginning</b> is sufficient <b>even though there is no</b> examination at the <b>end of</b> the seven days, <b>as we establish</b> the clean days <b>in</b> accordance with <b>their presumptive status. But</b> one might have thought that Rav would <b>not</b> permit her to consider all the days to have been clean in a case of an examination at the <b>end of</b> the seven days <b>even though there is no</b> examination at the <b>beginning of</b> the seven days, where no presumptive status was established. Therefore, this second statement of Rav <b>teaches us</b> that even if she only examined herself at the end of the seven clean days it is sufficient.
The Gemara raises a difficulty with regard to Rav Yirmeya’s explanation. <b>Is that so? But when Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael <b>he said: Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, raised an objection</b> to the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, that a woman who is uncertain whether or not she miscarried an actual fetus must bring an offering (see 29a). The reason is that the majority of pregnant women carry actual fetuses. Rabbi Yosef objected to this from the case of a woman who was <b>forgetful,</b> i.e., a woman who left town when she was pregnant, and later returned no longer pregnant. It is unknown whether she miscarried an actual fetus, and if it was a fetus, whether it was male or female. The conclusion there was that she does not have any days when blood she discharges is considered ritually pure, which is the <i>halakha</i> following a birth, as her miscarriage might not have been a fetus at all. Apparently, here one does not follow the principle that the majority of pregnant women carry actual fetuses.
Ravin continues: <b>And I do not know what his objection is,</b> as the reason that she does not have any days when blood she discharges is considered ritually pure is not only due to the uncertainty as to whether or not she miscarried a fetus, but because it is also unknown when that miscarriage occurred, i.e., even if she miscarried a fetus, perhaps the days when blood she discharges is considered ritually pure had already been completed. <b>As we maintain</b> that the <b>first week that she comes before us,</b> when the court is uncertain with regard to her impurity, <b>we</b> tell <b>her</b> to <b>immerse</b> every <b>night</b> of that week, in the manner of a woman purifying herself after menstruation or childbirth, but <b>we do not</b> tell <b>her</b> to <b>immerse during the daytime,</b> as she has not counted seven clean days (see 29b).
The Gemara explains how this discussion apparently contradicts Rav Yirmeya’s explanation. <b>And if it enters your mind</b> that <b>we do not require</b> all seven clean days to be <b>counted before us,</b> i.e., if an examination on the seventh day is sufficient, <b>let us</b> tell her to <b>immerse also</b> during <b>the daytime,</b> as <b>perhaps she gave birth to a male</b> baby <b>during</b> her days <b>of <i>ziva</i>, and</b> already <b>performed her</b> seven days of <b>counting</b> before she came before the court. The Gemara concludes: <b>Rather,</b> must one <b>not conclude from</b> this statement of Ravin that <b>we require</b> that her seven clean days be <b>counted before us,</b> which is why the court does not instruct her to immerse during the daytime.
The Gemara rejects this contention. <b>But didn’t we interpret</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, who said</b> that <b>we require</b> her seven clean days to be <b>counted before us?</b> By contrast, Rav’s statement was in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer, who holds that the days do not need to be counted before us.
§ The Gemara stated earlier that according to the opinion of the Rabbis, the seven clean days do not need to be counted before us. The Gemara analyzes their opinion: <b>And from where do you say that according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis we do not require</b> that the seven days be <b>counted before us?</b> This is <b>as we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to a woman who was <b>forgetful</b> and does not know whether she is now in her days of menstruation or days of <i>ziva</i>, <b>who said: I saw</b> blood on <b>one day of impurity,</b> the court instructs <b>her to immerse nine immersions.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> clarifies: Since there is no way of knowing whether she is a woman purifying herself after menstruation or after <i>ziva</i>, she must immerse <b>seven</b> immersions on the following seven nights, <b>for</b> purification from <b>menstruation,</b> as each of these days might be the last of the seven days of menstruation. <b>And</b> she must also immerse during <b>two</b> days as purification <b>from <i>ziva</i>,</b> i.e., on the day that she arrives, in case she experienced bleeding the day before, and on the following day, as perhaps she experienced bleeding on the day of her arrival. But if this woman says: <b>I saw</b> blood <b>at twilight</b> that renders me <b>impure,</b> the court instructs <b>her</b> to <b>immerse eleven immersions.</b>
The Gemara asks: These <b>eleven</b> days, <b>what is their purpose?</b> If she would normally require nine immersions, why does she require an extra two immersions if she experienced bleeding at twilight? <b>Rav Yirmeya of Difti said:</b> The <i>baraita</i> is referring specifically to a case <b>where she came before us at twilight</b> and says that she also experienced bleeding at twilight, but it is not clear whether she experienced bleeding on a previous day at twilight, or today at twilight.
Rav Yirmeya explains: Therefore, she requires <b>eight</b> immersions to purify herself <b>from menstruation,</b> seven in case each of the following nights is the night after the seventh day of menstruation, and the eighth in case she experienced bleeding during twilight of the day she arrived, and this occurred in a time which was actually part of the next day, such that she needs to immerse also on the eighth night from her arrival, <b>and three</b> additional immersions during the day to purify herself <b>from <i>ziva</i>.</b> She must immerse during the day three times: She must immerse immediately, because if she experienced bleeding on the previous day during twilight it may have still been day, and right now, at twilight, it might still be day; she must immerse on the next day, because if she experienced bleeding on the previous day during twilight it may have already been night; and she must immerse during the day following the next day, because perhaps she experienced bleeding this twilight after it was night.
If this woman who is forgetful with regard to her cycle of menstruation and <i>ziva</i> says: <b>I have not seen any</b> blood <b>at all,</b> the court instructs <b>her to immerse fifteen immersions. Rava said,</b> in reference to this final <i>halakha</i> in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>This <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>not</b> a logical <b><i>halakha</i>.</b> Rather, it is like the <i>halakha</i> that <b>they judge in</b> a place named <b>Galaḥi.</b> In that place they follow the behavior of Sodom, and say that with regard to one <b>who has</b> one <b>ox, he must shepherd</b> the local flocks <b>one day,</b> and one <b>who does not have an ox must shepherd</b> the local flocks for <b>two days.</b> It is not logical that a woman who has not experienced a flow of blood must immerse more times than one who has experienced a flow of blood.
Apropos the mention of Galaḥi, the Gemara relates an incident that occurred in that place. <b>There was an orphan</b> in that town, <b>the son of a widow [<i>armelata</i>],</b> who had no oxen of his own. The people of that town <b>gave him their oxen</b> to shepherd. This orphan <b>went and slaughtered</b> all of the oxen. <b>He said</b> to the townspeople: Whoever <b>has an ox should take one skin,</b> while one <b>who does not have an ox should take two skins.</b> The people of Galaḥi <b>said to</b> the orphan: <b>What is this that you are saying,</b> i.e., what is the reason? <b>He said to them: The end of the law is like the beginning of the law: Isn’t the beginning of the law</b> that one <b>who has no</b> ox <b>is preferred,</b> and must shepherd the oxen for two days? So too, with regard to <b>the end of the law,</b> one <b>who has no</b> ox <b>is preferred</b> and should receive two hides.
The Gemara returns to discuss Rava’s comment with regard to the ruling of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Here too</b> one can claim: <b>And if</b> in a case <b>where she says: I saw</b> blood, <b>it is sufficient for her</b> to immerse <b>either nine immersions or eleven immersions,</b> so too, in a case <b>where she says: I did not see</b> any flow of blood at all, is it logical that <b>she requires fifteen immersions?</b>
<b>Rather, say</b> that <b>this</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> means: If a woman says: <b>I saw</b> a flow of blood <b>but I do not know how many</b> days <b>I saw</b> blood, and likewise I do not know <b>whether I saw</b> the flow <b>during the days of menstruation or</b> if <b>I saw</b> the flow <b>during the days of <i>ziva</i>,</b> in such a case, the court instructs <b>her to immerse fifteen immersions.</b> The reason for these immersions is as follows: If <b>she comes before us during the daytime, we give her seven</b> immersions, beginning from that night, to remove the impurity <b>of menstruation.</b> Any of those seven nights might be the night after the last of her days of menstruation.

Daf 69b

<b>And</b> she requires <b>eight</b> immersions during the day to purify her <b>from</b> her <b><i>ziva</i>,</b> as it is possible that she experienced bleeding for three consecutive days, rendering her a greater <i>zava</i>, and one of those was on this day that she came before the court, and it is also possible that the day she arrived she did not experience bleeding, and she was a <i>zava</i> during her last clean day and had to immerse that day. If <b>she comes before us at night, we give her eight</b> immersions to purify herself <b>from her menstruation,</b> including one on the night that she comes before the court, <b>and seven</b> immersions during the day to purify herself <b>from</b> her <b><i>ziva</i>.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: With regard to her <b><i>ziva</i>,</b> she still <b>requires eight</b> immersions. Since it is possible that she experienced bleeding for the third day on the day before coming to the court, she might be a greater <i>zava</i>, who starts her clean days only the day after she arrived. In addition, any of the first seven days may be the last clean day, on which she has to immerse herself. The Gemara answers: <b>Rather,</b> in both <b>this</b> case <b>and that</b> case she requires <b>seven</b> immersions to purify herself <b>from</b> the impurity of <b>menstruation, and eight</b> immersions to purify herself <b>from</b> the impurity of <b><i>ziva</i>.</b>
The Gemara raises a further difficulty: If the woman comes <b>at night</b> to the court, she <b>requires eight</b> immersions to purify herself <b>from</b> her impurity of <b>menstruation.</b> Why does the <i>baraita</i> require her to immerse a total of only fifteen times when there are cases where she must immerse sixteen times?
The Gemara answers: With regard to purifying herself from the impurity of <b><i>ziva</i>, which</b> can be taught in <b>a distinct</b> manner, <b>as there is no difference whether she comes before us during the day</b> and <b>there is no difference whether she comes before us at night,</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>counts</b> the fixed amount of eight immersions. By contrast, with regard to purifying herself from <b>menstruation, which</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>cannot</b> teach in <b>a distinct</b> manner, <b>as when she comes before us at night she requires eight</b> immersions but if she comes before us <b>during the day</b> she does <b>not require eight</b> immersions, the <i>tanna</i> <b>did not count</b> both options, but mentioned only seven immersions, which is the minimum number required.
The Gemara returns to the initial purpose of this discussion, which was to indicate that the Rabbis do not require all seven days of counting before the court. <b>And if it enters your mind</b> that <b>we require</b> seven days of <b>counting before us, why do I</b> need <b>all of these immersions? She</b> should <b>count seven</b> clean days <b>and</b> only <b>afterward immerse. Rather,</b> must one <b>not conclude from this</b> that the <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who disagree with Rabbi Akiva and <b>who say</b> that <b>we do not require</b> seven days of <b>counting before us?</b>
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Yosef, said to Rav Ashi,</b> in rejection of this proof: But <b>didn’t you resolve</b> a difficulty in the <i>baraita</i>? Since you admit that the <i>baraita</i> in any event requires revision, <b>resolve</b> this difficulty too, <b>and say this:</b> If a woman comes and says: <b>I counted</b> clean days <b>but I do not know how many</b> days <b>I counted,</b> and I do not know <b>whether I counted during the days of menstruation or whether I counted during the days of <i>ziva</i>,</b> the court instructs <b>her to immerse fifteen immersions.</b> If so, there is no proof that the Rabbis hold that the counting does not need to be before the court.
The Gemara raises a difficulty with regard to this interpretation of the <i>baraita</i>: If it is referring to a case where the woman said: <b>I counted</b> clean days <b>but I do not know how many</b> days <b>I counted, it is impossible that she did not count at least one</b> clean <b>day.</b> If so, she should not be required to immerse on the eighth day, in which case <b>she is lacking</b> one <b>immersion,</b> as the <i>baraita</i> rules that she must immerse fifteen times.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rather, say</b> that she claims: <b>I do not know if I counted</b> any clean days <b>or I did not count</b> any clean days. Likewise, she does not know whether she saw the blood during her days of menstruation or during her days of <i>ziva</i>. Therefore, she must immerse fifteen times, as it is possible that she has not yet counted at all.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The corpses of <b>a <i>zav</i>, and a <i>zava</i>, and a menstruating woman, and a woman after childbirth, and a leper, who died, transmit ritual impurity by carrying</b> their corpses, <b>until the flesh decays.</b> With regard to the corpse of <b>a gentile who died,</b> although when alive he transmits impurity like a <i>zav</i>, once he dies he is <b>ritually pure</b> and is prevented <b>from transmitting impurity.</b>
<b>Beit Shammai say:</b> The status of <b>all women</b> when they <b>die</b> is as though they were <b>menstruating women</b> at the time of death. Therefore, the garments that they were wearing before they died are impure and require immersion. <b>And Beit Hillel say: Only</b> a woman <b>who died</b> with the impurity of <b>a menstruating woman</b> has the status of <b>a menstruating woman</b> after death.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that the corpse of one of these impure people transmits ritual impurity by carrying. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> does the mishna mean by the term: <b>By carrying? If we say</b> that it <b>literally</b> means <b>by carrying,</b> that is difficult: <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>every</b> other <b>corpse does not impart ritual impurity by carrying?</b> Since every corpse imparts impurity through carrying, why does the mishna need to specify this <i>halakha</i> in these specific cases?
<b>Rather, what</b> does the mishna mean when it states: <b>By carrying [<i>bemassa</i>]?</b> It means imparting impurity <b>through a very heavy stone [<i>even mesama</i>].</b> There is a unique <i>halakha</i> with regard to the ritual impurity of a <i>zav</i> and a menstruating woman. If they sit on an item, even one that cannot become ritually impure, and beneath that item there is a vessel, although the weight of the <i>zav</i> or the menstruating woman has no physical effect on the vessel, it becomes ritually impure.
The Gemara notes that the word <i>mesama</i> is based on a verse, <b>as it is written: “And a stone was brought and placed [<i>vesumat</i>] upon the mouth of the den;</b> and the king sealed it with his own signet and with the signet of his lords, that nothing might be changed concerning Daniel” (Daniel 6:18). Accordingly, the mishna is teaching that although a corpse does not normally impart ritual impurity to vessels under a heavy stone, these specific types of corpses do transmit impurity in this manner.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that the Sages decreed that these specific types of corpses impart ritual impurity through a heavy stone? <b>Rav said:</b> It is <b>a decree</b> due to the possibility that <b>perhaps</b> one of these people might <b>faint</b> while sitting on the heavy stone, and it might be mistakenly thought they are dead and do not impart impurity to the vessels beneath.
A <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that the Sages <b>said in the name of Rabbi Eliezer:</b> All of these types of corpses listed in the mishna impart ritual impurity through a heavy stone <b>until the belly</b> of the corpse <b>bursts.</b> The Sages imposed their decree only in cases where the corpse resembles a person who has fainted. Once the corpse is clearly no longer alive, it no longer imparts ritual impurity through a heavy stone.
§ The mishna teaches: With regard to the corpse of <b>a gentile who died,</b> although when alive he transmits impurity like a <i>zav</i>, once he dies he is ritually pure and is prevented from transmitting impurity. <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said: For what</b> reason <b>did</b> the Sages <b>say</b> that the corpse of <b>a gentile who died is ritually pure</b> and is prevented <b>from transmitting impurity by carrying? Because his impurity</b> that he transmits even <b>when alive is not by Torah law, but by rabbinic law.</b> The Sages decreed that every living gentile imparts ritual impurity in the manner of a <i>zav</i>; they did not extend their decree to include the corpse of a gentile in the manner of the corpse of a <i>zav</i>.
§ <b>The Sages taught: The</b> wise <b>people of Alexandria asked twelve matters of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Ḥinnana. Three</b> of them were <b>matters of wisdom, three</b> were <b>matters of <i>aggada</i>, three</b> were <b>matters of ignorance,</b> and <b>three</b> were <b>matters of behavior.</b>
The Gemara lists the questions. <b>Three</b> were <b>matters of wisdom:</b> The first question was with regard to <b>a <i>zav</i> and a <i>zava</i> and a menstruating woman and a woman after childbirth and the leper, who died: Until when do they transmit ritual impurity by carrying?</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to them: Until the flesh decays.</b> This is the <i>halakha</i> taught in the mishna.
The second question referred to the <b>daughter</b> of a wife who had been <b>sent away</b> by her husband, i.e., divorced, who then married another, but after her divorce from her second husband or his death she returned and remarried her first husband, to whom she is forbidden (see Deuteronomy 24:1–4), and a daughter was born from this marriage. <b>What</b> is <b>her,</b> i.e., the daughter’s, status <b>with regard to</b> marrying <b>a priest?</b>
<b>Do we say an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>And if</b> in the case of <b>a widow</b> married <b>to a High Priest, whose prohibition does not apply to all,</b> i.e., it is prohibited for her only to marry a High Priest (see Leviticus 21:13–15), and yet the lineage of <b>her son is flawed,</b> as he is disqualified from the priesthood, then in the case of <b>this</b> daughter of a remarried divorcée, <b>whose prohibition applies equally to all</b> men, <b>is it not right that her son</b> should be of <b>flawed</b> lineage? <b>Or perhaps</b> this comparison can be refuted: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about a widow married to a High Priest?</b> It is notable in <b>that she herself is disqualified</b> from the priesthood, i.e., if a High Priest engages in intercourse with her she is disqualified from partaking of <i>teruma</i>, whereas a remarried divorcée is not disqualified from partaking of <i>teruma</i>.
Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to them:</b>

Daf 70a

With regard to one who remarries his divorced wife, the Torah states: “Her former husband, who sent her away, may not take her again to be his wife, after she is defiled, for that is an abomination before the Lord; and you shall not cause the land to sin, which the Lord your God gives you for an inheritance” (Deuteronomy 24:4). By inference, <b>she,</b> the divorced wife, <b>is an abomination, but her children are not abominations.</b> In other words, if he transgressed the prohibition and remarried this woman, the daughters from that marriage are not disqualified from marrying priests.
The third question was as follows: <b>Two</b> wealthy people who were <b>lepers</b> came to purify themselves and each brought a sin offering, a guilt offering, and a burnt offering. <b>Their offerings became intermingled with each other, and the offering of one of them was sacrificed, and</b> subsequently <b>one of them died. What shall be with the second</b> individual, i.e., how can he complete his purification process? If the other one had not died, they could both bring the remaining offering with the stipulation that it should be sacrificed on behalf of whoever is the owner. But now that one is dead, the other person may not bring the remaining animal, as one may not sacrifice a sin offering for one who is dead. He may also not bring another animal instead, as the animal that was already sacrificed might have been his, and one may not bring a second sin offering.
Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to them:</b> The solution is for him to <b>write</b> a contract giving all <b>his possessions to others,</b> whom he trusts to return them as a gift later, <b>and he is</b> then considered to be <b>destitute. And</b> as a poor leper, he <b>brings a bird sin offering,</b> which can be <b>brought</b> even <b>in</b> a case of <b>uncertainty.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>But there is</b> the <b>guilt offering</b> that a leper must bring, and this must be an animal not a bird, and may not be brought in a case of uncertainty. How can this leper bring his guilt offering? <b>Shmuel says:</b> Rabbi Yehoshua was referring specifically to a case <b>where his guilt offering</b> had already been <b>sacrificed,</b> before the animals became intermingled.
<b>Rav Sheshet said:</b> Is it possible that <b>a great man like Shmuel would say a statement like this? In accordance with whose</b> opinion does this solution apply? <b>If it is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, who says</b> that if the leper was wealthy when he sacrificed his <b>guilt offering</b> he <b>has</b> thereby <b>fixed</b> his manner of atonement, and must bring animals as his other two offerings, it is difficult: <b>And once he fixed his guilt offering</b> as an animal <b>while he was wealthy, he may not bring</b> a bird <b>sin offering when he is destitute.</b>
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Nega’im</i> 14:11): With regard to <b>a leper who brought an offering of a destitute person and</b> thereafter <b>he became wealthy, or</b> if he brought an offering of <b>a wealthy person and</b> thereafter <b>he became destitute, everything follows after</b> the <b>sin offering;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Shimon.</b> If he was wealthy when he brought the sin offering, he brings the burnt offering of the wealthy; if he was destitute at that time, he brings the burnt offering of the destitute.
<b>And Rabbi Yehuda says: Everything,</b> i.e., the sin offering and the burnt offering, <b>follows after</b> his status at the time that his <b>guilt offering</b> was brought. <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: Everything follows after</b> the offering of the <b>birds,</b> brought seven days earlier, at the start of his purification process.
Rav Sheshet continues: <b>And if</b> Rabbi Yehoshua’s statement is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, who said</b> that the <b>sin offering fixed</b> the status of the remaining offerings, it is difficult: Why did Shmuel state that the case is where his guilt offering had already been sacrificed? <b>Even if the guilt offering had not been sacrificed</b> before the animals became intermingled, <b>let him bring another</b> animal as his guilt offering, and stipulate that if the guilt offering that was already slaughtered was his, this animal should be a peace offering. <b>As we have heard that Rabbi Shimon said: Let him bring</b> another animal <b>and stipulate</b> with regard to it.
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon says,</b> with regard to a leper of uncertain status who must bring a guilt offering and a <i>log</i> of oil for his purification: <b>The following day,</b> on the eighth day of his purification, he <b>brings his guilt offering and his <i>log</i></b> of oil <b>with it, and</b> the priest <b>stands him at the Gate of Nicanor, and</b> the leper <b>stipulates with regard to</b> the offering <b>and says: If this</b> person, i.e., I, was <b>a leper, this is his guilt offering and</b> this is <b>his <i>log</i></b> of oil <b>with it. And if not, this</b> animal that I brought for <b>a guilt offering shall be a voluntary peace offering,</b> as the two offerings are sacrificed in the same manner.
<b>And that guilt offering</b> of uncertain status <b>requires</b>

Daf 70b

that <b>its slaughter</b> must be performed <b>in the north</b> of the Temple courtyard, as in the case of a guilt offering, <b>and</b> it <b>requires placement</b> of the blood on the right <b>thumb and</b> right <b>big toe</b> and right earlobe of the leper, as described in Leviticus 14:14, <b>and</b> it requires <b>placing hands</b> on the head of the animal, <b>and</b> the accompanying wine <b>libations and waving of the breast and thigh,</b> like a peace offering. <b>And it is eaten by males of the priesthood for</b> one <b>day and</b> the following <b>night,</b> like a guilt offering, rather than for two days, like a peace offering.
<b>But the Rabbis did not concede to Rabbi Shimon, because</b> they hold that he thereby <b>brings sacrificial</b> animals <b>to a situation</b> where the time that they may be eaten is restricted, thereby increasing <b>the</b> likelihood of <b>disqualification,</b> as it might be a peace offering, which may be eaten for two days and one night.
The Gemara answers that <b>Shmuel holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon with regard to one</b> <i>halakha</i>, i.e., that it is not the guilt offering that fixes whether the leper must bring the offerings of a wealthy person or a destitute person, <b>but he disagrees with him with regard to one</b> other <i>halakha</i>, as he does not permit such a stipulation in the case of a guilt offering.
The Gemara details the <b>three matters of <i>aggada</i></b> that the sages of Alexandria asked Rabbi Yehoshua. <b>One verse states: “For I have no pleasure in the death of him that dies,</b> says the Lord God; but turn yourselves, and live” (Ezekiel 18:32). <b>And one verse states,</b> with regard to the sons of Eli the High Priest, who did not pay attention to the reproof of their father: “If one man sins against another, God shall judge him; but if a man sins against the Lord, who shall pray for him? But they did not listen to the voice of their father, <b>because the Lord desired to kill them”</b> (I Samuel 2:25). Rabbi Yehoshua replied to them: <b>Here,</b> the verse in Ezekiel is referring to a case <b>where</b> the sinners <b>repent,</b> whereas <b>there,</b> the verse in Samuel is speaking of a case <b>where</b> the sinners <b>do not repent.</b>
The sages of Alexandria also asked the following: <b>One verse states: “For</b> the Lord your God, He is God of gods, and Lord of lords, the great God, the mighty, and the awful, <b>Who shows no favor nor takes graft”</b> (Deuteronomy 10:17), <b>and one verse states: “The Lord shall show favor to you</b> and give you peace” (Numbers 6:26). How can this contradiction be resolved? Rabbi Yehoshua replied to them: <b>Here,</b> the verse in Numbers is dealing with the time <b>before</b> one’s <b>sentence</b> is issued, when God shows favor and forgives; <b>there,</b> the verse in Deuteronomy is referring to <b>after</b> the <b>sentence</b> has been issued, when He no longer forgives.
The sages of Alexandria further asked: <b>One verse states: “For the Lord has chosen Zion;</b> He has desired it for His dwelling place” (Psalms 132:13), <b>and one verse states: “For this city has been to Me a provocation of My anger and of My fury from the day that they built it until this day,</b> so that I should remove it from before My face” (Jeremiah 32:31). Rabbi Yehoshua replied to them: <b>Here,</b> the verse in Psalms is referring to the time <b>before Solomon married Pharaoh’s daughter</b> (see I Kings 3:1), whereas <b>there,</b> the verse in Jeremiah is speaking of the time <b>after Solomon married Pharaoh’s daughter.</b>
The Gemara lists the <b>three matters of ignorance</b> that the sages of Alexandria asked Rabbi Yehoshua. <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>the wife of Lot,</b> who was turned into a pillar of salt as she fled from the city of Sodom (Genesis 19:26), in terms of whether <b>she transmits ritual impurity</b> as a corpse? Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to them: A corpse transmits ritual impurity, but a pillar of salt,</b> even if it was formerly a person, <b>does not impart ritual impurity.</b>
The sages of Alexandria also asked Rabbi Yehoshua: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>the son of the Shunammite</b> woman, who died and was brought to life by Elisha (II Kings 4:33–36), in terms of whether <b>he transmits ritual impurity</b> as a corpse? Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to them: A corpse transmits ritual impurity, but a living</b> person <b>does not transmit ritual impurity,</b> even if he had been dead temporarily.
The sages of Alexandria also asked Rabbi Yehoshua: With regard to <b>the dead</b> who will be resurrected <b>in the future,</b> will they <b>require sprinkling</b> with ashes of the red heifer on the <b>third and seventh</b> days, like one who is purified after coming into contact with a corpse, <b>or</b> will <b>they not require</b> that sprinkling? Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to them: When they come to life, we will be clever for them</b> and clarify the <i>halakha</i>. <b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that Rabbi Yehoshua said to them: <b>When Moses our teacher comes with them,</b> he will tell us the correct <i>halakha</i>.
The sages of Alexandria also asked Rabbi Yehoshua <b>three matters of behavior: What</b> should <b>a person do to become wise?</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to them:</b> He should <b>increase</b> his time spent <b>sitting</b> in the study house <b>and minimize</b> his dealings <b>in merchandise.</b> The sages of Alexandria <b>said</b> to Rabbi Yehoshua: <b>Many</b> people <b>have done so, and</b> it <b>did not help them</b> to acquire wisdom. Rabbi Yehoshua responded: <b>Rather, they should pray for mercy</b> to receive wisdom <b>from the One to Whom wisdom belongs, as it is stated: “For the Lord gives wisdom; out of His mouth comes knowledge and discernment”</b> (Proverbs 2:6).
With regard to the subject of wisdom, <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya teaches a parable of a flesh-and-blood king who prepared a feast for his servants.</b> The servants eat the food placed before them, <b>but</b> in addition <b>he sends</b> some <b>of</b> the food <b>that is before him to those he loves.</b> Similarly, God sends some of His wisdom to those He loves, as the verse states: “For the Lord gives wisdom.”
The Gemara asks: Since the path to wisdom is through prayer, <b>what is</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>teaching us</b> when he says that one should increase his time spent sitting and studying? The Gemara answers that Rabbi Yehoshua is teaching <b>that this,</b> prayer, <b>without that,</b> sitting and learning, <b>does not suffice.</b>
The sages of Alexandria asked: <b>What</b> should <b>a person do to become wealthy?</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to them:</b> He should <b>increase</b> his time involved in <b>merchandise and conduct his business faithfully.</b> The sages of Alexandria <b>said</b> to Rabbi Yehoshua: <b>Many</b> people <b>have done so, and</b> it <b>did not help them</b> become rich. Rabbi Yehoshua replied: <b>Rather, they should pray for mercy</b> to receive wisdom <b>from the One to Whom wealth belongs, as it is stated: “Mine is the silver, and Mine the gold,</b> says the Lord of hosts” (Haggai 2:8).
The Gemara asks: Since the path to wealth is through prayer, <b>what is</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>teaching us</b> when he says that one should increase his time spent involved in merchandise and conduct his business faithfully? Once again, the Gemara answers: Rabbi Yehoshua is teaching <b>that this,</b> prayer, <b>without that,</b> being involved in honest business, <b>does not suffice.</b>
The sages of Alexandria further asked: <b>What</b> should <b>a person do to have male children?</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to them:</b> He should <b>marry a woman who is fit for him</b>

Daf 71a

<b>and sanctify himself</b> by acting modestly <b>at the time of sexual intercourse.</b>
The sages of Alexandria <b>said</b> to Rabbi Yehoshua: <b>Many</b> people <b>have done so, and</b> it <b>did not help them.</b> Rabbi Yehoshua said: <b>Rather, they should pray</b> to receive sons <b>from the One to Whom sons belong, as it is stated: “Behold, children are a heritage of the Lord; the fruit of the womb is a reward”</b> (Psalms 127:3).
The Gemara again asks: Since the path to sons is through prayer, <b>what is</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>teaching us</b> when he said that one should marry an appropriate woman and conduct himself with modesty during intercourse? The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yehoshua is teaching <b>that this,</b> prayer, <b>without that,</b> marrying an appropriate woman and being modest, <b>does not suffice.</b>
With regard to the verse from Psalms, the Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the phrase: <b>“The fruit of the womb is a reward”</b> (Psalms 127:3)? What act is rewarded here? <b>Rabbi Ḥama, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, says: In reward for</b> men <b>withholding their</b> semen <b>in their belly in order</b> to allow <b>their wives to emit seed first, the Holy One, Blessed be He, gives him the reward of the fruit of the womb,</b> i.e., sons.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Beit Shammai say:</b> The status of all women when they die is as though they were menstruating women. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Beit Shammai? If we say</b> that their opinion is <b>due to</b> that <b>which is written: “Then the queen was exceedingly distressed [<i>vatitḥalḥal</i>]”</b> (Esther 4:4), this is difficult. The Gemara first explains the derivation. <b>And Rav said:</b> This <b>teaches that she began to menstruate</b> out of fear, as the cavities [<i>ḥalalim</i>] of her body opened. <b>Here too,</b> when a woman is about to die, <b>due to the fear of the Angel of Death she sees</b> blood. This is difficult, as <b>didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (39a) <b>that trepidation eliminates</b> the flow of menstrual <b>blood?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> is <b>not difficult. Anxiety</b> generated by extended worry <b>contracts</b> the muscles and prevents the blood from flowing, but sudden <b>fear relaxes</b> the muscles and causes the blood to flow.
<b>But</b> if the reason Beit Shammai hold that all women who die have the status of menstruating women is due to fear, then what about <b>that which we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Beit Shammai say:</b> The status of <b>all men</b> when they <b>die</b> is as though they were <b><i>zavim</i>; and Beit Hillel say: Only</b> a man <b>who died</b> with the impurity of <b>a <i>zav</i></b> has the status of <b>a <i>zav</i>.</b> If the reason that Beit Shammai maintain that all women who die have the status of menstruating women is due to fear of the Angel of Death, presumably they also should consider all men who die to have the status of a <i>zav</i> for the same reason.
But this is difficult, as <b>I will apply here</b> the principle stated with regard to a <i>zav</i>: “An issue <b>out of his flesh”</b> (Leviticus 15:2) renders a man impure, <b>but not</b> an issue <b>due to circumstances beyond his control.</b> If a man has a discharge of <i>ziva</i> due to an illness or some accident, he does not become impure. Consequently, if he has a discharge due to fear after seeing the Angel of Death, he would not become ritually impure.
<b>Rather, the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Beit Shammai</b> is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>At first they would</b> ritually <b>immerse</b> all the <b>utensils</b> that had been used <b>by</b> women who <b>died</b> while <b>menstruating,</b> which had thereby contracted ritual impurity even if the utensils did not touch the women after their death. <b>And</b> as a result, <b>the living menstruating women were embarrassed,</b> as they saw that the status of a menstruating woman is so severe that it remains even after death. The Sages therefore <b>instituted that one must immerse</b> the utensils which had been used <b>by all</b> dying <b>women, due to the honor of living menstruating women.</b>
Similarly, <b>at first they would immerse</b> all the utensils that had been used by <b><i>zavin</i>,</b> men suffering from gonorrhea, <b>who died,</b> as the utensils had thereby contracted ritual impurity even if the utensils did not touch the men after their death. <b>And</b> as a result, <b>the living <i>zavin</i> were embarrassed.</b> Therefore, the Sages <b>instituted that one must immerse</b> the utensils that had been used <b>by all</b> dying men, <b>due to the honor of the living <i>zavin</i>.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>a woman who died, and</b> after her death <b>a quarter</b>-<i>log</i> <b>of blood emerged from her</b> body, although the blood emerged after death, it <b>transmits ritual impurity</b> by touching and carrying, <b>due to</b> the impurity of the <b>spot</b> of blood of a menstruating woman. This impurity as blood of menstruation applies to any amount of blood she emits, despite the <i>halakha</i> that generally, the blood of a corpse transmits impurity only if it is at least a quarter-<i>log</i> in volume. <b>And</b> as it is a quarter-<i>log</i> of blood, <b>it transmits impurity in a tent,</b> as it is the blood of a corpse.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> That quarter-<i>log</i> of blood <b>does not transmit impurity due to</b> the impurity of the <b>spot</b> of blood of a menstruating woman, <b>because that</b> blood <b>was displaced after she died. And Rabbi Yehuda concedes in</b> the case of a woman who is <b>sitting</b> in childbirth <b>on the travailing chair [<i>mashber</i>] and she died, and a quarter</b><i>-log</i> <b>of blood emerged from her</b> body, <b>that</b> this blood <b>transmits ritual impurity due to</b> the impurity of the <b>spot</b> of blood of a menstruating woman. In that case, the blood was displaced while she was still alive. <b>Rabbi Yosei said: For that</b> reason, that quarter-<i>log</i> of blood <b>does not transmit impurity in a tent,</b> as it did not come from a corpse.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that according to Rabbi Yehuda a quarter-<i>log</i> of blood that emerges from a woman after death does not transmit impurity due to the impurity of a spot of blood of a menstruating woman, despite the fact that it came from the uterus. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>By inference</b> one might think <b>that the first <i>tanna</i> holds</b> that <b>even though the blood was displaced after she died, it renders</b> one <b>ritually impure due to</b> the impurity of a blood <b>spot.</b> This is not reasonable, as a dead woman cannot attain the status of a menstruating woman.
<b>Rabbi Ze’eiri said:</b> Even the first <i>tanna</i> agrees that blood from the uterus which leaves the body after death does not impart impurity as a spot. Rather, the difference <b>between</b> the opinions of the first <i>tanna</i> and Rabbi Yehuda is whether the <b>place of</b> a woman’s <b>source,</b> i.e., her uterus, <b>is impure,</b> and therefore any blood that passes through there is impure, even if it left her body after death. The first <i>tanna</i> maintains that even blood that appears after her death transmits impurity like the blood of menstruation, as it passed through the uterus when she was still alive, whereas Rabbi Yehuda holds that this blood does not transmit impurity as blood of menstruation, despite the fact that it passed through her uterus.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And Rabbi Yehuda concedes</b> in the case of a woman who was sitting in childbirth when she died, that the quarter-<i>log</i> of blood which emerged from her body transmits the ritual impurity of the spot of the blood of a menstruating woman. And Rabbi Yosei said: For that reason, that quarter-<i>log</i> of blood does not transmit impurity in a tent.
The Gemara asks: <b>By inference,</b> one might conclude <b>that the first <i>tanna</i>,</b> i.e., Rabbi Yehuda, <b>holds</b> that the blood which emerges from a woman who died during childbirth <b>also transmits impurity in a tent.</b> This cannot be correct, as the blood left her while she was still alive. <b>Rav Yehuda said:</b> The difference <b>between</b> Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei is with regard to <b>blood of submission</b> discharged from a body at the time of death, which contains a mixture of blood that leaves a person when he is still alive and blood that emerges after his death. Rabbi Yehuda holds that the blood which emerges from a woman who dies during childbirth is blood of submission, which transmits impurity in a tent by rabbinic law. Rabbi Yosei maintains that it is clear that this blood emerged from her body before she died, and therefore it is not blood of submission.
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>What is blood of submission,</b> which imparts ritual impurity (see 62b)? <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yehuda, explained:</b> The case is one of a person who was <b>killed, from whom</b> a quarter-<i>log</i> of <b>blood emerged,</b> a flow which began <b>while he was alive and</b> continued <b>after his death,</b> and it is <b>uncertain</b> whether a full quarter-<i>log</i> <b>emerged while he was alive</b> and therefore does not transmit ritual impurity, and it is <b>uncertain</b> whether <b>it emerged</b> out <b>after his death,</b> in which case it imparts ritual impurity by Torah law, and it is <b>uncertain</b> whether the quarter-<i>log</i> emerged partly <b>while he was alive and</b> partly <b>after his death. That is blood of submission.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis say</b> that this is not blood of submission, but a case of uncertain ritual impurity by Torah law, as it might all have emerged after death. Therefore, one applies the principle that <b>in a private domain</b> a case of <b>uncertainty</b> is considered to be <b>ritually impure,</b> whereas <b>in a public domain</b> a case of <b>uncertainty</b> is considered to be <b>ritually pure.</b>
<b>Rather, what is blood of submission?</b> The case is one of a person who has been <b>killed from whom a quarter</b>-<i>log</i> of <b>blood emerged while he was alive and</b> continued emerging <b>after his death and has still not stopped</b> coming out. It is clear that a full quarter-<i>log</i> did not emerge after his death, but it is <b>uncertain</b> whether <b>the majority</b> emerged <b>while he was alive and the minority after his death,</b> and equally <b>uncertain</b> whether <b>the minority</b> emerged <b>while he was alive and the majority after his death. That is blood of submission.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> In the case of one who has been <b>killed from whom a quarter</b><i>-log</i> of <b>blood emerged, and he was lying in a bed and his blood was dripping into a hole</b> in the ground, the blood in the ground <b>is ritually impure, because the drop of death is mixed with it. And the Rabbis deem it ritually pure, because</b>

Daf 71b

each <b>first</b> drop and every other <b>first</b> drop is <b>separated</b> from the other drops of blood, i.e., it did not flow in a steady stream. Since the blood initially emerged while he was alive and is pure, every drop of blood which emerged after his death is nullified when it falls into that blood, and therefore the entire puddle of blood is ritually pure. The Gemara asks: <b>The Rabbis are saying well to Rabbi Yehuda;</b> how does he respond to their claim? The Gemara answers that <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> conforms <b>to his</b> line of <b>reasoning, as he said: Blood does not nullify blood.</b>
<b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> In the case of one who is <b>crucified on wood, whose blood</b> does not drip but <b>runs</b> down the wood <b>to the earth, and a quarter</b><i>-log</i> <b>of blood is found underneath him,</b> the blood is <b>ritually impure. Rabbi Yehuda deems</b> the blood <b>ritually pure.</b> He explains his reasoning: <b>As I say</b> that the quarter-<i>log</i> of blood found underneath the body came out while he was still alive, and <b>the drop of</b> blood that came out after his <b>death remains on the wood.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty with regard to the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda. <b>And Rabbi Yehuda, let him say to himself</b> with regard to one who was killed on a bed and his blood is dripping into a hole in the ground: <b>As I say</b> that all the blood found underneath the body emerged while he was still alive and <b>the drop of</b> blood that came out after his <b>death remains on the bed.</b> Why does Rabbi Yehuda deem the blood ritually impure in such a case? The Gemara answers: The case <b>of the bed is different, as</b> the blood <b>seeps</b> through the bed onto the floor, whereas in the case of one who is crucified some of the blood may remain on the tree.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Initially</b> the Sages <b>would say,</b> with regard to a woman who gave birth and observed the seven or fourteen days of impurity for a male or female child, respectively, and then immersed in a ritual bath and <b>who is observing</b> the period <b>of the blood of purity,</b> that <b>she would pour water</b> from a vessel in her hands <b>to</b> rinse <b>the Paschal offering.</b> Although it is permitted for such a woman to engage in intercourse with her husband, her halakhic status is like that of one who immersed that day and the sun has not yet set. She therefore assumes second-degree ritual impurity and confers third-degree ritual impurity upon <i>teruma</i> with which she comes into contact. Consequently, she may touch the vessel, as second-degree ritual impurity does not render a vessel impure. She may not touch the water, as it is designated for rinsing the Paschal offering and therefore it is treated with the sanctity of sacrificial food, which is rendered impure by second-degree ritual impurity.
The Sages <b>then said:</b> Her status <b>is like</b> that of one who came into <b>contact with one impure</b> with impurity imparted by <b>a corpse,</b> i.e., one with first-degree ritual impurity, who renders <b>consecrated</b> items impure. But with regard to all non-sacred items, even non-sacred items treated with the sanctity of sacrificial food, such as the water used to rinse the Paschal offering, she has second-degree ritual impurity. Consequently, it is permitted for her to touch not only the vessel, but the water inside it as well, <b>in accordance with the statement of Beit Hillel. Beit Shammai say:</b> The status of the woman is <b>even like</b> that of one who is <b>impure</b> due to contact with <b>a corpse,</b> who is a primary source of ritual impurity and renders even a non-sacred vessel impure.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches: A woman who gave birth, observed the days of impurity, immersed in a ritual bath, and who is now observing the period of the blood of purity <b>would pour</b> water from a vessel in her hands to rinse the Paschal offering. The Gemara infers: Pouring from a vessel, <b>yes,</b> this is permitted, but she may <b>not touch</b> the water itself. <b>Apparently, non-sacred</b> produce, e.g., even liquid such as the water for rinsing the Paschal offering, <b>that was prepared according to</b> the level of <b>ritual purity</b> required <b>for sacrificial</b> food, i.e., with the same stringencies as required for sacrificial food, <b>is considered like sacrificial</b> food.
But now <b>say the latter clause</b> of the mishna: The Sages <b>then said:</b> Her status <b>is like</b> that of one who came into <b>contact with one impure</b> with impurity imparted by <b>a corpse,</b> i.e., one with first-degree ritual impurity, who renders <b>consecrated</b> items impure. This indicates that <b>with regard to consecrated</b> items, <b>yes,</b> she renders them impure, but <b>with regard to non-sacred</b> items, e.g., the water used to rinse the Paschal offering, she does <b>not</b> render them impure. <b>Apparently, non-sacred</b> produce <b>that was prepared according to</b> the level of <b>ritual purity</b> required <b>for sacrificial</b> food <b>is not considered like sacrificial</b> food.
The Gemara explains: <b>Whose</b> opinion is expressed in the latter clause of <b>the mishna? It is</b> the opinion of <b>Abba Shaul, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Abba Shaul says:</b> With regard to <b>one</b> who was ritually impure <b>who immersed that day</b> and is waiting for nightfall for the purification process to be completed, he has the status of one who is impure with <b>first-</b>degree impurity <b>with regard to sacrificial</b> food, in <b>that</b> he <b>renders two</b> items of sacrificial food <b>impure, and disqualifies one</b> additional item. In other words, the first item of sacrificial food that he touches assumes the status of second-degree impurity. A second item that comes into contact with the first item assumes third-degree impurity. A third item that comes into contact with the second assumes fourth-degree impurity and is therefore disqualified from being eaten, but it does not impart impurity to other items.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>And</b> Beit Shammai <b>concede</b> to Beit Hillel that a woman observing the days of purity <b>partakes of</b> second-<b>tithe</b> produce, as it is permitted for one who immersed that day to eat second-tithe produce. <b>And she separates</b> part of <b>her</b> dough as <b><i>ḥalla</i>, and she draws</b> the vessel with the part of the dough that she separated <b>near</b> the rest of the dough, <b>and she designates it</b> with the <b>name</b> of <i>ḥalla</i>.
<b>And</b> Beit Shammai further concede to Beit Hillel <b>that if</b> a drop <b>from her saliva or from the blood of purity fell onto a loaf of <i>teruma</i>,</b> the loaf <b>is ritually pure,</b> as any liquid discharged from the body of one who immersed that day is ritually pure.
There is another dispute between the <i>tanna’im</i> with regard to a woman who completed her days of purity. <b>Beit Shammai say:</b> Her immersion at the end of the days of impurity does not render it permitted for her to enter the Temple or to partake of <i>teruma</i>; rather, <b>she requires immersion</b> even <b>at the conclusion</b> of the days of purity. <b>And Beit Hillel say: She does not require immersion at the conclusion</b> of the days of purity to render it permitted for her to partake of <i>teruma</i>, as the immersion at the end of the days of impurity is sufficient.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that Beit Shammai concede to Beit Hillel that the woman observing the days of purity partakes of second-tithe produce. The Gemara explains that the reason is <b>as the Master said:</b> When the period of ritual impurity of a <i>zav</i> or leper has been completed, and he <b>immersed</b> during the day <b>and ascended</b> from the ritual bath, he <b>may partake of</b> second <b>tithe</b> immediately.
The mishna teaches: <b>And she separates</b> part of <b>her</b> dough as <b><i>ḥalla</i>.</b> The Gemara explains that <b>non-consecrated</b> food that is <b>untithed produce with regard to <i>ḥalla</i>,</b> as it has not had <i>ḥalla</i> separated from it, e.g., this dough from which a piece has been set aside for the future separation of <i>ḥalla</i>, <b>is not considered like <i>ḥalla</i>,</b> and therefore is not rendered impure by the contact of a woman observing the days of purity.
The mishna also teaches that she <b>draws</b> the vessel with the part of the dough that she separated <b>near</b> the rest of the dough. The Gemara explains that this is <b>as the Master said:</b> It is <b>a mitzva to separate</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>from</b> produce that is situated <b>nearby</b> the produce it comes to exempt, <i>ab initio</i>.
The mishna states: <b>And she designates it</b> with the <b>name</b> of <i>ḥalla</i>. The Gemara explains that it is necessary for the <i>tanna</i> to teach this <i>halakha</i>, as it might <b>enter your mind to say: Let us decree lest she comes to touch</b> the <i>ḥalla</i> <b>from the outside.</b> Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that there is no such decree.
The mishna teaches: <b>And</b> Beit Shammai concede to Beit Hillel that <b>if</b> a drop <b>from her saliva</b> or from the blood of purity fell onto a loaf of <i>teruma</i>, that the loaf is ritually pure, as any liquid discharged from the body of one who immersed that day is ritually pure. The Gemara explains that the reason is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Tevul Yom</i> 2:1): The <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>liquids</b> that emerge <b>from one who immersed himself that day</b> from his state of ritual impurity <b>is like</b> that of <b>liquids that he touches. And</b> both <b>these and those,</b> the liquids that emanated from him and the liquids that he touched, <b>do not transmit ritual impurity.</b> This is the <i>halakha</i> <b>except for liquids</b> that come <b>from a <i>zav</i>, who is a primary source of ritual impurity.</b>
